Homage to the Buddhas everywhere Whose movements are unimpeded! As follows: Oṃ! O glorious one!
'di ni dpal mo che/ / 'jig rten mgon gyis bstan pa ste/ / phyag rgya kha sbyor ldan pa yi/ / rgyal srid chen po rab sbyin byed/ /
This vidyā [called] “She of Great Fortune” (mahālakṣmī), Has been instructed by the world’s leaders. When united with the “joined hands” hand gesture,[446] It bestows great sovereignty. [14]
na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ sarba satwA b+ha ya pra dA yi kA/ tad+ya thA/ o~M a dzi te ku mA ra rU pi NI/ o~M hi a gats+tsha ma ma kar yaM ku ru swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / sarvasattvābhaya- pradāyināṃ[447] / tadyathā / Oṃ ajite kumārarūpiṇi[448] / ehi āgaccha[449] mama kāryaṃ kuru svāhā //
Homage to the Buddhas everywhere Who grant fearlessness to all sentient beings, as follows: Oṃ! O she the invincible one of youthful form! Come! Come! Perform my duties! Hail!
mi thub ma zhes rnam grags ma/ / gzhon nu bdud rtsi las byung ba/ / gang ba'i phyag rgyar ldan pa yis/ / dgra rnams thams cad zlog par byed/ /
[This] famous [vidyā] called “Invincible one” (ajitā), Is a youthful maiden born from immortal nectar. When united with the “completed” hand gesture, It wards off all enemies. [15]
na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a tsin+t+yad+b+hu ta rU pi NAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM dza ye swA hA/ bi dza ye swA hA/ a dzi te swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / acintyadbhūtarūpiṇāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ jaye[450] svāhā / vijaye svāhā / ajite [svāhā / aparājite][451] svāhā //
Homage to the Buddhas everywhere who have inconceivably wonderful forms! as follows: Oṃ! O Victorious One, hail! O Triumphant One! Hail! O Invincible One! Hail! [O Unrivaled One! Hail!]
sring mo bzhi zhes rnam grags pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i rjes 'gro ba/ / sa rnams mtha' dag yongs rgyu zhing // sems can rjes su 'dzin byed pa/ /
These famous ones called the “Four Sisters” are the Bodhisattva’s attendants. They roam throughout the entire earth Showing favor to all sentient beings. [16]

ming po tu bu ru zhes grags/ / 'di rnams kyis ni rjes su spyod/ / gru yi bzhon pa mnyam zhon nas/ / rgya mtsho la ni nges par gnas/ / khu tshur phyag rgyas rnam par dgod/ / bsam pa thams cad yongs rdzogs byed/ /

The famous one called “Brother Tumburu,” Who is their attendant, Climbs aboard [their] ship Set down in the ocean. When [this vidyā] is used with the “fist” mudrā, It completely fulfills all hopes. [17]

na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ lo kA grA d+hi ba ti nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M ku mA ri ma hA ku mA ri krI Da krI Da/ ma hA rAk+Sha si bo d+hi satwA nu dz+nyA ta ma yu rA sa ne pA sha /par shU pA Ni rak+tAM gI rak+ta gan+d+d+hA nu le pa na pri ye pri ye/ kha kha khA hi khA hi hU~M nri t+ya rak+ta puSh+pA rtsi ta mU r+t+ti sa ma nu sma ra/ b+h+ra ma b+h+ra ma/ b+h+ra ma ya b+h+ra ma ya/ hu lu hu lu mA bi lam+ba/ sarba karmA Ni me ku ru ku ru/ pi tsi tra rU pa d+hA ri Ni/ tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha/ hU~M hU~M sarba bud+d+hA nu dz+nyA te swA hA/

Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / lokāgrādhipatīnām / tadyathā / Oṃ kumāri mahākumāri krīḍa krīḍa / mahārākṣasi bodhisattvānujñātamayūrāsane / pāsaparaśupāṇi[452] raktāṅgi raktagandhānulepanapriye- priye[453] / kha kha khāhi khāhi hūṃ nṛtya raktapuṣpārcitamūrti[454] samayam anusmara / bhrama bhrama bhramaya bhramaya / hulu hulu mā vilamba / sarvakarmāṇi me kuru kuru / vicitrarūpadhāriṇi / tiṣṭha tiṣṭha / hūṃ hūṃ / sarvabuddhānujñāte svāhā //

Homage to all Buddhas, pre-eminent lords of the world! Oṃ! Youthful maiden! O great youth! Sport! Sport! O great protectress[455] permitted by the bodhisattva! O you whose seat is a peacock, Whose hands hold a noose and axe, And whose limbs are red! The beloved who is anointed with crimson fragrance! kha kha khāhi khāhi hūṃ! Dancing! O you whose embodiment is worshipped with red flowers! Remember the vow! Wander! Wander! Delude! Delude! Conceal! Conceal! Don’t delay! O you who bears various forms, perform all my rituals! Remain! Remain! Hūṃ! Hūṃ! O she who is permitted by all the Buddhas! Hail!
sems can rjes su 'dzin byed pa'i/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pas na/ / sa rnams ma lus kun nas ni/ / rnam pa drug tu rab tu g.yos/ /
When [this vidyā] was explained by the bodhisattva Who shows favor to sentient beings,[456] The entire Earth Quaked thoroughly in six ways. [18]
sems can kun la phan don dang // gdug pa'i sems can zlog byed pa/ / bdag gi rig pa rtag tu grags/ / rtag tu srung bar yongs su grags/ /
Benefiting all sentient beings, Opposing wicked beings. My vidyā is forever famous, And known to eternally protect.[457] [19]
srung ba ltos 'gro de nyid kyi/ / 'jig rten mtshan mas legs par mtshan/ / snying rjes thugs ni brlan pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' de nas gsungs/ /
Distinguished by the worldly signs Of that same serpent protector,[458] The bodhisattva spoke accordingly, His mind drenched with compassion. [20]
byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid che/ / byis pa rnams la phan don du/ / gang la sems can spyod gsungs pa/ / 'gro ba rnams la rnam spyod ldan/ /
In order to benefit young people, The bodhisattva, the magnanimous one, Has proclaimed the proper conduct of sentient beings So that all living beings behave accordingly. [21]
phyag rgya dbyug pa'i srog shing ldan/ / bdag nyid chen pos sbyar nas ni/ / tshangs pa la sogs 'gugs byed na/ / mi rnams 'bras bu smos ci dgos/ /
When the Great Being Applies the “axe-pole” hand gesture And summons the Creator God Brahmā, etc. What need one say about its effect upon human beings? [22]
gzhon nu'i sems su ma lus pa'i/ / rtog pa 'di ni bsdus nas su/ / srin po rnams su grags pa yi/ / rig sngags 'di ni yang dag bstan/ /
In brief, this entire ritual, Which is for youthful-minded ones, and this vidyā, celebrated among the Protectors, Shall be explained. [23]
sems can rjes gzung 'dod pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' de ltar bshad/ / yig gsum zhes bya'i snying po 'di/ / rig sngags 'di ni yang dag bshad/ /
Wishing to assist sentient beings The bodhisattva shall explain it accordingly. This vidyā shall now be thoroughly explained As the essence-incantation “The three letters.” [24]
sems can kun la phan don du/ / nye bar longs spyod 'gugs pa'i mchog / phyag rgya dbyug pa'i srog shing ni/ / rnam bkod las rnams thams cad pa'o/ /
It is excellent for attracting objects of pleasure In order to benefit all sentient beings It is entrusted for all rituals with the “axle-pole” hand gesture. [25]
o~M hU~M dzaH/
“Oṃ Hūṃ Jaḥ!”
rig sngags 'di ni mdor bsdus nas/ / mi rnams 'bras bu byed pa yin/ /
In brief, this vidyā Brings about rewards for humanity. [26ab]
na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ sa man+to t+yo ti ta mUr+t+ti nAM/ a bi kr-i ta gra ha hU~M phaT swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / samantodyotitamūrtīnāṃ / Oṃ vikṛtagrahā[459] hūṃ phaṭ svāhā //
Homage to Buddhas everywhere Who are entirely luminous in form! Oṃ! She who overcomes [obstacles] with her ugliness! Hūṃ! Phaṭ! Svāhā!
nye ba'i snying po 'di yang ni/ / phyag rgya dgra sta yang dag ldan/ / de bzhin 'byung po 'gugs par byed/ / de bzhin gza' dang ma mor bcas/ /
When the near-essence incantation Is applied with the “axe” hand gesture, It summons all living creatures accordingly, As well as planets and mother spirits. [26cdef]
thams cad phyag rgyas rgyas btab pa/ / bkod na 'bras bu bcas par 'gyur/ / 'byung po rnams ni rnam skrag byed/ / gdug pa zhugs pa rnam par grol/ /
When applied to all mudrās impressed[460] [This vidyā] shall be fruitful. It terrifies all creatures And liberates those possessed by malicious [spirits]. [27]

'di ni bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i pho nya mo chen mo las thams cad pa ral pa gcig ma zhes bya ba rjes su spyod pa las thams cad pa ste bzlas pa tsam kho nas las thams cad byed do/ / 'byung po thams cad skrag par byed pa dang / 'gugs par byed pa dang / dbang du byed pa dang / rig pa 'dzin pa ji ltar 'dod pa de thams cad rdzogs par byed do/ /

Merely reciting this [vidyā], which is Blessed Noble Tārā’s attendant[461] called “the great female messenger Ekajaṭī,” performs all rituals.[462] It frightens, summons, and subjugates[463] all spirits, and fulfills whatever the practitioner desires.[464]
na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M prah+mA su prah+mA prah+mA/ baR+tsa se shAn+tiM ku ru swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / apratihataśāsanānāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ Brahmā subrahmā Brahmā / varcase śāntiṃ kuru svāhā //
Salutations to the Buddhas everywhere, Whose teachings are unimpeded! Oṃ Brahmā! Excellent Brahmā! O Brahmā! Pacify for [maintaining] energy! Hail!

sngags 'di tshangs pa chen po ste/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pa yin/ / 'byung po zhi ba rab tu thob/ / skad cig nyid la bsil bar 'gyur/ / phyag rgya pad+ma yang dag ldan/ / myur du dge legs thob par 'gyur/ /

The bodhisattva has explained This mantra [called] “Great Brahmā.” It makes spirits tranquil[465] And instantly calm. When [this vidyā] is used with the lotus hand gesture, One quickly attains well-being (svasti). [28]
mngon spyod kyi ni las rnams la/ / srid srung gi ni rig byed 'dod/ / 'di ni mdor bsdus brjod pa ste/ / cho ga 'di ni mdor bsdus pa'o/ /
The Atharva Veda is desired[466] For all rituals of domineering and destructive magic. This is expressed in brief, and Its ritual is explained in brief. [29]
na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM ga ru Da ba ha na tsakra pA ni tsa tur b+hu dza hU~M hU~M/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ bo d+hi satwa Adz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / apratihataśāsanānāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ garuḍavahana cakrapāṇi[467] caturbhuja hūṃ hūṃ / samayam anusmara / bodhisattva ājñāpayati svāhā //

Homage to the Buddhas everywhere Whose teachings are unimpeded, as follows: Oṃ! O you whose vehicle is Garuḍa! The four-armed one whose hand holds a discus![468] Hūṃ! Hūṃ! Remember the vow! Hail the bodhisattva who gives permission!

byang chub sems dpas bka' stsal pa/ / zhi ba'i don ni myur du byed/ / 'byung po rnams ni rnam 'jig byed/ / khyab 'jug gzugs kyi lus can yin/ / phyag rgya 'khor lor yang dag ldan/ / brtan pa'i don ni yang dag byed/ /

The aim of pacifying, Commanded by the bodhisattva, Endowed with Viṣṇu’s bodily form. Is quickly performed, scattering all spirits. When used with the “circle” hand gesture[469] [This vidyā] quickly performs the aim of paralyzing. [30]
gang 'di khyab 'jug rgyud du ni/ / cho ga rgyas par bstan pa ste/ / sems can kun gyi sgrub byed de/ / byang chub sems dpas bshad pa yin/ /
The rituals extensively explained In this Vaiṣṇava tantra Succeed for all sentient beings. Such is explained by the bodhisattva. [31]

na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ ma hA ma he shwa ra b+hu tA d+hi pa ti br-i Sha b+ha/ d+h+wa dze pra laM ba dza Ta mu ku Ta d+hA ri NI/ si ta b+hasma d+hu sa ra ta/ mUrti sa aM phaT phaT bo d+hi satwa Adz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/

Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / apratihataśāsanānāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ mahāmaheśvara bhūtādhipativṛṣabha[470] / dhvajapralamba jaṭāmukuṭadhāriṇī / sitabhasma dhūsaritamūrti [hūṃ][471] phaṭ phaṭ / bodhisattva ājñāpayati svāhā //

Homage to the Buddhas everywhere Whose teachings are unimpeded, as follows: Oṃ! O Great Lord! O bull among Lords of Creatures, Whose banner hangs down, who bears a crown of locks, And whose grayish form [is smeared with] white ashes! Hūṃ! Phaṭ! Phaṭ! The bodhisattva gives permission. Hail![472]
sems can rnams la phan 'dod pas/ / sngags 'di bdag gis rab tu brjod/ / mdung gi phyag rgya mnyam par ldan/ / 'byung po thams cad rnam 'jig pa/ /
Desiring to benefit sentient beings, I have proclaimed this mantra. When used with the “spear” hand gesture, It destroys all spirits. [32]
'di yang bstan pa'i cho ga 'di/ / sems can sa stengs gnas pa la/ / sngon ni zhi ba'i rgyud du bstan/ / yon tan sna tshogs rgya che ba/ / zhi ba'i rgyud kyis kyang brjod do/ /

This ritual, which was formerly explained [by me][473] To sentient beings inhabiting the earth, Was previously explained in the Śaiva Tantra. The Śaiva tantra expresses Its extensive variety of qualities. [33]

na maHsa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA naM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M sha ku ni pa ta ta pak+Shi Na/ sha ka kha kha/ khA hi khA hi sa ma ya ma nu sma ra hU~M tiSh+Tha bo d+hi satwa Adz+nyA pa ya ti swA hA/

Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / apratihataśāsanānāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ śakuna mahāśakuna padmavitatapakṣa sarvapannaganāśaka[474] / kha kha khāhi khāhi samayam anusmara hūṃ tiṣṭha bodhisattva ājñāpayati svāhā //

Homage to the Buddhas everywhere whose teachings are unimpeded! As follows: Oṃ! O Śakuna bird, great Śakuna bird, Whose wings are outstretched like a lotus, Who destroys all serpents, . . . Sky serpent! Sky serpent! Remember the vow! Hūṃ! Remain! The bodhisattva gives permission! Hail!
sngags 'di brtson 'grus chen po ste/ / nam mkha' lding zhes rnam par grags/ / gdul dka' 'dul ba rnams kyi mchog / gdengs ka can gyi dug rnams 'joms/ /
This mantra, the heroic And famous “Garuḍa,”[475] Supreme Disciplinarian of those difficult to tame, Destroys the poisons of hooded snakes. [34]
phyag rgya che dang yang dag ldan/ / phung khrol mi bzad bcas pa 'joms/ / brtan dang g.yo ba'i dug rnams ni/ / gso bar byed par the tshom med/ /
When applied with the “Great Seal,”[476] It destroys that which is useless and unbearable, And undoubtedly heals the [effects of] poisons From animate and inanimate [sources.] [35]
gdul bya'i sems can la brtse bas/ / byang chub sems dpa'i yang dag bka'/ / nam mkha' lding gi gzugs kyis spyod/ / 'dab chags rgyal po 'od chen ldan/ /
The bodhisattva’s precepts are for sentient beings disciplined by loving kindness. The majestic king of birds roams in Garuḍa’s form. [36]
ji srid nam mkha' lding rgyud du/ / bstan pa'i cho ga rgyas de rnams/ / sems can kun la phan pa'i rgyud/ / bdag gis kyang ni brjod pa yin/ /
As long as these extensive rituals Are taught in the Garuḍa Tantra, I will also express them In order to benefit all sentient beings. [37]
mkha' lding mngon par brjod rgyud du/ / khro bo'i rgyal po ma bstan na/ / gdengs can dug ni gzhom pa'i phyir/ / 'dab chags gzugs kyis rnam par rgyu/ /
Garuḍa is mentioned in the tantra When the wrathful king is not shown. He roams in a bird’s form In order to destroy cobra poison. [38]
ji srid 'jig rten pa yi sngags/ / de rnams cho ga dper brjod pa/ / gdul bya'i sems can don du ni/ / de lta de ltar rnam par spyod/ /
As long as worldly mantras Are expressed in [this] ritual text, I shall wander to the same extent, In order to discipline sentient beings. [39]
gang yang de bzhin gshegs sngags dang // rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag kyang // de rnams cho ga rab 'byam 'dir/ / snga ma kho nar gsungs pas yin/ /
The mantras, which belong to the Tathāgata, As well as the Vajra and Lotus families, have been previously expressed In those extensive rituals. [40]
ji ltar ma ma rnam mang po/ / byis pa 'bad pas srung byed pa/ / de bzhin byis mtha'i blo can la/ / nga ni rig sngags gzugs kyi rgyu/ /
Just as many mothers exert great effort to protect their children, in the same way, I wander in the form of a vidyā-mantra, to [protect] childish-minded ones.[477] [41]
stobs bcu ldan pas sngon gsungs pa/ / da lta'ang nga yis bstan pa yin/ / sngags rgyud don ni ma lus pa/ / rtogs pas rab gsungs 'od chen po/ /
The majestic one has spoken, having comprehended The entire meaning of the mantras and tantras Formerly spoken by [the Buddhas] Possessing Ten Powers, and now explained by me. [42]
rgyal ba mchog gis gang gsungs pa/ / stobs bcu ldan pa'i sras kyis gsungs/ / rmad byung bsam mi khyab gzugs can/ / spyan ras gzigs kyis gsungs pa'o/ /

That which has been recited by the excellent Conquerors and The [spiritual] sons of the [Buddhas] Possessing Ten Powers, Has also been proclaimed by Avalokiteśvara Whose form is inconceivably wonderful. [43]

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams de dang / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po de la kun du gzigs nas dam tshig thams cad yang dag par skul bar byed pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs so/ / gang du ting nge 'dzin la gnas pas sems can ma lus pa'i sgrub pa'i spyod pa'i yid/ sems can thams cad la rab tu gnas par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po snyoms par zhugs ma thag tu thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor chen po gnas rnam par bkra ba'i phyag na rin po che'i snying po rgyan bkod pa'i dkyil 'khor bsam gyis mi khyab cing rmad du byung ba'i rnam par 'phrul pa rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / spyod pa la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams dang / sa bcu dang ldan pa sa bcu'i dbang phyug la gnas pa rnams kyis kyang / dkyil 'khor de bri ba'am 'drir 'jug par mi nus na/ so so'i skye bor gyur pa'i sems can rnams kyis lta smos kyang ci dgos/ 'phags pa'i dkyil 'khor bzang po de'i dam tshig sgrub pa'i gnas la gnas pa byang chub sems dpa' chen pos gzigs nas/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' sa bcu la gnas pa rgyal tshab tu mngon par dbang bskur zhing dam tshig thob pa thams cad dang / spyod pa la zhugs pa rnams dang / zag pa dang bcas pa dang / zag pa med pa'i sems can thams cad spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis byin gyis brlabs kyis sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i rgyu mthun pa dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi khyad par gyis thugs las byung ba'i dkyil 'khor du zhugs pa bdag nyid kyis yang dag par shes par gyur to/ / so so'i skye bo thams cad kyis de yid kyis dmigs par mi nus na/ bri ba'am 'drir 'jug pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/ /

Then, you should know, the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara surveyed that great assembly and the entire world realm, and entered equipoise in the concentration called “Completely Admonishing All Pledges.” There, while he remained in deep concentration, all sentient beings became rooted in the understanding of the practices that succeed for all sentient beings. No sooner did the Bodhisattva Great Being enter equipoise, than the entire area of the assembly became[478] a maṇḍala of arrayed ornaments the essence of colorful, precious jewels[479] — an inconceivable and amazing [bodhisattva][480] manifestation. All Pratyekabuddhas, noble Śrāvakas, Bodhisattvas engaged in the career of conduct, and masterful ones[481] established on the tenth [bodhisattva] stage are unable to draw or even begin to draw that maṇḍala. What needs to be said of [its being drawn] by sentient beings who are ordinary people? Having seen the great bodhisattva[482] abiding in that condition, carrying out the pledge of that excellent, noble maṇḍala, all Buddha Lords, Prayekabuddhas, Noble Śrāvakas, and Bodhisattvas dwelling on the tenth stage who obtained the pledge[483] and initiation as a crowned prince and engaged in [its] practice, plus all sentient beings, both with and without fluxes (āsrava) — due to having been empowered by Avalokiteśvara, all became fully aware of their own entrance into the maṇḍala that is the result of the inconceivable career of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas and is mind-born from [Avalokiteśvara’s] distinguished meditative concentration. Even ordinary people cannot perceive it. What needs to be said about drawing it or having it drawn?[484]

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis dkyil 'khor chen po'i dam tshig la rjes su rab tu zhugs pa'i sems can de rnams la smras pa/ grogs po dag nyon cig /'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis kyang 'da' bar mi bya ba'i dam tshig yin na/ sems can rnams dang / 'phags pa gzhan rnams kyang lta smos kyang ci dgos/ de nas yang sems dpa' chen pos phyag na rdo rje gsang ba pa'i bdag po la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ mi las 'das pa'i dam tshig yid las byung ba ni nges par bstan to/ / mi rnams la/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams yongs su mya ngan las 'das na yang dag tu sems can rnams yang dag par zhugs nas/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i rig pa dang / sngags kyi dngos grub thams cad 'grub par 'gyur bar bshad par bya'o/ / de nas yang gsang ba pa'i bdag po phyag na rdo rjes/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras gang da lta dus la bab par shes na gsungs shig gsungs shig /

After that, the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara addressed those sentient beings engaged in the pledge of the great maṇḍala, “O friends! Please listen! This pledge is not to be violated even by Tathāgatas and Bodhisattvas, what more needs to be said about [its being violated by] sentient beings and other noble ones?”[485] Then, the Great Being also addressed Vajrapāṇi, the Lord of the Secret Ones, “You Sir, Son of the Conqueror, this mind-born [maṇḍala] pledge[486] is not to be violated, as indicated. Now I shall explain the [maṇḍala][487] to humanity. After the Tathāgatas had gone beyond suffering [to parinirvāṇa], sentient beings who have entered the place where [the maṇḍala is] shall achieve all the attainments (siddhi) of the mundane and supramundane vidyās and mantras.” In return, Vajrapāṇi, Lord of the Secret Ones, addressed the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, “O Son of the Conqueror, if you think that the time has come, please speak! Please speak!”
shAkya seng+ge 'jig rten mgon/ / yongs su mya ngan 'das pa na/ / mi rnams mchog gi sangs rgyas zhing // sems can sa stengs khyod dkyil 'khor/ /
After the world’s protector and Lion of the Śākya clan Passed beyond suffering, Sentient beings [made][488] your maṇḍala on this earth [To attain] supreme buddhahood among men. [44]

mthong ba tsam gyis 'jig rten na/ / sngags kyi dngos grub rab tu skye/ / mi shes cho ga nyams pa'am/ / dam tshig bdag por ma gyur na/ / tshangs pa bdag nyid chen pos kyang / / rig sngags dngos grub mi 'gyur ro/ /

By merely seeing [the maṇḍala] in this world, the mantras’ attainments (siddhi) will spring forth. If the ritual is unknowingly impaired, And you don’t master the pledge, The vidyās and mantras will not succeed, Even for the great-souled Brahmā. [45]
sngags la mngon par mi brtson dang // dam tshig bstan pa mi mthong na/ / rnam par du mar 'bad byas kyang // rig pa'i dngos grub mi 'gyur ro/ /
If one does not strive [to practice] that mantra[489] And does not observe the pledge, as indicated, Even if one makes great effort, The vidyās will not be successful. [46]
dam tshig sbyor ba nyams pa na/ / brgya byin gyis kyang rab 'bad las/ / rig pa'i dngos grub mi 'gyur na/ / sa stengs mi rnams smos ci dgos/ /
When one observes the pledge imperfectly, though using Śakra’s excellent efforts, The vidyās won’t be successful. What need one say about [the efforts of] human beings on the Earth? [47]
dam tshig bstan bcos de nyid shes/ / spyod pa'i las rnams sgrub pa de/ / 'jig rten pa dang 'phags pa'i sngags/ / bklags pa tsam gyis 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Knowing the essence of pledges and scriptures when performing the rituals of practice,[490] The worldly and noble mantras will be successful Merely by reading them. [48]
byang chub sems dpa'i dkyil 'khor du/ / rab zhugs las rnams thams cad byed/ / byang chub sems dpa' bstan pa la/ / de yi rig pa'i dngos grub rtag /
Having entered and performed all rituals in the bodhisattva’s maṇḍala, the success of its vidyās is guaranteed, as [stated] in the bodhisattva’s teachings. [49]

de nas yang gsang ba pa'i bdag po lag na rdo rjes/ sems dpa' chen po de la gsol ba btab par gyur to/ / kye kye sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis sems can gyi don gyi phyir dkyil 'khor cho ga gsungs so/ / dang po re zhig cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed dam/ nag pa can nam/ sa gcan gyi zla ba'i dkar po'i phyogs la rab tu bsngags pa'i nyi ma dang / gza' bzang po bltas te/ rgyu skar dge ba dang yang dag par ldan pa'i dkar po'i phyogs kyi tshes gcig dang / zla ba nya ba'am/ dus gzhan la dbyar gyi zla ba spangs te/ snga dro sa rab tu gnas par bya'o/ / grong khyer chen po la brten pa'am/ gang du dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon rang nyid gnas par te/ rgya mtshor 'jug pa'am/ chu klung la brten pa'am/ rgya mtsho'i ngogs dang nye bar grong khyer chen po'i byang shar gyi phyogs kyi char ha cang yang mi ring / ha cang yang mi nye bar dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon song nas/ nyi ma bdun nam/ zla phyed du mtha' gcig tu smyung ba'am/ nye bar gnas nas so sor gnas par bya'o/ /

After that, Vajrapāṇi, Lord of the Secret Ones, requested of that Great Being, “O Great Being, please speak briefly about the ritual of the maṇḍala in order to benefit sentient beings.” Having been implored in this way by the Lord of the Secret Ones, the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara spoke about the ritual of the maṇḍala to benefit sentient beings.[491] In the beginning, when an auspicious planet is observed on an auspicious day in the first half of the month of miracles [February/March], or the waxing moon of Caitra [March/April] or Vaiśakha [April–May], or during a full or new moon associated with an auspicious lunar asterism[492] or at another time, except for the [rainy] summer months, at dawn, a spot of earth is to be consecrated. [That spot of earth is] where a solitary maṇḍala hierophant, who has recourse to a great city, has gone to seek shelter — either the edge of the sea, a great river, or in the vicinity of the ocean shoreline, neither too close nor too far from the great city, to its northeast. There, he should dwell in solitude, fasting for seven days or half a month.[493]

gang gnas de rnams su'ang gtsang ma'i sa phyogs rdo ba dang / gyo mo dang / thal ba dang / sol ba dang / phub ma dang / thod pa dang / rus pa dang / rus pa gnas pa dang bral ba/ shin tu yongs su sbyang ba byas pa'i sa phyogs su/ srog chags med pa'i chu la/ ba byung lnga dang bsres pa'i tsan+dan dang / ga pur dang / gur gum gyi chus khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa stong phrag brgyad kyis mngon par bsngags pa des bcom ldan 'das ma'i phyag rgya chen po yang dag par ldan pas/ sa phyogs de la phyogs bzhi rnams su mngon par gtor zhing steng dang 'og dang thad ka dang phyogs bral rnams su'ang kun nas gtor bar bya'o/ /

In those places where the earth has been made completely clean — free from rocks, gravel, ashes, charcoal, chaff, and bones — one should sanctify a clean spot of earth by sprinkling it with vermin-free water, either mixed with the five cow products[494] or with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron. [That water] should also be consecrated with 8,000 repetitions of the vidyā of the Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā,” and with the application of Blessed [Tārā’s] Great Seal.[495] Then, one should scatter the water] all over that spot of earth: in the four cardinal directions, and the intermediate directions, as well as above, below, and straight to the horizon.
de nas sa phyogs der kun nas gru bzhir/ khru bcu drug gam/ khru bcu gnyis sam/ khru brgyad bya ste/ de la chen po ni khru bcu drug go/ /bar ma ni khru bcu gnyis so/ /chung ngu ni khru brgyad do/ /
Then make a square of sixteen cubits, twelve cubits, or eight cubits on that spot of earth: the largest [square] is sixteen cubits, the medium is twelve cubits, and the smallest is eight cubits.

dkyil 'khor rnam pa gsum po 'di/ / thams cad gzigs pas gsungs pa yin/ / rgyal srid 'dod phyir chen po ste/ / bar ma longs spyod 'phel bar byed/ / chung ngu sngags kyi dam tshig ni/ / las rnams kun byed zhi pa yin/ /

These are the three kinds of maṇḍalas Spoken about by the All-Seeing One.[496] The large one is for the purpose of desiring a kingdom. The middle-sized one is for increasing enjoyment. The small one [which protects][497] the mantra’s pledge, Is for performing all rites that pacify. [50]

de la yid la 'dod pa gang yang rung ba'i dkyil 'khor bri bar bya'o/ / de la sa'i phyogs der khru gnyis tsam brkos la/ der rdo ba dang / sol ba dang / thal ba dang / rus pa dang / skra la sogs pa dang / srog chags kyi rigs rnam pa sna tshogs pa gal te mthong na sa'i phyogs gzhan du brko bar bya'o/ / gnod pa med pa dang / nye bar 'tshe ba med pa der 'gyur ro/ / ri'i rtse mo dang / rgya mtshor 'bab pa'i chu klung chen po'i chu ngogs rnams su'ang gang rab tu 'bad pa chen pos shin tu so sor brtags te shin tu gtsang zhing srog chags med par byas nas bri bar bya'o/ / sa'i phyogs der slar yang srog chags med pa'i chu la ba'i rnam lnga bsres pas chu klung gi 'gram gyi sa gtsang ma'am/ grog mkhar gyi sa'am/ gang du srog chags med pa'i sa des dgang bar bya'o/ / bkang nas kyang legs par brdungs te kun nas mnyam par byas la ji ltar 'dod pa'i dkyil 'khor rnam pa gsum bya'o/ / seng ldeng gi phur bu bzhi la khro bo'i rgyal po nyid kyis lan bdun mngon par bsngags par byas nas phyogs bzhi rnams su gdab par bya'o/ / tshon sna lnga'i skud pa la khro bo'i rgyal pos lan bdun mngon par bsngags par byas nas kun nas dkyil 'khor gru bzhi pa'i rnam par dkri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du dbus kyi gnas su/ nang du'ang zur bzhi'i rnam par bya'o/ / dbus kyi nang na gnas pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis rtsa ba'i rig pa'am/ rtsa ba'i snying po stong phrag brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / phyag rgya chen po dang rtsa ba'i sngags kyis gtsug tor bcings te khro bo'i rtsa ba'i sngags kyis grogs bsrungs nas bdag nyid bsrung bar byas te/ bzlas pa byed bzhin du phyi rol du byung ste/ dkyil 'khor la g.yas su bskor ba byas nas kha shar du phyogs te ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug nas/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad yid la byas te dkyil 'khor de kun nas gru bzhi'i rnam par dkri bar bya'o/ / de nyid kyi phyi rol du zhag gcig smyung bar gnas pas rab tu gnas par bya'o/ /

In that place, one should draw the maṇḍala appropriately, as the mind desires. In that place, having excavated about two cubits of earth from that spot of earth, if one should see rocks, charcoal, ashes, bones, hair, or various species of vermin, etc., one should excavate another site. Any living beings who inhabit that place should not be harmed. Additionally, that place should be free from danger.[498] With great effort, having carefully examined [a mound of sand from][499] a mountain peak, or the bank of a stream or a large river flowing into the ocean, and having made it clean and free from insects, one should mark it off. Moreover, that spot of earth is to be filled with fragrant, fresh, and sacred earth from a riverbank, mixed with the five [ritually purifying] substances of a cow and vermin-free water or with earth from an anthill where no life remains. Having filled [that spot] to the brim [with good soil] and having beat it down well and made its surface even, one should make the three types of maṇḍalas according to one’s desires.[500] One should plant four ritual daggers of khadira wood that have been consecrated seven times with the mantra of the Wrathful King. One should completely outline the border of the square-shaped maṇḍala with five-colored thread that has been consecrated seven times with the recitation of the wrathful [king’s] essence-incantation. In the same way, one should make the interior central space square-shaped. The hierophant sitting in the center [of the maṇḍala] should recite the root vidyā or the root essence-incantation eight thousand times.[501] Having bound one’s headdress [while forming] the Great Seal [hand gesture] and [reciting] the root mantra, one will have protected one’s companions and oneself with the wrathful [king’s] root mantra.[502] While reciting the mantra, the hierophant goes outside [the maṇḍala], circumambulates it in a clock-wise manner, faces east, and sits down on a bundle of kuśa grass. Having called to mind all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas, [the hierophant] should enclose the four sides of the maṇḍala with kuśa grass[503] and should remain fasting for a day on the outside of that [maṇḍala].[504]

de la 'dir dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyi sngon spyad pa rnams byas te/ rang gi rig pa dang / sngags dang rgyud la mkhas pa'i mkhan pos sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir theg pa chen po la lhag par mos pas zhag gcig smyung bar gnas pas grogs bzang po dang yang dag par ldan pa/ bstan bcos rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i bya ba mthong bas tshon lnga'i phye ma zhib mo 'bar bas legs par sbyang ba byas nas/ rtsa ba'i rig pa'i sngags dang snying pos mngon par bsngags pa'i phye ma dkyil 'khor dbus su gdab par bya'o/ / pha rol du'ang rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan sgreng ba dang / rta babs bzhes brgyan pa dang / chu shing gi sdong bu 'bras bu'i tshogs kyis g.yur za zhing kun nas 'bras bu'i tshogs rnams kyis rab tu 'phyang bzhin pa dang / rnga bo che dang / rdza rnga dang / dung gi sgra nges par sgrogs pa'i sa'i phyogs su bsgrag par bya'o/ / ngos bzhir rjes su mthun pa'i bar du bsngags pa'i sgra'i chos mnyan par bya'o/ / phyogs bzhi rnams su theg pa chen po'i mdo sde'i glegs bam bklag par bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/ shes rab kyi pha rol du phyin pa lho phyogs su bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa zla ba sgron ma'i ting nge 'dzin nub phyogs su'o/ / 'phags pa sdong po bkod pa byang phyogs su'o/ / 'phags pa gser 'od dam pa shar phyogs su'o/ / de ltar glegs bam klog pa po med na mdo sde bzhi po klog par rtogs pa'i gang zag chos smra ba po la chos mnyan pa'i phyir gsol ba gdab par bya'o/ /

There, the maṇḍala hierophant,[505] whose preliminary duties have been performed, who is a learned man skilled in his own vidyās, mantras, and tantric teachings, who is exceedingly devoted to the Great Vehicle for the benefit of all sentient beings, who has fasted for a day and a night, who has good friends, and whose actions are prescribed by the various scriptures, should cleanse the very fine five-colored sand that has been consecrated with the essence-incantation and the mantra of the root vidyā and place that sand in the center of the maṇḍala. That spot of earth on the outside [of the maṇḍala] should be adorned with four archways, hoisted victory banners and pendants, and full bunches of hanging fruits. It should be planted with heaps of fruit-laden banana trees and should resonate with the sounds of the great drum, the kettledrum, and conch shell. One should hear words of Dharma favorably extolled on all four sides [of the maṇḍala]. Books of the Mahāyāna scriptures should be read in the four directions. One should read The Blessed Perfection of Wisdom [scripture][506] in the southern direction, The Noble Moonlight Concentration [scripture][507] in the western direction, The Noble Profound Array [scripture][508] in the northern direction, and The Noble Illustrious Golden Light Scripture[509] in the eastern direction. If there are no readers of books present, a Dharma reciter who is a person that has comprehended these four scriptures exceedingly well should be earnestly requested [to recite these scriptures][510] in order that the Dharma be heard.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon langs nas tsan+dan dang / ga pur dang / gur gum rnam par bsres pa'i me tog dkar po dri zhim pa la rtsa ba'i rig pa bzlas te/ dkyil 'khor de thams cad du gcal du dgram par bya'o/ / mngon par bkram nas phyi rol du byung ste/ zhag bdun gyi bar du 'dod pa'i kha zas bsten pa gnyis sam/ gsum/ byang chub kyi sems bskyed pa/ gso sbyong nye bar gnas pa bsten pa la gnas pa'i ri mo mkhan de grogs sam/ slob ma des khas blangs pa rab tu gzhug par bya'o/ / gang rtsa ba'i rig pa nyid kyis gtsug tor bcing ba byas nas/ de nas gser dang / dngul dang / rin po che rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i go 'phang rnam par bkra zhing / 'bar la mdzes pa'i zangs kyi phye ma zhib mo so sor bzung nas longs spyod chen po dang ldan zhing / chos dang ldan pa'i rgyal po chen po rnams 'dir gzhug par bya'o/ /

Then, the [maṇḍala] hierophant should stand up, recite the root vidyā over sweet-smelling white flowers mixed with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron, scatter [the flowers] all over the maṇḍala and go outside. [The maṇḍala hierophant] should accept two or three skillful painters,[511] either friends or disciples, who have been sustained by desirable food for up to seven days, who have generated the mind of enlightenment, who are accustomed to fasting, and who adhere to the doctrine, and he should install them [in the maṇḍala]. Wealthy Dharma kings who have tied the headdress [while reciting] the same root vidyā and have held the fine powders made respectively of gold, silver, different varieties of precious jewels, and copper of luminous beauty, are to commission[512] the depiction [of the maṇḍala].
dkyil 'khor mthong ba nyid las nges par byang chub la gzhol ba yin no/ / sngags sgrub par byed pa lta ci smos/
If the goal of enlightenment is certain By merely looking at the maṇḍala, What needs to be said about [becoming enlightened] While practicing mantras? [51]
shAkya'i skyes mchog mya ngan 'das/ / sems can bsod nams chung rnams la/ / 'di lta'i longs spyod ga la yod/ / cho ga 'di ni bstan par bya/ /
Once the Excellent Person of the Śākyas has passed beyond suffering, This ritual should be shown To sentient beings of little merit So they may enjoy seeing [a maṇḍala] such as this. [52]
byang chub sems dpa' 'od chen ldan/ / skye bo bkren pa gzigs nas ni/ / nyung zhing mdor bsdus dkyil 'khor ni/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bstan pa yin/ /
The resplendent bodhisattva Who sees a destitute person Should briefly extol the maṇḍala In a concise and small way. [53]

'bras sA lu dang thug po che'i phye ma shin tu zhib mo tshon sna lnga pa 'bar bas/ dkar po dang / ser po dang / dmar po dang / nag po dang / ljang gu'i kha dog tu kha bsgyur la/ sngar bzhag pa'i phye ma dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis blangs nas bcom ldan 'das ma'i phyag rgya chen po bcings te rtsa ba'i rig pas phye ma la phyag rgyas gdab par bya'o/ / gzhan zhi ba sgrub pa'i slob dpon gyis dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol lho shar gyi phyogs su las kyi cho ga mthong bas me thab bya'o/ / khru gnyis kyi tshad la dpangs khru gang tsam kho ra khor yug tu pad+ma'i ze ba'i rnam par shing pa lA sha'i yam shing rnams kyis me rab tu sbar te/ shing dpal 'bras kyi yam shing mtho gang tsam gyi tshad la rlan dang bcas pa/ zho dang sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pa rnams kyis rtsa ba'i snying pos sam/ phyag rgya dang / rtsa ba'i rig sngags kyis me lha spyan drang bar bya'o/ / spyan drangs nas kyang sngar brjod pa'i yi ge gcig pa nyid kyi rig pa'am/ rtsa ba'i rig pa'i snying pos slar yang brgya rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis gtsug tor gtsang zhing yo byad tshogs par byas nas bdag nyid dang ri mo mkhan ches mkhas pa'am/ slob ma byed du gzhug go/ /

The maṇḍala hierophant should then take the finely powdered rice and barley grains dyed[513] five brilliant colors: white, gold, red, black, and green, which had been previously placed [in the maṇḍala], tie the Great Seal hand gesture of the Blessed [Tārā], recite the root vidyā, and impress the powdered [grains] with the seal.[514] The maṇḍala hierophant who succeeds in appeasing others[515] and has observed the methods for conducting the ritual, should make a ritual hearth in the southeast direction outside the maṇḍala. It should be two cubits [wide] and about a full cubit deep. Its circumference should have the shape of a lotus blossom, and be lotus-shaped on the outside. Having ignited a fire using kindling of the palāśa tree, smear curds, honey, and butter on moist sticks of the wood apple tree that measure a full span. Then, he should invite the fire deity, using the root essence-incantation or the root vidyā and hand gesture. After having invited [the fire deity], he should perform a burnt offering 800 times using the same single-syllable vidyā previously expressed or the essence-incantation of the root vidyā. Then, having bound the headdress and performed the necessary requirements, the maṇḍala hierophant himself should have the great painter[s][516] who are skillful [professionals] or disciples perform [the burnt offerings].[517]

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams yid la byas nas sngar brjod pa'i bdug pa'i rig pas bsreg go/ / thal mo sbyar ba byas nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la phyag byas nas phye ma blangs te/ gzugs kyi rnam par bya zhing / ri mo mkhan mkhas pas rdzogs par bya'o/ / cho ga 'di dag gis dang po kho nar re zhig sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa rin po che seng+ge'i khri la bzhugs pa gnas gtsang ma'i gnas na chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa kun du bri'o/ / dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis kun du bris nas rjes su sgrub pa pos bdag nyid srung ba'i cho ga dang / rig pa byas nas 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma sbyin par bya ste/ dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol gyi phyogs bzhi dang steng dang 'og tu gtor bar bya'o/ / de nas khrus byas nas me thab dang nye bar song nas gos gtsang ma bgos te gtsang sbra dang / srung ba'i cho ga byas te rtsa ba'i rig pas gur gum dang bsres pa'i mar gyi sreg blugs stong phrag brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

Then, the maṇḍala hierophant calls to mind the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas and burns incense [while reciting] the incense vidyā mentioned earlier. Having folded his palms in prayer, [bowed] to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, made salutations to the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, and taken the sand, [the maṇḍala hierophant] should make an outline of a body and the skillful painter[s][518] should complete it. Using these rituals, first draw the Buddha Lord Śākyamuni, endowed with the best of all aspects, seated on a jeweled lion throne, and situated in the pure abode as if teaching the Dharma. Once that has been depicted by the maṇḍala hierophant, the assistant should perform the ritual for self protection, [pronounce] the vidyā, offer sacrificial cakes (gtor ma) to all spirits, and scatter [the cakes] outside the maṇḍala in the four directions, as well as above and below. Then, after having bathed, approached the hearth, donned clean clothes, and performed the ritual of purity and protection, they should perform the burnt offerings eight thousand times with an oblation of clarified butter mixed with saffron [while reciting] the root vidyā.

de nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste de nyid du bzlas pa byed cing de nyid du gnas par bya'o/ / yungs kar dkar po la khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad du mngon par bsngags te/ mngon par bsngags nas kham phor kha sbyor du gzhag par bya'o/ / bgegs kyi rnam par 'gyur ba'i gzugs rnams du ma dang / nga ro drag po dang / rlung dang / char dang / yul ngan gzhan dang gzhan gang yang rung ba 'ongs pa mthong na/ khros pas yungs kar gyi sreg blugs lan bdun sbyin sreg bya'o/ / de nas bgegs rab tu 'jigs par 'gyur ro/ / mi'i bgegs la ni lan lnga chang pa nas sbyin sreg byas na skyes bu de rengs par 'gyur ba'am/ nus pa med par 'gyur ba'am/ 'chi bar 'gyur ba'am/ skad cig de nyid la mi ma yin pas zin par 'gyur ro/ / de nas rjes su sgrub pa pos de nyid du ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug nas khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pas bzlas pa byed cing gnas par bya'o/ /

Then, having sat down on a bundle of kuśa grass, they should remain, reciting [the vidyā]. Having recited [the vidyā] of the Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā” eight hundred times over white mustard, upon finishing, [the mustard] is to be placed in a lidded vessel. If one should see many types of loathsome and demonic forms, plus terrifying, howling winds and rain, and any other calamities, the ritual of burnt offering should be performed seven times with [the vidyā of] the wrathful [king] and an oblation of white mustard. After that, the demonic hindrances will be destroyed.[519] If there is a hindering person, one should perform the ritual of burnt offerings five times, and that person will undoubtedly become paralyzed, disabled, dead, or possessed by a non-human spirit that very instant. If Indra[520] dies quickly [from this ritual], what needs to be said about [its effect upon] evil-minded human beings or other ordinary obstacles? [The hindering demons],[521] fearful of the Wrathful One “Captivated by Tārā,” will flee hither and thither and will certainly disappear. Thus, the attendant should remain seated there, on that kuśa grass mat, and should continue reciting the [vidyā of the] Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā.”

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i sku gzugs kyi g.yas kyi gzhogs su rang sangs rgyas gnyis pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa skyil krung gis nye bar bzhugs par bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu nyan thos chen po gnyis chos nyan par bya'o/ / de rnams kyi'ang g.yas su bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa ston ka'i sprin gyi mdog ltar dkar ba pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa phyag g.yon pas pad+ma bsnams nas/ g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa'o/ / de'i yang g.yas su bcom ldan 'das ma gos dkar mo phyag na pad+ma bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal bzhin pa pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar bzhugs pa/ ral ba'i cod pan 'chang ba/ dar la dkar po'i na bza' bsnams pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs bla gos bsnams pa/ thal ba nag po'i thig le gsum byas pa'o/ / de bzhin du brtan pa dang / khro gnyer can ma yang / rang rang gi gdan la rang rang gi spyod lam du gnas shing nye bar bzhugs pa'ang bya'o/ / de rnams kyi g.yas su bcom ldan 'das ma shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma dang / de bzhin gshegs pa spyan ma dang / gtsug tor rgyal mo'ang bya'o/ /

Next, to the right of Lord Śākyamuni’s body, the maṇḍala expert should make two Pratyekabuddhas sitting cross-legged on lotus seats. Below them, he should make two great Śrāvakas, listening to the Dharma. To their right is the Blessed Noble Avalokiteśvara, adorned with all ornaments and white as the color of autumn clouds. Sitting on a lotus seat, he holds a lotus with the left hand and displays a boon-granting gesture (varadā) with the right. To his right is the Blessed Pāṇḍaravāsinī,[522] holding a lotus in her [left] hand and sitting on a lotus seat. With her right hand, she appears as if paying homage to Lord Śākyamuni. She bears a crown of locks, wears clothes of white silk, an upper silk garment, and has three marks made of sacred black ash. In the same way, also make *Dṛdh[ā][523] and Bhṛkuṭī seated nearby, abiding on their own respective seats and in their own respective deportments. [Above][524] and to their right make Prajñāpāramitā, Tathāgata Locanā, and Uṣṇīṣarājñī.

de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' bcu drug bya ba la/ 'di lta ste/ kun du bzang po dang / sa'i snying po dang / nam mkha'i mdzod dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba dang / ngan song spong dang / byams pa phyag na rnga yab thogs pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la lta bzhin pa dang / dri ma med pa'i blo gros dang / dri ma med pa'i tog dang / nor bzang dang / zla 'od dang / dri ma med par grags pa dang / nad thams cad gso bar byed pa dang / chos thams cad kyi dbang phyug rgyal po dang / 'jig rten 'gro ba dang / blo gros chen po dang / mngon par 'dzin pa zhes pa ste/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po bcu drug po 'di rnams rab tu zhi ba'i sku dang / rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa bri'o/ / rig pa'i rgyal po'i gtso bo dang / rig pa'i rgyal mo dang / pad+ma'i rigs kyi gzugs dang / phyag rgya rnams lung las ji ltar bshad pa bzhin dang / gnas ji lta ba bzhin du bri'o/ / mtha'i gnas su'ang gru bzhi'i rnam par gnas gzhag par bya'o/ / pad+ma'i me tog legs par byas pa dang / rig pa'i lha gang gis dran pa yang gnas de rnams su gzhag par bya'o/ /

Make the sixteen Bodhisattvas accordingly, as follows: Samantabhadra, Kṣitigarbha, Gaganagañja, Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin Apāyajaha, Maitreya with yak tail in hand as if gazing at the Blessed Buddha, Vimalagati, Vimalaketu, Sudhana, Candraprabha, Vimalakīrti, Sarvavyādhicikitsaka, Sarva-dharmeśvararāja, Lokagati, Mahāmati, Abhidhara. Depict these sixteen great bodhisattvas as embodiments of tranquility, and adorned with all ornaments. The principle vidyārāja and vidyārājñī and the [remaining][525] corporeal forms and symbolic seals of the Lotus family are to be drawn in their proper places according to the explanation in the ancient scriptures. Also, put down square shapes along the border and fill them with well-made lotus blossoms and whichever deities of the vidyās one recalls [that have been thus-far omitted].[526]

de bzhin du bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yas kyi gzhogs su rang sangs rgyas nam mkha' dang / yongs su zhes bya ba gnyis kyang ngo //de bzhin du shar du kha bltas pa'i dkyil 'khor thams cad du 'jug pa'i sgo rnams bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon gyi gzhogs su rang sangs rgyas tsan+dan dang / grub pa zhes pa gzhan gnyis kyang kun tu bri'o/ / de rnams kyi 'og tu nyan thos chen po 'od srung chen po dang / ka t+ya na dang gnyis kun du bri'o/ / de rnams kyi'ang gzhogs su 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje ut+pa la ltar sngo bsangs su snang ba rab tu zhi ba'i gzugs rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ phyag g.yas rnga yab thogs pa/ g.yon pa khro bo'i spyi bor bzhag pa'o/ / rdo rje khu tshur dang / rdo rje lcags kyu dang / rdo rje lcags sgrog dang / dpung bzang dang / rdo rje sde rnams cha byad ji lta ba dang / mtshan ma ji lta ba bzhin du bgegs rnams 'joms pa'o/ / rig pa'i rgyal po dang / rgyal mo 'khor dang bcas pa thams cad dang / gzugs dang phyag rgya la sogs pa rnams ji ltar dran pa bzhin du bri'o/ /

In the same way, to the right of Lord Śākyamuni are two pratyekabuddhas called Ākāśa and Parivāsa. Similarly, one should make the entrance doors of all maṇḍalas, making the front in the east. On the left side of Lord Śākyamuni, one should draw two other Pratyekabuddhas called Candana and Siddha. Below them draw the two great Śrāvakas called Mahākāśyapa and Kātyāyana. To their left is Noble Vajrapāṇi, [whose complexion] is blue as the utpala lotus and whose serene form is adorned with all ornaments. His right hand bears a yak tail fan and his left is placed on [his] wrathful head. Vajramuṣṭī, Vajrāṅkuśī, Vajrasṛṅkhalā, Subahu, and Vajrasena subdue demonic hindrances according to their guises and insignia.[527] One should depict their corporeal forms and hand gestures, etc., together with all the vidyā kings (vidyārāja) and vidyā queens (vidyārājñī) [of the vajra family] that one recalls.

de rnams kyi'ang g.yon du gru bzhi'i rnam par rdo rje'i phyag rgya gnyis bri bar bya'o/ / bris nas kyang gnas gang du rig pa'i tshogs ma dran pa de rnams gnas 'dir bzhugs shig ces brjod par bya'o/ / de rnams kyi steng du pha rol tu phyin pa drug dang / bcom ldan 'das ma mA ma kI kun du bri ste rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa rab tu zhi ba'i lus so/ / de rnams kyi'ang steng du gtsug tor gyi rgyal po brgyad kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ phyag rgya bcings pa rang rang gi 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po chen po'i gzugs su kun du bri ste/ gser mdog dbang po rab tu zhi ba rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gzugs la cung zad blta ba sbyin pa rnams 'di lta ste/ gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba dang / gtsug tor mngon par 'phags pa dang / gtsug tor gdugs dkar po dang / rgyal ba'i gtsug tor dang / pad+ma'i gtsug tor dang / rnam par rgyal ba'i gtsug tor dang / gzi brjid phung po dang / gtsug tor mthon po zhes pa ste/ gtsug tor brgyad po 'di rnams kun du bri'o/ / 'jug pa'i phyogs kyi sgor ni byang chub sems dpa' gnyis bya ste/ g.yas phyogs su ni 'jig rten las 'das par 'gro ba zhes bya ba rab tu zhi ba'i lus ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ phyag g.yas mchog sbyin pas phreng ba 'dzin pa/ phyag g.yon pas spyi blugs 'dzin cing sgo la mngon du phyogs pa/ bzhin cung zad khro gnyer dang bcas pa kun du bri'o/ / 'jug pa'i sgo'i g.yon phyogs su ni byang chub sems dpa' chen po ma rgyal ba las rgyal ba bri bar bya ste/ rab tu zhi ba'i lus ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ phyag g.yon dbyug gu dang / ril ba spyi blugs 'dzin pa/ phyag g.yas pas bgrang phreng ba zung nas mchog sbyin pas rab tu sbyin par byed pa/ bzhin cung zad khro gnyer can 'jug pa'i sgo la mngon par phyogs pa kun du bri'o/ /

On their left, depict a double vajra seal inside a square. Having depicted that, one should proclaim, “Whichever groups of vidyās have been omitted, please let them sit here!”[528] Above them, draw the six Perfection goddesses (pāramitās) and Blessed Māmakī adorned with all ornaments and possessing serene forms. Also above them, are the eight uṣṇīṣarājas, shimmering with a blazing garland, and firm hand gestures. Depict each of them in the guise of a great emperor (mahācakravartin) with a golden complexion, well-controlled senses, adorned with all ornaments, and glancing obliquely at the body of the Tathāgata. They are as follows: Cakravartī-uṣṇīṣa, Abhyudgatoṣṇīṣa, Uṣṇīṣa-sitatāpatra, Jayoṣṇīṣa, Kamaloṣṇīṣa, Vijayoṣṇīṣa, Tejo-rāśi-uṣṇīṣa, and Uṣṇīṣāgra. Draw these eight Uṣṇīṣa[rājas] in this way.[529] Make two bodhisattvas flanking the entrance door. On the [entrance’s] right side is He Who Goes Beyond the World (Lokātikrāntagāmi), serene in form, bearing a crown of locks, holding a rosary and displaying a boon-granting gesture with the right hand, and holding a ritual water pot in the left. He should be drawn with a slightly wrathful expression, facing the door. On the left side of the entrance, draw the great bodhisattva He Who Conquers the Invincible (Ajitaṃjaya), serene in form, bearing a crown of locks, holding a staff and ritual water pot in the left hand, and with the right he holds meditation beads and bestows an offering of excellent gifts. He should be drawn with a slightly wrathful expression, facing the entrance door.

seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu chos kyi 'khor lo kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa de'i 'og tu rin po che'i gzhal yas khang de la gnas pa'i bcom ldan 'das ma rig pa'i rgyal mo chen mo ha cang mi skem/ ha cang mi sbom pa'i lus su gnas pa/ rab tu zhi ba'i sku/ gzugs mdzes shing cung zad 'dzum pa'i bzhin/ phyag g.yon pas ut+pal sngon po bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas dpal 'bras bsnams pa/ byis pa'i rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ rin po che'i cod pan 'chang ba/ mu tig gi phreng pas mchod phyir thogs pa byas pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs mnabs pa/ dar gyi na bzas smad g.yogs pa/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar bzhugs pa/ khro bo'i rgyal por gyur pa/ sgrol mas non pa la gzigs par gyur pa/ dkyil 'khor du 'jug pa'i sgo la mngon par phyogs pa/ blta na sdug pa thams cad du srin mo ral pa gcig pa byas pa'i gzugs 'chang ba kun du bri'o/ / de'i g.yas phyogs kyi gzhogs su pad+ma'i 'og tu khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa bri ste/ rnam par 'gyur ba chen po'i gzugs can kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ bka' so sor bzhes bzhin pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen por gyur pa la blta ba kun nas bri'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su pad+ma'i 'og tu gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i gzugs can byang chub sems dpa' lnga bri bar bya ste/ 'di lta ste/ shin tu dri ma med pa dang / shin tu dul ba dang / dag pa dang / mun pa sel byed dang / kun du snang ba zhes pa/ de rnams thams cad kyang gnas gtsang ma'i gnas na 'dug pa/ rin po che 'bar ba du ma'i rdo'i mthil dang 'dra ba/ kun nas 'bar ba rnam par bkra ba'i me tog rnams kyis gcal du bkram pa/ gzugs mdzes pa kun du bri'o/ / phyi rol gyi khor yug tu gru bzhir rta babs bzhi dang ldan pa rnams par bkra ba'i tshon sna lngas gsal ba/ shin tu drang ba'i mi dma' bas nang gi dkyil 'khor bya'o/ /

Below the lion throne is a wheel of Dharma, shimmering with a blazing garland. Below that [Dharma Wheel] is the Blessed One, the Queen of Mahāvidyās (Bhagavatī Mahāvidyārājñī) dwelling in that jeweled celestial palace. Her body is neither too thin, nor too fat, but serene and beautiful, and [her face] has a faint smile. She holds a blue utpala in her left hand and a myrobalan fruit[530] in her right. Adorned with all the ornaments of a youth, she bears a crown of jewels and a sacred thread[531] made of a string of pearls, wears an upper and lower garment of silk, and shimmers with a garland of blazing light. Seated on a lotus throne, she looks at the wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā” and faces the entry door of the maṇḍala. Depict her pleasant to look at in every way, bearing the form of a Protectress with a Single Lock of Hair (Rākṣasī Ekajaṭī).[532] Below the lotus, to the right, depict the Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā” (*Tārā-vikranta) whose loathsome form shimmers with a blazing garland. Draw him looking at the great Bodhisattva, as if receiving a command. Below the lotus and to the left, one should depict five bodhisattvas in the form of [the sons of][533] the gods from the heaven of the Pure Abodes. [These five called] Stainless, Disciplined, Pure, Dispelling Darkness, and All Illuminating[534] abide in the place of the Pure Abodes, which is beautifully depicted, scattered with multi-colored flowers that shine brightly like a stone floor made of many shimmering, precious jewels. Make four square-shaped archways in the four directions along the circumference outside the inner maṇḍala and bind [the entire circumference] with five different brightly colored straight lines.[535]

shar gyi phyogs su bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i steng du ri mo'i dbus su me tog gi rgyal po'i dbang po pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar bzhugs pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gzugs shin tu chung tsam du bya ste/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ phyag mchog sbyin pas rab tu sbyin pa/ sku'i gtsug tor la bzhugs pa'o/ / de'i g.yas su gtsug tor 'khor los sgyur ba'i phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / g.yon du gzi brjid phung po'i phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan ma'i steng du shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma bri bar bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi steng du shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin ma'i g.yas su bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag tu med pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i skur bya ste/ phyag mchog sbyin pas rab tu sbyin pa pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar bzhugs pa/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa'o/ / de'i yang g.yas su lhung bzed dang / chos gos kyi phyag rgya'o/ / de bzhin du mthar gyis 'jug pa'i gnas su pad+ma'i phyag rgya bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das me tog kun nas rgyas pa'i rgyal po de bzhin gshegs pa'i g.yon du gtsug tor gzi brjid phung po'i phyag rgya bri ste kun nas 'bar bas 'khrugs pa'o/ / de'i yang g.yon du de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog gi sku rin po che'i ri la nye bar bzhugs pa chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa be+eDUr+ya sngon po dang / mar gad dang / pad+ma rA ga rnam pa sna tshogs pa 'bar ba'i 'od 'byin pa/ kun nas kun du 'od gsal ba bri'o/ / de'i yang g.yon du rgyal ba'i gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba 'khrugs pa kun du bri'o/ / de'i yang g.yon du chos kyi 'khor lo'i phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba bri'o/ / de'i yang g.yon du ril ba spyi blugs dang bgrang phreng dang bzang po'i gdan gyi phyag rgya bri'o/ / sgo'i gnas su rdo rje rtse gsum pa gnyis ka nas kun nas 'bar bar bri'o/ /

In the eastern direction, above Lord Śākyamuni, in the center of the drawing, depict the Mighty Flower King (Saṅkusumitarājendra) seated on a lotus. He should be made in the miniature form of the Tathāgata, shimmering with a blazing halo of light, bestowing a boon-granting hand gesture, and seated on the headcrest of [Śākyamuni’s] image.[536] To his right, draw the seal of Uṣṇīṣa-cakravartin. On the left, draw the seal of Tejorāśi. Above the Tathāgata Locanā, draw the seal of Prajñāpāramitā. Above the Noble Lord Avalokiteśvara, to the right [of the seal][537] of Prajñāpāramitā, draw Lord Amitābha in the form of a Tathāgata, bestowing the boon-granting gesture, sitting on a lotus seat, and shimmering with a blazing halo of light. To his right, make the seal of an alms bowl and a monk’s religious garment. In the same way, in proper order, make the seal of a lotus in the entrance [to the maṇḍala]. To the left of the Tathāgata Lord Saṅkusumitarāja, depict the seal of Uṣṇīṣatejorāśi, shimmering with a blazing halo. To the left of that, depict the body of Tathāgata Ratnaketu as if teaching the Dharma, seated upon a jeweled mountain, and emitting the colorful, shimmering light of blue lapis lazuli, emeralds, and rubies. Draw him encircled with brilliant light. To his left, draw the seal of Jayoṣṇīṣa, shimmering with a blazing halo. To the left of that, depict the seal of a Dharma wheel, with a blazing halo. To the left of that, depict the seal of a mendicant’s staff and a cylindrical water pot, meditation beads, and a good seat. In the [maṇḍala’s] doorway, depict two three-pronged vajras blazing all around.

bcom ldan 'das spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi 'og tu phyag rgya chen po dbyug pa can dang / ut+pa la'i phyag rgya kun nas 'bar ba 'di dag phan tshun ma 'byar bar kun du bri'o/ / dkyil 'khor gyi rnam pa kun du bris pa'i phyi rol gyi dkyil 'khor de yang tshon sna lngas 'bar ba rnam par bkra zhing blta na sdug pa/ zur bzhis rnam par mdzes pa/ rta babs bzhi'i rnam pa phyogs bzhir ro/ / nang gi dkyil 'khor las khru gnyis tsam gyi phyi rol gyi shar phyogs su tshangs pa chen po bri bar bya ste/ gdong bzhi pa/ gos dkar po bgos pa/ stod g.yogs gos dkar po can/ mchod phyir thogs pa dkar po can/ gser gyi mdog ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ g.yon na dbyug pa dang spyi blugs thogs pa/ phyag na rdo rje'o/ / de'i yang g.yas su 'od gsal gyi lha'i bu bya ste/ lus dar la'i gos bgos pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs can/ bzhin rab tu zhi ba/ ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po can/ skyil krung gis nye bar 'dug pa/ phyag g.yas mchog sbyin pa'o/ / de'i yang g.yas su 'og min pa'i lha'i bu bya ste rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ rab tu zhi ba'i lus/ sems bsam gtan la gnas pa dar la'i gos bgos pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs can/ skyil krung gis nye bar 'dug pa/ phyag g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po can no/ / de'i rim pas dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / 'thab bral dang / brgya byin la sogs pa'i lha'i bu rnams bri bar bya ste/ go rims ji lta ba bzhin dang / cha byad dang / dbyibs ji lta ba bzhin no/ /

Below Lord Avalokiteśvara, depict two blazing seals: one of a blue lotus and another called “Great Seal and Staff,”[538] which do not touch each other. An outer maṇḍala should be drawn in the shape of [the inner] maṇḍala. It should be pleasant to behold: shining brilliantly with five different colors and beautifully square-shaped with four archways in the four directions. One should draw great Brahmā in the eastern direction, about two cubits outside of the inner maṇḍala. He is four-faced and wears white clothes, a white upper garment, and a white sacred thread. He has a golden complexion, bears a crown of locks, and holds a staff and pitcher in the left [hand] and a vajra in [his right] hand. To his right, make the Sons of the Gods of the heaven of Clear Light (Ābhāsvara). Their forms [are golden-colored and introspective in meditation.][539] They are clothed in silk, as they also bear an upper silk garment, a serene face, a crown of locks, and a white sacred thread. They sit cross-legged and their right hands display a boon-granting gesture. To their right, make the Sons of the Gods of the Akaniṣṭha heaven.[540] They are adorned with all ornaments, serene in form, and have their thoughts fixed in meditation. They wear clothes of silk, an upper silk garment, and a white sacred thread. They sit cross-legged and display the boon-granting gesture with their right hands. One should also depict the Sons of the Gods of the heavens of “The Happy Land” (Tuṣita),[541] “Those Who Enjoy Magical Creations,” (nirmāṇarati), “Those Who Overpower Others with Magical Creations,” (paranirmitavaśavartin), Yama,[542] and Śakra,[543] etc., in due order, guise, and proportion.

brgya byin gyi 'og tu rgyal po chen po bzhi'i ris te/ rtag myos dang / phreng thogs dang / lag na gzhong thogs dang / pi wang gnyis pa dang / sa bla pa'i lha'i bu rnams go rims ji lta ba dang / cha byad ji lta ba bzhin bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du lho phyogs su/ mi che ba dang / mi gdung ba dang / shin tu mthong dang / gya nom snang dang / dge chung dang / bsod nams skyes la sogs pa'i lha'i bu rnams cha byad dang / dbyibs ji lta ba bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du nub kyi phyogs dang / de bzhin du'ang / byang gi phyogs su'ang ngo //nub kyi phyogs su de rnams kyi 'og tu phreng gnyis la brten nas bri bar bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor gnyis kyi pha rol tu dkyil 'khor gsum par 'gyur te/ phyogs bzhir rgyal po chen po bzhi go rims bzhin du bri bar bya'o/ / byang phyogs su 'jug pa'i g.yas ngos su nor sbyin gter dang nye bar gnas pa rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ cod pan cung zad bcom pa/ gnod sbyin gyi gzugs can no/ / de'i g.yas su nor bu bzang po dang / gang ba bzang po gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon dag bri'o/ / de bzhin du rim gyis gnod sbyin ma chen mo 'phrog ma bri ste/ gzhon nu dga' byed phang na 'dug pa/ dkyil 'khor la nges par rtog bzhin pa bri'o/ / lngas rtsen dmar ser 'jigs su rung ba'ang bri ste/ de rnams kyi nye logs su gnod sbyin rnams kyi phyag rgya bri bar bya'o/ /

Below Śakra, draw the heaven of the four great kings, [the heavens of] the gods called Always Intoxicated (sadāmatta), Garland Bearers (mālādhāraḥ), Bowl Bearers (karoṭapāṇis), and Lute Bearers (vīṇādvitīyaka), plus the [heavens of] Sons of the Gods of the mid-space. They are to be drawn exactly according to order and guise. In the same way, in the southern direction, draw the Sons of the Gods of [the form realm heavens called] Avṛha, Atapa, Sudṛśa, Sudarśana, Parīttasubha, Puṇyaprasava, etc. Draw them according to their proper guise and proportion. The same is for the western direction, and also the northern direction. Below those in the western direction, depict [those] who are seated in two rows. Outside of the second maṇḍala is a third maṇḍala. The four Great Kings should be drawn in the four directions according to arrangement. In the north, to the right side of the entrance is Dhanada,[544] standing near a treasury. He is adorned with all ornaments, his crown somewhat tattered, and has the form of a yakṣa spirit. To his right, draw the yakṣa generals Manibhadra and Pūrṇabhadra. Similarly, in order, depict Hārītī the great female yakṣiṇī, Priyaṃkara the youth, sitting on her lap and reflecting upon the maṇḍala, and the [yakṣa called] Pañcika who is maroon in color and frightful. Draw the seals of the yakṣas nearby them.

de bzhin du rim gyis nub kyi phyogs su lha lag na zhags pa thogs pa dang / klu dga' bo dang / nye dga' bo dang / 'jog po dang / nor rgyas kyi bu la sogs pa rgyal po chen po brgyad bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du phreng gnyis pa la brten nas go rims bzhin du gnod sbyin dang / srin po dang / dri za dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / drang srong dang / grub pa dang / yi dgas dang / sha za dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi dang mi ma yin pa la sogs pa dang / sman dang / nor bu rin po che'i bye brag dang / ri bo dang / chu bo dang / gling rnams go rims bzhin du gtso bor grags pa dang / mchog tu gtso bo thams cad kyang bri bar bya'o/ /

Accordingly in the western direction, depict the water god Varuṇa bearing a noose in hand and the eight great serpent[545] kings headed by Ananda, Upananda, Takṣaka, and Vāsuki. In the same way, depict all the principally famous and pre-eminent cannibal demons, fragrance eaters, centaurs, great snakes, sages, tantric ascetics, hungry ghosts, flesh eaters, garuḍa birds, humans, and non-humans, etc., plus rocks that make the most precious medicines and jewels, mountains, rivers, and islands, arranged in two rows accordingly.

lho phyogs su gshin rje ma mo bdun gyi 'khor dang bcas pa bri bar bya'o/ / shar gyi phyogs su me lha kun 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ dbyug pa dang / ril pa spyi blugs dang bgrang phreng lag na thogs pa/ ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ gos dkar po bgos pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs can/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po can/ gser gyi mdog thal ba'i thig le gsum byas pa/ sna tshogs pa'i rgyan dang / mtshon cha dang / cha byad dang / dbyibs dang / kha dog de yang phreng gnyis pa la brten nas bri bar bya'o/ / thams cad nas 'jug pa'i dkyil 'khor chen por dka' zlog gi bdag po khyu mchog la zhon pa/ lag pa g.yas rtse gsum thogs pa'o/ / lha mo dka' zlog ma'ang rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa'o/ / smin drug gi bu'ang rma bya la zhon pa/ lag na mdung thung thogs pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can/ gdong drug ba lus dmar por snang ba gos ser po bgos shing stod g.yogs gos ser po can/ phyag g.yon pas dril bu thogs nas ba dan dmar po thogs pa'o/ / go rims bzhin du b+h+r-ing gi ri ti shin tu rid pa'i rnams pa dang / tshogs kyi bdag po chen po dang / dga' byed dbang phyug dang / nag po chen po dang / ma mo bdun po rgyan dang / cha byad dang / dbyibs ji lta bzhin du mngon par bri'o/ / nor lha brgyad dang / drang srong bdun dang / khyab 'jug phyag bzhi pa/ phyag na 'khor lo dang / be con dang / mdung dang / ral gri thogs pa/ nam mkha' lding gi bzhon pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa'o/ / gza' brgyad dang / rgyu skar nyi shu rtsa bdun dang / gang sa stengs kyi dkyil 'khor la rab tu rgyu ba'i nye ba'i gza' brgyad kyang bri'o/ / go rims bzhin du/ dkar po dang / nag po'i tshes bco lnga dang / khyim bcu gnyis dang / dus drug dang / zla ba bcu gnyis dang / lo tshigs dang / sring mo bzhi gru la zhon pa dang / lnga pa ming po chu la gnas pa rnams te/ mdor na/ phyag rgya rnams su rnam par gzhag par bya'o/ / lha rnams go rims bzhin du phreng gnyis su bya'o/ /

In the southern direction, depict Yama together with a retinue of seven mother spirits (matṛka). In the southeast is [the fire god] Agni, shimmering with a blazing halo of light, holding a staff, water pot, and meditation beads in hand, bearing a crown of locks, dressed in white clothes, possessing an upper garment of silk, a white sacred thread, a golden complexion, and distinguished by three marks made of sacred ash. [The seven mother spirits] should be drawn seated in two rows endowed with various types of ornaments, weapons, guises, shapes, and colors.[546] Surrounding the entry outside the great maṇḍala are Umāpati[547] who rides a bull and holds a trident in hand, Goddess Umā[548] who is [golden-complexioned and][549] adorned with all ornaments, and Kārtikeya[550] who is mounted on a peacock, bears a spear in hand, is youthful in form, six-faced, and red-complexioned, wears yellow clothes and a yellow upper garment, and holds a bell in the left hand and a red banner [in the right]. Bhṛṇgiriti,[551] who is very emaciated, Mahāgaṇapati,[552] Nandikeśvara,[553] Mahākāla, and the seven mother spirits should be depicted in succession with the proper ornaments, guise, and proportions. Also depict the eight gods of wealth (vasavas), the seven sages (ṛṣi), and the four-armed Viṣṇu mounted upon a garuḍa bird, holding a discus, conch, club, and sword, and adorned with all ornaments. [On the outside of the maṇḍala’s entrance,] one should also depict the eight planets, the twenty-seven lunar asterisms (nakṣatra), and the eight minor heavenly bodies ranging in a circle above the earth. In brief, established in the form of seals in two successive rows according to arrangement are the fifteen days of [the month] for both waxing and waning moons, the twelve [zodiacal] houses, the six seasons,[554] the twelve months, the course of a year, plus the four sisters and a fifth brother riding in a boat placed in the water.

mdor na dkyil 'khor gsum pa'ang / dkyil 'khor gsum la brten nas mngon par bri bar bya ste/ dkyil 'khor gsum po rnams su'ang gru bzhir rnam par gzhug par bya'o/ / 'di rnams bcom ldan 'das so/ / mdor bsdu na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das sems dpa' thams cad kyi gtso bo ni nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / pad+ma'i rigs 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ni g.yas su nges par bri bar bya'o/ / rdo rje'i rigs 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje ni g.yon du nges par bri bar bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi gtso bo 'phags pa kun du bzang po'ang nges par bri bar bya'o/ / 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa bzhin du phyag rgya rnams su nges par bri bar bya'o/ / 'di dag ni nang gi dkyil 'khor ro/ /

In brief, three interconnected maṇḍalas should be drawn in a square-shaped maṇḍala triad. Briefly, [this is what should be placed in the three square-shaped maṇḍalas:][555] the Lord Buddha, leader of all sentient beings, should surely be depicted. On his right, Noble Avalokiteśvara of the lotus family should surely be depicted. On [Buddha’s] left, Noble Vajrapāṇi of the vajra family should surely be depicted. One should also depict the chief bodhisattva Noble Samantabhadra. Mañjuśrī the youth[556] should surely be depicted. Whatever ones remain should be depicted [in the form of] seals, according to arrangement. This is the inner maṇḍala.

dkyil 'khor bar pa la yang / shar gyi phyogs su mi mjed kyi bdag po tshangs pa nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du lho'i phyogs su 'od gsal ba'o/ / 'og min dang gzugs can min pa rnams lha'i dkyil 'khor gyi rnam par ro/ / 'du shes med 'du shes med min gyi skye mched mi gsal ba'i lha rnams ni ma yin no/ /

In the middle maṇḍala, in the east, one should depict Brahmā, the chief of the world realm that endures [suffering], the Sahāloka. In the same way, in the southern part of the maṇḍala are the gods of [the form realm heavens] Ābhāsvara and Akaniṣṭha, and the gods of the formless realm. There are no gods that belong to the imperceptible level of “Neither Consciousness nor Non-consciousness.”[557]

byang gi phyogs su brgya byin lha'i rgyal po dang / rab 'thab bral dang / dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / 'od chung la sogs pa'i lha'i bu rnams lha'i rgyal po re re nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams ni ji ltar rnam par bzhag pa bzhin du phyag rgya rnams su mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du dkyil 'khor gsum par yang byang gi phyogs su 'byung po'i bdag po dbang ldan dka' thub zlog pa dang bcas pa nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / sgo gnyis pa'i nye logs su gzhon nu smin drug gi bu rma bya'i gdan la/ lag na mdung thung thogs pa/ lus dmar por snang ba/ gos ser po'i stod g.yogs bgos pa/ phyag g.yas na dril bu dang ba dan dmar po thogs pa/ gzhon nu'i gzugs can dkyil 'khor la nges par rtog bzhin pa'o/ / shar gyi phyogs su nam mkha' lding 'dab chags kyi gzugs can dang / drang srong mArkaN+Da nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnam par bzhag pa bzhin du phyag rgya rnams su yang ngo //lho shar du gzhon nu bzhi dang / gzhon nu ming po dang lhan cig pa gru'i bzhon pa la kun du gnas pa chu gter chen po la yongs su rgyu bar byed pa/ me lha'i rgyal po'ang nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ /

In the north, Śakra, the King of the Gods, and the Sons of the Gods of [the heavens of] Suyāma, Tuṣita, Sunirmitta, Paranirmita, Parittābha, Prabhṛtaya, etc., should be depicted one by one. Any remaining ones are to be drawn in [the form of] seals, according to sequence. Similarly, in the northern direction of the third maṇḍala, Īṣāna,[558] the Lord of Creatures, should be depicted together with Umā. Kārtikeya should be depicted near the second door, seated on a peacock, holding a small spear in [his left] hand, red-complexioned, possessing the form of a prince, clothed in an upper garment of yellow cloth, and holding a bell and red banner in his right hand. In the eastern direction, depict the sage Mārkaṇḍa in the form of Vainateya, a winged Garuḍa bird. The remaining ones should be established in [the form of] seals, according to arrangement. In the southeast, depict the four young sisters[559] together with their young brother, riding in a boat, traveling in the great ocean. Also, one should surely depict [Agni] the king of the fire deities.[560]

de bzhin du lho'i phyogs su lang ka'i grong gi srin po'i bdag po shin tu 'jigs su rung ba ste der shing pi tsu ma rda la brten nas gnas pa dang / rmugs 'dzin chu'i dbang po zhes bya ba gnod sbyin gyi gzugs can byang chub sems dpa' nges par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma phyag rgya rnams su'ang rnam par gzhag par bya'o/ / de bzhin du lho nub kyi phyogs su klu'i gtso bo dga' bo dang / nye dga' bo nges par bri bar bya ste/ gza'i gtso bo nyi ma yang ngo // nub kyi phyogs su thub pa ser skya zhes bya ba drang srong mchog dang / mu stegs can gcer bu pa'i khyu mchog /gcer bu'i gzugs su go rims bzhin du phyag rgya rnams su rnam par gzhag par bya'o/ / byang nub kyi phyogs su gnod sbyin gyi rgyal po nor sbyin dang / dri za'i rgyal po zur phud lnga pa dang / mi'am ci'i rgyal po ljon pa ste 'di rnams nges par bri bar bya'o/ / lhag ma ni dbyibs ji ltar kun du gnas pa bzhin du go rims bzhin phyag rgya rnams su'ang mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor bzhi mngon par bri'o zhes pa phyi rol gyi dkyil 'khor bzhi par ri mo lngas spras pa phyag rgya'i phreng bas mdzes par byas pa gru bzhi dang rta babs bzhi'i rnam pa dang / rgyal po chen po bzhis rnam par brgyan pa/ go rims ji lta ba bzhin du gnas pa 'di lta ste/ 'jug pa'i sgor phyag rgyar gyur pa ni ut+pa la sngon po bri'o/ / g.yas dang g.yon du ni pad+ma dang / rdo rje dang / dgra sta dang / dung dang / mdung rtse gsum dang / be con dang / 'khor lo dang / swa sti ka dang / bum pa dang / nya dang / dung dang / gdub kor dang / ril ba spyi blugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang / zhags pa dang / dril bu dang / gri dang / tho ba dang / gzhu dang / lcags mda' ste 'di rnams rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i mtshon cha'i mchog gi phyag rgyas khor yug tu grwa bzhir phreng bas khyab par bya'o/ /

In the southern direction, one should accordingly depict Vibhīṣana, the rākṣasa Lord of Lanka city,[561] leaning on the picumarda tree and bodhisattva Jambhalajalendra in the form of a yakṣa spirit. Similarly, according to arrangement, depict Yama, King of the Dead, as a hungry ghost endowed with magical powers. Also, depict the piśāca king Vikṣipanti. The remaining ones are to be drawn in [the form of] seals. In the southwestern direction the chiefs among snakes, Nanda and Upananda, should be depicted. Also, depict the sun, the foremost among the planets. In the west is the best of sages called Kapilamuni and the excellent “bull” among naked heretics, Nigranthatīrthakaraṛṣbha, who is naked. [The remaining ones][562] should be established in [the form of] seals. In the northwestern direction, Dhanada, king of the yakṣas, Pañcaśikha, king of gandharvas, and Druma, king of the kinnaras should be depicted. The rest should be depicted in [the form of] seals, according to dimension, placement, and arrangement. Draw the fourth maṇḍala in a square shape, bound by five [different colored] bands on the outside, decorated with a garland of seals, endowed with four archways, and adorned with the four great kings.[563] The following seals are to be placed in order and arranged accordingly: A blue utpala lotus is to be drawn in the entrance [to the maṇḍala]. To its right and left, the entire circumference [of the maṇḍala] should be covered with a square garland made of the seals of various kinds of excellent weapons, as follows: a red lotus, vajra, axe, [sword],[564] [lance],[565] trident, club, wheel, symbol of auspiciousness, flask, fish, conch, bracelet, pitcher, victory banner, flag, noose, bell, knife, hammer, bow, and iron arrow.

de nas phyi rol gyi phyogs bzhir phyag rgya chen po bzhi gzhag par bya ste/ byang phyogs su dkyil 'khor gru bzhi pa'i rnam pa can byas nas rdo rje gnyis ka nas rtse mo gsum pa'i rnam pa kun nas 'bar ba'o/ / shar phyogs su dkyil 'khor gru gsum pa'i rnam pa can kun nas 'bar ba can gzhag par bya'o/ / lho'i phyogs su dkyil 'khor gzhu'i rnam pa can byas nas lhung bzed kun nas 'bar ba can gzhag par bya'o/ / nub kyi phyogs su dkyil 'khor nyi ma'i rnam pa can byas nas ut+pa la sngon po rang gi sdong bu dang / 'dab ma dang ldan pa kun nas 'bar ba'o/ / phyogs bral rnams su phyag rgya bzhir 'gyur ro/ / nub byang gi phyogs su dkyil 'khor zlum po'i rnam pa byas nas zhags pa kun nas 'bar ba'o/ / lho nub kyi phyogs su dkyil 'khor ring po'i rnam pa byas nas dbyug pa kun nas 'bar ba'o/ / lho shar gyi phyogs su dkyil 'khor gru gsum pa'i rnam pa can byas nas dgra sta kun nas 'bar ba'o/ / byang shar gyi phyogs su ral gri kun nas 'bar ba gzhag par bya'o/ / thams cad nas mngon par bris nas steng dang 'og dang thad kar phyag rgya gsum phyi'i dkyil 'khor gyi sgo dang nye bar phye ma nyid kyis bri bar bya ba la 'di lta ste/ gos dang / bsil yab dang / lham kun nas 'bar ba de rnams mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / zhes so/ /
