Then, four great seals should be placed in the four cardinal directions outside [the maṇḍala]. In the north, make a square-shaped maṇḍala, endowed with two three-pronged vajras blazing all around. In the east, make a triangular-shaped maṇḍala with a red lotus blazing all around. In the south, make a crescent-shaped maṇḍala marked with a blazing alms bowl. In the west, make a solar-[shaped] maṇḍala marked with the petals and branches of a blue lotus, which are blazing all around. There are also four seals in the intermediate directions. In the northwest, make a circular-shaped maṇḍala with a blazing noose. In the southwest, make a crescent-shaped maṇḍala with a blazing staff. In the southeast, make a triangular-shaped maṇḍala with a blazing axe. In the northeast direction, place a blazing sword.[566] Having drawn [seals] in all [cardinal and intermediate] directions, as well as above, below, and straight to the horizon, one should use the same powdered [colors] to depict three seals near the door outside the maṇḍala. A garment of clothes, a fan, and a shoe which is entirely ablaze should be depicted.
byang chub sems dpa' blo ldan pas/ / sems can phan don 'dod pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor cho ga 'di rnams kyis/ / mdor bsdus 'dir ni bstan pa yin/ /
These rituals[567] of the maṇḍala Are explained here in brief By the intelligent bodhisattva Wishing to benefit sentient beings. [54]

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis dang po nyid du slob ma gzung bar bya ste/ dbang po ma tshang ba med pa dang yan lag thams cad mdzes pa'i bram ze dang / rgyal rigs dang / rje rigs dang / dmangs rigs byang chub tu sems bskyed pa theg pa chen po'i theg pa pa/ theg pa gzhan mi 'dod pa'i ngang tshul can gyi sems dpa' chen po dad cing dge ba'i chos can dang / rgyal srid chen po mngon par 'dod pa dang / longs spyod chung ba la smod pa dang / longs spyod chen po mngon par 'dod pa dang ldan pa dang / bzang zhing dul la tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i dge slong dang / dge slong ma dang / dge bsnyen dang / dge bsnyen ma sdom pa la gnas pa/ gso sbyong la nye bar gnas shing sdom pa la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' chen po la zhe mi sdang ba dang / phyogs chen po dang / rigs dang ldan pa dang / rang bzhin gyis chos spyod pa/ nyin dang mtshan du smyung bar gnas pa gos gtsang ma bgos pa/ skra dri zhim pa dang / khrus gsum byas pa/ mi smra bar gyur pa/ de'i nyin mo ga bur dang / gur gum dang / ma la ya'i tsan+dan dri zhim pos dri zhim par byas pa/ rtag tu nye reg byas pa dang ldan pa/ ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste/ bsrung ba'i cho ga byas pa dang / tshangs par spyod pa dang / bden pa dang ldan pa dang / rgyal bar dgongs pa phyi'i dkyil 'khor de nyid du ha cang yang mi nye ha cang yang mi ring bar gzhag par bya'o/ / gtsang zhing gtsang sbra byas pa ji srid gcig nas brgyad la sogs pa'i bar rnams te/ gzhan rnams ni ma yin no/ / de rnams kyang phan tshun kun du chags pa/ rgyal rigs spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur ba'i rgyal po chen po dang / de rnams kyi bu gzhon nu ma rnams grong pa'i chos ma shes pa ste bcom ldan 'das gzhon nu'i gzugs can byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'jam dpal byis pa'i skye bo rab tu sad par byed pa/ gzhon nu'i skye bo dga' bar byed pas so/ / de nas ches thog mar de lta bu'i grong pa'i chos mi shes pa rab tu gzhug par bya/ / rgyal po chen po mngon par 'phel ba dang / tshe dang nad med pa dang / dbang phyug dang longs spyod chen po mngon par 'phel ba dang / khyad par du'ang tshul khrims dang ldan pas rig pa'i dngos grub nges par gnas pa'i phyir ro/ /

Then, in the first place, the maṇḍala hierophant should acquire disciples who are [from the occupational groups of the] priests, nobility, common folk, or servants,[568] whose limbs are beautiful, whose faculties are not impaired, who generate the mind of enlightenment as travelers of the great vehicle and are not inclined toward longing for the Lesser Vehicle, who are heroic-minded, faithful, and possessed of the virtuous Dharma, who desire great sovereignty, disparage inferior pleasures,[569] and are endowed with a desire for great enjoyment, who are good-natured, disciplined, and moral, who are monks, nuns, laymen and laywomen abiding in their vows and maintaining their fasting vows, who are not inimical toward the great Bodhisattva, who are beneficial, of a good family,[570] and who practice Dharma naturally. [Candidates for initiation] are those who have fasted for a day and a night, donned clean clothes, made their hair fragrant, taken three baths, observed silence, made themselves fragrant with continual applications of the perfumes of camphor, saffron, and Malaya mountain sandalwood,[571] performed their protection rituals seated on kuśa grass mats, practiced celibacy, observed truthfulness, and reflected upon the Conqueror [Buddha]. [The maṇḍala hierophant] should situate [these candidates] neither too close nor too far outside the maṇḍala. [Candidates for initiation] who have maintained clean and pure [living habits] should number from one to eight, and no more. They are mutually acquainted nobles (kṣatriya) and great kings whose heads have been consecrated and whose offspring are boys and girls unfamiliar with the customs of rural culture. The Lord Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, who is youthful in form and awakens young people, makes youthful people rejoice![572] [179b-4] Therefore, such [young people] who do not know the customs of rural culture, should initially be installed [in the maṇḍala] in order to augment [the prosperity of] great kings, for long life, health, lordliness, and enjoyment, and especially for insuring the occult attainments (siddhi) of the vidyās for moral people.[573]

de ltar sngar bzhag pa byas nas grogs bzang po dang ldan pa'i slob dpon gyis ga pur gyi bdug pa bsregs te/ rgyab kyis phyogs pa min par phyi rol du 'byung bar bya ste/ byung nas kyang ji ltar bde ba'i chu shin tu gtsang sbra byas pa/ srog chags med pa/ rtsa ba'i rig pa brgyad brgya mngon par bzlas pa/ phyag rgya chen pos rgyas btab pa'i chus khrus byas nas/ nye reg byas te gos gtsang ma bgos pa'i gtsang mas/ me thab tu song nas/ ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste byang shar du mngon par phyogs pas ga bur dang gur gum tsan+dan dang bsres pa'i mar gyi sreg blugs stong phrag brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / sngar brjod pa'i cho gas spyan drangs pa dang / gshegs su gsol lo/ / slar yang dkyil 'khor du 'jug par bya'o/ / zhugs nas bum pa gang ba brgyad gtsang ma'i gos dang ldan pa shing sa ha ka ra'i yal 'dab dang 'bras bus rnam par brgyan pa gser dang dngul dang rin po che dang / 'bru nang du bcug pa/ de lta bu bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la so sor dbul bar bya'o/ / gnyis pa ni sangs rgyas thams cad la'o/ / gsum pa ni 'phags pa nyan thos kyi dge 'dun thams cad la'o/ / bzhi pa ni byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la'o/ / lnga pa ni byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la'o/ / drug pa ni lha thams cad la'o/ / bdun pa dang brgyad pa ni dkyil 'khor gnyis pa'i sgo khang du gzhag par bya ste/ gcig pa ni sems can thams cad dang thun mong du gyur bar yongs su bsngos nas gzhag par bya'o/ /

Having settled these matters in the same way, as before, the hierophant who possesses good companions should burn camphor incense and go outside [the maṇḍala] without turning his back [to it]. Having gone outside, he should clean a strip of cloth with water of the proper season,[574] bathe with water that lacks vermin, has been consecrated with the root vidyā eight hundred times, and impressed with the Great Seal, and rinse his mouth. Having become ritually pure and donned clean clothes, he should approach the fire hearth. Then, [the maṇḍala hierophant] should sit on a kuśa grass mat facing northeast and perform burnt offerings 8,000 times with an ablution of butter mixed with camphor, saffron, and sandalwood. Using the ritual previously expressed, he should invite the [wisdom being][575] and request it to depart. Furthermore, [the candidates] should be installed in the maṇḍala. Having entered, one should offer eight full vessels filled with gold, silver, precious jewels, fruit, and grain, shrouded in clean cloth, and decorated with the leafy and fruit-laden branches of sahakāra wood. Offer the first [vessel] to Lord Śākyamuni, the second to all Buddhas, the third to all communities of noble Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas, the fourth to all Bodhisattvas, the fifth to the great Bodhisattva Noble Avalokiteśvara, the sixth to all deities, and as for the seventh and eighth, which are to be placed in the entry porch of the second maṇḍala, the first is for all spirits and the second is consigned to all ordinary [spirits][576] and to all sentient beings.

de nas sngar brjod pa'i cho ga nyid kyis bdug pa bsreg cing ut+pa la'i phyag rgya bcings nas slar yang spyan drang bar bya ste/ sangs rgyas thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams dang / 'byung po thams cad dang / spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug kyang sngar brjod pa'i cho ga nyid kyis spyan drang bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du me tog dang / bdug pa dang / dri dang / mar me dang / lha bshos kyang sngar bstan pa nyid kyi las kyis lha bshos thams cad kyis thams cad du go rims bzhin du bya'o/ / mar me smos pa nyid kyis mar gyi mar me dbul bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pa thams cad la lha bshos smos pas/ sA lu'i zan zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang ldan pa/ 'o thug khyad par can gyis nye bar sbyar ba'i mar la btsos pa'i snum khur gyis mya ngan med pa 'khyil ba dang / khaN+Da la sogs pa thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la dbul bar bya'o/ / phyi rol gang ba dang / tsan+dan gyi thang chu sbrang rtsi dang 'o ma/ 'o thug btsos pa'i bza' ba rnams rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang / 'phags pa'i lha rnams la me tog dri zhim po rnams kyang dbul bar bya'o/ / la du can dang / gar+b+hat+k+wA khyad par dang / sngar gyi yo byad rnams lha thams cad dang / 'byung po'i tshogs dang / sems can thams cad la dbul bar bya'o/ /

After that, using the same ritual previously expressed, having burned incense and tied the blue lotus seal, one should perform the invocation again. All Buddhas, all Pratyekabuddhas, noble Śrāvakas, great Bodhisattvas, all sentient beings, all spirits, and Avalokiteśvara as well should be invoked with the same ritual previously expressed. In this way, having made offerings with flowers, incense, perfume, lamps, and offering cakes (gtor ma), using the activities previously expressed, every [ritual activity] should be carried out orderly. With the same lamps mentioned, one should offer butter lamps. Saying “an offering cake for all noble and non-noble ones” means that one should offer the Tathāgatas rich cake cooked in butter, prepared with excellent rice pudding made with thickly cooked rice, yogurt, and honey.[577] One should also offer sweet-smelling flowers and cooked foods, such as rice pudding full of clarified butter,[578] sandalwood gum, honey, and milk to all Pratyekabuddhas, Noble Śrāvakas, Great Bodhisattvas, and noble deities. Using a ritual with mantras, one should offer sweet pastry and such foods mentioned above to all the gods, groups of spirits, and all sentient beings.

de bzhin du sna ma dang / rgya spos kyi me tog dang / pun+nA ga la sogs pa rnams sngar nges par bstan pa/ sangs rgyas dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams dang / 'phags pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pa'i lha rnams thams cad la dbul bar bya'o/ / khyad par du de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la sna ma'i me tog dang / pad+ma'i rigs la pad+ma dang / de bzhin du phyag na rdo rje'i rigs la ut+pa la dang / gzhan rnams la tha mal pa'i sngags kyis so/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs la ga pur gyi bdug pa'o/ / pad+ma'i rigs la tsan+dan no/ / de bzhin du gsang ba'i bdag po rdo rje can nyid kyi gu gul du shes par bya'o/ / sngags gzhan thams cad la bdug pa tha mal pa dbul bar bya'o/ /

Similarly, offer the fragrant flowers formerly designated, such as jasmine, nāgara, and punnāga, etc., to the Buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, noble śrāvakas, great bodhisattvas, and all noble and ignoble deities. In particular, use jasmine flowers for the Tathāgata family, red lotuses for the Lotus family, blue lotuses for Vajrapāṇi’s family, and ordinary[579] [flowers] to the other [deities of the] mantras. One should know that camphor incense is for the Tathāgata family, sandalwood is for the lotus family, and similarly, a black resin[580] is for [the family of] Vajrapāṇi, Lord of the secret ones. One should offer ordinary incense to all other [deities of the][581] mantras.
'phags pa rnams ni thams cad la/ / mar gyi mar me dbul bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa min pa'i sngags rnams la/ / dri zhim til mar dbul du gzhug /
One should offer butter lamps[582] To all noble ones (ārya), Engage in offering fragrant sesame oil To the [gods][583] of the non-nobles (anārya). [55]
cho ga'i go rims bzhin du ni/ / bdug pa mthong ba'i rgyu yis so/ / de bzhin kho nar brjod pa'i dri/ / sngags rnams kun la rtag par de'o/ /
According to the stages of the ritual, There is an incense with a perceived cause. Only use that fragrance that has been designated at all times and for all mantras. [56]
de bzhin gshegs la gang brjod dang // phyag na rdo rjer gang brjod pa/ / rang rang gi ni rgyud rnams su/ /
Whatever has been expressed for the Tathāgata,[584] And whatever has been expressed for Vajrapāṇi Are in their own respective tantras.[585] [57]
sngags spyod don du sgrub pa pos/ / 'dir ni cho ga blta bar bya/ / kun nas rjes su 'jug pa'o/ / zhes pa'o/ /
In order to practice the mantras, The practitioner should observe and Fully comply with the ritual in this [text]. [58]

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon sngar cho ga mthong bas spyan drang ba dang / mchod pa dang / bdug pa la sogs pa dang / lha bshos rab tu dbul ba rjes su 'jug pa'i bya ba byas nas/ de'i 'og tu sgrub pa'i grogs mchog mkhas shing skyen pas/ 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma sha med pa thams cad dang / rnga pa Ta ha dang / dung gi sgra'i sgra dbyangs nges par sgrogs pas/ bdug pa dang / me tog dang / mar me dang / phreng bas rnam par spras pa phyogs bzhi rnams dang / phyogs bral rnams dang steng dang 'og dang thad ka thams cad du phyi'i dkyil 'khor la bskor ba byas nas 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma rgya cher gtang bar bya'o/ / de nas khrus byas nas slar yang zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pa'i 'bras sA lu dang / thug po che'i sbyin sreg rtsa ba'i rig pa'am snying pos stong phrag brgyad bya'o/ / sbyin sreg byas nas kyang sngar bkod pa'i dkyil 'khor la rjes su zhugs pa'i sems dpa' chen po la srung ba'i cho ga rnams byas pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis slob ma nyid du khas blangs pa/ byang chub tu sems bskyed pa/ gso sbyong byas pa/ sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la bdag nyid kyi lus dngos grub kyi don du phul ba/ sems can thams cad kyi nye bar longs spyod pa thun mong par gyur pa bla na med pa'i byang chub kyi snying po gnon par byed pa/ dge ba rnams thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi sangs rgyas thob par 'dod pa rnams la dkyil 'khor bstan pa nyid las sdig pa thams cad las grol bar 'gyur te/ mtshams med pa byed pa'i skye bo rnams kyang skad cig de la grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

After that, the maṇḍala expert who has previously seen the ritual should perform the following activities: the invocation, worship, burning of incense, and the presentation of food offerings to the gods. Then, the supremely skillful and swift assistant, having resounded the harmonious tones of the pataha drum and conch, [should take] the meatless sacrificial food offerings for all living beings, which are decorated with incense, flowers, lamps, and garlands, circumambulate the outside of the maṇḍala, and scatter the sacrificial cakes for all living beings widely in the four cardinal directions, the intermediate directions, above, below, and straight to the horizon. Having bathed, one should perform the burnt offering ritual once again 8,000 times with thick rice mixed with yogurt, honey, and butter, while employing the root vidyā or essence-incantation. Having performed the burnt offerings for the great [beings] installed in the maṇḍala previously established, those who’ve been accepted for instruction by the maṇḍala hierophant will be freed from all transgressions by merely looking at the maṇḍala. [There will be freedom from all transgressions] for those whose protection rituals have been performed, who have generated the thought of enlightenment, who have performed a fasting reparation, who have offered their own bodies to all Buddhas and bodhisattvas for the sake of success, who share enjoyment with all sentient beings, and for virtuous ones who mount the seat of unsurpassable enlightenment and desire to attain omniscient Buddha knowledge. Even for those people who have committed [any of the five] sins of immediate retribution,[586] there will be instantaneous liberation.

de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis gos mnyams pa tha ga pas btags ma thag pa/ skra dang bral ba/ rtsa ba'i rig pas lan bdun mngon par bsngags pa/ dri zhim po'i tsan+dan dang / gur gum gyis bsgos pa'i dar gyis dkyil 'khor du 'jug par 'dod pa rnams gdong g.yogs nas thog ma nas bcom ldan 'das ma sgrub pa pos rab tu 'jug par bya'o/ / rgyal po'i bu spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba'am/ rgyal rigs kyi bu'am/ gzhan yang spro ba chen po rgyal srid chen po 'dod pa'ang rab tu gzhug par bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor gnyis par gnas pa gdong g.yogs nas dri bzang po'i me tog tsan+dan dang gur gum dag gis rnam par bsres pa byin te/ shin tu gtsang sbra byas pa'i lag pa dag gis me tog 'thor du gzhug par bya'o/ / gang du de'i me tog babs pa de la de'i rig pa'i sngags sbyin par bya'o/ / skye ba gzhan rnams su de nyid dang 'di rjes su 'brel pa'o zhes kun du grags pa yin zhing / de nyid 'di'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang byang chub kyi snying po gnon par byed pa dang / byang chub chen po thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'i don du mngon par sgrub par byed pa'o/ / de nyid 'di'i bsgrub par bya ba dang / longs spyod chen po dang / rgyal srid chen po dang / dbang che bar grags pa'i gang zag dang / 'grogs pa 'di'i mngon par sgrub par byed pa'o/ / skye ba 'di nyid du/ sgrub pa gang dang ldan pa lhag par spyod pa las/ las rnams thams cad 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du rim gyis de lta bu la sogs pa ji srid du brgyad po rnams de srid de gzhan rnams ni ma yin no/ / zhes so/ / sgrub par 'dod pa gzhan yang ci ltar 'dod pa bzhin du sdig pa zad pa'i don du dam tshig tsam du 'gyur zhes pa'o/ /

Then, the maṇḍala hierophant who has veiled the faces of those desiring to enter the maṇḍala with a flawless silk cloth that has just been woven by a weaver, is free from hair, consecrated seven times with the root vidyā, and anointed with sweet-smelling sandalwood and saffron, should initially install [the candidates who are] practitioners of the Blessed [Tārā]. He should install either a king’s son whose head has been consecrated, or the son of the warrior class, or moreover, one who desires a great kingdom of great delight. Having covered the faces of those situated in the second maṇḍala and having given [each of] them a fragrant flower mixed with sandalwood and saffron, the maṇḍala hierophant should have them scatter their flowers with two clean hands. On the place where one’s flower has fallen [in the maṇḍala], that [wisdom being’s] vidyā should be given [to the initiation candidate].[587] [This is declared as one’s own mantra.][588] From life to life, one is bound to that [wisdom being]. That [wisdom being] is one’s virtuous friend, causing one to mount the seat of enlightenment, to accomplish the aim of bringing to fulfillment the omniscient wisdom of great enlightenment, and to bring about [one’s] great enjoyment, great sovereignty, and association with distinguished people. Due to one’s high resolve for full success in this very life, one shall accomplish all the rituals. Thus, in due order, there should be up to eight [candidates accepted for initiation] and no more. For the others who have a desire for occult attainments (siddhi),[589] according to their desires, it is said that there is a pledge just for the purpose of destroying sins.[590]

dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis mngon par dbang bskur ba sbyin na dang po re zhig dkyil 'khor gyi phyi rol ha cang mi ring / ha cang mi nye ba'i byang shar gyi phyogs kyi cha'i sa phyogs rtsa ba'i sngags kyis byin gyis brlabs shing sngags kyis dag par byas nas de nas rgyal po mngon par dbang bskur ba de bzhin du sems bzhin pas mtha' gcig tu sangs rgyas dang / chos dang / dge 'dun la mngon par dang ba'i dad pa dang / spro ba chen po dang ldan pa byang chub kyi sems dang ma bral ba/ theg pa chen po la zhugs pa/ dkon mchog gsum la bsnyen bkur byed pa/ dbang po ma tshang ba med cing ma smad pa/ skye ba 'di nyid la rig pa dang / sngags sgrub par 'dod pa/ bsam pa bzang zhing / sngags kyi spyod pa la spro ba'i yid dang ldan pa/ dge mtshan 'dod pa'i rang bzhin can/ sad pa'i rgyur yang rig pa'i don la rnam rtog med cing der gtad pa'i yid can de lta bu la sogs pa lnga ji srid par mngon par dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / lhag ma rnams spang bar bya'o zhes so/ / shes rab can dang spyod pa la ma rmongs pa'i khyad par las te/ gzhan rnams bsten par bya ba ma yin no/ / de nas rgyal po thams cad dbang bskur ba bzhin du yo byad thams cad bsags te/ slob dpon dang mkhan po mnyes par bya'o/ / de nas bla re bres te rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang gdugs dkar po mgo bor 'dzin bzhin pa dang / rnga yab dkar po g.yob bzhin pa dang / bkur sti chen pos dung dang / rnga bo che dang / rdza rnga'i dga' ba'i sgra nges par sgrogs pa dang / rgyal ba'i sgra dang / bkra shis kyi tshigs su bcad pas mngon par bsngags pa dang / bde legs kyi tshigs su bcad pa rgyal bas gsungs pa rnams kyis mngon par bstod bzhin pas bskor ba dang / bkra shis de byas nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag byas nas/ 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / slob dpon sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi sngags kyi spyod pa mngon par bsgrub pa la yang dag par rjes su 'jug pa dang / 'jig rten pa thams cad las 'das pa'i gsang chen rnam par thar pa'i dkyil 'khor du yang dag par rjes su 'jug pa dang / chos kyi rgyal srid thams cad kyis sangs rgyas nyid mngon par rtogs par 'dod pa dang / mdor bsdus nas brjod nas sangs rgyas nyid 'byung ba'i phyir bdag nyid spro bar bgyi'o zhes so/ /

When the maṇḍala hierophant bestows initiation, first of all, that spot of earth in the northeast direction, neither too far nor too close outside the maṇḍala should be purified with a mantra and empowered with the root mantra.[591] Then, up to five [candidates] should be initiated who imagine themselves to be taking part in a royal initiation,[592] who possess great enthusiasm and absolutely sincere faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and the Sangha, who are not separated from the thought of Enlightenment, who have entered into the Great Vehicle, who revere the Three Jewels, who have unimpaired and faultless senses, who desire to accomplish mantras and vidyās in this very life, who possess good intentions and enthusiasm toward the practice of mantras, who naturally desire virtuous marks, who lack false views about the aim of the vidyās and the cause of awakening, and whose minds are fixed on that. The remaining [candidates] are excluded. Apart from those who are distinguished in insight and unerring practice, others are not to be served. After that, having collected all the necessities for the initiation of all kings, the skillful hierophant should be satisfied [with the candidates]. Having spread out the canopy hung with victory banners, pendants, and a white umbrella at the top, [the candidates] should circumambulate [the maṇḍala][593] while waving a white yak tail and praising it respectfully with the joyfully sounding tones of the conch, great drum, and kettle drum, with words of victory,[594] with auspicious verses, and with verses of praise and blessing spoken by the Conquerors. Having blessed that [maṇḍala], made salutations to all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas [and bowed down to one’s teacher,][595] one should say the following, in brief. “O hierophant, I am enthusiastic to engage in the successful performance of all the Buddhas’ and bodhisattvas’ mantra practices, to enter into the maṇḍala of very secret liberation transcending the mundane [world], and wish that all dharmic kingdoms realize Buddhahood. In short, [I am enthusiastic] to become enlightened.”[596]

de nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste shar du mngon par phyogs pas dkyil 'khor mthong zhing rtogs pa la dang po re zhig rig pa'i mngon par dbang bskur ba byin nas phyag rgya chen po rtsa ba'i rig pa bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas rig pa dang / sngags dag gang gnas pa/ gro ga'i 'dab ma la gi wang gis bri bar bya'o/ / bris nas tsan+dan dang gur gum dag gis lag pa dag dang kham phor kha sbyar bkrus nas de nas gro ga'i 'dab ma kham phor kha sbyar gyi nang du bzhag par byas nas dkyil 'khor gyi nang du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi zhabs kyi drung du gzhag par bya'o/ / de nas der nye bar 'dug ste rig pa rtsa ba'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad snga ma nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / de nas der ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug pa mngon par dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / phyi rol gyi dkyil 'khor du thams cad dang thun mong du gyur pa'i bum pa gang ba sgo dang nye bar sngar bzhag pa blangs nas slob dpon gyis rtsa ba'i rig pa bzlas shing spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / slob ma ji ltar 'dod pa'i chus spyi bo nas mngon par dbang bskur bar bya'o zhes so/ / de nas de la kham phor kha sbyar de de'i ched du sbyin par bya'o/ / mar me la klog tu gzhug par bya'o/ / gal te des bcom ldan 'das rig pa'am sngags bzung ba nyid yin par gyur na bklags pa nyid las kyang las byed do/ / rnam pa gzhan du na rim gyis 'bad pas bsgrubs pas byed par 'gyur ro/ / gzhan rnams ni sngags bzlas pa kho nas 'grub par byed do/ / de nas sngags yongs su gzung bar 'gyur ro/ / dang po sgrub pa kho nas 'grub par byed do/ / zhes pa rnam par rtog pa med pa las so/ / de kho na sngar bris pa slob dpon gyi sgrub pa gsum gyis nges par 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / 'bad pa med par ro/ / de bzhin du thog mar rig pa'i mngon par dbang bskur ba sbyin par bya'o/ /

Then, having become seated on a kuśa grass mat, facing east, [the candidate] who views the maṇḍala and comprehends it, should first be given the vidyā initiation, and then be made to [tie][597] the Great Seal and recite the root vidyā. Then, using yellow pigment, one should write one’s own designated vidyā and mantra on a white birch bark leaf. Having written it and rubbed both hands and the lidded vessel with sandalwood and saffron, one should place the white birch bark leaf inside the lidded vessel and set it down inside the maṇḍala before the feet of the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara. Having become seated near that place, the mantra of the root vidyā should be recited eight hundred times as before. Then, while sitting on the kuśa grass mat, one is to be initiated. Outside the maṇḍala, having taken the full vessel for ordinary [spirits] and all [sentient beings],[598] which was previously placed near the [maṇḍala’s] entrance, the hierophant is to initiate [the candidate’s] head [with the water in this vessel], and recite the root vidyā. The heads of the [remaining][599] disciples are to be initiated with whatever water is desired. Then, the lidded clay vessel is to be given to that [disciple] for that purpose [of initiation]. [The disciple] should be made to read [the vidyā written on birch bark] by the lamplight. If that [disciple] comprehends[600] the vidyā or mantra from the Bhagavān merely by reading it, the ritual is performed. If, on the other hand, [one does not immediately comprehend it,] gradually, through effort one will succeed. Others will succeed merely by reciting the mantra and then will fully comprehend it. By saying, “one will be successful with only the first application [of the vidyā,]” means that this is because [the student] has no thought constructions. That which was formerly written by the hierophant[601] will surely succeed with three applications, even without effort.[602] In this way, one should initially bestow the vidyā initiation.

dkyil 'khor gnyis par mngon par dbang bskur ba ni/ dkyil 'khor gnyis par/ dkyil 'khor thams cad la dang / lha thams cad la gang rab tu bstabs pa'i bum pa gang ba des snga ma'i cho ga gang yin pa ji lta ba de nyid kyis spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur bar byas na sdig pa thams cad las grol bar 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis rjes su gnang bar 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi dam tshig dang / dkyil 'khor dang / sngags dang / phyag rgya sgrub pa la yang lhag par 'dod par 'gyur ro/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis slob dpon du mngon par dbang bskur ba sbyin no/ /

As for the initiation into the second maṇḍala, using the same ritual as before, one whose head has been consecrated with the full vessel dedicated to all deities[603] in the second maṇḍala will be liberated from all sins[604] and granted permission by all the Buddhas. One will also be instructed in the practice of all mundane and supramundane pledges, maṇḍalas, mantras, and seals. One [should imagine that] the hierophant’s initiation is given by all [higher] bodhisattvas.[605]

dkyil 'khor gsum par nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad la phul ba'i bum pa gang ba cho ga de nyid kyis spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / khyod la sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pa thams cad kyis 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa thams cad kyi rig pa'i sngags rnams dang / dkyil 'khor 'dri ba dang / nye bar ston pa dang / rgyud dang rgyud kyi phyag rgya dang spyad pa nges par ston pa dang / rang gi cho ga nges par ston par rjes su gnang ngo zhes brjod par bya'o/ / skye ba 'di nyid dam gang phyi ma gzhan dang gzhan rnams su sangs rgyas nyid nges par thob bo/ / de bzhin du rgyal ba dang rnam par rgyal ba'i mngon par dbang bskur ba dang sngar nges par bstan pa'i cho gas bcom ldan 'das la sngar phul ba'i bum pa gang ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' la phul ba'i bum pa gang bas de bzhin du kho nar mngon par dbang bskur ro/ / de bzhin du yang khyod la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams dang / nyan thos rnams kyis 'byung po thams cad kyis mi tshugs pa dang / lus can thams cad kyis mi thub cing rnam par rgyal ba dang / khyod sngags rnams thams cad ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du sgrubs shig ces rjes su gnang ngo zhes brjod par bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis sems can lnga po nyid re re la ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du mngon par dbang bskur pa sbyin par bya'o/ / de nas de dag rim gyis dkyil 'khor du bcug nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phul te/ dkyil 'khor la bskor ba lan gsum byas nas gshegs su gsol bar bya'o/ / de nas nyi ma gzhan la rim gyis rig pa dang gsang sngags kyi spyod pa rnams la bslab par bya zhing / rnam par sbyar bar bya'o/ /

In the third maṇḍala, one’s head should be initiated with the full vessel offered to all Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas, using the same ritual. [The hierophant] should say, “May all Buddhas and bodhisattvas who possess supernormal powers permit you to teach all the mundane and supramundane vidyās and mantras, the rules for drawing the maṇḍala, tantric seals, and tantric practices, and to teach your own rituals. Whether in this lifetime, in the next life, or in whatever other subsequent birth, may you surely attain Buddhahood!” In the same way, using the same ritual previously demonstrated in the two “Victory” initiations,[606] one should be initiated only with the [water in] the flask formerly consigned to the Bhagavān [Śākyamuni] and the [water in] the full flask offered to the Bodhisattvas. Similarly, [the hierophant] should say, “May you be permitted by the Buddha Lords, the Great Bodhisattvas, and Śrāvakas, [may you be] protected from assault by spirits, [may you be] invincible and victorious over all living beings, and may you accomplish whatever you wish with every mantra.” Then, the maṇḍala hierophant should respectively bestow five initiations to the five sentient beings, as they wish. After they have been sequentially introduced into the maṇḍala, have made an offering to the Buddha and all bodhisattvas, and circumambulated the maṇḍala three times, they should be excused. On another day, gradually, they are to be instructed in the practices of the vidyās and mantras and practice them.

skad cig de nyid la song nas sngar brten par phul ba/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po la sngar phul ba'i chu bum pa gang ba blangs nas/ dkyil 'khor du zhugs pa de rnams la chu khyor ba gsum shar du mngon par phyogs par byas nas 'thung du gzhug par bya'o/ / 'di skad brjod par bya ste/ kye byang chub sems dpa' chen po gsang ba'i dam tshig gang gis 'da' bar byed pa bsod nams ma yin pa mang po skye bar 'gyur ro/ / dkyil 'khor gang du'am/ der yang rigs dman pa gang gis dkyil 'khor du 'ongs pa de rnams kyang dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis snying rje chen po'i sems bskyed nas grogs byed pa'i lag par gos dkar po gtsang ma mgo bor bcings pa gzhan gyis sam gos kun du g.yogs te gnas pa dam tshig gi phyag rgya bcings nas rigs dman pa rnams kyis me tog gtor bar bya'o/ / de nas grogs byed pa de rnams kyis kyang / rab tu zhugs pa'i sems can thams cad kyis khrus bya'o/ / de rnams kyis yang dam tshig tsam de 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / sgrub pa yang grub par 'gyur ro/ / de sngar byas pa'i me'i bya ba'i gnas su song nas rtse mo ma nyams pa'i ku sha rnams kyis so/ / der yang me thab rnam pa gsum du brjod do/ / zhi ba dang / rgyas pa dang / mngon spyod do/ / zhi ba'i don du pad ma'i rnam pa'o/ / yang na tshim par byed pas dbang du byed pa'ang ngo //mngon spyod la zur gsum mo/ /

In that instant, having come and made a firm offering, [the hierophant] should take the full flask of water previously offered to the great Bodhisattva [Avalokiteśvara], and have those [disciples] who have entered the maṇḍala drink three handfuls of water [from the flask] while facing the eastern direction. Then he should address them accordingly: “Whoever violates the great bodhisattva’s secret pledge will generate numerous unmeritorious [results].”[607] Those from a lower family who have come to that maṇḍala, or any maṇḍala, should generate the thought of great compassion along with the maṇḍala hierophant. The pure white cloth in the assistant’s hand should be bound on their heads or they should be covered by another with the cloth. Having tied the designated seal of the established pledge, those from the lower families should scatter flowers. Those assistants and all sentient beings who’ve entered [the maṇḍala] should bathe. Even they will obtain the vow. Their practices will also be successful. When one has come to the place for making a fire, as was done previously, use kuśa grass with unbroken tips [for the following rituals]. Here, the three types of hearths for pacifying, prosperity, and fierce [rituals] shall be enumerated. The lotus-type [hearth] is for pacifying [the deity]. Make a crescent-shaped hearth to subjugate. The triangular [hearth] is for fierce rituals.

de la me'i bya ba'i cho ga thams cad la ku sha dgram par 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag bya ba byas nas shar gyi rtse mor me'i bya ba gzhag par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phyi nas me'i bya ba mdzad pa rnams la phyag byas nas lho'i rtse mor ro/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag byas nas/ byang gi rtse mor sbyin par bya'o/ / de bzhin du'ang bya ba rnams grogs byed pas gnas pa'i ngang tshul can gyis me'i bya ba ku sha rnams kyis so/ / thog mar rtsa ba'i rig pas so/ / thog mar zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar la btags pa'i 'bras yos kyi sbyin sreg nyi shu rtsa gcig sbyin par bya'o/ / zhi ba'i don du snying po'i mar gyis so/ / rgyas pa'i don du shing a pA marga gsum gyi sbyin sreg go/ / mngon spyod la ka Ta ke yis so/ / me'i bya ba'i cho ga 'di'ang thams cad du thun mong ba'i sgrub pa rnams la yang ngo //dkyil 'khor thams cad kyi nye bar spyod pa rnams su'ang ngo //de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis gnas gtsang ma'i gtso bo'i lha nyid bstan nas/ me'i cho ga'i bya ba byas te 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor thams cad du rab tu zhugs pa rnams la/ de nas rtsa ba'i rig pa bzlas pas mchod yon no/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams dang / gzhan yang rdzu 'phrul chen po'i lha'i khyad par rnams dang / bcom ldan 'das kyi nyan thos rnams kyang gsan du gsol/ gang dam tshig gi dkyil 'khor 'dir cho ga las 'das par yang rung ste/ gus par byed pa dang / gzhan yang gang cung zad bdag nyid nyams par bya ba de dag dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis dkyil 'khor thams cad rab tu gnas pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi spyod yul dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi spyod yul dang ma bral bar thob par gyur cig /myur du bde ba dang ldan pa thob par gyur cig /de skad ces brjod par bya'o/ /

In that [hearth], spread kuśa grass for all fire-making rituals. Having made salutations to all Buddhas, one should have a fire made in the eastern point [of the hearth]. In the southern point, behind the Bodhisattva Great Being, make salutations to the makers of the fire [ritual]. Having made salutations to all bodhisattvas, make an offering in the northern point. In this way, those duties [are to be performed] by the good-natured assistant, using kuśa grass to make a fire. At the beginning [of the ritual], use the root vidyā. Twenty-one burnt offerings of parched rice, mixed with yogurt, honey, and butter should be presented. Use the essence-incantation and butter for appeasing [rituals]. A burnt offering of three apāmārga sticks is used for the purpose of prosperity [rituals]. Straw (kaṭake)[608] is used for fierce [rituals]. This fire-making ritual also occurs in ordinary evocation rituals and in the practices of all maṇḍalas. After that, the maṇḍala hierophant should comment upon the chief deities from the Pure Abodes, perform the ritual of the fire ritual, and express these words, “Those who’ve entered into all the maṇḍalas and have recited the root vidyā, should make an offering. May the Buddha Lords, bodhisattvas, and moreover, the distinguished ones among the gods endowed with supernormal powers and Lord [Śākyamuni’s] Śrāvakas, please listen! It is [not][609] proper that anyone violate the ritual of the pledge in this maṇḍala! Be respectful! Moreover, may those who have minor handicaps,[610] by means of this root of virtue, remain in all maṇḍalas, and attain inseparability from the sphere of activity of all Tathāgatas and the sphere of activity of all bodhisattvas. May they also quickly possess happiness.”

dkyil 'khor du rab tu zhugs pa'i sems can rnams thams cad la/ mdor na byang chub kyi sems dang mi 'bral bar 'gyur bar bya'o/ / sbyinapa la rab tu chags pa dang / byams pa la sogs pa la gnas pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mchod pa dang / mdor na lung dang rig pa dang gsang sngags sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpas gsungs pa rnams blta bar bya/ byang chub kyi sems dang mi 'bral bar 'gyur bar bya'o zhes brjod par bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis byang chub sems dpa' la sogs pa de rnams thams cad la dri bzang po'i me tog gis mchod yon phul nas sam de nas yid kyis mchod yon phul nas rtsa ba'i rig pa bzlas pas gats+tsha gats+tsha zhes pa dang / swA hA zhes pa kho na bzlas pas phyogs bzhir rnam par bltas te/ bcom ldan 'das ma'i rtsa ba'i phyag rgya bcings nas gyen du nges par bltas pas gshegs su gsol bar bya'o/ / zhes pa'o/ /

And he should also say to all sentient beings who’ve entered into the maṇḍala, “In brief, do not become separated from the thought of enlightenment! One should be fond of giving, abide in love, etc.,[611] worship all the Buddha and bodhisattvas, and, in brief, observe the precepts, vidyās, and mantras that are spoken by the Buddhas and bodhisattvas. Do not become separated from the thought of enlightenment.” Then the maṇḍala hierophant who has consigned an offering of fragrant flowers to all the bodhisattvas, etc., or has consigned a mental offering, should also recite the root vidyā, look in the four directions while merely reciting “gaccha, gaccha” and “svāhā,” tie the basic seal of the Blessed [Tārā], look up, and entreat [the wisdom beings] to depart.
byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i cho ga las/ dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga rab 'byam gyi le'u ste gnyis pa rdzogs so// //
This completes the second chapter of the Extensive Ritual of the Maṇḍala from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka and The Fundamental Ritual [Text] of the Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[sgrub thabs kyi cho ga dang dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga rab 'byam]
Chapter A.3: The Extensive Ritual of the Maṇḍala and the Ritual of Sādhana

de nas sems dpa' chen po de slar yang thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor la rnam par gzigs nas lha'i bu rnams thams cad la smras par gyur te/ khyed rnams nyon cig /mchog gi grub pa mchog tu gsang ba sgrub thabs thams cad kyi cho ga rig pa'i las thams cad byed pa dang / rig pa'i las bzang po byed pa/ chen po nyid dang / don chen po byed pa/ phung khrol thams cad zlog par byed pa/ don thams cad sgrub par byed pa/ mchog tu bkra shis pa thams cad kun nas bkra shis pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis gsungs pa/ bdag gi mchog tu gsang ba'i snying po yang dag par gyur pa/ las phran tshegs thams cad la nye bar sbyar bar bya ba/ rig pa'i rgyal mo chen mo'i las chen po thams cad kyi dngos grub byed pa'i sgrol ma gang zhe na/

Then, that Great Being beheld the entire circle of the assembly, and spoke to all the Sons of the Gods, “Please listen!” [The essence incantation] of Noble Tārā, Queen of Mahāvidyās, makes all great rituals succeed. It is supremely successful! It is the best secret! It performs all activities of the vidyās and the rituals of all sādhanas! It performs the beneficial rituals of the vidyās, promotes greatness and tremendous welfare, reverses all that is profitless, accomplishes all that is purposeful, and [makes] all that is very inauspicious wholly auspicious! [This vidyā, which] has been spoken by all the Buddhas, has become my most secret essence incantation. It should even be used for all minor rituals. What is it?
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / tāre tuttāre ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels! Homage to Noble Avalokiteśvara, the Bodhisattva, Great Being, and Supremely Compassionate one! O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the quick one, hail!

grogs po dag 'di ni 'phags ma sgrol ma las chen po thams cad byed pa las phran tshegs thams cad bklags pas grub pa/ mchog tu gsang ba shin tu gsang ba mchog tu grub pa gzhan gyis rab tu sbyar ba'i las thams cad 'jig par byed pa'i rig pa 'di 'ang dkyil 'khor gnyis pa'i cho ga dang / sgrub thabs su gyur te/ 'phags ma sgrol mas las chen po thams cad mdor bsdus pa dang / las phran tshegs thams cad la'ang nye bar sbyar bar bya zhing / dkyil 'khor thams cad kyi cho ga dang sgrub thabs rnams la'ang ngo //nyin mtshan gang du 'am der yang rung ste/ gtsang ma'i phyogs su bri bar bya'o/ / bdag nyid nyes pa med pa dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis gcig pus dang po re zhig gru bzhi mnyam pa sgo bzhi pa khru bzhi'i tshad dang ldan pa'i dbus pad+ma'i phyag rgya de'i g.yas su ut+pa la sngon po dang / dbyug pa'i phyag rgya dang / ril ba spyi blugs kyi phyag rgya g.yon du rdo rje rtse gsum gyi phyag rgya dang / gos dkar mo'i phyag rgya dang / rta mgrin dang dpal chen po'i phyag rgya'o/ / shar sgor pad ma/ byang du ut+pa la/ lho ru rdo rje/ nub tu 'jug pa'i rim pa las 'das par/ steng du 'khyil ba'i rnam pa'i zhags pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / de'i 'og tu phyi nas me'i bya ba byas nas sngar brjod pa'i cho gas mchod pa la sogs pa byas te/ dkyil 'khor du 'jug par bya'o/ / de la rgyal srid 'dod pas had+p+ya'i shing du'o/ / longs spyod 'dod pas rang gi khyim gyi lha'o/ / rta 'dod pas rta'i bres su'o/ / glang po che 'dod pas glang po che'i bres su'o/ / bu 'dod pas bo de tse'i shing gi drung du'o/ / tshangs pa'i srin pos zin pa la tshangs pas bskyangs pa ru'o/ / klus zin pa la klu shing dang nye ba ru'o/ / mkha' 'gro mas zin pa la lam bzhi mdo ru'o/ / gnod sbyin gyis zin pa la pa Ta'i shing gi drung du'o/ / srul pos zin pa la khron pa'i drung du'o/ / gzhan rnams kyang ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du gang du'ang / de ru yang nyes pa med do/ / grogs po dag mdor bsdu na/ rig pa 'di ni dkyil 'khor dang / las thams cad pa ste/ las thams cad la rab tu sbyar bar bya'o/ / gsang chen 'di dang lhan cig rab tu sbyar bar bya ste dkyil 'khor 'di ni sems can rnams la phan par 'dod pa'i 'bras bu yod pa'o/ / longs spyod thams cad mngon par 'phel bar byed pa sgrol ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi rig pa sgrub pa po rnams la phan pa'i don gyi phyir 'byor pa thams cad mngon par 'phel bar byed pa ste/ mdor na phyi ma'i lus can 'byung bar 'gyur ba thams cad kyi slob dpon du gyur pa rab tu grags so/ /

O friends, this vidyā performs all of Noble Tārā’s[612] great rituals! Reading it accomplishes all minor rituals! It is a supreme secret! It is very secret, supremely successful, and it destroys all rituals performed by others. It is even for the sādhanas and rituals of the second maṇḍala. In brief, it is to be used for all of Noble Tārā’s great rituals as well as all minor rituals, and [can even be used] for the rituals and sādhanas of all maṇḍalas. For a full day and night, wherever is appropriate, one should depict [the maṇḍala] in a ritually pure place. At first, the faultless, solitary maṇḍala hierophant himself [should make] a square with four doors measuring four cubits and [place] a lotus seal in the center of that. On its right, place a seal of a blue utpala, a staff, and the seal of a round pitcher. On its left, place the seal of a three-pronged vajra and the seals of Pāṇḍaravāsinī, Hayagrīva, and Mahāśrī [Tārā]. [Place] a lotus in the eastern doorway, a blue lotus in the north, a vajra in the south, and in the west, beyond the steps to the entrance, [place] the seal of a bound noose. After having ignited a fire on the outside [of the maṇḍala] and worshipped [the maṇḍala], etc., with the ritual previously expressed, one should then enter the maṇḍala. As for [where one performs] that [ritual]: one who desires a kingdom [should perform the ritual] near hatsya trees; one who desires material wealth — [should perform it] in one’s own home; one who desires horses [should perform it] in a horse’s stall; one who desires elephants — [should perform it] in an elephant’s stall; one who desires a son — [should perform it] near the bode-rtsi tree;[613] for one possessed by a Brahmā rākṣasa — in [the place] protected by Brahman; for one seized by a serpent (nāga) — near the serpent tree; for one possessed by a ḍākinī — near the crossroads; for one possessed by a yakṣa — near the pata tree; for one possessed by an evil pūtana spirit — near a well. Wherever others perform this ritual] according to their desires, no harm will result. O friends, in brief, this vidyā should be applied to all rituals with maṇḍalas and all rituals with evocations (sādhanas). It should be applied together with this Great Secret.[614] This maṇḍala exists as a result of wishing to benefit sentient beings. The vidyā of Tārā’s maṇḍala increases all pleasures and in order to benefit practitioners, it increases all fortunes. In short, it is renowned as the spiritual guide for all future embodied beings.

de nas dkyil 'khor chen por gyur pa gang thob nas dpal med pa 'joms par byed cing zhi bar byed/ nad dang dgra 'phrog pa de lta bu'i dkyil 'khor sems can thams cad kyi gzi brjid dang stobs sgrub par byed pa mthong zhing thos nas de nas cho ga la rab tu dang ba skye bar 'gyur ba gang yin pa de rnams sangs rgyas thams cad kyi byang chub tu bdag gis lung ston par the tshom med do/ / gang yang ma 'ongs pa'i sangs rgyas 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten gyi 'dren pa de rnams kyang rjes su yi rang bar 'gyur ro/ /

Then, those who have profited from what is in the great maṇḍala — who have seen and heard that such a maṇḍala subdues and pacifies the undignified, eliminates disease and enmity, and causes all sentient beings to achieve radiance and strength — and who therefore have complete faith in the ritual, shall undoubtedly be instructed by me in the enlightenment of all the Buddhas. Moreover, the future Buddha shall appear and the world leaders shall also rejoice.
sa stengs dkyil 'khor smra ba ni/ / zhi ba'i las rnams thams cad byed/ / bkren pa rnams kyis 'phan pa thob/ /
[Tārā’s] maṇḍala spoken about on this earth Performs all rituals that pacify (śāntika), And [helps] the poor attain profit. [1]
sems can mgon med sdug bsngal can/ / rnams kyis dkyil 'khor rab sbyar bya/ / in+d+ra nI la sogs phye mas/ / dkyil 'khor yang dag kun du bri/ /
Suffering sentient beings who are protectorless Should thoroughly prepare the maṇḍala. Depict the maṇḍala perfectly With pulverized sapphires, etc. [2]
in+d+ra nI la sogs med na/ / sA lu'i phye mas yang dag bri/ / sA lu'i phye ma sogs med na/ / so phag phye ma sogs kyis bri/ / so phag phye ma sogs med na/ / bye ma rnams kyis yang dag bri/ /
If there are no sapphires, etc., Then depict it with powdered rice. If there is no powdered rice, Depict it with powdered brick. If there is no powdered brick, Depict it perfectly with sand. [3]
de ltar yon tan kun bsdus pa'i/ / sgrol ma'i dkyil 'khor rmad byung ba/ / 'jig rten mgon po'i yang dag bka'/ / byang chub sems dpas gsungs pa yin zhes so/ /
In this way, Tārā’s marvelous maṇḍala Is a collection of all [good] qualities. The perfect command of the World Protector [Buddha] Has been spoken by the Bodhisattva. [4]

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod dang ldan pa theg pa chen po'i mdo sde bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i cho ga las sgrub thabs kyi cho ga dang / dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga rab 'byam gyi le'u ste gsum pa rdzogs so// //

This completes the third chapter, “The Extensive Ritual of the Maṇḍala and the Ritual of Sādhana,” from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka-mahāyāna-sūtra and the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[rab 'byams kyi bris sku dang po]
Chapter B.1: The First Extensive Ritual of the Painted Image

de nas sems dpa' chen pos slar yang dkyil 'khor chen po de la kun du gzigs nas dngos po med pa'i rang bzhin yang dag par 'phags pa dgongs nas bcom ldan 'das ma rig pa'i rgyal po chen po de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis gsungs shing mngon par yi rang bar gyur pa/ mchog gi sgrub pa'i cho ga ras ris kyi cho ga gsungs so/ /

Then, the Great Being beheld that great maṇḍala once more, reflected upon it as the surpassing nature of non-substantiality, and spoke about the Blessed One, Queen of Mahāvidyās[615] and [her] ritual of the painted cloth, a ritual of supreme success, spoken about and rejoiced in by all the Tathāgatas.

dang po ra zhig dge ba'i nyi ma la dpa' bo'i rin gyis nyos pa'i ras bal blangs nas bram ze'i bu mo'i lag pas ras bal byed du gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas ras bal de la lhag par gnas par bya ste rtsa ba'i rig pa dpa' bo'i rin gyis nyos pa'i dog pa blangs nas 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang / nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad lhag par gnas par mdzod cig /bcom ldan 'das dang / byang chub sems dpa' chen po rnams legs par 'tsho zhing bdag gi skye ba 'bras bu yod pa dang / sngags kyi dngos grub lhag par gnas par mdzod cig /de'i dus su rnga pa Ta ha dang / rnga bo che dang / dung dang / pi wang dang / gling bu dang / 'khar rnga dang / rnga mur dza'i sgra thos par gyur pa'am/ rgyal rigs sam/ rgyal rigs mo'am/ bud med dam/ khye'u'am/ bu mo'am/ mi rnams glo bur du 'di skad ces/ rgyal dang / grub pa dang / dngos grub sbyin pa dang / byin pa dang / zung shig dang / dpal dang / 'bras bu dang bcas pa dang / las kyi 'khor lo dang / mang po zhes pa 'di lta bu la sogs pa gzhan yang dge ba'i spra rab tu 'don pa dang / dril bu'i sgra byung ba dang / dga' ba'i sgra yang rung ste/ de rnams rig pa 'dzin pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis kyi byin gyis brlabs par shes par bya'o/ / gzhan du dngos grub 'bras bu med do zhes pas so/ /

First of all, on an auspicious day, [the practitioner] who has accepted the raw cotton fiber purchased with a generous price should have it prepared by the hands of a brahman’s[616] daughter. Then, that cotton fiber should be consecrated. Having accepted the skein of cotton that was purchased with a fabulous price and [consecrated with] the root vidyā, [the practitioner] should say these words,[617] “All Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Śrāvakas, and Pratyekabuddhas, please consecrate [these cotton threads for me.[618]] May the Bhagavān and the great Bodhisattvas please make my birth fruitful, my life happy, and may they empower the occult attainments (siddhi) of the mantras.[619]” At that time, if [the practitioner] hears the sounds of the paṭaha drum, the great drum, the conch, the guitar, the reed pipe, the gong, and the muraja drum, or hears kṣatriya men and women, or (other) men and women, or boys or girls[620] adventitiously utter the propitious words, “Be victorious! Be successful! Give! Be given! Obtain success! Be glorious! Be fruitful! [Prevail over Śakra!][621] Multiply!” and other [such words]; and if one hears bells resound or any other delightful sounds, then the tantric practitioner should know that “These [words and sounds] have been empowered by the Blessed Buddhas and Bodhisattvas and the attainments will not be anything else but fruitful.”

de'i dus su de rnams ma rungs pa'i sgra 'byin pa'am/ zung shig /zo shig /'dzin du chu gcig /nyams pa rnam par brlag pa/ kyi hud/ ring ba med pa de lta bu la sogs pa'i sgra 'byin par byed pa dang / mi dang / ma he dang / ce spyang dang / bong bu dang / byi la dang / dud 'gro dman pa rkang gnyis pa/ rkang bzhi pa rnams kyi sgra 'don par gyur na/ de la sgrub pa pos mchog gi dngos grub med do zhes shes par bya zhing / skye ba 'di nyid la kun du brtul bar bya'o/ / slar yang snga ma bzhin du byas nas brtsam par bya ste/ de lta bu lan bdun gyis mtshams med pa lnga byed pa'ang bdun pa'i las kyi sbyor bas 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / zhes so/ / de nas sgrub pa pos gzhon nu ma de la srung ba byas nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug tu bcug ste shar du mngon par phyogs pa'am/ byang du mngon par phyogs par bzhag nas bdag nyid tsA ru'i ston mo bza' zhing gzhon nu ma de la yang tsA ru'i ston mo bzar gzhug par bya'o/ / snga ma kho nar yongs su brtags pa'i ku sha'i khres la cho ga de nyid kyis ras bal 'khal du gzhug par bya'o/ / dog pa de 'jam pa dang / legs par bsgrims pa sngar brlabs pa'i bu mos yang dag par blangs te/ gcig dang lnga dang brgyad la sogs pa nas ji srid bcu drug tsam gyi bar du kA ra ShA'i srang grangs legs par bgrangs pa dang ldan pa'i gzhon nu mas bya'o/ /

However, if inauspicious words are uttered at that time such as “Seize! Consume! Induce seizure! Degenerate! Fully destroy! Alas! It’s far off! There’s nothing!” etc., and if the sounds of [the monkey],[622] the buffalo, the wolf, the donkey, the cat, and [other] two and four-legged animals are uttered, regarding that, the tantric practitioner should know, “I won’t have any occult attainments (siddhi),” and should be ever diligent in this very life. [The practitioner] should begin by performing [service][623] again, as before, performing it seven times in the same way. With the seventh ritual preparation, even one who has committed the five sins of immediate retribution will succeed. After that, the practitioner who has performed a protection [ritual] for that young girl should seat her upon a bundle of kuśa grass. Having faced her toward the east or north, the practitioner then eats an agreeable feast and has that young girl eat the (same) agreeable feast.[624] Using the same ritual, seated upon a bundle of kuśa grass that was formerly arranged, she should then be put to the task of spinning the cotton. The formerly empowered[625] girl who has assembled the skein [of cotton thread] in a smooth and compact manner, should be paid a measure of karṣa coins, from one to three, five, eight, or sixteen [coins].
de la rab ni bcu drug bya/ / de bzhin 'bring ni brgyad pa ste/ / phran tshegs las rnams bsgrub pa la/ / lnga dang gcig ni tha ma'o/ /
Regarding her [craftsmanship], She makes sixteen (karṣa) for superior work, Eight for works of middling quality, and Five or at least one for trifling performances. [1]

sngags rnams kun la sngags rig pas/ / ji ltar nus pa bzhin du bya/ / de nas brtsams te gang cung zad/ / sdig pa'i las rnams sngon byas pa/ / dog pa la dmigs sems kyis ni/ / de yi skad cig nyid la 'jig /

The mantra knower should perform All mantras according to his or her ability. Having begun [recitation], [the karmic effects of] minor Non-virtuous actions, previously performed, Are immediately destroyed, By contemplating that skein. [2]
dog pa 'di ni blangs nas su/ / gtsang ma'i snod du gzhug par bya/ / phyogs su gyur par bzhag byas nas/ / ga pur gyi ni bdug pas bdug /
Having accepted this skein, Place it in a pure vessel. Having placed it as directed, Fumigate it with camphor incense. [3]
srog chags yan lag min 'byung ba'am/ / gur gum tsan+dan la sogs sam/ / tsam pa ka sogs mA li ka/ / dri zhim me tog rnams kyis bsgos/ /
Hoping that vermin do not appear [to infest the thread], Anoint [the skein] with saffron and sandalwood, etc., Or fragrant flowers Like magnolia and jasmine. [4]
gtsang ma'i phyogs su bzhag nas ni/ / srung ba'i cho ga byas nas ni/ / sngags rig las kun shes pa yis/ / shin tu mnyam bzhag bzlas par bya/ /
Having placed [the skein] in a pure place And performed the protection ritual, The knower of vidyās, mantras, and all the rituals, Should recite one-pointedly. [5]
de nas tha ga par song nas/ / ji ltar 'dod pa'i gla byin te/ / yan lag bral min skems min nyid/ / dkar po'i chos la rtag tu dga'/ /
Then, having gone to a weaver, Pay him as he wishes. He should neither lack limbs, nor be too thin, And always rejoice in virtuous natures.[626] [6]
nad kyis gdungs min rgan po min/ / lud pa dbugs mi bde las grol/ / ma ning mtshan gnyis min pa dang // de ni dman pa min nyid dang //
He should neither be afflicted by disease, nor too old, Be free from phlegm and asthma; and Neither a eunuch, a hermaphrodite,[627] Nor dishonorable. [7]
ngan par ltung ba spangs pa ni/ / kun nas mtshan nyid yang dag ldan/ / rab bsngags blta na sdug pa dang // blo yis kun du spyod pa dge/ /
Having abandoned transgressions And entirely possessed of auspicious marks, He should be praiseworthy, pleasant to look at, And possess virtuous mental conduct. [8]
'jig rten pa yi 'jug par brten/ / dngos grub 'dod pa de la ni/ / ras mchog 'thag pa byed pa la/ /
He should correctly observe the ways of the world And have a desire for success (siddhi) While weaving the excellent cloth.[628] [9]
rab bsngags dge ba'i stobs ldan nam/ / blo ldan bzo ni shin tu mkhas/ / shin tu mkhas par mchog gyur pa'i/ / ras ni 'thag byed mchog gis ni/ /
The intelligent, expert craftsperson, Praiseworthy and endowed with the strength of virtue, Produces the most superbly woven cloth Of the finest quality. [10]
ras kyi rab la bya ba yin/ / 'bring la 'bring po sgrub par byed/ / tha mas phran tshegs las rnams ni/ / dman pa nyid ni kun las so/ /
The best [weaver] produces the best [cloth]. The middling [weaver] produces middling products. The inferior [weaver] makes insignificant works, That are entirely inferior. [11]
bzo bos ji ltar smra ba bzhin/ / de las gru ni ji bzhin sbyin/ / bzo bo yi ni dang po'i ngag / smras pa de las sngags rig pas/ /
The craftsman should be paid[629] The exact amount he requests. Once the craftsman’s first words Are spoken, the tantric practitioner [12]
myur du rin ni sbyin par gyis/ / dpa' bo'i tshong zhes de la brjod/ / don du gnyer ba nyid dang de'i/ / rin gyi dngos po zlog par byed/ /
Quickly pays him that price. This is called the “heroic trade.” One exchanges a cash payment For an entity of the same value. [13]

myur du dngos grub byed gang 'di'i/ / ras ni bla na med pa'i mchog / las rnams shin tu mchod par 'os/ / lha dang mi yi bde nyid dang // 'byung po kun gyi dpal yin zhes/ / yang dag rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs/ /

This cloth of matchless excellence Quickly produces successful results, [Performs all] rituals,[630] and deserves the highest praise. “This [cloth] is the joy of humanity and gods, And the glory of all creatures!” The Rightly Perfected Buddha has proclaimed. [14]

de nas rig pa 'dzin pas tha ga pa la gso sbyong byin nas/ shin tu dag pa'i rgyu skar la'am/ cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed la'am/ dkar po'i nyi ma'am/ dkar po'i gza' nges par bltas te dkar po'i zla phyed gzhan la'ang rung ste/ shing sa ha kA ri'i snye ma dang me tog skyes shing shing gi me tog dang yal ga rgyas shing dpyid ka'i dus/ dus kyi mchog der snga dro nyi ma 'char ba'i tshe sngar bstan pa'i rgyu mthun dang bcas pas tha ga pa tsA ru'i bza' ba zos shing gos dkar po gyon pa mgo la gtsug tor bcings nas legs par bkrus pa/ tsan+dan dkar po dang / gur gum dag gang yang rung bas legs par byugs pa/ lus la rjes su byugs pa/ ga pur gyi dris kha bsgos pa/ yid dga' zhing bkres pa dang / skom pa dang bral bar byas nas/ thags kyi snas la sogs pa'i yon tan thams cad kyang sa dang / ba lang gi lci ba dag gis bkrus te gsar pa rnams kyang slar yang ba'i rnam lngas bkru bar bya'o/ / de nas srog chags med pa'i chus bkru bar bya'o/ / tsan+dan dkar po dang / gur gum gyis mngon par gtor bar bya'o/ / sa'i phyogs gtsang ma ca co dang bral zhing / ljongs kyi mi dang bral ba rnam par dben pa'i gnas bla gab dang bcas shing gsang bar me tog dang bdug pa la sogs pas mchod do/ / de nas rjes su sgrub pa pos yang dag par sbyong bar byed pa'i sngags nyid yungs kar dkar po la brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags par byas nas phyogs bzhi rnams dang / steng dang 'og dang phyogs bral rnams su gtor bar bya'o/ / de nas tha ga pa la yungs kar gyis yang dag par bsnun nas phyag rgya chen pos gtsug phud lnga pa bcings te/ gtsug tor bcing ba byas na srung ba chen po byas par 'gyur ro/ / gal te ras rab yin na zheng du khru bzhi/ chur khru brgyad kyi tshad 'di tsam du tha ga pas bran par bya'o/ / 'bring por gyur na zheng du khru do chur khru lnga nyid do/ / tha ma ni bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang gi tshad la chur ni sangs rgyas kyi khru gang nyid do/ /

After that, the tantric practitioner arranges a [one-day] fasting reparation for the weaver, after he has seen an auspicious planet or an auspicious star associated with a very auspicious lunar asterism [in the sky] or during the [waxing] half of the month of miracles,[631] or any other waxing moon in springtime, when the buds and flowers of the fragrant mango tree (sahakāra) emerge and branches [of other] trees are laden with flowers. In this most excellent [spring] season, when the early morning sun has risen, the weaver whose natural outcome[632] is as previously indicated should eat an enjoyable feast and don white garments. Having tied his well-washed [hair] into a crest on the top of his head and thoroughly anointed it with whatever white sandalwood and saffron is available, he should also anoint his body and rub[633] fragrance of camphor around his mouth. With his mind satisfied, [and his body] freed from hunger and thirst, he should ritually cleanse all instruments of the loom, its strings, etc., with earth and cow dung, and also wash the new [instruments] again with the five products of the cow.[634] Then he should wash them with vermin-free water and sprinkle them with white sandalwood and saffron. On that clean spot of earth that is free from noise and country folk, under a canopy in a place of solitude, [the practitioner] should secretly worship with flowers and incense, etc. Then, having consecrated white mustard[635] one hundred and eight times with the same purifying mantra, the tantric practitioner should scatter the mustard in the four cardinal directions, above, below, and in the intermediate directions. Then, having struck the weaver with the mustard, tied the five-pointed Great Seal,[636] and bound the headdress, [the practitioner] will have performed [the ritual of] great protection. If the raw cotton is superior, the weaver should make [the cloth] four cubits wide,[637] up to eight cubits long, [and very thick.[638]] If it is of middling quality, it should be one cubit wide and five cubits long. The width of an inferior [cloth] measures a full span[639] of the Sugata[640] and its length[641] is exactly a full cubit of the Buddha.
de las sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi mtho gang ni yul dbus kyi skyes bu tshad dang ldan pa'i khru gcig ste/ 'di ni bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho'o zhes bsgrags te
Here, what is proclaimed as the “span of the Sugata” is a full span of the Blessed Buddha [equal to] the one cubit measurement of a person from the central region of Madhyadeśa.[642]
tshad 'dis tshad kun du bshad do/ / 'di ni phur pa'i dngos grub tu/ / skyes bu mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / thub pa mi snang gyur 'og tu/ /

“Using this measurement, [all] measurements are explained.”[643] This [superior cloth] is for the supernormal power of flying.[644] The Excellent Person[645] has explained. After Śākyamuni left the world,[646] [15]
rgyal srid 'dod la 'bring po ste/ / longs spyod chen po don gnyer ba'i/ / skyes bu lha dang lha min dang // gdengs can tha ma grub par bshad/ /

Those with middling [results] desire sovereignty; [Whereas] people who strive to procure sublime pleasure Are said to achieve the inferior [accomplishments] Belonging to the gods, demi-gods, and nāgas. [16]

'bring la dngos grub 'bring po'o/ / ras 'bring po ni rtag pa ru/ / sems can kun gyi las rnams sgrub/ / phran tshegs las rnams bsgrub bya la/ / ras tha ma ni rtag pa ru/ / las rnams thams cad sgrub par byed/ /

Middling [goals achieve] middling results. The middling cloth always Achieves rituals[647] for all sentient beings. When minor rituals are to be accomplished, The inferior cloth always Accomplishes all rituals. [17]
rdzas rnams kun la rtag tu ni/ / las rnams thams cad sgrub par byed/ / ras ris gsum gyis nges bstan pa'i/ / dngos grub dpal don gnyer ba'i mi/ /
All materials [for the three cloths] Always accomplish all rituals. The results indicated by the three painted cloths Belong to persons of superior striving.[648] [18]
brgya byin bde sogs bdag po yang // cho ga nyams na mi 'grub ste/ / cho ga yang dag ldan gyur na/ / mi yi skye bo phal pa la'ang // 'bad pa yis ni las rnams kun/ / myur ba nyid du 'grub par 'gyur/ /

If the ritual is impaired, it won’t succeed even for Śakra, Śacī’s Lord, etc.[649] If the ritual is perfect, then, Even for ordinary human beings,[650] All rituals will quickly succeed by means of effort. [19]
rgyal dang rgyal mchog sras rnams kyis/ / sbyor ba 'di ni yang dag bshad/ / sems can bkren pa mgon med pa/ / sdug bsngal gyis gdungs kun gyi dpal/ /

These procedures, which are thoroughly explained By the Conquerors and the excellent Sons of the Conquerors,[651] Are the glory of all sentient beings who are poor, Protectorless, and scorched by suffering. [20]
byang chub lam du gang 'di ni/ / de nyid gzigs pa rnams kyis bstan/ / chos 'di byang chub rgyu yin par/ / sngags kyi lam gyis bstan pa yin/ /
That which is on the path to enlightenment Has been revealed by those who discern reality.[652] The Mantra Path teaches this Dharma As the cause of enlightenment. [21]
dkyil 'khor yang dag bstan pa gang // 'jig rten dkyil 'khor thams cad dang // 'jig rten 'das pa'ang 'grub 'gyur te/ / 'bad pa med par sngags rnams 'grub/ /
The maṇḍalas [rituals] that have been rightly demonstrated Shall succeed for all worldly maṇḍalas And even for the supramundane maṇḍalas. The mantras shall succeed effortlessly. [22]
gang zhig byang chub rgyur 'dod pa/ / de la rtag tu dngos grub 'gyur/ / rtag tu 'gro la mi phan pa/ / gzhan la dngos grub med par gsungs/ /
It is said that those who desire the cause of enlightenment, Will always have successful results (siddhi); Others who never benefit living beings Will never have successful results. [23]

byang chub ched du 'jug kun la/ / ras ris thams cad 'grub par gsungs/ / spyan ras gzigs kyi dbang phyug gi/ / dam tshig 'di ni khyad par du/ / myur du bya ba'i don bsgrub phyir/ / 'dir ni mtha' dag thob pa ru/ /

It is said, “All painted cloth [rituals] will succeed for all who work toward enlightenment.”[653] “After quickly accomplishing one’s goals, Especially this pledge of Avalokiteśvara, One attains everything here [in this world]!” [24]
bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa yin/ / de nas rim gyis bzo bo yis/ / 'bad pas ras ni btag par bya/ /
Thus, the Blessed one proclaims. Then, in stages, the craftsman Should weave the cloth with effort. [25]
nyin zhag lnga dang brgyad rnams dang // bcu drug gnyis ka bzhi dag dang // nyin mtshan nyid kyis myur ba ru/ / ras ni 'thag pa rdzogs pa dang //
The weaving of the cloth is completed Within five to eight days, Or sixteen days; or two to four days, When weaving quickly day and night. [26]
bzo bo mchog tu grub pa ni/ / nyin mtshan gyis ni dge ba yin/ / gtsang sbra'i spyod pa phun sum tshogs/ / bzo bo rtag tu byin brlabs pa/ /
The supremely successful craftsman Is virtuous day and night, Purifying practices perfected, And always empowered as a craftsman. [27]
thag ring gnas su song nas ni/ / bshang dang gci ba yongs su dor/ / 'ongs pa'i gos dang bcas bkral nas/ / gzhan pa'i gos gzhan bgo bya zhing //
Having gone to a distant place, Attended to the calls of nature,[654] And returned to bathe and dress, Then one should don other clothes. [28]
gos dkar 'chang zhing phreng bar ldan/ / yang dang yang du nye reg bya/ / lus la tsan+dan dkar pos byug / bzo la sogs pa gtsang bar bya/ /
Wearing white garments with a garland, The body should be rubbed again and again and Anointed with white sandalwood, and The craftsman’s hands should be clean. [29]
rtag tu 'jam zhing legs sbyangs pas/ / slar yang 'bad pas btag par bya/ / de la sogs pa'i rab sbyor ni/ / rgyal ba gzhan gyis gsungs pa'am/ /
[With hands] well-washed and always gentle, One should weave with effort, as before Using those preparations, etc., [or others][655] As proclaimed by the Conqueror. [30]
'bad pas rnam dpyad dang tshul gyis/ / ras ni ma lus btag par bya/ / ras kyi thags ni rdzogs pa dang // sngar gyi las kyis legs sprul pa/ / de rnams tshad ldan mnyams pa/ /
With effort and discrimination, The entire cloth should be woven. The cloth weaving, completed and Well-crafted with the former ritual, Possesses flawless measurements. [31]
bya'o bzang po'i nyin zhag la/ / rgyud dang rgyud du mnyam par 'jug / dkar po'i phyogs kyi mdzes pa la/ /
On an auspicious work-day, [the craftsman] Gains equipoise in the stream of consciousness[656] Under the beauty of the waxing moon, And refines the cloth. [32]
'od ma'i shing ni khru bzhi la/ / ras ni blangs nas de nas 'gro/ / nor ni rgya cher 'god pa yis/ / bzo bo bde legs byas nas ni/ /
Beautifying the edges with knotted fringes, [Fastening it][657] on a bamboo rod four cubits long, And paid an ample sum of money [for his work], The weaver is made very happy. [33]
brtul zhugs bzang po legs spyod pa'i/ / sngags pa ji ltar 'dod song nas/ / dri zhim me tog gis mchod de/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs su rnam par dgod/ /
Having accepted the cloth, and then departing, The well-behaved mantra practitioner who Observes vows well, goes wherever he wants, And worships [the cloth] with fragrant flowers. [34]
'di nyid kyis ni sngags kyis ni/ / srung ba'i cho ga rab tu byed/ / gang zhig ras bal sngon du ni/ / slar yang rnam mang yongs sbyangs pa/ /
Having laid it out in a pure place, [The practitioner] performs the protection ritual, Using the same mantra [used] for The cotton fiber that was formerly And repeatedly purified in many ways. [35]
de nyid kyis ni bdag nyid dang // ras nyid bsrung bar bya ba'o/ /
Both oneself and the cloth Should be protected with this [mantra]. [36]
byang chub sems dpa' dpa' bo che/ / sngags bzlas pa yis gsungs pa yin/ / sangs rgyas rnams ni mang pos dang // ngas kyang de ni slar yang ste/ /
Mantra recitation has been spoken about By the Bodhisattva, great hero, By many [former][658] Buddhas, And is now proclaimed again by me.[659] [37]
de nyid gsang sngags thams cad kyis/ / rnam par spyod pa'i sngags kyi gzugs/ / brtson 'grus chen po gzi brjid che/ / sngags kyi don kun sgrub pa po/ /
The practitioner who penetrates the essence Of every secret mantra, Who has great striving and great radiance, That one [achieves] all the mantra’s aims.[660] [38]
sna tshogs skyob pa'i rgyu rnams ni/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byed par 'gyur/ / 'dzam gling gnas pa'i sems can rnams/ / sems kyi spyod pa kun du rmongs/ /
The various causes of protection Shall execute diverse effects. Sentient beings living in this world,[661] Whose mental behavior is entirely confounded, [39]
dad pa med cing phyin ci log / log pa'i kun spyod la rab brkam/ / sngags rnams sgrub par mi byed pa'i/ / de nyid phyir na slar gsungs pa/ / 'khor ba mun pa'i btson rar 'khyams/ /

Who lack faith, have deviant views, Indulge in deviant activities, and Who do not successfully practice mantras, For these reasons, it is said, once more, They wander in the dark prison of cyclic existence. [40]
gang yang rtag tu yid dag cing // dad ldan ltad mo bkra shis dang // sngags rnams kun la rtag tu spyod/ / bdag nyid chen po dngos grub 'dod/ /
But those whose minds are always pure and Faithful during auspicious festivities, Who are noble and desire success (siddhi) While continually practicing all mantras, [41]
rtag tu 'dzin cing 'chang ba dang // spro ba che zhing gzi brjid che/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i sngags rnams gang // 'bad pa med par yang dag 'grub/ /
Who are enthusiastic and radiant, While holding and embracing [all mantras],[662] Will rightly and effortlessly accomplish The mantras spoken by the Conquerors. [42]
dad pa med pa'i skye bo la/ / dkar po'i chos rnams mi skye ste/ / sa bon tshwa sgor btab pa la/ / myu gu med cing 'bras med bzhin/ /
Virtuous natures[663] do not develop In living beings who lack faith; It is like a seed planted in salty soil: There will be neither buds nor fruit. [43]
dad pa rtag tu chos kyi rtsar/ / don kun gzigs pas gsungs pa yin/ / chos don ngang tshul can de rnams/ / sngags kyis dngos grub rtag tu brjod/ /
[The Buddhas who] “See Every Aim” state, “Faith is always the basis of Dharma!”[664] The success of the mantras are always proclaimed For those who’ve embodied the aims of Dharma.[665] [44]
de nas sgrub pos bzo bo ni/ / ri mo mkhan nam bdag kyang rung // ri mo mkhas pas ma 'dres pa'i/ / tshon rtsi kha dog gsal ba dang // kha dog can gyi tshon blangs nas/ /
Then, the practitioner, who is A capable,[666] skillful painter himself, Or a craftsman who is a painter, Holds the unmixed, brightly colored paint, And colorful pigments. [45]
ji ltar tha ga pa la ni/ / sngar gyi cho ga de nyid kyis/ / mtshan nyid yang dag ldan pa yis/ / ri mo mkhan la gong bzhin du/ / rgyas pa ru ni bya ba'o/ /
Using the same ritual Formerly used for the weaver, Perform it in its entirety, Just as before, for the painter Possessing excellent characteristics. [46]
ji ltar sngar bzhin tha ga pa'i/ / cho ga de nyid kyis ni de/ / ras la ri mo bri bar bya/ / yang na rang gis ri mo bri/ /
With the same ritual used for the weaver, Just as before, either that [craftsman] Should depict the drawing on cloth, Or [the practitioner] himself should draw the image. [47]
ga pur gur gum tsan+dan las/ / so phag tshon la bsgo bar bya/ / bdug pa bsregs shing sngags nyid kyis/ / lan grangs brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas/ /
Camphor, saffron, and sandalwood, etc.,[667] Should be applied to the paint. Burn incense, and with the same mantra, Recite one hundred and eight times. [48]
nA ga ge sar pun+nA ga/ / ba ku lA dang tsam pa kA/ / bA ri Shi ka d+hA na sku/ / mA li ta yi me tog sogs/ / ras de la ni mngon par gtor/ /
One scatters onto that cloth Flowers, etc such as jasmine, Nāgakesara, punnāga, Bakula,[668] and magnolia, Vārṣika, and dhānuṣkāri,[669] [49]

shar du mngon phyogs ku sha yi/ / khres la nyer 'dug dad pa'i blos/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' kun/ / sems dpar gyur pas 'di phra mo/ / lag pas blangs nas ma 'khrugs pa'i/ / sems kyis ras la ri mo bri/ /

[The painter] whose mind is clear, Seated on a bundle of kuśa grass facing east, Reflecting upon all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, And grasping this fine [paint brush[670]] in hand, With an untroubled mind, Draws the image on the cloth. [50]

dang po re zhig /de bzhin gshegs pa shAkya thub pa bri bar bya ste rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ skyes bu chen po'i mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis kyis mtshan pa/ dpe byad bzang po brgyad cus nye bar mdzes pa'i sku rin po che'i pad+ma la bzhugs pa kun nas 'od 'bar ba/ kun nas 'od 'dom gang gis nye bar mdzes pa'i sku/ chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa/ rab tu dang ba'i sku/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ dbus na gnas pa'i pad+ma baiDUr+ya'i sdong po can/ 'og na klu'i rgyal po sra ba gdan chen po pad+ma'i sdong bu de la 'dzin bzhin pas de bzhin gshegs pa la lta zhing lag pa g.yas pas phyag 'tshal ba/ dkar po rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ lus phyed mi'i rnam pa can gyi dga' bo dang / nye dga' bo bri bar bya'o/ /

First of all, one should draw Tathāgata Śākyamuni, possessing the best of all aspects and seated on a jeweled lotus. His body is marked with the thirty-two major characteristics of a Great Person and beautified with the eighty minor marks. His form is beautified by a full fathom of light blazing all around. He appears as if teaching the Dharma and his very translucent body possesses the best of all aspects. The lotus [upon which he sits] is situated in the center [of the painting] and has a lapis lazuli stem. Below are the [two][671] serpent kings, Nanda and Upananda, who should be drawn holding up that lotus stalk that forms a great, firm seat [for Śākyamuni]. They are looking at the Tathāgata and saluting him with their right hand. Their [serpent] bodies are half-human, white, and adorned with all ornaments.

pad+ma'i mtsho de'i khor yug tu pad+ma'i 'dab ma dang / me tog dang / cung zad kha bye ba dang rnam par kha bye ba dang / chu las skyes pa'i bya dang / nya la sogs pas mngon par khyab pa/ ma lus par bkod pa/ mdzes pa'i rnam par mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / gang bcom ldan 'das kyi rtsa ba'i pad+ma'i sdong bu dang / 'dab ma de nyid la rnam par 'phros pa'i pad+ma'i me tog du ma rnams rim gyis mtho ba'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su pad+ma'i me tog brgyad de/ de rnams la yang pad+ma rnams la bzhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' chen po brgyad kyi sku mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / dang po re zhig 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug pad+ma'i ze ba ltar cung zad dkar ba'i gur gum dang / gser gyi mdog can 'od dpag tu med pa'i cod pan gyis dbu la rnam par brgyan pa/ phyag na ut+pa la sngon po 'dzin pa g.yas kyi phyag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la phyag 'tshal bar byed bzhin pa/ sku mdzes pa de bzhin gshegs pa lta ba zhi ba'i rnam pa/ bzhin cung zad 'dzum pa/ kun nas 'bar bas 'khrigs pas dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su gnas pa'o/ /

A lotus lake should be drawn entirely arrayed in a beautiful and colorful manner, full of birds and fish, etc. and with its circumference lined with lotus leaves and flowers, both budding and in full bloom. Many lotus flowers rise successively [from branches][672] issuing forth from the same lotus leaves and stalk that forms a base for the Blessed One. To the left side [of Śākyamuni] are eight lotus flowers. The corporeal forms of eight great bodhisattvas should be drawn seated on those lotuses. First is Noble Avalokiteśvara,[673] whose complexion is the color of gold or saffron, or the light-yellow color of a lotus stamen. The crown of his head is adorned with Amitābha Buddha.
