He holds a blue utpala lotus in the [left] hand and is saluting the Tathāgata with his right hand. His body is handsome and calm as he gazes at the Tathāgata. With a faintly smiling face, he is enveloped by a circle of blazing light.

pad+ma gzhan la ni 'phags pa zla 'od gzhon nu de bzhin du mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / gsum pa la nor bzangs so/ / bzhi pa la sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba'o/ / lnga pa la nam mkha' mdzod do/ / drug pa la sa'i snying po'o/ / bdun pa la 'jam dpal lo/ / brgyad pa la spyan bzang ste/ 'di dag thams cad gzhon nu'i cha byad can/ / gzhon nu rgyan gyis mngon par brgyan pa mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas kyi gzhogs su byang chub sems dpa' chen po brgyad la/ byams pa ma gtogs pa rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa ste/ bcom ldan 'das kyi nye logs su 'phags pa byams pa tshangs par spyod pa'i cha byad 'dzin pa/ dbu la ral pa'i cod pan bcings pa/ gser mdog ngur smrig dmar po gsol ba/ dar la dmar po'i stod g.yogs byas pa/ tshom bu gsum gyi mtshan ma byas pa/ gzugs mdzes pa dbyig pa dang / ril ba spyi blugs g.yon gyi phyag tu bkod pa/ kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa phrag pa g.yon du bgos pa/ phyag g.yas pa bgrang phreng bzung nas de bzhin gshegs pa la phyag 'tshal bar byed bzhin pa/ der gtod pa'i lta ba/ bsam gtan la dmigs pa'i sems kyi spyod pa can no/ /

On another lotus, Noble Chandraprabha Kumārabhūta should be drawn in the same way. On the third [lotus] is Sudhana. On the fourth is Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin. On the fifth is Gaganagañja. On the sixth is Kṣitigarbha. On the seventh is Mañjuśrī.[674] On the eighth is Sulocana. All these have the features of a youth and should be drawn adorned with the ornaments of a youth. On the right side of the Blessed one are [also] eight great Bodhisattvas. Except for Maitreya, they are adorned with all ornaments. Noble Maitreya is near the Blessed one and bears the features of a celibate student.[675] He has a crown of locks tied on his head, a golden complexion, and wears saffron and red [garments], plus an upper garment of red silk. He is marked with three spots [of ash],[676] is handsome in form, and holds a staff and water pot in the left hand. On the left shoulder, he wears the hide of the spotted antelope.[677] Holding a string of beads with the right hand, he pays homage to the Tathāgata. With his view fixed on [the Tathāgata], he has the mental practice of being absorbed in meditation.

pad+ma gnyis pa la 'phags pa kun du bzang po pri yang ku ltar sngo bsangs kyi mdog sku rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ phyag g.yon pas yid bzhin gyi nor bu rin po che bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas dpal 'bras bsnams nas mchog sbyin pa/ mdzes pa'i gzugs can de bzhin du mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / gsum pa la 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ston ka'i sprin ltar dkar ba/ gser gyi rgyan gyis rnam par brgyan pa/ ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po can/ thams cad mkhyen pa dbu la byas pa/ 'phags pa 'od dpag med stobs bcu pa/ ral pa'i nang du nye bar bzhugs pa/ gzugs mdzes pa/ phyag g.yon na pad+ma bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas mchog sbyin pa/ bsam gtan la dmigs par gyur pa'i sems kyi spyod pa can sku kun nas gsal bar gyur pa'o/ /

On the second lotus is Samantabhadra. His complexion is green as the priyaṅgu plant.[678] His body is adorned with all ornaments, his left hand holds the precious wish-fulfilling jewel,[679] and his right hand holds the myrobalan fruit while bestowing the boon-granting gesture. He should be depicted accordingly, handsome in form. On the third [lotus] is Noble Avalokiteśvara,[680] white as autumn clouds, adorned with golden ornaments, bearing a crown of [matted] locks, and possessing a white sacred thread. The omniscient one, the noble Amitābha Daśabala, has been put on his head, seated inside his locks of hair. Handsome in form, he holds a lotus in the left hand and confers a boon-granting gesture with his right hand. He has the mental practice of one absorbed in meditation. His body is very luminous.

bzhi pa la 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje phyag g.yon pas rdo rje bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas nye bar 'gog pa 'bras bu dang bcas pa bsnams nas mchog sbyin pa/ gser mdog rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ mdzes pa'i gzugs can zhi ba'i lta ba dang ldan pa/ do shal phyed pas lus nye bar dkris pa/ mu tig gi do shal gyi mchod phyir thogs byas pa/ cod pan rin po che 'bar bas rnam par 'phro ba/ dar srab mo'i sham thabs dang / dar la dkar po'i bla gos byas pa'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang kun du bzang po'i sham thabs dang / bla gos kyang de bzhin no/ / lus kyi rnam pa ni sngar bstan pa ji bzhin no/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i pad+ma lnga pa la 'phags pa blo gros chen po/ drug pa la zhi ba'i blo gros/ bdun pa la rnam par snang mdzad kyi snying po'o/ / brgyad pa la ngan song spong ba zhes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' 'di rnams phyag na 'bras bu dang glegs bam bsnams pa/ rnam pa kun du mdzes pa/ dar la'i stod g.yogs can/ rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ g.yo ba dang ldan pa'i sku ngur smrig dmar po gsol ba/ skyil mo krung gis nye bar 'dug pa rin po che'i rdo leb la bzhugs pa zhi ba'i cha byad can/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa/ dri zhim po'i me tog gis gcal du bkram pa la 'di lta ste/ mA la tI dang / bAr+Shi kA dang / d+ha nu ska ri kA dang / pun+nAg dang / nA ga ge sar la sogs pa'i me tog rnams kyis ras la kun nas gcal du bkram bzhin pas mngon par bri'o/ /

On the fourth [lotus] is Vajrapāṇi. He holds a vajra in his left hand whereas his right hand displays a boon-granting gesture and holds [an Indian fig].[681] His complexion is golden, he is adorned with all ornaments, and has a handsome and peaceful appearance. His body is covered with full and half-sized [pearl] necklaces. He has a sacred thread made of pearl necklaces. His crown is inlaid with blazing jewels. His lower garment is of very fine silk and his upper garment is made of white silk. The lower and upper garments of Noble Avalokiteśvara and Samantabhadra are similar to his and the form of his body is just like that explained above. On the fifth lotus [to the right side] of the Tathāgata is the great Noble Mahāmati. On the sixth is Śāntimati. On the seventh is Vairocanagarbha. On the eighth is Apāyajahaḥ. These [four Bodhisattvas] should be drawn holding a fruit and a book in their hands, wearing flowing garments with an upper mantle of silk, adorned with all ornaments, and appearing entirely handsome. Above them, the eight Pratyekabuddhas should be drawn [as follows: Gandhamādana, Candana, Upariṣṭa, Śveta, Sitaketu, Indra, Nemi, and Sumeni.][682] One should draw them bearing the features of a monk, their bodies endowed with the [thirty-two] characteristics of a Great Person, dressed in saffron and red, sitting cross-legged on bejeweled stone slabs, appearing peaceful, shimmering with a blazing garland, and showered with fragrant flowers [similar to] those being scattered onto the cotton cloth, including mālati, vārṣikā, dhānuṣkāri, punnāga, and nāgakesara, etc.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon gyi gzhogs su 'phags pa 'jam dpal gang yin pa'i steng du rin po che du mas spras pa'i shin tu ring po'i rnam pa'i gzhal med kyi dkyil 'khor ro/ / brag ri'i rgyal po nye bar mdzes pa rin po che'i rdo leb kyis bkab pa ri bo'i rnam pa lta bur mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / der gnas pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brgyad mngon par bri bar bya ba la 'di lta ste/ rin chen gtsug tor can rin po che be+eDUr+ya'i 'od rnam par 'phro ba/ kun nas 'od 'dom gang ba/ pad+ma rA ga dang / in+d+ra nI la dang / ma ra ka ta la sogs pa dang / be+e DUr+ya dang / rdo'i snying po la sogs pa nor bu rin po che chen po'i khyad par rnams kyis kun nas rab tu 'bar bzhin pa/ cung zad nyi ma 'char ka'i mdog 'dra ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku chos gos ser po'i stod g.yogs mnabs pa/ skyil krung gis bzhugs pa/ chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa/ sham thabs ser po mnabs pa sku la skyes bu chen po'i mtshan gyis go cha bgos pa/ dpe byad bzang po brgyad cus nye bar mdzes pa'i sku rab tu zhi ba'i gzigs stangs can/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen gtsug tor can mngon par bri'o/ /

On the left side of Lord Śākyamuni, above Noble Avalokiteśvara,[683] one should draw an immeasurable, timeless orb (dkyil ’khor), studded with many precious jewels, similar in nature to a mountain covered with jeweled stone slabs as beautiful as the most excellent of mountains (Śailarāja). Dwelling in that [sphere], one should draw eight precious Buddhas, as follows. [First,] one should draw the Tathāgata Ratnaśikhin excellent in every respect, encircled in a full fathom of light, emitting the jeweled radiance of lapis lazuli, and fully ablaze with exquisite precious jewels such as rubies, sapphires, emeralds, and [semi-precious] jewels such as lapis lazuli, etc. His complexion is the color of a barely rising sun. The Tathāgata’s body is dressed in an upper mantle of pale yellow religious robes and a pale yellow lower garment. He sits cross-legged and appears as if explaining the Dharma. His body bears the armor of the [thirty-two] characteristics of a Great Being adorned with the eighty minor marks. His posture and appearance are very tranquil.

gnyis pa la de bzhin gshegs pa me tog yang dag par skyes pa'i rgyal po'i dbang po gser gyi mdog tu mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / nA ga ge sar ches bzang ba dang / ba ku la la sogs pa'i me tog rnams kyis mngon par gtor ba mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa 'jam dpal la mngon par gzigs bzhin pa kun nas 'od can rin po che'i 'od rnam par 'phro ba'i mthar thug pa'o/ / gsum pa la de bzhin gshegs pa sA la'i dbang po'i rgyal po mngon par bri bar bya ste pad+ma'i ge sar gyi mdog tu snang ba/ chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa'o/ / bzhi pa la de bzhin gshegs pa spyan bzang mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / lnga pa la bzod par dka' ba'o/ / drug pa la rnam par snang mdzad rgyal ba'o/ / bdun pa la sman gyi bla be+e DUr+ya'i 'od kyi rgyal po'o/ / brgyad pa la de bzhin gshegs pa sdug bsngal thams cad rab tu zhi bar byed pa'i dbang po'i rgyal ba mngon par bri bar bya ste/ thams cad gser gyi kha dog can de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'i rnam pa mi 'jigs pa sbyin par mdzad pa'o/ /

Second, one should depict the Tathāgata Saṅkusumita-rājendra,[684] with a golden complexion, showered with exceedingly fine flowers such as nāgakesara and bakula, gazing at Noble Mañjuśrī, and entirely radiant, bordered with a halo of jeweled radiance. Third, one should draw Tathāgata Śālendrarāja, whose complexion is the color of lotus filament, and who appears as though teaching the Dharma. Fourth, one should draw Tathāgata Sunetra. Fifth, Tathāgata Duḥprasaha. Sixth, Tathāgata Vairocanajina. Seventh, Bhaiṣajya-guru-vaidūryaprabharāja. And eighth, Tathāgata Sarvaduḥkhapraśamanarājendra. All have a golden complexion, assume the form of a Tathāgata, and confer the hand-gesture of fearlessness.

de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi steng du yang bris sku'i zur gnyis ka nas sprin gyi go bar na gnas pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu gnyis me tog gi char 'bebs par byed bzhin pa bri'o/ / bar snang la gnas nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang rang sangs rgyas dang 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad la phyag 'tshal bar byed bzhin pa/ mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / rang sangs rgyas rnams kyi byang du 'phags pa nyan thos chen po brgyad byang chub sems dpa' rnams dbu'i gnas spangs pa'i steng du mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/ gnas brtan shA ri'i bu dang / mo+od gal gyi bu chen po dang / 'od srung chen po dang / rab 'byor dang / sgra gcan 'dzin dang / dga' bo dang / bzang ldan dang / ka pi na zhes pa'o/ / rang sangs rgyas kyis rnams 'di lta ste/ dri ngad can dang / tsan+dan dang / nye ba'i 'chi ltas dang / dkar po dang / si ka dang / dbang po dang / mu khyud dang / mu khyud bzang po zhes pa'o/ / thams cad mchog tu shin tu mdzes pa zhi ba'i cha lugs/ zhi ba'i bdag nyid/ rab tu dul ba'i rnam pa'o/ / nyan thos chen po rnams thal mo sbyar bar byas nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la nges par rtog par byed pa'o/ / steng ngos su'ang gnas gtsang ma'i lha dang / nye bar gnas pa'i lha'i bu gzhan gnyis dar gyi bla re kun nas chur ring zhing shin tu mdzes pa bzung nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang rang sangs rgyas dang / 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad kyi steng du 'dzin par byed bzhin pa lha'i phreng ba dang gos 'chang ba'i lha'i bu mngon par bri'o/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i steng ngos su dbu la mu tig gi do shal dang / rin po che'i skud pa la pad+ma rA ga dang / in+d+ra nI la la sogs pa rnams kyis brgyus pa'i rin po che'i skud pa'i tshogs de la dar gyi bla re legs par bkod cing khor yug tu'ang mu tig gi do shal rab tu 'phyang ba mdzes par gyur pa mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi pad+ma'i gdan gyi 'og tu byang chub sems dpa' chen po dang nye bar klu'i rgyal po nye dga' bo'i gzhogs su rin po che'i ri bo/ pad+ma'i mtsho las mngon par 'phags pa/ rin po che'i n+yu gu dang / phug dang / ri sul dang / byi ru'i 'khri shing yongs su dkris pa'i rin po che'i shing dang / drang srong chen po nye bar gnas shing bsten pa'i ri bo/ /

Above the [eight] Tathāgatas, two Sons of the Gods of the Pure Abode should be drawn in both corners of the painted image, situated in the midst of clouds, hovering in the air, casting down a rain of flowers, and making salutations to all the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and noble Śrāvakas. Above the Pratyekabuddhas, avoiding the place above the heads of the Bodhisattvas, the eight great, noble Śrāvakas should be drawn as follows: the Elder Śāriputra, Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Mahākāśyapa, Subhūti, Rāhula, Nanda, Bhadrika, and Kaphiṇa.[685] All are very beautiful, have a calm demeanor, a peaceful nature, and are self-disciplined.[686] With their palms joined, the great Śrāvakas gaze steadfastly at the Buddha Lord Śākyamuni. Also along the upper edge [of the painting] are two other Sons of the Gods nearby the gods of the Pure Abodes. The two Sons of the Gods should be depicted dressed in divine clothes and garlands, and holding up a very long and beautiful silk canopy above all the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and noble monks. Around the head above the Lord Śākyamuni one should draw the well-disposed silk canopy on which are bundles of jeweled threads strung with rubies and sapphires, etc. Pearl necklaces are beautifully hung all along its borders. [On the left side] below the lotus throne of the Buddha Lord, aside the serpent king Upananda, and nearby the great Bodhisattva, a great jeweled mountain rises above a lake of lotuses, surrounded with jeweled sprouting plants, caves, mountain ravines, coral creeping plants, and jeweled trees. The mountain is worshipped and served by a great seer.

de'i steng du khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa drag po chen po'i gzugs can phyag g.yon pas zhags pa bzung nas/ g.yas pas dbyug pa 'dzin pa/ bzhin khro gnyer can/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po la blta zhing bka' nod par byed bzhin pa/ gsus pa rlo ba/ skra gyen du brdzes pa/ mig sman nag po sprin dang mtshungs pa/ ag tshom ser skya dang / skra ring zhing sen mo ring ba/ mig dmar ba/ mgrin pa'i phyogs sbrul gyis brgyan pa/ stag gi pags pa'i sham thabs can/ bgegs thams cad rnam par 'joms pa/ ches mi bzad pa chen po/ khro bo'i rgyal po chen po/ kun nas 'bar ba/ khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa rnams 'di nyid kho nas bri bar bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu ral pa can de dang de'o/ / ri de'i 'og tu rdo'i steng du nye bar 'dug pa/ pus mo sa la 'dud pa'i lus can lag pa spos phor thogs pa/ cha byad dang / dbyibs dang / 'jug pa dang spyod pa ji lta ba bzhin du byas pa/ 'phags pa 'jam dpal la lta bar gyur pa yang dag par bri'o/ /

Atop the mountain is a Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā.”[687] He possesses a very fierce form and holds a noose with his left hand and a staff with his right. His face has knitted brows and he beholds the great Bodhisattva as though receiving precepts from him. His belly hangs down and his hair stands on end, resembling clouds that are black as eye ointment.[688] He has a yellow beard, long hair, long nails, and red eyes. The area around his neck is ornamented with serpents and he wears a lower garment of tiger skin. He is an exceedingly ruthless Wrathful King, entirely ablaze, who thoroughly destroys all obstacles. One should only draw this particular Wrathful King, “Captivated by Tārā.” At the mountain’s base, one should draw a [practitioner][689] possessing matted locks, seated upon a rock, his knees bent upon the earth, his hands upholding an incense vessel, made exactly according to guise and form, compliance and behavior, and beholding Noble Avalokiteśvara.[690]

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i 'og g.yas kyi gzhogs su klu'i dbang po'i rgyal po dga' bo dang / nye logs su pad+ma'i mtsho las mngon par 'phags pa'i rin po che'i ri'i dbang po'i rgyal po gzhan gsungs pa de bzhin du mngon par bri ste/ khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa phan pa lha'i me tog gcal du bkram pa mngon par bri ste/ ri de ni spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi 'og tu bri'o/ / ri de ni shin tu mtho ba/ pad+ma rA ga'i rdo leb dang / de nyid kyi myu gu dang / be+e DUr+ya'i rang bzhin gyi rtse mo'i rnam par bri bar bya'o/ / de la brten pa'i lha mo spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi thugs rje/ 'phags ma sgrol ma lus rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ dar la dmar po'i stod g.yogs dang / dar la khra bo'i sham thabs can bud med kyi rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ phyag g.yon na ut+pal sngon po bsnams pa/ gser mdog can ma/ ha cang mi sbom/ ha cang mi rgan pa/ sems bsam gtan la gnas pa/ bka' nod cing 'dug pa/ phyag g.yas pas mchog sbyin par 'dod pa/ lus cung zad btud pa/ skyil mo krung gis nye bar 'dug pa/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la cung zad lta bar gyur pa/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas yongs su bskor ba'o/ / de nyid du'ang rin po che be+eDUr+ya'i rtse mo de nyid du'ang / pun+nA ga'i shing gis yongs su bskor ba/ yal ga thams cad la kun nas me tog gis spras shing / kha bye bar gyur pas bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma la mngon par bkab pa/ yal ga dud pa de nyid kyis kyang shin tu bkra ba'i byi ru'i myu gu 'brel ba rnam par bkra ba'i gzugs can gyi tshon rtsi 'bar ba na lha mo sgrol ma'i bzhin kun du snang bar mngon par bri'o/ /

On the right side, below Lord Śākyamuni, near the mighty king of serpents, Nanda, one should draw the Powerful King of Jeweled Mountains[691] rising above a lake of lotuses, situated in the same way as the other [mountain] described, except bereft of the Wrathful King “Captivated by Tārā” and showered with divine flowers. One should draw that mountain below Avalokiteśvara, making it elevated and lofty, endowed with slabs of ruby stones, sprouting ruby plants, and a peak made of vaiḍūrya.[692] The Goddess who inhabits that [mountain] is Noble Tārā, the Compassion of Avalokiteśvara. Her body is adorned with all ornaments. She has an upper garment of red silk and a lower garment of multi-colored silk. She is fully adorned with all the ornaments of a woman. She holds a blue utpala in her left hand, has a golden complexion, and is neither too thin, too fat, nor too old. Her mind is absorbed in meditation. She appears as if receiving precepts and willingly bestows [the gesture of granting] boons with her right hand. Her body is seated crossed-legged and slightly bowed [for respect]. Enveloped in a blazing garland, she glances obliquely at Noble Avalokiteśvara. Furthermore, on that jeweled vaidūrya peak, Tārā is entirely surrounded by punnāga trees whose flowers are budding and in full bloom on every branch. Sheltered by those same stooping branches, one should paint Goddess Tārā’s face entirely radiant, with blazing paint that has the luminous color of extremely beautiful, tiny coral shoots.
lha mo bgegs kun 'joms pa mo/ / 'jigs pa 'joms par byed pa'i mchog / sgrub pa po ni srung don du/ / mchog sbyin dge ba bri bar bya/ /
The Goddess is the destroyer of all obstacles, And superior in expelling danger. In order to protect the practitioner, One should depict the virtuous one With a boon-granting hand gesture. [51]
bud med gzugs 'chang lha mo ni/ / thugs rje stobs bcu ldan pa'i sras/ / 'byung po kun gyi dpal yin te/ / mchog sbyin byed ma bri bar bya/ /
The Goddess who bears the form of a woman, The compassionate one, the daughter of Daśabala,[693] Is the welfare of all creatures.[694] She who bestows boons should be drawn. [52]
lha mo las chen byed pa mo/ / byang chub sems dpa' 'od chen po/ / bgegs kun rnam par 'joms don du/ / sgrub pa po ni kun du 'dod/ /
In order to destroy all obstacles, The tantric practitioner always pays homage to The Goddess who performs great activities [And to] the illustrious Bodhisattva.[695] [53]

mi dbang rnams ni srung don du/ / dpal gyi don du rab tu grags/ / khro rgyal dbang po gang yin te/ / ri yi rtse mor gnas 'dod pa/ / bgegs kun rnam par gzhig pa'i phyir/ / rgyal mchog sras rnams kyis gsungs so/ /

Renowned for the role of The welfare and protection of kings, The powerful Wrathful King Has a desirable place on the mountain’s summit, In order to destroy all obstacles, The Sons of the Excellent Conqueror have declared. [54]
drag po chen po brtson 'grus che/ / gtum chen 'od zer chen po ste/ / bstan pa la sdang sems can rnams/ / tshar bcad ched nyid rab tu brtag /
[The Wrathful King] is extremely wrathful, Diligent, fierce, and radiant. He is chosen for restraining Sentient beings who are hostile toward the teachings. [55]
sgrub pa po ni srung don dang // bgegs rnams thams cad 'joms pa dang // mi bzad khro bo'i ngang tshul can/ / sngags kyi lha rnams 'gugs par byed/ /
In order to protect the practitioner And dispel all obstacles, Summon the gods of the mantra, Who have the nature of unbearable wrath. [56]
shin tu drag po drag gzugs can/ / brtse ba med cing nges par 'gog / sdig pa drag po spyod pa rnams/ / dbang du ma gyur dbang du byed/ /
Extremely fierce and wrathful in form, Merciless and prohibiting, [The mantra gods] subjugate invincible ones Who commit savage crimes, [57]
mkha' spyod sa la spyod pa dang // kun nas sa 'og spyod pa dang // thub pa'i bstan pa 'gal byed pa'i/ / gdug pa thams cad 'joms par byed/ /
They destroy all malicious types Who operate throughout the sky, The earth, and the underworld, To oppose Śākyamuni’s teachings. [58]
ras ni kun nas gru bzhi dang // grwa bzhi dag tu bri bar bya/ / ras kyi 'og gi mtha' rnams su'ang // chu bo rgya cher bya ba yin/ /
One should paint the cloth A perfect square with four corners. Along the lower borders of the cloth, Make a wide river abode. [59]
klu ni gdengs kas mtshan pa can/ / gcig nyid kun du bya ba yin/ / yan lag dkar zhing bzang ba dang // lus phyed mi yi rnam par skyes/ /
[It is inhabited by] a hooded serpent Who is completely solitary, Born with a body half-human in form, Whose limbs are fine and white, [60]
rtag tu thal mo sbyor byed pa/ / mgo bo'i steng du bzhag byas nas/ / gdengs ka bdun pa brtson 'grus che/ / dbang chen ldan pa'i klu de ni/ /
With palms always joined And placed above his head. Possessing seven hoods, Great prowess, and great power, [61]
ming ni mtha' yas zhes bya yin/ / de bzhin gshegs la nges par lta/ / nor bu rin chen gyis mdzes shing // shin tu mdzes shing gzugs mdzes pa/ /
That serpent is named “Ananta.” Draw him gazing at the Tathāgata, Beautified with precious jewels, Very handsome in form, [62]
rin chen rgyan gyis rnam par brgyan/ / 'bar ba'i phreng ldan kun du bri/ / klu dbang chen por rnam par grags/ /
Adorned with jeweled ornaments, and A halo of luminous light. He is renowned as the Great Lord of Serpents. [63]
thub pa'i bstan la rab zhugs pa'i/ / 'jig rten kun la phan par brtson/ / bgegs kun rnam par gzhom don du/ / chu bo la brten bri bar bya/ /
Striving to benefit the entire world that is Fully engaged in Śākyamuni’s teachings. In order to vanquish all hindering demons, One should draw this one residing in the river. [64]
de la ras kyi cho ga 'di/ / mdor bsdus rgyal bas gsungs pa yin/ / rgyas par de bzhin gshegs rnams kyis/ / kun nas bshad pa sngar gsungs so/ /
This ritual of the painted cloth mentioned above Has been discussed in brief by the Victor, And extensively explained by the Tathāgatas In a previous narration. [65]
mkhas pa gang zhig 'dri byed pa/ / de yi bsod nams mtha' yas so/ / sdig pa shin tu mi bzad pa/ / bskal pa bye ba byas pa gang // sa stengs bris sku mthong ba yis/ / de yi skad cig nyid la 'joms/ /

The wise one who executes this drawing, Obtains infinite merit for oneself. Yet, one who has committed Unbearable crimes for ten million aeons, Expiates himself [of these crimes] in a moment or two Merely by looking at this drawn image on the earth. [66]

mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang // tshul khrims 'chal dang smad pa dang // sdig pa kun la rab 'jug dang // 'khor bar yongs su rgyu ba yi/ / 'gro ba skye gnas dman pa rnams/ / de rnams ras ris 'dzin mi gzhug /

This painted cloth should not be concealed from [Living beings] who’ve committed the five sins of immediate retribution, Who are immoral and abhorrent, Who engage in every crime, Who wander in saṃsāra, and Who are born into inferior states. [67]
de rnams ras ris mthong bas ni/ / 'bras bu yod par thub dbang gsungs/ / de phyir mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / skad cig de la sdig pa 'jig /
“Those who merely look at this painted cloth Will have positive results!” said the Powerful Sage. Merely by looking at [the painted cloth], One’s sins abate instantly. [68]
dag pas 'jug pa nyid dang ni/ / rjes su zlos pa dag 'jug pa/ / sngags mnyan pa la brtson pa yi/ / mi rnams grub thob smos ci dgos/ /
What needs to be said about the results of people Who have faultless conduct, Who continually recite and Who constantly strive to listen to mantras? [69]
bskal pa bye bar sangs rgyas kun/ / mchod pa'i bsod nams gang yin pa/ / sa stengs ras ris 'dri ba yi/ / sngags pa bsod nams de thob 'gyur/ /
The amount of merit gained by worshipping All the Buddhas for ten million aeons Will be achieved by the tantric practitioner Who draws [this] painted cloth on the earth. [70]
gang gA yi ni bye ma yi/ / tshad du grags pa gang yin pa/ / de yi tshad gyur sangs rgyas dang // rgyal sras rang rgyal bse ru dang //
The result achieved from Bestowing a feast offering many times over In this world for the Buddhas, Conquerors’ sons, Pratyekabuddhas, [71]

nyan thos rnams la 'jig rten du/ / slar yang lan mang mchod ston gsol/ / 'bras bu thob pa gang yin de'i/ / sngags pa ras ris bris pa dang // mthong dang cho ga klog pa dang // rjes su yi rang ba nyid dang //

And Śrāvakas, numbering as many as The famous measurement Of the Ganges river sands, Is equal to [the results] of the mantra practitioner who depicts this painted cloth, Who views it, reads its ritual, And rejoices in it. [72]
cho ga thams cad rab brtags pa/ / de yi sngags kyi dngos grub des/ / ji srid 'jig rten pa yi sngags/ / gang zhig rgyal ba skyes mchog dang //
The mantras’ success is assured for the one Who has performed all the rituals in a superior manner. The mundane mantras, As well as all mantras spoken by [73]
de slob bse ru lha rnams dang // byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid ches/ / gsungs pa'i sngags rnams thams cad ni/ / ras ris 'di yi spyan sngar 'grub/ /
The Victor of Excellent Birth, His disciples, Pratyekabuddhas, deities, And the great Bodhisattvas themselves, Will succeed [when recited] in the presence of this painted cloth. [74]

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po'i mdo sde las/ bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen du brdzes pa'i rtsa ba'i cho ga rab 'byam gyi bris sku dang po rdzogs so// //
This completes the First Extensive [Ritual] of the Painted Image from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-Sūtra and the Fundamental Ritual Text of the Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[rab 'byam gyi bris sku bar pa]
Chapter B.3: The Third Extensive Ritual of the Middling Painted Cloth

de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor la gzigs nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bka' stsal pa/ sems dpa' chen po gzhan yang khyod kyi ras ris kyi cho ga bar ma yod de/ de ngas bshad par bya yis/ de legs par nyon la legs par yid la gyis shig /bshad par bya'o/ / dang po re zhig sngar bstan pa'i dog pa dang / sngar brjod pa nyid kyi cho ga dang / sngar yongs su brtags pa'i bzo bo dang / sngar gyi tshad bar ma nyid kyis ras shin tu dag pa/ 'jam pa/ shin tu sbyangs pa/ kha tshar dang bcas pa/ tshon ma 'dres pa/ skra dang 'dres pa dang bral ba la sogs pa rnams kyis tshad dang gzugs ma gtogs pa dang po ji lta ba de bzhin nyid kyis ras ris phyi ma 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

After that, having beheld the entire retinue, Blessed Śākyamuni spoke to the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, “O Great Being, furthermore, you have a middling ritual of the painted cloth. I shall explain it. Please listen thoroughly and comprehend it well as I explain.” First of all, one should depict the subsequent painted cloth exactly as the first, except for its shape and measurement.[696] One should use the spun threads formerly indicated, the same ritual previously expressed with the craftsman who was formerly chosen, and the very pure cotton cloth of the same medium dimensions — which is smooth, well-washed, fringed, purely colored, and free from hair, etc.

dang po re zhig gnas gtsang ma'i gnas kun nas mdzes pa'i rnam pa rin po che shel gyi rang bzhin lta bu mu tig dkar po'i do shal gyis brgyan pa/ de'i dbus su bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ rin po che seng ge'i khri la nye bar bzhugs pa/ chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug pad+ma'i ge sar du snang ba'am/ gur gum mam/ nyi ma'i kha dog can/ phrag pa g.yon pa'i phyogs su pad+ma bsnams pa/ thal mo sbyar ba byas te bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la nges par rtog bzhin pa/ bzhin cung zad 'dzum pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po/ bde legs dbus ma'i cod pan can/ mchod phyir thogs dkar po can/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga dang / mgo 'dud pa'o/ /

First, [depict] an extremely beautiful place in Śuddhāvāsa,[697] made of crystal and jewels, and decorated with white pearl necklaces. At its center, depict Bhagavān Śākyamuni, seated on a jeweled-lion throne, appearing as if explaining the Dharma, and possessing the most excellent of all aspects (ākāra). On his right side is Noble Avalokiteśvara, brilliant in color as a lotus filament, saffron, or sunlight. He holds a lotus beside his left shoulder, has his hands joined, and appears as if beholding the Bhagavān Śākyamuni. His face has a faint smile. The great Bodhisattva possesses an auspicious central uṣṇīṣa[698] and a white sacred thread. His head is bowed and his right knee is bent.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i g.yon gyi gzhogs su phyag na rdo rje pri yang ku ltar sngo bsangs sngar ji ltar bstan pa de bzhin du mngon par bri'o/ / 'on kyang bcom ldan 'das la rnga yab g.yob par byed bzhin pa'o/ / de'i gzhogs su 'phags pa byams pa dang / kun du bzang po dang / phyag na rdo rje dang / blo gros chen po dang / zhi ba'i blo gros dang / nam mkha' mdzod dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba ste 'di rnams rim gyis mngon par bri bar bya ste/ dang po ji lta ba bzhin du rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

To Bhagavān Śākyamuni’s left side, depict Vajrapāṇi, green as the priyaṅgu plant[699] and exactly as formerly explained. Moreover, he is fanning the Bhagavān. On this [same left] side, one should successively depict the following: Noble Maitreya, Samantabhadra, Vajrapāṇi,[700] Mahāmatī, Śāntimatī, Gaganagañja, and Sarvanīvaraṇa-viṣkambhin. One should depict them in the same manner as in the first [extensive ritual of the superior painted image], decorated with all ornaments.

de rnams kyi steng du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brgyad 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ bzhugs pa phyag g.yas mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa/ chos gos ser po'i bla gos mnabs pa'i sku can/ phyag g.yon pas chos gos kyi rna ba 'dzin pa/ cung zad dmar bar snang ba'i ngur smrig gi sham thabs can kun nas snang ba'i rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa me tog rab tu rgyas pa'i rgyal po dang / rin chen gtsug tor can dang / thams cad skyob dang / log par dad sel dang / gser thub dang / 'od srung dang / spyan bzang zhes pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'di rnams 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas kyi gzhogs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang / nye bar 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / nyan thos chen po brgyad dang / rang sangs rgyas brgyad sngar ji ltar bstan pa de bzhin du 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ 'on kyang 'phags pa mo+od gal gyi bu chen po dang / shA ri'i bu bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la rnga yab g.yob par byed bzhin du 'khor ba'i lus su mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / lha rnams kyi dbang po brgya byin dang / rab 'thab bral dang / dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / dag pa dang / dri ma med pa dang / shin tu mthong dang / 'od gsal dang / tshangs pa mi mjed kyi bdag po dang / 'og min te de lta bu la sogs pa'i lha'i bu gzugs na spyod pa dang / 'dod pa na spyod pa'i lha'i bu rnams rim gyis mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug dang nye bar gnas pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor nye bar spras pa dgod de/ rang gi+i gzugs dang cha byad 'chang ba 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

Above them, one should depict the eight Buddha Lords. They are to be seated and their right hands [display] the “have-no-fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā). They wear an upper garment of pale yellow monk’s robes and a lower maroon-colored garment. Their left hands hold the fringe of these robes. They possess the best of all aspects and are entirely luminous. Here, one should depict the Buddha Bhagavāns called Tathāgata Saṅkusumitarāja, Ratnaśikhin, Viśvabhu, Krakucchanda,[701] Kanakamuni, Kāśyāpa Buddha, and Sunetra. On the Bhagavān’s right side, near Noble Avalokiteśvara, one should depict the great circle of retinue. One should depict the eight great Śrāvakas and the eight Pratyekabuddhas exactly as formerly explained. Moreover, one should draw Noble Mahāmaugalyāyana and Śāriputra sitting while fanning the Buddha Bhagavān. In the same way, one should depict the Sons of the Gods (devaputras) of the Śuddhāvāsakāyika heaven. One should also depict the Sons of the Gods of the heavens of Śakra Lord of the [Vedic] Gods, Suyāma (free from conflict), Tuṣita (Buddhist paradise of Maitreya), Nirmāṇaratiḥ (Pleasure of Miracles), Śuddha (Pure), Vimala (Stainless), Sudṛśa (Auspicious Sight), Ābhāsvara (Clear Light), Brahmā Sahāṃpati (Lord of the Sahā realm), and Akaniṣṭha (None Higher, Akṣobhya’s heaven). In the same way, one should depict the rest of the Sons of the Gods of the form realm and the desire realm in succession. Having arranged and bedecked the circle of attendants residing near Avalokiteśvara, [the practitioner] should have his own form depicted, bearing proper attire.

bcom ldan 'das kyi seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu rgya mtsho chen po las mngon par 'phags pa'i kun nas rin po che'i ri bo ji srid du ras kyi mtha' mar 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ ras kyi mtha'i grwa'i phyogs gcig tu sgrub pa po cha byad dang dbyibs ji lta ba'i rnam pa pus mo dang / mgo bo btud pa/ lag pa spos phor thogs pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / rin po che'i ri bo de la 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi 'og tu khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa sngar ji ltar nges par bstan pa de bzhin du mngon par bri'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yon gyi gzhogs kyi seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi zhabs kyi drung dang nye ba der rin po che'i ri la bzhugs pa'i lha mo sgrol ma mngon par bri ste sngar ji ltar nges par bstan pa de bzhin 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ras de'i khor yug tu'ang me tog sil ma mngon par gtor te tsam pa ka dang / ut+pa la sngon po dang / pad+ma dang / so+o gan+d+hi ka dang / mA la tI dang / bar+Shi ka dang / d+hA nuskAr+Shi kA dang / pun+nA ga dang / nA ga ge sar la sogs pa'i me tog rnams kyis kho ra khor yug tu gcal du bkram par bya'o/ / ras kyi steng / ras kyi mtha'i grwa gnyis su lha'i bu gnyis me tog gi tshogs 'thor bar byed bzhin pa/ gzugs rnam par bkra ba/ bar snang la gnas pa'i char sprin gyi nang na lding ba kha dog dkar por mngon par bri bar bya'o/ /

Below the lion throne of the Buddha Lord, along the borders of the cloth, one should depict a great jeweled mountain rising above a vast oceans. On one side of the corner, at the edge of the cloth, a practitioner should be depicted in an orderly and attired manner, with knees bent and the head bowed, bearing aloft an incense-burning vessel. On that jeweled mountain, below Avalokiteśvara, depict the wrathful king “Captivated by Tārā,” exactly as formerly explained. On the left side of the Buddha Lord, below the lion throne and close to Noble Avalokiteśvara’s feet, depict the goddess Tārā seated on that jeweled mountain. Have her depicted exactly as was formerly explained.[702] Also, scatter fragments of flowers onto the circumference of the cotton cloth and line the circumference with flowers such as Magnolia, blue lotus, red lotus, saugandhika, mālatī, vārṣika, dhānuṣkārika, punnāga, and nāgakesara, etc. In both top corners along the edges of the cloth, depict two Sons of the Gods — white in complexion and charmingly shaped — suspended inside rain clouds that are situated in the atmosphere, and scattering bunches of flowers.
'di ni ras ris 'bring por brjod/ / rtag tu dge legs don 'byung ba/ / sa stengs skye bo mi rnams la/ / dngos grub 'bring po sbyin par byed/ /
This is expressed as the middling painting on cloth. It always gives rise to auspicious effects. It bestows middling[703] occult attainments (siddhi) To human beings on the earth. [1]
'khor bar kun du 'khor ba na/ / sdig pa cung zad sngon byas gang // 'dir ni bris sku mthong ba yis/ / de yis skad cig nyid la 'jig /
Whoever has previously transgressed — even a little bit — When wandering in saṃsāra, Destroys one’s [karma] instantly, By looking at the drawn image here [on this earth]. [2]
sems can rmongs ba mi shes ba/ / de rnams 'gro ba lnga por 'khyams/ / gang zhig byang chub sems dpa' yi/ / bris sku bar ma mthong ba yang //
Deluded and ignorant sentient beings Who wander in the five migration states,[704] And merely look at the medium [sized] Painted image of the Bodhisattva [3]
sdig pa byed par 'gyur ba dang // mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang // tshul 'chal gyis kyang 'grub par 'gyur/ / rnam pa sna tshogs sngags gsungs pa'ang //
Will have positive results, Even for those who have transgressed, Are immoral, or have committed [any of] The five sins of immediate retribution. [4]
shin tu myur bar dngos grub ni/ / bzlas pa byas pas thob par 'gyur/ / nad can rnams ni nad las grol/ / bkren pas nor ni rnyed par 'gyur/ / bud med rnams ni bu thob 'gyur/ /

Various kinds of spoken mantras, Having been recited, quickly attain Successful results (siddhi): Sick ones will be freed from illness, The destitute will acquire wealth, and Women will obtain sons. [5]
bris sku bar pa blta ba na/ / mthong ba tsam gyis de yi tshe/ / bsod nams rgyas pa chen po thob/ /
If beholding the middling painted image, One achieves extensive merit The moment one merely looks at it. [6]
nges par lha dang mi rnams kyi/ / bde ba'i skal ba can 'gyur mi/ / de yi skye ba gzhan la yang // nges par sangs rgyas nyid du 'gyur/ /
That person will attain the fortune and happiness Destined for the gods and humanity. And, in another [future] lifetime, One will surely become enlightened.[705] [7]
bri ba dang ni klog pa dang // lha mchod pa dang 'drir 'jug dang // de bzhin mthong dang reg nyid kyang // sdig pa kun las grol bar 'gyur/ /
Read and write, worship the gods, And engage in drawing [this image on cloth]. By merely seeing and touching [this image], One will become liberated from all crimes. [8]
'di ltar 'od chen bris sku la/ / don du gnyer dang gsol 'debs pa/ / rjes su yi rang ba las kyang // skye ba 'bras bcas myur du thob/ /
After caring for, praying before, and Ecstatically rejoicing in this extremely luminous painted image, One will quickly achieve a fruitful life. [9]
bskal mchog phye ma rnams kyis kyang // skye bos bsod nams gang thob pa/ / tshig tu brjod par mi nus so/ / bris sku mthong ba 'bras bur bcas/ /

Looking at this painted image bears as much fruit As a person who achieves so much merit, that [the amount] cannot be expressed in words — even within the time span of ten million of the most excellent aeons. [10]

zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde las bcom ldan 'das 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen du brdzes pa'i rtsa ba'i cho ga rab 'byam las/ le'u gsum pa yongs su rdzogs so// //

This completes the third chapter from the Extensive [Ritual of the Middling Painted Image] from the Bodhisattva-piṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-vaipulya-sūtra and the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[cho ga bzhi pa ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam]
Chapter B.4: The Fourth Extensive Ritual of The Painted Cloth (Small Ritual)

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas slar yang sems dpa' chen po de la bka' stsal pa sems dpa' chen po khyod kyi ras ris kyi cho ga chung ngu zhes bya ba gzhan gsum pa yang yod de/ / gang 'bad pa med par dngos grub 'grub par 'gyur ba ste/ sngar bstan pa nyid kyi cho ga nyid dang / bzo bos bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang gi tshad tsam thad kar dang / de bzhin kho nar kun nas gru bzhi pa la sngar bzhin du ras ris sngar bstan pa'i tshon rtsi rnams kyis 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / dang po re zhig byang chub sems dpa' chen po seng+ge'i gdan la skyil krung gis bzhugs pa byis pa khye'u sngar bzhin du chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa kun nas 'od zer 'phro bar byed bzhin pa/ mdzes pa'i gzugs can 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su 'phags pa kun du bzang po rin po che'i rdo leb la gnas pa phyag na rnga yab thogs pa g.yon na yid bzhin gyi nor bu thogs pa kha dog bri yang ku ltar sngo bsangs so/ /

Then, Bhagavān Śākyamuni addressed that Great Being once more. “O Great Being, You also have a third subsequent ritual called the ‘Small Ritual of the Painting on Cloth,’ which will accomplish occult attainments (siddhi) effortlessly.” You should have the painting depicted on a square piece of cloth measuring one full span of the Sugata, using the same ritual previously shown, the [same] artists, and the [same] paint previously explained. First one should depict the Great Bodhisattva seated cross-legged on a lion’s throne. He is youthful, appears as if explaining the Dharma as before, emanates rays of light all around, and possesses a beautiful form. To his left is Noble Samantabhadra, situated on a jeweled stone slab, holding a yak tail in his [right] hand and a wish-fulfilling jewel in his left [hand]. His complexion is green as the priyaṅgu plant.

g.yas kyi g.yogs su'ang 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug rin po che'i rdo leb la gnas pa phyag na rnga yab thogs shing / phyag g.yon pad+ma bsnams pa/ kun nas 'od dang ldan pa'i lus can 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug snga ma bzhin du mngon par bri bar bya'o/ / seng ge'i khri'i 'og tu gser gyi ri bo/ / ji srid ras kyi mtha'i bar du 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ras ris kyi mtha'i zur du 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi seng ge'i 'og tu g.yas kyi gzhogs su khro bo'i rgyal po sgrol mas non pa snga ma bzhin du 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu sgrub pa po lag na spos phor thogs pa snga ma bzhin du 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / de thams cad snga ma ji lta ba de bzhin du'o/ /

To his right is Noble Avalokiteśvara, situated on a jeweled stone slab, holding a yak tail in his [right] hand, and grasping a lotus in his left hand. His body is entirely luminous. Depict Noble Avalokiteśvara as before. Below the lion throne, one should depict a golden mountain extending to the edges of the cloth. In the [lower] corner, along the border of the painted cloth, and on the right side beneath Avalokiteśvara’s lion throne, depict the wrathful king “Captivated by Tārā.” Below him, depict the practitioner as before, holding up an incense vessel. All that is exactly according to what was previously [explained].

de nas 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi steng du de bzhin gshegs pa 'od dpag med 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ rin po che'i ri'i phug /sor bcu drug pa'i tshad na bzhugs pa/ khang pa brtsegs pa 'dri ba'i ri bo'i bya skyibs mtho ba 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ras ris de'i khor yug tu ri bo'i khor yug tu ri bo'i rnam pas yongs su bskor ba mngon par bri'o/ / ras ris de'i steng gi zur du gnas pa'i ri bo'i bya skyibs dang kun tu 'brel bar lding bzhin pa lta bu me tog sna tshogs 'thor bar byed pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i ris kyi lha'i bu dag pa dang rnam par dag pa zhes bya ba gnyis su 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ras de la me tog sna tshogs kyis gcal du bkram pa mngon par 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

Then, above Noble Avalokiteśvara, one should depict Tathāgata Amitābha. He should be depicted seated inside a jeweled cave measuring sixteen inches. The elevated rocky overhang of the mountain is like a storied house. One should depict the circumference of that painted cloth encircled with various kinds of mountains. Situated in the upper corners of the painted cloth, one should depict two Sons of the Gods of the Heaven of the Pure Abodes (śuddhāvāsakāyika) named Śuddha (“Pure One”) and Viśuddha (“Stainless One”). They are scattering all kinds of flowers and look as if they are floating within the contiguous rocky mountain overhangs. One should depict that cloth bestrewn with all kinds of flowers.
ras ris rnam gsum mtshan nyid ni/ / thams cad 'dir ni bstan pa las/ / 'di ni chung ngu zhes bya ste/ / ras ris phran tshegs las la shis/ /
The characteristics of the third type of painted cloth Have all been explained here. This painted cloth, which is called the “Small One,” Is auspicious for all minor rituals.[706] [1]
sdig las shin tu mi bzad pa/ / bskal pa bye ba stong phrag tu/ / ras ris mthong bas grol 'gyur te/ / ras ris mthong ba tsam gyis ni/ / skad cig nyid las grol bar 'gyur/ /
One who has committed unbearably non-virtuous actions For billions of aeons, will be liberated Merely by looking at this painted cloth. One will be liberated in an instant. [2]
bskal pa bye ba stong phrag tu/ / blo ldan sangs rgyas bsnyen bkur byas/ / ras ris tha ma mthong ba yi/ / bcu drug char yang mi phod do/ /
Having venerated the intelligent Buddhas, For billions of aeons does not equal even One-sixteenth the amount [of merit accumulated] From viewing the small painted cloth. [3]

sangs rgyas skyob pa thams cad la/ / mchod byas bsod nams gang yin de/ / ras ris chung ngu mthong ba la/ / mkhas pas de yi bsod nams thob/ / mdzes pa yi ni las rnams dang // longs spyod rgyur yang 'di spyod do/ /

A sage would attain as much merit By looking at the painted cloth As the merit gained by worshipping All the Buddhas and the [world] protectors. This [sage] would also perform beautiful rituals As the causes of complete enjoyment. [4]
rig dang gsang sngags ji snyed pa/ / tshangs dbang drang srong gis bshad dang / / nam mkha' lding gis gang bshad dang / / chu lha nyi ma lus ngan dang / /

To the extent that the vidyās and secret mantras have been explained by Brahmā, Indra, and the sages (ṛṣi), Fully explained by Garuḍa, and explained by The water god Varuna, the sun god Sūrya, Kubera, [5]
nor sbyin sogs dang srin po dang / / lha min dbang po thams cad dang / / lto 'phye che dang zla ba dang / / rlung dang gshin rje la sogs dang / /
The god of wealth Vaiśrāvaṇa, the demonized rākṣasas, And the all-powerful demi-gods (dānava), The great serpents (mahoraga), Soma, the god of ecstasy, The wind god Vāyu, Yama king of the dead, [6]
seng ge 'phrog byed sogs bshad pa'i/ / sngags rnams thams cad 'dir drangs te/ / ras ris spyan sngar 'grub par 'gyur/ /
And Viṣṇu in the form of Harisiṃha, etc.,[707] All mantras that have invited [the gods] here, In the presence of the painted cloth, shall be successful. [7]
zhi ba can dang de bzhin du/ / rgyas pa can rnams bya ba ste/ / de bzhin 'dir ni mi bzad pa/ / rgyal mchog gis smad spang bar bya/ /
In this way, here, [in the presence of the painted cloth], One shall execute all pacifying and prosperity [rituals], Excluding the unbearable [rituals,][708] Censured by the Excellent Conquerors. [8]
zhes byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde las bcom ldan 'das 'phags ma sgrol ma'i rtsa ba'i cho ga bzhi pa ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam rdzogs so// //
This completes the “Fourth Extensive Ritual of the Painted Cloth,” from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-vaipulya-sūtra, and the Fundamental Ritual Text of the Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā.
[ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam lnga pa]

d.crumb: B.5: the fifth ritual of the painted cloth

f.d: Chapter B.5: The Fifth Extensive Ritual of the Painted Cloth

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug stan las langs te bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la lan gsum bskor ba byas nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la phyag byas nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyis chos kyi rnam grangs 'di gsungs pa ni legs so legs so/ / rig pa'i brtul zhugs thams cad dpyad pa'i don dang / phan pa'i phyir dang / bde ba'i phyir dang / 'jig rten la snying brtse bas byang chub sems dpa'i thabs la mkhas pa bstan pa/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du 'gro bar byed pa'i chos lhag ma dang bcas pa nges par byang chub la rgyun du mchog tu gzhol ba/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis rig pa dang / sngags kyi spyod pa thams cad kyi don sgrub par byed pa bdag gi rig pa gsang chen 'di nyid skye bo thams cad rgyas par byed par 'gyur ba ma 'ongs pa'i dus 'jig rten gyi bla mar mya ngan las 'das pa na de bzhin gshegs pa nyi ma'i rigs nub pa sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / 'phags pa nyan thos thams cad kyis spangs shing thams cad bor te mun par gyur pa dang / snod kyi 'jig rten rnam par zhig ste 'phags pa'i lam dang / rig pa dang / sngags dang / sman dang / nor bu rin po che thams cad dang bral ba/ skye bo legs pas yongs su bzung ba'i snang ba med pa'i sems can gyi khams 'byung bar 'gyur te/ le lo can dang / dran pa nyams pa dang / ma dad pa dang / mi srun pa dang / mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis yongs su zin pa sgyu dang g.yo dang / brdzun dang g.yo ba'i spyod pa dang ldan pa de rnams/ chos kyi rnam grangs 'di thos nas kun du skrag par 'gyur te/ le lo dang / snyom las la mngon par dga' zhing dad pa med par 'gyur te/ 'dod pa tshol zhing gsang sngags tshol bar mi 'gyur te/ log par lta ba la dga' ba rnams kyang bsod nams ma yin pa mang po la 'jug par 'gyur te/ dam pa'i chos spong bar byed pa 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Then again, the Bodhisattva Great Being arose from his seat, circumambulated the Bhagavān Śākyamuni three times, bowed down at the Bhagavān’s two feet, and asked this of the Bhagavān. “This Dharma exposition spoken by the Bhagavān Tathāgata Arhat Samyaksaṃbuddha is truly excellent! For the welfare, happiness, and aims of observing all the vows of the vidyā, and out of compassion for the world, the bodhisattvas who teach a bodhisattva’s skillful means, who guide [others] to the precinct of nirvāṇā with remaining aggregates,[709] who are positively and continually absorbed in enlightenment, shall make all people prosper[710] with this very secret vidyā of mine. [This vidyā] is used to accomplish the aims of all the practices of the vidyās and mantras. “In the future, when the world’s spiritual guide Tathāgata Ādityavaṃśa dies and passes beyond [the world], it will be a time when all the [Buddha][711] fields will grow dark because abandoned by all Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and noble Śrāvakas, when the receptacle world will perish, and when the sentiency realm will become dark and devoid of a noble path, all vidyās, mantras, medicine, and precious jewels, as well as deprived of holy people (sādhu). At that [future] time, those who are lazy, forgetful, unfaithful, unprotected, surrounded by non-virtuous friends, and possessed of deceptive, false, and fickle activities will become assailed by fear upon hearing this Dharma exposition. Those who delight in being lazy and idle, who lack faith, pursue desires, and do not strive [in their practice of] mantras, and who delight in false views, will also engage in much that lacks merit and shall oppose the holy Dharma.

mnar med pa la mchog tu gzhol zhing drag po'i yang drag por 'gro ba sdug bsngal gyis gdungs pa de rnams kyi don gyi phyir dang / dbang du ma gyur pa rnams dbang du gyur par bya ba dang / dbang du gyur pa rnams la mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa dang / thabs la mkhas pas bsdu ba'i sbyor ba rig pa dang / ras ris kyi cho ga da lta gsungs pa'i dus la bab par dgongs na bcom ldan 'das gsung du gsol/ / de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das mchog tu gsang ba rig pa'i brtul zhugs kyi cho ga rab 'byam mchog tu gsang ba 'dod pa'i don byed pa don chen po rnam par 'byor par gyur pa rig pa bdun cu po thams cad kyi mchog gi snying po/ rnam par rtog pa med pa'i dus der 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de yang sems can rnams 'dul ba'i don gyi thabs la mkhas pas 'khor bar kun du 'jug pa rnams skyob pa/ nges par byang chub la mchog tu gzhol bar byed pa sangs rgyas bye ba phrag bdun cu rtsa drug gis gsungs par gyur pa/ 'di la rig pa ni/

“O Bhagavān, having realized that now is the time, in order to benefit those who are scorched by suffering and whose destinies are the most dreadful of the dreaded — pulling them down to the Avīci Hell of unceasing torment — please speak about the ritual of the painted cloth (paṭa), the vidyā used in conjunction with skillful means, and the method of bestowing fearlessness to those who have been and are being subjected to unrestrained [people].” Having been petitioned in this way, the Bhagavān [Śākyamuni complimented Avalokiteśvara, “O Avalokiteśvara, it is excellent that you have asked the Tathāgata to grant this request. Your][712] essence-incantation is a supreme secret! It makes the vidyā’s vows and rituals succeed. It produces the desired aims of the very secret and extensive ritual of the painting on cloth (paṭa). It is the most excellent of all seventy vidyās that are repositories of great purpose, and will be successful at a time without false notions.” Moreover, here is the vidyā that protects those who’ve entered the assembly through skillful means aimed toward disciplining sentient beings, which makes enlightenment its inevitable goal, and which has been previously spoken about by seventy-six million Buddhas:[713]
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA ren+d+ra tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Namo ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / tārentra Tāre tuttāre ture svāhā /
Homage to the three jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the quick one, Hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma shin tu rgyas pa zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called the “Very Extensive Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA re tu re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tāre ture ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, the quick one! The quick one! Hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma bzhin bzang ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Fair-faced noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tāre tuttāre ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the quick one, Hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma dbus legs ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Praiseworthy Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tad+ya thA/ tA re tut+ta re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tadyathā Tāre tuttāre ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, as follows: O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the quick one, hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma legs spyod ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Well-practiced Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tāre tuttāre Ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the quick one, Hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma mtshan legs ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Well-marked Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ta re tu re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tāre Tāre ture ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, O Tārā, the quick one, the quick one, hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma lho chung ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Small-bellied Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA re tut+tA re tu re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tare tuttare ture ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the very quick one, hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma legs gnas ma zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Properly abiding Noble Tārā.”
na mo rat+na tA yA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tA re tut+tA re/ tu re tu re swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Tāre tuttāre ture ture svāhā /
Homage to the Three Jewels, Homage to Noble Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, O Tārā, who rescues from pain, the very quick one, hail!
'phags ma sgrol ma nye bar 'dud pa zhes bya ba'o/ /
This is called “Respectful Salutation to Noble Tārā.”

zhes pa 'di bcom ldan 'das bdag gi rig pa chen po mchog gi snying po chen po dang mtshungs pa bya ba thams cad mchog tu grub pa/ sems can thams cad la sangs rgyas bzhin du skyes pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis rjes su yi rang ba/ 'jigs pa chen po brgyad las skyob pa/ las thams cad byed pa/ byang chub kyi lam ston pa po/ / pad+ma'i rigs kyi rig pa/ rab dang / 'bring dang / tha ma la yang dag par rab tu sbyor ba/ shin tu mdzes pa'i las kyi 'bras bu rnam par smin pa/ rab tu sbyin pa dang / bstan pa nub pa'i dus kyi tshe'ang 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / dam pa'i chos kyi tshul bsrung ba'i ched du/ mnyam par 'jug cing 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de rnams sbyor ba chung ngu nyid kyis rgyal srid chen po dang / longs spyod chen po'i dbang phyug gi don de rnams 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de rnams shin tu myur bar de'i tshe de'i dus su dngos grub thob par 'gyur ro/ / ras ris kyi cho ga mdor bsdus par gyur pa 'di de'i tshe de'i dus na 'jigs pa chen po dang / snyigs ma lnga'i sems can bsod nams chung ba 'byung bar 'gyur te/ dbang chung bar grags pa/ tshe thung ba/ brtson 'grus zhan pas ras ris kyi cho ga shin tu rgyas pa'i las bsgrub par bya ba la sogs pa'i las rnams rab tu brtson par mi nus te/ de rnams kyi don du ches mdor bsdus te gsungs pa ni/ dang po re zhig dpa' bo'i rin gyis dog pa nyos/ srang tshad tsam mam srang phyed tsam/ dkyus su khru gang tsam la zheng du khru phyed tsam pa'i ras kha tshar dang bcas pa tha ga pas btag par bya'o/ / yang na slar yang skra dang bral ba'i ras kyi dum bu gsar pa steng 'og tu ji ltar 'dod pa khru gnyis sam bzhi'am/ drug gam/ lnga'am/ bcu'am/ brgyad pa'i ras shin tu dkar ba blangs te/ ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du ri mo mkhan 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / tsan+dan dang ga pur dang gur gum gyis bsgos pa'i ma 'dres pa'i tshon rtsi de rnams dang / ras tsan+dan dang / gur gum dang / ga pur rnams gcig tu byas pas srog chags med pa'i chu rnyog ma med pa dang bsres te/ snod gsar par ras sbang du bcug nas nyi ma gsum du legs par mnan la bzhag go/ / gtsang ba'i phyogs su srung ba byas te bdag nyid kyang gtsang mar byas nas/ dkar po'i phyogs kyi nya la ras kyi snod kyi mdun du kha shar du phyogs pas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste/ sngags kyi tshig 'di lan stong phrag brgyad brjod par bya'o/ /

“O Bhagavān, these [vidyās] are equal in greatness to my most concise essence-incantation (parama-hṛdaya),[714] which is a great vidyā. They accomplish all tasks with excellence, [help][715] all sentient beings to be born as a Buddha, are rejoiced in by all Buddhas, protect from the eight great dangers, perform all rituals, point out the path to enlightenment, are applied together with the superior, middling, and lesser vidyās of the lotus family, bestow ripened fruits of very auspicious karma, and will be successful even when the Teacher [Buddha] disappears. They will be equally applicable and successful for the purpose of protecting the path of the illustrious Dharma. Even with little application, they will accomplish the majestic aims of great sovereignty and great enjoyment. At the very time [of application], they will quickly achieve magical results (siddhi).[716] These most excellent essence-incantations shall even be successful for the purpose of verifying [the Dharma]. In short, one will achieve results (siddhi) to the same extent that one applies [the vidyās]. “The abbreviated ritual of the painting on cloth [should be performed] at a time when great danger and the five impurities (pañca-kaṣaya) exist, and when there will be sentient beings of little merit, little power, a short lifespan, little enjoyment, and weak striving. For the purpose of those who will not be able to undertake the extensive ritual of the painting on cloth, etc., that very extensive [ritual] is discussed in brief.” First, purchase a skein [of cloth] with a “heroic” price. A weaver should weave the cloth together with fringes measuring full pala[717] by a half pala or a full cubit (hasta)[718] in length and half a cubit in width. Then, as above, one should accept the new portion of the cotton cloth that is free from hair both above and below. Having accepted the very white cloth of two or four, or five or six, or eight or ten cubits, according to one’s wishes, the painter should begin to draw [the image]. Having prepared those pure paints dabbed with sandalwood, camphor, and saffron, and the cloth dabbed with sandalwood, saffron, and camphor, one should soak the cloth inside a new vessel stirring it in water that is not muddy nor which contains vermin. One should keep it thoroughly immersed (in this vessel) for three days. In a pure direction, perform a protection [ritual], and purify one’s own self as well. Then, on a day during the waxing moon, sit down on a bundle of kuśa grass facing the eastern direction, near the vessel containing the cloth. One should recite this mantra ritual 8,000 times.

tad+ya thA/ oM he he b+ha ga bA na/ ba hu rU pa d+ha ra di bya tsak+Shu Sha/ a ba lo ka ya/ a ba lo ka ya mAM/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ ku mA ra rU pa d+ha ra Na/ ma hA bo d+hi satwa/ kiny+tsa ra ya si hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/
Tadyathā Oṃ he he Bhagavān / bahurūpadhara divyacakṣuṣ / avalokaya / avalokaya mām / samaya manusmara / kumārarūpadharaṇa / mahābodhisattve / kiñcarāyasi hūṃ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā //

sngags 'di bzlas pa byas la de nyid du nyal bar bya'o/ / rmi lam du grub pa'am/ mi 'grub par ston par 'gyur ro/ / de nas langs nas grub pa'i mtshan ma'i rmi lam mthong na/ ring po mi thogs par/ ras ris bri bar bya'o/ / gal te grub pa'i mtshan ma'i rmi lam ma mthong na ras de snod de nas phyung ste nyi ma la bskam par bya'o/ / bskams nas slar yang snod gsar pa gzhan zhig tu legs par sbas la srung ba byas te gzhag par bya'o/ / de nas slar yang mchog gi snying po de rnams las sngags gang yang rung ba gcig bzung nas ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du yi ge drug po rnams las slar yang yi ge 'bum bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas ches myur bar ras ris 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / dang po re zhig ras de blangs nas/ cho 'phrul gyi zla phyed dam/ gzhan yang dkar po'i nyi ma dang / rgyu skar dge ba dang / yang dag par ldan pa/ dge ba'i tshes dkar po'i gza'i res kyi nyi ma la shin tu mdzes pa'i dge mtshan dang / bkra shis phun sum tshogs pa'i mtshan mo nam phyed kyi dus kyi tshe/ ri mo mkhan gso sbyong la nye bar gnas pas ras ris de 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ /

After having recited this mantra accordingly, one should lie down to sleep. One will be shown in a dream whether [this ritual] will succeed or not. Upon arising, if one perceives signs of success in a dream, one should draw the painted cloth without delay. If signs of success are not perceived in one’s dream, one should take that cloth out of that vessel, and let it dry out for one day. After it dries, as before, one should thoroughly immerse [the cloth] in another new vessel, concealing it well, and perform the protection [ritual]. Then, as desired, having chosen one appropriate mantra from those excellent essence-incantations, as before, one should repeatedly recite 100,000 recitations of the syllables belonging to the six syllables.[719] Then, the [ritual of the] painted cloth will rapidly succeed. First, the painter should accept that cloth on a day during the month of miracles, or another day of the waxing moon, under an auspicious constellation, at an auspicious time, and on a day of a changing planet during the waxing moon. Then, the painter who has been fasting should begin to paint that cloth at midnight, on that sublimely auspicious night with lucky omens that are very beautiful.

gtsang ma'i phyogs su ga pur gyi bdug pa bsregs te dang po re zhig 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug sku rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa byas te/ dbu zur phud can skyes bu chen po'i mtshan gyis rnam par brgyan pa/ gser gyi mdog can/ dar la sngon po g.yo bzhin pa'i sham thams cad dar la sngon po'i bla gos mnabs pa/ seng ge'i khril skyil thung phyed pas bzhugs te chos 'chad bzhin pa/ zhabs g.yas pa rin po che'i zhabs rten la bzhag pa/ seng ge'i khri la bzhugs pa/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ blta na sdug pa bzhin cung zad 'dzum pa/ sgrub pa po la gzigs par gyur pa bri bar bya'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su 'phags pa kun du bzang po pri yang ku ltar sngo bsangs/ rnga yab dkar po g.yob bzhin pa/ phyag g.yon na yid bzhin gyi nor bu bsnams pa/ lus thams cad mdzes pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ dar la sngon po g.yo ba dang bcas pa'i sham thabs mnabs pa/ mu tig gi do shal gyi mchod phyir thogs pa can/ phyag g.yon pas pad+ma dkar po bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas rnga yab dkar po gser gyi yu ba can bsnams nas g.yob par byed bzhin pa zhi ba'i rnam pa can spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la blta bar gyur pa'o/ / de bzhin du 'phags pa kun du bzang po pad+ma dkar po'i gdan la bzhugs pa ste de dag gnyis ka'ang de ltar mngon par bri'o/ / pad+ma'i sdong bu gcig las 'thon pa'i pad+ma gsum gyi dbu ma rtsa ba'i pad+ma'i ze 'bru la byang chub sems dpa' chen po'i seng ge'i khri dang rin po che'i zhabs rten no/ / pad+ma gzhan la ni 'phags pa kun du bzang po'o/ / pad+ma gsum pa la ni 'phags pa mthu chen thob bo/ /

Then, having burned camphor incense in a pure direction, one should initially draw an image of Noble Avalokiteśvara.[720] He is to be adorned with all ornaments, a topknot[721] on his head, the marks of a great person[722] with a golden complexion, lower garments of swaying blue silk, and an upper mantle of blue silk. He is to be seated cross-legged on a lion throne, as if teaching the Dharma. Seated upon the lion throne, [his] right foot rests upon a jeweled footstool. One should depict [Avalokiteśvara] endowed with the best of all aspects, handsome to look at, with a faint smile, looking at the practitioner (sādhaka). On his right side, depict Noble Samantabhadra, green as the priyaṅku plant, waving a white yak tail and holding a wish-fulfilling jewel (cintāmaṇi) in his left hand. His entire body is beautiful, adorned with all ornaments, as he wears a lower cloth of billowing blue silk and a sacred thread of pearl necklaces, and [seated on a white lotus. To the left of Noble Avalokiteśvara, depict Noble Mahāsthāmaprāpta with flowing blue clothes. His entire body is beautiful, adorned with all ornaments and a sacred thread of pearl necklaces][723] holding a white lotus with the left hand and waving a golden-handled white yak tail with the right hand, possessing a peaceful demeanor, and gazing at Avalokiteśvara in the same way as is Noble Samantabhadra. Draw those two seated upon a white lotus throne. The lion throne and jeweled foot stool of the Great Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara is situated on the corolla of the main lotus, at the center of the three lotuses departing from a single lotus stem. On another lotus is Samantabhadra. On the third lotus is Noble Mahāsthāmaprāpta.

pad+ma'i sdong bu de ni mdzes pa/ rin po che mar gad kyi rnam pa la pad+ma'i me tog du ma kha bye ba dang / phyed tsam kha bye ba dang / me tog kha ma bye ba dang ldan pa/ mtsho chen po ma dros pa las byung ba'i klu'i rgyal po dga' bo dang nye dga' gnyis mtsho chen po las skyes pa'i pad+ma'i sdong bu la 'dzin pa/ klu'i rgyal po de gnyis kha dog dkar ba/ gdengs ka bdun gyis brgyan pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis mdzes pa/ lus phyed mi'i lus la sbrul gyi gdengs kas mtshan pa/ phyed sbrul gyi lus can 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la nges par rtog bzhin pa/ phyed chu'i nang du nub pa/ nor bu rin po che dang gos kyis nye bar mdzes pa bri bar bya'o/ / mtsho chen po de'i khor yug gi 'og tu ras ris kyi mtha'i grwa g.yas kyi gzhogs su sgrub pa po/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi zhabs kyi dkyil 'khor la nges par rtog bzhin pa lag na spos phor thogs pa lus dang pus mo'i lha nga 'dud pa/ cha byad dang kha dog ji lta ba bzhin du mngon par bri'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi steng du/ ras kyi mtha' gnyis su lha'i bu phreng ba 'dzin pa gnyis me tog gi phreng ba bzung nas nam mkha' la lding ba/ me tog gi tshogs chen po 'thor bar byed bzhin pa/ shin tu mdzes pa dag mngon par bri'o/ / ras ris de'i khor yug tu nA ga ge sar la sogs pa'i me tog rab tu bkram pa bri bar bya ste/ ji ltar 'dod pa'i gzugs gsum lhag par gnas pa'am/ mngon par bri'o/ /

That lotus stalk is as beautiful as a precious emerald and has many unopened, half-blossoming, and fully blossomed lotus flowers. The lotus stem rises out of a great lake. Its stem is held by the two nāga kings Nanda and Upananda who also emerge from the great Cool Lake (Anavatapta). Those two nāga kings are white in color, adorned with seven hoods, beautified with all ornaments, and marked with serpent hoods on their half-human, half-serpent bodies. Draw them half-immersed in the water, beautified with clothes and jewels, and reflecting upon Noble Avalokiteśvara. The practitioner is positioned sideways in the right corner at the edge of the painted cloth, below the circumference of that great lake. He examines the retinue at the feet of Noble Avalokiteśvara, lifts up an incense vessel in his hand, and his kneeling body bows. One should draw him with the proper clothing and color. Above Avalokiteśvara, at both corners of the cloth, one should depict two very beautiful Sons of the Gods (devaputra), holding up garlands, grasping flower garlands, suspended in the sky, and scattering large bunches of flowers. One should draw nāgagesara flowers, etc. all along the borders of the cloth.

'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa dang / 'phags pa kun du bzang po dang / 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje phyag na rnga yab thogs pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / sgrub pa po ji ltar 'dod pa'i gzugs gsum po rnams gdon mi za bar 'drir gzhug par bya ste ji ltar 'dod pa'i rnam pa dang / dbyibs ji ltar gnas pa bzhin du'am/ sgrub pa po ji lta ji ltar 'dod pa de lta de ltar bri bar bya'o/ / dbus su byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po/ mtha' gnyis su'ang / phyag na rdo rje dang / kun du bzang po ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du gdon mi za bar 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ji ltar rnyed pa'i ras kyi dum bu mtho gang ngam/ khru gang tsam la bdag nyid dam/ gzhan gyis sam/ ri mo mkhan gso sbyong med pa'am/ dad pa can nam/ gtsang ma'am/ mi gtsang ba'am/ tshul khrims dang ldan pa'am/ tshul khrims 'chal pa'ang rung ste/ ri mo mkhan gyis 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / sgrub pa po bdag nyid ni/ gdon mi za bar sngon spyad pa byas pa/ dad pas byang chub tu sems bskyed pa gdon mi za bar 'gyur bas te/ de ltar na sngags 'grub par 'gyur gyi gzhan du sdig pa byed pas nam yang ma yin no/ /

If desired, one may [solely] depict three bodily forms situated [in the painting]: Noble Avalokiteśvara as if teaching the Dharma, with Noble Samantabhadra and Noble Vajrapāṇi holding up yak tails. One should certainly depict these three forms in a desirable manner, and one should also depict the practitioner with whatever shape and aspect is desired. One should undoubtedly depict the Bodhisattva Great Being in the middle and Vajrapāṇi and Samantabhadra at the two edges according to one’s wishes. On a cotton cloth that is either a full span or a full cubit long, as desired, [the image] is to be drawn by an artist who is either oneself or another. Such an artist is one who has fasted or who hasn’t fasted, who is faithful or unfaithful, who is pure or impure, and who is moral or immoral. On the other hand, the practitioner should be properly prepared, faithful, and without a doubt, have generated the thought of enlightenment. The mantras shall never succeed for those who commit non-virtuous actions toward others.
de ltar dad par gyur pa yis/ / sngags kyi lha rnams bsgrub bya zhing // dad pa de yis gsang sngags rgyal/ / 'grub 'gyur 'dir ni gzhan du min/ /
The gods of the mantra are to be invoked By one who is faithful. The most excellent of secret mantras succeeds for One who has faith, not for another. [1]
gang phyir dad pa theg pa'i mchog / gang gis 'dren pa 'gro bar byed/ / dad pa med pa'i mi rnams la/ / dkar po'i chos rnams mi skye ste/ /
Those who have faith are drawn toward And abide by the excellent vehicle. Virtuous Dharmas do not arise In those people who lack faith, [2]
sa bon me yis tshig pa las/ / myu gu sngon po ji bzhin no/ / dad dang ldan pa'i mi rnams la/ / sangs rgyas las rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Just as new green shoots [cannot] sprout from seeds scorched by fire. The rituals of the Buddha shall succeed For people endowed with faith. [3]
lta rnams kun dang khyad par du/ / gsang sngags rnams ni thams cad ni/ / dad pa med na mi 'grub bo/ /
All the secret mantras [used to invoke] All the gods, in particular, Shall not succeed If one lacks faith. [4]
'jig rten pa yi lha rnams dang // gang yang 'jig rten 'das de bzhin/ / dad dang ldan par brjod pa dang // rnyog pa bral bas 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Stainless ones who express faith in Worldly gods as well as Those who have passed beyond the world, Shall be successful. [5]
yid ni byang chub der son pas/ / de rnams byang chub nges par 'grub/ / gzhan gyis 'grub par ma gsungs te/ / bstan pa 'di las zlog pa yin/ /
Those whose minds have awakened to that [thought of] enlightenment, Shall surely attain enlightenment. Success is not mentioned for others Who have turned away from this teaching. [6]
ras ris chung dang chen po dang // bar ma yongs su bsgrags pa yin/ / las rnams thams cad sgrub byed pa/ / de ni rab tu bshad par bya/ /
The cotton cloth that is either inferior, Mediocre, or distinguished has been extolled. I have now thoroughly explained The methods of accomplishing all the rituals. [7]

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde las bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi cho ga las ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam lnga pa rdzogs so// //
This completes the Fifth Extensive Ritual of the Painted Cloth from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-vaipulya-sūtra and from the [Fundamental] Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[mchog gi sgrub pa'i thabs kyi cho ga /las kyi 'bras bu drug pa]
Chapter B.6: The Fruits of Ritual Actions of the Superior Sādhana

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bka' stsal pa/ sems can chen po khyod kyis sems can de rnams kyi don gyi phyir bstan pa gang yin pa de rnams ras ris kyi cho ga rab 'byam bshad pa 'di thabs nyung ngu nyid kyis 'grub par 'gyur te de rnams kyi don gyi phyir sgrub par byed pa thabs yon tan rgyas pa rab tu dbye bas rnam par phye ba las rnam par dbye ba de yang dag par mthun par bshad par bya'i/ de legs par nyon la/ legs par yid la gyis shig sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir bshad par bya'o/ / de nas yang byang chub sems dpas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das bdag cag gis 'byor ba bstan par mdzad cing sngags kyi spyod pa'i yon tan sgrub pa'i mthu gsal bar mdzad pa legs par gsungs pa ni legs so/ / bcom ldan 'das gang da lta de'i dus la bab par dgongs nas bdag cag la thugs brtse ba'i slad du bka' stsal du gsol/ de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor la gzigs nas 'dzum pa mdzad do/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i zhal gyi sgo nas 'od zer sngon po dang / ser po dang / dkar po dang / btsod dang / shel gyi kha dog la sogs pa byung bar gyur to/ / 'od zer de byung ma thag tu thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor snang bar byas nas stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi gnas thams cad spa bkod par mdzad nas/ rgyu skar gyi 'od dang / ri'i lha'i tshogs kyi 'od dang / gang du zla ba dang nyi ma 'di ltar mthu che zhing rdzu 'phrul che ba de dag gi 'od kyang spa bkod par mdzad nas de rnams mi gsal zhing 'od med par gyur te rnam par snang bar mi 'gyur zhing spa bkong bar mdzad de nor bu dang sngags dang sman dang rin po che'i 'od thams cad med par byas nas slar yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i zhal gyi sgor nub par gyur to/ /

Then, the Bhagavan Śakyamuni spoke again to the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva Avalokiteśvara, “O Great Being! For the benefit of those living beings who are instructed by you, you shall explain the extensive ritual of the painted cloth. They will accomplish it, even with very little skillful means. For the purpose of those living beings, I shall harmoniously explain that division of rituals distinguished by extensive, excellent qualities, which are the means of performing the sādhana. Listen well and keep it carefully in mind! I shall explain it for the benefit of all living beings.” Then again, the Bodhisattva spoke to the Bhagavān, “O Bhagavān! That is excellent! These well-spoken words clarify for us the power of accomplishment, which has the virtuous activities of the mantra and supports our livelihood. O Bhagavān! Having considered that now is the time, we ask you to please speak [about these practices] out of compassion for us!” Then, the Bhagavān Śakyamuni looked at the entire circle of the assembly and smiled. After that, from Bhagavān Śakyamuni’s mouth emerged light rays the colors of blue, yellow, white, maroon, and crystal. As soon as those light rays appeared, they illuminated the entire circle of the assembly. Having outshone all the places of Māra in the billion world galaxy, they overpowered the light of the constellations and the assembly of mountain gods. They even outshone the light of the sun and the moon with their great, miraculous power. [Those celestial bodies] did not shine, nor emit any light. They were not visible, because they were overpowered [by those light rays]. Having made lustreless all the light of jewels, mantras, medicine, and precious things, once again [those light rays] sunk back into Bhagavān Śakyamuni’s mouth.
