dang po re zhig rig pa'i brtul zhugs dang / tshul khrims yang dag par blang ba dang po nyid du yang dag par blangs te/ dang po re zhig dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis nye bar bstan pa'i dam tshig la yang dag par rjes su 'jug par bya'o/ / khyod kyis rtog pa'i rgyal po gsungs pa/ sngar nges par bstan pa gsal ba/ yid gzhungs pa dang ldan pa/ slob dpon du dbang bskur ba thob pa/ khyod kyis bstan pa'i cho ga shes pa/ mkhas pa/ gsal ba/ chos dang ldan pa/ bden par smra ba/ spro ba che ba/ byas pa gzo ba/ brtan pa/ sems bzang pa/ ha cang mi rgan cing ha cang mi gzhon pa/ rnyed pa dang / bkur sti thams cad la 'dod pa med pa/ tshangs par spyod pa/ snying rje dang ldan pa/ rnyed pa tsam gyis sam longs spyod rgyur ram/ rjes su chags pa'i rgyur yang brdzun mi smra na/ shin tu chung ngu tsam nyid dang / rnyed pa dang / rmongs pa'i rnam pa lta smos/ dam bcas pa brtan pa dang / 'byung po thams cad la mnyam pa nyid du snying brtse ba dang ldan pa dang / sbyin pa dang tshul khrims dang / sngar spyad pa byas pa khyod kyi gsang ba'i rig pa dang / sngags rjes su zlos pa dang / rig pa sngon du bsnyen pa byas pa khyod kyi dkyil 'khor du yang dag par zhugs pa/ 'jig rten shes pa/ yang dag par rjes su 'dzin par byed pa/ 'bras bu dang ldan zhing mkhas pa/ legs pa la rab tu zhugs pa/ mi 'jigs shing mi gnod la/ chags pa med pa/ dpa' ba/ brtson 'grus brtan pa/ nad med pa ste/ nad gang gis las su mi rung ba'i ngang tshul can dang / rigs che zhing mtho bar rab tu skyes pa zhes pa/ yon tan 'di rnams dang ldan pa ni dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon du 'gyur te/

“At first, for a while, having accepted a vow of the vidyā and [practice of][808] morality, one should engage in the pledge instructed by the expert maṇḍala teacher. “[A person] who has been spoken about by you in the best of ritual texts, who has previously undergone a thorough religious education, possesses intelligence, has received initiation as a teacher, who is knowledgeable about the rituals of your doctrine, is distinctly skillful, virtuous, a truth-speaker, very enthusiastic, shows gratitude, is firm, good-hearted, neither too old nor too young, unattached to gain and respect, practices pure conduct, is compassionate, and does not speak lies for the causes of attachment and enjoyment, or even for the cause of a little profit. What needs to be said about those [who speak lies for] little profit, gain, or due to delusion? [One who] is firm in promises, possesses impartial compassion for all creatures, performs giving, morality, and preliminary practices, recites your secret vidyā and mantra, has performed previous service to the vidyā, is fully engaged in your maṇḍala, knows the world, is gracious, dutiful and skillful, is fully engaged in virtue, fearless and unharmed, without attachment, heroic, firm in effort, healthy, not having vulnerability to any illness that makes one’s disposition unsuitable for performing the rituals, and is well-born in a prominent family and of noble birth. Such a [person] who is endowed with these qualities shall become a maṇḍala teacher.

sgrub pa po yang de dang 'dra ba'am/ yan lag cung zad ma rdzogs pa'o/ / de lta bu'i dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon la mchod pa byas nas 'di'i don du gsol ba gdab par bya ste/ slob dpon gyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i rig pa dang sngags dang bcom ldan 'das ma de'i dkyil 'khor gyi dam tshig la rjes su 'jug par 'tshal na bdag cag la rjes su brtse ba'i don dang / phan pa'i thugs bskyed nas de slob dpon gyis gsung du gsol/ de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon gyis sngar bstan pa'i cho gas slob ma ji lta ba bzhin rim gyis brtags nas gzhug par bya zhing sngar bzhin du mngon par dbang bskur ba byin nas rig pa dang sngags byin la rim pa ji lta bar dam tshig bstan par bya'o/ / gsang chen dang / phyag rgya dang / rgyud dang / sngags dang las rnams kyang dus ring mo nyid nas yongs su brtags te/ bsam pa shes nas rgyud dang sngags la sogs pa dang / las rnams thams cad bstan par bya'o/ / gzhan du ma yin no zhes pa'i cho ga 'di rab tu bsgrags so/ / de nas slob mas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon la ji ltar nus pas gang gis slob dpon dgyes pa'am bdag nyid dang longs spyod kyang dbul bar bya'o/ / de nas dkyil 'khor gyi slob dpon des bu'i 'du shes nye bar gzhag par bya'o/ / bu bzhin du bskyang bar bya'o/ / ma bzhin longs spyod kyis nye bar bsdu bar bya'o/ /

“The practitioner (sādhaka) also [has qualities] similar to that or the elements of religious service (aṅga) will be deficient to a certain degree. In this way, having performed a worship ceremony for the maṇḍala teacher, a prayer should be performed for his benefit. The maṇḍala teacher, desiring to engage in the vidyā and mantra of the Bodhisatta Great Being, and the maṇḍala pledge of that Bhagavatī [Tārā], having generated compassion and the intention to benefit us, we request that the teacher please speak about that [ritual]. “Then, the maṇḍala teacher, with the ritual previously shown, having gradually examined the disciples, accordingly, should have them enter [the maṇḍala]. And, as before, having bestowed initiation, and upon bestowing the vidyā and mantra, he should gradually teach the pledge. For a long time, having thoroughly examined the Great Secret, mudrā, tantra, mantras, and the rituals, and knowledgeable about mental disposition, he should teach tantra, mantra, etc., all the rituals. This ritual has been proclaimed, and nothing else. “Then, the disciple should respectfully offer himself and enjoyment to the maṇḍala teacher, to the best of his ability, delighting the teacher through that. Subsequently, the maṇḍala teacher should consider [the disciple] as his own son, and protect him like a child. Like a mother, [the disciple] should be provided with sensual enjoyment.

de nas sgrub pa po des rig pa dang sngags gang yang rung ba zhig bzung nas mtha' gcig tu song ste/ sngar bstan pa'i gnas rgya cher gong ma bzhin du sbyar bas rig pa la sogs pa de rnams nyid kyis spyan drang ba dang / gshegs su gsol ba dang / mar me dang / dri dang / bdug pa dang / gtor ma dang / lha bshos dag dkyil 'khor du gsungs pa'i cho ga nyid kyis rgyas par byas te spyan drangs nas gdan phul ba thun mtshams gsum du khrus gsum bya zhing gos lan gsum brjes te nyi ma so so la bzlas pa bya'o/ / de la thun mtshams kyi dus zhes bya ba ni mtshan mo'i mtha' nas brtsams te ji srid nyi ma 'char ba'i dus tsam gyi bar 'di la dang por bshad do/ / nyi ma gung ni nyi ma shar ba'i mthar dus tsam gyi tshad kyi mtshams nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor nam mkha' la yang dag par brten pa ni cho ga shes pas gung gi thun mtshams su shes par bya'o/ / nub pa'i dus su yang lhag ma bzhi cha tsam thun mtshams gsum par brjod par bya'o/ /

“Then, that practitioner, having held in mind whatever vidyā and mantra, as is suitable, and having gone in solitude to a place previously instructed, should prepare [the ritual] extensively, as before. Using those vidyās, etc., [the disciple] should extensively perform the rituals spoken about for the maṇḍala, including the invitation and dismissal [of the gods], butter lamps, perfume, incense, sacrificial cakes, and [divine] food offerings. Having invited [the gods], offer [them] a seat. Having taken three baths at three junctures of the day and night,[809] and changed clothes three times, one should recite for each distinct [part of the] day. Then, at the time of the juncture [between day and night], having begun from the end of the night until about the time of the rising sun, this is explained as the first [juncture]. Regarding the midday noon sun, from the juncture [that begins] about the time of the end of the rising sun up until the time when the sun is a circle in the sky, the ritual-knower should know it as the juncture of the noonday [sun]. As well, one should recite during the third juncture, from the time of [the sun’s] disappearance [at sunset] up until the [beginning of] the remaining portion of the fourth watch.”
slob dpon mkhas pa bshes gnyen can/ / tshul khrims brtul zhugs yang dag ldan/ / chen po'i rigs su 'khrungs pa dang / / kun nas brtson 'grus brtan pa ni/ /
The knowledgeable, skillful teacher Devoted to morality and vows, Born into a noble lineage, Whose diligence is always firm. [1]
sngags dang rgyud sogs yang dag ldan/ / bya ba kun la blo gros byang / / phra zhing mkhas la tshad shes pa/ / chos kyi dbyings ni rtag tu 'dzin/ /
Absorbed in mantra and tantra, Wise and competent in all actions, Knowing the exact measure of subtle scholarship, Continuously occupied with the sphere of Dharma. [2]
spro ba che zhing gzi brjid ldan/ / 'jig rten chos la ltos pa med/ / thub pa mchog gi chos la dad/ / 'jig rten pa rnams dor ba dang / /
Possessed of great enthusiasm and brilliance, Unconcerned with worldly Dharma, Possessed of faith in the excellent ascetic’s Dharma, Rejecting all worldly things. [3]
bzlas pa bya zhing rnam dben byas/ / sngon du bsnyen pa rjes brten pa/ / byang chub sems dpa'i gsang sngags shes/ / de las gzhan pa'i rkyen rnams mthong / /
Recitation performed, knower of solitude, Firm in preliminary service, Knowing the mantras spoken by bodhisattvas; Due to this, he sees the conditions of others. [4]
sangs rgyas kyis gsungs gsang sngags dang / / 'jig rten pa yi rab sbyor shes/ / srung ba byas shing mthu brtan pa/ / gtsang sbra'i kun spyod la rtag dga'/ /
Knowing the uses of worldly and Secret mantras spoken by the Buddha, Protection performed, firm in strength, and Always delighting in conduct of moral purity, [5]
sangs rgyas nye bstan lam la ni/ / kun nas rjes su 'jug pa dang / / gsang sngags rgyal bas gsungs pa yin/ / gsang sngags zlos la rtag tu brtson/ /
Continually engaged in the path Shown by the Buddha, Always diligent in the recitation of secret mantras Spoken about and praised by the Conqueror. [6]

rtag tu mthong chos 'bras bu dang / / 'jig rten pha rol de bzhin nyid/ / sdig pa kun la 'jigs pa dang / / phra mo tsam la'ang de bzhin no/ / gtsang zhing mkhas la le lo med/ / yid gzhungs blta na sdug pa dang / /

Fearful of all non-virtuous actions, Even the most subtle [of defilements], The results of which always ripen In the present life and the next life. Pure, wise, and energetic, A sage with pleasing appearance. [7]

stobs bcu pas bshad sngags gang dang / / de bzhin kho nar rgyal sras dang / / 'jig rten pa yi sngags gang nyid/ / rdo rje pad+ma'i rigs dag la'ang / / de la rtag tu ngal bar byas/ / gzhung dang bstan bcos don 'dzin pa/ /

One whose mantras are explained by Daśabala,[810] As well as the Sons of the Conqueror, Whose worldly mantras belong to The Lotus and Vajra families, and Who continually devotes effort to them, Comprehends the meaning of scriptures and commentary. [8]
nad med nus pa med min pa/ / rga dang nad ni rnam par spangs/ / de bzhin bshes gnyen can sngags grub/ / kun nas myur du byed pa dang / /
Lacking disease, not powerless, Shunning old age and illness, One who is endowed with knowing, Always quickly accomplishes the mantras. [9]
mtha' yi ring min zhing de bzhin/ / tshangs par spyod cing shes rab che/ / khyad par du ni shes pa dang / /
He does not procrastinate, and likewise, Has little pride, skillfully interpets body language,[811] Observes celibacy, has great insight, And is particularly intelligent. [10]
gcig tu 'du 'dzi med pa dang / / dpa' zhing dbang bskur thob pa dang / / de 'dir byang chub pha rol son/ / srid pa zhi bar byed la brtson/ / de bzhin nyid du rig sngags bya/ /

[Living] alone, without hustle and bustle, Heroic, initiation received, Having gone to the other side of enlightenment, here, He is diligent in pacifying rebirth. Just so, the vidyā-mantras performed.[812] [11]
mthu chen 'jig rten shes pa dang / / 'gro ba sems can rjes sems pa/ / dpal nyid dang ni rab tu ldan/ / sbyin dang 'byung po phan la dga'/ /
Powerful and knowledgeable about the world, Thinking about living beings and [their] destinies, Endowed with excellent resources. Giving and delighting in the benefit of living creatures. [12]
de bzhin khyad 'phags slob dpon la/ / rtag tu gsol ba gdab par bya/ / des ni dkyil 'khor bris pa yi/ / sngags kyi dngos grub ster bar byed/ /
Thus, prayers should always be performed For this especially noble teacher, For that one shall bestow the attainments of the mantra Belonging to the painted maṇḍala. [13]
de nyid kyis ni dbang bskur gyis/ / 'bras bu chen po sbyin par 'gyur/ / dngos grub 'dod pa'i slob mas kyang / / thub pa bzhin du rtag tu mchod/ /
The initiation given by that one Will bestow abundant fruitfulness. That one is always worshipped as a sage By students who desire attainment. [14]
de yi gsung ni mi 'gom pa/ / slob mas 'bad pas bya ba yin/ / ji ltar 'byor cing bdog pa yi/ / longs spyod de la dbul bar bya/ /
His words should not be disregarded, But carried out with effort by students. Similarly, one’s own possessions and enjoyment Should be offered to this [teacher]. [15]
nyung ngu tsam mam mang yang rung / / gang gis mnyes par 'gyur ba dang / / lus ni 'tsho ba'i rgyu yi phyir/ / pha la nor ni ster ba ltar/ /
[Offer] very little or a lot, as is appropriate, Through which he will be delighted. Just as [a child] bestows wealth[813] to one’s father, For one’s body is the main condition for life, [16]
de bzhin slob ma chos shes pas/ / slob dpon la ni nor dbul bya/ / mtha' yi dbang phyug dngos grub thob/ / tshe dang de bzhin nad med dang / / rgyas pa'i 'gro ba thob par 'gyur/ /
Similarly, a student who is a Dharma-knower, Who offers wealth to the teacher, Achieves the attainments of glory,[814] And shall achieve health, vitality, And a life of prosperity. [17]
slob mas bla ma de mchod na/ / de yi sngags rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ / lam dang cho ga nyer mthong dang / / bsnyen pa las kyang brten pa las/ /
When the student worships that guru, Through that, the mantras will be successful. Through seeing the path and the rituals, and From serving and propitiating. [18]
de bzhin ri mor byas mchod las/ / sangs rgyas thams cad dgyes par 'gyur/ / de bzhin rgyal mchog sras rnams dang / / lha rnams thams cad dgyes par 'gyur/ /
As well as, from honoring and worshipping All the Buddhas shall be delighted, In the same way, the Sons of the Excellent Conqueror and All the Gods shall be pleased. [19]
bla ma rtag tu bsnyen bkur na/ / bla ma sngags rnams mthong ba yis/ / 'di dag thams cad brtan par 'gyur/ /
While continuously venerating the guru, All that shall be explained,[815] By the gurus who perceive the mantras. [20]
sgrub pos sngon dang thog mar ni/ / dam tshig la ni rjes 'jug bya/ / dman nam de dag mnyam yang rung / / gal te ches mchog gyur pa yang / /
In the beginning, as before, the practitioner Should engage in the pledge. Whether [the practitioners] are inferior, equal, or even superior, [21]
rmongs pa'am lhag par khro ba yis/ / rtag tu bla ma brnyas mi bya/ / des kyang rgyud 'dir de la ni/ / man ngag rtag tu sbyin par bya/ /
The guru should never be disrespected Due to [a practitioner’s] foolishness or anger.[816] That [teacher] should always give Religious instruction on that tantra. [22]
gang tshe sngags kyi dngos grub byin/ / 'dis ni ser sna byas pa min/ / sngar bstan slob ma de la ni/ /
When bestowing the mantra’s powers, A student who was formerly instructed Should not be stingy due to that. [23]
man ngag rtag tu sbyin par bya/ / gang tshe sngags kyi dngos grub byin/ / lus can zhen pa 'phel byed pa'i/ / mig ni gang la yod gyur pa/ / de nyid slob ma nyid bya'o/ /
One who possesses an eye Of increasing affection for living beings — Make that one your student. [24]
slob dpon nam ni slob ma'i rgyur/ / phan tshun rjes su 'jug byed pa/ / gang du zhen pa'i rgyun skyong ba/ / 'jam po'i rgyun ni 'dzin pa ste/ / de la sngags ni sbyin par bya/ /
The causes for teacher or disciple are When they display mutual respect, Protecting the continuity of affection, And upholding the stream of tender love, At that time, bestow the mantra. [25]
slob dpon de bzhin slob ma ni/ / slob ma bla mar mthong ba la/ / rtag tu spro bar 'gyur ba'am/ / gnyis kas dngos grub yang dag 'byor/ /
When teacher views disciple, And disciple views the guru, While continually enthusiastic, They help one another acquire siddhi. [26]
de la rtag tu lam nyid dang / / sngags kyi spyod pa rjes bstan bya/ / gnyis kas pha dang bur shes pas/ / sngags ni 'bras bcas rjes 'jug pa/ /
The activities of the mantra and the path Should always be shown to them. By recognizing each other as parent and child, The mantra will be fruitful. [27]
brtan dang dga' ba de bzhin thob/ / rtag tu slob mas bla ma ni/ / rab tu 'bad pas bsrung bar bya/ / bu ni bdag nyid chen po rnams/ /
Similarly, while those two attain firmness and joy, The student who always protects the guru With excellent effort, Is an offspring of Great Beings (mahātma).[817] [28]
sangs rgyas chos rgyun mi 'chad 'gyur/ / de med mgon med de rnams la/ / ji skad gsungs pa'i sngags rnams sbyin/ /
The Buddhas’ Stream of Dharma shall not be interrupted. Bestow the above-mentioned mantras To those who are protectorless And bereft of that [Dharma]. [29]
sems can bkren dang ma ning la'ang / / thams cad la ni khyad par du/ / sngags kyi spyod pa khyad par 'phags/ /
For all living beings, especially Those who are impoverished and powerless, The mantra’s practices are superior. [30]
tha ma mchog dang bar ma la/ / dus rnams kun tu bya ba'o/ / yongs su thob pa'i chos rnams la/ / rjes su gzung ba'i rgyun bya'o/ /
At all times, perform Small, middling, and superior [practices]. For those who have received the Dharma, [Mantras] are performed to show favor. [31]
'gro ba blo gros nges pa yi/ / 'dod pa rnams la'ang rab sbyin bya/ / de phyir ji ltar 'dod pa'i sngags/ / slob ma nyid kyis blang bar bya/ /
Impart them also to those who desire Certainty of knowing their destiny.[818] For that purpose, the disciple Shall receive desirable mantras. [32]
de nyid kyis ni nyer bstan pas/ / lam nyid yin no gzhan du min/ / dngos grub 'dod pas gang de la/ /
Those who desire attainment (siddhi), When others have gone to the other side [of enlightenment],[819] [Should go] by means of the path That has been shown, not another. [33]
pha ni pha rol song ba na/ / pha bzhin mgo bos phyag byas te/ / de nas ji ltar 'dod par 'gro/ / de nas 'dir ni song nas ni/ / mnyam par bzhag pas gsang sngags bzlas/ /
Like a father, bow down [eagerly][820] and Go [alone] according to your desire. Then, having gone to an isolated place,[821] Recite secret mantras one-pointedly. [34]
slong mo slong ba'i rjes 'jug cing / / smra ba bcad de dus gsum bzlas/ / de ltar bstan pa nyid du 'gyur/ / ji lta'i lam la rab 'jug pa/ /
After begging for alms, Recite three times silently. Just as was [previously] shown, One should set out on the path. [35]
de tshe rnam 'gyur de gcod pa/ / khang stong dang ni dgon pa che/ / ri bo che dang chu klung ngogs/ / gtsang dang ba lang gnas mtsho chen/ /
At that time, engage in service in a sacred place.[822] Whether an empty home, wilderness solitude, A mountain peak,[823] a pure river bank, A cowbarn, or a great lake, [36]
rnam dben skye bo spangs pa bsten/ / lha khang dang ni shing drung dang / / mtshan gcig ri ni mthon po dang / / rgya mtsho che 'gram nyams dga' dang / /
Serve in solitude, avoiding living beings. In the [empty] home of a god,[824] beneath a tree, Beside an image of Śiva (ekaliṅga), a high boulder, A pleasant ocean shoreline, [37]
chu gling ngam ni gling rnams dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs sngar bstan pa'i/ / yul rnams sna tshogs yid 'ong ba/ / 'di rnams las kyang phyogs gzhan du/ / mnyam par bzhag pas sngags bzlas bya/ /
On a tiny river islet, or Bigger islands of various kinds, or Entirely pleasing lands formerly shown. One who concentrates should recite the mantra In these and other places. [38]
grogs po mtshan nyid ldan pa ni/ / sngags don nges pa'i rtog ge pa/ / ltas ni rnam pa de nyid shes/ / dpa' zhing g.yul las rnam rgyal ba/ /
A friend endowed with distinctive marks, A logician of ethics and the meaning of mantras, Knowing the true nature of various omens, Heroic, and victorious in battle, [39]
snying stobs ldan zhing bzod pa can/ / dad dang tshul khrims phun tshogs ldan/ / rgyal bas gsungs pa'i yul 'dir ni/ / rab bsngags mtshan nyid dang ldan pa/ /
Possessing courage and tolerance,[825] Endowed with faith and perfect morality, In this country[826] spoken about by the Victor, Possessed of the same praiseworthy signs, [40]
bzod dang ldan pa'i grogs po yis/ / 'bad pa med par nyid kyis ni/ / las rnams rgyal ba 'grub par 'gyur/ /
With this patient companion, Even without effort on his or her part, All the rituals will be successful. [41]
tho rangs mal nas langs nas ni/ / 'bab chu mtsho chen las byung ba'i/ / srog chags med cing dri ma med/ / chu de nyid la khrus byas nas/ /
Having arisen at dawn, and Having bathed in that same water that Lacks insects and odors and is Produced from a waterfall or a great lake, [42]
sa dang ba byung phye ma yis/ / sngags shes lus ni dril phyis bya/ / de nas sngags kyis sbyang byas pa'i/ / chu nyid shin tu dri med la/ /
The mantra-knower’s body should be rubbed and Ritually cleaned with soil, cow products, and sand. Then, in the same odorless water Purified with mantras, [43]
zlos po brtson pas khrus bya'o/ / ha cang yun ring khrus mi bya/ / de nas langs la lag pa dag / sa dag gis kyang bkru bar bya/ /
The reciter should bathe diligently. He should bathe neither too short nor too long. Then, having stood up [on the shore],[827] He should cleanse both hands with fresh earth. [44]
bdun dang bdun dang yang lan bdun/ / nyi shu rtsa gcig nye reg bya/ / yang der so shing kun du spyad/ / so sbyangs nas ni dor bar bya/ /

Touch [the hands closely to the earth] seven and seven, And again seven times, twenty-one [altogether]. Then, use a toothpick to cleanse [the teeth] thoroughly. Having cleansed the teeth, throw it out. [45]
de nas skyob la phyag byas shing / / 'jig rten mgon la phyag byas nas/ / sngags rig mchod pa yid 'ong bya/ / bya ba sna tshogs bstod mchod kyis/ /
After that, having solicited protection, and Having made salutations to the world protector, The mantra-knower makes a pleasant worship ceremony With offerings and praises of various kinds. [46]
yang dang yang du yang dag bstod/ / de bzhin dri zhim me tog gis/ / ston pa skyob la mchod yon dbul/ / sangs rgyas rnams la mgos phyag byas/ /
Having praised thoroughly, again and again, In this way, with fragrant flowers Make offerings to the Teacher and Protector, And bow down to the Buddhas.[828] [47]
de tshe slob mar gyur pa rnams/ / 'jig rten mgon po de rnams kyi/ / spyan snga nyid du sdig pa bshags/ / bdag nyid dag kyang phul byas nas/ /
At that time, those who are disciples, Expiate their sins [by repenting] Before those World Protectors, Having offered themselves up [to them]. [48]
ras ris spyan sngar 'khod par bya/ / ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug / sngags rig gnyis ka 'dug nas ni/ / mtshan nyid ji lta ba bzhin te/ /
Becoming seated before the painted cloth, Sitting on a kuśa grass mat, Both mantra-knowers became seated According to the essence of the ritual. [49]
der ni bgrang phreng nyid kyis ni/ / rab tu 'bad pas bzlas pa bya/ / de tshe sngags gzhan mi bzlas so/ /
There, using the same string of recitation beads, One should recite with right effort. Do not recite other mantras at that time. [50]
cho ga dman pa yang spang zhing / / ha cang mchog kyang de bzhin no/ / bar ma bar ma'i las dag la/ / brtul zhugs can dag sngags bzlas bya/ /
Abandoned inferior rituals, as well as Those that are excessively superior. Those who observe vows should recite mantras From the rituals of middling quality. [51]
ha cang mthon po spang bar bya/ / gal te tshig ni dman pa'ang min/ / bar ma bar ma'i las rnams la/ / rab tu bsngags par rgyal bas gsungs/ /
Abandon saying the mantra too loudly, Or in a voice that is too quiet, The rituals of middling quality, Are recommended as best by the Conqueror. [52]
ha cang mtho min dma' ba min/ / bar mar rtag tu bzlas pa bya/ / sngon gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyis/ / tshig ni dpal dang ldan par gsungs/ /
Neither excessively high nor too low, One should always recite [mantras of] middling quality. [These] words, possessed of glory, Have been spoken by all the former Buddhas. [53]
gzhan gyi drung du mi bzlas shing / / gzhan gyi las lam rtag tu gsang / / bdag nyid rig pa'i yul du bzlas/ /
Therefore, do not recite in the presence of others. Always conceal the path from others. Recite in the land of your own understanding [in secret].[829] [54]
sngags ni bar ma de bzhin du/ / bzlas pas rab tu 'byor bar 'gyur/ / sngags ni legs par thos pa 'ga'/ / dngos grub 'bring po 'dod pa nyid/ / sngags ni dge bar bzlas par bya/ /
One should apply the mantra, By reciting [it] in a moderate [voice]. Whoever has heard the mantra’s meaning, And wishes for middling attainments, Should virtuously recite the mantra. [55]
de phyir skye bo dang bral bar/ / sngags kyi de nyid don legs thos/ / tshogs dang bral zhing rnam dben par/ / zlos pa pos ni sngags bzlas bya/ /
Due to that, dwell apart from people, and Listen well to the meaning of the mantra’s true nature. Living free from crowds, in solitude, The reciter should mutter the mantra. [56]
mtshan mo yi ni bzhi cha dang / / de yi phyed kyi phyed nyid kyi/ / skya rengs dmar po'i dus tsam ste/ / nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor shar ba na/ /
During the fourth part of the night, Belonging to [the last] quarter of that [stage], At the time of the copper-red dawn, When the circle of the sun is rising, [57]
thun ni dang por re bzhin du/ / thub pa'i skyes mchog gis gsungs so/ / dus kyi tshad ni bzhi yin te/ / bar mar yongs su bsgrags pa yin/ /
At daybreak, accordingly, The Wise, Excellent Person explained. During four units of time, The middling [mantra] was fully proclaimed. [58]
de nas nyi ma phyed nub na/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa de tshe btang / / sngags zlos bor ba de yi tshe/ / mchod yon phul nas gshegs su gsol/ /
Then, once half the sun has set, When it’s time to abandon mantra recitation, At that time, the mantra reciter Presents an offering and dismisses [the deity]. [59]
brtul zhugs can gyis rnam gzhan spang / / de tshe bor ba'i gdugs lhag na/ / thub pa'i bstan la dge ba bya/ / shes rab pha rol phyin la sogs/ /
The vow holder, having abandoned other [activities], Devotes any remaining time To performing virtuous actions such as [reading] The Sage’s teachings, the Prajñāpāramitā, etc. [60]
dam pa'i chos ni klog pa dang / / sa bcu pa yi glegs bam ni/ / mchod dang klog pa rtag tu'o/ /
Read the holy Dharma and A volume of the ten [Bodhisattva] stages, Continually worship and read. [61]
de nas dus la bab gyur na/ / rang sngags sngags kyi mgon po dang / / thub pa skyes mchog phyag byas nas/ / de nas 'tsho ba la 'gro zhing / /
Then, when the time arrives, make salutations to The Mantra Lord of one’s own mantra and The Wise, Excellent Person. After that, go to work. [62]
de bzhin dus su spyod par ldan/ / dus su za zhing dbang po thul/ / sgrub po chos dang ldan pa dang / / sangs rgyas bstan la rab dad brtson/ /
Similarly, in time, become active, eat, and subdue the senses. The practitioner — endowed with Dharma, Who is diligent, and has faith in the Buddha’s Teachings — [63]
grong gzhan du ni 'jug pa na/ / mi smra gtsang sbra spyod la dga'/ / sems can rtag tu chos ldan pa'i/ / khyim du bsod snyoms dag la 'jug /
When entering another village, such a reciter Remains silent, delights in the practice of purity, and Enters for alms into the homes of People who are always religious. [64]

zlos po srog chags med pa'i chu/ / tshos par grub pa gtsang mar 'dod/ / yang dag lta ba phun sum tshogs/ / sangs rgyas bstan la rab tu dad/ / de lta'i khyim du rtag tu ni/ / bsod snyoms don du slong mo blang / /

Wishing for water devoid of insects And pure, well-cooked [food], The alms seeker should accept the alms In a home [whose inhabitants] always Have right views, prosperity, and Right faith in the Buddha’s teachings. [65]
dper na brtson pas go bgos te/ / nyam nga'i yul du rab tu 'jug / rtag tu dgra ni 'joms par byed/ / dgra rnams kyis gzhom mi nus pa/ /
For example, just as a diligent [warrior] Dons armor when he enters a serious battle, Always destroys the enemy, and Cannot be defeated by the enemy, [66]
de bzhin sngags pa slong mos 'tsho/ / rtag tu grong du 'jug pa na/ / de bzhin chags par 'os pa yi/ / gzugs sgra mthong na mi dge ba/ /
In the same way, the mantra practitioner living by alms, Upon entering a village, Always sees sounds and forms causing attachment That are not virtuous! [67]
'dod chags zhi ba'i don gyi phyir/ / mi sdug dge ba bsgom par bya/ / lang tsho'i rnam pas brgyan pa yi/ / bud med lus ni mthong nas kyang / /
For the purpose of pacifying attachment, That one should meditate on the virtue of ugliness. Having seen the body of a [man or a] woman Ornamented with the aspects of youth, therefore, [68]
smad cing rul ba'i lus rnams ni/ / srin bus zos shing dur khrod gnas/ / lus kyi mi rtag sdug bsngal ba/ / mi gtsang dri mi zhim par bsgom/ /
Meditate on putrid bodies soiled by urine, etc., Situated in a cemetery and consumed by worms, Bodies that are impermanent and suffering, Unclean, and exuding an unpleasant odor. [69]
gang la byis pa rmongs pa yi/ / 'gro ba lnga por 'gro zhing 'khor/ / las kyi srad bus brgyus pa ni/ / yun ring dus su mya ngan byed/ /
When childish people circle and Wander in the five destinies, Stitched together by the thread of karma, It causes suffering for a long time. [70]
mi shes sgrib pas rmongs pa ni/ / dmus long sdug bsngal rgyu can no/ / gang du blo ni phyin ci log / chags pas skye bo phongs par 'gyur/ /
Ignorant ones, deluded by moral defilement, and Born blind, possess the cause of suffering. When their minds have wrong views, due to attachment, They will become destitute. [71]
rnam pa sna tshogs las lam gyis/ / rnam pa du mar chags gyur pa/ / ring nas khyogs kyis 'gro ba ni/ / 'gro dang 'ong ba spyod par byed/ /
Due to karmic paths of various kinds, They will become attached in many ways, For a long time, they will live mounted on a palanquin, Which controls their coming and going. [72]
rtag pa nyid phyir rjes chags pa/ / 'dzin pa'i kun du spyod pa spyod/ / gang du sems can mi dge dga'/ / lam du yun ring rgyu bar byed/ /
Perpetually attached, Behaving with habitual grasping, When living beings delight in non-virtue, It makes them wander for a long time on the path. [73]
zo chun khyud mo'i rnam pa bzhin/ / srid pa'i mtsho chung 'byung ba rnams/ / 'gro ba de rnams mi bzad pa'i/ / sdug bsngal chu bos kun du g.yengs/ /
Those born in the sea of transmigration, Similar in form to the rim of a water mill, Waft to and fro with the waters of suffering, Unbearable for those beings. [74]
de bzhin bud med sdug bsngal gyi/ / rtsa ba 'ba' zhig yin pa ru/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' dang / / de bzhin nyan thos rang rgyal dang / / thub pa rnams kyis gsungs pa yin/ /
Accordingly, [attachment to the opposite sex][830] is The only root of suffering. This has been spoken about by the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Śrāvakas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sages. [75]
srid pa'i rgya mtsho mi 'khrugs pa'i/ / mtsho chen 'di dag bskam par dka'/ / bud med sems kyis bslus pa yi/ / sems can gnas gang bying ba de/ /
The unassailable ocean of existence Whose waters are difficult to desiccate, Is where living beings are drowning, Seduced by the thoughts of [men or] women. [76]
dmyal ba dud 'gro'i 'jig rten dang / / yi dgas 'jig rten lha ma yin/ / de bzhin mi yi 'jig rten nyid/ / lha yi 'gro bar 'gro bar bya/ /

They will go to the hell realm, the world realm of the animals, The world realm of hungry ghosts and [that] of the demi-gods. Similarly, they will go to the world realm of human beings, And the destiny of the gods. [77]
rtag tu kun nas yongs su 'khor/ / bud med chags pas bslus pa ni/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho btson ra yi/ / 'dam rdzab chen por bying bar 'gyur/ /
Continually wandering, Seduced by attachment to [men or] women, They will drown in a filthy swamp, Imprisoned in the ocean of existence. [78]
bud med chags pa'i blun po'i mi/ / ro la chags pa'i ce spyang bzhin/ / gang la sems can rtag dga' ba/ / mi bzad sdug bsngal bzod par byed/ /
Foolish men are attached to women, As jackals are attached to the taste [of dead bodies]. When living beings are fondly attached in a perpetual manner, They endure unbearable suffering. [79]
dkar po chos la nges par nyams/ / sangs rgyas bstan la rab tu gnas/ / srid pa'i mtsho yi sdug bsngal nyid/ / thams cad zlog par byed pa yin/ /
When the virtuous Dharma is declining[831] Engage in the Buddha’s teachings To ward off all suffering In the ocean of existence. [80]
sngags zlos pa la dga' zhing brtson/ / dbang cher grags shing yid dang ldan/ / gzi brjid ldan zhing sngags thub pa/ / de rnams la ni sdug bsngal med/ /
Delighting in and striving to recite mantras, Powerful, renowned, intelligent, Heroic, whose foes are conquered,[832] Those [people] have no suffering. [81]
yang dag sdom dang tshags bden shes/ / bla ma lha ma mchod pa byed/ / ma dang pha la gus pa rnams/ / gsum po rnams la sdug bsngal med/ /
Those who respect mother and father, Have moral restraint and knowledge of the truth of Brahmā,[833] Worship the gods and the guru — Those three have no suffering. [82]
mi rtag sdug bsngal stong pa dang / / gzhan gyi don la rjes su bsnyen/ / bud med lus la 'byung po'i gzugs/ / de bzhin 'bras dang zug rngu dang / /
Impermanent, painful, empty, Serving the interests of others, [Imagine] a woman’s [or a man’s] body with a ghost’s form, Afflicted with boils. [83]
blo ngan phung po'i lcags kyus zin/ / 'khor ba las ni mi 'da' ba/ / rtag tu bud med chags gyur pa/ / de la dngos grub yod pa min/ /
The evil-minded, consumed by the iron hook of the aggregates,[834] Does not escape saṃsāra, Always attached to [men or] women, That one will not have attainments (siddhi). [84]
de la mchog 'gro yod ma yin/ / 'gro ba 'bring yang yod ma yin/ / dngos grub chung ngu'ang yod ma yin/ / 'dir ni zlos po khrims 'chal na/ /
That one will not have a higher destiny,[835] Nor a middling destiny,[836] Nor even a tiny attainment,[837] In the case when the reciter is immoral. [85]
tshul khrims 'chal la thub dbang gis/ / sngags kyi dngos grub ma bstan to/ / mya ngan 'das grong 'gro ba yi/ / lam yang med cing phyogs dang bral/ /
The Lord of Sages[838] does not show immoral ones The attainments of the mantra. Lost, they lack a direction and a path Leading to the city of nirvāṇā. [86]
'dir ni byis pa smad pa la/ / sngags grub pa ni ga la yod/ / skye bo tshul 'chal 'di la ni/ / de la bde 'gro'ang yong ma yin/ /
When [an immoral person] is childish and despised, How can the mantras be successful? In this case, an immoral person Will not even experience happiness. [87]
bde ba nyid la gzhol ba'ang med/ / de bzhin rgyal bas gsungs pa'i sngags/ / grub par 'gyur ba smos ci dgos/ /

Since [immoral ones] will not reach the highest heaven, Nor be absorbed in happiness, What needs to be said about [their achieving] the success of the mantras Spoken accordingly by the Conqueror? [88]
ta la'i shing gi mgo bo ni/ / gang tshe bcad na slar yang ni/ / sngon po nyid du mi 'gyur zhing / / myu gu slar yang nam zhig 'gyur/ /
When the top of a Palmyra tree Is cut, again and again, It will not become green again, and New shoots will never reappear. [89]
de bzhin sngags grub rmongs pa ni/ / tshul khrims 'chal zhing sdig pa'i las/ / rtag tu slar yang bud med chags/ / mi dge'i grogs dang phrad pa la/ / sngags kyi rgyal po ga la 'grub/ /

Similarly, for one who is deluded by the mantra’s attainments, Immoral and sinful in actions, Always fondly attached to women, and Involved with non-virtuous friends, How can even the best of mantras succeed? [90]
de bas gang tshe zlos pa po/ / bde bar gshegs pas spangs pa yi/ / bud med nyes pa rnams spyad de/ / gang gi dngos grub bsgrub bya ste/ /
Due to that, when the mantra reciter Has examined the faults of women [or men],[839] Rejected by the Sugata, Their attainments are accomplished. [91]
byis pa bud med la rmongs pa/ / gzhan gyis grub par ma bstan no/ / de nas dang por blo ldan pa/ / gtsang zhing 'du 'dzi med la dga'/ /
The attainments of others who are Childish, infatuated with women [or men], are not discussed [in this text]. Therefore, at first, an intelligent one Should delight in purity and quietude.[840] [92]
rigs ldan brtan zhing dpa' ba dang / / sems bzang ldan zhing mthong na dga'/ / chos dang chos min rnams dpyod shes/ / de rnams grub pa rnyed mi dka'/ /
Those of good lineage, strong, brave, Good-hearted and attractive, Able to discriminate righteousness from unrighteousness, For them, attainments are not difficult to acquire.[841] [93]
de ltar sngags shes zhugs pa ni/ / grong du bsod snyoms phyir du 'jug / ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin song nas/ / sngar ni brtags pa'i gnas dag tu/ /
In this way, the mantra-knower proceeds by Entering a village for the purpose of alms, Having gone wherever he likes, To places previously examined. [94]
mkhas pas dag pa'i blos bza' ba/ / bza' ba phyogs su bzhag nas ni/ /
Having settled in a place to eat, The wise one eats with a pure mind. [Having placed the food in a pure place, The pure-minded one lives on alms.][842] [95]
phyi rol song nas rkang pa bkru/ / de nas slar yang gnas de ru/ / srog chags med pa'i chu rnams kyis/ / dang po 'dren pa nyid yin te/ /
Having gone outside that dwelling Bathed the feet, then [bathe] once again, Using water without bugs, First, [wash] the calves. [96]
gnyis pa la ni lag g.yon gyis/ / rked pa man chad dril phyis bya/ / kun du g.yas pa slar byin nas/ / lag pas yis bkru bar bya/ /
Second, with the left hand, [Rub and wipe the calves again].[843] Having performed that again with the right [hand], Cleanse the hand with fresh earth. [97]
sngar bzhag pa yi dag pa dang / / gtsang ma rnams kyi bdun nyid du/ / bza' zhing dag chus gtsang sbrar byas/ /
Ritually purified as previously established With seven cleanings, and [Purified with mantras,][844] Be cleansed with pure water and food. [98]
ser skya'i ba las byung ba yi/ / ba yi lci ba ser po dag / gtsang zhing dri med snod blang la/ / srog chags med pa'i chus sbyar te/ /
Having taken fresh cow dung Produced by a light-brown cow Combine it with water devoid of insects, In a clean, odorless vessel.[845] [99]
dang por ston pa thub pa yi/ / mchog la dkyil 'khor bya ba yin/ / khyad par khru gang tsam du 'o/ / gnyis pa rang sngags mgon po la/ / gsum pa rigs kyi lha mo la/ /
First, make a maṇḍala for The Most Excellent, Capable Teacher. It should be a full cubit in size. The second is for the Lord of one’s own mantra, and The third is for the goddess of the family. [100]
gang zhig sngags pa zlos pa po/ / slar yang rtag tu bya ba yin/ / bzhi pa sems can thams cad kyi/ / nye bar longs spyod don du grags/ /
Whichever the mantra, The reciter should perform it repeatedly, as before. The fourth [maṇḍala] is praised for the purpose of The enjoyment of all living beings. [101]
g.yas su 'jig rten mgon po yi/ / dkyil 'khor 'di ni rtag tu bya/ / dkon mchog gsum gyi ched du ni/ / dkyil 'khor de ni gru bzhi pa'o/ /
On the right, always make The maṇḍala of the world protectors. That maṇḍala has four [corners],[846] For the purpose of the three jewels. [102]
gnyis pa rang sangs rgyas rnams dang / / gsum pa stobs bcu ldan pa'i sras/ / dkyil 'khor bdun po 'di dag ni/ / kun nas gru bzhi pa ru'o/ /
The second is for the Prateyekabuddhas. The third is for the sons of Daśabala [Buddha]. These seven maṇḍalas Are entirely square. [103]
khru gang ngam ni khru phyed rung / / nyin re zhing yang bya ba'o/ / zlos pos de tshe sbas pa'i phyogs/ / sdig pa 'joms byed nyin re bzhin/ /
Every day, one should make them A cubit or half a cubit, as is appropriate. At that time, in a hidden place, the reciter Should destroy defilements daily. [104]
de nas sngags pa thub pa langs/ / lag gnyis 'bad pas bkrus nas ni/ / gtsang ma'i chu yis nye reg bya/ / dag cing srog chags spangs pa yi/ /
Then, the capable mantra reciter should stand up, Diligently wash both hands, and Sprinkle them with clean water That is pure and devoid of living beings. [105]
dri ma med pa'i gtsang ma ni/ / 'bad pas gtsang ma'i snod du blang / / mtsho chen dang ni 'bab chu'am/ / chu mig chu bo la gnas pa/ /
Having taken a vessel that is cleansed with effort, Place it, stainless and clean, In a great lake, waterfall, Spring or river. [106]
gtsang ma'i phyogs nas byung ba yi/ / sems can gtsang ma lag gis bcus/ / sngags pas slar yang nye reg bya/ / gnyis sam gsum du rtag tu yang / /
By hand, a pure person should scoop up [The water] produced in a clean place. The mantra reciter should be sprinkled again, Two or three [times], continuously. [107]
de nas kha la reg bya zhing / / de bzhin nyid du rna ba'i rgyun/ / mig dang sna yi bu ga dang / /
Then, rinse the mouth, and Similarly, continuously sprinkle the ears, The eyes, the nostrils, both arms, [108]
spyi bo lte ba'i phyogs reg bya/ / dge ba spyod pas lan lnga'am bdun/ / cho ga bzhin du thams cad bya/ /
The head, and the navel area. With this virtuous practice, [sprinkling][847] five or seven times, One should perform all rituals in this way. [109]
gtsang sbra'i spyod pa phun sum tshogs/ / zlos po gtsang mar gyur nas ni/ / bsod snyoms snod ni blangs nas su/ / chu yi nang du 'gro bar bya/ /
The reciter who has practiced cleanliness perfectly, Having become purified, and Having taken an alms vessel, Should go to a place with water. [110]
gang du chu bo rab gnas pa/ / de bzhin dma' bar gyur pa dang / / chu klung rab tu 'bab la sogs/ / blang bar bkru bar bya/ /
Wherever one becomes situated Whether at a lake, A descending river, or a spring, etc.[848] [Alms][849] received should always be washed. [111]
slar yang de nas langs nas ni/ / gtsug lag khang ngam gnas su 'gro/ / gang su sngon ni yang dag bsten/ / gang du gnas pa der 'gro bya/ /
Having risen from there, again, Go to a monastery or a dwelling place. One should go to whichever place One has previously relied upon. [112]
song nas zlos pos phyogs de ru/ / lhung bzed de ni gzhag par bya/ / de nas myur du nye reg bya/ / de bzhin slar yang lhung bzed blang / /
Having gone to that place, The reciter should put down his begging bowl. Then, quickly bathe, and Pick up the begging bowl, as before. [113]
lhung bzed sa la lo ma 'am/ / dngul lam de bzhin gser nyid dang / / zangs sam shing shun dag kyang rung / / ston pa la ni lha bshos dbul/ /
In a begging bowl [made of] earth or leaves, Silver or gold, Bronze or tree bark, as is appropriate, Give a divine food offering to the Teacher. [114]
ston la lha bshos phul nas ni/ / slar yang rig sngags rgyal la'o/ / 'gron po gcig ni 'ongs gyur dang / / sdug bsngal can la'ang ci nus sbyin/ /

Having given a divine food offering to the Teacher, Give again, to the best of one’s ability To [the deity of] one’s own vidyā, the best of mantras, To a guest who has arrived, and to those who suffer. [115]
bshos nyid kyang ni thams cad du/ / kun nas nges par bza' ba nyid/ / ha cang mang po sbyin mi bya/ / sngags shes 'dir ni gdung mi bya/ / kun nas rig pa ldan par bya/ /

Food offerings that are Entirely edible in every way Should not be given in excessive amounts, Nor should the mantra-knower’s [body][850] be deprived, But have what is sufficient for the occasion. [116]
lto ba'i tshad tsam bzhag nas ni/ / gzhan pa'i zan ni rtag tu'o/ / bkres dang skom pas nyen pa yis/ / sngags don sgrub par mi nus te/ /
Always leave a bellyful Of cooked food for another [time]. Due to pain of hunger and thirst, One cannot accomplish the mantra’s goal.[851] [117]
ha cang nyung dang mang zos na/ / sngags don bsnyen par mi nus so/ / de nyid phyir na rgyal dbang gis/ / sems can zas kyis gnas so zhes/ / lus can kun la gsungs pa yin/ /

If eating too much or too little, One cannot serve the mantra’s aim. For that very reason, the Most Powerful of Conquerors,[852] Spoke to all embodied creatures about “the conditions of food for living beings.” [118]

gang gis mi rnams 'tsho ba dang / / lha dang lha min dri za dang / / klu dang gnod sbyin mi'am ci/ /
srin po yi dgas sha za dang / / 'byung po skar ma gza' dag ni/ / gang zhig zas la mi ltos pa/ / de ni 'ga' yang yod ma yin/ /

Whoever is living — whether humans, Gods, asuras, and gandharvas, Nāgas, yakṣas, and kinnaras, [119]
Rākṣasas, pretas, and piśācas,[853] Spirits, constellations, or planets — Who does not depend on food, Does not exist![854] [120]
rtag tu kha zas rags pa ni/ / kham gyi zas zhes grags pa'o/ / sems can phra mo'i zas can spang / / de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa ni/ /
[They] always have coarse food, Known as morsel food. Living beings [who eat] subtle food are also Spoken about by the Tathāgata. [121]
bsam gtan zas can rtag par ni/ / gzugs ni spyod cing g.yo ba ste/ / gzugs med nyid kyi lha rnams kyang / / ting 'dzin 'bras bu za ba'o/ /
They are [celestial beings] who move about in the form [realm], And always possess the food of meditation. The gods of the formless [realm], Also subsist on the fruits of meditation. [122]
srid pa bar ma'i sems can yang / / dri za bar ni rab tu grags/ / de bzhin 'dod khams sems can rnams/ / zas ni rnam pa sna tshogs za/ /
Living beings of the intermediate space (bar do), Well-known as odor-eaters (gandharva), And sentient beings of the desire realm, Eat various kinds of food. [123]
'dod dang ldan pa'i lha dang mi/ / kham gyi zas ni za bar byed/ / de nyid phyir na thub dbang gis/ / sems can zas kyis gnas pa zhes/ / chos kyi rgyu ru bstan pa yin/ /
Gods and human beings possessing desire Makes them eat coarse, morsel food. For this reason, the Powerful Sage [Said], “Living beings exist by food,” Showing [food] as the cause of Dharma. [124]
gang de rnams ni rab tu grags/ / zlos po rtag tu brtson pa ni/ / zas kyi tshod ni rig par bya/ /
[This] is proclaimed among those [living beings]. The reciter who always strives Shall know the correct amount of food [to eat]. [125]

gang phyir rig pa bsnyen pa ni/ / zas 'di la ni rab tu gnas/ / kun spyod ma nor dag pa dang / / dge zhing tshangs par spyod pa dang / / zas kyi tshod kyang shes pa la/ / de yis dngos grub rnyed mi dka'/ /

One who serves the vidyā, Lives on food in this way, and Has unmistakably pure conduct, Virtue, and self restraint; Who knows the correct portion of food, Will acquire attainments without difficulty. [126]
dper na khur ni drang ba'i rgyur/ / shing rta yun ring gnas don du/ / shing rta'i mig ni sku bar byed/ /
For example, in order to haul a burden In a chariot for a long time, One puts oil on the axle of the chariot. [127]
de bzhin sngags pa sngags rig pas/ / zas ni gnas pa'i ched du spyad/ / lus ni gso ba'i don du ni/ /
Similarly, the tantric man And mantra knower Uses food to live and For the purpose of nourishing the body. [128]
zlos po rtag tu gso bar bya/ / sngags rnams bsgrub pa'i don phyir dang / / byang chub tshogs kyi rgyu yi phyir/ /
The reciter should always be nourished. For the purpose of the aim of accomplishing mantras, For the cause of preparing for enlightenment, and
mi yi 'jig rten rjes gzung rgyur/ /
For the reason of benefiting the mortal world. [129]
de bzhin rtag tu sngags bzlas bya/ / de nyid phyir na thub pa'i gtsos/ / brtson 'grus chen pos 'di gsungs so/ /
Thus, one should continually recite the mantra. For that very reason, the most excellent of sages And the very diligent one[855] spoke about this. [130]
mtshan ni 'od srung zhes bya bas/ / sngon ni de tshe sa stengs der/ / sgrol ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal po 'dir/ / 'byung po rnams la legs don du/ / sngags ni rab tu gsungs pa yin/ /
In a former time on this Earth, There was [a Buddha] named Kāśyapa (“Protected by Light”). His mantra is proclaimed For the welfare of living beings In this excellent ritual text to Tārā. [131]
sdug bsngal gyur pa'i 'jig rten kun/ / dbul zhing skyo la sha thang ba/ / mchog tu nyon mongs gyur pa rnams/ / 'di rnams don du gsungs pa yin/ /
[His mantra] is spoken for the welfare of Those [who reside in] every painful world realm, Distressed by poverty and sorrow, And thoroughly defiled. [132]
'byung po rnams la legs pa nyid/ / slar yang kun du bsten pa rnams/ / 'byung po kun gyi zas don du/ / gsang sngags 'di ni mchog tu gsungs/ /
For the goodness of living creatures, Who thoroughly rely upon [this mantra], And for the sake of food for all creatures, This secret mantra is praised as the most precious! [133]
nga yis gsang sngags 'di brjod kyi/ / byang sems la bsten thams cad dang / / nyan thos rnams ni mnyan par gyis/ / nad kyis zin pa 'joms byed cing / /
Śrāvakas and all those who rely upon The mind of enlightenment, please listen! This secret mantra expressed by me, Shall completely destroy disease.[856] [134]
bkres pa'i nad kyis gzir ba dang / / gang yang sems can skom pa dang / / sdug bsngal thams cad zhi don dang / / 'byor pa 'dod rnams mnyan par gyis/ /
Thirsty living beings Tormented with the disease of hunger, Yet desirous of material treasures, Please listen, in order to pacifying all suffering! [135]
'od srung 'od ni chen po la/ / thub pa'i gtso bos de skad gsungs/ / nyon mongs rnams ni yid mgu nas/ / khyab bdag de la gsol ba 'debs/ /
Kāśyapa, One of Great Light, and Lord of Sages, spoke in this way. The Śrāvakas, whose minds were pleased, Made a request of the All-Pervading Lord. [136]
chos kyi rgyal po thub pa che/ / chos mkhyen gsang sngags bshad du gsol/ / dam tshig mchog la nyer gnas pa'i/ / sems can rnams la rjes brtser mdzod/ /
“Oh Dharma King, Great Sage, Dharma knower, and treasure chest of compassion, Please explain the secret mantra To living beings who are ready for the excellent pledge!” [137]
de skad gsol nas thub pa yis/ / sngags mchog rgyas par gsung bar byed/ / ka la ping ka sgra dbyangs dang // rnga bo che dang sprin gyi sgra/ /
Having been beseeched in this way, the Sage Spoke extensively about the supreme mantra. With the voice of the kalavinka bird, A great drum, and thunder, [138]
tshangs dbyangs brtson 'grus chen po dang / / tshangs pa'i sras gang rgyal mchog gis/ / gang yang cung zad 'dir 'ongs pa/ / rkang med pa dang rkang mangs dang / /
The very powerful voice of Brahmā, and The sons of Brahmā, the foremost Conqueror, [The Sage said,] “Whoever has come here, [Whether] the footless,[857] or the many-footed,[858] [139]
rkang gnyis pa dang rkang bzhi pa/ / 'byung po'i tshogs rnams kun nyon cig / mdor na sems can don kun du/ / bde 'byung sngags ni bshad par bya/ /
The two-footed or four-footed, [including] All groups of creatures, please listen! In short, for the benefit of all living beings, I shall explain the mantra that produces happiness. [140]
'das dang ma 'ongs da ltar gyi/ / sems can la sogs 'dir lhags pa/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad par bya/ / 'byor pa 'dod pa rnams nyon cig /
To past, present, and future Living beings, etc., who are assembled here, I shall explain it, in brief. Those who desire good fortune, please listen!” [141]

na maH sa man+ta bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M ga ga ne/ ga ga na/ gany+dzo A na ya/ sarba la hu la hu/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra/ A kar+Sha Ne/ mA bi lam+ba/ ya the pi taM saM pA dA ya swA hA/
Namaḥ sarvabuddhānāṃ / apratihataśāsanānāṃ / Tadyathā / Oṃ gagane / gaganagañj[e][859] ānaya / sarva lahu lahu / samaya manusmara / ākarṣani / mā vilamba / yathepsitaṃ me saṃpādaya svāhā //
Homage to all Buddhas, whose teachings are unimpeded! As follows: In the sky! In the treasury of sky! Bring everything! Observe the pledge! Attract! Don’t delay! Fulfill my desires! Svāhā!

bcom ldan 'das 'od srung gis de skad ces gsungs nas/ cang mi gsung bar gyur to/ / yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gis/ rig pa'i sngags kyi tshig 'di rgya cher gsungs pa'i bar skabs 'dir nam mkha' thams cad chen po la 'os pa'i zas kyi sprin gyis yongs su gang bar gyur to/ / stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi nam mkha'i mthil thams cad zas kyi sprin gyis rab tu g.yogs par snang bar gyur to/ /

Thus, the Bhagavān Kāśyapa spoke accordingly, and became silent. On this occasion that Bhagavān Kāśyapa spoke extensively about words of the vidyā-mantra, the entire expanse of the sky appeared completely filled with a cloud of costly food. The entire surface of the sky encompassing the entire billion world galaxy appeared completely covered with a cloud of food.
bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du mngon par 'dod pa'i don du

zas thams cad dang / /ji ltar mngon par/ sred pa'i bza' ba de/ de rnams su char 'bab par gyur to/ / ji ltar mngon par sred pa'i bza' ba de rnams kyis zas kyi bya ba bkres pa'i sdug bsngal zhi ba'i don dang / skom pa rnams kyis btung ba yan lag brgyad dang ldan pa'i chu bo'i rgyun lta bu btung bar bya ba yang yid la 'dod pa bzhin du der bab par gyur to/ /

Whatever delicious food one wished to eat would become like falling rain for them. To the extent that desirable food is made for the purpose of pacifying the suffering of hunger, and water from river streams possessing the eight attributes[860] is made into drinks for thirsty ones, [food and drinks] descended there according to the mind’s desire.

sems can thams cad kyang skad cig de la bkres pa'i nad thams cad rab tu zhi ba dang / skom pa thams cad bsal bar byas par gyur to/ / thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor thams cad kyang ngo mtshar thob cing tshim pa thob nas bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa la mngon par dga' zhing rjes su yi rangs nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal nas de nyid du mi snang bar gyur to/ / bcom ldan 'das 'od srung yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i gnas la yongs su bzhugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa ngas kyang de'i tshe rtog pa'i rgyal po'i cho ga 'di la sems can thams cad kyi don gyi phyir dang / bkres pa dang / skom pa bsal ba'i don gyi phyir dang / khyad par du sngags zlos pa po thams cad kyi phyir gsungs pa la mngon par rjes su yi rang ngo //dang po re zhig zlos pa pos sngags 'di bsgrub par bya'o/ / gal te bsod snyoms la 'gro bar mi spro na ri'i rtse mor 'dzegs nas 'bum phrag bdun bzlas pa bya/ / de nas dkar gsum bza' ba'am/ 'o ma btung ba'o/ / ri'i rtse mo de nyid du 'phags ma sgrol ma'i ras ris bar ma sngar bzhin du bzhag nas mchod pa chen po byas te gtor ma dang lha bshos rgya chen po byas nas/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gis gsungs pa'i gsang sngags 'di nyid kyis seng ldeng gi yam shing rnams kyis me sbar nas u dum bA ra'i yam shing la zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar la btags pa rlan dang bcas pa'am/ / dpal 'bras kyi yam shing kyang rung ste stong phrag brgyad du sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

In that very instant, all thirst was cleared away and all illnesses due to hunger were pacified for every sentient being. All beings in the entire circle became consoled and amazed with wonder, rejoiced in ecstasy, and delighted in the words spoken by Bhagavān Kāśyapa. Having bowed down at the two feet of the Bhagavān, they dispersed. The Bhagavān Kāśyapa remained in the state of a Tathāgata.[861] The Bhagavān Śākyamuni also rejoiced in what was spoken at that time. First, the reciter should practice this mantra in this most excellent of ritual texts for the purpose of benefiting all living beings, for the purpose of the aim of eliminating all hunger and thirst, and especially for the benefit of all mantra reciters. If one is not enthusiastic enough to ask for alms, having climbed to the summit of a mountain, one should recite seven hundred thousand times.[862] Then, eat the three whites[863] and drink milk. On that mountain summit, having set up that medium-sized painted cloth of Ārya Tārā, as before, one should perform a large worship ceremony. Having created extensively large sacrificial cakes and divine food offerings, with that same secret mantra spoken by the completely perfected Buddha Kāśyapa, and having ignited a fire with sacrificial sticks of khadira wood, one should perform burnt offerings eight thousand times with sacrificial sticks of udumbari wood, moistened and crushed in curds, honey, and butter, or with sacrificial sticks of śrīphala wood,[864] as is suitable.

de nas mtshan phyed kyi dus kyi tshe sprin nag po chen po dang / rlung gi dkyil 'khor 'ong bar 'gyur te 'jigs par mi bya/ langs na 'gro bar yang mi bya'o/ / bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i snying pos bdag nyid bsrung bar bya zhing //dkyil 'khor bcing ba dang / grogs rnams kyang sngar bzhin bsrung bar bya'o/ / de nas rlung nag po'i dkyil 'khor mi snang bar 'gyur te/ bud med kyang rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa/ 'od kyi phreng ba dang ldan pas phyogs rnams kyang kun du snang bar byed bzhin pa/ sgrub pa po'i mdun du 'dug ste/ kye kye sems dpa' chen po longs shig / grub pa yin no/ / zhes so/ / de nas sgrub pa pos sna ma'i me tog dang bsres pa'i dri chus mchod yon dbul lo/ / de nas de nyid du mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / nyi ma de nas bdag nyid dam 'di'i grogs po nyi shu rtsa lnga la deng nas ji ltar mngon par 'dod pa'i bza' ba rnams rab tu ster bar byed do/ / ji ltar 'dod pa'i yo byad rnams kyang kun du sbyin par byed do/ / de nas sgrub pa pos mchod yon phul nas gshegs su gsol bar bya'o/ / ras ris la bskor ba lan gsum byas nas ras ris blangs te sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag byas nas de nas ri'i rtse mo'am/ mi med pa'i gnas su 'gro bar bya'o/ / der bdag nyid dam/ grogs pos phyag dar byas nas dgram par bya ba rnams bkram la gnas der nam mkha' la 'gro ba la sogs pa'i las rnams bya'o/ / de nas sgrub pa pos sngar bzhin du ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste ras ris bar ma sngar bzhin du bzhugs su gsol nas seng ldeng gi shing gis me sbar la thun gsum du pad+ma dkar po'i me tog /zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pa rnams kyis nyi ma nyi shu rtsa gcig tu/ rtsa ba'i rig pa'am snying po'am nye ba'i snying pos las chen po thams cad kyi ched du'am yi ge gcig pa'i ched du stong phrag brgyad du sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

Then, at midnight, a huge black cloud and a circle of wind will come. Do not be afraid, and upon standing up, do not depart. One should protect oneself with the essence incantation of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā, bind[865] the maṇḍala, and also protect friends, as before. Then, once the circle of black wind disappears, a woman ornamented with all ornaments and endowed with a garland of light fully illuminating the directions will remain in the presence of the practitioner [and say,] “O Great Being! Rise up! Be successful!”[866] Then, the practitioner should offer drinking water with fragrant water mixed with jasmine flowers.[867] After that, she will disappear from there. From that day on, she will bestow desirable food offerings to oneself, or twenty-five of one’s friends. She will also bestow desirable necessities. After that, the practitioner, having made an offering of drinking water, requested [the deity] to depart. Having circumambulated the painted cloth three times, and having picked up the painted cloth, [the practitioner] that has made salutations to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas should go to the summit of a mountain or a place without people. There, having swept earnestly, by oneself or with friends, one should spread out [the painted cloth]. Upon spreading it out in that place, one should perform actions such as moving in the sky, etc. Then, the practitioner should seat themselves on a bundle of kuśa grass as before. Having requested [Tārā] to take up residence in the medium painted cloth as before, one should perform burnt offerings eight thousand times for twenty-one days at the three junctures of the day in a fire ignited with khadira wood using white lotus flowers crushed in curds, honey, and butter, along with the root vidyā, the essence incantation, or the near-essence incantation, for the sake of all the rituals, or for the purpose of the single syllable [most concise essence-incantation].

de nas mtshan phyed kyi dus kyi tshe sbyin sreg gi mthar bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma mngon sum du mthong bar 'gyur zhing / 'dod pa'i mchog gnang bar byed do/ / nam mkha' la 'gro ba'am/ mi snang ba'am byang chub sems dpa'i sa'am/ Rang sangs rgyas sam/ mngon par shes pa lnga nyid dam/ tshe ring ba nyid dam/ rgyal srid chen po dang / longs spyod chen po nyid kyi ched dam/ rgyal po chen po mnyes pa nyid dam/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi rjes su rnam par spyod pa nyid dam/ mdor na yid la 'dod pa de thams cad gnang bar byed do/ / gang blangs kyang rung ste/ de mthun par gnang bar byed cing / grub pa'i rdzas rnams thams cad kyang thob bo/ / sems can chen po rnams 'gugs par byed pa'am/ mdor na ji lta ji ltar zhus pa de thams cad mdzad do/ / las kyi nyes pa rab tu spags pa yang yang dag par sbyong bar byed do/ / zhes bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas gsungs so/ / las kyi cho ga gzhan pa bar ma'i sgrub thabs su 'gyur ba ni/ / dang po re zhig khyad par gyi gnas sam/ gtsang ma'i phyogs sam/ chu klung ngam/ chu gling gi 'gram du sngar bzhin du thams cad byas nas ras ris zhal nub tu phyogs par gzhag la/ bdag nyid kha shar du phyogs bas gnas nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste/ rgyas par gong bzhin du sbyar bar bya ste thun gsum du 'bum phrag drug bzlas par bya'o/ / bzlas pa yongs su rdzogs pa dang / dong ka'i me tog tsan+dan dkar po dang bsres pa'am gur gum dang bsres pas snga ma de bzhin kho nar me sbar nas stong phrag brgyad sbyin sreg bya'o/ / sbyin sreg gi mthar ras ris 'gul na blon po nyid do/ / ras ris la 'od kyi snang ba byung na 'od las rgyal srid do/ / ras ris kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs na rgyal po chen po bzhi'i rigs kyi rgyal srid do/ / ras ris la me byung na sum cu rtsa gsum gyi dbang phyug nyid de brgya byin nyid do/ / ras ris chos ston par byed pa byung na byang chub sems dpa' gsum gyi dbang phyug nyid do/ / ras ris kyi phyag spyi bor reg na mngon par shes pa lnga dang / sa bdun rjes su thob pa dang / stobs bcu nges pa nyid rim gyis thob par byed pa nyid do/ /

Then, at midnight, at the end of the burnt offerings, Bhagavatī Tārā will be seen directly, before one’s very eyes. She will grant the desired boons: moving in the sky, invisibility, the bodhisattva stage(s), the state of a Pratyekabuddha or Śrāvaka, the five kinds of supernormal perception, long life, a great kingdom, great enjoyment, becoming the beloved of the king, or following Noble Avalokiteśvara. In short, she will grant whatever desires one has in mind. Whatever one requests[868] will be granted accordingly, and one will acquire all accomplished things. She will summon Great Beings and, in short, she will carry out all that accordingly. She will completely purify the defiled faults of karma. Thus, the Bhagavān Śākyamuni has spoken. Moreover, as before, there are ritual methods for the practice (sādhana) of the medium [painted cloth]. First, in a particular place, or pure direction, river, or island, having performed everything as before, having set up the painted cloth facing west, and having situated oneself facing east, one should sit down on a kuśa grass mat, prepare extensively as mentioned above, and recite [the mantra] six hundred thousand times at the three junctures [dawn, noon, and dusk]. Once the recitation is completely perfected, mix karṇikāra flowers with white sandalwood, or mix them with saffron. Having ignited a fire as before, perform burnt offerings eight thousand times. At the end of the burnt offerings, if the painted cloth shakes, [one will attain] the state of a state minister. If the painted cloth produces an illuminating light, a kingdom will arise from the light. If the painted cloth shakes with a garland of blazing light all around, there will be a kingdom belonging to a region of four great kings.[869] If the painted cloth produces fire, Indra, lord [of the heaven] of the thirty-three gods [will appear]. If the painted cloth produces a Dharma teaching, one will master the first three bodhisattva [stages].[870] If the painted cloth touches one’s head, it will cause one to successively achieve the five kinds of supernormal perception, the seven [bodhisattva] stages, and to gradually attain certainty of the ten powers (i.e., Buddhahood).

de nas sgrub pa pos bcom ldan 'das 'od srung gis gsungs pa'i sngags bsgrubs te bkres pa dang skom pa phyir gzhil ba'i don rjes su thob pa de nyid kyis dang / cho ga de nyid kyis yo byad kyi rig pa'i spyod pa'i don sgrub pa'i thabs kyi cho ga'i chos la yang dag par nan tan bya'i gzhan du grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar rim gyis sngags kyi spyod pa la rjes su 'jug cing mdor na nan tan nges par sgrub par byed de/ rdzas dang sman dang yo byad kyi khyad par dang / nor bu rin po che rnams ji ltar sngar nges par bstan pa bzhin du sgrub par byed do/ /

Then, having accomplished the mantra that was spoken by Bhagavān Kāśyapa, with that very attainment of the aim of expelling hunger and thirst, and with the implements of that ritual, [the practitioner] should earnestly perform the Dharma with its methods of evocation (sādhana) whose aim is to practice the vidyā. [If practiced] otherwise, there will be no accomplishment. Thus, through gradually engaging in the mantra practice, and in brief, with continuous exertion, success is certain. One will acquire the materials, medicines, distinctive implements, and very precious jewels previously shown.
sngags shes sngags ni zlos pa po'ang // cho ga bshad pa la sems pa/ / sngags pa de tshe de phyogs su/ / gtsang ma'i 'gro bas zas kyang ni/ /
The mantra knower and mantra reciter, Ponders the explanation of the ritual. At that time, the mantra practitioner Goes to a pure place and eats. [142]
zos nas yid ni dga' ba dang // dbang po yongs su rdzogs pa dang // lhung bzed lhag ma rtag blangs te/ / sems bzang chu bo gtsang mar 'gro/ /
Having eaten, completely pleasing the mind And nourishing the senses, Take the leftovers in one’s begging bowl, and With good thoughts, go to a clean river. [143]
mtha' gcig tu ni bor nas ni/ / brtul zhugs can gyis dud 'gro sbyin/ / dud 'gro rnams la mthun byin nas/ / 'bad pas lhung bzed bkru bar byed/ /
Having departed in solitude, The ascetic gives [food scraps] to the animals. Having given sympathetically to the animals, Wash the begging bowl with effort. [144]
lhag ma lhung bzed bya ba ni/ / sgum med zas dang dri bral gang //
[Then, with effort, Make an earthen cooking vessel.][871] Leftovers made for the begging bowl must be Food without oil and bereft of flesh.[872] [145]
lhung bzed lhag mar thub pas gsungs // gang du slong ba'i snod du ni/ / de ru zan ni mi bza' ste/ /
The begging bowl is discussed by the Sage, Regarding the food in the alms vessel That has not been eaten. [146]
der ni bza' ba 'bras bu dang // rdzas rnams rtag tu bza' mi bya/ / pad 'dab kyis kyang ma yin te/ / ut+pa la las byung bas sam/ /
There, food made of fruit And [other] uneaten food ingredients Should never be [eaten] with lotus leaves, Nor with [a vessel] produced from a blue lotus (utpala). [147]
dri bzang ldan rnams spangs pa ste/ / sngags pas der ni mi bza'o/ / gang yang sngags pas ku mu da/ / sla k+Sha u dum bA ra las byung / /

Abandon [bowls] with a fragrant smell. The mantra practitioner will not eat in that, Nor one produced from the leaves of a white water lily (kumuda), An Indian fig tree (plakṣa), or an uḍumbara tree. [148]
pa Ti'i 'dab ma dang yang ni/ / tsher ma'i yal ga'i ri khrod byung / / a mra'i 'dab ma ru yang min/ / de bzhin sA Ta la las byung / /
As well, [abandon bowls] produced from vaṭa leaves, or Thorny branches from the mountain peaks. Āmra leaves are not appropriate, as well as Those produced from the pāṭala.[873] [149]
sA la'i 'dab ma shi ri Sha/ / byang chub shing las byung ba dang / / gang du bcom ldan sangs rgyas ni/ / shAkya seng ge bzhugs pa yi/ /
[Avoid bowls made of] Sāla leaves, Śirīṣa, or Produced from bodhi tree wood, Where that Bhagavān Buddha Śākyasiṃha was seated. [150]
shing de 'bad pas spang bar bya/ / shing de yi ni yal ga dang / / nA ga ge sar shing la'ang min/ /
With effort, that tree should be avoided. Do not carve [a bowl] from[874] branches of that tree Or from nāgakesara wood, [Nor even drink from its leaves.][875] [151]
gang du nam yang bza' mi bya/ / mkhas pas de kun cis kyang spang / / thub pa'i lo ma'i spyil po ni/ / rmongs pas nam yang 'gom mi bya/ /
Never eat from any of these [materials]. The wise one abandons all of that, in every case. Even a fool would not step over the leaves [that form] The Sage’s thatched hut. [152]
sngags pa dam tshig nyams par 'gyur/ / zas ni lo ma de rnams las/ / gzhan pa'i lo ma rnams su bza'/ /
[If eating food on those materials,] The mantra practitioner will spoil his pledge. [Be sure to] eat food on leaves Other than those leaves. [153]
sa byung zangs su nges bstan dang / / de bzhin gser dang dngul las byung / / shel dang rdo ba las byung ba/ /
[Bowls made] from earth or copper are advised, As well as [those] produced from gold and silver, And [those] produced from crystal and stone. [154]
de bzhin bza' ba blangs nas ni/ / rtag tu sngags pas der ni bza'/ / lo ma'i rgyab tu mi bza' ste/ / de bzhin lag pa'i mthil du'ang min/ /
Having accepted food in this way, The mantra practitioner always[876] eats in that. [The practitioner] does not eat on the back of a leaf, Nor eat out of the palm of the hand. [155]

stobs bcu pa yi sras rnams dang / / rang rgyal bse ru lta bu gang / / de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyan thos gtso/ / lo ma gzhan dang lha bshos 'byung / / zlos pos de rnams spang bar bya/ / yi ge rkang pas kyang mi 'gom/ /

The reciter should abandon those and Other leaves on which food offerings are produced For [Bodhisattvas,] the sons of [Buddha] Daśabala, Rhinoceros-like Prateyekbuddhas, and Śrāvakas who are the foremost disciples of the Tathāgata But do not step over [the offering] with your feet.[877] [156]
sna tshogs bza' ba snum khur dang / / de bzhin btung dang bza' ba rnams/ / sngags pas 'bad pas blang bar bya/ /
Various kinds of food cooked with oil and In the same way, food and drinks, should be accepted By the mantra practitioner, with effort. [157]
rgyal dang rgyal ba'i mchog rnams dang / / de bzhin nyan thos skyes bu mchog / dkon mchog gsum la phul ba yi/ / lha bshos thams cad nyid kyang ni/ / zlos pos rtag tu spang bar bya/ /
The reciter should always abandon The totality of food offerings Presented to the supreme Conqueror of Conquerors, The most Excellent Person of the Śrāvakas, And the three jewels. [158]
chung ngu tsam yang lus can la/ / sngags rnams de yis mi 'grub ste/ / kun nas bkra shis thams cad dang / / rtag tu dpal ni smos ci dgos/ /
Those mantras will not accomplish Insignificant matters for living beings, What needs to be said about [their ability to accomplish] Entirely auspicious and meritorious matters? [159]
rgyal ba can dang zhi ba can/ / lha bshos gtor ma za byed pa/ / de tshe de yi kun mi 'grub/ /
[For rituals that] promote prosperity[878] and appeasing, [And fulfill all hopes],[879] Nothing will succeed for [the practitioner] who Eats sacrificial cakes of divine food offerings. [160]
gtsang zhing mkhas la tshul khrims ldan/ / snying rje snying rje'i las can dang / / gtsang sbra'i spyod pa la dga' ba/ / rig sngags kun du sgrub par byed/ /
[For one who is] compassionate and just, Endowed with purity of learning and morality, Who delights in the practice of cleanliness, The vidyā-mantras shall always succeed. [161]
sems can gzhan la byin pa'i zas/ / zlos pos de ni bza' mi bya/ / gzhan gyis rab tu ma brtags pa'i/ / zas gzhan bza' bar mi bya'o/ /
That reciter should not eat Food given to other living beings, Moreover, other foods should not be eaten Without thorough examination by another. [162]
rang la byin pas kha zas ni/ / cung zad tsam yang blang bar bya/ / sngags shes de ltar 'jug pa ni/ / de yi dngos grub sdig pa'i dgra/ /
Food given to oneself, Should be accepted sparingly, The focused mantra-knower’s Attainment is the enemy of defilement. [163]

yongs su rdzogs par byed par gnas/ / zlos pos cho ga 'di yis ni/ / bza' ba len pa'i brtul zhugs can/ / thub pa rnams kyis legs par bsngags/ / sngags rnams thams cad sgrub pa la/ / mdor na cho ga mthong ba yis/ / bza' ba kun dang las rnams la'o/ /

Resolved to bring [the ritual] to completion, The reciter and vow-holder, Using this ritual, accepts food that is offered, And is well-praised by the sages. All the mantras shall be successful, while Observing the ritual methods, in brief, For all foods and rituals. [164]

de nas gzhan yang rab 'chad byed/ / sngags ni thams cad sbyong bar byed/ / de nas zlos pos nye reg bya/ / de tshe sngags 'di brjod par bya/ / de tshe sngags pas lan bdun du/ / lus sbyong byed pa bzlas byas nas/ /

Furthermore, I shall explain The mantra that purifies everything. After that, the reciter, consecrated by water, Should clearly express this mantra at that time. Once the mantra practitioner performs the recitation Seven times, it will purify the body. [165]
'byung po'i tshogs dang lha rnams 'dir/ / de don rgyas pa mnyan par gyis/ / lus kun nye reg byas nas su/ / thub pas sngags 'di brjod par bya/ /
O creatures and gods assembled here, Please listen to [the mantra’s] extensive meaning, Once the entire body has been consecrated, The sage shall express this mantra. [166]
na maH sarba bud+d+hA nAM/ a pra hi ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ oM sarba kilbi Sha/ nA sha ni/ nA sha ya/ sarba duSh+Ta pra yuk+taM/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra hU~M dzaHswA hA/
Namaḥ sarvabuddhānāṃ / apratihata śāsanānāṃ / Tadyathā / Oṃ sarvakilviṣa / nāṣani / nāṣaya / Sarvaduṣṭaprayuktaṃ / samayamanusmara hūṃ jaḥ svāhā //
Homage to all the Buddhas, whose teachings are unobstructed. As follows: Destroy all defilements! Destroy all that is associated with evil! Remember the vow. Hūṃ Jaḥ Svāhā!

sngags 'dis bslab pa'i zas gzhan gang yang rung ba yongs su spyod pa na sngags lan bdun mngon par bsngags pa byas nas yongs su longs spyad par bya'o/ / zos nas snga ma bzhin du nye reg byas te spyi bo la sogs pa'i lus thams cad du byugs nas de nas ngal bso bar bya'o/ / ngal sos nas yud tsam phyed dam thun gcig la'o/ / de nas ras ris dang / sangs rgyas thams cad la mngon par phyag byas nas/ dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam bklag par bya'o/ / 'phags pa shes rab kyi pha rol du phyin pa dang / 'phags ma zla ba sgron ma'i ting nge 'dzin dang / 'phags pas bcu pa dang / 'phags pa gser 'od dam pa dang / 'phags pa rma bya chen mo dang / 'phags pa rin po che tog gi gzungs te 'di rnams las gzhan dang gzhan gang yang rung ba bklag par bya'o/ / nyi ma'i dus kyi tshad bzhi cha tsam du'o/ / de nas yongs su zhi nas ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du bklag par bya ste glegs bam brtul nas gos gtsang ma bgos te dam pa'i chos la phyag byas nas de nas khrus kyi ched du chu klung gi 'gram mam mtsho phran chen por 'jug pas song nas/ srog chags med pa'i chu blangs te lan bdun mngon par bsngags par byas nas rig pa 'dis chu la gdab bo/ / gang zhe na/

Use this mantra with food that has been received through begging or any other way, and having consecrated [the food] seven times with the mantra, one will totally enjoy it! Having eaten, and consecrated by massaging, as before, anoint the entire body from the head down. After that, one should rest. After resting for about an hour or one watch [of three hours], make salutations to the painted cloth and all the Buddhas and read a book of the virtuous Dharma [such as]: Ārya Prajñāpāramitā, Ārya Candrapradīpa-samādhi, Ārya Daśabhūmika, Ārya Suvarṇa-prabhāsottama, Ārya Mahāmāyūrī, Ārya Ratnaketu-dhāriṇī. One should read from these [books] and any other, as is suitable, for up to one fourth of the day. Then, having become completely calm, one should read whatever one desires. Having put the book aside, cover [the book] with pure cloth, and make salutations to the virtuous Dharma. Then, at bath time, having gone to a river bank or entered into a small, deep lake, having taken earth lacking vermin, consecrate it with the mantra seven times, and cast it into the water with this vidyā. What is it?
na maH sa man+ta bud d+hA nAM a pra ti ha ta shA sa nA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M sarba duSh+Ta staM b+ha ya hU~M/ na dI ba ra d+ha ri Ne/ sa ma ya ma nu sma ra phaT phaT swA hA/
Namaḥ samantabuddhānāṃ / apratihata śāsanānāṃ / tadyathā / Oṃ sarvaduṣṭastambhaya hūṃ / nadīvaradhāriṇe / samayamanusmara phaṭ phaṭ svāhā //
Homage to all the Buddhas, whose teachings are unobstructed. As follows: Oṃ! Paralyze all the wicked, Hūṃ! Sustain the most beautiful of rivers. Remember the vow. Phaṭ Phaṭ Svāhā!

'dis srung ba byas nas phyogs rnams bcing ba dang / grogs rnams dang / dkyil 'khor bcing ba dang / kha bcing ba dang / gdug pa dang / rab tu gdug pa rnams thams cad 'gugs par byed pa dang / bgegs bcing ba la yang srad bu la lan bdun bzlas nas rked pa'i phyogs su bcings pas thams cad yongs su 'chags pa dang / bzlas pa'i dus thams cad dang / khrus kyi dus thams cad dang / gdug pa'i bgegs rnam par gzhom pa dang / rab tu zhi ba'i don du sngags 'di stong phrag gcig bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas las thams cad byed do/ / pad+ma'i gdan la phyag rgya chen po dang ldan pa dgod par bya'o/ / las rnams thams cad du thams cad kyi rnam pa gzhan du mi 'gyur ro/ / de nas sgrub pa pos sa las byung ba'i phye ma la sogs pa rnams blangs nas ji ltar bde bar khrus bya zhing srog chags med pa'i chus khrus byas te/ thams cad du las thams cad la srog chags med pa nyid kyis bya'o/ / de nas khrus byas nas sa'i rang bzhin nam gzhan dri zhim po dang ldan pa'i dri dang / yo byad kyi khyad par gyis rjes su byug par bya'o/ / chu'i nang du mchil ma dang / bshang ba dang gci ba la sogs pa yang dor bar mi bya'o/ / rtse bar yang mi bya'o/ / snying rje dang ldan pas bdag dang sems can thams cad la so sor brtag par bya ste/ bdag med pa dang / stong pa dang / sdug bsngal dang ldan pa dang / sdug bsngal nye bar 'gags pa dang / tshor bas mngon par non pa dang / chu rlabs bzhin du mngon par 'byung ba'i rab tu sbyor ba'i sdug bsngal dang ldan pa'i sems can rnams 'di ltar sgrub pa dang bral ba sngags shes pas gang de bzhin du dug dang / gcod pa dang / ltung ba dang / rnam par 'thor ba dang / rnam par 'jigs pa la sogs pa rnams kyis sdug bsngal gyi phung po nye bar 'gog par bya bzhin pa/ 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho thibs po gnas pa'i bdag nyid du mthong zhing gnas med pa dang skyob pa med pa dang / skyabs med pa dang / shin tu dman pa'i yid can gyi bdag nyid du brtags nas sgom pa po mgrin pa nub tsam gyi chu na gnas pa'am/ lte ba tsam du gnas pa'i chu de nyid kyi nang du sems rtse gcig tu nye bar gzung bar bya'o/ /

Having been protected with this, recite [the vidyā] seven times over thread for binding the directions, summon all rituals to bind the maṇḍala of friends, bind the mouth, bind all wicked ones, and all of the most wicked of wicked ones, and bind demonic obstacles. Having bound the waist area, one should roam everywhere. At all times of recitation, and at all times of bathing, one should recite this mantra one thousand times for the purpose of pacifying and vanquishing all poisonous obstacles. It performs all rituals. One should spread out a lotus seat endowed with the Great Seal. Perform everything for every ritual. Do not [consider performing the rituals in] any other way. Then, the practitioner receives the powders, etc. made from clay, bathed comfortably with water devoid of insects, and performed all rituals everywhere [with water] devoid of insects. After that, having bathed, one should smear oneself with hardening earth possessing a fragrant smell, and using special implements. One should not cast mucus, fecal matter, or urine into the water. One should not even play [in the water]. Endowed with compassion, one should examine oneself and all living beings as selfless and empty. As for sentient beings endowed with suffering, obstructed by suffering, overcome with feelings, possessed of suffering that washes over them like waves of water,[880] and thus deprived of a practice (sādhana), the mantra knower should likewise subdue the heap of suffering such as [being] poisoned, cut and felled, torn up and utterly destroyed, and so on, having visualized oneself dwelling in the impenetrable ocean of existence (saṃsāra). Then, having carefully considered oneself as if homeless, protectorless, without a refuge, and of very low status, the meditator should focus upon this single object of thought while remaining in that water submerged up to his throat, or up to his navel.
