dang por re zhig pad+ma chen po'i 'dab ma la me tog chen po dang ldan pa pad+ma chen po'i lo mas nye bar mdzes pa/ blta na sdug pa/ rin po che be+eDUr+ya'i rang bzhin las byung ba'i sdong bu dang / rin po che ma da ka las grub pa'i pad+ma'i ge sar dang / shel las byas pa'i sdong po legs par kha phye ba dang de'i rjes su skyes pa'i shel dang pad+ma rA ga'i me tog rnams kyis mdzes pa'o/ / de'i steng du seng ge'i khri rin po che du mas nye bar mdzes pa ras bcos bu zung gis bkab pa'o/ / de'i steng du bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das bsam par bya ste/ chos ston par mdzad cing bzhugs pa gser gyi mdog tu snang ba kun nas 'od 'bar ba'i phreng bas khyab pa'i 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis brgyan pa tshad chen po nam mkha' lta bu mchog tu bris bzhin pa/ skyil mo krung gis nye bar bzhugs pa/ g.yas su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ pad+ma chen po'i gdan la bzhugs ba/ rnga yab bsnams pa/ bcom ldan 'das bzhugs pa'i grwa na 'khod de/ lus dmar ser gur gum btags pa'i kha dog lta bu'o/ /

First, [visualize] a large blossoming lotus possessing a huge flower, and beautified with large lotus leaves, pleasing to look at. The stalk is made from precious vaiḍūrya, [the leaves are] made from precious emerald,[881] and the center of that lotus has a thousand crystal petals in full blossom, beautified with flowers of crystal and rubies budding from it. Above that is a lion throne, made from the essence of jewels, beautified with many jewels, and covered with a pair of colorful cotton cloths. One should contemplate the Bhagavān Buddha seated on top of that [throne], teaching the Dharma, [his complexion] a shining golden color, ornamented with a circle of light containing a penetrating garland of blazing light rays, drawn in huge dimensions — as large as the sky, and seated cross-legged. On the right is Noble Avalokiteśvara, possessing the best of all aspects, seated on a large lotus seat, waving a yak tail fan, dwelling at an angle to the seated Bhagavān, with a bodily complexion like powdered reddish-gold saffron.[882]

g.yon du 'phags pa mthu chen po thob ston ka'i sprin ltar dkar ba phyag na rnga yab thogs pa'o/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' brgyad la/ 'phags pa byams pa dang / kun du bzang po dang / sa'i snying po dang / nam mkha'i mdzod dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sel ba dang / 'phags pa 'jam dpal dang / 'phags pa phyag na rdo rje dang / nor bzang zhes pa byang chub sems dpa' bcu po 'di rnams kyi g.yas su rang sangs rgyas brgyad bsam par bya ste/ tsan+dan dang / spos ngad ldan dang / tog dang / tog dkar dang / 'dod pa dang / nye ba'i 'dod pa dang / mu khyud dang / mu khyud brgyad do/ / de nyid du nyan thos chen po brgyad gnas pa la 'di lta ste 'phags pa mo+od gal gyi bu chen po dang / 'phags pa shA ri'i bu dang / ba lang bdag dang / b+ha ra d+h+wa dza bsod snyoms len dang / pi lin da'i bu dang / 'phags pa sgra gcan zin dang / 'phags pa 'od srung chen po dang / 'phags pa kun dga' bo zhes pa'i nyan thos chen po de rnams dang nye bar dge slong gi dge 'dun mtha' yas pa bsgom par bya'o/ / rang sangs rgyas rnams dang nye bar rang sangs rgyas mtha' yas pa bsgom par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' brgyad po rnams kyi gnas su'ang byang chub sems dpa'i dge 'dun mtha' yas pa bsgom par bya'o/ / de bzhin du kun nas 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor du 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po dang ldan par bsgom par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' chen po bdag nyid kyang lte ba tsam gyi chu la gnas bzhin du lha dang mi'i me tog rnam pa sna tshogs pa la me tog man dA ra ba dang / man dA ra ba chen po dang / pad+ma dang / pad+ma chen po dang / d+hA nu skA ri ka dang / par+Shi ka dang in+t+ra ba ra'i me tog rnam pa sna tshogs pa tshad chen po phung po chen por gnas pa ri rab tsam gyi me tog gi phur mas bcom ldan 'das la mchod pa bya zhing / 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la phye ma dang / chos gos dang / gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan rnams dang / lha dang mi'i mar me mang po bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong phrag yid du 'ong ba rnams kyis mchod par bya'o/ / de bzhin du gtor ma dang / bdug pa dang / lha bshos dang / mchod pa dang / bsnyen bkur la sogs pa yo byad lha dang mi'i nyer mkho rnams dbul bar bya'o/ /

On the left is Noble Mahāsthāmaprāpta, white as an autumn cloud with a yak tail in hand. Similarly, the eight bodhisattvas are Ārya Maitreya, Samantabhadra, Kṣitigarbha, Gagagañja, Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhī, Ārya Mañjuśrī,[883] Ārya Vajrapāṇi, and Sudhana. To the right of those ten bodhisattvas, one should contemplate the eight Pratyekabuddhas: Candana, Gandhamādana, Ketu, [Suketu],[884] Sitaketu, Iṣṭa, Upāriṣṭa,[885] Nemi. In the same way, the eight great Śrāvakas are standing there, as follows: Ārya Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Śāriputra, Gavāṃpati, Piṇḍolabharadvāja, Pilindavatsa, Āryarāhula, Mahākaśyapa, and Āryānanda. Near these great Śrāvakas, one should contemplate the infinite assembly of monks (bhikṣu). Near the Pratyekabuddhas, one should contemplate an infinite [assembly of] Pratyekabuddhas. In the place of the eight Bodhisattvas, one should also contemplate an infinite assembly of bodhisattvas. In the same way, one should contemplate the entire circle of the assembly. [One should also contemplate] oneself as a great bodhisattva, standing in the water up to one’s navel, performing a worship ceremony for the Bhagavān. Use various kinds of flowers belonging to gods and men, as well as various kinds of large flowers such as māndārava flowers, great māndāravas, lotuses, great lotuses, dhānuskārika, vārṣika, blue lotuses (indīvara),[886] and large-scale flower buds placed in a large heap. As well, one should also worship the Noble Śrāvakas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Bodhisattvas with powders, religious robes, umbrellas, royal banners, and flags, plus many hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of pleasing butter lamps belonging to gods and human beings. Similarly, one should offer sacrificial cakes, incense, divine food offerings, pūja, reverence, implements, etc., and the necessities of gods and men.

bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i smin mtshams kyi mdzod spu nas 'od zer mngon par 'phro bzhin pas bdag nyid dang phyogs thams cad kyang kun du snang bzhin par bsgom par bya'o/ / sgom pa po bsam gtan la zhugs ma thag tu/ tshangs pa'i bsod nams kyi 'bras bu thob bo/ / nges par byang chub mchog tu gzhol bar 'gyur ro/ /

One should contemplate light rays emanating from the treasury of hair (ūrṇakośa) between Bhagavān Śākyamuni’s eyebrows. [Imagine those light rays] entirely illuminating all the directions and oneself. As soon as the meditation practitioner enters one-pointed concentration, [that practitioner] will acquire the fruits of Brahmā’s merit and will surely embrace supreme enlightenment.
de lta bu sogs bsam gtan rnams/ / 'jig rten skyes mchog rnams kyis gsungs/ / 'byung po kun kyang legs pa dang / / sngags pa rnams la phan don dang / /
In this way, the concentrations, etc., Are spoken about by the excellent people of the world, In order to benefit the best of all creatures, And all mantra practitioners. [167]
de tshe bsam gtan dang po'i gtso/ / sngags pa kun la phan don du/ / sems can rnams kyi phyir gsungs so/ /
At that time, the foremost concentration Is spoken about for the benefit of all mantra practitioners And for living beings. [168]
de nas thub mchog bdun pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor rnam par brjod par bya/ / thub pas dang por gsungs pa yin/ / gnyis pa yi ni dkyil 'khor dang / / gsum par yang ni de las gzhan/ /

Then, one should discuss the maṇḍala Belonging to the [best],[887] most excellent sage. The first is spoken about by the sage. The maṇḍala of the second and the third, [Are spoken about] in addition to that. [169]
dang por mchog gi dngos grub ste/ / bar ma la ni de bzhin gzhan/ / chung ngu la ni phran tshegs 'grub/ / thub pa mchog gis nges par gsungs/ /

The first is for supreme attainments (siddhis), The middling [maṇḍala] has other [attainments], and The inferior [maṇḍala] accomplishes small [attainments], As was certainly stated by the excellent sage. [170]
de bzhin ras ris bsam gtan ni/ / thu bo bar ma chung ngu ste/ / thams cad sdig pa 'jig byed pa'o/ /
Thus, the concentrations for [the creation of] the painted cloth, Whether supreme, middling, or small,[888] Destroy all sins. [171]
de las gzhan yang mkhas pas ni/ / bsam gtan rnam pa rab bsgrub bya/ / bsam gtan de la rab gnas na/ / sngags rnams de la 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Other than that, the wise one Shall accomplish that type of concentration. When firmly established in that concentration, That [wise] one will accomplish those mantras. [172]
ji ltar 'dod pa'i cho ga bshad/ / zlos pos bsam gtan bsgoms nas ni/ / sngags kyi mchod yon der phul nas/ / ji ltar bde bar gshegs su gsol/ /
Thus, the reciter explained the desired ritual, Having contemplated the concentration, Presented a mantra offering there, and Respectfully permitted [the deity] to happily depart. [173]
chu tshogs de las bsgral nas ni/ / de nas ji ltar bde bar 'gro/ / gnas ni sngon du nges bstan par/ / cho ga mthong bas legs zhi bar/ /
Having crossed that body of water, Then, proceed happily To the place formerly shown, Fully appeased, having seen the ritual. [174]
de la sngags pas gsang sngags bzlas/ / sngar las ji ltar brjod pa bzhin/ / rang gi lha ni spyan drangs pa/ / der ni sngags kyis gshegs su gsol/ /
When the mantra practitioner recites the secret mantra, Expressed as it was during the former ritual, One’s own deity who was invoked there, With the mantra, is permitted to depart. [175]
de nas bdag nyid de bzhin nyid/ / grogs po rnams ni bsrungs byas nas/ / dge ba'i las kyis de nyid shes/ / cho ga'i las la dga' zhing 'dud/ /
Then, having protected oneself, And one’s friends in this way, The virtuous knower of the rituals’ principles, Longs for[889] and delights in executing the ritual. [176]
rnam pa sna tshogs bstod mchod kyis/ / gang zag mchog la kun bstod nas/ / rang sngags sngags kyis mgon po dang / / nyan thos rang rgyal bse ru dang / /
Using various reverent offerings and praises, Having extolled the Excellent Person, One’s own mantra, the mantra Lord, Śrāvakas, Pratyekabuddhas, [177]
byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / 'jig rten gsum po rjes 'dzin bzod/ / de nas gsang sngags zlos pa pos/ / stan de las ni slar langs nas/ /
And Bodhisattva Great Beings, Able to show favor to the three worlds, The reciter of the secret mantra, Arose from that seat, as before, [178]
thag ring gnas su song nas ni/ / phyi rol rlung gi rnam par spangs/ / snabs dang mchil ma rnam par dor/ / bshang dang gci ba'ang de bzhin no/ /
And went to a distant place, Deprived of outside winds, To discharge mucus and spittle, Urine and excrement. [179]
nyin par byang du kha phyogs shing / / mtshan mo lho ru kha blta'o/ / sngags zlos pos ni nam yang der/ / don rnams bsam par mi bya'o/ /
During the day, [sit] facing north, At night, [sit] facing south. Once there, the mantra reciter, Should never think about ordinary [worldly] matters. [180]
der ni rang las byed gsungs pa'i/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa mi bya'o/ / rab sngags 'gro ba mtshan sogs kyi/ / de tshe sa stengs nyer 'dug ste/ /
There, do not perform[890] mantra recitation, Spoken to perform one’s own rituals. The praiseworthy one is seated On the surface of the earth.[891] [181]
dag pa'i chu yis nye reg bya/ / gtsang ma'i gos mtha' chur gzhug bya/ / sa yi phung po bdun nyid kyis/ / 'bad pas rkang pa bkrus byas nas/ /
Having cleansed [the body] with pure water, Immerse the hem of clean clothes in the water, And cleanse both feet with effort, Using seven heaps of fragrant earth. [182]
rab tu 'dzag pa bdun blangs nas/ / bshang ba 'dzag pa sum cu ste/ / gnyis ka'i mtha' la lag pa dag / mchil ma dor ba nyid dang ni/ / snabs la'ang gnyis de de bzhin no/ /
Clean the hands at the end of both discharges: Seven [times] for expelling [urine], And thirty [times] for excrement. Also [clean] when casting out phlegm, And similarly when [expelling] mucus. [183]
de nas 'bad pas nye reg bya/ / gnas la ring du song ba'i sar/ / de bzhin sgra tsam song nas ni/ / lam la sogs pa yangs pa ru/ /
Then, with effort, rinse [the body.] Having gone a long distance from that place, Having gone as far as the voice [can be heard], Avoiding the road, etc. [184]
de nas gzhan gyi ci 'dod bzhin/ / lho phyogs mtha' yi phyi rol tu/ / chu dang g.yang sa med pa dang / / de bzhin bye mas khyab pa dang / /
Otherwise, [go] wherever one wishes, Outside the border of the southern direction, Which has water, but lacks a deep chasm, And is also covered with sandy soil. [185]
chu klung spangs shing ngogs kyang spangs/ / 'bad pas mi gtsang chu spangs par/ / gsang zhing shin tu sbyangs pa dang / / bas mtha' ljongs ni spangs pa dang / /
Avoid the river, avoid the bank, With effort, avoid dirty water, Concealed and very clean, Avoid the suburbs. [186]
rnam par dben pa'i sar song nas/ / sngags pas mi gtsang dor bar bya/ / zlos po dus ni shes byas nas/ / ji ltar 'dod pa'i shugs dag min/ /
Having gone to a solitary spot, The mantra practitioner casts out impurities. The reciter, knowing the proper time, Should not delay the process. [187]
de nas dag pa'i phyogs song ste/ / bas mthar de bzhin bshang ba dang / / gci ba'i bya ba byas nas ni/ / de ru lus ni ci bde bar/ /
Then, having gone to a clean area, Defecate in solitude, and Discharge urine, There, where the body is comfortable. [188]
gnyis ka'ang gsang g.yogs sbas pa dang / / skye bo med pa'i sa spang bar/ /
Either on a secret, hidden covering, or On the surface of the earth without people,

mi smra reg pa spangs nas ni/ / rtag tu gci ba bya ba yin/ / lus la lha gnas bshang ba dang // brtul zhugs can dag gtsang sbra bya/ / reg na gzhon sha can rnams 'dod/ / srog chags spangs pa'i sa rnams ni/ /

Silently, avoiding touching anything, One should always expel urine, [189] And eliminate feces from the body. The vow-holder should always be clean, Touching fragrant earth that is soft, Powdered, and devoid of insects. [190]

gsum po tshul bzhin blangs nas ni/ / rtag pa kho nar bshang lam la'o/ / de bzhin gnyis ka'i mthar lag pa/ / sngags pas rtag tu sa dag ni/ / sngar bstan pa dag blangs nas ni/ / zlos bos rtag tu rkang pa nyid/ / g.yas dang de las gzhan pa ni/ / phan tshun nyid du kun bzhag nas/ / 'bad pas rkang pa bkru bar bya/ /

Having grasped [earth with these] three [qualities], In this way, always [clean] the anus, When finished, with [two] hands. The mantra practitioner always uses clean earth. [191] Having taken that [earth] previously shown, The reciter, always [cleanses] the feet, The right and the [left] Having pressed them together, The feet should be cleansed with effort. [192]

rgya cher sngar ni brjod pa bzhin/ / sngags zlos po yi gtsang sbra yang // dri nga med pa'i gtsang sbra ste/ / rtag tu thub pa nyid kyis gsungs/ / 'di dag mdor bsdus bstan pa yin/ / rgyud rnams kun du mthong ngo zhes/ / mnga' bdag thub pa nyid kyis gsungs/ / de nas zlos pos nye reg bya/ / sdom brtson dngos grub las la dga'/ / sngar brjod pa yi cho ga yis/ / yid kyi nang gi dag pa yin/ /

The purity of the mantra reciters Has been extensively expressed in the past. Just as stainless bodily purity Has always been discussed by the Sages.[892] [193] These [rules] have been discussed in brief, And are seen in all the tantras. Spoken about by the Master Sage. [194] Then, the reciter should be consecrated by bathing. The ascetic delights in the rituals of attainment. The mind is purified from within Using the ritual previously expressed. [195]

gtsang sbra rnam pa lnga ru brjod/ / sngags pas sngags rnams thams cad du/ / lus kyi gtsang sbra de bzhin du/ / ngag yid kho nar rab tu bsgrags/ / bzhi pa bden pa'i gtsang sbra ste/ / chu ni lnga par brjod par bya/ / bden pa'i chos ni khro ba thul/ / rgyud shes bstan bcos mthong ba dang // phra mo'i de nyid don la mkhas/ / sngags shes las la grags pa dang // rgyu yis nang la mkhas pa ste/ / de la dngos grub rnyed mi dka'/ / bden pa'i chos ni rnam spangs pa'i/ / brdzun pa'i tshig ni smra mi bya/ /

Five kinds of purification [rituals] are explained For mantra practitioners in all the [tantras]:[893] Purification of body, as well as Speech and mind are exclusively extolled. The fourth is purification of truth. [Purification of] water is expressed as the fifth. [196] The Dharma of truth tames anger. Knowers of tantra and seers of scripture are Skillful in the meaning of [reality’s] subtle nature, Knowledgeable about mantras, engaged in rituals, [197] And learned about the inner nature of causes.[894] For them, attainments are not difficult to acquire. Words of falsehood should not be spoken,[895] These are rejected by the Dharma of Truth. [198]

bden pa thams cad rnam spangs pa'i/ / ma rungs rab tu ma rungs nyid/ / rnam par sdang dang 'khrugs bcas dang // rtsub cing gnad ni 'gems pa dang // bden pa'i chos ni rnam par nyams/ / sems can gzhan la gdung bar byed/ / phra ma nyon mongs can sems dang // chos rnams thams cad spangs pa dang // de bzhin 'tshe ba'i bdag nyid can/ / rtag tu khrims 'chal chos min spyod/ / sngags zlos pa yis spang bar bya/ / de bzhin nyid du grong gi chos/ /

Those who abandon all the truths Who are cunning and absolutely cruel, Extremely angry and quarrelsome, And merciless murderers,[896] [199] Damage the Dharma of truth, Torment other living beings, Slander, possess defiled thoughts, Abandon all virtue (dharma), [200] Are violent in nature, always immoral, And never practice the Dharma. The mantra reciter abandons [these characteristics] As well as the [uncivilized] duties of a villager. [201]

khro ba brnab sems 'byung ba yi/ / 'jig rten pha rol 'jigs pa rnams/ / blo ldan rang rgyal bse ru dang / / slar yang rtag tu nyon mongs dang / / sngon gyi sangs rgyas rnams kyis smad/ / de bzhin rtag tu brdzun smra ba/ / 'jig rten dngos grub 'dod don gnyer/ / sa stengs brdzun smra nye bar smra/ / mi bzad dmyal ba chen por ltung / / sngon gyis nyes pa las de bzhin/ / dga' bas gshin rje'i 'jig rten du/ / rtag tu slar yang der gnas so/ / rtag tu brdzun smras nyer 'tsho ba/ / mi bzad ngan 'gror ltung bar 'gyur/ /

Fears of the next world Arise from anger and greed. Thus, liars are always Censured by wise [Bodhisattvas][897] Pratyekabuddhas, Śrāvakas, And moreover, by the former Buddhas. [202] Talkative liars on the surface of the earth Who strive to acquire worldly accomplishments, Fall into the great, unbearable hells,[898] According to the certainty of former actions. [203] Due to [attachment to] pleasure, they will remain there, Perpetually in the world of Yama. Always living with liars, They will fall into unbearable, lower states. [204]

thig nag rab tu tsha ba dang / / yang sos ral gri lo ma dang / / de bzhin shal ma la yi nags/ / der ni bskal pa mang por gnas/ / brdzun du smra ba'i skye bo ni/ / gsang sngags log par smra ba dang / / rmongs pas log par brjod pa yi/ / 'byung po rnams la slu byed pa/ / de la grub pa ga la yod/ / de phyir rmongs pa las 'di yis/ / sngags kyi dngos grub ma mthong nas/ / sngags pa'i dngos grub med do zhes/ / 'di skad du ni tshig smra ba/ / gang gis sangs rgyas bstan pa ni/ / sa stengs 'dir ni rab spangs pa/ / bskal pa bye ba mang po yis/ / de yis grub par ga la 'gyur/ / de phyir 'di ni mi bzad pa'i/ / 'jigs chen mnar med 'tshed par 'gyur/ / yang sos dang ni thig nag dang / / rab tu tsha bar 'tshed pa dang / /

In the burning hell “Sawn to Pieces,”[899] The forest of “Biting Sword-like Leaves” And the Śālmali Forest,[900] There, they remain for many aeons. [205] Living beings who are liars, Say the secret mantra incorrectly. When ignorant ones pronounce it incorrectly, They deceive living creatures. [206] How could that one accomplish anything? Due to [lying], this deluded one does not realize The attainments of the mantra for this ritual. Thus, the mantra practitioner has no attainments. [207] Once words are spoken [erroneously] in this way, Having abandoned the Buddha’s teachings On the surface of this Earth, How could that one accomplish anything — Even after many tens of millions of aeons? [208] Due to that, one will boil in the unbearable Avīci hell [Unceasing Torment] of Great Dangers, And the scorching hells of Sañjīva[901] and Kālasūtra[902] [209]
der ni bskal pa chen por gnas/ / dam tshig snang ba bral ba'i phyir/ / dmyal ba mi bzad mun pa ru/ / byis pa'i skye bo 'tshed par byed/ /
Remaining there for a Great Aeon, Disconnected from the illuminating, virtuous Dharma, Makes immature people roast In the unbearable darkness of hell. [210]

dam pa'i chos la smad pa dang / / mi shes mun pas bsgribs pa dang / / ye shes byis pa'i ngo bo 'am/ / rmongs pa log pa'i nga rgyal can/ / rig pa'i rgyal po brnyas byed pa/ / mi bzad dmyal bar ltung bar 'gyur/ / de phyir sdig pa mi bya zhing / / log par smra ba'ang smad pa yin/ / dam pa'i chos la brnyas pa dang / / log par lta ba smad pa yin/ / de phyir rtag tu dad gyur nas/ / gsang sngags cho ga rtag tu bsten/ / bden par smra zhing chos shes pa/ / sems can rnams la rtag tu phan/ /

Covered with the darkness of ignorance, One blames the virtuous Dharma, Due to an ignorant, childish nature, Deluded by false pride. [211] Disrespecting the best of vidyās, One will fall into an unbearable hell. Due to that, neither commit non-virtuous action, Nor speak falsely, nor censure [the Dharma]. [212] Those who disrespect the virtuous Dharma, And have wrong views are censured. Therefore, be forever faithful, Always serve the ritual of the secret mantra, Speak the truth, know the Dharma, and Always benefit living beings. [213]

sngags shes sngags ni sten par byed/ / de yi dngos grub nges par 'gyur/ / mchog dang 'bring dang tha ma yis/ / las ni rnam pa sna tshogs byed/ / las rnams bya ba rnams kyis byed/ / rtag tu phan pa'i bya ba yis/ / bya ba'i las dang yang dag ldan/ / de la rtag tu grub par 'gyur/ / bya ba'i don dang don kun phyir/ / las ni rnam pa sna tshogs bya/ / bya ba'i don du bya min gang / / bya ba'i las la sbyar bar bya/ / 'bras bcas nyid kyi bya don gyi/ / bya ba nyid du rtag tu bya/ /

Attainment is certain for that mantra knower Who serves the mantra, and Performs various kinds of Superior, middling, and minor rituals. [214] One who undertakes the activities of the rituals, With performances that are always beneficial, And is devoted to the rituals of performance, Will always be successful. [215] For the sake of ritual activities (kriyā) and indeed all aims, One should always engage in the aims of ritual performance. Anything that is done for the purpose of ritual or not Should still be performed in accordance with the ritual. Always engage in just those purposive ritual actions And those [actions] associated with the [ultimate] fruit. [216]

bya ba las dang 'bras bu nyid/ / bya ba las 'bras rtag tu'o/ / 'bras med 'bras bu nyid 'gyur zhing / / 'bras bu nyid kyang rtag tu 'bras/ / 'bras med 'bras bu bcas pa nyid/ / thams cad nyid kyang 'bras bu bcas/ / rnal 'byor sngags ni bsgrub bya ste/ / yang dag sbyor dang bral ba yang / / bral dang yang dag ldan sgrub po/ / bsgrub bya sgrub byed med par ni/ / de la grub pa yod ma yin/ / grub pa'i rdzas ni thams cad kyang / / grub pa'i rgyu dang 'gal ba yin/ / sngags kyi dngos grub ma grub pa/ / sngags ni sgrub par byed pa'i rgyu/ /

As for the ritual actions performed and fruits The ritual actions (kriyā) performed are always [fruitful]. What is fruitless shall become fruitful, While the fruitful shall always be fruitful. All — the fruitless together with the fruitful — Shall only be fruitful. [217] Through right application (saṃyoga), the mantra is accomplished. A practitioner who is separated from right application, Lacking the method to be accomplished, Will not have success (siddhi). [218] That one will not succeed [when] All the ingredients of accomplishment As well as the causes of accomplishment are contradicted. That one will not accomplish the siddhis of the mantra. The mantras are the cause of propitiating the deity. [219]

byed par 'dod pa de las te/ / 'dod pa'i las ni byang bar 'gyur/ / las min las ni thams cad la/ / las kyi rgyud ni mi bya'o/ / sngags dang rgyud kyi don ldan pa'i/ / las ni mtha' dag brtsam par bya/ / brtsams dang rtsom pa'i 'dud pa yi/ / las nyid brtsam par mi bya'o/ / bya ba ma brtsams sngags rnams ni/ / lus can kun la 'grub mi 'gyur/ /

Wishing to perform that ritual Gives rise to the action one strives to perform. Inaction during all rituals May not produce the causes of the rituals.[903] [220] Undertake all rituals Endowed with the aims of mantra and tantra. One should not undertake [inaction] Regarding rituals begun or to be started. [221] The mantras whose performances have not commenced Will not succeed for all living beings. [222]

sems can kun rjes skyong ba yi/ / thub pa'i gtso bos sngon gsungs pa/ / gsang sngags smra bas bstan pa yi/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyi yang dag sdom/ / sgrub po sngags ni kun shes shing / / rtog pa'i rgyal po 'di la tshig / sngags kyi tshul gyis bstan pa yin/ / lam ni byang chub rgyur gyur pa/ / sngags kun nyid ni sgrub par byed/ / rig pa mnyam par 'gyur ba yin/ / de ni ring por mi thogs par/ / mkhas pas dngos grub 'gyur ba yin/ /

The protector of all living beings, And pre-eminent Sage, previously spoke about The pledge of the Bodhisattvas [Sons of the Conqueror][904] As explained by the oral teachings of the secret mantra. [223] The practitioner and knower of all the mantras and Words in this [matchless][905] king of ritual texts, [States:] The path for the cause of enlightenment Is explained using the methods of the Mantra[yāna]. [224] All the mantras to be accomplished Shall become equal to the vidyā.[906] For that one among the wise ones, There shall be attainment without delay! [225]

'byung po thams cad zhi don du/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis rab tu bsgrags/ / gsang sngags tshul gyi lam 'dis ni/ / mya ngan 'das grong 'gro ba yi/ / de bzhin rtag tu byang chub lam/ / chos don thams cad rdzogs par byed/ / de yi mthar thug dpung gnyen ni/ / dang po gnas ni sangs rgyas nyid/ / de bzhin 'dir ni lhun grub tu/ / 'bras bur bcas pa'i dngos grub thob/ / sna tshogs las dang chos shes pa/ / sngags rnams byed par 'gyur ba yin/ /

For the purpose of pacifying all creatures, One will reach the city of nirvāṇa, Through this path of the secret mantra system, Proclaimed by all the Buddhas. [226] Thus, the eternal path to enlightenment Fulfills all the aims of Dharma,[907] The conclusion of which is to embrace Buddhahood as the foremost state. [227] The attainment of siddhis, together with fruits Will be spontaneously achieved here. The knower of Dharma and various rituals Will perform the mantras. [228]

tshul khrims bsam gtan rnam thar rnams/ / 'di rnams mdor bsdus thob pa yin/ / dngos grub don kun sgrub byed pa/ / rgyal ba gtso bos gsungs pa yin/ / gang zag rkang pa'i don thob pa/ / dam pa'i 'gro bar gnas pa dang / / de bzhin rtag tu gnod sbyin gtso/ / tha mas rgyal srid rgyu yin te/ / lha min lha yi 'jig rten gyi/ / de bzhin de rnams bdag po ni/ / sngags pas thams cad thob par 'gyur/ / bya ba 'bras bcas byed par 'gyur/ /

In short, by acquiring these [three] — Morality, meditation, and liberation — One will attain every goal of accomplishment (siddhi), As expressed by the pre-eminent Conqueror. [229] An ordinary person[908] who obtains [the] true meaning, Dwells in a sacred state, Just as, [even] the lowliest ruler Is always the cause of a kingdom. [230] Accordingly, the master of those [living in] The worlds of gods, demi-gods, and humans,[909] Will attain everything through the mantra, And will carry out the rituals together with the fruits. [231]

gtsang sbra'i kun spyod yang dag ldan/ / tshul khrims bsam gtan rtag tu dga'/ / sngags rnams kun tu gsungs pa yin/ / de nas sngags pas sngags bzlas bya/ / sngags pa 'byor ba 'dod pa yis/ / rnam pa sna tshogs las byas te/ / de bzhin mchog dang bar ma dang / / tha ma nyid kyang bya ba yin/ / tha mas longs spyod 'phel ba yin/ / bar mas gong ma'i lus can nyid/ / mchog nyid kyis ni ldang ba nyid/ / zlos pos rtag tu thob par byed/ /

Possessing clean habits of daily living, and Always delighting in morality and meditation, The mantra practitioner should recite the mantra Among all mantras that are spoken. [232] The mantra practitioner desiring good fortune, Has performed rituals of various kinds, Thus, the performances are Superior, middling, and lowest. [233] The reciter[910] always attains Increased enjoyment with the lowest [rituals], A superior body with middling [rituals], and The best [attainments] with superior [rituals].[911] [234]
sngags pas bzlas mthar ngal bso zhing / / ji srid dus su brtag par bya/ / bzlas pa'i dus la bab pa na/ / der ni bsgrub pa bya ba yin/ /
At the end of recitation, the mantra practitioner rests,[912] And should examine the time. When the time has arrived for recitation, The practice (sādhana) should be performed there. [235]
de bzhin las rnams sgrub par byed/ /
In this way, [all] the rituals will be performed. [236]

de la rtag tu bzlas pas skyes bu rang gi sdig pa zad par byed do/ / sngags pas sngon las kyi cho ga gang byas pa skye ba brgyud pa rnams su grub par gnas pa de/ de bzhin du las tshogs la rnyed par 'gyur ba de skyes pas sngags bzlas pas/ slar yang sngags zlos pa po'i sdig pa zad pa'i don dang / las de 'joms shing sngags grub par 'gyur te/ de bzhin du mchog dang / bar ma dang tha ma'i 'jig rten gyi mchod pa dang bzlas pas sdig pa ma lus par zad par byed cing / skye ba brgyud pa rnams su gang bar byas/ sdig pa de thams cad 'jig par byed de de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi sngags bzlas pas/ lus rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa dang / thub pa rnams kyis gnas pas dga' ba dang / yon tan thams cad kyis grags par 'gyur ba dang / gnod sbyin gyi khang par gnas pa'i rgyal po nyid dang / rtag tu don thams cad kyi dngos grub kyang thob pa dang ldan no/ /

There, the reciter will always exhaust the defilements of his being. The mantra practitioner who has performed the methods of former rituals will remain a siddha in successive births. Similarly, this one will achieve a multitude of rituals. The person who has recited the mantra will furthermore accomplish the aim of consuming the defilements of the mantra reciter, will destroy bad karma, and will accomplish the mantra. Similarly, the reciter and worshiper who belong to the superior, middling, and inferior worlds will entirely consume defilement, and will destroy all non-virtuous action made in successive lives. Capable ones who recite the mantras of the Tathāgatas, whose bodies are adorned with ornaments of various kinds, who delight in living, who continually cultivate all good qualities, shall attain sovereignty over the dwelling places of the yakṣas, and always achieve the attainments (siddhi) of every aim.

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde/ bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las/ ras ris bar ma'i cho ga rab 'byam ste dgu pa rdzogs so// //

This completes the ninth chapter of the Extensive Ritual of the Middling Painted Cloth from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyānavaipulya sūtra, and the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[ras ris bar ma'i cho ga rab 'byam las bcu pa bgrang phreng gi cho ga]
Chapter B.10: The Extensive Chapter of the Ritual of Prayer Beads

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor la gzigs nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bka' stsal pa/ byang chub sems dpa' chen po khyod nyon cig /khyod kyi rig pa'i sngags rjes su spyod pa sems can mtha' dag gi don la brtson pa/ sems can rnams gang gis bzlas par bya ba'i rig pa'i sngags dang / gang dang ldan pas bgrang bar bya ba'i bgrang phreng gi cho ga /rgyud thams cad kyi thun mong gi sgrub thabs kyi cho ga sngags thams cad kyi cho ga de legs par nyon la/ legs par yid la zung shig bshad par bya'o/ / de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / sems dpa' chen pos bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das legs so legs so/ / bcom ldan 'das bdag cag la rjes su brtse bas nye bar blangs nas rig pa'i sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa dang / dam tshig la rab tu zhugs pa'i sems can rnams dang / semasacan thams cad kyi don gyi phyir yang de bka' stsal du gsol/ / de skad ces gsol ba dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ / sems dpa' chen po rnam par dbye ba rgyas par bshad par bya'o nyon cig /gang gis sngags thams cad kyi spyod pa la mngon par brtson pa/ sems can gyi don thams cad sgrub par byed pa de gang zhe na/ dang po re zhig /sngags su 'gyur ba ni/

Once more, the Bhagavān Śākyamuni looked at the entire circle of the assembly, and spoke to the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva Noble Avalokiteśvara. “O Great Bodhisattva! Please listen! The ritual of threading prayer beads, which is a ritual of propitiating the deity common to all tantras and a ritual of propitiating the deity of all mantras, shall be counted in accordance with your vidyā-mantra, and with the vidyā-mantra to be recited by sentient beings striving for the aims of all living beings. Please listen well and keep it in mind!” Having been addressed in this way, the Great Being asked the Bhagavān these words, “O Bhagavān. Excellent! Excellent! Out of compassion for us, having suffered for the benefit of sentient beings who have engaged in the pledge and in the practices of all vidyā-mantras, and for the aims of all living beings, let the Bhagavān please speak about that [vidyā-mantra].” Having been spoken to in this way, the Bhagavān said this to the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva Avalokiteśvara, “O Great Being! Please listen. [That vidyā-mantra] shall be fully explained, part by part, through which all the aims of living beings who expend effort to practice all the mantras shall be successful! What is it?

na maHsarba bud+hA nAM/ a tsin+t+ya d+d+hU ta/ rU pi nAM/ a tsin+t+yad+d+hu ta/ rU pi nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M ku ru ku ru sarba aR+tha sA d+hA ya/ sarba duSh+Ta bi mo ha ni/ ga ga nA ba laM be/ bi sho d+hA ya swA hA/
Namaḥ sarva buddhānāṃ acintyadbhutarūpināṃ / Tadyathā Oṃ kuru kuru sarva artha sādhaya [sādhaya][913] / Sarva-duṣṭa-vimohani / gaganāvalambe / viśodhaya svāhā //
Praise all the Buddhas whose forms are inconceivably wonderful. As follows: Oṃ Perform! Perform all aims! Succeed! Succeed! Deluding all that is evil! Support the heavens! Purify! Hail!
rig pa 'dis bgrang phreng thams cad la las bya'o/ / sbyang ba dang / dbugs pa dang / blang ba dang / rgyu ba la sogs pa'i las rnams bya'o/ /
This vidyā shall perform the rituals for all prayer beads and shall perform the rituals for purifying [the beads], piercing [a hole in the beads], seizing, and threading[914] [the beads].”
dang po bgrang phreng shing la ni/ lan grangs sum cu rtsa bdun du/ / de yis mngon par bsngags byas nas/ / brtul zhugs can gyis bsrung ba bya/ /
First, having consecrated Wooden prayer beads Thirty-seven times with that [vidyā], A vow holder, whose protection has been performed, [1]
mtshan mo gcig tu gnyid log nas/ / der ni rmi lam brtag par bya/ / mi ma yin gzugs kun rdzogs pa/ / mi sdug lhag par mche ba gtsigs/ /
Falls asleep for one night. There, [the vow holder] sees in dream A non-human being, possessing an ugly, fang-bearing form. [2]

sngags pa la ni des smras pa/ / bcom ldan sems pa ji bzhin long / / sgrub po tho rangs langs nas ni/ / shing de ru ni 'gro bar byed/ / mi sdug gzugs ldan gtsigs pa che/ / rmi lam du yang ma mthong na/ / sngags pas shing de bor bar bya/ / de nas gzhan du 'gro bar gyis/ / dang po ru drAk+Sha yin te/ / de las gzhan pa dbang po'i shing / / bo de tse ni 'dod pa'o/ / gzhan yang 'bras bu 'byung ba yi/ / shing la 'dzegs pa'i legs rdzogs pa'i/ / grogs dang lhan cig 'dzeg par bya/ / grogs po med par gyur na ni/ / rang nyid de la 'dzeg par bya/ /

That [being] says to the mantra practitioner, “Oh fortunate one! Request whatever you wish!”[915] Causing the practitioner to arise at dawn, And go directly to that tree. [3] If the fang-bearing, ugly [creature], Is not seen according to the dream,[916] The mantra practitioner should leave that tree, And then, go to another. [4] At first, there is Rudrākṣa,[917] Other than that, there is the Indrākṣa tree. A Putrajīva [tree] is desirable.[918] Moreover, one should climb [5] A fruit-bearing tree, with a friend Who is an excellent climber. If one does not have any friends, Climb that [tree] alone. [6]

steng gi yal ga'i 'bras gnas su/ / 'dzegs nas phun tshogs brtul zhugs can/ / de la rtag tu bag yod pas/ / steng gi yal ga'i 'bras bu blangs/ / steng gi sa la legs sbyar bya/ / steng gi mchog gi dngos grub tu/ / gang zag mchog gis gsungs pa yin/ / bar mar dngos grub 'bring po ste/ / tha ma la ni 'og ma'o/ / srog chags rnams kyis ma smad pa'i/ / 'bras bu de rnams yang dag blang / / nub kyi yal ga las thob pa/ / rdzas kyi rgyur ni bsgrub par bya/ /

The perfect ascetic, having climbed To a place with fruit on a top branch, Continually mindful and discreet, Takes a fruit [protruding][919] from a top branch, and Practices the ritual [on that branch] above. [7] The upper [branch] is for the highest attainments (siddhi), As is stated by the Excellent Person, The middle [branch] is for moderate attainments, The bottom [branch] is for minor attainments. [8] Having carefully picked fruit That has not been damaged by insects, Obtained from branches in the west, They will be used as the substance[920] [for the beads]. [9]

byang gi gnod sbyin mo la sogs/ / lha rnams lhan cig 'gugs par byed/ / dgug pa'i bya ba bshad pa ni/ / kun gyi don du zhi phyir ro/ / lha dang lha min g.yul 'gyed dang / / mi'am ci dang srin po rnams/ / 'dod pa rnam pa sna tshogs byed/ / 'byung po thams cad rgyas pa'i phyir/ / 'bras bu dang bcas las rnams ni/ / ma lus spyod pa byed pa'o/ / shar gyi phyogs su yal ga dang / / der gnas 'bras bu 'byung ba rnams/ /

In the north, summon female tree spirits (yakṣiṇi), etc. Together with the gods (deva). It is explained that summoning is performed In order to pacify all [creatures].[921] [10] Gods (devatā) and demi-gods (asura)[922] engaged in battle, Kinnara[923] and rākṣasa Performed various kinds of [rituals],[924] For the prosperity of all creatures. [11] Performing the complete practice Of rituals, together with the fruits, On branches in the [tree’s] eastern direction, In that place, fruits will spring forth. [12]

de bzhin 'bad pas byas gyur na/ / tshe ring po yi don gyi rgyu/ / rtag tu sngags kyis dngos grub 'bras/ / rnam pa sna tshogs byed pa yin/ / gang zhig lhor ni 'gro ba yi/ / yal ga lo mar rab ldan pa/ / sems can rnams kyi srog 'phrog byed/ / de ni zlos pos 'bad pas spang / / lho ru rten pa'i yal ga la/ / 'bras bu gang du yang dag brjod/ / phyogs der gdung dbye dgra rnams kyi/ / srog ni 'jig par byed pa yi/ /

If performed with effort in this way, The causes for the purpose of long life, And the attainments resulting from recitation Are always fruitful, as are rituals of various kinds. [13] With effort, the reciter should abandon Branches that are laden with leaves Bending southward. That [ritual] deprives living beings of life. [14] Reciting evenly with those [prayer beads][925] Over fruits growing upward,[926] and On limbs leaning south, Causes pain[927] destroying the life[928] of enemies. [15]

bsod nams ma yin mang po'i rgyu/ / de ni zlos pos 'bad pas spangs/ / 'og tu 'phyang ba'i yal gar gnas/ / 'bras bu gang zhig rab bsgrags pa/ / lha ma yin dang ldan pa yi/ / sa yi 'og tu de rnams 'gro/ / de rnams 'bras bcas phreng ba ni/ / blangs nas yang dag rab bsgrags pa/ / 'og tu 'gro ba'i 'khri shing la/ / de nas de ni sa 'og 'gro/ / de ru rab tu zhugs nas lha'i/ / bde nyid zlos pos der 'gyur ro/ /

The causes are many for lack of merit. The reciter abandons that, with effort. Fruits that are celebrated Are located beneath a hanging branch. [16] Going with them beneath the earth[929] Belonging to the Dānava [maidens],[930] Having grasped prayer beads, together with those fruits, One will be thoroughly praised. [17] Like a creeping plant going below, Proceed with that to the underground, Having remained there, The reciter will obtain the happiness of the gods. [18]

lha min bu mos yang dag ldan/ / de ni bskal par gnas par byed/ / bgrang phreng 'bras bu kun blangs nas/ / de nas zlos pos bzlas pa bya/ / lhan cig srung ba byas nas ni/ / de nas ji ltar bde bar 'gro/ / de nyid ring po'i gnas su ni/ / gtsang ma'i phyogs der sngags pa ni/ / de bzhin rtag tu 'dug par bya/ / bgrang phreng skyes pa sbyar bar bya/ / brtson pas bgrang phreng 'bras bu blang / / de nas kun tu yang dag sbyang / /

United with an Asura maiden, Dwell there, and remain for an aeon, Having grasped the entire fruit and prayer beads, The reciter should then recite.[931] [19] Protection performed, together with [friends],[932] One then goes happily To a distant place in a pure direction. There, the mantra practitioner [20] Should always dwell accordingly, Producing and purifying prayer beads. With effort, having grasped the beads and fruit, Then, completely purify them. [21]

der ni phreng ba dbugs par grags/ / gsum bdun brgyad dang gcig dang ni/ / lan grangs nyi shu rtsa gcig tu/ / sngags shes der ni sbyang bar bya/ / rtag tu snga ma'i sngags kyis ni/ / brgyad dam bdun du bzlas byas pa/ / de nas de ni dag par 'dod/ / pad+ma'i rtsa lag legs brjod pas/ / bu mos bkal ba'i srad bu yi/ / sum 'gyur lnga dang ldan pa yi/ / brtul zhugs can gyis phreng thag bya/ /

Pierce the beads [imbued with the mantra][933] One, three, seven, eight, and [up to] twenty-one times. [22] There, the mantra knower should be purified, Always using the same, former mantra. Perform recitation for seven or eight [times]. Consequently, wish for that one’s purity. [23] Using thread produced[934] from lotus stalk fiber, That has been spun by a girl,[935] A vow holder should make the prayer bead cord Endowed with three or five strands. [24]

sngags kyi de nyid shes pas brgyu/ / 'bras bu phra mo zlum por bcas/ / rtag tu srogs chags bu ga med/ / yan lag ma nyams ma smad pa/ / mdzes shing kha dog sdug pa dang / / bu ga med cing gas pa med/ / ril bu zlum po ji bzhin pa/ / de bzhin ru drAk+Sha dang ni/ / bo de tse dang in+t+ra k+Sha/ / 'bras nyid rtag tu lung thang mdzes/ / 'bras bu dam pa'am gang gi tshe/ / sngags pa mchog tu brtson pa yis/ / 'bad pas bgrang phreng brgyu bar bya/ /

The knower of the mantra’s essence Strings together the small, round fruit, Always without worm holes, Neither mutilated nor blemished. [25] Beautiful, with attractive colors, Lacking holes and cracks, Just like round pills, including Rudrākṣa, Sutajīva, and Indrākṣa fruit. [26] Always undamaged and beautiful, At the time when the fruit has no defects, The mantra practitioner who has supreme striving, Using effort, should thread the prayer beads. [27]

gser ram yang na dngul dag gam/ / nor bu shel las byung ba dang / / mu tig dung nyid mu sa ra/ / byi ru yis kyang bya ba ste/ / phreng ba rnam pa sna tshogs bya/ / gzhan yang rin chen las byung ba'i/ / bgrang phreng bzang po bya ba dang / / sa las byung ba'i ldum po yi/ / ril bus bgrang phreng can dag ni/ / mnyam par bzhag ste srad bu brgyu/ / gzhan yang ril bu 'ga' zhig gam/ / 'bras bu'am khams las byung ba yis/ /

Made from either gold or silver, Jewels or crystal, Made with pearl, conch, Musāra, or coral, [28] Thread a variety of prayer beads, [including] Prayer beads of excellent quality Made of precious jewels, as well as Those with round balls made of earth. [29] Those who possess prayer beads And meditate on the strung thread, With beads made of any other fruit or Even, made from metal. [30]

ku sha'i rtse mos brgyus pa yang / / zlos pos 'bad de bya ba yin/ / brgya rtsa brgyad dam nyi shu lnga/ / lnga bcu 'di dag bar ma yin/ / sngags pa mnyam par gzhag pa yis/ / 'bras bu'i tshad rnams brgyu bar bya/ / stong rtsa brgyad pa nyid bya ba/ phreng ba 'di ni thu bo yin/ / phreng ba rnam pa 'di bzhi ni/ / sngags pas rtag tu brgyu bar bya/ / de nas brgyus te sngags rnams ni/ / phyi mo gsum mam gnyis nyid dang / /

Strung together with tips of kuśa grass, One who recites should perform that with effort. One hundred and eight or twenty-five, And fifty for middling ones. [31] The mantra practitioner who concentrates Should thread different varieties of fruit. One should make one thousand and eight [beads] For the prayer bead garland that is superior. [32] The four sections of this prayer bead garland Are always strung by a mantra practitioner. It is strung [while reciting] mantras Until two or three mātrās in length.[936] [33]

rgya lcags las byung gdu bu dang / / de bzhin gser dang dngul dag dang / / de nas zangs byung gdu bus kyang / / phreng ba kun nas brgyu bar bya/ / de nas mtha' ru yang mig bya/ / de la rim gyis dgod par bya/ / 'bad pas mdzes par dkri ba bya/ / sangs rgyas ma lus bzhugs par ni/ / yongs su gsal bar byas de nas/ / dkyil 'khor lta bur mthong ba yin/ / sbrul gyi gdengs ka'i rnam pa bzhin/ / yongs su dkris pas brgyan pa yin/ / mu tig do shal rnams mtshungs shing / / mgul rgyan rnam par sprul pa'o/ / de nas 'bab chu dge ba'i mthar/ / dri ma med la khrus byas nas/ /

The prayer bead collection[937] should be strung With bracelets made of iron, as well as Bracelets made of gold, silver, and then, bracelets of copper. [34] Next, having made a noose at the end, Set it down gradually, and With effort, coil it beautifully, Staying entirely bound.[938] [35] Having made it clearly visible, then, One should view the circular shape, Ornamented by coiling it In the shape of a hooded serpent, [36] Similar to pearl necklaces, and A serpent in the form of a necklace. Then, having bathed in the stainless [water][939] At the edge of a virtuous river, [37]

go rims ji bzhin khrus byas te/ / chu yi gnas la ldang bar bya/ / de bzhin brtson pas nye reg bya/ / bgrang phreng srad bu blangs nas ni/ / ba yi rnam lngas rab tu bkru/ / sa yi phye mas rab bkrus nas/ / gtsang ma'i gos la dri bzang gis/ / rjes su nye bar byugs pa dang / / rab tu bsngags pa'i kha dog kyang / / tsan+dan dkar po gur gum dang / / 'bad pas dron mos bkru bar bya/ / de bzhin gnyis ka 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

Having bathed in stages, Rise up from the water’s abode. Having bathed properly, with effort, Grasp the [small][940] threaded prayer beads, [38] Cleansed with the five products of a cow,[941] and Cleansed with fine particles of earth. Afterward, anointed on clean cloth And with fragrant [water].[942] [39] With effort and warmth, wash [the beads] With white sandalwood and saffron of praiseworthy color. Then, both shall depart. [40]

ji lta'i gnas su song nas ni/ / gang du ras ris bar pa ni/ / rgyal mchog thub pa'i gtso bo ni/ / shAkya seng ge mi yi mchog / ston pa'i gzugs brnyan de bzhin du/ / sa stengs rgyal ba'i ring bsrel can/ / mchod pa de yi spyan sngar dgod/ / de dang nye bar bzhag nas ni/ / de tshe de yi spyan snga ru/ / dam tshig la gnas stong rtsa brgyad/ / son pa'am brgya yang gcig tu ni/ / brgyad dang bcas pa bzlas byas nas/ /

Having gone to a place such as that, where there is A medium-sized painted cloth, [with an image of] The Excellent Victor, Chief of Silent Ascetics, The Lion among the Śākyas, and Best of Men. [41] Thus, place the offering [of prayer beads][943] In the presence of the image of the Teacher [Śākyamuni], Possessing the bodily relics of a Victor upon the Earth. Having placed [the offering] near that [image], [42] At that time, in the presence of that [image], Maintain the pledge and perform recitations of One thousand and eight seed syllables or One hundred, from one to eight [times]. [43]

nyin mtshan smyung bar gnas gyur nas/ / bdun pa'i thub la phreng ba dbul/ / snga ma de bzhin bzlas bya ba/ / tshad nyid de dang mnyam par bya/ / de nas phreng la yongs su bzlas/ / mtshan mo de nyid du 'khod de/ / ku sha bting ba'i sa gzhi la/ / sngags shes der ni nyal bar bya/ / rmi lam gang dang gang mthong ba/ / dge ba'i rmi lam mthong na ni/ / rmi lam nges par bstan pa yin/ / dngos grub de yis bsgrub par bya/ /

Having fasted for a day and a night, Offer the prayer beads to the [true][944] Silent Sage. Having recited as before, Perform it evenly in the same way. [44] Then, having recited continuously over the strung beads, Remain seated during that same night, On an earth foundation covered with kuśa grass. The mantra-knower should sleep there. [45] Whatever is seen in a dream, When observing a virtuous dream, That one shall accomplish the attainments (siddhi) Indicated in the dream. [46]

sangs rgyas nyan thos bse ru rnams/ / gal te rmi lam mthong gyur na/ / sngags pas 'bras bu bcas par 'grub/ / nges par de yi cho ga bya/ / dge slong gzugs dang bram ze yi/ / gzugs brnyan sna tshogs mdzes pa mthong / / gal te rmi lam de mthong na/ / phreng ba dbul bya de bzhin du/ / sngags kyi don kun sgrub pa po/ / de bzhin gdon mi za bar 'grub/ /

If a Buddha, Śrāvaka, or Prateykabuddha[945] Are seen in a dream, The mantra practitioner will be fruitful. Surely, perform this ritual. [47] Seeing a beautiful image Of a brahman[946] and the body of a monk, If having seen that in a dream, Offer prayer beads in that way, and Without a doubt, that practitioner will accomplish All the aims of the mantra. [48]

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las/ ras ris bar ma'i cho ga rab 'byam las bcu pa bgrang phreng gi cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam rdzogs so// //

This completes the extensive tenth chapter of the Ritual of Prayer Beads from the Extensive Ritual of the Middling Painted Cloth, from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-vaipulya Sūtra and the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[bgrang phreng srad bu'i cho ga]
Chapter B.11: The Extensive Ritual of the Fire Sacrifice

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas slar yang thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po la gzigs nas byang chub sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bka' stsal pa/ sems dpa' chen po khyod kyi rig pa'i sngags kyi le'u rdzogs pa'i khyad par gyi cho ga dang / sbyin sreg gi las rab tu sbyor ba'i rig pa'i sgrub pa yod de/ me la nye bar spyod pa'i khyad par gyi cho ga las gang du rig pa'i spyod pa la mngon par brtson pa'i sems can rnams rab tu sbyor zhing gnas par 'gyur ba de gang zhe na/ rig pa'i sngags kyi tshogs gsang chen ni/

Then, the Bhagavan Śakyamuni beheld the entire circle of the assembly, as before, and said this to the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva Noble Avalokiteśvara. “O Great Being! Your chapter of vidyā-mantras with a distinguished ritual compendium for the vidyā practitioner engaged in burnt offering rituals, has a distinguished ritual of fire worship, which shall be used by living beings who strive to practice the vidyā. What is it? The very secret words of the vidyā-mantra are:
tad+ya thA/ o~M tiSh+Tha ha ri ping+ga le/ hi rak+Sha di hi da dA dI pA ya hU~M phaT phaT swA hA/
Tadyathā Oṃ [ut]tiṣṭha haripiṅgale / Hi rakṣa d[e]hi dadāpāya Hūṃ phaṭ phaṭ [sarvavighnaṃ vināśaya] svāhā //
As follows: Oṃ Rise up! O Fire! Protect! Receive an offering! Hūṃ phaṭ phaṭ [destroy all obstacles] svāhā //

spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'di ni mchog gi snying po las thams cad byed pa/ 'dod pa thams cad ster ba'o/ / dang po re zhig sgrub pa pos me'i snying po 'di lan cig bzlas pas/ mar gyi sreg blugs gsum me la sbyin sreg bya ste me lha spyan drangs par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du rab tu sbyar te/ zhi ba can dang / rgyas pa can dang / drag po'i las rnams la yam shing rnam pa gsum du 'gyur ro/ /

“O Avalokiteśvara, this most excellent essence incantation [of fire], performs all rituals and grants all desires.” At first, the practitioner who has recited this essence [incantation] of Agni once, and has made a burnt offering using three sacrificial offerings of butter in the fire, shall invite the fire god Agni. Having been employed in this way, the fuel sticks in three parts will be used in the pacifying, prosperity, and fierce rituals.

mya ngan med shing zhi don du/ / khyad par brlan dang bcas pa nyid/ / mtho gang 'am ni khru gang tsam/ / sor mo gsum du'ang mtho ba yi/ / snam pa'i rnam pa rab tu shes/ / cho ga 'di ni bya ba yin/ / bu ga med cing ser ga med/ / de bzhin ne tso'i gshog pa 'dra/ / ljang dang dkar ba'i kha dog gam/ / kha dog nag po spang bar bya/ / srin bu rnams kyis zos pa spang / / bu ga med pa'ang yang dag sbyin/ /

Aṣoka wood is for the purpose of pacifying, Containing moisture is preferable, Measuring a little less than a cubit or a span, Or [the width of] three raised fingers, [1] This ritual should be performed. [With] an auspicious type [of wood] that is smooth, Without holes and cracks, Similar to parrot wings. [2] The colors white and green, And the color black should be avoided. Those eaten by worms should be shunned. Those without holes should be offered. [3]

gzhan yang kha dog mchog min pa/ / tha ma'i chos kyang spangs pa'o/ / de rnams skam dang rlon pa'ang yin/ / de yi tshe yang brtsam par bya/ / ma rul yon po min nyid dang / / shin tu ring ba'ang spang bar bya/ / de nas me thab byas nas ni/ / kun nas zur ni bzhi pa ru/ / 'og nyid du ni 'bad pas brko/ / khru bzhi pa yi tshad dang ni/ / khru gsum khru ni gnyis pa dang / / de bzhin nyid du khru gcig pa/ / rtag tu srog chags spangs pa dang / / bye mas leg par sbyar ba de/ / de nas pad 'dra'i kha khyer ni/ / kun nas dkyil 'khor rnam pa'o/ /

Furthermore, inferior colors And inferior Dharma should be avoided. Those [sticks] should [neither] be too dry [nor] too wet,[947] At the time when one begins [the ritual]. [4] They should neither be rotten nor crooked, Those that are very long should also be rejected. Then, make the fire hearth On all four sides. [5] Dig below, with effort, About four cubits in depth, Three cubits, two cubits, And, in the same way, even one cubit. [6] Always devoid of worms, And well-mixed with sand, Then, make a [raised] hearth like a lotus, In the shape of a complete circle (maṇḍala). [7]

yang na 'bad pas zur bzhi pa/ / 'dab ma gsum du bya ba'o/ / zhi ba can dang rgyas pa can/ / 'di yang yang dag bsgrags pa yin/ / mngon spyod la ni sa dbus su/ / rdo rje bya zhing rtse gnyis su/ / rtse mo gsum du bya ba yin/ / me thab rgya la khru gnyis re/ / gtsang ma'i phyogs su de bzhin bdar/ / chu klung 'gram du de bzhin spyad/ / bstan pa gcig gi phyogs rnams dang / / dur khrod khang pa stong pa ru/ / sbyin sreg legs par brtsam par bya/ / de bzhin ri bo'i rtse nyid dang / / rtag tu lha khang stong pa dang / / de bzhin nyid du dgon pa che/ / gang yang sgrub pa'i phyogs rnams ni/ / gang zag mchog gis gsungs pa dang / / sbyin sreg las ni thams cad la/ / de rnams gnas su gsungs pa yin/ /

Moreover, with effort, make three petals in all four corners. This is also proclaimed For pacifying and prosperity [rituals]. [8] For fierce abhicāra rituals, In the middle of that spot of earth, Make a single vajra with three points on both ends, Two cubits in width, inside the hearth. [9] Then, gently rub [the wood] in a pure place, Next to a [beautiful] river bank, In the region of a single mountain, And in an empty cemetery abode. [10] The burnt offering should be properly undertaken In like manner on a mountain peak, Always in an empty temple, and Similarly in the wilderness solitude. [11] The regions for practice Are stated by the Excellent Person. Those places are mentioned For all the burnt offering rituals. [12]

khru gang tshad du gnas pa yi/ / ku sha'i khres la nyer 'dug nas/ / der ni sngags shes khyad par du/ / sbyin sreg gi ni las bya'o/ / gnas de nyid du rab gnas pas/ / myur du dngos grub the tshom med/ / shar dang byang du kha phyogs pas/ / zhi ba can dang rgyas pa bya/ / lho ru drag po'i lam rnams te/ / de ni sngags pas spang bar bya/ / shar bltas zhi ba'i dngos grub ste/ / rgyas pa can yang byang du phyogs/ / de yis sngags ni dus rtag tu/ / rig pa'i bzlas pa brtsam par bya/ / bil ba arga slak+Sha dang / / n+ya gro d+ha yis rgyas las bya/ /

Seated upon a bundle of kuśa grass, On an area measuring almost a cubit, There, the distinguished mantra-knower, Should perform the burnt offering ritual. [13] Having become well-situated in that very place, Quickly and without a doubt, attainment will result. Facing the eastern and northern directions, Perform appeasing and prosperity [rituals]. [14] [Facing] south, fierce rituals [are performed]. The mantra practitioner should avoid those. Facing east, attainment for appeasing [rituals] will result. Face north for prosperity [rituals] as well. [15] Using those two [directions], the mantra practitioner Should begin reciting the vidyā continuously. Perform prosperity rituals using bilba, Amra, plakṣa, and nyagrodha [wood]. [16]

mngon spyod shing ni skam po dang / / tsha ba skyur dang rnon po rnams/ / de dag thams cad spang bya ste/ / thub pa rnams kyis rtag tu bkag / zhi ba can dang rgyas pa can/ / rlon pa'i shing gis rab tu shis/ / de bzhin drag las la shing skam/ / tsha ba skyur dang rnon po rnams/ / yam shing de rnams med na ni/ / shing la de rnams su rtag bya/ / rtse mo gnyis su brtag pa bya/ / sngo dang snum dang 'dra ba dang / / rma bya'i mgrin pa dang mtshungs pa'i/ / rnam pa de lta'i ku sha yis/ / kho ra yug tu ku sha ni/ / rtag tu dgram par bya ba ni/ / zhi ba can dang rgyas pa can/ / mar gad dang ni mtshungs pas so/ / de bzhin rtag tu skam po'i rtsis/ /

For fierce rituals, one should avoid All wooden sticks that are Moist, hot, pungent, and sharp. They are always prohibited by the silent sages. [17] For appeasing and prosperity [rituals], Using moist wood is commendable. Similarly, dry, withered wood for fierce rituals Is always rejected by the silent sages. [18] If you don’t have those types of sacrificial sticks, Visualize pieces of wood as them. Visualize kuśa grass with two points, Green and smooth, like a peacock’s neck in form. [19] The kuśa grass should always be scattered Along the circumference [of the hearth]. For appeasing and prosperity [rituals], Always use dry grass [green] as emeralds. [20]

sdig pa'i las ni bya ba ste/ / 'dir ni rgyal ba mchog gis bkag / dri med chu ni dag pa la/ / rtag tu srin bus spangs pa yi/ / de nas kun nas bsang gtor bya/ / g.yas phyogs su ni bskor byas te/ / brtson pas me ni sbar bar bya/ / cho ga ji bzhin nye reg bya/ / gtsang ma'i rtswa yi rtsa ba yis/ / sgron me tshad dang ldan byas nas/ / de nas khu tshur brtsams byas nas/ / 'bad pas me ni sbar bar bya/ / kha yi rlung gis mi bya ste/ / rtag tu gos kyi mthas kyang min/ / sham thabs bla gos mngon par spang / / gos gzhan gyis kyang lag pa yi/ /

Performing evil rituals here [on the Earth] Is prohibited by the Excellent Conqueror. With pure, stainless water Always devoid of worms, [21] Having sprinkled all around [with that water] While circumambulating to the right, One should cleanse oneself, according to ritual. Then, with effort, one should ignite the fire. [22] With roots of pure kuśa grass, Measuring the size of a torch, Having made a fist, One should ignite the fire with effort. [23] Do not [blow] air from the mouth, Never use ends of clothing. Avoid under garments and upper garments, And any other clothes. [24]

rlung gi nye bar gzhom pa la/ / mngon par dga' bas ma yin no/ / gtsang ma'i rlung yab de bzhin gos/ / nor bus kyang ni rlung yab bya/ / rlung ni yang dag 'byung ba 'dis/ / me ni mnyam par byas pa la/ / sngags shes pas ni me sbar bya'o/ / sbyin sreg don du mnyam gzhag pas/ / de nas g.yas pa min pa yis/ / der ni bsang gtor byas nas ni/ / der ni ba yi mar gyis ni/ / sreg blugs gsum ni sbyin par bya/ / de nas kyang ni phyag bya ste/ / sangs rgyas kun dang skyob pa dang / / rang sngags sngags kyi mgon po la/ / de nas ci 'dod phyag bya'o/ /

Do not delight in extinguishing [the fire] with one’s hand. Using a clean fan [made] from cloth, Leaves, or feathers, one should fan gently. [25] Using this [fan], wind will arise, Making the fire [burn] evenly. The mantra knower, having become well-concentrated For the purpose of the burnt offering, shall ignite the fire. [26] Then, not using the right hand, Cleanse that [fire] Having offered it three oblations Using cow’s butter. [27] After that, make salutations To all the Buddhas, the Protectors, And the Mantra Lord of one’s own mantra. After that, make salutations for whatever is desired. [28]

de tshe me yi snying po yi/ / sngags ni lan brgya bzlas pa yis/ / brtson ldan dri zhim me tog gis/ / rtag tu me ni spyan drang bya/ / sngags shes rtag tu spyan drangs nas/ / gnas la mkhas pas gdan dang gnas/ / sngags des dbul zhing gzhan gyis min/ / zho dang mar du bsres pa dang / / sbrang rtsi btags pa'i yam shing ni/ / de las lan gsum sbyin sreg bya/ / rgyas pa'i don du sngags dang las/ / kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng ba yis/ / 'khrugs pa der ni nges sbyar bya/ / skom pa tshim par bsam par bya/ / zhi ba'i las dang rgyas pa can/ / de la gsang sngags rig pa yis/ / lha yi gzugs ni dga' ba'o/ /

After making one hundred recitations of the mantra and The essence incantation of Agni, God of Fire, Through one’s own efforts, using fragrant flowers, One should continually invite Agni. [29] Having summoned [Agni] continuously, The mantra knower, knowledgeable about [offering Agni] a seat, Offers [Agni] a place to sit with that mantra, Not with another [mantra]. [30] Having crushed sacrificial sticks with honey, And curds mixed with butter, Perform the burnt offering three times over the fire. The ritual and mantra are for the purpose of prosperity. [31] [948]Once that raging [fire] is surely prepared, With a garland fully ablaze, Meditate on satisfying the thirsty one. For rituals of appeasing and prosperity, Delight that one, divine in form, With that very secret vidyā-mantra. [32]

mngon spyod las la thun mong pa'i/ / nges par 'byung ba'i lha rnams las/ / gzhan pa'i gzugs ni blta bar bya/ / rim pa ji bzhin me thab 'dir/ / ji ltar rnyed pa'i me tog dang / / mar la lan bdun yongs bzlas pas/ / de tshe spyan drang rnam pa der/ / ji ltar slar yang spyan drangs pa/ / lhag par gnas pas gnyis ka gnas/ / yam shing rdzas dang bsres pa dang / / mar dang sbrang rtsi mnyam bstan pa/ / de bzhin du ni zho bsres pas/ / stong ngam 'bum gyi tshad dang ni/ / brgya dang brgyad du'ang rtag par bya/ / de bzhin sngags pas rig pa bzung / / lan re bzlas shing me la dor/ /

Visualize forms — other than The gods that emerge from Mundane and fierce rituals — In succession, over this fire hearth. [33] Having recited seven times over butter And flowers of propitiation, At the time of invitation, in that manner, Summon, again, as before. [34] Having occupied both seats, Mix the substance of the sacrificial sticks, With equal amounts of butter and honey. Then mix it with curds, exactly so. [35] One should also imagine from one hundred To one thousand, or one hundred and eight [offerings]. In this way, the mantra practitioner, holding the vidyā in mind, Should recite it each time, casting wood in the fire. [36]

'bar ba'i me yi phreng ba dang / / de bzhin me lce gcig gyur pa/ / zhi ba'i las kyi sbyin sreg bya/ / du ba med la'ang rgyas pa can/ / du bcas drag po'i las rnams ni/ / rgyal bas smad cing spangs pa yin/ / me ni kha dog ldan gyur na/ / sbyin sreg las ni rab tu sbyar/ / zhi ba can la kha dog dkar/ / rgyal ba mchog gis rtag tu bsngags/ / gal te me dkar sbyin sreg byed/ / de la sngags rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ / de bzhin rtag tu kha dog dkar/ / rgyas pa can gyis dngos grub 'dod/ / nag po du ba'i kha dog dang / / ser skya yang ni sdig pa can/ /

When a garland of blazing fire Becomes a single tongue of fire, Perform the burnt offering ceremony of pacifying. Or, when there is no smoke, the prosperity ritual. [37] Fierce rituals with smoke Are censured and renounced by the Conqueror. If the fire possesses color, The burnt offering ritual was properly performed. [38] Pacifying [rituals] have a white-colored [fire]. These are always praised by the Excellent Conqueror. If the fire is white when performing the burnt offering, The mantras for that [ritual] will be successful. [39] Similarly, if the [fire’s] color is continually [red][949] Wish for attainments of prosperity [rituals]. When the color of the smoke is black, Or yellow-grey, evil [will result]. [40]

kha dog rnam gsum rab bsgyur bas/ / dngos grub rnam gsum 'di dag yin/ / gzhan pa'i kha dog sprin mdog gam/ / slar yang brtan pa'i sa stengs der/ / sngags pa de la dngos grub med/ / de lta'i kha dog 'dra ba'am/ / rnam pa sna tshogs kha dog can/ / me ni 'bar ba de mthong na/ / slar yang las rnams brtsam par bya/ / phyir zhing bzlas pa bya ba yin/ / gal te sngags ni grub gyur na/ / las kyi cho ga mthong ba yis/ / slar yang sbyin sreg la rab 'jug / gshegs gsol spyan drang nyid la ni/ / me yi sngags ni brjod par bya/ /

When [the fire] transforms into three distinct colors, There are three types of attainments.[950] [For] other colors, [such as] the color of clouds,[951] Colors similar to that, or colors of various kinds, There are no attainments for those mantra practitioners, Again, on the surface of the earth. [41] When seeing that fire burning [with undesirable colors], One should begin the rituals once again. Subsequently, if [the mantra is] repeatedly recited, Then, the mantra will be successful. [42] By seeing the methods of the ritual, Engage again in the burnt offering. One should express the fire mantra For the invitation and dismissal [of the deity]. [43]

sngar ni rab tu brtags pas kyang / / dkyil 'khor 'di ni gshegs su gsol/ / spyan drang ba yi las rnams ni/ / de nyid du ni las rnams kyang / / de nyid kyis ni bya ba yin/ / me yi spyod pa de bzhin gzugs/ / ras ris kyi ni spyan sngar brtsam/ / der ni sngags rnams 'grub 'gyur bar/ / sngon gyi de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs/ / rgyal bas bsngags pa'i las rnams ni/ / thams cad de nyid du bya'o/ / gzhan pa'i las ni bya ba ste/ / sdig pa'i las ni khyad par du/ / gang du rgyal mchog gis smod dang / / 'jig rten 'gal dang smad rnams so/ /

Using the previous preparations For the rituals of invitation And dismissal in this maṇḍala, By means of that [burnt offering ritual], [All] rituals are performed accordingly. [44] The fire practices of such form, Are practiced in the presence of the painted cloth, There, the mantras will be successful. This was formerly stated by the Tathāgata. The rituals praised by the Conqueror, Shall be performed in their entirety. [45] Additional rituals shall not be performed, Especially the sinful rituals, Which are censured by the excellent Conqueror, And reviled and despised by the world. [46]

ldang dang 'khor los sgyur ba dang / / byang chub sems dpa'i sa rnams dang / / de bzhin mngon shes lnga dang ni/ / 'jig rten lha nyid ldan pa 'grub/ / rtag tu ras ris la brtson shes/ / sbyin sreg las la mkhas pa ni/ / sa yi 'og gi bdag po'am/ / yang na bar snang spyod par 'gyur/ / sa bla'i lha dang gnod sbyin nyid/ / rtag tu gnod sbyin mo rnams 'gugs/ / rgyal srid bdag po nyid dang ni/ / yul dang yang na grong nyid dam/ / rig pa 'dzin dang lha min nyid/ / sems can thams cad dbang du byed/ / 'byung po thams cad 'gugs par byed/ / sems dpa' chen po bdag nyid che/ /

A brave wheel-turning emperor, who has attained The bodhisattva stages and The five kinds of supernatural perception, As well as divinity in the world, shall succeed. [47] An expert in the ritual of burnt offerings, Knowing how to strive near the painted cloth, Becomes a Lord of the Underworld, Or even moves through space, [48] Always summoning heavenly gods, Male and female nature spirits, Rulers of kingdoms, Countries, and even villages, [49] Magicians (vidyādhara) and antigods (asuras), Subjugating all living beings, and Summoning all creatures, [including] Great Beings and Great-Souled Ones. [50]

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' che/ / sa bcu la ni yang dag brten/ / sbyin sreg las kyis 'gugs byed na/ / sa stengs mi rnams smos ci dgos/ / sde dpon bdag po de bzhin du/ / khyad par 'jig rten dbang phyug dang / / 'byung po thams cad kun dbang byed/ / de bzhin nyid du mi bdag nyid/ / 'byung po thams cad dbang don dang / / yang na sa stengs rgyal po mnyam/ / de bzhin rtag tu las kun la/ / thams cad sbyin sreg gis ni bya/ /

When Bodhisattva Great Beings Who depend upon the tenth bodhisattva stage, Are summoned by the burnt offering ritual, What needs to be said about [the ritual’s ability to summon] Human beings on the surface of the Earth? [51] Similarly, [what needs to be said about its ability to summon] a district general, And a distinctly powerful world ruler, or To subjugate all creatures, As well as the Lord of Men! [52] For the purpose of subjugating all creatures, Including kings on the surface of the Earth, Always perform all the rituals in this way, At all times, with burnt offerings. [53]

kun nas kun tu brtson ldan pas/ / las kun yang dag bsten par bya/ / de ched nges par bsgrub par bya/ / dpal don las ni mchog yin te/ / bar ma nyid kyang sgrub par byed/ / yang na chung ngu nyid kyang ngo / / de bzhin du ni rdzas rnams kun/ / de bzhin slar yang 'grub par gsungs/ / sbyin sreg las la rab 'jug pas/ / 'bras bur bcas pa'i dngos grub mthong / / phyag rgya bcing dang rig pa nyid/ / las rnams kun la rtag tu bya/ / sbyin sreg las la rab 'jug pas/ / bdag nyid srung bar 'gyur ba yin/ / de nas sngags 'di bklag par bya/ / 'di ni rtag tu las rnams la/ / bdun bzlas pa'am brgyad bzlas so/ /

One who possesses continual striving, and Relies upon all the rituals, Due to that, shall surely accomplish The ritual that is best for auspicious aims. [54] [Rituals with] middling [attainments] shall also succeed, And small ones, too. In this way, All materials have been discussed regarding attainment, Again, according to [the three types]. [55] Having engaged in the ritual of burnt offering, One will see attainments together with their fruits. Having bound the mudrā [and recited] the same vidyā, One should always perform all the rituals. [56] By engaging in the ritual of burnt offerings, One will have performed self-protection. Then, one should read this mantra. This is always in the rituals. Recite it seven or recite it eight [times]. [57]
na maHsarba bud+d+ha bo d+hi satwA nAM/ a pra ti ha ta ga ti ma ga tA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M dz+wA la tiSh+tha hU~M/ ru ru bi shwa sam+b+ha be swA hA/ /
Namaḥ sarva buddhabodhisattvānāṃ / Apratihata gatiṃ gatānāṃ / Tadyathā / Oṃ jvāla tiṣṭha hūṃ / ru ru viśva sambhave svāhā //
(“Homage to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas The Gone Ones (tathāgata) whose gait is unobstructed, As follows: Oṃ! Remain burning! Hūṃ! Roar! Roar! You who gives birth to everything! Praise!”)

sngags kyi rab sbyor 'di yis ni/ / slar yang shing la bzlas bya ba/ / gnyis bzlas pa'am bdun bzlas pa/ / sngags rig des mer sbyin sreg bya/ / me tog bdug pa dri dag gam/ / mdor na thams cad nyid kyang ni/ / gsang sngags bzlas pa'i chu rnams kyis/ / 'di nyid kyis ni bsang gtor bya/ / de nas las rnams thams cad ni/ / rgyu 'dis cho ga brtsam par bya/ / las rnams dag ni thams cad la/ / snga ma'i rab sbyor nyid kyis bya/ /

Using this application of the mantra, One should recite it repeatedly over the wood. Reciting [the vidyā] two or seven [times], That mantra-knower performs burnt offerings in the fire. [58] Flowers, incense, perfumes, or In short, everything combined That belongs to this [ritual], should be cleansed and sprinkled With the waters consecrated with the secret mantra. [59] Then, one should begin the performance, With the underlying motive for all the rituals, All the rituals should be performed in their entirety With the former application. [60]

sngar gyi skra can ma bcings nas/ / phyag rgya chen mor grags ldan ma/ / bsrung ba byas par gyur de nas/ / zlos pos rig pa gcig gis ni/ / las rnams thams cad brtsam par bya/ / dngos grub rgyu la mkhas pa yis/ / gal te dge mtshan mthong gyur pa/ / rtag tu dge ba'i sgra grags na/ / de la sngags kyi 'bras bu ni/ / ji ltar 'dod bzhin mchog stsol 'gyur/ / dang po las la rab sbyor dang / / sngags kyi rgyu la rab 'jug pas/ / 'bras med 'bras bu bcas pa nyid/ / dngos grub de la brjod par bya/ /

Having bound the [mudrā] for women, noted before, Associated with the famous Mahāmudrā, With protection performed, then, The reciter, using one vidyā, and An expert on the causes of accomplishment, Should begin all the rituals. [61] If a virtuous sign is seen, or Continually virtuous sounds [are heard], That one will have a fruitful mantra, And will be granted boons according to one’s wishes. [62] Beginning with the application of the rituals, And engaging in the causes of the mantra, The fruitless will become fruitful. Attainments shall be proclaimed for that one! [63]

rgyal ba'i sgra 'am pa Ta ha/ / rnga bo che yi sgra grags na/ / brtson ldan kun 'gro'i dngos grub ste/ / sbyin sreg las la yang dag brten/ / gzhan yang dge mtshan dpal dang ni/ / 'dab chags sgra ni bzang po dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs sgra dbyangs sam/ / rgyal bas bsngags shing rab bsngags pa/ / bkra shis bzang po yid 'ong dang / / rnam pa sna tshogs sgra dang ni/ / gdugs dang rgyal mtshan ba dan dang / / bud med rgyan gyis brgyan pa dang / / de bzhin bum pa gang ba dang / / mchod yon mthong na dngos grub rgyu/ / kha dog rnam pa du ma dang / / rab sngags 'jig rten gyis mchod pa'i/ / dge slong rnams dang dge slong ma/ / mthong nas de rnams blta ba la/ / gsang sngags spyod tshul sna tshogs 'grub/ /

When [one hears] the sound of victory or The famous sound of the great pataha drum, Attainments shall occur for all living creatures Who strive and depend upon the burnt offering rituals. [64] Moreover, superior signs of virtue and Sounds of birds are auspicious. Melodious sounds of various kinds, Are praised and extolled by the Conqueror. Auspicious, fortunate, and agreeable Sounds of various types [indicate attainment]. [65] When seeing an umbrella, victory banner, and flag Adorned with women’s ornaments, As well as a full water pot and Respectful offering materials, [know them] as causes of attainment. [66] Having seen monks and nuns [Adorned with] many different colors, Praised and worshipped by the world, Upon seeing them, the secret mantras’ Diverse scope of power shall be successful. [67]

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo sde/ bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las/ bgrang phreng srad bu'i cho ga'i le'u rab 'byam bcu gcig pa yongs su rdzogs so// //

This completes the eleventh extensive chapter of the Ritual [of the Fire Sacrifice] from the Bodhisattvapiṭaka Avataṃsaka Mahāyāna-vaipulya Sutrā and the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
[le'u rab 'byam bcu gnyis pa]
Chapter B.12: Untitled [The Great Secret]

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas slar yang 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po la gzigs nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la bka' stsal pa/ sems dpa' chen po khyod kyi rig pa'i gsang chen yod do/ / sngags thams cad kyi sgrub thabs kyi cho ga'i dam tshig shes pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi chos kyi mdzod las byung ba/ chos kyi sprin la mthun par rab tu zhugs pa/ nam mkha'i rang bzhin/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sngags kyi mnga' bdag ches gtso bor gyur pa sems dpa' chen po dper na de bzhin gshegs pa ni sems can thams cad kyi gtso bo/ / ches gtso bor gyur pa lha dang mi rnams kyi nang nas skyes bu'i khyu mchog sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das yin no/ / byang chub sems dpa' de bzhin du rig pa'i rgyal po 'di ni sngags thams cad kyi mchog tu bstan cing / gtso bo dam pa yin te/ de bzhin gshegs pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das brjod du med pa rnams kyis sngar gsungs pa de bzhin gshegs pa rin chen tog gi mchog gi snying po mchog tu gsang ba kun nas bkra shis par 'dod pa sangs rgyas thams cad kyis yang dag par bstod cing rab tu bsngags la/ sems can thams cad la dbugs 'byin pa/ sdig pa thams cad rab tu zhi bar byed pa/ 'dod pa thams cad sbyin pa/ re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa de gang zhe na/ /

Once more, the Bhagavān Śākyamuni beheld the great circle of the assembly, as before, and spoke to the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva Noble Avalokiteśvara. “O Great Being! Your vidyā is a great secret. It encapsulates the knowedge of the pledge for the rituals of propitiation (sādhana) of all mantras.[952] It is arisen from the Treasury of Dharma of all the Tathagatas.[953] It is the entrance to the Cloud of Dharma,[954] having the nature of space. It has become the most excellent master of all mundane and supramundane mantras. O Great Being! For example, just as the Tathāgata has become the most supreme chief among all living beings, and the Buddha Bhagavān is the most Excellent Person among gods and men, O Bodhisattva, in the same way, this king among vidyās is the sacred master and most excellent teaching of all mantras formerly spoken about by the Tathāgatas and the Buddha Bhagavāns as numerous as the inexpressible [number] of sand particles in the Ganges River. [This vidyā is as] desirable as the entirely auspicious, supremely secret essence of the Tathāgatas’ jeweled crowning ornament, praised and completely commended by all the Buddhas, consoling all living beings who suffocate, letting them breathe, completely pacifying all non-virtuous actions, granting all desires, and fulfilling all hopes. What is it?”

bar skabs 'dir bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i smin mtshams kyi mdzod spu nas sangs rgyas thams cad yang dag par skul bar byed pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer byung bar gyur to/ / gang 'di/ phyogs bcu steng 'og thams cad dang ldan pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnams kun du snang zhing sems can thams cad kyi yid kyang tshim par byas nas slar yang bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i gtsug tor du nub par gyur to/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi gtsug tor nas kun nas 'bar ba'i 'phro ba'i lus can blta bar mi nus pa'i sems can kun gang gis kyang mi thub pa/ 'od chen po yang dag par byung ba/ 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis lus brgyan pa/ rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i gzugs can/ 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i gzugs dang ldan pa/ rig pa'i rgyal po yi ge gcig pa zhes bya bar gyur to/ / byung nas nam mkha'i dkyil kun du snang bar byas te/ rig pa'i rgyal po thams cad kyis yongs su bskor ba/ rig pa 'dzin pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong phrag du mas mdun du bdar nas mchod bzhin pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi bla ma/ rig pa'i 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal pos mngon par bsngags bzhin pa/ sangs rgyas thams cad la mnga' sgyur bzhin pa/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' sa bcu la bzhugs pa rnams kyi rim gro byed bzhin pa'i blo gros chen po/ nam mkha'i dkyil thams cad kyi lha'i rin po ches nye bar mdzes pa dang / nor bu rin po che'i don du byas pas thams cad bkang ste/ mdzes pa'i gzugs can mchog tu 'od gsal ba/ sprul pa po rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i gzugs bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong phrag 'byin bzhin pa/ yi ge gcig pa'i sgra 'don bzhin pa/ 'od zer chen po 'bar ba rab tu 'phro bzhin pa bar snang gi phyogs su gnas par gyur nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la nye bar phyogs nas lta bar byed bzhin pa/ de thams cad dang ldan pa'i gnas gtsang ma'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po la kun tu lta zhing snang bar byed bzhin pa'o/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pas yi ge gcig pa'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po 'di bka' stsal to/ /

In that very instant, from the circle of hair (ūrṇakośa) located between Bhagavān Śākyamuni’s eyebrows, the light rays called “Urging all Buddhas” sprang forth, entirely illuminating all the Buddha fields in the ten directions, above and below. Having soothed the minds of all living beings, once again, [those rays] disappeared as they sank into Bhagavān Śākyamuni’s cranial protuberance (ūṣṇīṣa). Then, from the Bhagavān’s cranial protuberance, the King of Vidyās (vidyārāja) called “The Single Syllable” emerged as a great ray of light, whose emanating body was all ablaze, unable to be looked at, invincible by all living beings, a body adorned with a circle of light and forms of various kinds, including the form of a great universal monarch.
