In short, by merely remembering it for all dangers, one can apply it to protect from the eight famous [dangers] among [all] these [dangers]. If one expresses this vidyā, performs it successfully, and fully engages in it, one will not fall erroneously into bad destinies. Any son of the family who is destitute — yet generates the thought of enlightenment, reads and recites [this vidyā], and carries out [its practices], even though harboring attachment in mind, having died and transmigrated, shall be reborn in Sukhāvati. Here is the evocation ritual (sādhana) for this [vidyā]. Draw Bhagavān Avalokiteśvara having just arrived, bestowing the “have no fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā), with his locks tied up, and his body adorned with the [thirty-two] marks of a great person (mahāpuruṣa). He has three eyes. Moon beams burst forth from his body. He protects from all eight [great] dangers. Bhagavān Amitābha is seated on his head. He wears a white sacred thread. The practitioner is as before. Having depicted the painting on cloth according to specifications, make a large offering. This same [person] should make offerings with rituals utilizing perfumes, flowers, incense, and ritual cakes. One who has concentrated with steadfastness in the performance [of these rituals], having fasted for an undetermined period of time seated on a bundle of kuśa grass, should recite this great king of vidyās “Saving All Living Beings” 8,000 times, with the essence of loving kindness.

de nas grub par 'gyur te gang 'dod pa de thams cad dang / las phran tshegs la sogs pa byed do/ / chus dug 'joms par byed do/ / ku shas byabs pas rims nyin gcig pa'am/ nyin gnyis pa'am nyin bzhi pa la sogs pa 'joms par byed do/ / sngags bzlas pa nyid me tog la yongs su bzlas te gang la byin pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / mdor na bya bas pas nad thams cad 'joms par byed do/ / 'di'i sgrub thabs su gyur pa ni ras ris sngar brjod pa'i gnas su bzhugs su gsol nas 'bum bzlas so/ / mthar mtshan mo gcig smyung bar gnas par gnas pas phyogs skyong rnams la gtor ma dbul te/ gtor ma ni dkar gsum du 'gyur ro/ / mchod pa'i cho ga byas nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste srod nas brtsams nas/ ji srid dngos grub kyi mtshan mar gyur gyi bar de srid du bzlas par bya'o/ / ras ris rab tu 'gul ba dang / mar me'i rtse mo 'phel na thams cad la dbang ba'i rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / ma grub na yul rnyed do/ / mi 'jigs pa thams cad rab tu sbyin no/ / bzlas pas sems can thams cad dbang du byed do/ / nad thams cad rab tu zhi bar byed do/ / 'ching ba thams cad gcod par byed do/ / yang na dran pas 'gro bar byed do/ /

Then, if successful, [the ritual] shall carry out everything that one desires and it shall perform minor rituals as well. It shall destroy poison with water. Having ritually cleansed oneself with kuśa grass, it shall destroy all infectious diseases within one, two, or four days. Having recited this same mantra recitation over flowers, to whomever one gives [these flowers] shall become powerful. In short, having purified oneself [with this vidyā], one shall destroy all diseases. As for this one’s sādhana, make a request seated in the presence of the painted cloth formerly expressed, and recite [the vidyā] 100,000 [times]. At the end of a one-night fast, offer ritual cakes to the protectors of the [four cardinal] directions. The ritual cakes should contain the three whites [i.e., curds, milk, and butter]. Having performed the ritual of honor offerings, one should sit down upon a bundle of kuśa grass. Having begun at twilight, one should continue to recite until there are signs of success (siddhi). If the painted cloth shakes and the flames of the butter lamps increase, one will become a powerful king over the entire [earth]. If one is not successful, one will [at least] acquire a province. It will bestow fearlessness to all. Reciting [this vidyā] subjugates all sentient beings, thoroughly pacifies all diseases, and severs all [karmic] bonds. Furthermore, remembering it keeps one alive!

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal por sems can thams cad rjes su son par byed pa po zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the powerful king of vidyās called “Savior of All Living Beings,” in the excellent “Extensive” samādhi from the Fundamental Ritual Text of Blessed Noble Tārā.

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du gser 'od ces bya ba'i rig pa chen po'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por bcom ldan 'das ma'i yang rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por bka' stsal to/ /

Then, while the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara was cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, he uttered the king of ritual texts of the Mahāvidyā called “Golden Light,” which also belongs to the most excellent ritual text of the Bhagavatī [Tārā].

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this excellent king of vidyās called “Golden Light,” which is permitted by many Buddhas, makes all sentient beings as virtuous as gold, is successful when read, liberates one from all yakṣa spirits and makes them depart. Merely reciting it destroys all diseases. This is the ritual of the painting on cloth for that [vidyā]. Depict Bhagavān Noble Avalokiteśvara bright as the color of gold with his locks bound up. His right hand bestows the “have no fear” hand gesture and his [left] hand holds a water pitcher. He is ornamented with a garland of lotuses, wears white clothes, his face smiles broadly, and his two feet rest upon a lotus. The practitioner lifts an incense vessel in hand as before. Having performed the ritual of the painting on cloth according to those [instructions], one should become seated in the place of recitation as before and recite [the vidyā] 500,000 times.

After that, perform accordingly as before. One should acquire whatever one desires using burnt offerings of aloewood.[985] Summon with burnt offerings of sandalwood. One will please all living beings with burnt offerings of jasmine flowers. Having begun at the time of the new moon, during the month of miracles, in front of the painted cloth, using the ritual of offering (pūja), one should make 8,000 recitations during the three junctures [dawn, dusk, and dawn] for a day and a night. Having remained fasting for three nights, and having placed the painted cloth on an island of a river or along the bank of a river flowing into the ocean, perform the ritual of offering (pūja). Having begun at evening twilight, recite until there are signs of accomplishment (siddhi): the painted cloth quivers, or the flaming tips of the butter lamp increase, or a rain of flowers falls from the sky, or one hears the clap of thunder and lightning. Through the quivering of the painted cloth, one will become a great king. [If] the flaming tips of the butter lamp increase, one will become a village chieftain (rje bo). [If] flowers fall [from the sky], one will become the lord of a province (bdag po). If [one hears] the clap of thunder, one will acquire sixteen villages. If one is not successful, one should thoroughly procure all needed furnishings to prepare the ritual (again). It will dispel all diseases.

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the excellent king of vidyās called “Vidyā Initiation.” Whoever reads or recites it shall pay their respects to twelve million Buddhas. By continually reciting it, one will not fall erroneously into any of the bad destines. One will remember one’s births in 1,200 [former] existences. One should remember [this vidyā] at all times, at the three junctures of the day and night, and with the five supernormal perceptions. For countless aeons, one will neither transmigrate in the body of a piśāca or rākṣasa, etc. nor [incur] any diseases among them. As for this one’s painted cloth ritual, one should draw Noble Avalokiteśvara on a flawless cloth possessing the characteristics mentioned above. Depict him with his locks bound up, a white complexion, a lotus in hand, with his right hand bestowing the boon-granting gesture (varadā-mudrā) and with his left hand holding a lotus (padma). Above him, draw twelve completely perfected Buddhas. They should be golden in color and bestow the “without fear” hand gesture, as follows: Padmaguru, Guṇaguru, Jñaneśvara, Sadānirghoṣa, Vilokita, Ūṣṇiṣavāti, Sarvarākṣita, Viśraddhāpanaya, Kanakamuni, Kaśyapa, Śākyamuni, Amitābha, and Akṣobhya.[986] Draw these rightly perfected Buddhas very meticulously. Having begun to draw the painted cloth in this way, seated in the place mentioned above, one should recite [the vidyā] 300,000 times. With this [vidyā] one should offer perfume, flowers, incense, etc. Recite it 300,000 times in order to empower any action. Then, having fasted for three nights and made a very large offering to the painted cloth, place [black] collyrium or [red] arsenic sulfide or [yellow] bile inside an aśvattha leaf in the presence of the painted cloth and recite [the vidyā] 1,000 times using the ritual mentioned above. Sit down on kuśa grass and begin [the rituals] at twilight. To the extent that one recites [the vidyā], the leaves will either become warm, raise smoke, or catch on fire. By making them warm, one will subjugate everything. By raising smoke, one will become invisible. By creating flames, one will move through the sky. If the painted cloth shakes, one will [rule over] an entire kingdom.

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this excellent queen[987] of vidyās “Garland of Profuse Devotion,” permitted by many Buddhas and producing many bodhisattva concentrations, shall be successful! Any poor person who prepares the image on cloth within a month’s time, will succeed and prosper. This vidyā should be worshipped with meaningful gifts wherever a destitute person profits. This ritual shall make worldly preparations successful. Then there is the method to invoke [the deity]. Draw the figure of Bhagavān Avalokiteśvara on a cotton cloth as formerly expressed. Having begun on the ninth [day], one should complete it on a day of the waxing moon. Depict [Avalokiteśvara] seated on a white lotus throne, with his locks bound up (ūrdhvajaṭa). Above [Avalokiteśvara] are two [Buddhas]: Noble Amitābha and Śākyamuni on the same side. To Noble Avalokiteśvara’s right [side] depict Mahāśrī [Tārā].[988] To his left side is Vajrasena. The body of [Avalokiteśvara] is white in color, white as autumn clouds, holding a round golden vase and water pot in hand. Treasured goods should be offered to them as follows: atimuktaka flowers for Noble Avalokiteśvara’s head, a garland of varṣa flowers for Noble Amitābha, a garland of jasmine flowers for Śākyamuni, a garland of nāgagesara flowers for Mahāśrī, and a garland of white flowers and fragrant incense for Vajrasena. Having requested to set down the cloth image in the place mentioned above, one should recite [the vidyā] 300,000 times. Then, for a day and a night, having sat down on a kuśa grass mat, perform a large offering of garlands of flowers for the painted cloth. Whoever performs with that [ritual], performs it bravely for all. One should recite that great queen of vidyās until the sign appears of all the garlands [of flowers] quiver. When there is a sign of success, one will achieve all that one desires. All those who have performed 600,000 burnt offerings mixed with sesame in front of the painted cloth will acquire a kingdom. If desiring the abundance of a province, perform 300,000 burnt offerings mustard, sesame, and tsekata in front of the painted cloth, and one will acquire a province. If performing burnt offerings in front of the painted cloth 700,000 [times] with sesame crushed in honey, saffron, hard varnish, pearl, and kuṣṭha (ru rta), one will acquire a vast kingdom. If [the ritual is] not successful, one will acquire a province and become a very wealthy lord (bdag po).

This completes the king of vidyās called “Garland of Profuse Devotion” from the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

The words of this great mantra summon all yakṣas here.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+hA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ na maHsarba se na sa ta ye/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi sa twA ya/ ma ha sa twa ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ yak+Sha dzrim+b+ha na muk+tA ya/ sarbaM yak+ShaM hr-i da yaM/ gu h+ya a d+hi pa tA ya b+ha ga bAn Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ hr-i da ya/ ma nu sma ra/ sat+ya ma nu sA la/ tad+ya thA shI le shI la ba ti dA ni pra ye shan+te satwA dar+Sha nan ta thA ga ta sarba dz+nyA dz+nyA na dar+Sha na ma ma sa raM pra yats+tshe sarba satwA hi tAr+thA ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya / mahāsattvāya / mahākāruṇikāya / yakṣajṛmbhanamuktāya / sarvaṃ yakṣaṃ hṛdayaṃ / guhya adhipatāya bhagavānāryāvalokiteśvarāya / hṛdaya / manusmara / satyamunusālaya / tadyathā / śīle śīlavati dānapriye śānte satvādarśanana tathāgata sarvajñā jñānādarśana mamasaraṃprayacchasarvasattvāhitārthāya svāhā //

stobs chen pos pha rol gnon pa'i gsang sngags 'di gsungs pa dang stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams gang du gnas pa bkug nas gnod sbyin thams cad kyi dbang po byang chub sems dpa'i mthu las phyag na rdo rjes gsang ba'i dbang po phran tshegs ma yin pa nyid kyis rdzu 'phrul chen po dang ldan pas tshig 'di smras so/ / sems can gyi don la brtson par sems pas gang la la sgrol ma sgrub pa de'i dngos grub nges par byin cig phyed phyed rtag tu phan pas bya'o/ / sems can thams cad kyis de dran par byas nas lha mo sgrol ma 'di lus can rnams bsrung ba dang / bskyab pa dang / sba bar bya'o/ / gang bdag gi bka' mi byed na phyag na rdo rje gsang ba'i bdag po dang / rdo rje 'chang ba stobs chen pos mgo tshal pa bdun du 'gas par 'gyur ro/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes sngon ma can 'di ni mthu chen po thob pa gnod sbyin thams cad 'gugs par byed pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po bklags pa tsam gyis gdug pa dang 'jigs pa thams cad las srung ba'o/ / de nas 'di sgrub pa'i thabs brjod par bya ste/ sngar gsungs pa'i ras ris kyi cho ga 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ ral pa gyen du brdzes pa/ pad+ma'i sdong bu phyag na bsnams pa/ phyag na pad+ma g.yang gzhi nag po 'phyang ba/ gos dkar po can skyil krung gis bzhugs pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po dag bri bar bya ba la 'di lta ste/ rgyal ba dang / rnam par rgyal ba dang / rtag tu ri bo dang / gsang ldan gyi bu dang / nor bu bzang po dang / bzang 'gro'i bu dang / byams pa'i bu dang / dpa' bo bzang po'i bu dang / tshangs pa dang / chu la sems te de lta bu la sogs pa gnod sbyin gyi rgyal po mang po 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ khug ma dang sa bon gyis gang ba phyag na bsnams pa'i gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon rnams nye bar 'dug par bya'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su rnam par rgyal ba'i mtha' dang / sdong po dang / rnam rgyal thob pa dang / ma 'gags pa dang / mkha' lding rgyal po zhes pa gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon 'di rnams thams cad sngar bzhin kha dog ljang gu'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas su rig pa 'dzin pa yang lag na spos phor thogs pa sngar bzhin no/ / rgyu skar skag la 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas ras ris ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten nam/ phyogs gtsang ma gzhan du bzhugs su gsol nas/ sngags 'dis spyan drang bar bya'o/ /

Having spoken this secret mantra that vanquishes the enemy by means of great power, and having summoned residents from any world realm of the billion world galaxy, Lord of All Yakṣas, Vajrapāṇi, Lord of the Secret ones, possessing miraculous power that is more significant than a bodhisattva’s powers, spoke these words. “May the occult attainments (siddhis) of that successful [vidyā of] Tārā be given to anyone with thoughts that strive for the purpose of sentient beings. May [others] profit through its continual performance. All sentient beings who remember that [vidyā], shall make this goddess Tārā protect, defend, and conceal living beings. If one does not carry out my precepts, their heads shall burst apart into seven pieces through the great powers of Lord of the secret ones Vajrapāṇi and Vajradhāra. O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, as for the one who possesses the former knowledge of omniscience, merely reading the king of vidyās called “Summoning All Yakṣas” protects one from poison and all dangers. Then, this [vidyā’s] evocation ritual will be expressed. [Using] the ritual for the image on cloth mentioned above, begin drawing Noble Avalokiteśvara with his locks tied up, holding a round water pot, a lotus stem in [one] hand, and a lotus in [the other] hand. He has a black antelope skin that hangs down, white clothes, and is seated cross-legged. To his right side, draw great Yakṣa chiefs Victorious (Jaya), Very Victorious (Vijaya), Entirely Firm (Acala), Son of Snow (Himavatīputra), Excellent Wealth (Maṇibhadra), Good Destiny’s Son (Sadgatiputra), Son of Maitrī (Maitrīputra), Son of the Excellent Hero (Vīrabhadra-putra), Brahmā, and Udakacitti. In the same way, one should draw many yakṣa kings. The yakṣa generals are to be seated and their hands filled with small pouches and seeds. To [Avalokiteśvara’s] left side are five yakṣa chiefs, all green in color as before: Vijayānta, Nīla, Vijayaprāpta, Aniruddha, and Guruḍarāja. On the left side of the Bhagavān is the tantric practitioner lifting an incense vessel in hand as before. One should begin to draw the image on cloth during the lunar mansion (nakṣatra) of Aśleṣa. Having asked [the deity] to abide [in] the image on cloth or a stūpa filled with relics in another pure direction, invite [the deity] with this mantra.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+hA ya/ na maHyak+Sha se nA pa ta ye/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ tad+ya thA/ dza ye bi dza ye a gu ru e hi e hi s+thA nAM/ A kra ma/ bi dza ye/ ba ha shAn+ti ka ra swA hA/ sngags 'dis bcom ldan 'das dang gnod sbyin thams cad spyan drang bar bya'o/ /

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Amitābhāya / Namaḥ Yakṣasenāpataye / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / Mahāsattvāya / tadyathā / Jaye vijaye āguru ehi ehi sthānāṃ / ākrama / vijaye / bahaśānti kara svāhā // With this mantra, one should invite the Bhagavān and all yakṣiṇīs.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+hA ya na maHsarba yak+Sha se na pa ta ye na mo na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ ra ra ra ra shA n+ti bi dza ye swA hA/ 'dis dri dang bdug pa la sogs pa thams cad dbul bar bya'o/ /

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Amitābhāya / Namaḥ Sarvayakṣasenāpataye / Namo nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / mahāsattvāya / mahākāruṇikāya / Ra ra ra ra śānti vijaye svāhā // With this [mantra], one should offer all [kinds of] perfume and incense, etc.

de bzhin du ras ris kyi spyan sngar 'bum phrag gsum bzlas pa bya'o/ / zla ba nya la nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas pas/ bcom ldan 'das la zho dang 'o ma'i zan gyi gtor ma dbul bar bya'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su gnas pa'i gnod sbyin gyi sde dpon chen po rnams la zho dang bu ram dbul bar bya'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su bris pa rnams la til dang til gyi thug pa dbul bar bya'o/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la a ga ru'i bdug pa dbul lo/ / dri tsan+dan dbul lo/ / phreng ba sna ma'i me tog dbul bar bya'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su gnas pa'i sde dpon rnams la thang chu lnga'i bdug pa dang / ka ra bI ra dkar po'i me tog go/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su sra rtsi pog gi bdug pa dang / a ti muk+ta ka'i me tog dbul bar bya'o/ / de ltar ji ltar nus pa'i mchod pa byas nas stong phrag brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas dus gsum du de bzhin du mchod pa bya zhing 'o ma dang / nas zan bza' zhing pad+ma dkar po re re la yongs su bzlas nas ras ris kyi spyan sngar bcom ldan 'das la dbul bar bya'o/ / de ltar ji srid 'bum phrag gcig gi mthar bris pa'i gnod sbyin thams cad rdzu 'phrul ston par byed do/ / ras ris 'gul ba dang / me tog g.yo ba thun mtshams su mthong ngo / / de nas grub par 'gyur te gnod sbyin thams cad dbang du 'gyur ro/ / nam mkha' la yang grub bo zhes pa'i sgra thos so/ / rig pa 'dzin pa'i mchog stsol bar byed do/ / tshol ba de gnod sbyin gyi bka' byed par 'gyur ro/ / ma grub na las thams cad kyi rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu rmi lam du gnod sbyin rnams dge ba dang mi dge ba mthong ba sbyin par byed do/ /

Accordingly, one should recite [the vidyā] 300,000 times in front of the painted cloth. Having fasted for a day and a night during the full moon, one should offer the Bhagavān sacrificial cakes of grain cooked with milk and curds. On the right side, one should offer curds and molasses to the great chiefs of the yakṣas. On the left side, one should offer sesame and sesame broth to the drawings. To Avalokiteśvara, one should offer agaru incense. Offer sandalwood perfume. One should offer garlands of jasmine flowers. To the chiefs placed on the right side, [offer] incense of five gums and white karavira flowers. The those situated on the left side, offer incense of varnish and atimuktaka flowers.[989] In this way, having made an offering according to one’s ability, one should recite 8,000 times. Then, having made offerings at each of the three junctures of the day, eaten food cooked with milk, and recited over each white lotus, one should make an offering to Bhagavān [Avalokiteśvara] in front of the painted cloth. If one sees the painted cloth move, and flowers quiver at twilight or day break, then [the ritual] will succeed and one will subjugate all yakṣas. One will even hear the word “Success!” in the sky. One will be granted the practitioner’s boon. That [search] will be performed by the commands of all the yakṣas. If unsuccessful, one will become the king of all [minor] rituals, and continually receive visions in dreams of the virtues and non-virtues of yakṣas.[990]

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa gnod sbyin thams cad kun tu 'ong ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Summoning all Yakṣas” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis 'byung po'i bdag po lha'i bu dbang ldan la smras pa/ lha'i bu rdzu 'phrul chen po can khyod kyis rigs bzhin du 'jug par 'gyur ba/ bcom ldan 'das ma rig pa'i rgyal mo chen mo rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po bshad par bya'o/ / de la sngags kyi tshig 'di rnams ni 'jig rten pa thams cad kyi rig pa'i sngags su yang dag par 'dod do/ /

Then, the Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara spoke to [Śiva], the Lord of Creatures, the Powerful One, and the Son of the Gods (Paśupati Īśāna Devaputra). “O Son of the Gods, [you] who possess miraculous power, [I] shall explain [the mantra called] ‘Inviting Īśāna’s[991] Family,’ from the most excellent ritual text of the Blessed Queen of Mahāvidyās (Bhagavatī Mahāvidyā-rājñī). These words of magical speech in that [vidyā] are desirable for all worldly vidyās and mantras.”

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ I sha na ku la ma btu yi Sh+ya mi/ b+ha ga ba te/ Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra te dza na ra ra ra ra ra bi pu tsi bi pu tsi/ bra ma thA/ pra ma pra ma tha/ pra ma thA/ gardza gardza gardza/ Ti Ti Ti/ sa sa sa/ u u u/ la la la/ tsa tsa tsa/ A gats+tsha a gats+tsha/ b+ha ga bA na/ A r+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ pa ra ma hr-i da yaM/ d+hA ra yi Sh+ya ti i shwo rA s+ya bi po ma ti twAM pra sAM tha/ ba raM nge yaM/ sarba satwA hi ti/ d+hu taM/ ba ra/ yak+Sha ya/ sarka ra/ mu ni mu ni/ a pra ti ha ta/ bI t+yo kr-i ta ha ti kr-i ta yak+Sha kr-i ta/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya / mahāsattvāya / mahākāruṇikāya / Īśanakulam avatuyiṣyāmi / bhagavate / Ārya Avalokiteśvaratejana ra ra ra ra ra vipuci vipuci pramathā / pramatha pramatha pramatha / garja garja garja / ṭi ṭi ṭi / sa sa sa / u u u / la la la / ca ca ca / āgaccha āgaccha / bhagavān / Āryāvalokiteśvarāya / paramahṛdayaṃ / dhārayiṣyati Iśvārasya vipomatitvāṃprasātha / varaṃdeyaṃ / sarvasattvāhiti / dhutaṃ / varaṃ / yakṣaya / sarkara / muni muni / apratihata / vītyokṛta hitakṛta yakṣakṛta / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya svāhā //

dbang ldan gyi rigs kun nas 'dren pa'i sngags byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi zhal nas gsungs ba lha'i bu rdzu 'phrul chen po rnams kyis smras pa/ sa stengs kyi mi sems can gyi don 'dod pa rnams kyi 'dod pa sgrub pa'i don du sngags 'di rab tu gsungs so/ / gang 'di sgrub pa'i sgrub pa po gang la la dngos grub 'dod pa la khyod kyis de la mchog sbyin par bya'o/ / sems can gyi don la brtson pa'i bsam pa can bye ba phrag bcu dang / rang gis rab tu gsungs pa'i sngags rnams sa stengs su sgrub pa la lha rnams 'gugs pa rab tu brjod pa'i sngags 'di stobs chen po sgrub pa dang / rig pa chen po rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i gzugs can gyi sgrol ma de'i gzi brjid dang stobs sbyin par bya zhing / 'byung po'i tshogs thams cad kyis skyobs shig / de nas 'di'i sgrub pa'i cho gar 'gyur te/ sngar brjod pa'i cho gas ras la bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gser gyi mdog ltar snang ba/ phyag na pad+ma g.yas kyis mchog sbyin pa/ phyag g.yon pas pad+ma bsnams pa/ ral pa'i cod pan 'phyang ba/ spyi bor bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag med bzhugs pa'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi g.yas su yangs pa dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi gzugs can gyi byang chub sems dpa' la byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs kyis yongs su bskor ba bri bar bya'o/ / g.yon gyi gzhogs su dbang ldan la sogs pa'i sems dpa' chen po rnams bri bar bya'o/ / gang gi tshe mig gsum pa'o/ /

“This mantra that ‘Invites Īśāna’s Family,’ which has also been spoken by the Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas, and spoken by the Sons of the Gods who possess miraculous power, was well expressed for the purpose of accomplishing the wishes and desired aims of sentient beings who are human beings on this earth. You shall grant a boon to any practitioner who has completed this [ritual] and who desires magical success (siddhi). May [these mantras] protect all hosts of creatures, particularly, the mantras that are well expressed by me and the ten billion [beings] who wish to strive for the purpose of sentient beings, and that summon the gods for success on this earth. May this well expressed mantra that achieves power, and the Mahāvidyā, bestow the power and brilliance that belongs to Tārā, possessing various kinds of forms.” Then there is the evocation ritual for this [vidyā]. With the ritual previously expressed, on cotton cloth, the body of Noble Bhagavān Avalokiteśvara shines like the color of gold. Padmapāṇi displays the boon-granting gesture (varadā-mudrā) with the right [hand], while the left hand holds a lotus. His crown of locks hangs down. Bhagavān Amitābha is seated on his head. To the right of Noble Avalokiteśvara, depict a Bodhisattva assuming the form of the “Extensive Samādhi,” surrounded by a group of bodhisattvas. To [Avalokiteśvara’s] left, depict the Great Beings Īśāna, etc., each of whom has three eyes.

sngar brjod pa'i gnas su ras ris 'di'i steng gi phyogs kyi cha rnams su bzhag nas/ nag po'i bcu bzhi pa nas brtsams te mchod pa'i cho ga bya zhing 'di nyid kyis 'bum bzlas par bya ste sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas pa nag po'i bcu bzhi pa la byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la dkar po'i gtor ma dbul bar bya zhing a ga ru dang tu ruSh+ka'i bdug pa dbul bar bya'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug la 'o ma dang lhan cig pa'i bdug pa dbul bar bya zhing kha dog thams cad du snang ba thams cad 'dod pa'i rigs la zho dang bu ram gyi bza' ba dang / gu gul gyi bdug pa dbul bar bya'o/ / ras ris kyi phyi rol du 'byung po thams cad pa'i gtor ma dbul zhing / dge slong rnams la yon dang bcas pa'i ston mo dbul lo/ / phyugs bdag rnams la zho zan dbul zhing de'i zhi ba thob par bya'o/ / ji srid du zla ba nya ba'i bar du dus gsum du stong phrag brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas srod nas brtsams nas ji srid dngos grub kyi mtshan ma dbang ldan gyi mig 'phro bar byed pa de srid du bzlas pa bya'o/ / 'dir dngos grub kyi mtshan ma byung ba de nas me tog phreng ba dbul bar bya zhing / gu gul gyi bdug pa dbul lo/ / gang dka' thub pa rnams kyis ji ltar byung ba zos nas yon dbul bar bya'o/ / de nas thams cad byed do/ / me tog gam/ 'bras bu'am/ dri dang / gos la sogs pa la mngon par bsngags nas gang la byin pa de bran nyid du nye bar gnas so/ /

In the place formerly mentioned, having set down the borders of the surface of the painted cloth, begin from the fourteenth day of the waning moon [i.e., new moon], recite 100,000 times with the same [vidyā,] and perform a ritual of offering. One will have performed preliminary service. Remain fasting for a day and a night, make an offering of white sacrificial cakes to all bodhisattvas on the fourteenth day of the waning moon, and offer akaru and duruka incense. One should offer incense together with milk to Noble Avalokiteśvara, and one should offer curds, food with molasses, and gugul incense to the desired lineage, entirely illuminated in all colors. Outside of the painted cloth, offer sacrificial cakes to all creatures and offer a feast with gifts to the monks. Offer curds with cooked food to the Lords of Beasts, and obtain four of them. One should recite 8,000 times at the three junctures of the day for up to a day and a night. Then, having begun at twilight, one should recite as long as and up until there are signs of success (siddhi) emanating the eye of power. When signs of success appear, then offer a flower garland and gugul incense. Having fed ascetics who have appeared, one should offer them gifts. Then, perform all rituals. Having consecrated flowers, fruit, perfumes, or clothes, etc. with mantra recitation, bless them and continue to serve them.

rgyal srid kyi longs spyod 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar zho dang mar dang 'o thug gis sbyin sreg bya ste/ 'bum phrag gcig gi mthar rig pa 'dzin pa'i gtsug phud 'bar bar 'gyur ro/ / chad pa dbang du bya bar 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar mtshan mo gsum thun gsum du til dang / til gyi thug pa'i sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / bu mo dbang du bya bar 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar mtshan mo gsum thun gsum du dang po btsas pa'i 'o ma'i sbyin sreg stong phrag brgyad byas na rnyed do/ / phyugs kyi bdag po rnams dbang du bya bar 'dod na thal ba'i sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur te/ zhag bdun thun gsum du stong phrag brgyad bzlas na de ji srid 'jig rten pa'i las las 'das pa rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i sa'i steng gi mi rnams kyi ting nge 'dzin thams cad byed de/ sngags 'di la the tshom med do/ /

If one desires the enjoyments of a kingdom, perform burnt offerings with curds, butter, and milky porridge in front of the image on cloth. [If one succeeds,] at the end of one hundred [performances], the head crest of the tantric practitioner shall ignite. If one desires to subdue a punishment, perform burnt offerings of sesame and sesame porridge for three junctures of three nights in the presence of the image on cloth, and one will bring it under control. If desiring to subjugate a woman, perform 8,000 burnt offerings with the milk of a first-born cow at the three watches of three nights in the presence of the image on cloth, and one will profit. If desiring to subjugate the rulers of the cardinal directions, perform burnt offerings with ashes and one will subjugate them. When making 8,000 recitations during three watches over seven days, one will perform all concentrations (samādhis) of people on the surface of this earth as well as perform a multitude of worldly and supramundane rituals. For this mantra, this is certain!
'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa dbang ldan gyi rigs kun tu 'ong ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the great king of vidyās known as “Inviting Īśāna’s Family,” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du sems can la rjes su brtse bas bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por 'jug par byed bzhin pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po rjes su dran nas gsungs pa/

Then, the Bodhisattva Mahasattva Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the best “Extensive” samādhi as before, with loving kindness for sentient beings, remembered the king of vidyās called “Engaging” from the Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s best ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ na mo bid+yA rA dzA ya/ tad+ya thA/ bi shud+d+ha pra ba/ kaR+Sha kar+Sha b+ha shi She bi d+yA d+ha ra gu h+ye ka ma nu smA ra bud+d+ha sat+ye na d+harma satwA na/ saM g+ha sat+ye na/ Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra satwe na/ sid+h+ya n+tA me man+t+ra pa dA phaT phaT yA/ / mu ni mu nA ya/ sa ma tha sa mA ya/ ud+d+ha raM te ko ka rA n+te ma nu smA ra Ta/ hr-i da ta sa kA rA To TaM/ ka Ta Te swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Namo vidyārājāya / tadyathā / viśuddhapraba / karṣa karṣa bhaśiṣe vidyādhara guhyeka manusmara buddhasatyena / dharmasatyena / saṃghasatyena / ārya avalokiteśvarāsatyena / siddhyantu me mantrapadā phaṭ phaṭ[a]yā / muni munāya / samatha samāya / uddharaṃ te kokarānte manusmāratra / hṛdayasakārātotaṃ / kaṭaṭāṃ svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa 'jug par byed bzhin pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po bzlas pas gdug pa de thams cad 'jigs par byed pa/ gdon dang rig pa thams cad zlog par byed pa/ mdor na re ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'o/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub pa 'byung bar 'gyur te/ bcom ldan 'das spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ sku mdog dkar po/ ral pa dud kha/ bzhin rab tu 'dzum pa/ phyag g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa/ phyag g.yon pas pad+ma bsnams pa/ gser gyi them skas bzang po la 'jug bzhin pa bri bar bya'o/ / ngang pa dang / bya ku ra ba dang / ngur pa dang / shang shang te'u dang / ne tso la sogs pa rab tu bsngags pa'i bya rnams g.yas kyi g.yas su 'jug pa skor ba byed pa bri bar bya'o/ / mi'am ci gnyis glu len bzhin pa bri bar bya ste/ g.yon pas rna ba 'gebs pa bri bar bya'o/ / sgrub pa po yang 'og tu kha phyogs pa spos phor lag na thogs pa/ bcom ldan 'das 'jug par byed bzhin pa la lta bar byed pa/ pus mo btsugs pa/ g.yas kyi 'og tu byang chub sems dpa'i lus las 'od kyis mnan pa bri bar bya'o/ / rnam pa de lta bu'i ras ris 'drir bcug nas/ sngar brjod pa'i gnas su ras ris bzhugs su gsol te/ yang dag par brtsam par bya'o/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, reciting this king of vidyās “Engaging” frightens all injurious ones, destroys all poisons, drives away all evil spirits (gdon) and diverts all vidyās. In short, it completely fulfills all hopes. Then, there is the evocation ritual for this [vidyā]. One should depict Bhagavān Avalokiteśvara, his body white in color, his locks the color of smoke, and his face with a wide smile. His right hand displays the boon-granting gesture (varadā-mudrā) and his left hand holds a lotus. He steps onto a fine golden ladder.[992] Surround him on the right with praiseworthy birds such as the male goose, osprey, wild duck, peasant, and parrot, etc. Draw two singing kinnaras concealing their ears with their left hands. One should also depict the practitioner below, facing [Avalokiteśvara], holding up an incense vessel in hand, and kneeling as he looks at the engaging face of the Bhagavān. Depict him beneath and to the right [of Avalokiteśvara], overwhelmed by light rays emanating from the Bodhisattva’s body. Having begun to depict the image on cloth in that way, and having requested to place the image on cloth in the place mentioned above, one should compose [the image].
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ dzA ti hu ti ma ma a ba tA d+ya swA hA/ dkyil 'khor gyi sngags so/ /
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / Jātihuti mama avatādya svāhā // [This is the] mantra for the maṇḍala.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya mu ne mu ne swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya / mune mune svāhā //

'dis thams cad byed pa ste/ 'bum phrag lngar bzlas ba bya'o/ / sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / mthar zho dang sbrang rtsi dang mar gyis btags pa'i pad+ma stong phrag brgyar sbyin sreg bya'o/ / mthar nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas pa ste/ dpag tu med pa bzlas pas dngos grub kyi mtshan ma ras ris rab tu 'gul na sa chen po'i bdag por 'gyur ro/ / mi 'gul na yul gyi bdag por 'gyur ro/ / rtag tu bzlas pas gter mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / ras ris kyi spyan sngar pad+ma 'bum phrag bcu dbul bar bya ste grong rnyed do/ / stong phrag sum cu dbul bar bya ste grong lnga rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / rig pa'i rgyal po'i sbyor bas rtag tu 'dod cing dran par byed na de dbul bar mi 'gyur ro/ /

This performs all [rituals]. One should recite it 500,000 times and perform burnt offerings of lotuses crushed with curds, honey, and butter. At the end, fast for a day and a night. By reciting [the vidyā] without interruption, if the painted cloth moves, it is a sign of magical success (siddhi) and one will become a ruler (bdag po) over the entire earth. If [the cloth] does not move, one will still rule over a province (yul). By continually reciting [the vidyā], one will find treasure. Should one offer a thousand lotuses in the presence of the image on cloth, one will acquire a village. If offering 3,000 [lotuses], one will acquire five villages. By continually wishing for and remembering to apply this king of vidyās, one will not be poor.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par byung ba'i 'jug par byed bzhin pa rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Engaging” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in The Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin pas bcom ldan 'das la rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po yi ge bcu pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen por don chen po rmad du byung ba sangs rgyas bye ba phrag bcus rjes su yi rang bar mdzad pa/ phra mo thams cad sel bar byed pa/ sems can thams cad srung bar byed pa'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po gsungs par gyur to/ /

The Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara cultivated the best “Extensive” samādhi and uttered the most amazing, purposeful king of vidyās called “Ten Letters” from the Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s best ritual text, performed and rejoiced in by ten million Buddhas. It removes all that is trifling and protects all sentient beings.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ / ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni ka ya/ tad+ya thA/ o~M g+haT+Ta ni phu ma ta na swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya/ Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya / mahāsattvāya / mahākāruṇikāya / Tadyatha / Oṃ ghaṭṭani phu ma ta na svāhā /

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa yi ge bcu pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po thogs pa med pa las thams cad pa/ sangs rgyas bye ba phrag bcus gnang ba/ mngon par mdzes pa srung ba la/ rtag pa kho nar mchod pa bya'o/ / de nas 'di sgrub pa'i mchod par 'gyur te/ ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la ji ltar 'byor pa'i mchod pa byas nas 'di nyid kyi dri dang bdug pa la sogs phul nas bye ba bzlas par bya'o/ / rgyal srid chen po rnyed do/ / 'bum phrag bcur bzlas na gser stong rnyed do/ / mchod rten gyi drung du dkyil 'khor stong nye bar byugs nas dri dang bdug pa la sogs pa phul te 'bum bzlas na gang 'dod pa'i rgyal po de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / chu klung chen po dang / chu gling dang / mchod rten bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang gi tshad la 'bum phrag gsum bzlas pa bya'o/ / rgyal srid chen po rnyed de don chen po yang dag par 'gyur ro/ / gang zhig sngags 'di rtag tu dran par byed pa de ni sangs rgyas bye ba phrag bcus rjes su yi rang zhing / rab tu bsngags la thams cad du son pa'o/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta! This is the unobstructed King of Mahāvidyās called “Ten Letters.” It [performs] all activities, is permitted by one hundred million Buddhas, lustrous, and should be continually and exclusively worshipped as a protective amulet. Then, this is the offering for practice. Having performed a worship ceremony for treasures near a stūpa filled with relics, and offered the same fragrance and incense, etc., one should perform ten million recitations. One will acquire a kingdom. If performing one million recitations, one will acquire one thousand gold [pieces]. Having anointed one thousand maṇḍalas in front of a reliquary mound (stūpa), and offered perfume and incense, etc., upon performing 100,000 recitations, one will gain control over whichever kingdom is desired. One should perform 300,000 recitations over a great river, a river island, and a reliquary mound measuring a full span of the Sugata. Having acquired a great kingdom, one will become very important. One who continually remembers this mantra, will be rejoiced in by one hundred million Buddhas, and will live entirely amidst praise.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa yi ge bcu ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Ten Letters” produced from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /
Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the best “Extensive” samādhi, uttered the king of vidyās called “Head Initiation” from Blessed Noble Tārā’s best ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo ak+Sho b+h+ya ya/ tad+ya thA/ na mo bi muk+ta/ dar+Sha nA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ na mo gam+b+hi ra g+ho Sha ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ ku mA ri/ ku mA ri/ ma no dza be Shu nA dza ye/ sha ra da bi dza yA ya/ duM du b+hi swa rA ya/ de bi de bi de bi pU dzi tA ya/ na ma skr-i ta gardza tA ya/ ra ra la la kha gA ya swA hA/ ba ru NA ya swA hA/ a pra ti ha ta/ ba da nA ya swA hA/ brah+ma shwa ra g+ho Sha ru tra ya swA hA/ bi sa ti/ sa ti rA dzA ya swA hA/ Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ mUr+d+hA nA ba ra Na swA hA/ ma ma kar+yaM ku ru swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Akṣobhyaya / tadyathā / Namo vimukta / darṣanāya / tathāgatāya / Namo gambhirabhoṣāya / tathāgatāya / Namo Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / kumāri / kumāri / manoja veṣunājaye / śaradavijayāya / duma dubhisvarāya / devi devi devi pūjitāya / namaskṛta garjitāya / rara lala khagāya svāhā / varuṇāya svāhā / apratihata / vadanāya svāhā / brahmeśvaraghoṣarutrāya svāhā / visati / satirājāya svāhā / Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / mūrdhānāvaraṇa svāhā/ mama kāryaṃ kuru svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen por bdag gi spyi bor skyes pa sangs rgyas bye ba phrag du mas gsungs pa/ sangs rgyas du ma'i phyag gis mngon par dbang bskur bar/ mngon par bskur ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa 'od dpag med kyi gnas su gyur pa/ las phran tshegs thams cad myur du bklags pas grub pa'o/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur te/ ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten gyi drung du gso sbyong la gnas pas 'bum bzlas so/ / glags tshol ba thams cad las rnam par grol bar 'gyur ro/ / rgyu skar sa ga'i nyi ma la ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la dri dang / me tog la sogs pa phul nas kha tshar ma bcad pa'i ras la 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ ral pa gyen du brdzes pa/ pad+ma la bzhugs pa/ bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag med thub pa la thal mo sbyar nas phyag 'tshal bar byed bzhin pa bri bar bya'o/ / rig pa 'dzin pa lag na spos phor thogs pa bcom ldan 'das la lta bar byed bzhin pa'o/ / rnam pa de lta bu phyogs sam nyin zhag bcu gnyis kyi nang der 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / rnam pa de lta bu'i ras ris 'drir bcug nas mchod rten gyi drung du ras ris bzhugs su gsol te/ de la 'di nyid kyis thams cad byas la 'bum phrag lnga bzlas par bya'o/ / mthar mtshan mo smyung bar gnas te ras ris la mchod pa chen po byas nas sna ma'i me tog stong phrag brgyad la re re la yongs su bzlas nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la bsnun par bya'o/ / de lta bu thun gsum du 'bum phrag gcig byas pa'i mthar bcom ldan 'das kyis mchog stsol bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te rig pa 'dzin pa nyid lus 'bar bar byed dam/ ras ris 'gul ba dang ldeg pa dang mar me'i rtse mo 'phel na rgyal srid do/ / gal te sgrub pa byed par 'dod na thos pa 'dzin pa nyid dam/ smra ba'i mchog nyid dam/ mig sman dang / ldong ros dang / gi wang la byas pa ras ris kyi spyan sngar thams cad sgrub par byed na dngos grub rnam pa gsum du 'gyur ro/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, the excellent king of vidyās called “Head Initiation,” generated on my head, is spoken by many millions of Buddhas, is an initiation empowered by the hands of many Buddhas, and has become the residence of Tathāgata Amitābha. Reading it quickly accomplishes all difficulties of the minor rituals. Then there is the ritual of evoking [the deity] of this [vidyā]. Having remained fasting near a reliquary mound (stūpa) filled with relics, one should recite [the vidyā] 100,000 times. Having sought the opportunity, [this vidyā] will free one from all [sins]. Having offered perfume and flowers, etc., to a reliquary mound (stūpa) with relics on a day of the Viśākhā lunar mansion (nakṣatra), one should begin to depict Noble Avalokiteśvara on a cloth with uncut fringes. Depict him with his locks bound up, seated on a lotus, and with folded palms making salutations to Bhagavān Amitābha, the silent sage (muni). A practitioner lifts an incense vessel in hand while looking at the Bhagavān. One should draw that [image] within twelve days according to those guidelines. Having begun to draw the image on cloth in this way, request to place the painted cloth near a reliquary shrine (stūpa). After having made everything on that [cloth] with the same [ritual], one should make 500,000 recitations. At the end of that, remain fasting for a night, make a large offering for the painted cloth, recite over each of 8,000 jasmine flowers, and prick the feet of the Bhagavān [in the image]. At the end of 100,000 recitations, performed during the three junctures [i.e., dawn, noon, and twilight,] the Bhagavān will bestow a boon. If the body of the practitioner [in the painting] blazes, the painted cloth shakes, and the tips of the butter lamps increase, one will [acquire] a kingdom. If one who desires to accomplish [the ritual] is a good listener who remembers what is heard (śrutadharatā) or an excellent speaker (vādināṃvara), and if one accomplishes everything in the presence of the image on cloth made of [black] collyrium, [red] arsenic sulfide, and [yellow] bile,[993] there will be the three kinds of magical results (siddhi).[994]

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las skyes pa spyi bor mngon par dbang bskur ba zhes bya ba'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of ritual texts[995] called “Head Initiation” produced from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po gsungs nas/ bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por 'od dang ldan pa'i mtshan nyid zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po 'di gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, [while cultivating] the best “Extensive” samādhi, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Signs of Light” from the most excellent ritual text of the Bhagavatī [Tārā].

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+hA ya/ na mo bi pa sh+yAM/ shi khI/ bi shwa b+huHna ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ ma hA shAn+ta pra b+hA ya/ pra mu di ta/ kA pa tsa nA ya ni t+yo tA ba/ tsit+ta ya/ b+ha ga bA na hr-i da ya ma nu sma ra/ a tsi sh+ma t+yaM lo kA d+hA to/ / sarba bo d+hi satwA sar+Sha t+ma d+h+ye b+hA Shi taM/ buN+D+ha sat+yaM/ d+harma sat+yaM/ saMg+ha sat+yaM/ a nA g+ha mi sat+yaM/ sro ta A ba n+ni sat+yaM/ yak+Sha sat+yaM/ kush+mA N+DA sat+yaM/ bUrba bo d+hi satwAM/ hr-i da ya ma nu sma ra he he he he he twe twe twe twe twe ra ra ra ra ra la la la la la o~M kA ra pra b+he b+he b+h+yaM pany+tsa ya b+ha shri taM kalpa sarba bud+d+ha sa rA dza taM twa me ba/ rak+ShaM baM da twA si ra swa pra NA mya haM kha ga kha ga / bi dza a sa ra dza ti ya swA hA/ a ba lo ki te shwa rA bi dza ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Amitābhāya / Nama Vipaśyāṃ / ṣikhī / viśvabhu / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / Mahāsattvāya / Mahākāruṇikāya / pramudita / kāvacanāyanityotāva / cittaya / bhagavān hṛdaya manusmara / aciśmatyaṃ lokādhāto / sarvabodhisattvāparṣat madhye bhāṣitaṃ / buddhasatyaṃ / dharmasatyaṃ / saṃghasatyaṃ / anāghami satyaṃ / srota āpannisatyaṃ / yakṣasatyaṃ / kuśmāṇḍāsatyaṃ / purvabodhisattvasatyaṃ / hṛdaya manusmara he he he he he hve hve hve hve hve ra ra ra ra ra la la la la la / oṃ kāraprabebhyaṃ pañcayābhāśitaṃ kalpasarva-buddhasarājitaṃ tvam eva / rakṣaṃ vaṃ datvāsirasvapraṇām-yahaṃ khaga khaga / bija aparājitāya svāhā // Avalokiteśvarāvijayasvāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa 'od zer dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po las phran tshegs rnams thams cad bklags pas grub pa'o/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs su 'gyur te/ ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten gyi drung du'am/ ri'i rtse mo'am/ rgya mtshor 'gro ba'i chu klung gi 'gram mam/ chu'i dbus sam/ gling du 'o ma dang zan za bas 'di nyid kyis thams cad byas la 'bum bzla bar bya ste sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / de nas mig sman dang ldong ros dang gi wang ste de rnams gcig tu byas la a shwat+tha'i 'dab mas btums te ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la mchod pa byas nas thun gsum du ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste rdzas la nyi ma nyi shu rtsa gcig kho nar bzlas par bya'o/ / dro bar gyur pa dang / du ba 'thul ba dang / 'bar bar gyur na grub pa yin te/ dang pos ni dbang du byed do/ / gnyis pas ni mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / gsum pas ni nam mkha' la 'gro'o/ / ras ris rab tu 'gul na rgyal srid rnyed do/ /

Having read this excellent king of vidyās called “Light Rays Attaining Great Power,” all insignificant rituals succeed. Then, there is the propitiation ritual (sādhana) for this [vidyā]. In front of a reliquary mound (stūpa) possessing bodily relics, a mountain peak, the bank of a river flowing into the ocean, or an island [in] the middle of the water, having eaten barley cooked with milk, and having performed all of the same [rituals], make 100,000 recitations, and one will have performed preliminary service. Then, having combined [black] collyrium, [red] arsenic sulfide, and [yellow] bile, and wrapped it in aśvattha leaves, perform a worship ceremony for the reliquary mound (stūpa) with relics. Seated on a kuśa grass mat for three junctures of the time,[996] one should recite exactly 21 days over possessions. If they become warm, then smoke, and blaze, [the ritual] is successful. With the first, one will subjugate. With the second, one will become invisibile. With the third, one will move in the sky. If the painted cloth quivers, one will acquire a kingdom.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa 'od zer dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of ritual texts[997] called “[Signs] of Light Rays,” born from the best “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom par byed bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma rig pa'i rgyal mo chen por rtog pa'i rgyal por pad+ma kun tu snang ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the best “Extensive” samādhi as before, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Fully Illuminated Lotus” from the most excellent ritual text of The Blessed Queen of Mahāvidyās (Bhagavatī Mahāvidyārājñī).[998]

na maHsu brna ba b+ha sA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ ar+ha te/ sam+m+ya k+saM bud+d+hA ya/ beSh+Ti ko Ti yak+Sha pa ri bri ti ya na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ ut+d+d+ha dz+dza Ta/ pra dz+wa li ta ya/ pad+ma a b+hA saHta thA ga tA ba tsa ne na twa ya b+ha shI taM/ kalpaM/ sarba k+ShA ya/ kIrta nA ya/ sarba satwA hi ta/ a nu karta/ sarba satwA pa ra dzi tA ya/ sarba satwA hi tAr+thA ya/ sarba sid+d+hA/ tsa tA ya ga niHna ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ tad+ya thA/ d+ha ma ni d+ha ma ni/ b+hu r+b+hu ba/ o~M o~M o~M o~M/ / bi pu ri ri/ pu ne swA hA/ bi dza ya pa Ta pa Ta kA ra swA hA/ ma hA ya sha a nu mu ne swA hA/ a pra ti ha ta pa tsa ne swA hA/

Namaḥ suvarnāvabhāsāya / tathāgatāya / arhate / Samyaksaṃbuddhaya / veṣṭikoṭiyakṣaparivṛtāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / Mahāsattvāya / Mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / Urdh[v]ajaṭā / prajvalitāya / padma avabhāsaḥ / tathāgatāvacanenatvayabhaśīti / kalpaṃ / sarvakṣaya / kīrtanaya / sarvasattvāhita / anukartaṃ / sarvasatt[v]āparājitāya / sarvasattvāhitārthāya / sarvasiddhā / cityayoginiḥ nama Ārya Avalokitesśvarāya / tadyathā / dhamanidhamani / bhūrbhuva / oṃ oṃ oṃ / vipuriri / pune svāhā / vijaya paṭa paṭa paṭa kāra svāhā / mahāyaśa anumune svāhā / apratihanapacane svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa pad+ma kun du snang ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po pad+ma kun tu snang bas de bzhin du bdag gi snying po 'di gang de dran pa tsam gyis 'di'i 'jigs pa chen po thams cad med par 'gyur ro/ / gang yang nyin mtshan gsum du 'di byas nas de yun ring po nas mtshams med pa lnga byas pa thams cad yongs su sbyong bar 'gyur ro/ / rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i rmi lam mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / sgrub thabs kyi cho ga ni ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la dri dang bdug pa la sogs pa phul nas 'bum phrag gsum bzlas par bya'o/ / mthar mtshan mo smyung bar gnas pas zla ba bcu gnyis su 'o ma bcu gnyis dang / zho bcu gnyis dang / bum pa gang ba bcu gnyis dang / sbrang rtsi'i bum pa bcu gnyis dang / til dang thug pa'i bum pa bcu gnyis dang / kuSh+mA N+Da'i kham phor bcu gnyis su bdug pa dang / kham phor bcu gnyis su pad+ma dang / slong mo'i zas bcu gnyis bza' bar bya'o/ / de nas srod der de lta bu la sogs pa'i mchod pa'i cho ga byas nas de nas gur gum byugs la der ut+pal sngon po'i kha dog dang mtshungs pa'i sna ma'i me tog gi phreng ba phul nas mchod rten gyi spyan sngar nag po'i bcu bzhi'am/ zla ba nya ba la lag pa g.yas pas ral gri bzung nas ku sha'i khres la nye bar 'dug ste stong phrag brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / mthar grub pa'i mtshan ma nam mkha' nas legs so legs so zhes bya ba'i tshig thos par 'gyur ro/ / de nas ral gri 'bar bar 'gyur te skad cig de nyid la lha'i lus 'khor dang bcas par 'gyur ro/ / bskal pa chen por gnas so/ / de nas ral gri 'gul lam/ mchod rten g.yo bar byed na mi'i rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / yang na gang 'dod cing don du gnyer ba de 'grub ste/ dngos grub kyi yul rnyed do/ /

O Mahāsthamaprapta, one who merely remembers this excellent king of vidyās called “Fully Illuminating Lotus,” which is also my essence, will eliminate all of the great dangers. Anyone who performs it for three days and nights, will completely purify all who have committed the five sins of immediate retribution for a long time. They will see dreams of various kinds. As for the ritual of propitiation [of the deity], having offered incense and perfume to a reliquary mound containing bodily relics, one should recite 300,000 times. At the end of that, remain fasting for a night, [offer] twelve milks for the twelveth [day of the] month, twelve curds, twelve full waterpots, twelve pots of honey, twelve pots of soup with sesame, twelve cups of kuṣmāṇḍa, lotuses for twelve cups, and eat twelve alms meals. Then, from twilight, perform the ritual of offering in the same way, etc. After that, having smeared saffron and offered flower garlands of jasmine flowers similar in color to the blue utpala lotus, in front of the reliquary mound on the fourteenth day of the waning moon[999] or during the full moon, grasp a sword with the right hand, become seated on a kuśa grass mat, and recite 8,000 times. At the end of that, the signs of success would be hearing the words “Excellent! Excellent!” from the sky. Then, the sword will ignite, and, in that very instant, a divine body will appear together with retinue. One will live for a great aeon. Then, if the sword quivers or the reliquary mound sways, one will become king among men. Moreover, one will obtain whatever one desires and strives to procure. Having achieved that which one strives for, one will obtain a sphere of accomplishment (siddhi).

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po las nges par skyes pa pad+ma kun tu snang ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “The Fully Illuminating Lotus,” born from the most excellent “Extensive samādhi” in the Funda–mental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs ba dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma rig pa'i rgyal po chen po rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por dpe byad brgyad cus rjes su byed pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive samādhi” as before, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Imitating the Eighty Minor Marks” from the best ritual text of the Blessed [Queen][1000] of Mahāvidyās.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ o~M dri dza TA ya/ na maHka maN+Da lu ha stA ya/ na maHpad+ma bi b+hu Shi tA ya/ na maHpad+ma yA nA yA/ na maHpad+ma ha stA yA/ na mo maN+Da la shi khA ya/ na mo a shI t+ya nU byaM dza na/ lak+Sha NA ya/ na mo a su rA/ re kuny+tsi tA ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / Mahāsattvāya / Oṃ drijaṭāya / Namaḥ padmavibhuṣitāya / namaḥ padmayānāyāḥ / namaḥ padmahastāyāḥ / namo maṇḍalaśikhāya / namo aśītyanūbyaṃjana / lakṣaṇāya / namo asurā / rekuñcitāya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dpe byad brgyad cu'i rjes su byed pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po sgrol ma'i rtog pa don chen po sbyin pa ste gang la la 'di dran par byed pa de'i don thams cad grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho ga ni rgya mtshor 'gro ba'i chu klung ngam/ chu gling ngam/ rgya mtsho'i chu gling du gang bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang gi tshad kyi bye ma'i rang bzhin gyi mchod rten byas te/ srog shing btsugs nas dri dang bdug pa la sogs pa ji ltar 'byor pas re re'i spyan sngar stong phrag brgyad bzlas bar bya'o/ / ji srid du mchod rten stong phrag brgyad po rdzogs kyi bar du'o/ / gal te phyis mchod rten 'bar nas chen po'i bdag por 'gyur ro/ / de nas 'bar na grub par 'gyur ro/ / de nas las thams cad du 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po 'am/ rgyal po'i blon po'am/ bud med dam/ skyes pa dbang du bya bar 'dod na mchod rten gyi spyan sngar dri la sogs pa phul nas stong phrag brgyad bzlas pa bya'o/ / nyi ma bdun thun gsum du byas na dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / gang blangs pa de rnyed do/ / 'jigs pa la dam tshig la gnas te bzlas pa byas na 'jigs pa med par 'gyur ro/ / las phra mo rnams bklags pa tsam gyis grub ste/ las thams cad byed do/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this great king of vidyās called “Imitating the Eighty Minor Marks” bestows the great aims [of] Tārā’s ritual text. Whoever remembers this [vidyā] shall accomplish all aims. Here is the propitation ritual associated with that [vidyā]. Make a stūpa out of sand equaling the measurement of a full span of the Sugata where there is a river that flows into the ocean, or on an island in a river or in the ocean. Having planted a “soul pole” (srog shing) in the stūpa and attached perfume and incense, etc., recite 8,000 [times] in front of each [stūpa]. Up until the completion of the 8,000th stūpa, if the stūpa blazes up from behind, one will become a lord over the entire earth. After that, if it burns, one will be successful. [This] is for all rituals. If one desires to control a king, a king’s minister, a woman, or a man, having offered perfume, etc. in front of the stūpa, one should recite 8,000 times. Upon performing [the recitations] at the three junctures [dawn, noon, and twilight] over seven days, one will become delighted. Accept whatever is received. Having adhered to a pledge for [protection from] the dangers, reciting [this vidyā] will eliminate danger. By merely reading [this vidyā], minor rituals shall succeed. It performs all rituals.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa dpe byad brgyad cu'i rjes su byed pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po rdzogs so// //

This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Imitating the Eighty Minor Marks,” born from the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du/ bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po yon tan gyi rgyan zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

The Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the “Extensive” samādhi, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Ornament of Good Qualities” from Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s Most Excellent Ritual Text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ bi mu k+ti te dze/ a b+ha ya d+harma/ ra si gu na sA ga ra pad+me ma na si/ prah+me n+d+ra pra ti pan+na ma ho t+ya na/ tad+ya thA/ dA ma na/ dA ma ni/ tu ru tu ru/ tiSh+tha tiSh+tha/ ma d+hu ma d+hu/ mad d+hi/ mad d+hi/ sarba kA t+yaM ku ru swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / vimuktiteja / abhayadharma / rasigunasāgarapadme manasi / brahmendrapratipannamahotyata / tadyathā / dāmana / dāmani / turu turu / tiṣṭhati tiṣṭhati / madhu madhu / madadhi madadhi / sarvakāryaṃ kuru svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa yon tan gyi rgyan zhes bya ba/ sems can thams cad kyi 'dod pa'i don thams cad sbyin pa/ gang rig pa'i rgyal po yon tan rgyan 'di rtag tu dran par 'gyur ba de dus ring por mi thogs par las thams cad byed par 'gyur ro/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur te/ sngar brjod pa'i cho gas bcom ldan 'das 'od dpag med thub pa'i ras ris 'drir gzhug go/ / 'dab ma stong pa la skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/ chos ston par mdzad bzhin pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / g.yas kyi gzhogs su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug pad+ma la bzhugs pa sku mdog dkar po ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ bcom ldan 'das la phyag 'tshal bzhin pa'o/ / de'i 'og tu sgrub pa po lag na spos phor thogs pa pus mo btsugs pa ste/ sngar bzhin no/ / ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten du ras ris de bzhugs su gsol nas/ tshes grangs dang / byed pa dang / yud tsam dge bas gso sbyong yan lag brgyad pa dang / byams pa la gnas te mchod pa rgya chen po byas te zla ba nya la stong phrag bcur bzlas par bya'o/ / 'dis sngon du bsnyen pa byas na mchod rten de nyid la pad+ma re re la yongs su bzlas nas ras ris kyi spyan sngar dbul bar bya'o/ / nyi ma re re la stong dbul bar bya ste/ gang tshes gcig nas brtsams nas ji srid bcu gnyis kyi bar du'o/ / mtshan mo gsum du smyung bar gnas pas ras ris la mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / mar gyis btags pa'i pad+ma dkar po stong phrag gsum sbyin sreg bya'o/ / ras ris kyi phreng ba g.yo ba dang / mar me 'phel te gzhan du 'phro bar byed na 'di ni dngos grub kyi mtshan ma ste rgyal srid chen po rnyed do/ / ma grub na yul rnyed do/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, “Ornament of Good Qualities” grants all the desired aims of all sentient beings. Whoever always remembers this king of vidyās “Ornament of Good Qualities” will perform all rituals for a long time without obstruction. Then there is the ritual of propitiation (sādhana) associated with that [vidyā]. Using the ritual previously expressed, permit the image of the Silent Sage (muni) Bhagavān Amitābha to be drawn on cotton cloth, seated cross-legged on a thousand-petalled [lotus]. He should be drawn as if teaching the Dharma. To his right, draw Noble Avalokiteśvara, seated on a lotus, his body colored white, bearing a crown of locks, bowing respectfully to the Bhagavān. A practitioner is below him, kneeling and lifting an incense vessel in hand as before. Request [the deity] to enter the painted cloth next to a stūpa with bodily relics. For many auspicious days, activities, and moments, [perform] the eight limbs of a fasting reparation, dwell in loving kindness, perform a very extensive offering, and make 10,000 recitations during the full moon. Upon completing preliminary service with this [ritual], having made a complete recitation for each lotus next to that very same stūpa, make an offering in front of the painted cloth. One should make one thousand offerings on each day. Having begun from the first day of the new moon, [continue] up to the twelfth. Having remained fasting for three nights, make a vast offering to the painted cloth, and perform burnt offerings 3,000 times with white lotuses crushed with curds, honey, and butter. If the arrangement of the painted cloth moves and the [tips] of the butter lamps increase, or elsewhere expand, this is a sign of magical success and one will acquire a great kingdom. If unsuccessful, one will acquire a province (yul).

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po las nges par skyes pa yon tan gyi rgyan zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Ornament of Good Qualities,” born from the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi from the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavati Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po chen po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal po chen po der bde ba can gyi bkod pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, cultivated the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, and uttered the king of vidyās called “Happy Land Array” (Sukhāvativyūha) from the most excellent ritual text of Bhagavatī [Tārā].

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+hA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ ar+ha te/ samya k+saM bud+d+hA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ po d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ ud+d+ha pra dz+wa li ta dza TA ya su khA bat+yaM/ pra mo tsa te/ tad+ya thA/ b+ha ga ba to/ a mi tA b+hA sA ya/ pA dA mU le/ ma ma tsa hr-i da ya/ pra ti gr-ih+Na b+ha ga bA na/ ma ma a nu/ kam+pa mu sa tA ya/ tad+ya thA/ sA d+hu sa d+huM/ suSh+Thu pa ri Sh+ya mi ti laM g+ha lang+g+ha dz+yo tiSh+pa pa ti/ bi b+hu d+ha pad+ma ha sta ya su me su me/ bi su ma gi ri gi ri Ni swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Amitābhāya / Tathāgatāya / Arhate / Samyaksaṃbuddhāya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / Bodhisattvāya / Mahāsattvāya / Mahākāruṇikāya / Ūrdhvaprajvalitajaṭāya / sukhāvatyaṃ / pramocate / tadyathā / bhagavato / Amitāb[h]āsaya / pādāmūle / mamacahṛdaya / pratigṛhṇatu bhagavāna / mama anu / kampāmusatayi / tadyathā / sādhu sādhū / suṣthu pariṣyāmi ti laṇghalanghaḥ jyotiṣthapati / vibhudhapadmahastāya sume sume / visuma giri giriṇi svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa/ bde ba can gyi bkod pa zhes bya ba rig pa'i rgyal po chen po bzlas pa tsam gyis 'jigs pa thams cad las srung ba'o/ / 'di'i cho ga ni bla gab med par shing gcig gi 'og tu bum pa tsam gyi mchod rten byas nas de'i spyan sngar a ga ru 'bum gyis sbyin sreg bya'o/ / gang gi don du sbyin sreg byas pa de'i mchog rnyed do/ / rgyal po'am/ rgyal po'i blon po dbang du bya bar 'dod pas mchod rten gyi spyan sngar lan tshwa'i gzugs brnyan gyi gzugs brnyan byas nas pa lA sha'i me la nyi ma gsum la lan bdun thun mtshams gsum du sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / bud med dbang du bya bar 'dod na thang gi phyogs su yungs kar khrag gis btags pa rnams seng ldeng gi me la yungs kar dang seng ldeng btags pa rnams kyi nyi ma gsum du thun mtshams gsum du stong rtsa brgyad sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / rgya mtshor 'gro ba'i chu klung gi bye ma la mchod rten sor bzhi tsam mam/ mtho gang tsam mam/ bde bar gshegs pa'i mtho gang gi tshad tsam pa brgyad lhag pa'i stong byas la srog shing phul te mchod pa la sogs pa'i tshogs re re'i spyan sngar stong rtsa brgyad bzlas par bya ste/ ji srid stong rtsa brgyad gnas pa na dong tse stong stong rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / rgya mtsho'i ngogs su mchod rten re re'i spyan sngar cho ga sngon du 'gro bas stong phrag brgya bzlas na bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug mthong ste/ mchog ci 'dod pa de stsol bar mdzad cing gang tshol ba de rnyed do/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, merely by reciting this excellent king of vidyās called “Happy Land Array” protects from all dangers. As for its ritual, make a stūpa roughly the size of a water pot beneath a single tree without a canopy, and perform 100,000 burnt offerings with aloe wood (akaru) in front of that [stūpa]. Having performed a burnt offering for whatever purpose, one will obtain its boon. If desiring to control a king or king’s minister, having made an image out of salt in front of the stūpa, upon performing burnt offerings seven times at the three junctures of the day for three days in fire of pālaśa wood, one will be in control. If desiring to control a woman, upon performing 8,000 burnt offerings at the three junctures of the day for three days with pulverized khadira wood and white mustard over fire of khadira wood, mixed with blood and white mustard on a flat place, one will become powerful. Having made 1,008 stūpas measuring four sor, a full span, or a full span of the Sugata with sand from a river draining into the ocean, and having offered a soul pole, recite [the vidyā] 1,008 times in front of each [stūpa] with the ritual of honor offerings, etc. If sitting for 1,008 [performances], one will acquire 1,000 copper coins (khaśārpaṇa). If reciting 100,000 times in front of each [reliquary mound] that is situated along the ocean’s shore, proceeding according to the former ritual, one will obtain a vision of Bhagavān Noble Avalokiteśvara. Whatever excellent thing one desires and searches for, one will find.
bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa bde ba can gyi bkod pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Happy Land Array” from the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang ting nge 'dzin de nyid sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por dpa' bo ldan ma zhes bya ba rig pa'i rgyal po gsungs so// //

Then, the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the same samādhi as before, uttered the king of vidyās called “Heroine”[1001] from the Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s most excellent ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ shi ri bi si ri smr-i ti ba tsa ne/ te dzo ba d+ha ni ha ra ha ra a mu kaM me ba sa mA gats+tsha tu ra ma ni/ bi ra ma Ni/ bi ra bA si/ mi ni sau/ ta mu ta khe pA ti bar+Na swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / śirivisiri smṛtivadani / tijovandhani hara hara amukaṃmeva samāgaccha turamaṇi / viramaṇi / viravāsi / minisau / tamutakhepītavarṇa svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa dpa' bo dang ldan ma zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal mo chen mo sems can thams cad rjes su srung bar byed pa/ rgyal ba mchog gi sras rnams kyi gang dpa' ba dang ldan pa'i rig pa 'di rtag tu dran pa de nor gyi dngos grub nges par de'i brtson pa dang bcas pa dang / de'i 'dod pa las 'grub bo/ / 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur te/ bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi wang gis 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ pad+ma'i gdan la phyag na pad+ma ste/ g.yas pas mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa/ rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa'o/ / de'i g.yas su sgrub pa po ste sngar bzhin no/ / ras ris de ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la dri dang bdug pa dang / phreng ba phul nas nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas par zla ba nya ba la 'o thug gi kham phor bcu gnyis phul nas a ga ru'i bdug spos dbul lo/ / de nas ku sha'i khres la 'dug ste stong rtsa brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / las thams cad kyi dngos grub ni 'di nyid kyi cho gas 'bum bzlas par bya'o/ / phyi nas ras ris kyi spyan sngar dkyil 'khor nye bar byugs te sna ma'i me tog re re la yongs su bzlas nas dkyil 'khor du gtor bar bya'o/ / de lta bu nyi ma bdun du thun gsum du ji srid stong rtsa brgyad byas na nyi ma bdun pa la gang 'dod pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / ras ris kyi spyan sngar a ga ru nag po 'bum phrag gsum sbyin sreg byas na rgyal srid rnyed do/ / ma grub na grong ngo / /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this excellent queen of vidyās called “Heroic” protects all sentient beings. The sons of the Excellent Conqueror who always remember this vidyā called “Heroine” shall surely accomplish the rituals that aim for and strive for the magical result of wealth. Here is the evocation ritual for that [vidyā]. Depict Bhagavān Ārya Avalokiteśvara with [yellow] bile seated on a lotus, holding a lotus in his [left] hand, bestowing the “Have No Fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā) with the right, and adorned with all ornaments. On his right is the practitioner as before. Having offered perfume, flowers, incense, and garlands to that painted cloth on a reliquary mound with bodily relics, and having fasted for a day and a night, offer twelve clay cups of rice porridge during the full moon and burning incense of akaru. Then, having sat down on a bundle of kuśa grass, make 1,008 recitations. One will have performed preliminary service. Regarding the magical results of all the rituals, one should recite 100,000 times with the same ritual. Subsequently, smear a circle in front of the painted cloth. Having recited over each jasmine flower, cast them into the circle. In this way, upon performing up to 1,008 times during three junctures over seven days, whatever one desires, one will control for seven days. Upon performing 300,000 burnt offering with black aloewood (akaru) in front of the painted cloth, one will acquire a kingdom. If unsuccessful, [one will acquire] a village.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa dpa' bo ldan ma zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal mo chen mo yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent queen of vidyās called “Heroine” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po de nyid sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating that same king of samādhis, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Bestowing Fearlessness” from Bhagavatī [Tārā’s] most excellent ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ dIp+ta ping+ga le ha ri ping+ga le a so ni tA d+ha drA le hi e hi/ ma ma pa raM pra yats+tsha swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / Dīptapiṅgale haripiṅgale asonitādhadrā ehi ehi Mamavaraṃ prayaccha svāhā /

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste/ mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po'o/ / de nas 'di'i cho ga ni/ ras sam 'bras bu can la sen rtsis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ pad+ma'i gdan la pad+ma'i phyag can/ mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa'o/ / sgrub pa po yang sngar bzhin no/ / de'i spyan sngar thun gsum du mar gyis btags pa'i tsan+dan dmar po'i sbyin sreg 'bum byas na gser brgya rnyed do/ / 'bum phrag bdun sbyin sreg byas na rgyal srid rnyed do/ / 'dir pad+ma rA ga 'byung bar 'gyur ba ni/

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the king of vidyās “Bestowing Fearlessness.” Here is its ritual. Using paint, depict Noble Avalokiteśvara on cloth or parchment (’bras bu can), [seated] on a lotus throne, with a lotus in hand, bestowing the “Have No Fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā). The practitioner is just as before. In front of that [painted cloth], if one has performed 100,000 burnt offerings of red sandalwood crushed with butter at the three junctures, one will acquire one hundred gold coins. If performing 700,000 burnt offerings, one will acquire a kingdom. In this [ritual,] rubies (padmarāga) will appear.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ yi ge ts+tshi twe tsa pa ri pra Na/ ai shra t+yaM/ da dA ti/ me badzri Ni/ g+hi Ni/ mo ha ni/ mo ha dza/ dzaM b+ha ni/ staM b+ha ni/ a b+ha ya pra di/ a b+ha ya pra di/ la la la la/ la la la la swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā yigecchitvecaparipraṇa / Auśratyaṃ / dadāti / mebajriṇi / mohani / mohaja / jambhani / stambhani / abhayaprada / abhayaprade / lalalala / lalalala svāhā //

'di'i cho ga ni tsan+dan dmar pos 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug bri bar bya'o/ / de'i spyan sngar mar dang sbrang rtsis btags pa'i me tog dmar po sbyin sreg 'bum byas na/ pad+ma rA ga brgyad rnyed do/ / zas kyi sngags kyi cho gar 'gyur ba ni/ 'di ni mthu chen po thob pa pad+ma rA ga sbyin pa'i sngags so/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the mantra for bestowing rubies (padmarāga). As for its ritual, draw Noble Avalokiteśvara with red saffron. If one performs 100,000 burnt offerings with red flowers crushed in butter and honey in the presence of that [cloth], one will find one hundred rubies. This is the ritual for the food mantra.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ pra byA ka rI/ pra b+ha kA ri/ dz+yo ti Sh+ma ti su tsi bi mu tsA ya swA hA/
