Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / Tadyathā prabyākarī / prabhakārī / prabhkārī / jyotiṣmati suci vimucāya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste/ zas gos sbyin pa'i sngags so/ / 'di'i cho ga ni khrag dang ba bla las 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug bri bar bya'o/ / de'i spyan sngar mar gyis btags pa'i 'o thug gi sbyin sreg ji srid 'bum phrag gcig byas na gnas thams cad du zas gos rnyed do/ / 'di ni dngul sbyin par 'gyur te/

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the mantra for bestowing food and clothes. As for its ritual, depict Noble Avalokiteśvara using blood and yellow arsenic (ba bla). In the presence of this [image], perform 100,000 burnt offerings of soup mixed with butter, and one will find food and clothes everywhere. This is for bestowing silver.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ dz+wa la dz+wa la pra dz+wa la/ b+ha na g+ha na/ ha TA ya/ sA da ya/ sA da ya/ e hi e hi/ phu phu phu phu/ g+hu g+hu/ phu ra swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā jvala jvala prajvala ghana ghana haṭāya / sādhaya sādhaya / ehi ehi / phu phu phu phu / ghu ghu / phura svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa dngul sbyin pa'i sngags te/ 'di'i cho ga ni/ gur gum gyis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ de'i spyan sngar zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / sbrang rtsi mar gyis btags pa'i nA ga ge sar gyi sbyin sreg 'bum byas na dngul brgya rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / yang 'dir gser rab tu sbyin pa'i sngags ni/

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the mantra for bestowing silver. As for its ritual, one should depict Noble Avalokiteśvara with saffron. If performing 100,000 burnt offerings with nagagesara flowers crushed in curds, honey, and butter in the presence of that [image], one will find 100 silver [coins]. Moreover, here is the mantra for bestowing gold.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo b+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ ga ru ru pha ra ba ra/ ba ri li swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / ga ru ru pha ra va ra / va ri li svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste gser sbyin pa'i sngags so/ / 'di'i cho ga ni ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la mal+li ka'i me tog re re la yongs su bzlas nas mchod rten gyi drung du gtor bar bya'o/ / thun gsum du stong phrag brgyad gtor na zla ba'i nang du gser brgya rnyed do/ / ras ris kyi cho gar 'gyur ba ni ras la bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ral pa gyen du brdzes pa/ phyag na spyi blugs bsnams pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ras ris nges grong ngam dgon par a shwa t+tha'i shing gi 'og tu gtsang ma'i phyogs su bzhugs nas sra rtsi pog gi sreg blugs 'bum phrag bdun sbyin sreg byas na bcom ldan 'das kyis myur du rgyal srid stsol bar 'gyur ro/ /zhes pa de rnams lnga po tsam ni

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the mantra for bestowing gold. As for its ritual, recite over mallika flowers one by one, and a stūpa filled with relics, and scatter [the flowers] near the stūpa. If one scatters 8,000 [flowers] at the three junctures of the day, one will find 100 gold [coins]. As for the ritual of the image on cloth, depict Bhagavān Noble Avalokiteśvara on cotton cloth, with his locks bound up, holding a water pot in hand and seated on a lotus throne. Having placed the image on cloth in a pure direction beneath an aśvattha tree in a village or a solitary place, if one performs 700,000 burnt offerings with oblations of resin and varnish, the Bhagavān shall quickly bestow a kingdom. This is the fifth type [of ritual].
bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma'i rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa rdzogs so// //
This completes “Bestowing Fearlessness” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po bsgoms nas/ bcom ldan 'das ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por o~M yig rab tu 'byung ba zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

The Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi as before, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Arising from the Letter Oṃ”[1002] from Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s most excellent ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo a mi tA b+h+yA s+ya ta thA ga tA ya/ aR+ha te/ samyak+saM bud+d+ha s+ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ a muk+te/ a muk+te/ tsats+tsha da ne/ mA d+he ni mA d+he ni/ su ru d+hi/ ru ta mA ya/ d+ha rI/ hu hu/ hu hu/ ma tha ma tha ma tha/ o~M ra pra mu kha/ pA la pA la/ ma hA pA ri pA la/ te dza/ na ma stu te/ sarba duSh+Ta twaM bA si sA tA Ni mA ne swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Namo Āmitābhāya / tathāgatāya / arhati / samyaksaṃbuddhāsya / Nama Ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / amukte / cacchadane / mādheni mādheni / surudhi / ruttamāya/ dhā / rī / hu hu / hu hu / matha matha matha / oṃ pramukha / pāla / pāla / mahāparipāla / tija / namo stute / sarvaduṣṭatvaṃ vāsisātāṇi māne svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste/ 'khor ba'i sna thag grol bar byed pa zhes bya ba rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gang 'di rtag tu dran par byed na 'khor bar yun ring du mi 'khor ro/ / bzlas pa nyid kyis mtshams med pa lnga po rnams rnam par sbyong bar byed do/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho ga ni sngar brjod pa'i ras la bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug nam mkha' la 'gro ba/ kun nas 'od 'bar ba/ pad+ma phyag na bsnams pa/ g.yas par mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa'o/ / sgrub pa po yang dag pa'i lus kyi mgo bos bdug pa sreg pa cha byad dang rnam pa ji lta ba bzhin 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas ras ris de sngar brjod pa'i gnas su bzhugs nas dri dang / me tog dang / bdug pa la sogs pa 'di nyid kyis phul la 'bum phrag gsum bzlas par bya'o/ / sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / mtshams med pa lnga po rnams rnam par sbyong bar byed do/ / 'bum phrag drug bzlas pas dam bcas pa rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / gdug pa sha za dang srin po rnams 'ching bar 'dod na ku sha'i sna thag gis bskor nas stong phrag brgyad mngon par bsngags te gdug pa gang na gnas pa'i shing ngam khyim la sogs pa la dkri bar bya'o/ / gdug pa thams cad bcings par 'gyur ro/ / gdug pa'i sems dang sems can rnams zil gyis gnon par 'gyur ro/ / rna ba'i mig sman sgrub par 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar stong phrag rdzogs pa'i sreg blugs byas nas a shwat+tha'i 'dab ma bdun gyi nang du bzhag nas du ba 'thul na de rnams rgyal ba'i spyan dang mtshungs par 'gyur ro/ / lo stong phrag gsum du 'tsho bar byed do/ / ras ris kyi spyan sngar pad+ma dkar po 'bum phrag gsum dbul bar bya'o/ / rgyal srid rnyed do/ / ma grub na yul rnyed do/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, whoever continually remembers this excellent king of vidyās called “Liberation from Saṃsāra’s Noose” shall not be reborn in saṃsāra for a long time. Reciting it even purifies those who’ve committed the five sins of immediate retribution. Then, there is a propitiation ritual (sādhana) associated with this [vidyā]. On a cotton cloth similar to that mentioned above, [depict] Bhagavān Ārya Avalokiteśvara, moving in the sky, completely ablaze with light rays. He holds a lotus in [his left] hand while bestowing the “Have No Fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā) with his right [hand]. One should draw a practitioner with a full head and body, proper aspect and guise, burning incense. Having laid down the image on cloth in the place previously mentioned, recite [the vidyā] 300,000 times over offerings of perfume, flowers, incense, etc., and it will propitiate the deity as before. It will even fully purify those who’ve committed the five sins of immediate retribution. Reciting it 600,000 times fulfills one’s vows. If one wishes to capture malicious spirits, piśācas, and rākṣasas, surround [the painting] with a noose made of kuśa grass and recite [the vidyā] 8,000 times. It shall ensnare the trees or homes that are the dwelling places of malicious spirits. It will shackle all malicious spirits. It will overpower sentient beings and malicious beings. If one desires to manufacture collyrium for the ear, perform 1,000 complete oblations in front of the painted cloth, and place [oblations] inside seven aśvattha leaves. If smoke rises, those [leaves] shall become equal to the [medicinal flowers called] “Eye of the Conqueror.”[1003] It will make one live for 3,000 years. One should offer 300,000 white lotuses in front of the painted cloth. One will acquire a kingdom. If unsuccessful, one will acquire a province.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa/ 'khor ba'i sna thag grol bar byed pa zhes bya ba rig pa'i rgyal po chen po rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Liberation from Saṃsāra’s Noose,” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por yi ge bcu gcig pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po 'di gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, uttered this excellent king of vidyās called “Eleven Letters” from Bhagavatī [Tārā]’s most excellent ritual text.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ da sha ni/ ka ra Ni/ bi ka ra Ni/ bi d+hu li/ bI la ya swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / daśani / karaṇi / vikaraṇi / vidhuli / vīlaya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa yi ge bcu gcig pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po rtag tu sangs rgyas bcu gcig la'ang 'di bdag gis sngon bshad pa ste rtag tu bzlas pas gser rnyed do/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho ga ni sgrub pa'i ched du 'gyur te/ sngar brjod pa'i ras ris nA ga ge sar gyi phye ma dang pa li ka bsres pas 'drir gzhug ste/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ bsam gtan sgom pa/ phyag na pad+ma bsnams pa/ phyag g.yas pas bgrang phreng bsnams pa/ sku mdog dkar po'o/ / sgrub pa po yang sngar bzhin no/ / ras ris dang po'i gnas su bzhag nas/ 'bum phrag lnga bzlas par bya'o/ / sngon du bsnyen ba byas par 'gyur ro/ / ri'i rtse mor nyi ma gsum du mi bza' bar stong phrag nyi shu bzlas par bya ste/ gser stong rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / tsan+dan dkar po'i tshon gyis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug sngar brjod pa bzhin 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / de'i spyan sngar tsan+dan dkar po'i zhogs ma dang bcas pa 'bum phrag gsum sbyin sreg byas na rgyal srid rnyed do/ / ma grub na grong rnyed de yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin pa la'o/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, by continually reciting this vidyā called “Eleven Letters,” which was formerly explained by me to the eleven Buddhas, one will acquire gold. Then, there is the ritual to propitiate [the deity] of this [vidyā], which is for the purpose of success. On a cloth similar to that previously mentioned, using a mixture of balika flowers with powdered nāgagesara flowers, one should depict Avalokiteśvara seated on a lotus throne, with his stream of consciousness in meditation (bsam gtan sgom), holding a lotus in [his left] hand and a rosary with his right hand. His body is white in color. The practitioner is the same as before. Having set down the image on cloth in the first place, one should make 300,000 recitations and propitiate the deity as before. One should then make 20,000 recitations without eating for three days on a mountain top, and one will acquire 1,000 gold [coins]. With paint the color of white sandalwood, one should begin painting Noble Avalokiteśvara, as expressed above. If one performs 300,000 burnt offerings with fragments of white sandalwood in the presence of that [image on cloth], one will acquire a kingdom. If unsuccessful, one will acquire a village.
bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa 'dod cing don du gnyer ba sbyin pa'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //

Cultivated in the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, this completes the excellent king of vidyās “Bestowing Provisions and Desires,” from the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs ba dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes rtog pa'i rgyal po chen por ras ris kyi gnas zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

Then, the Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Abode of the Painted Cloth” in the most excellent ritual text of Bhagavatī Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ ka Te ni ka Te/ ka TAM ka Te/ dz+yo ti/ tiSh+ma tI/ bi pu le swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya / bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / kaṭeni kaṭe / kaṭāṃ kaṭe / jyoti / tiṣmatī / vipule svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa ras ris kyi gnas zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po'o/ / rtag tu bzlas pas don sbyin par byed cing sdig pa thams cad rnam par 'joms par byed pa grub par yang 'gyur ro/ / yang 'di'i cho ga ni sngar brjod pa'i ras ris la 'od dpag med 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/ ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par zhugs pa'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi g.yas su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ral pa'i cod pan 'chang ba/ dar dkar po'i stod g.yogs can/ bcom ldan 'das la thal mo sbyor bar byed bzhin pa'o/ / g.yon du 'phags pa mthu chen thob pri yang ku ltar sngo bsangs pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa bcom ldan 'das la thal mo sbyor bar byed pa'o/ / de lta bu'i ras ris 'drir bcug nas gtsang ma'i phyogs su pa Ta'i shing la so so so sor bzhag nas 'di nyid kyis dri dang me tog la sogs pa phul la 'bum phrag bdun bzlas par bya'o/ / sngon du bsnyen pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / mthar mtshan mo gsum du smyung bar gnas te/ me tog dkar po stong phrag brgyad la re re la yongs su bzlas nas spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi drung du dbul bar bya'o/ / dngos grub kyi mtshan ma ni pad+ma stong rtsa brgyad po de rnams gcig tu gnas par 'gyur te/ 'di ni dngos grub kyi mtshan ma'o/ / 'di dag phye mar byas nas gzhan sha la dang bsres te rgyal po'am/ rgyal po'i blon po'am/ gang la byin pa de dbang du 'gyur ro/ / nad kyis gdungs pa la byin na nad thams cad nye bar zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / phye ma des mtshan ma dang ldan pa mo la rdul btab na bu rnyed do/ / tho rangs bdag nyid kyi spyi bor phye ma des rdul btab na skye bo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar gang 'dod pa de thams cad phye ma des byed do/ / grol bar byed na nye bar gzhag pa'i nad dam/ khrag 'dzag pa'am/ mtshan mar gdol pa'am/ de bzhin du dug la sogs pa thams cad la 'thung du bcug pa'am/ cung zad byug par sbyin par bya ste/ nad thams cad zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the excellent king of vidyās called “Abode of the Painted Cloth.” Continually reciting it will grant your aims and destroy all sins. As well, for its [propitiation] ritual, depict Amitābha on the painted cloth expressed before, seated cross-legged, equipoised in samādhi. To the Bhagavān’s right is Noble Avalokiteśvara, bearing a crown of locks, with an upper garment of white silk, his palms folded in reverence for the Bhagavān. On the Bhagavān’s left is Noble Mahāstāmaprāpta, green as the priyaṅku plant, seated on a lotus throne, his palms folded in reverence for the Bhagavān. Having begun to depict the painted cloth in this way, set it aside on vaṭa wood in a pure place, and recite 700,000 times over offerings of perfume and flowers, etc. One will have performed preliminary service. At the end of that, remain fasting for three nights, make complete recitation for each of 8,000 white flowers, and make an offering in front of Avalokiteśvara. A sign of success is that 1,008 lotuses will manifest at once. This is a sign of success. Having ground these [lotuses] into powder, and mixed them with other cow [products], one will gain control over a king, or a king’s minister, or whomever it is given. If [that powder is] given to someone tormented with disease, it will pacify all diseases. If casting that powder upon a woman possessing signs of fertility, she will produce a son. At dawn, if casting this powder on one’s own head, one will delight all living beings. Similarly, that powder will perform whatever is desired. If desiring to be free [from illness], ingest it or apply it as ointment for illness, menstruation, to reveal signs, or similarly, for all poisons, etc., and one will pacify all diseases.

yang 'dir ras kyi gnas kyi phye ma'i cho ga ni nA ga ge sar dang / tsan+dan dang / da ma na ka dang / ta ma la'i 'dab ma dang / pu shel tse dang / ru rta dang / me tog brgya pa ste/ 'di rnams cha mnyam par sbyar nas phye mar byed du gzhug go/ / 'di ni ras ris kyi gnas kyi phye ma ste brgya phrag brgyad mngon par bsngags nas gang la btung ba la sogs par byin pa de dbang du 'gyur te/ bran nyid du nye bar gnas pa dang / mtshon cha'i 'jigs pa med pa dang / gnyis mnyam du rnyed cing rab tu 'jug go/ /
de bzhin du 'jigs pa la ras ris kyi spyan sngar pad+ma dkar po 'bum phrag gsum dbul bar bya ste yul chen po rnyed do/ / arga'i shing gis me rab tu sbar nas pad+ma dmar pos 'bum phrag bdun sbyin sreg byas na rgyal srid chen po rnyed do/ / ma grub na grong khyer chen po rnyed do/ / til gyi sbyin sreg 'bum phrag gcig byas na grong gcig rnyed do/ / 'bum phrag lnga sbyin sreg byas na nor sbyin pa dang mchog sbyin par byed cing / de dbang du byed do/ / dung la brgya bzlas pa nyid kyis don thams cad thob par 'gyur ro/ /

Moreover, there is the ritual of powder for the abode of the painted cloth. Having prepared equal parts of the following: petals of nagagesara, sandalwood, damanaka, and tamāla, plus uśīra plant, kuṣṭha, and a one-hundred-year-old flower, make them into powder. Having rightly praised this powder eight hundred times for the abode of the painted cloth, one will control whomever is given that powder to drink, etc., remain in service, lack dangers of swords, find two together, and be in command. In this way, if one offers 300,000 white lotuses in the presence of the painted cloth for dangers, one will acquire a large province (yul). If one performs 700,000 burnt offerings with red lotuses, kindled in fire made with arka wood, one will acquire a vast kingdom. If unsuccessful, one will acquire a huge city. If making one hundred thousand burnt offerings of sesame, one will find one village. If making 500,000 burnt offerings and bestowing a gift of wealth and boons, one will gain contol over it. By reciting [this vidyā] one hundred times over conch shell, one will attain all aims.
bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa'i rgyud chen po ras ris kyi gnas yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the “Abode of Painted Cloth” in the Mahā-tantra of the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

slar yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du pad+ma'i mtha' zhes pa'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /
The Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi as before, uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Lotus Border.”

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ bya dza ni/ be dza ni/ be dza ha te/ pad+ma ShaN+Da ni/ pA sI ni bud+d+he/ bud+d+hA ya/ pa raM pa rA ya/ sarba ga ti bi dza yA ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / vyajani / vijani / vijahate / padmaṣaṇḍani / vāsīni buddhe / vuddhāya / paraṃ parāya / sarvagativijayāya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa pad+ma'i mtha' zhes bya ba'i rig pa chen po ste 'di rtag tu bzlas pas phyir bzlog par 'gyur zhing nad thams cad las rnam par grol bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur te gro ga'i 'dab ma la gi bang gis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ pad+ma la bzhugs pa thams cad dkar po ral pa gyen du brdzes pa phyag g.yon pas pad+ma dang / g.yas pas ril ba spyi blugs bsnams pa'i phyag go/ / de nas ras ris gtsang ma'i gnas su bzhugs su gsol nas 'di nyid kyis dri dang bdug pa la sogs pa thams cad bya zhing 'bum phrag gsum bzlas par bya'o/ / mthar nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas nas dkar po'i tshes gcig nas brtsams te bcom ldan 'das la me tog stong phrag brgyad la lan re bzlas nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs la bsnun par bya'o/ / de ltar ji srid du stong phrag brgyad cu rdzogs pa'i mthar mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas srod nas brtsams te bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas nam mkha' las grub bo zhes pa'i tshig 'byung ste/ gal te mngon par 'dod pa de rnyed do/ / rgyal po dang gang dbang du byed par 'dod na sna ma'i phreng ba yongs su blangs nas me tog de re re la mngon par bsngags nas ras ris kyi spyan sngar dbul te/ nyin zhag bdun thun gsum du dbul bar byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / bram ze dbang du bya bar 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar pa lA sha'i me la nyin zhag bdun thun gsum du g.yang gzhi nag po'i pags pas sbyin sreg byas na dbang du 'gyur ro/ / ras ris kyi spyan sngar bi la ba'i me la u dum bA ra'i me tog gis sbyin sreg byas na zhag gsum gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / dmangs rigs dbang du bya bar 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar arga'i me la lan tshwa'i sbyin sreg byas na nyi ma gsum gyis dbang du 'gyur ro/ / thun mong ba'i bud med dbang du bya bar 'dod na me de la nas kyi sbyin sreg bya'o/ / dge slong ngam bram ze dbang du bya bar 'dod na ras ris kyi spyan sngar seng ldeng gi me la dU ra ba'i sbyin sreg thun gsum nyi ma bdun du byas na bdun pa la dbang du 'gyur te/ gang dbang du bya ba de la zla ba gcig tu bzlas pas de dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

O Mahāstāmaprāpta, continually reciting this mahāvidyā called “Lotus Border” will expel and free one from all diseases. Then there is its evocation ritual. Depict Ārya Avalokiteśvara with [yellow] bile on white birch-bark leaves, seated on a lotus, entirely white, his locks bound up, holding a lotus with his left hand and a round water pot in his right hand. Having asked to set down the image on cloth in a pure place, using that same [vidyā,] one should make 300,000 recitations with all [offerings of] perfume and incense, etc. At the end of that, having fasted for a day and a night, having begun from the first day of the waxing moon, recite for the Bhagavān each time over 8,000 flowers, and prick the feet of the Bhagavān [in the painting]. One should recite accordingly, beginning at midnight, and make a very extensive offering after completing 80,000 [performances]. Then, if the words “accomplished one” arise in the sky, one shall attain whatever one desires. If one desires to subjugate a king or someone [else], having accepted a garland of jasmine flowers, and having recited [the vidyā] over every single one of those flowers, one should make an offering in the presence of the painted cloth. If one has made offerings for seven days at the three junctures of the day, one will attain power. If one desires to overpower a brahman, one should make burnt offerings with the hide of a black antelope at the three junctures of the day for seven days over fire kindled with pālaśa wood, and one will gain control. If one has performed burnt offerings with udumbara flowers over fire kindled with bilba wood in the presence of the painted cloth, within three days, one will gain control. If one desires to subjugate a commoner (dmangs rig), one should perform burnt offerings with salt over fire kindled with arka wood in the presence of the painted cloth, and one will gain power within three days. If one desires to overpower an ordinary woman, perform burnt offerings of barley over that fire. If one desires to overpower a monk or a brahman, and if one performs burnt offerings with durva [grass] over khadira wood in the presence of the painted cloth for seven days at the three junctures, one will attain power on the seventh [day]. Having recited for one month over whatever is to be controlled, one will gain power over that.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las skyes pa pad+ma'i mtha' zhes bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of mantras called “Lotus Border” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal por pad+ma gzi brjid ces bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /

Then the Bodhisattva Great Being Noble Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi, uttered the king of mantras (mantrarāja) called “Radiant Lotus,” found in the most excellent ritual text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ da ma ne da ma ne/ shAn+te shAn+te/ mA na se/ bi dza ye/ dza ye ba he/ an g+he/ a Narge/ dar+sha ne/ a pra ti hi ha ta/ sA sa ne/ tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha/ bi dza ya ba he/ ma ba ba raM/ sho b+ha ne/ ru ru ru ru ru ru ru/ rA ya swA hA/

Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / damane damane / śānte śānte / mānase / vijaye / jayavahe / anghe / aṅarge / darśane / apratihata / sāsane / tiṣṭha tiṣṭha / vijayavahe / mavavaraṃ / śobhane / ru ru ru ru ru ru / rāya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa pad+ma gzi brjid ces bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po'o/ / 'di rtag tu bzlas pas nad thams cad med par 'gyur ro/ / de nas 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur te/ le brgan rtsi'i chu dang 'dres pa'i tshon gyis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi ras ris 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / dkar po ral pa gyen du brdzes pa phyag na pad+ma bsnams pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la nye bar 'dug pa/ kun nas 'bar ba'i phreng bas 'khrugs pa'o/ / de nas gtsang ma'i phyogs su bzhugs nas/ 'di nyid kyi dri dang / me tog dang / bdug pa sreg cing 'bum phrag lnga bzlas par bya'o/ / de nas tsan+dan dkar po zho dang / sbrang rtsi dang / mar la btags pa'i sbyin sreg 'bum phrag gsum bya'o/ / de ma thag tu rgyal srid rnyed do/ / ma grub na grong gcig go/ / ras ris kyi spyan sngar pa lA sha'i 'am/ a ga ru mar gyis btags pa'i sbyin sreg byas na gos bye ba brgya rnyed do/ / le brgan rtsi'i sreg blugs 'bum byas na gter mthong ngo / / gang bstan pa zla ba gcig tu bzlas na de'i don rnyed do zhes pa ste 'dod pas nye bar gzhag pa ma gtogs so/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, this is the excellent king of mantras called “Radiant Lotus.” By continually reciting it, there will be no diseases. Then there is its evocation ritual. One should begin to paint Noble Avalokiteśvara with pure, unmixed paint and the juice of the poppy plant (le brgan). Make him white with his locks bound up, holding a lotus in hand, seated on a lotus throne, and shimmering with a garland of blazing light. Then, having placed the painted cloth in a pure direction, one should [offer] perfume, flowers, and incense and make 500,000 recitations with this same [vidyā]. One should perform 300,000 burnt offerings with white sandalwood crushed with curds, honey, and butter. One will immediately acquire a kingdom. If one is unsuccessful, one will acquire one village. If performing burnt offerings with pālaśa or akaru wood crushed with butter in the presence of the painted cloth, one will acquire a billion garments. If one makes 100,000 oblations with poppy plant juice, one will find treasure. One who recites a teaching for one month will acquire one’s aims, except if they are imbedded in desire.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa pad+ma gzi brjid ces bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of mantras called “Radiant Lotus” born from the “Extensive” samādhi, in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug bcom ldan 'das ma rtog pa'i rgyal por dpal be'u zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po gsungs so/ /
The Bodhisattva Great Being uttered the excellent king of vidyās called “Endless Knot”[1004] from Bhagavatī [Tārā’s] most excellent ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ ba su ra/ ma ra/ ba na/ g+hu g+hu/ naM pa raM/ pA ra ya naM/ e hi e hi/ bu d+h+ya bud+h+ya/ bo d+h+ya ye swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / vasura / maravara / ghu ghu / niparaṃ / ehi ehi / budhya budhya / bodhaye svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste/ dpal be'u zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po dran pa tsam gyis nye bar 'tshe ba thams cad 'joms par byed pa'o/ / 'di'i cho ga ni gur gum dang bsres pa'i tshon gyis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya'o/ / ral pa gyen du brdzes pa/ pad+ma la bzhugs pa/ phyag g.yon na pad+ma bsnams pa/ g.yas pas mchog sbyin pa/ thugs kar dpal be'u'i mtshan mas brgyan pa'o/ / g.yas su gur gum gyis dpal be'u bri bar bya'o/ / ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la ras ris zhal nub tu phyogs par bzhugs nas/ mchod rten de nyid kyis bdug pa bsregs te 'bum phrag gsum bzlas par bya'o/ / mthar nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas te/ nA ga ge sar re re la yongs su bzlas nas 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi thugs kar bsnun par bya'o/ / de lta bu zla b.rardzogs par byas na gter chen po mthong bar byed do/ / nyi ma bdun gyis gser stong rnyed do/ / phyogs kyi yul rnyed do/ /

O Mahāstāmaprāpta, merely remembering this excellent king of vidyās called “Endless Knot” destroys all harm (hiṃsa). Its ritual [is as follows]. Depict Noble Avalokiteśvara with paint that is mixed with saffron. His locks are bound up and he is seated on a lotus, holding a lotus in his left hand, and bestowing the boon-granting gesture with his right hand. He is adorned with the mark of an endless knot (śrīvatsa) over his heart. Paint an endless knot with saffron on his right. Having placed a stūpa together with its relics in the western direction facing the painted cloth, and having burnt incense with this same [vidyā] for that same reliquary shrine, one should make 300,000 recitations. At the end of that, one should remain fasting for a day and a night. After reciting over nāgagesara flowers one by one, one should prick Noble Avalokiteśvara’s heart [as it appears in the painting]. In this way, if one completes this [ritual] within a month, one will find a large treasure. [If completing it] within seven days, one will acquire 1,000 gold [pieces]. One will acquire regional territory.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa dpal be'u zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Endless Knot,” born from the “Extensive” samādhi, in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug slar yang yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyal po sgom bzhin du bcom ldan 'das ma'i rtog pa'i rgyal por mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa zhes bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po gsungs so/ /

Then, the Bodhisattva Great Being Avalokiteśvara, while cultivating the most excellent “Extensive” samādhi as before, uttered the king of mantras called “Bestowing Fearlessness” in Bhagavatī [Tārā’s] most excellent ritual text.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya a ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ go pa ti ba ti/ tsa ra pa ti pa ti/ sha sa ni/ sha si ni/ b+hU b+hU/ tsi li ci li tsi lpa ya swA hA/
Namo ratna trayāya / Nama ārya Avalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya / tadyathā / gopatipati / carapatipati / śasani / śasani / bhū bhū / cili cili cilāpaya svāhā //

'di ni mthu chen po thob pa dang bcas pa ste/ mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa zhes bya ba'i sngags kyi rgyal po chen po rtag tu bzlas pas sa'i rgyal por 'gyur ro/ / 'di'i sgrub thabs kyi cho gar 'gyur ba ni ras la li khri'i phye ma dang bsres pa'i tshon gyis 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug 'drir gzhug par bya ste/ ral pa gyen du brdzes pa/ ril ba spyi blugs phyag na bsnams pa/ gzhogs su son pa/ pad+ma'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ mi 'jigs pa rab tu sbyin pa'o/ / de nas ras ris de ring bsrel dang bcas pa'i mchod rten la/ mchod rten gyi byang du bzhugs nas 'di nyid kyis ji ltar 'byor pa'i mchod pa byas nas 'bum bzlas so/ / mthar nyin mtshan du smyung bar gnas pas mchod pa rgya chen po byas nas srod nas brtsams nas bzlas par bya/ nam mkha' las grub po zhes pa'i sgra thos par 'gyur te gang du mchod pa der char lhung bar 'gyur ro/ / ma grub na yul rnyed do/ / de'i spyan sngar pa lA sha'i me la klu shing gi me tog mar la btags pa'i sbyin sreg 'bum byas na dngul 'bum rnyed do/ / dong tse brgya rnyed par 'gyur ro/ /

O Mahāsthāmaprāpta, by continually reciting this excellent king of mantras called “Bestowing Fearlessness,” one will become king over the inhabitants of the earth! As for its evocation ritual (sādhana), one should depict Noble Avalokiteśvara upon a cotton cloth using paint that is mixed with powdered vermillion (li khri). His locks are bound up, and his hand holds a round water pot, a seed syllable is on its side. He is seated on a lotus throne and bestows the “Have No Fear” hand gesture (abhaya-mudrā). Then, having placed the painted image on cloth to the north of a stūpa filled with relics, make an offering of treasured goods and make 100,000 recitations with this same [vidyā]. At the end of [the offerings and recitations], one should fast for a day and a night, make a vast offering, and recite [the vidyā] beginning at midnight. [If] one hears the words “Successful One!” in the sky, whatever one desires will fall like rain! If unsuccessful, one will acquire a province (yul). In the presence of that [painted image on cloth], if one performs 100,000 burnt offerings with flowers from the snake tree (nāgavṛkṣa) crushed in butter and kindled over fire made with pālaśa wood, one will find 100,000 silver coins. One will [also] find 100 copper coins.

bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa'i mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa zhes bya ba'i rig pa'i rgyal po chen po yongs su rdzogs so// //
This completes the excellent king of vidyās called “Bestowing Fearlessness,” born from the “Extensive” samādhi in the Fundamental Ritual Text of Bhagavatī Ārya Tārā Ūrdhvajaṭā.

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod phal po che theg pa chen po'i mdo sde bcom ldan 'das ma 'phags ma sgrol ma ral pa gyen brdzes kyi rtsa ba'i rtog pa las yangs pa dang ldan pa'i ting nge 'dzin las nges par skyes pa'i rig pa'i sngags rnams te le'u rab 'byam bcu gsum pa rdzogs so// //

Sarvatathāgatamātṛtārāviśvakarmabhavatantranāma The Tantra on the Origin of All Rites of Tārā, Mother of All the Tathāgatas
Translated by Samye Translations
[gleng gzhi]
Chapter 1. Introduction
'phags pa 'jam dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to noble Mañjuśrī!

'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das dga' ldan gyi gnas na bzhugs te/ byang chub sems dpa' byams pa dang / 'jam dpal la sogs pa dpag tu med pa dang / ku ru kul+le dang / ri khrod lo ma can las sogs pa dang / tshangs pa dang brgya byin la sogs pa dpag tu med pa dag gis lha rdzas kyi me tog pad+ma dang / ku mu da dang / man dA ra ba la sogs pa lha rdzas kyi me tog dpag tu med pa dag dang / dung dang / pi bang dang / rnga dang / rdza rnga dang / gau rgyud mangs la sogs pa lha'i rol mo dpag tu med pa dang lha'i gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan la sogs pa dpag tu med pa thogs te/ bcom ldan 'das la g.yas phyogs nas bskor te/ mchod pa sna tshogs kyi mchod pa'i sprin gyis mchod do/ /

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was residing in Tuṣita with Maitreya, Mañjuśrī, Kurukullā, Parṇaśavarī, Brahmā, Śakra, and countless other bodhisattvas, gods, and goddesses, who circumambulated him clockwise while holding up an array of offerings beyond count, including heavenly flowers such as lotuses, water lilies, and mandārava flowers, heavenly instruments such as conches, vīṇās, drums, clay drums, and śūrpavīṇās,[9] and heavenly parasols, banners, flags, and the like. They worshiped him with clouds of diverse offerings.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis pha rol gyi sde rab tu 'joms pa rdo rje lta bu zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag ste/ bzhag ma thag tu sa chen po yang g.yos/ bdud kyi dkyil 'khor yang pham par byas te/ 'od kyi snang ba chen po yang bkye'o/ / de yang 'di lta ste/ dkar po dang / dmar po dang / ser po dang / ljang gu dang / mthing ga dang 'dres pa ste 'od sna tshogs bkye ste/ sdug bsngal dang bcas pa rnams sbyangs te/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi yum sgrol ma ku ru kul+le'i gtsug tu nub par gyur to/ / gtsug tu nub ma thag tu mchod pa'i sprin gyi char ba yang 'bab par gyur to/ / de nas lha mo de dper na sprin dang bral ba'i nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor lta bur gyur to/ / de'i tshe bstod pa'i tshigs su bcad pa 'dis bstod pa/

The Blessed One then entered the vajra-like samādhi that vanquishes all opponents. The entire earth shook immediately, the maṇḍala of māras was defeated, and the Blessed One radiated intense light in a spectrum of different colors‍—white, red, yellow, green, dark blue, and a combination of colors‍—that purified everyone who was suffering. Tārā, the mother of all the buddhas, then descended to the goddess Kurukullā’s crown. At that very instant, rain showered down from the offering clouds, and the goddess became like the orb of the sun unobscured by clouds. The Blessed One then lauded her with this verse of praise:
zhing khams thams cad yongs su dag pa la/ / rin chen me tog mang po char du phab/ / dus gsum sangs rgyas thams cad bskyed pa'i yum/ / yum gyur sgrol ma khyod la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / ces gsungs so/ /
“Throughout all utterly pure realms, Precious flowers are raining down. Mother of all the buddhas throughout the three times, Mother Tārā, I praise and revere you!”

de'i tshe byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs te/ bcom ldan 'das la gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad zab pa'i phyir ci'i phyir bskyed/ gang gis na yum yin zhe na/

At that moment, the bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī draped his shawl over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, and addressed the Blessed One: “Blessed One, the buddhas of the three times are so profound. How are they produced? Who says that Tārā is their mother?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ 'jam dpal bden mod kyi dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyang ma skyes pa/ ma 'gags pa/ dri ma med pa/ dri ma dang bral ba med pa 'grib pa med pa 'phel ba med pa rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das pa'o/ / de'i phyir chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin ni de'o/ /

The Blessed One replied, “Mañjuśrī, what you say is indeed true. The buddhas of the three times are not born and do not cease; they are neither defiled nor free of defilement, they do not increase or decrease, and are by nature nirvāṇa. Thus, they are the very nature of all things.”

byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas ni ma skyes pa/ ma 'gags pa/ dri ma med pa/ dri ma dang bral ba med pa/ 'grib pa med pa/ 'phel ba med pa rang bzhin gyis mya ngan las 'das pa de ji ltar skye bar 'gyur/

The bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī then asked, “Blessed One, if the buddhas of the three times are not born and do not cease, are neither defiled nor free of defilement, do not increase or decrease, and are by nature nirvāṇa, how do they take birth?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ 'jam dpal mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya ba ni don dam pa'o/ / mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya ba ni chos kyi dbyings so/ / yang dag pa'i mtha'i tshig bla dgas so/ / snying rje chen po'o/ / kun rdzob ngo bo 'khor ba'i tshig bla dgas so/ / de las 'das pa ni dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas bskyed pa'i yum mo/ / de'i phyir 'khor ba dang mya ngan las 'das pa'o/ / 'jam dpal de ltar na yum du yid la bya'o/ /

The Blessed One replied, “Mañjuśrī, nirvāṇa is the ultimate; nirvāṇa is the realm of phenomena. These are all synonyms for the very limit of reality. Great compassion and relative essence are synonyms for saṃsāra. Beyond these is the mother who gives birth to the buddhas of the three times. Thus, she is beyond saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. Mañjuśrī, this is why she is considered a mother.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ 'jam dpal de bas na chos rnams kyi de kho na nyid shes pas 'di bsgom par bya'o/ / gzungs sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / nan tan du bsgrub par bya'o/ / 'di'i yon tan shes par bya'o/ / 'di mchod par bya'o/ / lung nod par bya'o/ / the tshom med par bya'o/ / las la nan tan du bya'o/ / 'di'i bsngags pa yid la bya'o/ / las so so'i sgo nas bsgrub par bya'o/ /

“Therefore, Mañjuśrī,” the Blessed One continued, “knowing the essential nature of all things, meditate upon her. Recite the following dhāraṇī-mantra, practice assiduously, know her qualities, and make offerings to her. Receive instructions and rid yourself of all doubt. Apply yourself to her rites, keep her praise in mind, and reach accomplishment by means of these different rites.”[10]
de skad ces byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la bstan to/ /
Thus, the Blessed One taught the bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī.
des ni gleng gzhi'i le'u bstan pa ste le'u dang po'o// //
This was the first chapter, “Providing an Introduction.”
[mchod pa]
Chapter 2. Offering

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas bcom ldan 'das la gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das 'di ji ltar bsgom par bya/ 'dil ji ltar du nan tan du bya zhes smras pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ 'jam dpal 'di ltar yid la bya'o/ / 'jam dpal chos thams cad ni ma skyes pa'o/ / chos thams cad ni ma 'gags pa'o/ / chos thams cad ni dri ma dang bral ba'o/ / chos thams cad ni mya ngan las 'das shing rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag par bsgom par bya'o/ /

The bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī then asked the Blessed One, “Blessed One, how should I meditate? How should I assiduously practice this?” “Mañjuśrī,” replied the Blessed One, “apply your mind as follows. Mañjuśrī, you should meditate on the fact that all phenomena are unborn, all phenomena are unceasing, all phenomena are undefiled, and all phenomena are nirvāṇa and naturally pure.
'jam dpal de'i phyir sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / o~M swa b+ha ba shud d+haHsarba d+harmAHswa b+hA ba shud d+ho& haM/ zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
“Mañjuśrī, to that end, recite this mantra: “oṁ svabhāvaśuddhāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāvaśuddho ’ham.”[11]

yang bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ mngal las skyes pa dang / sgo nga las skyes pa dang / drod gsher las skyes pa dang / brdzus te skye ba dag la bltas te byams pa bsgom par bya'o/ / skye ba dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / 'chi ba la snying rje chen po bskyed par bya'o/ / stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang / smon pa med pa dang / rang bzhin gyis 'dus ma byas pa la dga' ba dang btang snyoms bsgom par bya'o/ / 'jam dpal de lta bas na/ rgyu ni tshad med pa bzhi'o des bskyed pa ni byang chub kyi sems so/ / de'i phyir de la nan tan du yid la bya'o/ /

The Blessed One continued, “Cultivate loving kindness while reflecting on those who are born from the womb, from eggs, and from heat and moisture, and those born miraculously. Generate great compassion focusing on birth, aging, illness, and death. Cultivate joy and equanimity in emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, and the naturally unconditioned. Mañjuśrī, the four immeasurables thus are the cause that produces bodhicitta, so take this earnestly to heart.
'jam dpal de'i phyir sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / o~M b+ho d+hi tsit+ta ut+pa dA ya a haM/ zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
“Furthermore, Mañjuśrī, recite the following mantra: “oṁ bodhicittam utpādaya aham.”[12]
yang bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ mchod pa 'di rnams kyis mchod par bya'o/ /
The Blessed One continued, “You should offer worship with the following offerings:
gang yang phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams bzhugs pa'i/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis byin gyis brlabs pa yi/ / phye ma'i phur ma bdug pa'i bye brag rnams/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod par bya'o/ /
“To the mother who gave birth to the victors I offer dishes of different powdered incenses That have been blessed by the buddhas Who dwell in the worlds of the ten directions.
gang yang phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams bzhugs pa'i/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i yum mchog sangs rgyas spyan/ / me tog sil ma phreng ba'i bye brag rnams/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod par bgyi/ /
“To Buddhalocanā, supreme mother of the tathāgatas[13] Who dwell in the worlds of the ten directions, The mother who gave birth to the victors, I offer flower petals and garlands of every type.
gang yang phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams bzhugs pa'i/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i yum mchog rin po che/ / rin chen mar me'i bye brag phreng ba rnams/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod par bgyi/ /
“To the precious supreme mother of the tathāgatas Who dwell in the worlds of the ten directions, The mother who gave birth to the victors, I offer rows of exquisite lamps.
gang yang phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams bzhugs pa'i/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i yum mchog na bza' dkar/ / dri zhim chu gtsang spos ngad ldang ba'i chu/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod par bgyi/ /
“To Pāṇḍaravāsinī, supreme mother of the tathāgatas Who dwell in the worlds of the ten directions, The mother who gave birth to the victors, I offer the most fragrant water, delicious and pure.
gang yang phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams bzhugs pa'i/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum mchog 'phrin las ldan/ / bza' dang bca' ba la sogs zhal zas rnams/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la dbul bar bgyi/ /
“To the supreme mother who gave birth to the victors Who dwell in the worlds of the ten directions, The mother of the victors who is rich with activity, I offer a feast of food and drink.
sdug bsngal thams cad rab tu zhi mdzad pa'i/ / glu dang rol mo sil snyan bcas pa'i sgra/ / gdugs dang rgyal mtshan ba dan 'phan gdugs bcas/ / phyogs bcu kun nas sprin bzhin gtibs gyur cig /
“May the sounds of song, instruments, and cymbals, Assuaging each and every ill, As well as parasols, banners, flags, and streamers, Fill the ten directions like clouds!
dpag bsam gyis ni shing dag dang / / ljon pa'i shing dang shing dag gis/ / dri zhim lo 'dab bcas pa'i shing / / phyogs bcu kun nas gtibs gyur cig /
“May trees that grant all wishes, Trees rich with fruit, trees fragrant with scent, And trees laden with leaf boughs Cover all of the ten directions!
spos kyi dri ngad ldang ba'i char/ / 'bru dang me tog la sogs pa'i/ / yid du 'ong ba'i dri zhim char/ / nges par kun tu 'bab par shog /
“May rains infused with perfumed fragrance, Rains with the delicious scent Of grains, flowers, and all pleasing things, Pour down regularly in all directions!

'bab chu lteng ka lu ma dang / / mtsho dang rdzing bu dag dang ni/ / ro brgya dag dang ldan pa'i mtsho/ / dad pa la sogs bcas pa yi/ / rin chen khang pa yid 'ong ba'i/ / dra ba dra ba phyed pa dang / / shar nub 'od bcas nyi zla dag dang ni/ / khang pa shin tu yid du 'ong ba rnams/ / rgyal ba bskyed pa'i yum la mchod bya'o/ /

“To the mother who gave birth to the victors, I offer dwellings that delight the mind‍— Exquisite mansions made of jewels Adorned with long and short garlands, With the shining sun and moon in the east and west And with rivers, reservoirs, and ponds, Lakes and pools, And seas of a hundred flavors, All with geese[14] and other birds.”

'jam dpal de'i phyir mchod pa'i sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ /
o~M sarba ta thA ga ta d+hU pe pU dza me g+ha sa mu da s+phar Na sa ma ye hU~M/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta puSh+pa pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra s+pha ra Na sa ma ye hU~M/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta A lo ka pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra spa ra Na sa ma ye hU~M/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta gan d+he pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra s+pha ra Na sa ma ye hU~M/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta nai wi d+ye pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra s+pha ra Na sa ma ya hU~M/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta shap+da pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra spar Na sa ma ye hU~M/ zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, to this end, recite the following offering mantra:
“oṁ sarva-tathāgata-dhūpa-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ. oṁ sarva-tathāgata-puṣpa-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ. oṁ sarva-tathāgata-āloka-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ. oṁ sarva-tathāgata-gandha-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ. oṁ sarva-tathāgata-naivedya-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ. oṁ sarva-tathāgata-śabda-pūjā-megha-samudra-spharaṇa-samaye hūṁ.”[15]
mchod pa'i le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //
This was the second chapter, “Offering.”
[bstod pa]
Chapter 3. Praise

de nas yang 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la gsungs pa/ 'jam dpal yum 'di ni dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyi yum mo/ / 'jam dpal de'i phyir dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyis bstod pa 'di 'jam dpal khyod kyi yid la gyis shig /

The Blessed One again addressed the bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī, “Mañjuśrī, this mother is the mother of all the buddhas of the three times. Therefore, Mañjuśrī, memorize this praise used by all the buddhas of the three times.”
de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bstod pa'i gzungs sngags gsungs pa/
The Blessed One then recited this dhāraṇī-mantra of praise:[16]
na maHsarba ta thA ga tA nAM/ tad+ya thA/ o~M na maHsU ka saM na maH tA rA yai tA ra mi ta/
“namaḥ sarva-tathāgatānāṃ tadyathā oṁ namaḥ sūkasaṃ[17] namaḥ tārāyai tāramātā.[18]
na ma stA re tu re bI rek+Sha Nair+d+yu ti ni b+he k+Sha Ne/ trai lo kya nA thA bak+t+rA p+dza/ bi kA sat+ke sa rod b+ha be/
“namas tāre ture vīre kṣana-dyuti-nibhekṣaṇe.[19] trailokya-nātha-vaktrābja-vikasat-keśarodbhave.
na maHsha ta sa ra ts+tsan+d+ra/ saM pUr+N+Na pa Ta lA na nE/ tA rA sa ha sra ni ka ra/ pra ha sat+ki ra No dz+dz+wa le/
“namaḥ śata-śarac-candra-saṃpūrṇa-paṭalānane tārā-sahasra-nikara-prahasat-kiraṇojjvale.
na maHka na ka nI lAp+dza/ pA Ni pad+ma bi b+hU Shi te/ dA na bIr+ya ta paH shAnati/ ti ti k+Sha d+h+yA na go tsa re/
“namaḥ kanaka-nīlābja-pāṇi-padma-vibhūṣite dāna-vīrya-tapaḥ-śānti-titikṣā-dhyāna-gocare.
na ma sta thA ga toSh+NI Sha/ bi dza yA nan+ta tsA ri Ni/ a she Sha pA ra mi tA prA p+ta/ dzi na pu tra ni se bi te/
“namas tathāgatoṣṇīṣa-vijayānanta-cāriṇi aśeṣa-pāramitā-prāpta-jina-putra-niṣevite.
na ma stu t+tA ra hUM kA ra/ pU ri tA shA de gan+ta re/ sap+ta lo ka kra mA krA n+ti/ niHshe ShA kaR+Sha Na k+Sha me/
“namas tuttāra-hūṁ-kāra-pūritāśā-dig-antare sapta-loka-kramākrānti niḥśeṣākarṣaṇakṣame.
na maH sha krA na la brah+ma/ ma ru dwi shwe shwa rA r+ts+tsi te/ b+hU ta be tA Da gan d+ha rba/ gaNai R+Yak+Sha pU ra skri te/
“namaḥ śakrānala-brahma-marud-viśveśvarārcite bhūta-vetāla-gandharva-gaṇa-yakṣa-puras-kṛte.
na ma s+t+ra Di ti phaT kA ra/ pa ra yan+t+ra pra mar+d+d+ha ni/ pra t+yA lI D+ha pA da n+yA se/ shi khi dz+wa lA gu le k+Sha Ne/
“namas traḍ iti phaṭ-kāra-para-yantra-pramardini pratyālīḍha-pada-nyāse śikhi-jvālākulekṣane.
na mastu re ma hA g+ho re/ mA ra bI ra bi nA sha ne/ b+h+r-i ku TI kr-i ta bAk+t+rAp+dza/ sarba sha truM ni sU da ni/
“namas ture mahā-ghore māra-vīra-vināśane bhṛkuṭī-kṛta-vaktrābja-sarva-śatru-niṣūdani.
na ma s+t+ri rat+na mu drAM ka / hr-i d+yAM gu li bi b+hU Shi te/ b+hU Shi tA she Sha di ka tsa kra / ni kar swa ka rA ku le/
“namas tri-ratna-mudrāṅka-hṛdyāṅguli-vibhūṣite bhūṣitāśeṣa-dik-cakra-nikara-svakarākule.
na maH pra mu di tA To pa/ mu ku TA k+Shi p+ta mA li ni/ ha sat+pa ha sa t+tut+tA re/ mA ra lo ka ba shang+ka ri/
“namaḥ pramuditāṭopa-mukuṭā-kṣipta-mālini hasat-prahasa-tuttāre māra-loka-vaśaṅkari.
na maH sa man+ta b+hU pA la/ paT lA kaR+Sha Na k+Sha me/ tsa lad b+h-i ku Ti hU~M kA ra/ sarbA pa da bi mo tsa ni/
“namaḥ samanta-bhūpāla-paṭalākarṣaṇa-kṣame calad-bhṛkuṭi-hūṁ-kāra-sarvāpada-vimocani.
na maH shi khaN+Da khaN+Den+du/ mu ku TA b+ha ra No dz+dz+wa le/ a mi tA b+ha dza TA b+hA ra/ b+hA swa re kir No d+h+ru be/
“namaḥ śikhaṇḍa-khaṇḍeṇdu-mukuṭābharaṇojjvale amitābha-jaṭābhāra-bhāsure kiraṇa-dhruve.
na maH kalpA n+ta hu ta b+hug / dz+wA lA mA lAn+ta ras+thi te/ A lI D+ha mu di tA ban d+ha/ ri pu tsa kra bi nA sa ni/
“namaḥ kalpānta-hutabhug-jvālā-mālāntara-sthite ālīḍha-muditā-bandha-ripu-cakra-vināśani.
na maH ka ra ta lA g+hA ta/ tsa ra NA ha ta b+hU ta le/ b+h+r-i ku TI kr-i ta hU~M kA ra/ sap+ta pA tA la b+he di ni/
“namaḥ kara-talāghāta-caraṇāhata-bhūtale bhṛkuṭī-kṛta-hūṁ-kāra-sapta-pātāla-bhedini.
na maH shi be shu b+he shAn+te/ shAn+ta ni rbA Na go tsa re swA hA pra Na ba saM yuk+te/ ma hA pA pa ka nA sa ni/
“namaḥ śive śubhe śānte śānta-nirvāṇa-gocare svāhā-praṇava-saṃyukte mahā-pātaka-nāśani.
na maH pra mu di tA ban d+ha/ ri pu gA tra pra b+he di ni/ da shA k+Sha ra pa da n+yA se/ bi d+dzA hU~M kA ra dI pi te/
“namaḥ pramuditābandha-ripu-gātra-prabhedini daśākṣara-pada-nyāse vidyā-hūṁ-kāra-dīpite.
na ma stu re pA da g+hA ta/ hU~M kA rA kA ra bI dzi te/ me ru man+da ra kai lA sa/ b+hu ba na tra ya tsA li ni/
“namas ture padāghāta-hūṁ-kārākāra-bījite meru-mandara-kailāsa-bhuvana-traya-cālini.

'jam dpal gzungs 'di ni dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs shing / dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad skyed pa'i yum sgrol ma lam rungs pa 'joms pa'i sgo nas bstod pa ste/ phan yon ni bsam gyis mi khyab pa'o/ / 'jam dpal de'i phyir brjod par bya'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, this dhāraṇī was blessed by all the buddhas of the three times. It extols Tārā, the mother of all the buddhas of the three times, by vanquishing all evil. Its benefits are inconceivable. Therefore, Mañjuśrī, recite it!

gzungs 'di brjod pa'i gang zag ni sems can dmyal ba dang / yi dgas dang dud 'gro la sogs pa'i gnas su nam yang skye bar mi 'gyur ro/ / yul mtha' 'khob dang kla klo dang / dbang po ma tshang pa la sogs par nam yang skye bar mi 'gyur ro/ / rims dang / 'brum bu dang / nad 'go ba la sogs pa'i nad kyi 'jigs pa thams cad las grol zhing nad kyi 'jigs pa mi 'byung ngo / / 'jigs pa chen po brgyad la sogs pa las grol bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The person who recites this dhāraṇī will never be reborn as a hell being, as a hungry ghost, as an animal, or in any other such miserable state. They will never be reborn in borderlands, as a barbarian, with impaired faculties, or the like. They will be freed from the dangers of fever, boils, infectious diseases, and all other illnesses, and such perils will not reoccur. They will be freed from the eight great dangers and the like.

'jam dpal dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyi bstod pa 'di 'dzin pa'i gang zag de ni/ dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad la mchod pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / 'di 'dzin pa'i gang zag de ni mtshams med pa la sogs pa'i sdig pa ma lus par byang bar 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas thams cad mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / dus ma yin par 'chi ba mi 'byung zhing / nam 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe/ dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad skyed pa'i yum sgrol ma mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di 'dzin pa'i gang zag de ni yid la ci bsams pa thams cad 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / gzugs phun sum tshogs pa dang / kha dog phun sum tshogs pa la sogs pa phun sum tshogs pa thams cad 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / rmi lam ngan pa dang / ltas ngan pa dang / mi ma yin pa'i par du gcod pa thams cad zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / dus gsum gyi bden pa yang mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / yum sgrol ma'i sku dngos su mthong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the person who memorizes this praise used by all the buddhas of the three times makes offerings to all of them. All the acts with immediate retribution and other misdeeds of the person who memorizes this will be purified, and that person will see all the buddhas. They will not meet an untimely death, and, when the time of death comes, they will see Tārā, the mother of all the buddhas of the three times. The person who memorizes this will be able to accomplish whatever they have in mind. They will obtain a perfect body, a perfect complexion, and all other perfect attributes.[23] Nightmares, bad omens,[24] and interference by nonhumans will all be pacified. They will come to see the truth of the three times and behold Tārā’s form in person.

The bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī then asked the Blessed One, “In what way should I earnestly focus on this dhāraṇī-mantra?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ sdug bsngal las grol bar 'dod cing zab mo'i don la mos pas nan tan du bya'o/ / de nas ta~M las byung ba'i 'od zer las steng 'og thams cad du rdo rjer gyur te/ 'jam dpal sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / o~M badzra dz+wa la badzra ta na hU~M phaT/ zhes brjod par bya'o/ / de nas ta~M las byung ba'i yi ge e dkar po bsgom par bya'o/ / de'i steng du ba~M sngon po bsgom par bya'o/ / de'i steng du la~M ser po bsgom par bya'o/ / de'i steng du ya~M ljang gu bsgom par bya'o/ / de'i steng du ra~M dmar po bsgom par bya'o/ / de rnams kyis 'od zer 'phro ba dang bsdu ba bya ste/ o~M d+harma d+hA tu bi shud d+ha hU~M/ o~M aM d+hA tu bi shud d+ha hU~M/ o~M sa man+ta bi shud d+ha hU~M/ o~M prak+Sha ki shud d+ha hU~M/ o~M k+Sha ta bu thA na bi shud d+ha hU~M/ o~M na maHsarba ta thA ga ta maN+Da la sa man+ta pi shud d+ha hU~M/

The Blessed One replied, “You should earnestly focus on this dhāraṇī while wishing to be free of suffering and pursuing the profound. You should then visualize light rays, streaming forth from the syllable tāṁ,[26] that transform everything above and below into vajra. Next, Mañjuśrī, you should recite the mantra oṁ vajra jvala vajra tana hūṁ phaṭ.[27] Then, visualize a white syllable e[28] appearing from tāṁ. Above that, visualize a blue vaṁ,[29] on top of which is a yellow laṁ, on top of which is a green yaṁ, on top of which is a red raṁ. All of these syllables emanate and reabsorb light rays. “oṁ dharmadhātu-viśuddha hūṁ | oṁ aṃ dhātu-viśuddha hūṁ | oṁ samanta-viśuddha hūṁ | oṁ pakṣa-viśuddha[30] hūṁ | oṁ kṣata-vyutthāna[31]-viśuddha hūṁ | oṁ namaḥ sarva-tathāgata-maṇḍala samanta-viśuddha[32] hūṁ.[33]

'jam dpal gyis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das sprul pa la sogs pa rnams ni ji lta bu/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal 'gro ba drug po rnams ni nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa'i khams so/ / de lta bas na sprul pa lta bu dang sgyu ma dang 'ja' tshon dang smig rgyu dang chu zla dang gzugs brnyan lta bur rig par bya'o/ /

Mañjuśrī then asked, “Blessed One, what is meant by ‘apparition’ and so forth?” The Blessed One replied, “Mañjuśrī, being afflicted is the basic constitution of the six classes of beings. Therefore, understand them to be like apparitions, illusions, rainbows, mirages, reflections in water, and images in a mirror.”
lha'i le'u ste bzhi pa'o// //
This was the fourth chapter, “The Deities.”
[dbang bskur ba]
Chapter 5. Initiation

de nas 'jam dpal gyis zhus pa/ bcom ldan 'das lha de lhas ji ltar byin gyis brlab par bya/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal sprul pa lta bu dang sgyu ma lta bu dang 'ja' tshon lta bu dang smig rgyu lta bu dang chu zla lta bu dang gzugs brnyan lta bus so/ / 'jam dpal gyis smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das sprul pa zhes bya ba ji lta bu/

Mañjuśrī then asked, “Blessed One, how are these deities to be empowered by deities?” The Blessed One replied, “In the manner, Mañjuśrī, of apparitions, illusions, rainbows, mirages, reflections in water, and images in a mirror.” Mañjuśrī then asked, “Blessed One, what is an ‘apparition’?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ sprul pa zhes bya ba ni yang dag pa ma yin zhing gnyis ka 'khrul pa'o/ / sgyu ma ni gzhan 'khrul pa'o/ / 'ja' tshon ni stong pa'o/ / smig rgyu ni yul 'khrul cing stod pa'o/ / chu zla ni rgyu 'bras so/ / gzugs brnyan ni dri za'i grong khyer te/ 'jam dpal 'khrul pa ni de bzhin te nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa'i khams kyang de bzhin no/ / 'jam dpal de lta bas na lhas lha la byin gyis rlob pa yang 'dra'o/ /

The Blessed One replied, “An ‘apparition’ is something unreal that is mistaken by both.[38] An ‘illusion’ is something mistaken by others.[39] A ‘rainbow’ is empty. A ‘mirage’ is a mistaken, empty appearance. A ‘reflection in water’ is causal. An ‘image in a mirror’ is like a city of gandharvas. Mañjuśrī, this is delusion; this is the constitution of the afflicted. Therefore, Mañjuśrī, the empowerment of deities by deities is similar to this.

'jam dpal sprul pa dang sgyu ma dang 'ja' tshon dang smig rgyu dang chu zla dang gzugs brnyan ni thogs pa med cing thogs pa dang bral ba'o/ / tha dad pa med cing tha dad pa dang bral ba'o/ / 'jam dpal de'i phyir de'i rang bzhin de dang 'dra bar yid la gyis shig /

“Mañjuśrī, apparitions, illusions, rainbows, mirages, reflections in water, and images in a mirror are unimpeded; they are free of all impediments. They are not differentiated and lack differentiation. Therefore, Mañjuśrī, think of their nature in this way.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis byin gyis brlab pa mdzad pa ni/ lag pa thal mo khong stong du sbyar te/ gung mo gnyis brkyang ste rtse sbyar nas/ mdzub mo gnyis dang srin lag gnyis gung mo la reg ste zur bcag nas mthe'u chungadang mthe bo rtse sprad nas nang sbyar ba ni rdo rje'i phyag rgya'o/ /

The Blessed One then granted empowerment with the vajra mudrā: palms joined so that there is an empty space between them,[40] the two middle fingers raised so that they join at the tips, the two index fingers and two ring fingers pressed against the sides of the middle fingers, and the little fingers and thumbs placed inside with their tips touching.
de'i sngags ni o~M sarba ta tha ga ta a taM a haM badzra sta na sarba ta thA ga ta badzra sta na hU~M zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The mantra to be recited is: oṁ sarva-tathāgata ahaṃ vajras tana sarva-tathāgata-vajras tana hūṁ.[41]

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das kyis dbang bskur bar mdzad pa ni/ lag pa thal mo sbyar te mthe'u chung dang srin lag gnyis phyir bkan te/ gung mo rtse sprad de mthe bos mdzub mo gnyis mnan pa ni rin po che'i phyag rgya ste

Following that, the Blessed One conferred empowerment with the jewel mudrā: hands joined at the palms, the little fingers and ring fingers spread out, the tips of the middle fingers joined, and the thumbs pressing down on the two index fingers.

mgo bo'i steng du bzhag nas sngags brjod pa ni/ o~M sarba ta thA ga ta tsin+tA ma Ni dz+wa la ni sarba ta thA ga ta a haM shud d+ha pa ri shud d+hA ya swA hA/ zhes bya ba'i sngags 'dis phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyis dbang bskur zhing byin gyis brlabs pa'o/ /

Placing his hands above his head, he recited this mantra: “oṁ sarva-tathāgata-cintāmaṇi-jvalani sarva-tathāgata ahaṃ śuddha-pariśuddhāya svāhā.”[42] All buddhas throughout all ten directions conferred initiation and bestowed empowerment with this mantra.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis thugs kyi rigs thams cad kyi dam tshig gi phyag rgya ni lag pA gnyis thal mo sbyar te sor mo rnams phan tshun du so sor bsnol gung mo bsgreng ste/ mthe bong dang mthe'u chung yang gshibs te bsgreng ba ni dam tshig gi phyag rgya ste sngags ni oM sarba ta thA ga ta badzra sa ma ya hU~M zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

Then, the Blessed One formed the samaya mudrā of all the heart families: hands joined at the palms with the fingertips interlaced, middle fingers stretched out, and thumbs and little fingers joined and stretched out. This is the samaya mudrā. The mantra is: oṁ sarva-tathāgata-vajra-samaya hūṁ.[43]
dbang bskur ba'i le'u ste lnga pa'o// //
This was the fifth chapter, “Initiation.”
[sngags]
Chapter 6. Mantras
de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nus gsol pa/
The bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī then spoke these lines of praise for the Mother:

zla ba nyi ma'i sku 'dra ba'i/ / ljang gu'i mdog can 'gying bag can/ / pad+ma zla ba'i steng na bzhugs/ / sangs rgyas thams cad skyed pa'i yum/ / sems can kun gyi skyabs gyur pa'i/ / ut+pal bsnams la phyag 'tshal bstod/ /
ces yum la bstod

“Her moon-and-sun-like form, Green in color and graceful in bearing, Is poised atop a lotus and moon. I salute and praise the mother of all the buddhas And protector of all beings, Who holds an utpala in her hand!”

nas gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das 'di'i gsang sngags ni gang gis 'grub ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'di'i gzungs sngags ni 'di'o/ / oM na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma s+t+rai ya d+h+wa sarba ta thA ga tA nAM na mastA rA yai/ na mastA re tu re bI rAk+Sha Ne d+yu ti ni b+he k+Sha Ne/ trai lo kya na thA bak+t+rA p+dza bi ka shat+ke sa ro da b+ha be/ na maHsha ta sha rats+tsan+d+ra saM pUN+Na pa Ta lA na ne/ tA rA sa ha sra ni ka ra pra ka shat+nyi ra No dz+dz+wa li/ na maHka na ka nI lA p+dza pA Ni pad+ma bi b+hU Sha te/ dA na bIr+ya ta paHshA na ti te ti k+Sha d+h+yA na go tsa re/ na ma sta thA ga toSh+NI Sha bi dza yA nan+ta tsa ri/ a she Sha pa ra mi tA prA p+ta dzi na pu tre Na se bi te tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ / gzungs sngags ni 'di'o/ /

He then asked, “Blessed One, how is the mantra of the Mother practiced? The Blessed One replied, “Her dhāraṇī-mantra is as follows: “oṁ namo ratna-trayāya | namas traiyadhva-sarva-tathāgatānāṃ namas tārāyai. “namas tāre ture vīre kṣaṇa-dyuti-nibhekṣane trailokya-nātha-vaktrābja-vikasat-keśarodbhave. “namaḥ śata-śarac-candra-sampūrṇa-paṭalānane tārā-sahasra-nikara-prahasat-kiraṇojjvale. “namaḥ kanaka-nīlābja-pāṇi-padma-vibhūṣite dāna-vīrya-tapaḥ-śānti-titikṣā-dhyāna-gocare. “namas tathāgatoṣṇīṣa-vijayānanta-cāriṇi aśeṣa-pāramitā-prāpta-jina-putra-niṣevite. “tāre tuttāre ture svāhā. “That is the dhāraṇī-mantra you should recite.
snying po ni 'di'o/ / oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ /
“The heart mantra is: “oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.
oM tut+tA re tu re tu re swA hA/ pad+ma'i rigs kyi snying po'o/ /
“The heart mantra for the lotus family is: “oṁ tuttāre ture ture svāhā.
oM tA re tu re tu re swA hA/ rin po che'i rigs kyi snying po'o/ /
“The heart mantra for the jewel family is: “oṁ tāre ture ture svāhā.
oM tu re tut+tA re swA hA/ las kyi rigs kyi snying po'o/ /
“The heart mantra for the karma family is: “oṁ ture tuttāre svāhā.
oM tA re tut+tA re tA re swA hA/ rdo rje'i rigs kyi snying po'o/ /
“The heart mantra for the vajra family is: “oṁ tāre tuttāre tāre svāhā.
oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ las sna tshogs pa'i snying po'o/ /
“The heart mantra for the various rites is: “oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.
oM tA re tA re tut+tA re hU~M kA ra pU ri tA sha di gan+ta res p+ta lo ka tra mA trAn ti/ a she ShA kar+Sha k+Sha mi hIH dbang du bsdu ba'i sngags so/ /
“The mantra for enthralling is: “oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre hūṁ-kāra-pūritāśā-dig-antare | sapta-loka-kramākrānti[44] | aśeṣākarṣaṇa-kṣami hrīḥ.
oM tA re tA re tut+tA re hU~M swA hA/ kA ra pu ri tA shA di gan+ta re sap+ta lo kak+kA mA krAM ti a she Sha pun+TiM ku ru kar+Sha Nak+Sha mi ho/ /
“The mantra for increasing is: “oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre hūṁ svāhā-kāra-pūritāśā-dig-antare | sapta-loka-kramākrānti aśeṣa-puṣṭiṃ kuru ākarṣaṇa-kṣami ho.
rgyas pa'i sngags so/ / oM tA re tA re tut+tA re hU~M kA ra pU ri tA shA di gaM ta ri sap+ta lo ka krA mA krA na ti uSh+NI Sha a li ka ra yA kar+Sha Na k+Sha mi phaT/ de ni las kyi sngags so/ /
“The mantra for rites is: “oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre hūṁ-kāra-pūritāśā-dig-antare | sapta-loka-kramākrānti uṣṇīṣa alikaraya-[45] ākarṣaṇa-kṣami phaṭ.
oM tA re tA re tut+tA re tu re hU~M kA rA bu ri tA shA di gaM tsa ris b+ha lo ka krA mA krA nA ti niH a she Sha shAn+tiM ku ru kA r+Sha Na k+Sha mi swA hA/ klu zhi ba'i sngags so/ /
“The mantra for pacifying nāgas is: “oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre ture hūṁ-kāra-pūritāśā-dig-antare[46] | sapta-loka-krāmākrānti aśeṣa-śāntiṃ kuru-ākarṣaṇa-kṣami svāhā.[47]

oM tA re tA re tu re tut+tA re swA hA/ sha krA na la bra h+ma ru drai sh+tse shwa rA rtsi te b+hU ta be tA la gaM dar ba ga Na yak+Sha pu ra skr-i te phaT kA ra yan+t+ra pra marda ni pra t+yA lI D+ta pA da n+yA sa shi khi dz+wA lA ku li dza li ri ma hA hro ri mA ra bIr bi nA sha ni/ b+h+r-i ku Ti kr-i ta bA ka trA p+dza sarba sha tru ni sU da ni rat+na mu drAM ka hr-i d+yAM gu li bi b+hU Shi t+ya p+hU Shi tA she Sha di ka tsakra kA ra sau ka rA ku li hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT phaT phaT/ las sna tshogs pa'i sngags so/ /

“The mantra for the various rites is: “oṁ tāre tāre ture tuttāre svāhā. “śakrānala-brahma-rudraiś ceśvarārcite bhūta-vetāla-gandharva-gaṇa-yakṣa-puras-kṛte. “phaṭ-kāra-parayantra-pramardani pratyālīḍha-pada-nyāsa-śikhi-jvālākulekṣaṇe.[48] “mahā-ghori māra-vīra-vināśani bhṛkuṭī-kṛta-vāktrābja-sarva-śatru-niṣūdani. “ratna-mudrāṅka-hṛdyāṅguli-vibhūṣite bhūṣitāśeṣa[49]-dik-cakra-nikara[50]-sva-karākule. “hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ.

oM i n+tsA ya/ ya mA ya/ ba ru NA ya/ yak+ShA ya/ ag+n+nA ya/ bA ya be/ nai ri t+yai rak+Sha se/ oM in+d+ra pA lA ya/ sU r+yA ya tsan+t+rA ya/ u ti a ya bu mi ye/ a kA ro mu khaM sarba d+harmA NAM/ Ad+ya nu t+pan+na twA ta oM AHhU~M phaT swA hA/ zhes bya ba ni las thams cad grub pa'i sngags so/ /

“The mantra for accomplishing all rites is: “oṁ indrāya | yamāya | varuṇāya | yakṣāya | agnaye | vāyave | nairṛtyai rakṣase. || “oṁ indra-pālāya | sūryāya candrāya | udaya-bhūmaye[51] | a-kāro mukhaṃ sarva-dharmānām | ādyanutpannatvāt oṁ āḥ hūṁ phaṭ svāhā.”[52]
