This was the sixth chapter, “Mantra.”
[zhi ba'i las]
Chapter 7. The Pacifying Rite

'jam dpal las ni 'di'o/ / spos kyi khang pa yid du 'ong bar dri zhim po'i chag chag btab ste/ maN+Dal dkar po tsan+dan dkar po'i chus byugs la me tog sil ma gtor te/ bum pa dkar po rin po che las byas pa'i nang du rin po che lnga ni/ gser dang mu tig dang man shel dang byi ru dang mu men gzhug par bya'o/ / spos lnga ni tsan+dan dang a ga ru dang du ru ska dang ga pur dang pu shel tse gzhug par bya'o/ / 'bru lnga ni nas dang gro dang sran ma dang 'bras dang til mar gzhug par bya'o/ / snying po lnga ni bu ram dang sbrang rtsi dang mar dang lan tshwa dang til gzhug par bya'o/ / gtsang ma'i ras kha tshar mnyams pas dkris te dbus su gzhag go/ / gang ba'i bum pa bzhi yang gzhag par bya'o/ / pog phor bzhi dang me tog la sogs pa bzhi yang gzhag par bya'o/ / de ltar rdzogs pas 'di bsam gtan du bya'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the pacifying rite is as follows. Sprinkle scented water in a shrine chamber, arrange a white maṇḍala there, anoint it with water infused with white sandalwood,[53] and scatter flower petals over it. In a white[54] vase made of precious materials, place the five precious substances comprising gold, pearl, crystal, coral, and sapphire; the five types of incense comprising sandalwood, aloeswood, frankincense, camphor, and vetiver; the five types of grain comprising barley, wheat, pulses, rice, and sesame oil; and the five essences comprising molasses, honey, butter, salt, and sesame seeds. Wrap the vase in a clean piece of cloth that has its fringe intact and place it in the center. Arrange a further four full vases, as well as four incense burners, four sets of flowers, and so on. Having completed these preparations, meditate as follows.

yi ge ta~M las byung ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i yum sgrol ma dpa' mo rnal 'byor ma'i lus su bsgom pa ni/ pad+ma rgyas pa las byung zhing zla ba rgyas pa la bzhugs pa sku mdog ston ka'i zla ba ltar dkar ba gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa lta bu'i sku do shal dang dpung rgyan dang rin po che'i chun 'phyang la sogs pas mdzes par brgyan pa/ pany+tsa li ka'i gos kyis smad dkris pa ka shi ka'i ras kyis stod g.yogs pa skyil krung phyed pa dang bcas pa zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa zhal 'dzum zhing spyan 'khyug pa/ phyag g.yas pa mchog sbyin mdzad pa/ g.yon pa ut+pa la sdong bu dang bcas pa 'dzin pa/ sku las 'od zer 'phro zhing pad+ma dkar po ge sar dang bcas pa'i dkyil na bdud rtsi'i rgyun sku las 'od zer 'phro ba can du byang chub sems dpa' dpag tu med pa dang bcas pa bsams te bzlas pa 'di bya'o/ / o~M tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ /

“Visualize the heroine Tārā, the mother rich in diligence who takes the form of a yoginī, emerging from the syllable tāṁ. She springs from a blossoming lotus and sits on a full moon disk. Her body is white like the autumn moon, she is in the prime of youth, and she is beautifully adorned with a long necklace, armlets, jewel tassels, and other ornaments. She wears a skirt made of Pañcāla cloth and a top made of silk from Kāśī. She is seated in the half-lotus posture, has one face and two hands, and smiles with darting eyes. Her right hand is in the boon-granting gesture, and her left holds an utpala flower by the stem. Light rays stream from her body, and amṛta flows down from the center of the white lotus and its anthers. She is accompanied by countless bodhisattvas, whose bodies also emit light. As you imagine this, recite the following mantra: “oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.
de nas las kyi sngags dang bcas pa la ni gcig gam/ bdun nam/ nyi shu rtsa gcig gam/ brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas/ gsol ba btab na 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /
“If you then recite this together with the mantra for the rite, either one, seven, twenty-one, or one hundred and eight times, and make a request, it will be fulfilled.

'jam dpal de'i phan yon ni mtshams med pa lnga dang de dang nye ba lnga dang sdang ba dang rmi lam ngan pa thams cad zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / 'jam dpal de'i phan yon ni ngan song gsum gyi sdug bsngal zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / mi khom pa brgyad du nam yang skye bar mi 'gyur ro/ / 'jam dpal 'di'i phan yon ni tshe rabs dran pa dang dbang po gsal ba dang yid gzhungs par 'gyur ro/ / bzo'i gnas thams cad la mkhas par 'gyur ro/ / stobs dang mdangs dang gzi mdangs phun sum tshogs par 'gyur ro/ / 'jig rten skyong ba thams cad kyis srung ba dang skyob pa dang sbed pa dang phan par byed de/ gang du phyin pa thams cad du bkra shis par 'gyur ro/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that the five acts with immediate retribution, the five secondary acts with immediate retribution, and all hostility and nightmares will be pacified. Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that the suffering of the three lower realms will be pacified, and you will never again be reborn in any of the eight unfree states. Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that you will come to remember your past lives, have lucid faculties, be intelligent, and become expert in all arts and crafts. You will be endowed with perfect strength, complexion, and charisma. All the worldly protectors will watch over you, protect you, conceal you, and assist you. Wherever you go, everything will be auspicious.”
zhi ba'i las kyi le'u ste bdun pa'o// //
This was the seventh chapter, “The Pacifying Rite.”
[rgyas pa'i las]
Chapter 8. The Increasing Rite

'jam dpal rgyas pa'i las 'di'o/ / spos kyi khang pa dri zhim pa dang ldan pa'i gnas su ba ser skya'i rnam lngas skyong nul bya ste dri zhim pos byugs pa'i maN+Dal bya'o/ / me tog gi tshom bu yang dgram par bya'o/ / rgyas pa las byung ba'i thang ka yang dgram par bya'o/ / rin po che rnam pa lnga dang 'bru dang sman la sogs pa dag la ril bu nyi shu rtsa gcig bya ste/ rin po che'i ga 'ur bcug la maN+Dal gyi dbus su gzhag par bya'o/ / pog phor bzhi yang gzhag par bya'o/ / me tog la sogs pa yang gzhag par byas nas bsam gtan bsgom par bya ste/

“Mañjuśrī, the rite for increasing is as follows. Smear the floor of a shrine chamber with the five substances of a red-brown cow and arrange a maṇḍala anointed with scented water. Pile heaps of flowers on it and set out an illustration for the increasing rite. Prepare twenty-one pills made from the five precious substances, grains, medicinal substances, and so on, place them in an amulet made of precious materials, and set the amulet in the center of the maṇḍala. Also arrange four incense burners, flowers, and so on. Then, cultivate the following meditation.

yi ge ta~M las bskyed pa'i myur ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i yum sgrol ma dpa' mo gcig ma rnal 'byor ma'i lus su bsgom pa ni pad+ma rgyas pa las byung zhing nyi zla'i steng du rgyas pa'i sku ston ka'i zla ba ltar gsal ba sprin dang bral ba'i nyi ma lta bur gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa lta bu'i sku mdog ser po do shal dang dpung rgyan dang rin po che'i chun 'phyang la sogs pas mdzes par brgyan pa/ pany+tsa li ka'i gos kyis smad dkris pa/ ka shi ka'i ras kyis stod g.yogs pa skyil krung phyed pa dang bcas pa zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa zhal 'dzum zhing spyan 'khyug pa/ phyag g.yas pa mchog sbyin mdzad pa/ g.yon pa ut+pa la sdong pu dang bcas pa 'dzin pa sku las 'od 'phro zhing pad+ma'i ge sar dang bcas pa'i dkyil na bdud rtsi'i rgyun sku las 'od 'phro ba lha'i tshogs dang lha ma yin gyi tshogs dang nam mkha' lding gi tshogs dang mi 'am ci'i tshogs dang mi'i tshogs dang dri za'i tshogs dang lto 'phye chen po'i tshogs dang srin po la sogs pa'i stobs zil gyis gnon pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dpag tu med pa dang bcas pa bsgom ste bzlas pa 'di bya'o/ / oM tA re tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas pa bya'o/ /

“Visualize the single heroine[55] Tārā, the mother rich in swift diligence who takes the form of a yoginī, emerging from the syllable tāṁ. She springs from a blossoming lotus and sits upon a full moon disk. Her extensive body is yellow in color, radiant like the autumn moon, and aglow with youthfulness like the sun unobscured by clouds. She is beautifully adorned with a long necklace, armlets, jewel tassels, and other ornaments. She wears a skirt made of Pañcāla cloth and a top made of silk from Kāśī. She is seated in the half-lotus posture, has one face and two hands, and smiles with darting eyes. Her right hand is in the boon-granting gesture, while her left holds an utpala flower by the stem. Light rays stream from her body, and amṛta flows down from the center of the lotus and its anthers. She is accompanied by countless bodhisattvas, who emit light from their bodies and overcome the power of the throngs of gods, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, humans,[56] gandharvas, mahoragas, and rākṣasas. Visualizing this, recite the following mantra: “oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.
de nas las kyi sngags dang bcas pas lan gcig gam bdun nam nyi shu rtsa gcig gam brgya rtsa brgyad brjod nas/ gsol ba btab na 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /
“If you then recite it together with the mantra for the rite, either one, seven, twenty-one, or one hundred and eight times, and make a request, it will be fulfilled.

'jam dpal de'i phan yon ni lha'i tshogs dang lha ma yin gyi tshogs dang nam mkha' lding gi tshogs dang mi'am ci'i tshogs dang / mi'i tshogs dang dri za'i tshogs dang lto 'phye chen po'i tshogs dang / srin po'i tshogs thams cad kyis de'i stobs thub par mi 'gyur la/ srung ba dang skyob pa yang byed par 'gyur ro dus ma yin par 'chi ba dang / rtsod pa dang / rmi lam ngan pa dang / ltas ngan pa dang / rims dang / 'brum bu dang / g.yan pa la sogs pas mi tshugs so/ / nam 'chi ba'i tshe yang stobs dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / ngan song gsum du mi 'gyur ro/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this rite are such that even the throngs of gods, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, humans, gandharvas, mahoragas, and rākṣasas will be unable to withstand its power. Rather, they will guard and protect you. You will remain unharmed by untimely death, conflict, nightmares, bad omens, fever, boils, infectious diseases, and the like. Even at the time of death, you will remain strong, and you will not be reborn in the lower realms.
'jam dpal las des yo byad dang tshe dang bkrag dang stobs dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong ba dang stobs dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ /
“Mañjuśrī, through this rite you will acquire all necessary goods, longevity, vibrancy,[57] and strength. You will come to see the tathāgatas and be imbued with strength.”[58]
rgyas pa'i las kyi le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //
This was the eighth chapter, “The Increasing Rite.”
[dbang gi las]
Chapter 9. The Enthralling Rite

'jam dpal dbang du bsdu ba'i las ni 'di'o/ / dur khrod dam shing gcig gam/ chu bo chen po'i 'gram mam gtsug lag khang du bya'o/ / khang pa der ba'i rnam lngas skyong nul byas te dri zhim pos byugs pa'i maN+Dal me tog sil ma dgram par bya'o/ / yum gyi sku gzugs kyang bzhugs te pog phor dang me tog la sogs pa yang bsham par bya'o/ / me tog dang 'bras bu nus pa dang ldan pa'i rdzas dag rin po che'i ga 'ur bcug la maN+Dal gyi dbus su gzhag par bya'o/ / de nas bsam gtan bsgom pa ni/

“Mañjuśrī, the rite for enthralling is as follows. Practice this rite in a charnel ground, by a lone tree, on the bank of a large river, or in a temple. Smear the site with the five substances from a cow, and scatter flower petals over the maṇḍala that has been anointed with fragrant water. Arrange an image of the Mother, together with incense burners, flowers, and so forth. Fill an amulet made of precious materials with flowers, fruits, and other potent substances, and install it in the center of the maṇḍala. Then cultivate the following meditation.

tA~M las byung ba'i myur ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i yum sgrol ma dpa' mo rnal 'byor ma'i lus su bsgom pa ni pad+ma las byung zhing nyi zla'i steng na sku mdog ban+du ka'i me tog ltar dmar ba gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa lta bu'i sku do shal dang dpung rgyan dang rin po che'i chun 'phyang la sogs pas mdzes par brgyan pa/ pany+tsa li ka'i gos kyis smad dkris pa/ ka shi ka'i ras kyis stod g.yogs pa/ 'gying bag gi tshul gyis bzhengs pa/ zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa zhal bzhad cing cher bzhad pa spyan 'khyug pa phyag g.yas thugs ka na 'dud pa/ g.yon sdong bu dang bcas pa'i ut+pa la 'dzin pa/ sku las 'od 'phro ba dang bcas pa las rang dang mthun pa'i 'od 'khrug pa dang bcas pa'i sku byang chub sems dpa' dpag tu med pa lha mo dpag tu med pa dang bcas pa bsam ste bzlas pa 'di bya'o/ / oM tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ /

“Visualize the heroine Tārā, the mother rich in swift diligence who takes the form of a yoginī, emerging from the syllable tāṁ. She springs from a blossoming lotus and sits upon sun and moon disks.[59] Her body is red in color like the bandhūka flower and is in the prime of youth. She is beautifully adorned with a long necklace, armlets, jewel tassels, and other ornaments. She wears a skirt of Pañcāla cloth and a top made of silk from Kāśī. She stands with a graceful poise, has one face and two hands, smiles, and laughs with darting eyes. Her right hand is at her heart in a gesture of reverence, and her left hand holds an utpala flower by the stem. Her body radiates light, and from this light appear countless bodhisattvas together with countless goddesses,[60] all vividly aglow with a flurry of light like her own. While visualizing this, recite the following mantra: “oṁ tuttāre ture svāhā.
de nas las kyi sngags dang bcas pa lan gcig gam bdun nam nyi shu rtsa gcig gam brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas gsol ba btab na 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /
“If you then recite this together with the mantra for the rite, either one, seven, twenty-one, or one hundred and eight times, and make a request, it will be fulfilled.
'jam dpal de'i phan yon ni sa bdag gi rgyal po la sogs pa 'jig rten gsum po thams cad dbang du 'gyur ro/ / thams cad khugs par 'gyur ro/ /
“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that you will enthrall the entire threefold universe, including the lords of the earth, and have the ability to bring everything under your control.”
dbang gi las kyi le'u ste dgu pa'o// //
This was the ninth chapter, “The Enthralling Rite.”
[drag po'i phrin las]
Chapter 10. The Aggressive Rite

'jam dpal drag po'i las bya bar 'dod pas gnas ni dur khrod dam shing gcig gam chu bo chen po'i 'gram mam gtsug lag khang du bya'o/ / khang pa der ba'i rnam lngas chag chag btab ste dri zhim po'i chus maN+Dal bya'o/ / sku gzugs la sogs pa yang dgram par bya'o/ / gro ga'am ras sam shing shun la rgyal po la sogs pa'i gzugs nim pa'i chus bris la maN+Dal gyi steng du kham pa'i ga 'ur gzhug par bya'o/ / de nas maN+Dal gyi steng du gzhag par bya'o/ / pog phor la sogs pa'i mchod pa yang bsham par bya'o/ / de nas bsam gtan bsgom par bya ste

“Mañjuśrī, if you wish to perform the aggressive rite you should do so in a charnel ground, by a lone tree, on the bank of a large river, or in a temple. Sprinkle the site with the five substances from a cow, arrange a maṇḍala anointed with fragrant water, set out an image, and so forth. Use neem water to draw an image of the king or other patron on birch bark, cloth, or other kind of bark, put the drawing inside a clay amulet atop the maṇḍala, and set the amulet on the maṇḍala. In addition, arrange incense burners and other offerings. Cultivate the following meditation.

yi ge ta~M las bskyed pa'i myur ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i yum sgrol ma dpa' mo rnal 'byor ma'i lus su bsgom pa ni pad+ma rgyas pa las byung zhing nyi zla'i steng na bzhugs pa sku mdog ljang gu kun nas gsal ba gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa lta bu'i sku do shal dang dpung rgyan dang rin po che'i chun 'phyang la sogs pas mdzes par brgyan pa/ pany+tsa li ka'i gos kyis smad dkris pa ka shi ka'i gos kyis stod g.yogs pa zhabs g.yas brkyang ba g.yon bskum pas bzhugs pa zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa zhal mche ba gtsigs pa spyan ni rab tu 'bar zhing dbu skra gyen du brdzes pa dbu'i zla ba'i steng na a mi tA b+ha dang bcas pa bskal pa'i me dpung nang na bzhugs pa phyag g.yas na 'khor lo 'dzin pa g.yon sdigs mdzub dang bcas pa'i ut+pa la sdong bu dang bcas pa 'dzin pa/ sku las khro bo 'phro ba khro mo dpag tu med pa dang lhan cig tu'o/ / de'i bzlas pa ni 'di'o/ / oM tu re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ /

“Visualize the heroine Tārā, the mother rich in swift diligence who appears in the form of a yoginī, emerging from the syllable tāṁ. She springs from a blossoming lotus and sits upon sun and moon disks.[61] Her body is green, radiant, and in the prime of youth. She is beautifully adorned with a long necklace, armlets, jewel tassels, and other ornaments. She wears a skirt of Pañcāla cloth and a top made of silk from Kāśī. She is seated with her right leg outstretched and her left leg drawn in, has one face and two hands, and bares her teeth with her eyes ablaze. Her hair streams upward, Amitābha sits on a moon disk above her head, and she is surrounded by apocalyptic fire. In her right hand she holds a wheel, and with her left she makes the threatening gesture while holding an utpala flower by the stem. Countless wrathful beings, both male and female, radiate from her body. The mantra recitation is: “oṁ ture tuttāre ture svāhā.
de nas las kyi sngags dang bcas pa lan gcig gam bdun nam nyi shu rtsa gcig gam brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas shing nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum bzlas nas gsol ba btab na 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“If you then recite it together with the mantra for the rite either one, seven, twenty-one, or one hundred and eight times, three times a day and three times a night, and make a request, it will be fulfilled.

'jam dpal 'di'i phan yon ni nyon mongs pa dang las dang rnam par smin pa dang ngan song la sogs pa thams cad 'joms pa'o/ / 'jam dpal ma rungs pa'i dgra dang gdon dang bgegs la sogs pa thams cad 'joms par 'gyur ro/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that afflictions, karma, karmic ripening, rebirth in lower realms, and so on will all be overcome. Mañjuśrī, vicious enemies, māras, obstructers, and other such harmful influences will also all be overcome.”
drag po'i phrin las kyi le'u ste bcu pa'o// //
This was the tenth chapter, “The Aggressive Rite.”
[phrin las sna tshogs]
Chapter 11. The Rite for All Activities

'jam dpal phrin las sna tshogs pa'i las ni 'di'o/ / dur khrod dam shing gcig gam mchod rten gyi mdun nam chu bo chen po'i 'gram du las bya'o/ / khang pa der ba'i rnam lngas skyong nul bya ste/ dri zhim pos byugs pa'i maN+Dal la me tog sil ma dgram par bya'o/ / yum gyi sku gzugs kyang bzhugs te/ sbra tshil las byas pa'i gzugs kyi snying gar dur khrod kyi ras la sngags bcu pa dang gsal ba'i yi ge gnyis dang bcas pa la ming gi yi ge mtha' dang bcas pa bcug ste/ maN+Dal gyi dbus su gzhag par bya'o/ / pog por dang me tog la sogs pa yang gzhag par byas nas/ de nas bsam gtan bsgom pa ni

“Mañjuśrī, the rite that can be used for all activities is as follows. It should be performed in a charnel ground, by a lone tree, before a stūpa, or on the bank of a large river. Smear the site with the five substances from a cow, scatter flower petals over a maṇḍala that has been anointed with fragrant water, and set out an image of the Mother. At the heart of a wax effigy, insert a piece of charnel-ground shroud inscribed with the ten-syllable mantra[62] and the two sets of syllables[63] appended with the target’s name, and place the effigy in the center of the maṇḍala. In addition, arrange incense burners, flowers, and so on. Then cultivate the following meditation.

ta~M las byung ba'i myur ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan pa'i sku/ yum sgrol ma dpa' mo rnal 'byor pa'i lus su bsgom pa ni/ pad+ma las byung zhing nyi zla'i steng na sku mdog nag po shin tu 'tsher ba gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa lta bu'i sku do shal dang dpung rgyan dang rin po che'i chun 'phyang la sogs pas mdzes par brgyan pa/ pany+tsa li ka'i gos kyis smad dkris pa ka shi ka'i gos kyis stod g.yogs byas pa zhabs brkyang bskum du bzhugs pa zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa mche ba zla ba phyed pa lta bu gcigs pa zhal khro gnyer hU~M sgra dang bcas pa dbu skra dmar ser gyen du phyogs pa dbu la zla ba'i steng na a mi tA b+ha bzhugs pa/ bskal pa'i me dpung dang bcas pa'i 'od las 'jigs pa brgyad las bsrung ba'i lha mo brgyad 'phro ba phyag g.yas na gri gug 'dzin cing g.yon pa sdong bu dang bcas pa'i ut+pa la'i steng na me tog gis bkang ba'i bram ze'i thod pa can 'dzin pa khro bo'i tshogs dang bcas pa bsgom par bya'o/ / sngags ni 'di bzlas par bya'o/ / oM tA re tu re tut+tA re swA hA/ zhes bzlas par bya'o/ /

“Visualize the heroine Tārā, the mother rich in swift diligence who appears in the form of a yoginī, emerging from the syllable tāṁ. She springs from a blossoming lotus and sits upon sun and moon disks. Her body is black, gleaming, and in the prime of youth. She is beautifully adorned with a long necklace, armlets, jewel tassels, and other ornaments. She wears a skirt of Pañcāla cloth and a top made of silk from Kāśī. She is seated with one leg outstretched and the other drawn in, and she has one face and two hands. Baring her fangs in a shape like a crescent moon, her face is drawn in a frown, and she resounds with hūṁ. Her orange hair rises from her head, above which sits Amitābha upon a moon disk. She is surrounded by apocalyptic fires from which emanate the eight goddesses that grant protection from the eight dangers. In her right hand she holds a curved knife, and in her left she holds an utpala flower by the stem, on top of which is a brahmin’s skull filled with flowers. She is surrounded by a horde of wrathful deities. Visualizing this, recite the following mantra: “oṁ tāre ture tuttāre svāhā.
de nas las kyi sngags dang bcas pa lan gcig gam bdun nam nyi shu rtsa gcig gam/ brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas gsol btab nas 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“If you then recite it together with the mantra for the rite either one, seven, twenty-one, or one hundred and eight times, three times a day and three times a night, and make a request, it will be fulfilled.
'jam dpal 'di'i phan yon ni phrin las bzhi 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / 'jigs pa las bsrung bar 'gyur ro/ /
“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that all four activities will be accomplished, and you will be protected from all danger.”
phrin las sna tshogs kyi le'u ste bcu gcig pa'o// //
This was the eleventh chapter, on the rite for all activities.
[rdo rje rigs kyi yum]

d.crumb: 12. The Mother of the Vajra Family

f.d: Chapter 12. The Mother of the Vajra Family

de nas yang bcom ldan 'das la sangs rgyas thams cad bskyed pa'i yum ni rigs lnga'i bdag nyid kyi yum ji ltar lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal rdo rje rigs kyi yum ni zhal bzhi ma phyag brgyad ma dung gi mdog can gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa/ zhal dkar ba dang gnag pa dang dmar ba dang ser po'i zhal bzhi'o/ / rigs lngas dbu la mtshan pa spyan gsum pa'o/ / phyag brgyad ni rdo rje dang mda' dang mdung thung dang tha ma la mchog sbyin gyi phyag rgya'o/ / ut+pa la dang gzhu dang rdo rje lcags kyu dang zhags pa dang sdigs mdzub ni g.yon pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / rdo rje skyil krung gis bzhugs shing chos sku'i rang bzhin can no/ /

Mañjuśrī again asked the Blessed One, “How is the mother who gives birth to all buddhas also the mother who is the essential identity of the five families?” The Blessed One explained, “Mañjuśrī, the mother of the vajra family has four faces and eight hands, is the color of a conch, and is in the prime of youth. Her four faces are white, black, red, and yellow. Her head is marked by the five families, and she has three eyes. Her four right hands hold a vajra, an arrow, and a short spear,[64] while the lowermost hand is in the boon-granting gesture. In her left hands she holds an utpala flower, a bow, and a vajra hook, and she wields a lasso while making the threatening gesture. She sits in the vajra posture and is of dharmakāya nature.

'jam dpal de'i sngags ni 'di'o/ / na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya dz+nyA na sA ga rA ya/ a k+Sho b+h+yaH byu ha rA dzA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ aR+ha te b+h+yaH saM myaka saM bud+d+hA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ po d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ oM tA re tu re tut+tA re swA hA/ zhes brjod pas rdo rje'i rigs thams cad kyis me tog dang mar me dang dri chab dang bshos gtsang gis mchod do/ /

“Mañjuśrī, this is her mantra: “namo ratna-trayāya | nama ārya-jñāna-sāgarāya | akṣobhya-vyūha-rājāya | tathāgatāya | arhate samyak-sambuddhāya | nama āryāvalokiteśvarāya | bodhisattvāya | mahāsattvāya | mahā-kāruṇikāya | tadyathā | oṁ tāre ture tuttāre svāhā.[65] “With this, the entire vajra family makes offerings of flowers, lamps, scented water, and fine foods.

'jam dpal de'i las ni 'di'o/ / spra tshil las gang la bya ba'i gzugs byas te/ skrod pa'i rdzas ni bya rog dang hu lu'i sha ming dang bcas pa'i snying gar bcug nas sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / oM a mu kaM me ba sham na ya swA hA/

“Mañjuśrī, her rite is as follows. Mold a wax effigy of whoever is the target, and insert into the effigy’s heart the expelling substances‍—the flesh of a crow and owl[66]‍—together with the name, and then recite this mantra: “oṁ amukam me vaśam ānaya svāhā.[67]
zhes brjod nas rlung gi phyogs su spas na 'jam dpal 'thab cing 'byer bar 'gyur te gzhan du 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
“If you recite this and then hide the effigy in the northwest, Mañjuśrī, the target will meet with conflict and division and flee elsewhere.”
rdo rje rigs kyi yum gyi le'u ste bcu gnyis pa'o// //
This was the twelfth chapter, “The Mother of the Vajra Family.”
[pad+ma rigs kyi yum]

d.crumb: 13. The Mother of the Lotus Family

f.d: Chapter 13. The Mother of the Lotus Family

'jam dpal pad+ma'i rigs kyi yum ni zhal bzhi pa phyag brgyad pa/ rtsa ba'i zhal ni dmar mo ban+du ka'i me tog gi mdog can gyi sku gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa g.yas zhal dkar po/ g.yon zhal nag po rgyab zhal ser po rigs bzhis dbu la mtshan pa spyan gsum pa'o/ / phyag brgyad na pad+ma dang mda' dang mdung dang tha ma mchog sbyin gyi phyag rgya'o/ / ut+pa la gzhu dang rdo rje lcags kyu dang zhags pa dang sdigs mdzub ni g.yon pa'i phyag rgya'o/ / rdo rje skyil mo krung gis bzhugs shing chos sku'i rang bzhin can no/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the mother of the lotus family has four faces and eight hands. Her main face is red like a bandhūka flower, as is her youthful body. Her right face is white, her left face black, and her rear face yellow. Each is marked on its crown with the four families and has three eyes. In her right hands she holds a lotus, an arrow, and a spear, while the lowermost hand is in the boon-granting gesture. In her left hands she holds an utpala flower, a bow, and a vajra hook, and she wields a lasso while making the threatening gesture. She sits in the vajra posture and is of dharmakāya nature.

'jam dpal de'i sngags ni 'di'o/ / na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya dz+nyA na sA ga rA ya/ a mi ta b+ha de ba byu ha rA dzA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ aR+ha te b+h+yaH saM myaki saM bud+d+hA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/ oM tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes brjod pas pad+ma'i rigs thams cad kyis me tog dang bdug spos dang mar me dang dri chab dang zhal zas kyis mchod do/ /

“Mañjuśrī, this is her mantra: “namo ratna-trayāya | nama ārya-jñāna-sāgarāya | amitābha-deva-vyūha-rājāya | tathāgatāya | arhate samyak-sambuddhāya | nama āryāvalokiteśvarāya | bodhisattvāya | mahāsattvāya | mahā-kāruṇikāya | tadyathā | oṁ tuttāre ture svāhā.[68] “With that, the entire lotus family makes offerings of flowers, incense, lamps, scented water, and foods.

'jam dpal de'i las ni 'di'o/ / d+ha du ra dang nim pa dang mya ngan 'tshang gis me tog btags te phye ma sbrang rtsi dang lde gu byas nas sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / oM a mu ka a mi ta naM ku mA ri ma hA mu ri dra ba te na da s+ya pi ta ba yats+tsha tu hU~M hrIH/

“Mañjuśrī, her rite is as follows. Grind datura, neem, and aśoka flowers, use honey to make the powder into an ointment with honey, and then recite this mantra: “oṁ amukābhidhānāṃ kumārīm mahyam udvāhena tasyaḥ pitā prayacchatu hūṁ hrīḥ.[69]
zhes brjod nas lus la byugs na rang dbang med par khugs par 'gyur ro/ /
“If you then apply the ointment to your body, the target will be helplessly drawn to you.”
pad+ma rigs kyi yum gyi le'u ste bcu gsum pa'o// //
This was the thirteenth chapter, “The Mother of the Lotus Family.”

d.crumb: 14. The Mother of All the Tathāgatas

f.d: Chapter 14. The Mother of All the Tathāgatas

'jam dpal de bzhin gshegs pa'i yum ni zhal bzhi phyag brgyad pa ser mo gser bsregs pa lta bu'i sku gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa/ rtsa ba'i zhal ser po g.yas dkar ba g.yon dmar ba rgyab kyi zhal gnag pa rigs bzhis dbu la mtshan pa spyan gsum pa'o/ / phyag brgyad na 'khor lo dang mda' dang mdung dang tha ma mchog sbyin mdzad pa'o/ / ut+pa la dang gzhu dang rdo rje lcags kyu dang zhags pa dang sdigs mdzub dang bcas pa g.yon na 'dzin pa'o/ / rdo rje skyil mo krung gis bzhugs shing chos sku'i rang bzhin can no/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the mother of the tathāgata family has four faces and eight hands. Her body is yellow like molten gold and in the prime of youth. Her main face is yellow, her right face is white, her left face is red, and her rear face is black. Each is marked on its crown with the four families and has three eyes. In her right hands she holds a wheel, an arrow, and a spear, while the lowermost hand is in the boon-granting gesture. In her left hands she holds an utpala flower, a bow, and a vajra hook, and she wields a lasso while making the threatening gesture. She sits in the vajra posture and is of dharmakāya nature.

'jam dpal de'i sngags ni 'di'o/ / na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo Ar+ya dz+nyA na sA ga rA ya bai ro tsa na byU ha rA dzA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ aR+ha te b+h+yaH saM myaka saM bud+d+hA ya/ tad+ya thA/ oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
“Mañjuśrī, this is her mantra: “namo ratna-trayāya | namo ārya-jñāna-sāgarāya vairocana-vyūha-rājāya | tathāgatāya | arhate samyak-sambuddhāya | tadyathā | oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.[70]
zhes brjod pas ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs thams cad kyis mchod pa'i me tog dang mar me dang bdug pa dang dri la sogs pas mchod do/ /
“With that, the entire tathāgata family makes offerings of flowers, lamps, incense, fragrances, and so on.

'jam dpal de'i las ni 'di'o/ / thal chen dang sa zhag la gzugs bya ste snying gar gsal byed gnyis kyi yi ge'i mtha' can bcug la sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ / oM mA ra ya mA ra ya/ kA ra ya kA ra ya/ staM b+ha ya staM b+ha ya/ dzaM b+ha ya dzaM b+ha ya/ hU~M hU~M hU~M/ la~M la~M la~M la~M la~M/ zhes brjod nas lam rgya gram du sba bar bya'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, her rite is as follows. Make an effigy from corpse ash and the saturated earth beneath it, and into its heart insert the name ending with the two sets of syllables. Then recite this mantra: “oṁ māraya māraya | kāraya kāraya | stambhaya stambhaya | jambhaya jambhaya. | hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ | laṁ laṁ laṁ laṁ laṁ.[71] “Say that and then bury the effigy at a crossroads.”

This was the fourteenth chapter, “The Mother of All Tathāgatas.”

d.crumb: 15. The Mother of the Jewel Family

f.d: Chapter 15. The Mother of the Jewel Family

'jam dpal rin po che'i rigs kyi yum ni zhal bzhi phyag brgyad pa rtsa ba'i zhal ni mthing ga gzhon nu lang tsho la bab pa mthing ga'i sku zhal g.yas dkar ba g.yon dmar ba rgyab zhal ser ba rigs bzhis dbu la mtshan pa spyan gsum pa'o/ / phyag brgyad ni rin po che dang mda' dang mdung dang tha ma mchog sbyin mdzad pa'o/ / ut+pal dang gzhu dang rdo rje lcags kyu dang zhags pa dang sdigs mdzub g.yon pa na 'dzin pa'o/ / rdo rje skyil mo krung gis bzhugs shing chos sku'i rang bzhin can no/ / @#/ /'jam dpal de'i sngags ni 'di'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the mother of the jewel family has four faces and eight hands. Her main face is dark blue, as is her youthful body. Her right face is white, her left face is red, and her rear face is yellow. Each is marked on its crown with the four families and has three eyes. In her right hands she holds a jewel, an arrow, and a spear, while the lowermost hand is in the boon-granting gesture. In her left hands she holds an utpala flower, a bow, and a vajra hook, and she wields a lasso while making the threatening gesture. She sits in the vajra posture and is of dharmakāya nature.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na ma Ar+ya dz+nyA na swA ga rA ya saM b+ha ba byu ha rA dzA ya/ ta thA ga tA ya/ aR+ha te b+h+yaH saM myaka saM bud+d+hA ya/ na ma Ar+yA ba lo ki te shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ / tad+ya thA/ oM tA re tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes brjod pas rin po che'i rigs thams cad kyis me tog dang bdug spos dang mar me dang dri chab kyis mchod do/ /

“Mañjuśrī, this is her mantra: “namo ratna-trayāya | nama ārya-jñāna-sāgarāya ratnasambhava[72]-vyūha-rājāya | tathāgatāya | arhate samyak-sambuddhāya | nama āryāvalokiteśvarāya | bodhisattvāya | mahāsattvāya | mahā-kāruṇikāya | tadyathā | oṁ tāre tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.[73] “With that, the entire jewel family make offerings of flowers, incense, lamps, and scented water.

“Mañjuśrī, her rite is as follows. Mix together rotten rhododendron root,[74] bugs born from manure, and two seeds. Insert them into a clay amulet, and recite this mantra: “oṁ amukābhidhānam ākarṣaya ākarṣaya | amukīm mamepsitaṃ svapnaṃ kathaya hūṁ hrīḥ.[75]
zhes bzlas te ma la 'og tu sbas na yon tan shes shing mi phyed par 'gyur ro/ /

In her left hands she holds an utpala flower, a bow, and a vajra hook, and she wields a lasso while making the threatening gesture. She sits in the vajra posture and is of dharmakāya nature.

“Mañjuśrī, her rite summons all women in a way that leaves them free of jealousy. To perform it, mix together the eyes, tongue, and heart of a pigeon, cow bezoar, and silver ore. Make this mixture into pills with neem. Then recite this mantra: “cala pracala śīghragāmiṇi devadattam[78] uccāṭaya amukavasanaṃ muktaṃ kuru ānaya mahārihate hrīḥ svāhā.[79]
zhes bzlas te byugs na mo thams cad khugs par 'gyur dbang du 'gyur te phrag dog med par 'gyur ro/ /

Chapter 17. Fire Pūjā

de ltar las kyi bye brag bstan nas 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pas smras pa/ las rnams thams cad kun rdzogs par byed pa sbyin sreg ji ltar nan tan du bya zhes smras pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'jam dpal 'di thams cad kyi sngon du 'gro zhing so so'i las bsgrub pa'i phyir sbyin sreg bya'o/ /

Once these different types of rites had been taught, Youthful Mañjuśrī asked, “How should one earnestly perform the fire pūjā that completes all rites?” The Blessed One replied, “Mañjuśrī, following these rites, a fire pūjā needs to be performed in order to bring them to fulfillment.

de la dang po zhi ba'i las bya ba ni tshes gsum pa'i zla ba la kha dog dang mthun pa'i khang bu bya ste rdo rje dkar po dgod par bya'o/ / bud shing ni tsan+dan dkar po'i shing la sogs pa la bya'o/ / de la me sbar te sku gzugs mdun du bzhag ste 'bras dang khre dang ci tse dang til dkar po la sngags gdab pa ni/ oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ lan bdun nam nyi shu rtsa gcig tu bzlas te

“To perform a fire pūjā for the first of the rites, the pacifying rite, do as follows. On the third day of the lunar month, build a small hut of the corresponding color[80] and set out a white vajra. For firewood, use the wood of white sandalwood trees and the like. Light the fire, place an image before it, and incant rice, beautyberry, millet, and white sesame seeds with the following mantra, reciting it either seven or twenty-one times: “oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.

me'i nang du dor bar bya'o/ / zho dang 'o ma la sngags btab ste shAn+tiM ku ru dang bcas pas dbul bar bya'o/ / 'o ma can gyi shing dang mar dkar po la ni sarba pA baM dang bcas pas phul te bstod pa bya'o/ /

“Then throw the grains and seeds into the fire. Incant yogurt and milk with the mantra and offer them while saying śāntiṃ kuru.[81] Offer wood from a tree with milky sap, along with white butter, and say sarva-pāpam,[82] and then render praise.[83]

'jam dpal me tog dkar po dang bcas pa'i me'i khang par tsan+dan la sogs pa'i dri zhim po'i shing la me sbar te/ sku gzugs mdun du bzhag la chu dang yungs kar la sngags btab la mer gtor ba'i sngags ni/ / tad+ya thA/ oM sarba ta thA ga ta/ tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bya ba'i sngags dang sarba bA baM shAn+tiM ku ru swA hA/ zhes bya ba chu khyor ba brgya rtsa brgyad dbul bar bya'o/ /

“Mañjuśrī, in a fire hut adorned with white flowers, light a fire of sandalwood or other such fragrant wood, and set an image in front of it. Incant water and white mustard seeds with the mantra, and recite the following mantra while throwing them into the fire: “tadyathā | oṁ sarva-tathāgata | tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.[84] “And: “sarva-pāpaṃ śāntiṃ kuru svāhā.[85] “While chanting these, offer one hundred and eight handfuls of water.

'jam dpal de'i phan yon ni mtshams med pa la sogs pa'i sdig pa zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / nad 'go ba dang gdon la sogs pa thams cad kyang zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / skye ba thams cad du tshe rabs dran par 'gyur ro/ /

“Mañjuśrī, the benefits of this are such that misdeeds, including the acts with immediate retribution, will be pacified, infectious diseases, harmful spirits, and the like will all be pacified, and you will recall all your past lives in each of your rebirths.
'jam dpal ba'i rnam pa lngas byug pas byugs te/ me'i khang bu dri dang ldan pa'i khang par spra tshil las gzugs byas pa dang bcas pa sngags 'dis bsreg go/ / oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/
“Mañjuśrī, anoint the fire hut with the five substances from a cow, and in this odorous hut, burn an effigy made[86] of wax while reciting this mantra: “oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā.
zhes bya bas bsregs na dbang du 'gyur zhing tshar gcad par yang 'gyur ro/ /
“Once it has been burned, the target will be overpowered or even annihilated.”
sbyin sreg gi le'u ste bcu bdun pa'o// //
This was the seventeenth chapter, “Fire Pūjā.”

d.crumb: 18. The Protective Circle for Pacifying Rites

f.d: Chapter 18. The Protective Circle for Pacifying Rites
de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis 'dzum pa mdzad de/ byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nu la 'khor lo'i rim pa bka' stsal to/ /
The Blessed One then smiled and taught Youthful Mañjuśrī the procedures for the circles.

'khor lo ling tshe dgu pa la oM dad hA gnyis kyi dbus su che ge mo dang bcas pa bri/ rak+ShaHrak+ShaHzhes pa ni bsrung ba'o/ / phyogs mtshams su oM tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ zhes bya ba bris te kun la swA hA'i bar du bcug pa gro ga la gur gum gyis bris nas dpung ba la btags na bsrung ba'i mchog tu 'gyur ro/ /

“In a circle with nine compartments, write oṁ and hā with the target’s name in between. Use the words rakṣaḥ rakṣaḥ[87] for protection. In the surrounding compartments, write oṁ tāre tuttāre ture svāhā, with svāhā written between each syllable. Written on birch bark with saffron and then fastened to the upper arm, this serves as the best protection.”

f.d: Chapter 19. The Protective Circle for Enthralling Rites

“For protection during enthralling rites, write oṁ and hā, with the target’s name in between, within a nine-compartment circle. Use the words rakṣaḥ rakṣaḥ for protection. In the surrounding compartments, write tāre tuttāre ture svāhā,[88] with the syllable mu between each of those syllables. Write this on red birch bark with lac dye and fasten it to the navel so that it cannot be seen. This will be the best protection and will enthrall.”

d.crumb: 21. A More Elaborate Protective Circle for Increasing Rites

f.d: Chapter 21. A More Elaborate Protective Circle for Increasing Rites

de nas bar chad thams cad bsrung ba'i 'khor lo ni mu khyud gsum la tha ma ling tshe brgyad pa'o/ / dbus su ming gi mtha' can gyi swA hA rak+ShaHdang bcas pa'o/ / mu khyud nang ma la u u u u u u u u zhes bya ba dgod par bya'o/ / ling tshe brgyad pa phyi ma la ni/ oM tA re tu re tut+tA re zhes bya ba'i yig 'bru rnams u dang u'i bar du bcug pa bkod la gro ga 'am shing shun la gur gum gyis bris te spyi bo'am mchan khung du mis mi mthong bar btags na gnod pa thams cad las thar ro/ / sngags ni ci mang du grangs dang ldan par bzlas so/ /

“For a protective circle that guards against all obstacles,[89] use a triple-rimmed circle with eight compartments in the outermost circle. In its central compartment write svāhā appended to the target’s name along with rakṣaḥ. In the innermost rim, write u u u u u u u u.[90] In the outer, eight-compartment rim, write oṁ tāre ture tuttāre, bracketing each syllable with u. Draw this with saffron on birch bark or other bark. Tie it to the crown of the head or under the arm so that people cannot see it, and one will be freed from all harm. Recite the mantra as many times as you can.”

d.crumb: 22. The Magical Protective Circle for Great Pacification

f.d: Chapter 22. The Magical Protective Circle for Great Pacification

de nas phrin las thams cad bsgrub pa'i 'khor lo ni grog 'am ras la ling tshe dgu pa'i 'khor lo tsan+dan dkar po'i chus bris te sngags dgod ba ni/ a A i I u U e ai o oM r-i r-I l-i l-I aM aHzhes bya ba phyi'i mu khyud la'o/ / nang gi mu khyud la tA re tut+tA re tu re swA hA/ oM dang hA'i bar du rak+ShaH shIn+taM ku ru swA hA zhes pa ni steng gi 'khor lo'o/ / 'og gi 'khor lo ni sngags bzlog pas so/ / phyi'i dbyangs yig kyang bzlog par shes par bya'o/ / dbus su ni oM dang hA'i bar du rak+ShaHshAn+tiM ku ru bri bar bya'o/ /

“Now for the circle that accomplishes all activities, on birch bark or cloth, draw a circle with nine compartments using water infused with white sandalwood. In the outermost rim, write a ā i ī u ū e ai o au ṛ ṝ ḷ ḹ aṃ aḥ. In the inner rim, write tāre tuttāre ture svāhā. Write rakṣaḥ śāntiṃ kuru svāhā[91] between oṁ and hā in the upper part of the circle, and reverse the mantra in the lower part of the circle. Know that the vowels on the outside are to be reversed. In the center, write rakṣaḥ śāntiṃ kuru between oṁ and hā.”

Chapter 23. The Pacifying Circle

de nas phrin las bzhi'i las so so'i 'khor lo ni zhi ba ni kham pa la ga'u kha sbyor bya ste mer bsregs la kha dog dkar pos byug par bya'o/ / de'i nang du 'khor lo ling tshe dgu pa bris te sngags dgod pa ni/ oM tA re tut+tA re tu re zhes bya ba re'u mig brgyad la'o/ / ru ru oM ru ru/ ru ru tA ru ru/ ru ru re ru ru/ ru ru tu ta ru ru/ ru ru tA ru ru/ ru ru re ru ru/ ru ru tu ru ru/ ru ru re ru ru/ zhes bri'o/ / dbus su ni ku ru shAn+tiM ku ru swA hA zhes bris te ga 'ur sbyar te dbus su srad pu dkar po dang ldan pa'i ga'u maN+Dal thog tu bzhag la/ me tog dkar pos mchod cing mchod pa rnam pa lnga yang dbul te dus gsum du mchod na zhi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Next are the circles for the individual rites of the four activities. For pacifying, make a clay amulet with a lid, bake it, and color it white. Inside it, draw a circle with nine compartments. The mantra oṁ tāre tuttāre ture should be written in the eight surrounding panels as follows: ru ru oṁ ru ru | ru ru tā ru ru | ru ru re ru ru | ru ru tut ru ru | ru ru tā ru ru | ru ru re ru ru | ru ru tu ru ru | ru ru re ru ru. In the central compartment, write kuru śāntiṃ kuru svāhā. Close the amulet and place it, along with a white thread, on the maṇḍala. If you then worship at the three times with white flowers and the five kinds of offerings, the pacification will succeed.”
zhi ba'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa gsum pa'o// //
This was the twenty-third chapter, “The Pacifying Circle.”
[zhi ba chen po]
Chapter 24. Great Pacification

de nas zhi ba chen po'i las bya ba ni kham pa la ga'u kha sbyor bya ste tsan+dan dkar pos snag tsha byas la 'khor lo phyi nang dang ldan pa'i ling tshe dgu pa bri bar bya'o/ / sngags dgod pa ni swA shAn+ti ku ru hA zhes bya ba dbus su bri'o/ / mu khyud nang ma la ni a a zhes bya ba brgyad dgod par bya'o/ / mu khyud phyi ma la ni a oM a a tA a a re a/ a tuta a/ a tA a/ a re a/ a tu a/ a re a/ zhes bya ba bri bar bya'o/ / ga'u me tog gi phreng ba bcings te maN+Dal gyi steng du bzhag nas dus bzhir mchod cing zhag bdun du sngags ma nor bar bzlas na zhi ba chen por 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

“To accomplish the activity of great pacification, make a clay amulet with a lid. Make ink out of white sandalwood[92] and use it to draw a nine-compartment circle with inner and outer sections. In the central compartment write the mantra svā śāntiṃ kuru hā.[93] Inside the inner rim, write eight sets of a a. Inside the outer rim, write a oṁ a | a tā a | a re a | a tut a | a tā a | a re a | a tu a | a re a. Tie a flower garland around the amulet and place it on the maṇḍala. Make offerings to it at the four times and recite the mantra without error for seven days. If you do, the great pacification will succeed.”
zhi ba chen po'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa bzhi pa'o// //
This was the twenty-fourth chapter, “Great Pacification.”
[rgyas pa'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 25. The Increasing Circle

de nas rgyas pa'i las bya ba ni gur gum mam gi wang gis gro ga la 'khor lo phyi nang dang ldan pa'i ling tshe dgu pa bri ste/ dbus su sar+b+ba puSh+TiM ku ru/ oM a zhes bya ba dgod par bya'o/ / ling tshe nang ma brgyad la oM brgyad bri bar bya'o/ / ling tshe phyi ma brgyad la/ oM oM oM/ oM tA oM/ oM re oM/ oM tuta oM/ oM tA oM/ oM re oM/ oM tu oM/ oM re oM/ zhes bya ba bris nas kham pa'i ga'ur bcug ste me tog ser po nA ga puSh+pa'i me tog dang mchod pa lnga dus bzhir zla ba rgyas nas bzung nas zhag bdun du mchod na tshe dang bsod nams thams cad rgyas par 'grub bo/ /

“To perform the increasing rite, draw a nine-compartment circle with an inner and outer rim on birch bark, using either saffron or bezoar. In the central compartment write sarvapuṣṭiṃ kuru oṁ a,[94] and in each of the eight inner compartments, write oṁ. In the eight outer compartments, write oṁ oṁ oṁ | oṁ tā oṁ | oṁ re oṁ | oṁ tut oṁ | oṁ tā oṁ | oṁ re oṁ | oṁ tu oṁ | oṁ re oṁ. Then place the circle inside a clay amulet and worship it with yellow flowers, such as the nāga flower, and the five offerings at the four times each day for seven days, starting on the full moon. Your lifespan and merit will thereby be increased.”
rgyas pa'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa lnga pa'o// //
This was the twenty-fifth chapter, “The Increasing Circle.”
[dbang drag gi 'khor lo]
Chapter 26. The Forceful Enthralling Circle

de nas dbang du bsdu bar 'dod na/ kaN+Da ka ri'i shun pa dang seng ldeng gi shun pa dang mdzo mo shing gi shun pa bkus pa'i khu bas bse gab bam ga'u la 'khor lo bri ba ni ling tshe dgu pa'o/ / sngags dgod pa ni dbus su a swA tsa a mo g+ha A hrIHha/ zhes bri bar bya'o/ / ling tshe brgyad la ni/ a oM a/ a tA a/ a re a/ a tuta a/ a tA a/ a re a/ a tu a/ a re a/ zhes bris nas thod pa kha sbyor gyi nang du bcug la skud pa sngon pos bkris te me tog dmar po dang mchod pa lngas dus bzhir zla ba kham pa'i dus su mchod na thams cad dbang du 'du'o/ /

“If you wish to enthrall, draw a circle with nine compartments on a rhinoceros hide or an amulet using pigment made of the extracts of the bark of areca, cutch, and caragana trees.[95] In the central compartment of the circle write the mantra a svā ca amogha a hrīḥ hā.[96] In the eight compartments write a oṁ a | a tā a | a re a | a tut a | a tā a | a re a | a tu a | a re a. Then, place it inside a skull cup covered with a lid, and bind it with blue thread. When the moon is full, worship it during the four times using red flowers and the five offerings. If you do, everything will be enthralled.”
dbang drag gi 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa drug pa'o// //
This was the twenty-sixth chapter, “The Forceful Enthralling Circle.”

d.crumb: dbye zhing dbang du bsdu ba'i 'khor lo

f.d: [dbye zhing dbang du bsdu ba'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 27. The Isolating and Enthralling Circle

de nas dbang du 'du bar byed pa ni/ srin lag gi khrag dang rgya skyegs kyi khu ba dang dur khrod kyi sol ba dang kan ka'i khu ba rnams kyis bris te/ dur khrod kyi ras sam mi shi ba'i gos la 'khor lo ling tshe dgu pa bri'o/ / dbus su a mo g+ha hrIHha zhes bri'o/ / rtsibs brgyad la oM de oM/ tA ba tA/ re data re/ tut+tA tuta/ tA a tA/ re mo re/ tu g+ha tu/ re hriHzhes bya ba bris te ga'ur srin mgo dmar po dang 'khor lo phral nas gtsang po phar 'gram tshur 'gram du sbas na dbye zhing dbang du 'gyur ro/ /

“To enthrall, use blood from your ring finger, lac dye,[97] charnel-ground charcoal, and gold[98] to draw a circle with nine compartments on a charnel-ground shroud[99] or the clothes of a dead person. In its central compartment write amogha hrīḥ ha.[100] On the eight spokes, write oṁ de oṁ | tā va tā | re dat re | tut ta tut | tā a tā | re mo re | tu gha tu | re hriḥ re.[101] Insert the circle into an amulet along with the head of a worm. Breaking it in two, conceal each part on opposite sides of a riverbank. If you do that, isolating and enthralling will be accomplished.”
dbye zhing dbang du bsdu ba'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa bdun pa'o// //
This was the twenty-seventh chapter, “The Isolating and Enthralling Circle.”
[bskrad pa'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 28. The Banishing Circle

de nas bskrad par 'dod na ra dug pa dang khrag dang ra mas rnams sbyar nas/ dur khrod kyi ras la 'khor lo gnyis bris te ling tshe dgu pa'i dbus su has u tsa ha ha ha/ bri bar bya'o/ / ling tshe brgyad la ha oM ha/ ha tA ha/ ha re ha/ ha tuta ha/ ha tA ha/ ha re ha/ ha tu ha/ ha re ha/ zhes bris te kha sbyar ka pA lar bcug ste skud pa sngon pos bcings te dur khrod du sbas na bskrad par 'gyur ro/ /

“If you wish to banish, use a mixture of the goat poison plant,[102] blood, and indigo to draw two circles with nine compartments on a charnel-ground shroud. In the central compartment write ha sa u ca ha ha ha, and in the eight surrounding compartments write ha oṁ ha | ha tā ha | ha re ha | ha tut ha | ha tā ha | ha re ha | ha tu ha | ha re ha. Place the circle into a skull cup covered with a lid, bind it with blue thread, and conceal it in a charnel ground. The banishment will then be successful.”
bskrad pa'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa brgyad pa'o// //
This was the twenty-eight chapter, on the banishing circle.
[dbye ba'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 29. The Isolating Circle

de nas dbye ba'i 'khor lo ni/ dur khrod kyi sol ba dang bya rog dang 'ug pa'i khrag dang dug rnams mnyam par bsres pa'i snag tshas 'khor lo phyi nang bcas pa'i ling tshe dgu pa bris te dbus su phaT swA de ba da ta ta hA phaT zhes bya ba bri'o/ / ling tshe nang ma brgyad la phaT phaT phaT phaT phaT phaT phaT phaT/ zhes bya ba bri'o/ / ling tshe phyi ma brgyad la phaT oM phaT/ phaT tA phaT/ phaT re phaT/ phaT tuta phaT/ phaT tA phaT/ phaT re phaT/ phaT tu phaT/ phaT re phaT zhes bya ba bri ste/ bya rog dang 'ug pa'i sgo ngar bcug ste brag dang chu 'thab sar sgo nga sbas na 'bye bar 'gyur ro/ /

“To make an isolating circle, use ink made from a mixture of equal parts of charnel-ground charcoal, crow blood, owl blood, and poison to draw nine compartments with an inner and outer circle. In the central compartment write phaṭ svā devadatta[103] hā phaṭ. In the eight inner compartments write phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ. In the eight outer compartments write phaṭ oṁ phaṭ | phaṭ tā phaṭ | phaṭ re phaṭ | phaṭ tut phaṭ | phaṭ tā phaṭ | phaṭ re phaṭ | phaṭ tu phaṭ | phaṭ re phaṭ. Place it in a crow and owl egg and conceal it at the base of a waterfall. Isolating will thereby be successful.”
dbye ba'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste nyi shu rtsa dgu pa'o// //
This was the twenty-ninth chapter, “The Isolating Circle.”
[gsad pa'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 30. The Slaying Circle

de nas gsad pa'i 'khor lo ni/ dug dang khrag dang ske tshe rnams mnyam par sbyar bas ling tshe dgu pa'i 'khor lo phyi nang dang bcas pa bris te/ dbus su hU~M swA mA ra ya hA phaT zhes bya ba bri'o/ / ling tshe nang ma la hU~M phaT hU~M/ phaT hU~M phaT/ hU~M phaT hU~M/ phaT hU~M phaT/ hU~M phaT hU~M/ phaT hU~M phaT/ hU~M phaT hU~M/ phaT hU~M phaT/ zhes bya ba bri'o/ / ling tshe phyi ma la hU~M oM phaT/ hU~M tA phaT/ hU~M re phaT/ hU~M tuta phaT/ hU~M tA phaT/ hU~M re phaT/ hU~M tu phaT/ hU~M re phaT/ zhes bya ba bris te/ rabs chad pho mo'i thod pa la bris te sngags mang du bzlas nas dur khrod du sbas na 'chi bar 'gyur ro/ /

“The circle for slaying is as follows. Use a mixture of equal parts of poison, blood, and mustard seed to draw a nine-compartment circle with inner and outer sections. In the central compartment write hūṁ svā māraya hā phaṭ.[104] In the inner compartments write hūṁ phaṭ hūṁ | phaṭ hūṁ phaṭ | hūṁ phaṭ hūṁ | phaṭ hūṁ phaṭ | hūṁ phaṭ hūṁ | phaṭ hūṁ phaṭ | hūṁ phaṭ hūṁ | phaṭ hūṁ phaṭ. In the outer compartments write hūṁ oṁ phaṭ | hūṁ tā phaṭ | hūṁ re phaṭ | hūṁ tut phaṭ | hūṁ tā phaṭ | hūṁ re phaṭ | hūṁ tu phaṭ | hūṁ re phaṭ. Write these on the skull of a childless man or woman, repeat the mantra many times, and then hide it in a charnel ground. If you do so, death will ensue.”
gsad pa'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste sum cu pa'o// //
This was the thirtieth chapter, “The Slaying Circle.”
[myos byed kyi 'khor lo]
Chapter 31. The Insanity-Inducing Circle

de nas myos pa'i 'khor lo ni da du ra'i chus ras sam sho gu la ling tshe dgu pa phyi nang du bcas pa bris te/ dbus su ha ha de ba da ta ta ha ha/ zhes bri'o/ / ling tshe nang ma la h+ha h+ha h+ha h+ha h+ha h+ha h+ha h+ha/ zhes bri bar bya'o/ / phyi ma brgyad la/ h+ha oM h+ha/ h+ha tA h+ha/ h+ha re h+ha/ h+ha tu ta h+ha/ h+ha tA h+ha/ h+ha re h+ha/ h+ha tu h+ha/ h+ha re h+ha/ zhes bya ba bris te/ rtswa'i ga 'ur bcug nas bzlas pa ci nas kyang myur bar bya ste/ lam rgya gram du sbas te da du ra spungs na myos par 'gyur ro/ / gso na mar sbrang rtsi ba'i 'o mas ling ga bkrus na 'tsho bar 'gyur ro/ /

“To make a circle that will induce insanity, use water infused with datura to draw a nine-compartment circle with inner and outer sections on cloth or paper. In the central compartment write ha ha devadatta ha ha. In the inner compartments write hha hha hha hha hha hha hha hha. In the eight outer compartments write hha oṁ hha | hha tā hha | hha re hha | hha tut hha | hha tā hha | hha re hha | hha tu hha | hha re hha. Place the circle into a grass amulet and recite the mantra as fast as you can. Then conceal it at a crossroads[105] and pile datura on it. Insanity will then be induced. To relieve the insanity, wash an effigy with butter, honey, and cow’s milk. The target will thereby recover.”
myos byed kyi 'khor lo'i le'u ste sum cu rtsa gcig pa'o// //
This was the thirty-first chapter, “The Insanity-Inducing Circle.”
[mnan pa'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 32. The Suppressing Circle

de nas mnan pa'i 'khor lo ni g.yam pa la ling tshe dgu pa'i 'khor lo bris te/ yung ba'i chus ling tshe dgu pa'i dbus su ga swa staM b+ha ya/ staM b+ha ya b+ha ha zhes bya ba bri'o/ / ling tshe brgyad la/ ga oM ga / ga tA ga / ga re ga / ga tuta ga / ga tA ga / ga re ga / ga tu ga / ga re ga / zhes bya ba bris te/ 'khor lo kha sbyar nas lam rgya gram du sbas na 'gul mi shes par 'gyur ro/ /

“The circle that suppresses is as follows. Draw a nine-compartment circle on slate. In the central compartment, use water infused with turmeric to write ga svā stambhaya | stambhaya ga hā.[106] In the eight compartments, write ga oṁ ga | ga tā ga | ga re ga | ga tut ga | ga tā ga | ga re ga | ga tu ga | ga re ga. If the circle is folded and hidden at a crossroads, the target will be unable to move.”
mnan pa'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste sum cu rtsa gnyis pa'o// //
This was the thirty-second chapter, on the suppressing circle.
[dgra mnan pa'i 'khor lo]
Chapter 33. The Great Suppression Circle

de nas mnan pa chen po ni yung ba'i khu bas snag tsha byas te/ kham pa'i ga'u'i nang du phyi nang ling tshe dgu pa'i 'khor lo bris te sngags dgod pa ni/ dbus su rga swA staM b+ha ya staM b+ha ya rga ha zhes bya ba bri'o/ / nang ma la ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha/ zhes bya ba brgyad bri'o/ / phyi rol gyi ling tshe brgyad la ni/ rga oM rga/ rga tArga/ rga re rga/ rga tuta rga/ rta tA rga/ rga re rga/ rga tu rga/ rga re rga/ zhes bya ba bris te/ bsgrub pa 'phags ma la byas la dgra gang nas 'ong ba'i phyogs su sbas na bsrung bar 'gyur zhing dgra'i sgor sbas na mnan par 'gyur ro/ /

“For the great suppression circle, use ink made of turmeric to draw nine compartments with inner and outer circles inside a clay amulet. In the central compartment write this mantra: ṛga svā staṃbhaya staṃbhaya ṛga hā.[107] In the inner compartments write ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha eight times. In the eight outer compartments write ṛga oṁ ṛga | ṛga tā ṛga | ṛga re ṛga | ṛga tut ṛga | ṛga tā ṛga | ṛga re ṛga | ṛga tu ṛga | ṛga re ṛga and finalize it with the addition of the Ārya Tārā mantra.[108] Conceal it in the direction from which the enemy is approaching, and it will grant protection. If you conceal it by the enemy’s door, they will be suppressed.”
dgra mnan pa'i 'khor lo'i le'u ste sum cu rtsa gsum pa'o// //
This was the thirty-third chapter, “The Circle That Suppresses Enemies.”

d.crumb: rig sngags kyi sbyor ba gnon pa

f.d: [rig sngags kyi sbyor ba gnon pa]

d.crumb: 34. The Circle That Suppresses the Sorcery of Vidyā-Mantra

f.d: Chapter 34. The Circle That Suppresses the Sorcery of Vidyā-Mantra

de nas rig sngags kyi sbyor ba gnon par byed pa'i 'khor lo ni yung ba'i khu bas g.yam pa'am/ lhang tsher ma gnyis gang yang rung ba la 'khor lo bris te/ ling tshe dgu pa phyi nang dang bcas pa bri'o/ / sngags dgod pa ni/ dbus su wa swA staM b+ha ya staM b+ha ya hA/ 'khor lo nang ma la/ wa wa wa wa wa wa wa wa/ zhes bya ba bri'o/ / phyi ma la/ wa oM wa/ wa tA wa/ wa re wa/ wa tuta wa/ wa tA wa/ wa re wa/ wa tu wa/ wa re wa/ zhes bya ba bris te phan tshun g.yas g.yon du 'khor lo re re sbas na gnon par 'gyur ro/ /

“To make the circle that suppresses the sorcery of vidyā-mantra, draw the circle —a nine-compartment circle with inner and outer sections —with liquid turmeric on two slabs of either slate or mica. As for the mantras, in the central compartment write va svā staṃbhaya staṃbhaya hā.[109] In the inner section write va va va va va va va va. In the outer section write va oṁ va | va tā va | va re va | va tut va | va tā va | va re va | va tu va | va re va. Then conceal the two circles separately, side by side, and the sorcery of vidyā-mantra will be suppressed.”
rig sngags kyi sbyor ba gnon pa'i le'u ste sum cu rtsa bzhi pa'o// //
This was the thirty-fourth chapter, “Suppressing the Sorcery of Vidyā-Mantra.”

d.crumb: dam tshig dang sdom pa bstan pa

f.d: [dam tshig dang sdom pa bstan pa]
Chapter 35. Teaching the Samayas and Vows

de nas bcom ldan 'das la byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nus me tog man dA ra ba dang pad+ma dang / ku mu da la sogs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pas bcom ldan 'das la gtor to/ / lha rdzas kyi rol mo'i sgra du ma yang bsgrags so/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das la gsol pa/ dam tshig kyang gang gis 'grub par 'gyur zhes zhus pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/

The bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī then scattered an inconceivable[110] array of flowers —mandārava flowers, lotuses, water lilies, and many others —over the Blessed One, while a symphony of divine music resounded. He asked the Blessed One, “How are the samayas to be fulfilled?” The Blessed One replied:
so so'i dam tshig sdom gnas te/ / lha yi 'khor lo dang ldan pas/ / srog chags dag ni gsad pa spangs/ / ma byin blang bar mi bya zhing / /
“Those who maintain their respective samayas And are connected to the circle of deities Should abandon the killing of beings, Not take what is not given,
bud med mi bsten smad mi bya/ / brdzun ni rnam pa kun tu spang / / myos 'gyur dag dang sha dag dang / / rku zhing rnam pa rtag tu spang / /
“Not frequent women or abuse them, Avoid all types of lies, Relinquish intoxicants, meat, And all types of stealing,
mo rnams thams cad kun la ni/ / chags pa'i sems ni spang ba ste/ / ma bzhin du ni kun la ni/ / phan pa'i sems kyis kun la bkur/ /
“Cast aside lustful attitudes Toward each and every woman, And show them benevolent respect As if they were one’s own mother.
dam tshig sdom la gnas pa yis/ / las rnams kun la mthu yod 'gyur/ / zhes bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs so/ /
“For those who maintain these samaya commitments, All rites will be effective.” Thus spoke the Blessed One.
dam tshig dang sdom pa bstan pa'i le'u ste sum cu rtsa lnga pa'o// //
This was the thirty-fifth chapter, “Teaching the Samayas and Vows.”
[mjug don]
Chapter 36. The Conclusion

de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin dang tshangs pa la sogs pa'i lha dpag tu med pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gzhon nu la sogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i 'khor dpag tu med pa dang / lha dang / mi dang / lha ma yin dang / dri zar bcas pa'i 'jig rten yi rangs te/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa la mngon par bstod do/ /

The vast gathering of countless gods —including the lord of gods Indra, Brahmā, and others —the bodhisattva Youthful Mañjuśrī, a countless retinue of other bodhisattvas, and the world with its gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas[111] rejoiced and praised what the Blessed One had said.
bcom ldan 'das ma sgrol ma'i rgyud las sna tshogs bstan pa zhes bya ba rdzogs so// //
This completes “The Tantra on All Rites of Blessed Lady Tārā.”
['gyur byang]
Colophon
rgya gar gyi mkhan po d+harmA shrI mi tra dang / bod kyi lots+tsha ba dge slong chos kyi bzang pos bsgyur ba'o// //
Translated by the Indian preceptor Dharmaśrīmitra and the Tibetan translator and monk Chökyi Sangpo.

d.crumb: 'phags ma sgrol ma 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob pa'i mdo

f.d: 'phags ma sgrol ma 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob pa'i mdo

d.crumb: The Noble Sūtra Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Dangers

f.d: The Noble Sūtra Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Dangers
Translated by Samye Translations
rgya gar skad du/ Ar+ya tA ra aSh+Ta g+ho re tA sbI sU tra/ bod skad du/ 'phags ma sgrol ma 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob pa'i mdo/
*Āryatārāṣṭaghoratāraṇīsūtra Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Dangers
dkon mchog gsum la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rje btsun ma sgrol ma la phyag 'tshal lo/ / bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the Three Jewels. Homage to the venerable lady Tārā. Homage to the Blessed Śākyamuni.
'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das ri rab kyi steng lha'i gnas na bzhugs te/ de nyid du 'khor rnams kyi nang nas lha mo sgrol mas 'di skad ces smras so/ /
Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was dwelling in the realm of gods atop Mount Meru. At that time, the goddess Tārā, who was in the assembly, spoke the following words:

mtho ris rin chen lta bu 'di thob nas/ / las dang las kyi 'bras bu shes par byos/ / bzang po sten cing ngan pa spang bar gyis/ / gang dag sdig pa'i las rnams spyod byed pa/ / 'jig rten pha rol mthur du 'bab 'gyur te/ /

“Now that you have reached this jewel-like higher realm, You should understand actions and their results: Adhere to the good and abandon the bad, For those who engage in evil actions [F.223.a] Will plunge downward when they pass from this world.
dud 'gro glen rkugs gcig la gcig za dang / / gyen mthur 'bab 'dzeg g.yang sa ngal ba'i lam/ / 'jigs shing nga skrag shin du skyi g.ya' ba/ / zon dang bcas pa'i sdug bsngal bsam mi khyab/ /

“Animals, dull and mute, devour one another. They climb and descend, up and down, on an abysmal path of toil. Terrified and afraid, they tremble in panic, As their dreadful suffering defies imagination.
yi dgas ltogs shing skom dang lus mi 'tsham/ / bza' btung snang yang gzhan gyis bsrungs pa dang / / kha cig zos kyang me dang mtshon du 'gyur/ / ltogs shing skom pa'i sdug bsngal bsam mi khyab/ /

“Pretas suffer from hunger and thirst, their bodies deformed. If food and drink should appear, it is guarded by others, And even if they consume a little, it turns into fire and swords. Their suffering from hunger and thirst defies imagination.
dmyal bar skyes pa'i sems can de dag ni/ / rang dbang med par gshin rje gdug pas khrid/ / bsregs shing btsos te mtshon gyis rab tu 'thub/ / bsran glags med pa'i sdug bsngal tsha dang grang / /
“Those beings who are born in the hell realms Are powerlessly led by Yama’s henchmen. Burned and boiled, they are sliced asunder by swords; Their suffering from heat and cold is unbearable.
des na tshe 'dir sdig pa'i las byed pa/ / rang gis rang la mngan ni char byas yin/ / bskal pa mang por sdug bsngal drag pos gdungs/ / thar pa'i dus med bsran pa'i glags kyang med/ /

“Thus, those who commit evil deeds in this life Are committing a great injury to themselves. They will be tormented by intense suffering for many eons, With no chance to escape and no means of enduring it.
dran pa gsal bas las kyi 'bras bur shes/ / sdug bsngal ma bzod smre sngags rang la rmo/ / skad ngan drag po'i ku sgras gzhan yang skrag / de la sogs te sdug bsngal bsam mi khyab/ /

“Keep this clearly in mind, and understand the results of actions. Otherwise you will sow your own unbearable suffering and lament. Even others will be frightened by the terrible din of your agonized screams, For these kinds of sufferings are beyond imagination!
gang dag nyes dmigs rab tu shes gyis la/ / ngan song gsum gyi rgyu rnams rab tu spangs/ / sdig pa'i rnam pa phra rags gang la yang / / lus ngag yid kyi sgo nas spyad da re/ /
“Whoever understands such grave faults Will abandon the causes of the three lower realms. Wherever evil manifests, subtle or coarse, Act swiftly by way of body, speech, and mind.
rang yang bde la 'gro rnams yongs la phan/ / chags sdang rmongs spangs snying rje'i rtsa ba brtan/ / sgo gsum dang bas 'bad de dge ba spyad/ / shin du zab pa'i snying po 'di la 'bad/ /

“You will then be happy and offer help to all beings. You will give up attachment, aversion, and ignorance and strengthen the root of compassion. You will practice virtue, striving avidly with body, speech, and mind, And endeavor in this most profound quintessence.[6]

me tog sad kyis khyer ba'i 'bras bu la/ / so nam byas kyang myu gu mi skye ltar/ / sdom nyams the tshom zos pa'i gang zag gis/ / shin tu zab pa'i rig sngags bsgrub gyur kyang / / byin brlabs 'byung ngo snyam yang 'byung mi srid/ / rtsol ba de dag ngal ba don med 'gyur/ /

“The fruit of a flower overcome by frost, Although cultivated, will produce no sprouts. Likewise, those who transgress their vows and entertain doubts May practice the most profound of vidyāmantras, Thinking, ‘Blessings will come,’ but this is impossible‍— Their efforts amount to meaningless hardship.
rig sngags de yang skye bo'i tshig dang mtshungs/ / ting 'dzin rnams kyang byis pa'i bsam pa 'dra/ / skyon med skyes bus rig sngags de bsgrubs na/ / ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du myur du 'grub/ /

“Their vidyāmantra becomes like the prattle of common folk, And their absorption resembles the musings of a child. But if people without fault practice vidyāmantras, They shall swiftly accomplish whatever they desire.

dper na n+ya gro d+ha'i sa bon ni/ / shin tu phra yang chu lud legs bran na/ / dgung zla bdun na dpag tshad tsam du skye/ / bems po phyi'i 'gyur yang de 'dra na/ / rig pas rig pa bsgrub pa lta ci smos/ / 'od gsal nang gi 'gyur la dpag tu med/ /

“Minute though it is, the seed of the banyan tree Well moistened with water and manure In seven months can grow as much as a league. If there can be so much change in outer matter, What need to speak of accomplishing knowledge with knowledge? The inner change of luminosity is beyond all measure.
tshong dpon lam la mkhas pa dag la brten/ / gru tshags legs pas rgya mtshor zhugs gyur na/ / rin chen 'dod pa bzhin du rnyed gyur nas/ / rang gi gnas su legs par phyin pa yin/ /
“If one relies on a merchant who knows the way And sets out to sea in an excellent ship, One will find whatever riches are desired And sail smoothly back to one’s home.
byams dang snying rje dga' dang btang snyoms rten/ / byang chub sems ldan dge ba spyad gyur na/ / yang dag rdzogs kyi lam la zhugs 'gyur te/ / nges par mkhyen nyid sa la 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
“If one relies on love, compassion, joy, and equanimity And practices virtue endowed with the mind of awakening, One will set out on a truly perfect path And be sure to reach the land of wisdom.
mda' nyid skyes bu'i 'theb nas shor gyur na/ / mi 'phang snyam yang shin tu 'phangs par 'gyur/ / chos nyid don kun chub pa'i gang zag ni/ / mi phyin snyam yang pha rol phyin par 'gyur/ /

“When an arrow is released from a person’s fingers, It has certainly been shot, even if one thinks otherwise. When a person fully comprehends the meaning of reality, The other shore has been reached, even if one thinks otherwise.

bya cha'i rnam pa rang bzhin rdzogs gyur nas/ / sangs rgyas 'bras bu 'thob par the tsom med/ / chos nyid rnam par dag pa de rtogs na/ / bdag med srog med srog kyang gcad du med/ / las med de'i rnam par smin pa med/ / mtha' rnams rab spangs skyes bu rnam par grol/ /

“Once the aspects of conduct are naturally perfected, The fruit of buddhahood will undoubtedly be attained. When the pristine nature of reality is realized, There is no self, no life force, and also no termination of life force. There is no action and no ripening of action. The extremes are abandoned, and one is liberated.

de don rtogs phyir bdag gis bshad pa'i/ / snying po 'di la gus pas bzlas gyur na/ / bskal pa grangs med gsum gyi sdig kyang 'dzad/ / ngan song gsum dang 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal kun/ / rab tu sbyong zhing sgrib pa rnams gyang 'dag / don dang ldan pa'i snying po 'di lta ste/

“In order for you to realize that goal, Devotedly recite this quintessence as I proclaim it. If you do, the evil deeds of three incalculable eons will be eradicated, The three lower realms and all the suffering of saṃsāra will be purified, And the obscurations will be cleared away. The meaningful quintessence is as follows:
o~M byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen mo/ lha mo khyod kyis bskyab tu gsol/ /
oṁ, bodhisattva great lady, goddess, please protect us![7]
o~M na mo Ar+ya a ba lo ki hi shwa rA ya/ bo d+hi satwA ya/ ma hA satwA ya/ ma hA kA ru Ni kA ya/ tad+ya thA/
oṁ nama āryāvalokiteśvarāya bodhisattvāya mahāsattvāya mahākāruṇikāya |[8] tadyathā |[9]
o~M tA re tud tA re tu re sarba duSh+TAn/ pra duSh+Ta na ma ma kri te/ dzam b+ha ya/ stam b+ha ya/ mo hA ya/ ban d+ha ya/ hU~M hU~M hU~M/ phaT phaT phaT swA hA/
oṁ tāre tuttāre ture sarvaduṣṭān praduṣṭān mama kṛte jambhaya stambhaya mohaya bandhaya hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā |[10]

ma ma Ar+yA ba lo b+ha yA na rA/ bo d+hi satwA/ ma hA satwA ni/ a d+hiSh+ThA na/ a d+hiSh+Thi te ma ma sarba karma a ba ra Na swa b+hA ba/ shud d+he bi shud d+he/ sho d+ha ya bi sho d+ha ya hU~M phaT swA hA/
nama āryāvalobhayā narā bodhisattvā mahāsattvāni adhiṣṭhānādhiṣṭhite mama sarvakarmāvaraṇa svabhāvaśuddhe viśuddhe śodhaya viśodhaya hūṁ phaṭ svāhā |[11]
de nas sangs rgyas nyid kyis su/ / lha mo nyid la rab tu bstod/ /
“Then the goddess, who is herself The embodiment of buddhahood, is praised:[12]

thugs rje shin du che bas 'gro ba'i don mdzad ma/ / mtshan dang dpe byad rdzogs shing rin chen rgyan gyis spras/ / shin tu mdzes tshul 'dzum zhing bzhad pa'i bzhin/ / spyan gyi skye mched zar ma'i pad+ma 'dra/ /

“ ‘Lady who acts with immense compassion for the good of beings‍— You have all the major and minor marks and are bedecked with precious substances. Your smile is ravishing, your countenance is joyful, And your eyes are like flax blossoms.
snyan gyi skye mched ug cos bye ba 'dra/ / shangs kyi skye mched ad pal bum bu 'dra/ / zhal gyi skye mched ha lo rgyas pa 'dra/ / sna tshogs sku mnga' na chung mtshan ldan sku/ /
“ ‘Your ears are like blossoming trumpet flowers. Your nose is like a lotus bud. Your mouth is like a mallow in full bloom. You have a sparkling body and the figure of a young maiden.
chos kyi sgra sgrogs ka la ping ka'i gsung / / sems can kun la byams mgon thugs rje'i thugs/ / 'khor ba'i skyon gyis ma gos pad ma g.yon/ / sems can don rnams mdzad phyir skyabs sbyin g.yas/ /

“ ‘Your speech is like a kalaviṅka bird, proclaiming the Dharma. Your compassionate mind guards all beings with love. Your left hand holds a lotus, for you are unstained by saṃsāra’s flaws. Your right hand grants protection to all beings to fulfill their aims.
thabs dang shes rab nyi zla'i gdan la bzhugs/ / rje btsun sgrol ma la ni skyabs su mchi/ / 'khor ba'i g.yang sa che las bdag skyobs shig /
“ ‘You are seated on the sun and moon of method and wisdom. Venerable lady Tārā, we take refuge in you! Protect us from the great abyss of saṃsāra!
'gro drug rang kha'i gnas su 'khor ra re/ / thugs rje chen mo'i zhags pas bdag zung shig / ngan song gsum gyi gnas su sho ra re/ / 'khyams med pa'i lam du bdag chug shig /
“ ‘As we circle within the six transmigrations, May you secure us with your noose of great compassion. As we go astray into the three lower realms, May you place us on a path free from straying.
log par lta ba'i rigs su skyes sa re/ / bla ma byang sems mnga' dang bdag sprod cig / bshes gnyen ngan pa dag dang phrad da re'o/ /
“ ‘As we are born into families with wrong views, Please introduce us to teachers who possess the mind of awakening, Lest we encounter unwholesome teachers.

seng ge glang chen me dang sbrul/ / mi rgod chu dang rims rnams dang / / sha zas 'jigs pa brgyad po las/ / skyob mdzad khyed la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'jig rten 'di dang gzhan dag tu/ / 'jigs pa brgyad las bskyab tu gsol/ /

“ ‘You protect from the eight dangers‍— Lions, elephants, fire, snakes, Robbers, waters, infectious diseases, and demons. We pay homage to you! In this world and in others as well, Protect us from these eight dangers!

pha rol 'bras bu ma thob bar dag tu/ / sbyin dang tshul khrims bzod pa brtson 'grus dang / / bsam gtan shes rab thabs dang smon lam dang / / stobs dang de bzhin ye shes pha rol phyin/ / bcu po de dang mi 'bral 'grogs par shog /

“ ‘Until we have reached our goal, the other shore, May we make the ten perfections of generosity, moral conduct, Patience, diligence, concentration, insight, Method, aspiration, strength, and wisdom Our inseparable allies!’

rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la las chos 'di bri ba dang / bklag pa dang / kha thon dang / kun chub pa dang / tshul bzhin du yid la bya ba dang / gzhan dag la yang rgya chen bstan par bya'o zhes bka' stsal pa dang / thams cad dang ldan pa'i 'khor rnams yi rangs te mngon par bstod do/ /

“Sons and daughters of noble family should write down this teaching, read it, recite it, understand it, contemplate it correctly, and explain it extensively to others.” At her words, the whole assembly rejoiced and offered praise.
rje btsun ma sgrol ma 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob pa'i mdo' rdzogs s+ho// // yang zhus ste skar//
This completes the sūtra “Venerable Lady Tārā Who Protects from the Eight Dangers.”[13]

d.crumb: lha mo sgrol ma'i mtshan brgya rtsa brgyad pa

f.d: lha mo sgrol ma'i mtshan brgya rtsa brgyad pa

d.crumb: The Hundred and Eight Names of the Goddess Tārā

f.d: The Hundred and Eight Names of the Goddess Tārā
Translated by Samye Translations
@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ tA ra de bI nA ma aSh+Ta sha ta ka na/ bod skad du/ lha mo sgrol ma'i mtshan brgya rtsa brgyad pa zhes bya ba/
Tārādevīnāmāṣṭaśataka The Hundred and Eight Names of the Goddess Tārā
lha mo chen mo sgrol ma rnam par rgyal ba'i nor bu rnam pa sna tshogs kyi do shal dang / na bza' dang / sham thabs kyi gshal kas 'jig rten gyi khams chen po'i bla re byas pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the great goddess Tārā, the completely victorious jewel, who, with her exquisite necklace, garments, and lower robes, is a canopy for the great worldly realm.
de nas lha mo sgrol mas de'i tshe sngon ma mthong ma thos pa'i gzungs kyi mchog brjod pa/
At that time, the goddess Tārā uttered this supreme dhāraṇī, which had never been seen or heard before:

oM trai lo kya bi dza ya/ a tsit+ta dzA ya/ a ni ra tsi dza tA ya/ su dzA ya/ bi dzA ya/ ma hA dzA ya/ bi dzA ya/ dza ya dza ya/ he he/ sma ra sma ra/ ba ra ba ra/ bar da/ ma hA de bi/ bi la sa/ bi la sa/ bi la sa/ ba dza a mo ta ka ri bi dza ya de bi/ hI hI/ ki ni ki ni pi lam ba se/ sma ra sma ra/ ma hA pra dz+nyA a ni ba ta/ badzra ma ma hA kA ru Ni ka / b+ha gi ni hrUM hrUM/ s+phuT s+phuT/ s+pho Ta s+pho Ta/ A be sha ya/ A be sha ya/ d+hu na d+hu na/ bi d+hu na bi d+hu na/ kaM pa kaM pa/ kaM pa ya/ su ra b+hi gan+d+ha/ a ti si ta/ mu khe ha la da ba la/ saM ga rA dza na/ bi ma bi gi / bi nA sha ya/ bi nA sha ya/ he b+ha ga ba ti/ san+t+ra sa ya/ bi g+ha nA na/ pa ri ba lA ya/ a smA kaM a smA kaM/ mA da ni mA da ni/ saM bo d+ha ya/ saM mo ha ya/ ha ra ha ra/ hi ri hi ri/ hu ru hu ru/ bi ta ka ra/ ba ra dza/ haM haM/ tro tA ya/ haM haM/ san+t+ra tA ya/ san+t+ro ya/ man+ta man+ta/ maR+da maR+da/ tsa ra tsa ra/ saM tsa ra saM tsa ra/ be ga be ga be ga ba ti/ na mo na mo na maHswA hA/

oṁ trailokyavijaya | acittajaya | aniracijataya | sujaya | vijaya | mahājaya | vijaya[2] | jaya jaya | he he | smara smara | vara vara varada | mahādevi | vilasa | vilasa | vilasa | vaja amotakari vijayadevi | hī hī | kiṇi kiṇi[3] vilambase | smara smara | mahāprajñā anipata | vajramahākāruṇika[4] | bhagini hruṃ hruṃ | sphuṭa sphuṭa | sphoṭa sphoṭa | āveśaya āveśaya | dhuna dhuna | vidhuna vidhuna | kampa kampa | kampaya | surabhigandha | atisita | mukhe haladavala | saṃgarājana | vimavigi | vināśaya vināśaya | he bhagavati | santrāsaya[5] vighanān | parivalāya asmākaṃ asmākaṃ | mādani mādani | saṃbodhaya | saṃmohaya | hara hara | hiri hiri | huru huru | vitakara | varaja | haṃ haṃ | trotāya | haṃ haṃ | santratāya | santroya | manta manta | marda marda | cara cara | saṃcara saṃcara | vega vega vegavati | namo namo namaḥ svāhā |[6]

de nas lha dang lha min tshogs/ / srin po gnod sbyin mi'am ci/ / lto 'phye chen po'i tshogs rnams dang / / 'byung po dri za log 'dren rnams/ / 'jig rten gsum du grags pa'i mchog / gsang sngags chen po 'di thos nas/ / skrag cing mgo bo smad gyur te/ / lag pa chen po yongs bskyod nas/ /

Upon hearing this great mantra, Supremely renowned in the three realms, The assemblies of gods and asuras, Together with the hordes of rākṣasas, Yakṣas, kinnaras, mahoragas, Bhūtas, gandharvas, and vināyakas, Grew afraid and hung their heads low. With their mighty arms trembling, they said:
gang gis 'di nas sa gsum 'di/ / mtha' dag khyab par byas pa'i phyir/ / 'dod pa'i lha yi ngag bzlog pa/ / sgrol ma spyan yangs phyag 'tshal lo/ /
“Homage to you, Tārā, the broad-eyed one, Who turns away the speech of Kāmadeva, So that your names[7] may fill the three realms!
spyan ras gzigs kyi rigs smos pa/ / che ba nyid kyi grags pa 'od/ / spyan yangs khyod ni sems can rnams/ / phan bzhed slad du 'byung ba lags/ /
“Proclaimer of Avalokiteśvara’s lineage, Light renowned for its greatness, O broad-eyed one, You came into being to help sentient beings!”

de nas dbang phyug la sogs pa/ / lha dang lha min 'dus kun dang / / rig sngags 'chang gi bdag po dang / / de bzhin rig sngags 'chang ba rnams/ / bla gos phrag pa gcig gzar te/ / bskor ba mchog ni byas nas kyang / / pus mo'i lha nga sa steng du/ / btsugs nas tshig ni 'di skad smras/ /

Then, all the gods and asuras, Such as Śiva and the others, gathered together. The lords among vidyādharas And the vidyādharas themselves Draped their upper garments across their shoulders, Performed excellent circumambulations, and, Bending their knees to the ground, Spoke the following words:
sgrol ma 'od 'bar de la ni/ / phyag 'tshal phyag 'tshal phyag 'tshal lo/ / ming brgya rtsa brgyad dam pa yi/ / dpe med ming ni brjod par bgyi/ /
“O Tārā, goddess of blazing light, To you we pay homage! Homage! Homage to you! Your hundred and eight peerless and pristine names We will now recite:
bkra shis rnam rgyal dpal bzang ba/ / skye dgu'i dbang phyug mngon shes myur/ / dbang phyug rab dga' 'jigs la drag / rgod bag med cing dregs pa med/ /

“Glorious, exalted one, ever victorious and propitious, Your extrasensory powers are as swift as Prajāpati’s. Your fierceness instills fear in the Lord of Love,[8] Yet you are free of carelessness and conceit.
pad+ma'i spyan dang pad+ma'i zhal/ / pad+ma'i lte ba rab gtsang sbyin/ / spyan bzang spyan ni yangs pa ste/ / sngo ba ut+pal sngon po'i 'od/ /
“Your eyes, face, and navel Are lotus-like and exude purity. Your broad, beautiful eyes glow blue[9] Like the blue of the utpala flower.
skyob pa skyabs 'os bde ba sbyin/ / de bzhin stobs sbyin gzugs sbyin pa/ / mgon po mgon mdzad drag mo ste/ / dkon mchog gsum po rgyal mdzad ma/ /
“You protect all those worthy of care, Granting them happiness, strength, and beauty. Protector and fierce guardian, You enact the deeds of the Three Jewels.
