sgros dmar sen mo dmar ba ste/ / spyan rtsa dmar pos gzigs par mdzad/ / dga' mdzad dga' stobs pad+ma lags/ / pad+ma'i mdog can pad mdog dgyes/ /
“Your lips and fingernails shine red. With bloodshot eyes you gaze. Joyful, lotus-like force of joy, You are the color of the lotus, in whose hues you delight!
'jig rten gsum 'dul zhi ba ste/ / 'jigs pa'i cha lugs stobs mo che/ / 'dul du 'chug ma 'dul mdzad ma/ / bstod ldan mi mchog dam pa lags/ /
“With your extraordinary strength and frightful attire You tame and pacify the three worlds. Subduer who acts to tame beings, Noble one, you are praised as supreme among all.[10]
rab gsal 'dul ba rdo rje can/ / rnam par rgyal ba 'od gsal ba/ / byang chub rdul med dri ma med/ / zla ba lha mchog rnams kyi rjed/ /
“Holder of the vajra of resplendent clarity that tames beings, Utterly victorious clear light, You are awake, beyond taint or stain, And you are honored[11] by Candra and the outstanding gods.
sred bya dang ni sred bya'i bar/ / rgyu zhing gshegs la 'od zer mdzes/ / chu lha g.yul 'gyed 'gying bag can/ / skyes mchog rang bzhin yid 'phros rgyas/ /
“Your beautiful beams of light Pervade all objects of desire.[12] Majestic in your battle with Varuṇa, Supreme one, your mind is naturally expansive and pervasive.
gtsug phud gsum po lto tshil gsum/ / spyan gsum dri ma gsum sel ba/ / srid pa sel mdzad khong dge ba/ / tshig ldan mar yang de bzhin grags/ /

“With your triple crown ornament, three belly folds,[13] and three eyes You clear away the three defilements. Dispeller of phenomenal existence, lady of deep virtue, You are also renowned for your eloquence.
rgyal ba sbyin pa bsod nams sbyin/ / sdig pa 'joms ma 'jigs pa med/ / nor sbyin mdog sbyin zhi ba ma/ / gzugs bzang phyal bzang nu ma bzang / /
“You grant victory and merit And fearlessly vanquish evil. Lady of peace who grants wealth and luster, Your form, belly, and bosom are most elegant!
sgyu 'phrul sgyu 'phrul ldan zhing 'dul/ / dul ba bsrung pa rdul sel ba/ / phreng ba thogs ma rgyags mdzad ma/ / rgyags pa sbyin ma dregs spong ma/ /
“Lady of illusion who tames the field of illusory displays,[14] You uphold discipline and dispel all impurity. Holding a garland, you bring elation, Grant exhilaration,[15] and remove all conceit.
drag mo lags te gzi bskyed ma/ / dkar mo zhi mdzad bde ba mo/ / skye dgu'i bdag mo tshangs par ldan/ / tshangs sbyin dbang phyug dam pa lags/ /
“Wrathful lady who inspires splendor, White lady of bliss who brings peace, Sovereign lady of all living beings, noble and mighty goddess, You hold and bestow sacred knowledge.[16]
zla ba'i 'od can zla ba'i zhal/ / zla ba'i gzi ni 'phrog par mdzad/ / nyi ma'i gzi 'phrog dgyes pa mo/ / yid 'ong bzang zhing zhi ba mo/ /
“Your moon-like face glows with moonlight, Stealing away the moon’s own effulgence. Lady who delights in robbing the radiance of the sun, You are beautiful, exalted, and wholly at peace!
bde ba bde ldan mu dang stegs/ / bkra shis bgegs rnams sel mdzad ma/ / nor spel bsod nams rnam par rgyal/ / 'dzam bu'i chu bo gser dngul 'od/ /

“Blissful[17] steppingstone to happiness, You remove all that stands in the way of good fortune. You make wealth increase and merit ever-victorious. You gleam like gold and silver from the Jambu River.
'jigs pa sel ba 'jigs med sbyin/ / sgrol ma lags te zla ba'i zhal/ / sems can kun la med mi 'gyur/ / mchod gnas phyag gnas dga' mdzad ma/ /
“Dispeller of fears and bestower of fearlessness, You are Tārā; your face is like the moon. You never stray far from any sentient being. You bring joy and are worthy of worship and homage.
cha lugs sngo ba cha lugs bzang / / rgyan dmar rgyan du thogs pa ste/ / na bza' gser mnabs gang ga ma/ / dkar mo 'bar ba rnam par gzigs/ /
gi'u wang gi thig le spos/ / 'khor ldan rdo rje chu lha nyid/ / dkyil 'khor mchog mnga' 'jigs mdzad ma/ / tshems dkar bzhad cing tshems dkar 'dzum/ /
“Fragrant as a ball of bezoar, You are the adamantine Varuṇa and retinue. Fearsome lady, queen of the supreme maṇḍala, With your white teeth you laugh and smile.
dpung rgyan snyan cha gdub 'khor thogs/ / do shal 'bar ba'i chun po can/ / 'og pag bzang ldan zhal bzang ma/ / grogs ni nim pa'i lo ma thogs/ /

“You wear armlets, earrings, and bracelets And are wreathed in glimmering crystal necklaces. Lady with a face of beauty, wearing a superb sash, You are accompanied by the one who holds a sprig of neem leaves.[18]
nor bu'i cod pan nor bu 'chang / / nor bu'i rgyan rnams rgyan du thogs/ / nor bu'i 'od zer snang ba can/ / nor bu'i dkyil 'khor rgyan mnga' ba/ /
“You wear a jeweled diadem, hold a jewel, And are adorned with jeweled ornaments. You are adorned with a band of beautiful gems, And sparkle like precious stones.
'bar ba'i mdog mnga' rdo rje can/ / skyes pa bud med sad par mdzad/ / zhi ba dbyig thogs mche ba can/ / tshangs pa'i shugs can rlung dang ldan/ /
“Vajra lady, you radiate with blazing colors, Awakening men and women both. Fanged one who wields the rod[19] of peace, You are as strong as Brahmā and as swift as the wind.[20]
bud med lags te mkha' las gshegs/ / lha mo mchog gi 'od 'phrog ma/ / 'od dang ldan pa 'dod pas 'dul/ / 'dod pa'i khro bo rab 'joms ma/ /
“You are the woman who descends from the sky And shines with the light of a supreme goddess.[21] Luminous one who conquers through desire, You have vanquished the torment of desire.
drag po thor tshugs gtsug pud can/ / tshangs pa tshangs pa'i gsung ldan rgyal/ / bing ka'i skad 'dra pheg bzang ma/ / 'jig rten dbang phyug rigs mchog skyes/ /

“Wrathful one with a topknot and diadem, victorious one, You are Brahmā and have the speech of Brahmā. Your beautiful voice rings like the call of the kalaviṅka.[22] Sovereign of the world, you are born within the supreme family!
dbyig pa'i shing lo rdo rje thogs/ / drag mo rin chen 'od kyis brgyan/ / gshegs na snyan cha dri med g.yo/ / gshin rje ba yi yid la 'jug /

“Fierce lady adorned with the resplendence of jewels And holding a staff with adamantine leaves, Your immaculate earrings sway as you move. Such is how you dawn in the minds of those in Yama’s realm.[23]
rig sngags 'chang ma gzugs 'chang ma/ / stobs lnga stobs dang ldan par mdzad/ / stobs dang stobs med mnga' ba ste/ / shes rab mtshon gyis gcod par mdzad/ /
“You are the one taking the form of a vidyādharī. You are endowed with five strengths and bestow strength. Wielding strength as well as absence of strength,[24] You cut with the blade of wisdom.
sgyu rtsal lags te sgyu rtsal ldan/ / de bzhin brjod dang smra ba lags/ / steng nas khyams dang khyams bzang tshul/ / tsam pa ka yi chun pos gsal/ /
“You are crafty and full of art, And your voice resounds mightily, Like a bouquet of campaka flowers Brightens a courtyard or hall from above.[25]
ser mo tsan pa legs pa'i rten/ / drag mo phyag na chun po thogs/ / skal ba bzang mo gshal ka can/ / de bzhin shin tu shas cher dgyes/ /
Wrathful one, you hold a bouquet in your hand And are an excellent support for yellow-clad monastics.[26] Fortunate one, you are decked in ornaments[27] And experience great delight.
rigs mtshan shin tu stobs dang ldan/ / rdo rje khro bo dga' mdzad ma/ / bde ldan blo ldan rdo rje'i thabs/ / blo mdzad shes rab skyed par mdzad/ /
“Vajra fury who brings joy, You are endowed with the signs and great strength of your lineage. With your bliss, intelligence, and adamantine means, You bestow understanding[28] and increase wisdom.
lha mo lam me cod pan can/ / lha rnams kun las tshul lhag pa/ / sred med bu mo sdig pa sel/ / bkra shis ngo tsha shes dang dgyes/ /
“Goddess of the resplendent diadem, Your manner is greater than all the gods. As Nārāyaṇī, you dispel negativity, And you delight in auspiciousness and modesty.
rab tu dga' ma 'grogs na dga'/ / spyod tshul dga' la dga' dang ldan/ / dga' ma dga' bar mdzad pa ste/ / chos rnams kun gyi legs pa'i rten/ /

“Lady of gladness, you delight all who associate with you And you delight in those who delight in wholesome conduct. Delightful lady who exudes delight, You are an excellent support for all qualities.[29]
sangs rgyas sprul pa sbrul mdzad ma/ / nga rgyal sel bar mdzad pa ste/ / las dang nyon mongs rab 'joms shing / / 'dod pa'i sde rnams rab 'joms ma/ /
“Lady who emanates buddha emanations, And who works to dispel pride, You destroy karma and afflictions, And conquer all forms of desire.
shes pa bcu mnga' sangs rgyas pa/ / pha rol phyin pa bcu la gnas/ / sa bcu dag la mnga' brnyes pa/ / stobs rnams bcu bos cher gsal ma/ /
“You are a buddha with the ten knowledges, And you uphold the ten perfections. You have reached the ten grounds, And shine bright with the light of the ten strengths.
rdo rje cod pan rdo rje 'chang / / rdo rje phra mo lha min sel/ / dus kyi rdo rje rab tu rgyags/ / rdo rje lcags kyu bde dang dpal/ /
“You wear a vajra diadem and wield a vajra. With your subtle vajra you clear away asuras. With the vajra of time[30] you bring elation, And you wield the vajra hook of bliss and glory.
rdo rje zhags pa zhags ba bzang / / sgeg mo rdo rje phyag na bsnams/ / yid 'ong yid la tshim par mdzad/ / pha rol bgegs rnams sel mdzad ma/ /
“Charming lady who holds a vajra in her hand And wields a vajra lasso, an excellent lasso, You are captivating; you bring satisfaction to the mind, And you dispel all opponents and obstacle makers.
tshim mdzad shas cher bde ba ste/ / rol cing gar thabs ston par mdzad/ / chos can ha la ha la'i 'od/ / chos sbyin rnam par gzigs pa lags/ /
“You bring about contentment and great happiness, And reveal the way of play and dance. Rich in Dharma, you have the radiance of halāhala. Giver of the Dharma, your gaze is vast.
khyod ni rdo rje 'phro ba dang / / bdud rtsi rdo rjer brjod pa ste/ / rdo rje 'bar ba stobs mo che/ / lha mo chen mo khyod phyag 'tshal/ /
“You are a vajra emanation, And are said to be vajra nectar. Great goddess, powerful with a blazing vajra, To you we pay homage!
bdag cag rnams kyis bstod pa yis/ / mtshan brgya rtsa brgyad mchog 'di brjod/ / kye kye bcom ldan mchog nyid ni/ / smra ba rnams kyi mchog lags gsung / /
“With this praise of ours, We recite your hundred and eight sublime names. Amazing! The supreme Blessed One herself[31] Has spoken the most sublime of utterances.”[32]
de nas zla ba'i 'od 'dra zhing / / 'bar la 'phro bar ldan pa yi/ / lha mo sgrol ma brjid bag can/ / 'dzum bzhin du ni rab smras pa/ /
Then, the magnificent goddess Tārā, Who is like the light of the moon And blazes with radiance, Revealed a smile and spoke:

dbang phyug chen po la sogs kun/ / nga yi tshig ni mnyan par gyis/ / thams cad rtag tu mthun par ni/ / stobs bcu dag la brtson par gyis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshul chen yang / / dus kun tu ni bsrung bar gyis/ / zhi ba'i lam la dmigs pas ni/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho mi bzad cing / / 'jigs pa chen po'i gzhir gyur pa/ / rgal dka' khyed kyis rgal bar gyis/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i grong khyer la/ / dmigs nas brtson te 'jug par gyis/ /

“Maheśvara and the rest of you, Listen now to my words. Always be agreeable with everyone As you strive to attain the ten strengths. At all times, protect the great way Of the thus-gone ones. Keeping your minds on the path of peace, You must cross over the unbearable ocean of cyclic existence, Which is the source of great terrors And is so difficult to ford. Setting your mind upon the city of nirvāṇa, You must strive for it and enter it.”
de nas nyi 'od 'bar ba yi/ / phreng ba lta bu mdzes pa'i zhal/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'brug gi sgra/ / 'dra ba'i tshig ni bka' stsal pa/ /
Then Tārā, whose face is as beautiful As a garland of the sun’s blazing rays, Spoke the following words Like the rumbling thunder of the Thus-Gone One:
kye ma rig sngags sgrol ma'i mchog / mun pa sel bar byed pa dang / / mthu stobs rgya chen skyed byed pa/ / sgrib pa thams cad gcod byed pa/ /
“O wonder! This excellent vidyāmantra of Tārā Clears away all darkness, Creates immense power and strength, And cuts through all obscurations.
tshogs rnams skyed pa'i gzi brjid kyis/ / dag par byas pa ma yin pas/ / shas cher dga' bar byed pa yi/ / gzungs 'di thos par mi 'gyur ro/ /
“This dhāraṇī, which brings so much joy, Will not be heard by the masses Who have not purified themselves By cultivating inner confidence.
sngon chad sangs rgyas brtson byas pa'i/ / brtan po gzi brjid dag rnams la/ / dam tshig chen po rig sngags kyi/ / dam tshig 'di ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
“This great samaya, the samaya of this vidyāmantra, Will arise for those Who have developed stable confidence, From their prior efforts toward buddhahood.

nyon mongs mtha' dag rab 'joms shing / / sdig pa thams cad sel byed pa/ / sems can thams cad rab 'byed pa'i/ / gzungs sngags rdo rje mchog 'dzin pa/ / su zhig mnyam par bzhag pa yis/ / nyan tam 'chang ngam klog byed na/ / rang byung gis ni gsungs pa bzhin/ / de yi don kun grub par 'gyur/ /

“Whoever upholds this sublime, indestructible dhāraṇī-mantra, Which quells all afflictions, Eliminates all negativity, And nurtures all beings‍—[33] Whoever, in meditative equipoise, Hears it, reads it, or keeps it in mind‍— Will accomplish all their aims As was stated by the Self-Arisen One.
nyon mongs kun las rnam grol zhing / / sems can kun las lhag pa'i mchog / 'jig rten dag tu chos shes la/ / 'dzud pa'i de bzhin gshegs dang mtshungs/ /
“They will be liberated from all affliction, Become the most excellent of sentient beings, And will be equal to the thus-gone ones Who are immersed in knowledge of every world’s phenomena.
su zhig ming brgya rtsa brgyad 'di/ / 'don zhing sgrol ma zla ba'i zhal/ / de bzhin stod byed de dag ni/ / sangs rgyas nyid kyang thob par 'gyur/ /
“Whoever chants these hundred and eight names And praises Tārā’s moon-like face in this way Will reach buddhahood itself.
de yi don kyang grub 'gyur zhing / / rgyal po rnams dang stobs chen mi/ / gzhan yang sems can bgrang ba gang / / thams cad de yi dbang du 'gyur/ /
They will accomplish all their aims And gain control over kings, powerful people, And any number of other beings.
lha mo sgrol ma zhal bzang ba'i/ / ming brgya rtsa brgyad grags pa 'di/ / 'jig rten dag na rgyags pa dang / / nyon mongs mi rigs kun sel ba'o/ /
“This praise, known as The Hundred and Eight Names of the Goddess Tārā with a Lovely Face, Fills the many worlds And dispels all afflictions and everything untoward!

de nas bdud ris gyen du g.yos pa'i ri bo 'khrug byed pa/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ri bo mchog dang 'dra ba'i sku mnga' ba/ / 'od gsal lha dang mi rnams legs par sad par mdzad pa po/ / rgyal sras thu bo rnams kyis khyab par stobs kyis brten pa yis/ /
“Her body, which is like the supreme mountain of thus-gone ones, Shakes the mountain ascended by the clans of māras. She is the light that fully awakens gods and humans.
gsung rab rtag tu tshogs chen brda sprod la/ / don chen grags shing phan phyir zhugs pa gang / / rab des chos de dang ni sdud byed dang / / de bzhin khyad par sems pa'i rims sel bas/ /

“This eminent one is renowned for her profound dedication To the great collection of well-spoken teachings Ceaselessly transmitted by the most eminent of the Victor’s heirs Through their stability in the unique[34] powers. Appearing for the benefit of all, she condenses this Dharma, And thus expertly soothes the fevers of the mind.”
bzod med nyon mongs sel ba dang / / zhi ba'i yid ni skyed pa'i tshig / rgyal ba'i mchog gis bka' stsal nas/ / gzhes par gyur te mi gsung bzhugs/ /
After these words that dispel unbearable afflictions, And which produce a tranquil mind, Were spoken by the supreme Victor, Tārā remained still and did not speak further.

de nas sgrol mchog lha mos gtsor gyur dga' bar byed cing yid 'phrog la/ / dga' ba rgya chen skyed cing tshe dang bde sbyin bstan pa'i tshig thos pas/ / lha tshogs lha min tshogs bcas mtha' dag dga' bas rgyas shing rmad byung nas/ / rab tu dga' zhing spyi bos thal mo sbyar te smra ba zhi bar gyur/ /

Astonished and enraptured by the sublime goddess Tārā, The entire assembly of devas and asuras was filled with joy and wonder Upon hearing these instructive words that evoke deep joy and grant happiness and long life. Overjoyed, they joined their hands above their heads as their speech was stilled.
sgrol ma'i mchog ces bya ba'i gzungs te lha mo sgrol ma'i mtshan brgya rtsa brgyad pa rdzogs so// //
This completes the dhāraṇī named “Supreme Tārā, the Hundred and Eight Names of the Goddess Tārā.”

d.crumb: 'phags ma sgrol ma ku ru ku l+le'i rtog pa/

f.d: 'phags ma sgrol ma ku ru ku l+le'i rtog pa/

d.crumb: The Practice Manual of Noble Tārā Kurukullā

f.d: The Practice Manual of Noble Tārā Kurukullā
Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ Ar+ya tA re ku ru kul+le kalpa/ bod skad du/ 'phags ma sgrol ma ku ru ku l+le'i rtog pa/
'phags pa 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to noble Mañjuśrī, the youthful one.
Chapter 1

'phags ma lha mo sgrol ma la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rnal 'byor rgya mtsho'i rgyud kyi ni/ / gzhung dang rtog pa nyams shing nub par gyur nas yang / / sgrol ma 'byung ba'i ting 'dzin zhes bya rgyud kyi gtso/ / de yang nub par gyur nas rtog pa 'di yang 'byung / /

Homage to the noble goddess, Tārā. The tantra of The Arising of Tārā is an ocean of yogic practice. Although its scripture and practice manual had declined and disappeared, There was The Meditative Absorption of Tārā, chief among tantras. Once that, too, became lost, this practice manual appeared.
sems can mang po'i don du rnal 'byor pa/ / rgyas par bstan pa'i rgyud las bsdus byas nas/ / rtog pa 'di ni 'jig rten dbang phyug gsungs/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mnyan par gyis/ /
For the sake of many beings, and as a compendium of the tantras That elaborately teach the yogic practices, Lokeśvāra, Lord of the World, taught this manual of practice. Listen, all bodhisattvas!
'jig rten skyabs med gyur la rnam bltas nas/ / 'gro kun don byed pa yi tshul 'di ni/ / sdug bsngal gsum gyis sdug bsngal gyur bltas nas/ / gus pa chen pos khyod kyis blang b.rabyos/ /
This method that benefits all beings Is based on seeing that the world is without refuge, And tormented by the three types of suffering. Receive this with great reverence!

'jig rten rnam rtog zhi bar bya phyir rtog pa 'di/ / sangs rgyas thams cad kyis ni rab tu gsungs/ / dpal ldan gru 'dzin ri la 'jam dpal dang / / pad+ma bsnams dang rgyal bar byed pa dang / /
sgrib pa rnam sel blo gros rgya mtsho dang / / byams pa la sogs tshogs rnams thams cad kyis/ / gang yang chos kyi tshig 'di thos gyur nas/ / rjes su yi rang spyi bos gus phyag byas/ /

In order to pacify the concepts of the world, All buddhas teach this manual of practice. On the holy Potala mountain, Mañjuśrī, Padmapāṇi, Jaya, Sarvanivaraṇaviṣkambhin, Sāgaramati, Maitreya, and others‍—the full gathering‍— All heard these words of the Dharma, Rejoiced, and bowed their heads to the ground in veneration.

rgyal ba'i sras kyis mnga' byas bstod pa 'am/ / yang na glu dang dbyangs dag byas pa yis/ / sna tshogs gar gyis 'di ni mchod pa byas/ / gnod sbyin srin po yi dgas 'jig rten dang / /
sna tshogs bu mo dang ni rgyu skar dang / / sa yi dbang dang lag na rdo rje dang / / rlabs rnams sna tshogs can gang gnas pa yi/ / klu yi bu mo zur gyis blta bas lta ba dang / /

The children of the victorious ones mastered it and praised it; They worshiped it with song, melody, And various types of dance. Yakṣas, rākṣasas, the world of ghosts, Various maidens, the heavenly bodies, Thunderbolt bearers, lords of the earth, Nāga girls who live in the billowing seas Where they cast coquettish glances,

sa 'og skyong dang lha dbang grub pa'i bu mos mchod/ / dri za'i rgyal mo nu ma shin tu rgyas pa dang / / rig pa 'dzin dang mi 'am ci yi chung ma dang / / gnod sbyin chung ma ri yi bu mo'i bu dag ni/ /
gang yin bdag dang skyabs med ces ni 'di skad smra/ / gang phyir skyabs med skyabs gyur sangs rgyas bstan pa 'dir/ / mgon med mgon gyur 'jig rten mgon po khyod/ / bde ba bskyed cing ngo mtshar che gyur gang / /

The guardians of the nether world, and the daughters of the surasiddhas‍—these all worshiped. Gandharva queens with eye-catching breasts, Female knowledge holders, kinnarīs, Himavat’s daughters, as well as others, all spoke in this way: “For us there is no refuge. Yet this teaching of the Buddha is the refuge for those who have none. Protector of those without a refuge, protector of the world, You engender bliss and great wonder about this teaching.”
mgon po tshogs kyi tshig dbang 'di thos nas/ / nyid kyi dbang du byed pa'i gsang sngags gsungs/ / sngags kyi rgyal po bud med kun thos pas/ / mthar thug sangs rgyas bde ba du ma 'byung / /

The Lord, hearing these words of the assembly, Pronounced the secret mantra, which he himself mastered, And upon hearing this king of mantras, all the females there Experienced numerous forms of the bliss of final buddhahood.
rdo rje reg pas khams kyang 'dzag par 'gyur/ / zur gyis lta bar byed pas lta byed cing / / rkang pa dag kyang sa la gya tshom 'dor/ / 'dod chags shin tu bde bas khu 'bab tshe/ /

By the touch of the vajra their bodies released the juice, And casting sidelong glances, They impatiently stamped their feet on the ground. Carried away by the bliss of passion, they let their juices flow.
'di ltar mthong nas lha yi bu mo la/ / 'gro ba dbang byed ku ru kul+le'i sngags/ / ras ris bri dang gsang sngags bsgrub pa'i phyir/ / dus la bab pa'i tshig 'di mgon smros zhes/ /

May the Protector observe this and dispense Timely words to these celestial girls‍— The mantra of Kurukullā that enthralls wandering beings‍— And the practice of painting in combination with this mantra.

de ltar bcom ldan 'jig rten mgon pos gsungs/ / de tshe 'jig rten dbang phyug las rnams rab tu gsungs/ / ku ru kul+le'i ri mo'i lugs/ / gang zhig bris pa tsam gyis ni/ /
sgrub pa po yis 'bras thob pa/ / de nas yang dag bshad par bya/ / ri mo mkhan ni gang zhig gis/ / tshes grangs gang dang dus gang la/ /

When the Blessed One, the Protector of the World, had proclaimed his intent, He, the Master of the World, began to teach the stages of the ritual: The method for creating an image of Kurukullā, The mere painting of which Brings fruition to the practitioner, I will now explain in full. Who can create the picture? On which day of the month and at which hour?

sgrol ma 'byung las bshad pa bzhin/ / de ni bdag gis bshad par bya/ / ri mo mkhan ni gang zhig gis/ / gang gi mig ni dmar 'gyur zhing / /
lag pa de bzhin rkang pa dmar/ / bya yi mig can e n+ya'i rkang / / des ni sgrol ma bri bar bya/ / dpyid kyi zla ba dang po yi/ /

That I shall now explain In accordance with the prescriptions of The Arising of Tārā. The one who paints the picture Should have reddish eyes, As well as red hands and feet, Eyes like those of a bird, and the legs of a black antelope. It is such a person who shall draw the Savioress. In the first month of spring,

mya ngan med pa'i tshes brgyad nyin/ / thun ni phyed dang gnyis pa la/ / sgrol ma'i mig ni bri bar bya/ / mngar gsum bza' zhing nya la sogs/ /
sha dang chang yang spang bar bya/ / dmar po'i gos kyang rtag tu bgo/ / dmar po'i dri yis rtag tu byug / byams pa'i sems ni bskyed byas la/ /

On the eighth day of Caitra, Halfway through the second watch‍— This is when the eyes of Tārā should be drawn. The artist must eat the three sweets And abstain from fish, meat, and alcohol. Always dressed in red, He must be smeared with a red fragrant paste. Having brought forth a mind of loving-kindness,

tho rangs khrus byas bsangs nas su/ / lan gsum gos ni brjes nas su/ / dbang du byed ma yang dag bri/ / zhal gcig mig ni yangs pa dang / /
phyag bzhi ma la gur gum mdog / bcu drug lo lon sgeg bcas 'dra/ / bud med sgyu mas rgyags pa bri/ /

He should bathe at dawn in a sanctified location. Then, having changed into a garment of three pieces, He should correctly draw The Enchantress: Single-faced, with elongated eyes, Four-armed and of the color of kunkuma, Sixteen years old and displaying an amorous sentiment, And puffed up with pride on account of her magical feminine charm.

gzhon nu ma dmar ser mos byas pa'i skud pa las ras byas la/ de dang thags mkhan gnyis ka zan dang 'o ma bza' bar bya zhing / de nas pad+ma'i gdan la stod g.yogs dmar po'i gos dang bcas pas rin po che'i rna cha dang / rin po che'i cod pan dang / g.yas pas mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa dang / gnyis pas mda' sna rtser 'gengs pa/ g.yon pas gzhu 'dzin pa dang / ut+pal dmar po gnyis pa na bsnams pa dang / 'od dpag med cod pan na bzhugs pa ri'i phug na gnas pa'i ku ru kul+le'o/ / ku ru kul+le'i 'og tu ni sgra gcan 'dzin no/ / de'i steng du 'dod pa'i dbang phyug chung ma dang bcas pa'o/ / 'dod pa'i lha'i steng du zla ba'i dkyil 'khor ro/ / de la pad+ma dmar po'i gdan no/ / de la gnas pa'i sna tshogs pa'i cha byad can gyi bcom ldan 'das ma bris la/ ras ris rab tu gnas par bya'o/ / de'i mdun du mchod pa rnam pa bcwa brgyad byas la/ yar gyi ngo'i tshes brgyad zla ba nya'i bar du bzlas pa bya'o/ / sgrol ma'i snying po ni 'di yin te/

The canvas should be woven with thread spun by a female of fair complexion. Both she and the weaver should eat milk-porridge. Upon a lotus seat, wearing an upper garment of red cloth, jewel earrings, and a jewel diadem, she displays the mudrā granting fearlessness with her lower right hand, and with her second right hand holds an arrow that she draws to the tip of her ear.[3] In her upper left hand she holds a bow, and in the second left, a red utpala. Crowned by Amitābha, dwelling in a cave in the mountains, she is Kurukullā. Below Kurukullā is Rāhu, and above him, Kāmadeva with his spouse. Above Kāmadeva there is a moon disk, and upon the moon disk a red lotus seat. On this seat one must paint the Blessed Lady with all her beautiful features, and then consecrate her image. In front of the painting, from the eighth through the full moon day, one should perform the eighteenfold pūjā, and recite the mantra. This is the heart essence of Tārā:
oM ku ru ku l+le hrIHhU~M swA hA
oṃ kurukulle hrīḥ hūṃ svāhā

zhes bya ba'i sngags so/ / de nas sngon du bsnyen pa 'bum tsam byas la/ yang ston zla tha chungs sam/ dpyid zla 'bring po'am/ dbyar zla 'bring po'i sangs rgyas la mchod pa'i dus tshigs kyi nyin par tho rangs kyi khrus byas la gso sbyong bzung nas mchod pa thams cad kyis mchod la/ nyan thos kyi dge 'dun la mchod ston gsol/ / de nas theg pa chen po'i gsang sngags pa'i tshogs la mchod ston byas nas yon phul la/ pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs nas/ bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas/ ji ltar 'dod pa'i dngos grub blang bar bya'o/ / nyan thos kyi dge 'dun gang na bzhugs pa dang / theg pa chen po la dga' ba'i tshogs rnams la phyag byas nas bzod par gsol te/ gang na bcom ldan 'das ma'i ras ris bkram pa'i phyogs der nye bar song la/ dngos grub gang 'dod pa'i don du rig pa 'dzin pas bsam gtan dang ldan par gnas la yi ge grangs kyi 'bum bzlas pa bya'o/ /

This is the mantra. Having done the preliminary propitiation consisting of one hundred thousand recitations, next, on a buddha-day in the month of Kārttika, Vaiśakha, or Āṣāḍha, having bathed at dawn and observed the restoration of vows ceremony, the practitioner should offer a complete pūjā. He should present a feast for the congregation of listeners, and next offer a feast with gifts for the community of those practicing the secret mantra of the Great Vehicle. Placing his right knee on the ground, and with his robe thrown over one shoulder, he should receive the desired accomplishments. He should salute and ask the pardon of the saṅgha of listeners and the community of those who delight in the Great Vehicle. Having gone to the place where the painting of the Blessed Lady is displayed, this knowledge holder should, for the sake of the desired accomplishments, enter meditation and recite the mantra one hundred thousand times for each of its syllables.
cha gcig gis ni shes rab 'phel/ / cha gnyis kyis ni dbang du byed/ / gang zhig cha ni gsum pa yis/ / mis ni dug kyang 'gugs par 'gyur/ /
myos shing 'gying ba'i bud med rnams dang ni/ / 'jig rten thams cad kyis ni mchod par 'gyur/ / sbyor ba goms pas lha mo mdzes rnams la/ / sngags 'chang des ni ci ltar 'dod par spyod/ /
By mad and haughty women, and by the entire world, This practitioner will be honored. Because of familiarity with the practice, this mantra holder May do as he wishes with beautiful goddesses.

de yi ming tsam gyis ni mtshungs med dug can 'bros pa dang / / gdengs ka'i gtso bo'i 'od kyis dpal ldan dag kyang nya bzhin 'gyur/ / bzlas brjod ldan pa yi ni ngag gi dbang phyug byed 'gyur bas/ / rig pas 'gying ba'i stobs dang ldan pa'i mkhas pa'ang lan med byed/ /

The mere sound of his name will cause those of incomparable poison to flee, And even those as brilliant as the leader of the hooded will become just like a fish. Those who engage in recitation, by means of their power of speech, Render speechless even the experts who possess the majestic power of spells.

rig pa 'dzin pa glang po rta yi rgyab tu zhon pa dang / / rig ma mdzes mas legs par 'khyud cing mgul nas 'jus pa las/ / sngags rig pa yi gtso bo yi ni stobs kyis rgyal bar 'gyur/ / mthar gyur pa yi rgyal srid longs spyod dag la yid kyis spyod/ /

Holders of mantra, who ride elephants and horses, Embraced by their beautiful consorts who clasp their necks‍— These are conquered by the power of the best among mantra-adepts. Their minds partake of the pleasures of perfect kingdoms.

'dod pa'i lha las dga' ba'i bu la sogs pa ri khrod ma/ / sred med bu las dpa' mo mi phyed pa las bde sogs dang / / tshogs bdag las ni dri med dbyangs kyi dbang phyug dkar mo dang / / sa 'dzin lha las phun tshogs mnga' ba sngags kyis rnam rgyal byed/ /

Rati from Kāmadeva and Pārvatī from Śiva;[4] Similarly, Śrī from Nārāyaṇa, Śacī from Ākhaṇḍala, The white Amalagīśvariṇī from Vācaspati, and Lakṣmī from the Sustainer of the Earth‍— These they win by means of the mantra.

gsang sngags ldan par bcom ldan 'das ma gang zhig sgom byed pa/ / des ni sna tshogs gter dang gser dang dngul dang rna cha dang / / gos la sogs pa'i nor rnams kun la ched du gang bsams pa/ / sems kyis thams cad ma lus kun nas longs spyod byed/ /

Those who possess the mantra and meditate on the Blessed Lady Will gain various treasures, gold, silver, earrings, Garments, and other such wealth. Their minds will partake of whatever they wish for, without exception.

rgyal las rgyal srid dbang po'i yul 'das shing las 'bras bu dang / / klu dang chu klung rgya mtsho rnams las chu rnams 'gugs/ / sngags dang ldan pas 'thung zhing zas la sngags kyis dag par byed/ / skye bo sngags med par ni longs spyod grub pa med/ /

Having taken the kingdom from the king, the fruit from the tree that transcends the senses, And the waters from the nāgas, rivers, and oceans, Absorbed in the mantra, they drink and eat while purifying through the mantra. For people without the mantra, no enjoyment can be won.
nags skyes glang po rta mchog ri dgas dang ldan pa/ / dug bcas gdengs ka can gyi sbrul mchog dang / / chu srin chu glang stag dang bse dag dang / / rang gi sngags kyi stobs kyis bkug nas ni/ /

zhon yang ngo mtshar med par byas pa yi ni mig dag gis/ / lta bar gal te gsang sngags grub pa de yis mthong bar 'gyur/ / gal te snying rje'i lta bas 'jig rten 'di ltar sdug bsngal bas/ / rgud par gyur pa'i mi mnyam pa la bsngags pa des/ /
yid bzhin nor bu bzhin du 'jig rten la phan sgron ma yin/ / 'jig rten ma lus sgron mer byed cing zhi bar byed/ / bdud rnams bcom nas nor gyi char rgyun 'bebs par byed/ / dpag bsam shing du gyur nas 'gro rnams ci 'dod sbyin par byed/ /

If also they look with eyes free from wonder, The mantra-adepts will thereby see. If with the eye of compassion mantra-adepts regard the world, Which is stricken by all sorts of suffering, They will become Tārā,[5] benefiting the world like the wish-fulfilling jewel. The entire world will become of Tārā[6] and know peace. Having overcome the demons, they bring down a rain of wealth; As a wish-fulfilling tree, they grant beings whatever they wish for.

nor gyi dbang phyug ma lus pa yi nor rnams kun bkug nas/ / sems can kun la phan pa'i phyir du sbyin par byed/ / de bzhin phongs pa'i 'jig rten rnams kyi ched du gos dag dang / / stan dang khyim dang bla re dag tu sgrol mas mdzad pa dang / /

Having drawn to them all the riches of the lords of wealth without exception, They give it away for the benefit of all beings. Likewise, for the benefit of the destitute in the world Tārā creates clothes, seats, homes, and parasols.
rgya mtsho'i gling du tshong ba'i gru zhig gyur pa'i phongs pa la/ / gzings dang gru la sogs par sgrol mas mdzad par 'gyur/ / sgrol ma de bsgoms rnal 'byor pa/ / dang po sdug bsngal lhan cig gyur/ /
For those suffering on islands, due to the wreckage of their merchant vessels, Tārā creates boats, ships, and so on. The yogins who meditate on this Tārā Will first experience some suffering.
de spangs nas ni cung zhig na/ / mis ni ston mo rnyed par 'gyur/ / gnyis par gos ni rnyed par 'gyur/ / de bzhin btsun mo dang yang 'phrad/ /
Yet once that is over, such people Will soon discover feasts. Next they will acquire garments, Just as they will meet with noble women.
de nas so rtsi longs spyod 'gyur/ / ma blangs par yang ci 'dod spyod/ / gal te tshangs spyod yin na yang / / lha mchog bskyed pa'i bu mo spyod/ /
Then they will enjoy the betel. That which they wish for will be obtained without asking. Even if one is celibate, One may engage with a woman of supreme, celestial birth.

sems can gsod la dga' ba yis/ / bstan pa 'di la 'grub mi 'gyur/ / dge ba bcu la dga' 'gyur zhing / / theg pa che la sems gcig pas/ / rdo rje chos kyi bka' bzhin du/ / dngos grub mchog ni des spyod 'gyur/ /

Those who take pleasure in killing sentient beings Will not succeed in this discipline. Those who delight in the ten virtues, And are single-minded in their devotion to the Great Vehicle, Will, in accordance with Vajradharma’s words, Hereby experience the supreme accomplishment.
'di ni ras ris la 'jug pa'i rtog pa ste dang po'o// //
This was the first chapter, the instructions for the practice of painting.
Chapter 2
chos mchod pa yi sbyor ba yis/ / gang gi chos nyid brnyes gyur na/ / chos kyi dbyings su rang gyur pa/ / de nas yang dag bshad par bya/ /
Through the method of worship in accordance with the Dharma, One will attain dharmatā And oneself will become the dharmadhātu. That shall now be correctly explained.[7]
de'i rjes la dpag bsam shing gi sgrub pa 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / brag gi yi ge las byung ba/ / dpag bsam shing ni rnam par bsgom/ / ut+pal yongs su gyur pa las/ / shing ni g.yon du bsgom par bya/ /

Now follows the practice method of the wish-fulfilling tree: One should visualize, arising from the syllable vṛm,[8] A wish-fulfilling tree. As a transformation of the utpala, It should be visualized to the left.
sna tshogs nor gyi char pa dag / nam mkha'i dkyil nas 'bab pa yis/ / 'dod pa'i bsam pa rdzogs byed pa/ / de ltar bsgoms na nor bdag 'gyur/ /
A rain of various riches Falls from the middle of the sky, And so fulfills wishes and desires. The one who meditates like this becomes the Lord of Wealth.
gling bzhi pa yi sems can rnams/ / sems kyi 'od zer gyis bkug nas/ / rtag tu rin chen bdun rang bzhin/ / de dag la ni rab sbyin bya/ /
The sentient beings of the four continents One must summon through light rays of the mind And so generously provide them With the gifts that consist of the seven jewels:

yongs kyi gtso bo rin chen dang / / de bzhin rin chen rgya mtsho skyes/ / bud med rin chen rta rin chen/ / de bzhin ral gri rin chen dang / /
glang po rin chen sogs rin chen/ / sangs rgyas rnams la yid kyis dbul/ / bud med rgyan gyis brgyan byas la/ / sna tshogs gzugs can 'gying ba rnams/ /
sangs rgyas 'bras bu 'dod rnams kyis/ / sangs rgyas rnams la rtag tu dbul/ / 'dis ni sangs rgyas thams cad dang / / rig pa 'dzin pa thob par 'gyur/ /

The jewel of the foremost teacher, The jewel born from the sea, The jewel of a woman, the jewel of a horse, The jewel of a sword, The jewel of an elephant‍—such jewels Should be offered mentally to the buddhas. The jewel of a woman, adorned with ornaments And displaying abundant attractions, Should always be offered to the buddhas By those who wish for the fruit of buddhahood. Through this all buddhas And knowledge holders will be achieved.

rin po che ni yongs rgyas pa'i/ / yongs kyi gtso bo nor dbang phyug / sangs rgyas 'bras bu 'dod pa yis/
sangs rgyas rnams la dbul bar bya/ / de bzhin rin chen gzhan dag kyang / / gus dang bcas pas yongs btang na/ / rdo rje chos su gyur nas ni/ / sems can kun gyi don byed 'gyur/ / 'di ni dpag bsam shing gi sgrub pa'i thabs so/ /

Replete with his treasures, A foremost teacher, a lord of wealth, Should be offered to the buddhas By those who wish for the fruit of buddhahood. When likewise the other jewels Are respectfully surrendered One will turn into Vajradharma And so become the benefactor of all beings. This was the practice method of the wish-fulfilling tree.
sems nyid sangs rgyas thams cad do/ / sems nyid kyis ni rnam par grol/ / sems kyis 'ching ba rnams las thar/ / sems kyis grol ba dang ldan 'gyur/ /
All the buddhas are mind itself. By mind itself one is liberated. Bondage is broken by the mind, Through mind one attains freedom.
sems ma gtogs par dngos don rnams/ / gzhan dag gzhan par ma mthong ste/ / sangs rgyas nyid dang dngos grub kun/ / gang phyir phun tshogs gzhan ma mthong / /
Apart from in the mind Things and entities are not seen anywhere at all. Hence, there is no perfection to be seen Apart from buddhahood and all the accomplishments.
gang yang snod dang sems can rnams/ / 'byung dang 'byung las gyur pa dag / zag med lhag par mthong ba yis/ / sems tsam yin zhes rab tu bsgrags/ /
The environments and sentient beings, The elements and their derivatives, Have been declared to be “mind only” By those who possess the undefiled special vision.
de bas 'bad pa thams cad kyis/ / sems kyi me long phyis byas na/ / rang bzhin glo bur ba yi skyon/ / rim gyis rab tu zad par 'gyur/ /
Therefore, one should make every effort To cleanse the mirror of the mind. Faults, which are by nature extrinsic, Will gradually be utterly exhausted.
dbyangs yig dang po las byung ba/ / dri med rdzogs pa'i zla ba ste/ / sems nyid zla bar bsgom byas nas/ / de yi steng du sa bon dgod/ /
From the first of the vowels Arises a stainless full moon. Meditating on mind itself as that moon, One places upon it the seed-syllable:
dro ba rnams kyi bzhi pa na/ / me yi mdog gi steng na gnas/ / yi ge i dang yang dag ldan/ / nam mkha' gnyis kyis rnam par brgyan/ /
The fourth in the sibilant group Is positioned atop the syllable of fire, Joined with the syllable ī, And adorned with the two skies.

de yi sna tshogs 'od rnams kyis/ / 'gro ba'i dri ma med byas nas/ / stong gsum 'di sogs mkha' dbyings te/ / ku ru kul+le'i rir zhugs pas/ /
de yis sgrol ma bskul nas ni/ / bkug nas mdun du gnas par byed/ / de nas mkhas pas sa bon la/ / mchod pa chen po'i sprin rnams spro/ /
me tog spos dang mar me dang / / de bzhin dri dang lha bshos sogs/ / phyag rgya phreng ba de bzhin du/ / gar dang glu yis mchod sogs mchod/ /

A multicolored light from that Cleanses beings of their impurities, And turns this billionfold world, and other such universes, into the field of space. Having entered the Kurukullā mountain It rouses Tārā, and as she is summoned, She is made to be present before oneself. The wise must then from the syllable Send forth a great cloud of offerings: Flowers, incense, and lamps; Perfume, food, and the like; Gestures, garlands, Theatrical shows, songs, and other such offerings.

dkon mchog gsum la skyabs su mchi/ / sdig pa thams cad so sor bshags/ / 'gro ba'i dge la rjes yi rang / / sangs rgyas byang chub yid kyis bzung / /
sngags 'di lan gsum brjod nas ni/ / de nas gshegs su gsol bar bgyi/ / sems ni byams pas gnas byas la/ / slar yang der ni gzhag par bya/ /

snying rje'i sems ni bskyed byas nas/ / rab dga'i sems kyang bskyed par bya/ / phyi nas thams cad btang snyoms la/ / sems tsam la ni mnyam par gzhag /
tha mal rnam par spang ba'i phyir/ / sems kyang slar yang stong par bya/ / yang srid len pa'i phung po lnga/ / stong pa nyid kyi me yis bsreg /

Having engendered a mind of compassion, One should as well bring forth a mind of joy. Afterward, one should regard everything with equanimity In its condition of being “mind only.” Then, in order to discard the ordinary, The mind must once more be emptied. The five aggregates of the process of reexistence Shall be consumed by the fire of emptiness.
oM shUn+ya tA dz+nyA na badzra swa b+hA ba ah+ma ko& haM/ /
Oṃ śūnyatājñānavajrasvabhāvātmako ˈham.[9]
yud tsam stong pa'i rnal 'byor nyid/ / byas nas sems ni ngal sos bya/ / sngon gyi dam bcas dran byas nas/ / sa bon tsam zhig yang dran bya/ /
For a while one should practice this emptiness yoga And so bring the mind refreshing rest. Recollecting the vows taken earlier, One should once more focus on simply the seed-syllable.
gcig pu mya ngan 'das pa yis/ / sems can bslus par 'gyur ba'i phyir/ / srid pa'i rgya mtsho mtha' med las/ / bdag gis de dag ci ltar bsgral/ /
“An exclusive nirvāṇa Would mean deceiving sentient beings. How shall I liberate them From the endless ocean of existence?”
'di ltar bsams nas brtse ldan des/ / sems med pa yi stong pa yang / / chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin sems/ / sems nyid kyis ni bskyed par bya/ /
Contemplating thus, the one who possesses love Will abandon the emptiness devoid of mind. A mind that is of the nature of the field of phenomena Must be brought forth through mind itself.
sangs rgyas byin rlabs las sa bon/ / de la ut+pal zhes byar 'gyur/ / ut+pal dkyil du zla ba'i gzugs/ / yi ge a las byung ba'o/ /
By the Buddha’s blessing arises the seed-syllable, And from that, that which is called an utpala. On the utpala, there is a moon disk Arisen from the syllable a.
slar yang zla ba der sa bon/ / de las 'od zer 'phros gyur pa/ / de yis ma lus 'jig rten khams/ / rnam par sbyangs par bsgom par bya/ /
On that moon, again, is the seed-syllable, From which emanate rays of light. Thereby all realms of the world Are seen to be thoroughly purified.
de yis sbyangs shing gsal byas nas/ / 'od zer kun gyis sangs rgyas tshogs/ / ut+pal la zhugs bsgom par bya/ / de las sgrol ma 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Once they are purified and illumined, One should perceive that great numbers of buddhas Melt into light and enter the seed-syllable. From that arises Tārā.
bstan 'dra'i lha mo btsod mdog can/ / rgyan rnams kun gyis rnam brgyan pas/ / dam tshig gzugs ni mnyam bskyed nas/ / ye shes 'khor lo yang dag bkug /
As explained, the goddess is of the color of madder rose And adorned with all of the ornaments. First one should develop the samaya form And then summon the wisdom circle.
yud tsam gyis ni nges rdzogs pa'o/ / ye shes 'khor lo mdun gnas pa/ / dam tshig phyag rgya'i sbyor ba yis/ / kha yi lam nas gzhug par bya/ /
This occurs in an instant. The wisdom circle remains in front. With the application of the samaya seal They should enter by the open pathway.
lag pa thal mo sbyar byas nas/ / mthe'u chung gnyis ni bsgom par bya/ / gung mo gnyis ni rtse mor sbyar/ / rtse mo'i nang du ming med gzhug /
The palms of the hands are joined And the two little fingers visualized. The middle fingers are joined at the tips And the ring fingers are between them.
mdzub mo gnyis ni dbu mar sbyar/ / mthe bong gnyis ni 'og tu bkug / dam tshig phyag rgya 'di bcings nas/ / 'khor lo bkug nas gzhug par bya/ /
The index fingers are joined to the middle ones And the thumbs are bent below. Having formed the samaya seal in this way One must summon the circle and cause it to enter.

sangs rgyas rnams la tshigs bcad 'dis/ / dbang bskur bar ni gsol ba gdab/ /
byang chub rdo rje sangs rgyas la/ / ji ltar mchod chen gsol mdzad pa/ / bdag kyang bskyab pa'i don gyi phyir/ / nam mkha'i rdo rje deng bdag stsol/ /

With the following verses to the buddhas One should request empowerment: “Just as Bodhivajra offers The great worship to the buddhas, So too, in order to protect me, Please, now grant it to me, O Khavajra.”

rgyal ba'i dbang bskur zhes bya bas/ / spyan la sogs pa lnga pa'o/ /
rgyal po'i me tog dbang bskur zhing / / chen por gyur pa de stsol mdzod/ /
With the so-called “empowerment of the Victor” Locanā and the other four arise. “The consecration of a king with flowers, Great ones, bestow that upon me.”
rdo rje chen pos dbang bskur ba/ / khams gsum po yis phyag byas pa/ / gsang ba gsum gyi gnas las byung / / sangs rgyas kun gyis sbyin par bya/ /
“The empowerment by the great vajra, Which is venerated throughout the three realms, And which originates from the abodes of three secrets, That shall be given by all the buddhas.”

sangs rgyas sgrol ma dbang bskur bas/ / chos ni gtsug gi nor bur 'gyur/ /
'od zer dmar po sna tshogs kyis/ / 'gro ba gsum po snang bar byed/ / dbang bskur rin chen thob 'gyur na/ / dngos grub thams cad rab sgrub byed/ /

As the buddhas empower Tārā She becomes crowned with the Dharma. With red light of different hues She illuminates the three worlds. One who has obtained the jewel of empowerment Will attain all accomplishments.

ji ltar slar bstan cho ga yis/ / lo phyed brtan par brtsams nas ni/ / gtor ma dus gsum gtang bar bya/ / sngags 'di yis ni khar ba 'am/ /
khur ba la sogs cho ga yis/ / rmi lam mtshan ma thob par 'gyur/ / ral gri sa 'og dngos grub dang / / mi snang ba dang bcud len dang / /
mi mthong ba dang mkha' spyod nyid/ / de bzhin rkang byug mig sman dang / / rmi lam mtshan ma ston 'gyur zhing / / dngos grub rang nyid 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

By means of the described ritual One must practice stably for half a year And offer bali at the three times. By means of this mantra, And through the ritual of cane or cakes, One will obtain a sign during a dream. The sword, the accomplishment of the netherworld, Invisibility, the extraction of essences, Anonymity, celestial realms, Foot unguent, and eye ointment‍— The signs will be seen in dreams And the accomplishments themselves will manifest.
gal te de la dga' 'gyur na/ / grub pa phra mo sgrol mas grub/ / 'khor los sgyur nas rgyal srid dang / / dbang po'i longs spyod thams cad byed/ /
If one becomes fond of these, Minor accomplishments will be attained through Tārā. Having become a universal monarch, one attains The kingdom and the pleasures of the senses.

sgom dang bzlas par ldan pa la/ / rmi lam du yang rab grub ba byed/ / zla drug tha ma'i zla gcig go/ / mtshan gcig rangs par bzlas byas te/ /
ut+pal phyag rgya bcings nas ni/ / bzlas nas phyag rgya yud kyis 'bar/ / phyag rgya 'di yi mthu yis ni/ / btsun mo dang bcas tshangs pa dang / /

For the one endowed with meditation and recitation These are even attained in dreams. At the final moon among the six, Recite delightedly for one night And form the utpala mudrā. As one recites, it suddenly bursts into flames. By the power of this mudrā Brahma, Indra, Upendra, Rudra, and so forth,

dbang po nye dbang drag po sogs/ / bkug nas dbang du 'gyur bar byed/ / deng nas brtsams nas dngos grub kun/ / bdag 'khor 'ching ba las grol 'gyur/ /
chu dang 'dam gyi skyon dag gis/ / pad+ma gos par mi 'gyur ltar/ / dngul chu reg nas du mar 'gyur/ / bsdus nas slar yang gcig tu 'gyur/ /

Together with their spouses, Are summoned and arrive enthralled. From then on, one will be accomplished in every respect And be free from the bonds of saṃsāra, Just as a lotus will be unstained By water soiled with mud. When touched, quicksilver becomes many, Yet when coalesced, it once more becomes one;

thams cad mkhyen pa nyid 'gyur na/ / dngos grub thob pa'i sems de bzhin/ / grub pa'i dngul chus reg gyur nas/ / zangs ma gser du 'gyur ba bzhin/ /
grub pa'i gsang sngags kyis reg nas/ / sngags pa sangs rgyas skur yang 'gyur/ / lha yi dbang phyug du 'gyur zhing / / khams gsum kun gyi dbang phyug 'gyur/ /

Within the state of omniscience The same is the case with the accomplished one’s mind. When touched by perfected quicksilver, Copper turns to gold; Likewise, when touched by the perfected mantra, Practitioners of mantra will become the bodies of the Buddha. They attain the station of the lord of the gods And become lords of the triple universe.

sangs rgyas rigs su byung nas ni/ / 'khor lo bskor bar yang 'gyur ro/ / bltams dang rab tu 'byung mdzad pa/ / dka' ba spyod pa'i spyod mdzad cing / /
byang chub spyod pa'ang spyod mdzad na/ / sangs rgyas nyid kyang dran par mdzad/ / lha las babs dang sprul pa dang / / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba dang / /

When born in the family of the Buddha, They become turners of the wheel. They are born, go forth into homelessness, Practice the difficult conduct, And as they also engage in the conduct of enlightenment, They recollect buddhahood itself. Likewise, they descend from the gods, manifest emanations, Turn the wheel of Dharma,

mya ngan 'das pa chen po dang / / dur khrod gshegs pa de bzhin no/ / 'jig rten gsum du lus spangs nas/ / rgyal ba longs spyod rdzogs sku yis/ /
gnas gtsang mar ni slar gshegs nas/ / sprul par byung ba'i sku yang 'ong / / glegs bam ras ris rim pa yis/ / chos kyi sku yang 'jug par mdzad/ / gang gis de yi grub pa'i sngags/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis de nyid gsungs/ /

Attain the great nirvāṇa, And depart for a cemetery. Having left their bodies in the triple world, The victorious ones, by means of the enjoyment body, Return again to the pure abodes, And so the emanation body emerges. By means of the procedures of books and paintings, There is engagement with the dharma body as well. Hence, the mantra, thereby established, Has indeed been taught by the buddhas.

de nas bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis de nyid kyi thugs la rnam par brtags nas byang chub sems dpa' chen po lag na rdo rje la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ / lag na rdo rje ji ltar na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis rdo rje'i sku chos kyi dbyings kyi sku sa'i phyogs gang du dus byed par 'gyur ba yin/ de nas lag na rdo rjes sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' de dag la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / gang yang byang chub sems dpa' dag gis 'di skad du/ ci ltar na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rdo rje'i sku chos kyi dbyings kyi sku mi phyed pa'i sku sa'i phyogs 'ga' zhig tu dus byed par 'gyur ba yin zhes smra/ des 'di skad nyon cig / byang chub sems dpa' de dag gang mya ngan las 'das pa zhes bya ba de ni bde ba can du 'gro ba'o/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis smras pa/ ci lag na rdo rje sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams chos sku spangs nas bde ba can du 'gro ba'am/ rigs kyi bu 'on te sprul pa'i sku spangs nas longs spyod rdzogs pa'i skus bde ba can du 'gro bar 'gyur/ lag na rdo rje chos kyi sku spangs nas 'gro bar 'gyur zhes bya ba de ji lta bu yin/ lag na rdo rjes smras pa/ ci ltar sgyu ma mkhan gyi skyes bu gang zhig gis dgos pa'i don bsgrub pa'i phyir sgyu ma sprul nas dgos pa sgrub par byed do/ / de bzhin du

All the blessed ones, the thus-gone ones, then addressed the great bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi, so as to examine his noble mind: “How, O Vajrapāṇi, could the buddhas, the blessed ones, who possess vajra bodies, who possess dharmadhātu bodies, possibly die at some location on earth?” Vajrapāṇi, in turn, offered the following words to those buddhas and bodhisattvas: “The bodhisattvas have asked me this: ‘How could buddhas, who possess vajra bodies, dharmadhātu bodies, bodies of nonduality, possibly die at some location on earth?’ ” And he continued, “Listen, O bodhisattvas, the so-called nirvāṇa means a passage to the realm of bliss.” “O Vajrapāṇi,” inquired the bodhisattvas, “do the buddhas, the blessed ones, go to the realm of bliss after they relinquish the dharma body, or do they go to the realm of bliss by means of the enjoyment body, having left behind their emanation body? How could they depart, having left behind the dharma body?” Vajrapāṇi replied, “A person with magical powers may employ magic for some specific purpose, and so also succeed in achieving that purpose. Likewise:
gdod nas grub pa'i sangs rgyas rnams/ / sems can yongs su gzung ba'i phyir/ / 'khor los sgyur ba 'das gyur nas/ / skye ba yongs su 'dzin par mdzad/ /
“Accomplished since the beginning, The buddhas engage in the act of accepting birth, To provide for sentient beings, When a universal monarch has gone beyond.
gang tshe sangs rgyas 'das pa na/ / de tshe 'khor los sgyur ba 'byung / / de gnyis med par 'jig rten 'dir/ / nam yang 'byung ba ma yin no/ /
“When a buddha goes beyond, A universal monarch appears. In this world there is never a time When both of them are absent.
gdul bya'i 'jig rten la brten nas/ / rkang gnyis mchog gis brtul nas ni/ / lo ni brgyad cur bzhugs mdzad de/ / sangs rgyas rgyal ba'i gnas su gshegs/ /
“The Buddha, the best among those who walk on two feet, Provided guidance to beings in need of guidance. After having remained for eighty years, He departed for the abode of the victorious ones.
sangs rgyas sgyu ma spangs nas ni/ / rgyal ba'i pho brang bde chen du/ / rab zhi bde ba chen po la/ / kun du dga' ba'i gzugs kyis bzhugs/ /

“Having left behind their magical illusion of a buddha, They remain in great bliss, which is the palace of the victorious ones; Within the perfect peace of great bliss They abide in a form that is in all ways delightful.
byed po rtag pa gcig pus bzhugs/ / yin snyam drang srong rnams sems te/ / de lta'i ngo bo de min zhes/ / de ni skad cig bsdoms par 'dod/ /
“An agent, eternal and singular‍— Thus the sages regard the mind.[10] Yet it is taught that it is not of such an essence; Rather, it is held to be composed of moments.
bdag tu 'dzin pas 'khrul pa rnams/ / rtag tu rtag pa'i don 'dod pa/ / mi rtag nyid la 'jug bya'i phyir/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi sku gtong mdzad/ /

“The victorious ones will relinquish their bodies For those deluded because of holding on to a self, And for those who always want things to be permanent, So that they may be introduced to impermanence.
dngos po kun gyi dngos bdag nyid/ / thugs kyis thams cad mkhyen te dag / 'di dag 'di gnas ma yin zhes/ / byas pa'i nges pa yod ma yin/ /
“Those who are of the nature of all things, And whose minds know everything, Cannot definitively be said To be absent anywhere.
kun rdzob bden pa la brten nas/ / stong gsum 'di sogs gdul bya la/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis chos bstan pa/ / nam mkha' mnyam par rab tu 'jug /
“Based on the relative truth, And for those in this billionfold universe and elsewhere who are in need of guidance, The buddhas teach the Dharma Throughout the extent of space.
sangs rgyas 'byung ba de nyid min/ / sangs rgyas 'gags pa'ang de bzhin te/ / thams cad ro gcig gyur pa yi/ / 'byung dang 'jig pa'i rang bzhin no/ /
“There is no real birth of a buddha, Nor is there any real death of a buddha. Where everything is of the same taste, This is the nature of arising and ceasing.
de ni chos dbyings gzugs gcig ste/ / sgrib pa lnga po spangs pa'o/ / zab cing rgya ni che ba'i gzugs/ / de nyid ngo bor de nyid bzhugs/ /

“The buddhas are of the same body within the dharmadhātu, And they are free of the five obscurations. The body of the profound and the vast‍— It is as the essence of this reality that a buddha remains.
gnyis ka yod pa ma yin phyir/ / gdod nas yod pa ma yin no/ / de ni gdod nas ma skyes pas/ / skye ba ma yin 'gag ma yin/ /
“Since neither is the case, They do, from the beginning, not exist. Since from the beginning they have not arisen They do not arise and they do not cease.”

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis smras pa/ lag na rdo rje sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das khams gsum la rjes su ston pa mdzad pa/ skye ba med pa 'gag pa med pa ci lta bu yin/ smras pa/ kyai byang chub sems dpa' rnams de ji snyam du sems/ gang sangs rgyas ji snyed pa de gang zhig yod pa yin nam/ 'on te med pa zhig yin/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis smras pa/ lag na rdo rje sangs rgyas rnams ni yod pa yang ma yin med pa yang ma yin no/ / lag na rdo rjes smras pa/

The bodhisattvas asked, “How is it, O Vajrapāṇi, that the buddhas, the blessed ones, the teachers of the three worlds, neither arise nor cease?” “Now, O bodhisattvas, what do you think?” asked Vajrapāṇi in return. “Does the one who is the Buddha exist, or not exist?” “O Vajrapāṇi, buddhas neither exist nor do they not exist,” replied the bodhisattvas. Vajrapāṇi then said:
ma skyes pa ni skye ba yin/ / skyes pa phyir yang skye mi 'gyur/ / don dam nyid du dpyad na ni/ / de phyir gdod nas ma skyes pa/ /
“Indeed, it is the unborn that is born; The born will never be born. When investigated in terms of the ultimate They are unborn since the beginning.
de bzhin 'chi ba 'chi mi 'gyur/ / 'chi ba med pa 'chi ba min/ / mi gnas pa la gnas pa med/ / gnas pa de la gnas mi dgos/ /
“Likewise, the dead do not die, Nor does the one who is not dead. The nonabiding does not abide, And the one who abides is not in need of abiding.
gal te ma skyes nyams 'gyur zhing / / ma skyes pa nyid skye 'gyur na/ / ri bong gi ni rwa nyid kyang / / skye ba dang ni 'gag par 'gyur/ /
“If that which has not been born were subject to decay, Or if the unborn were subject to arising, Then a rabbit’s horn would also Be subject to arising and cessation.
gang tshe yod pa skye 'gyur na/ / skyes pa slar yang skye bar 'gyur/ / gal te med pa skye na yang / / mo sham bu yang skye bar 'gyur/ /
“If that which exists were to arise, That which has arisen would arise once more. Also, if that which does not exist were to arise, The barren woman’s son would arise too.
de phyir thams cad ma rig pa/ / 'du byed gsum gyi mtshan nyid yin/ / phung po lnga ldan 'gro ba rnams/ / snang ba tsam du rnam par shes/ /
“Therefore, everything is ignorance, Formations that possess the three characteristics. The worlds that possess the five aggregates Are known as mere appearance.
re zhig rigs pa 'dis byang chub sems dpa' rnams sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi mya ngan las 'das pa shes par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis smras pa/

“The bodhisattvas should understand the nirvāṇa that pertains to the buddhas, the blessed ones, through this reasoning.”
The bodhisattvas asked:
thams cad skyed pa med pa'i phyir/ / sngags 'di ci ltar rgyud ci ltar/ / dkyil 'khor sgom pa ji lta bu/ / dngos grub de ni ji ltar 'grub/ /
“When nothing is produced, What are mantras, what are tantras, And how does one visualize the maṇḍala? How, then, is accomplishment gained?”
lag na rdo rjes smras pa/
Vajrapāṇi replied:
rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba ni/ / dngos po rnams ni 'byung ba ltar/ / sngags dang phyag rgya sogs brten nas/ / dngos grub rnams ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
“Originating in dependence‍— This is how things arise. Likewise, depending on mantras, mudrās, and so forth, The accomplishments are gained.
dngos grub rnams ni kun rdzob pa/ / sangs rgyas pha rol phyin pa yang / / sangs rgyas rdo rje sems dpa' nyid/ / kun rdzob nyid du rab sgrub 'gyur/ /
“The accomplishments are relative, And so are the transcendences of the Buddha. Buddhahood, the state of Vajrasattva, Is perfectly accomplished in terms of the relative.”
rtog pa gnyis pa'o// //
This was the second chapter.
Chapter 3
sngags bzlas pa yi cho ga'i rim/ / de nas yang dag bshad bya ba/ / gang zhig shes pa tsam gyis ni/ / sgrub pos dngos grub 'gyur bas so/ /
The progression of the ritual for reciting the mantra Shall now be explained. By merely understanding it, The practitioner will reach success.
byi ru yis ni dbang du byed/ / pus kar gos ni dug zhi byed/ / shel gyis shes rab 'phel bar byed/ / las gsum la ni sbyar bar bya/ /
Coral is used for enthrallment, Puṣkara removes poison, And with crystal insight will expand. These are to be used in three activities.

skye gnas kyi rnam par dag pa a shwat+tha'i 'dab ma'i rnam pa lta bu'i thab khung byas la/ mya ngan med pa'i shing la me sbar nas/ cho ga bzhin du ut+pal dmar po brgya rtsa brgyad sbyin bsreg byas te/ gar mkhan gyi khyim nas me blangs la mngar gsum gyis bsgos nas/ rtsa ba'i sngags dang bya ba yin no/ / phyi nas 'khrul 'khor bya ba yin te/ zla mtshan gyis gos pa'i ras la dkyil 'khor gru gsum bris nas/ dkyil 'khor du bsgrub bya dang / sgrub pa po'i ming dang bcas pa'i bskul ba'i tshig dang bcas par bris te/ che ge mo bdag gi dbang du gyur cig byas nas/ de nas rtsa ba'i sngags kyis spel nas/ rgya skyegs kyi khu ba dang / lag pa g.yon pa'i srin lag gi khrag dang / ga bur dang / gur gum dang / gla rtsi rnams kyi tshon rtsis bri bar bya'o/ / shes rab 'phel bar 'dod na thab khung de nyid du a rga'am/ ka ra bI ra'i shing la bram ze'i sbyin sreg gi me blangs la sbar te/ a ka ru ka'i sha'i khyi'i ma'am/ shu dag gi sbyin sreg khri bya'o/ / dug zhi bar byed na thab khung de nyid du tsan+dan gyi shing la me sbar la/ ping ta ka ra'i me tog gi sbyin bsreg bya'o/ / des ni dug thams cad zhi bar 'gugs par 'gyur ro/ / sna tshogs kyi zug gzer rnams med par byed cing zhi bar byed do/ / mkha' lding gi rig pa'i rgyud kyi cho ga'o/ /

In a pit the shape of an aśvattha tree leaf, which is the pure nature of the place of birth, one should light a fire with wood from the aśoka tree. One must then, in the prescribed way, perform one hundred and eight offerings of red lotus flowers. The fire should be obtained from the home of an actor. The offerings are to be smeared with the three sweets and presented together with the root mantra. Next comes the diagram. One should draw a triangular maṇḍala on cotton smeared with the mark of the moon. Within it, one writes entreating words that include the names of the practitioner and the one to be won: “Let me succeed in attracting such and such a person!” As one enriches this with the root mantra, one should write with a paint of liquid lac, blood from one’s left ring finger, camphor, kunkuma, and musk. If one wishes to increase insight one should, in the same pit as before, burn arka and karavīra with the sacrificial fire used for brahmin oblations. One should offer aṭarūṣaka leaves[11] or sweet flag ten thousand times. For removing poison, one should light a fire in the same basin with wood of the sandal tree, and in that offer the flowers of the piṇḍatagara. Thus one will become a curer of all poison. One will heal the different pains and bring peace. This is the rite of the gāruḍa knowledge tantra.
khams gsum pa yi lam gnas pa'i/ / btsun mor grags pa ji snyed pa/ / sbyin sreg 'khrul 'khor sbyor ba yis/ / de kun bkug nas spyod par byed/ /
On the paths of the triple universe One will attract and engage with All those who are known as noblewomen By means of oblation and the diagram.
byams pa chags pa'i lta ba yis/ / sems de yis ni dbang du byed/ / 'gro ba thams cad dbang byas nas/ / sangs rgyas byang chub nges par spyod/ /

Loving-kindness through looking with impassioned love‍— It is through such a mind that one performs enthrallment. Having enthralled all beings, One establishes them in the enlightenment of the Buddha.
'di ni dbang du bya ba'i cho ga'o/ /
This is the rite of enthrallment.
rnam pa kun mkhyen zhes bya ba/ / shes rab med par thob mi 'gyur/ / de phyir de thob 'dod pa gang / / shes rab rnon po bsgrub par bya/ /
The so-called “knower of everything” Cannot be attained without insight. The one who wishes to attain it Should therefore develop incisive insight.
bzlas dang sbyin sreg sbyor ba yis/ / chos rnams kun la spyod pa'o/ / blo ni dag gsal dri ma med/ / de nyid shes rab pha rol phyin/ /
Through the practice of recitation and oblations One will encounter all phenomena. The mind that is pure, bright, and stainless‍— That indeed is the transcendent insight.
rnal 'byor pa ni grol bar 'gyur/ / gri ha pi da'i lo ma dang / / sha ti dang ni shing mngar dang / / bram ze mo dang ma ga ta/ / sbrang dang bcas pas bza' bar bya/ /
The yogin will be liberated. The leaves of gṛhābhidhāna, Ṣaṭhī, licorice, Brahmāṇī, māgadhī, and honey‍— These are to be eaten.
shes rab 'phel bar bya ba'i cho ga'o// //
This is the ritual for increasing insight.
dug rjes sbrang rtsi mar dang bcas/ / 'khor lo bzang rtsa de bzhin te/ / mche ba'i dug gis bzung ba la/ / bskus dang 'thungs pas zhi bar mdzad/ /
Next[12] there is honey with ghee, Cakrāṅkita, and the good root‍— By applying this to the place struck by the poisonous fangs, Or by drinking it, one will neutralize the poison.
dug gzhil ba'i sman no/ /
This is the medicine that overcomes poison.
dza ri tsaN+DA li dag dang / / nad pa'i sdi ni mar khur bcas/ / lus kyi srin bu shi ba'i ro/ / zos nas dbang du 'gyur ba yin/ /
Jārī and caṇḍālikā, Snehamallī and ghee, As well as dead intestinal worms‍— When eaten, these effect enthrallment.
dbang du bya ba'i sman no/ /
This is the medicine for performing enthrallment.
dug 'gugs pas ni 'gro ba zhi/ / shes rab 'phel bas sangs rgyas nyid/ / chos kyi 'khor lo skor ba ni/ / skad cig gis ni dbang byed 'gyur/ /

The removal of poison brings peace in the world; From the development of insight comes buddhahood. Turning the wheel of Dharma will be accomplished In an instant by the one who practices enthrallment.
bdag gzhan don rab bsgrub pa la/ / theg pa chen por thabs gzhan med/ / rig pa lan gcig bsgrubs pa yis/ / 'phral du yid ches byed pa yin/ /
For accomplishing the benefit of oneself and others There is no other means within the Great Vehicle. The practice of a spell just once Will immediately be convincing.
hrIHyig myos pa'i snod bsams nas/ / bud med rnams ni 'dzag par 'gyur/ / lce snying dkyil du hrIHde nyid/ / bsams na blo rnams skye bar byed/ /
Thinking of the syllable hrīḥ at the vessel of frenzy Will cause women to drip. Thinking of it upon the tongue or in the center of the heart, Will engender insights.
mche bas bzung ba las bsgoms pa/ / chos kyi yi ge mdzes pa yis/ / yi ge dag ni dug zhi byed/ / sgrol ma'i snying po khams gsum las/ /
When meditated upon in relation to the bite of the fangs This beautiful syllable of Dharma Will destroy poison. This heart of Tārā conquers the three worlds‍—
rgyal ba yin par brtse ba can gyis rnam shes bya/ / ngag gi skyon rnams zad pas dug sel sems kyi skyon spangs pas/ / shes rab 'phel 'gyur lus kyi skyon rnams zad pas dbang du byed/ /

That should be understood by those who love. As the negativities of speech completely disappear, one will be able to remove poison; when those of the mind disappear, insight will increase; and when the flaws of the body are exhausted, one will bring about enthrallment.

de phyir 'gro 'di mi dge la zhen dngos grub thob mi 'gyur/ / de phyir rgyal ba'i sras kyis phan phyir sdig rnams spang bar bya phyir bgyi/ / phyag rgya bcing ba'i khyad par gyis ni nges par lus kyi skyon rnams zad par 'gyur/ / sngags kyis lce yi tshogs kyi skyon rnams gang yin pa yi

Hence, since this world is attached to nonvirtue, it does not gain accomplishment. Therefore, O sons of the victorious ones, you must act to benefit, and give up evil. By means of the specific gestures, the faults associated with the body certainly disappear and, through the mantra, so do the faults associated with the composites of the tongue.

sems kyi skyon/ / bsam gtan dga' ba'i sems kyis dga' bar 'gyur bar dad pa dri med kyis/ / lus kyi yid rnams g.yo ba med pa de tshe sangs rgyas byin gyis rlobs/ / sdig med mig gis sdig lta snying rje ldan pa 'jig rten gsum gyi rgyal por 'gyur/ / sbyin pas bsod nams stobs lhag gyur par sa stengs gtso bo sbyin bdag brtson ldan 'gyur/ /

The faults associated with the mind fade away in those whose minds delight in meditation. With the joy of stainless faith, the cognitions of the body become unmoving‍—that is the time of the Buddha’s blessing. The one who sees with an eye free from evil and who possesses compassion will become king of the three worlds. With his power of merit superior because of generosity, he becomes the foremost on the surface of the earth, a benefactor endowed with diligence.

le lo spangs pas mkhas pas dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal cung zad kyang mi myong / / de phyir sangs rgyas sras kyi snying rje'i nor dang brtson 'grus spyod pa dag la brten/ / nam mkha'i dkyil du sangs rgyas rnams bltas bsam gtan stobs kyis sangs rgyas rnams la sems/ / rmi lam na yang rtag tu bdag nyid sangs rgyas rnams kyis bskor ba mthong / /

Having given up laziness, and by means of wisdom, he will not experience even a bit of the suffering of hell. Therefore, one relies on the wealth of the compassion of the sons of the victorious ones, and on their diligent conduct. Perceiving the buddhas in the center of the sky, one regards the buddhas by the power of concentration. Even in sleep one should always perceive oneself to be surrounded by the buddhas.

mkhas pas 'chi tshe ri rab rtser gshegs dang / / bzhon pa sna tshogs zhon pa'i sangs rgyas rnams/ / snying rje'i bdag nyid can gyis mthong 'gyur zhing / / sdig pa byas pas dmyal ba'i grong khyer mthong bar 'gyur/ /

At the time of death the wise proceed to the summit of Mount Meru; Buddhas riding in various vehicles‍— These are seen by the ones who are compassionate by nature. Doing evil produces the perception of the cities of hell.
de rnams rnam dag rgyud yin te/ /
This is the tantra for purification.

blo yang der ni gnas par 'gyur/ / de yi phyir ni ci nas kyang / / gos dkar dag gi btsun mor 'dod/ / de nyid dug ni zhi byed pas/ / rta mgrin gyis ni go 'phang gnas/ / 'dod chags rdo rje'i tshig 'byung ba/ / 'gro ba gsum po dbang du byed/ /

Where there is desire there is poison; Insight also is present there.[13] Therefore, how can Pāṇḍarā Be regarded as the queen of speech?[14] She is indeed the curer of poison Abiding on the level of Hayagrīva.[15] Manifesting as the speech of the vajra of passion, She enthralls the three worlds.
'dod chags kyi rigs kyi rgyud bsgrub pa'o// //
This is the practice of the tantra of the desire family.
de nas sbyor ba gzhan 'byung bar 'gyur te/
Next follows another method:

dkyil 'khor gru gsum byas nas ni/ / slar yang gru gsum gzhan zhig go/ / dbang po phyogs nas brtsams nas ni/ / oM la sogs pa mkhas pas bri/ /
mtshams drug tu ni sa bon drug / chos kyi sa bon dkyil du'o/ / yi ge phuHyi nang byas pa/ / de ni sgo yi ma them bri/ /

Having created a triangular maṇḍala And, in addition, another triangle, The wise must, starting from Indra’s quarter, Write the syllable oṃ and so forth. The six seed-syllables are in the six corners, And the seed-syllable of Dharma is in the center. Placed within a phuḥ syllable, It should be drawn on the doorstep.
sbrul bskrad pa'i rgyud do/ /
This is the tantra for driving away snakes.
de nas bud med skal ba dang ldan par bya ba'i phyir/ sbyor ba gzhan dag bshad par bya ste/
Now, to bring women fortune, another method shall be explained:

'dab ma bdun pa'i ut+pal byas la/ de la yi ge bdun sbyar bar bya'o/ / de'i lte ba la hrIHgnyis kyis brten pa'i bsgrub bya'i ming dbang du bya ba'i cho ga bzhin du gro ga'am/ yang na me tog dang bcas pa'i ras la bris la rig pa'i ril bu byas nas dpung pa la gdags par bya'o/ /

One should draw a lotus flower with seven petals and apply the seven syllables to it. In its center one should, according to the enthrallment procedure, write the name of the person to be enthralled, supported by a pair of hrīḥ syllables. One should draw this on birch bark, or on cotton with flowers, and make it into a charm that is to be worn on the upper arm.
bdag po bud med bran du 'gyur/ / rgyal po'ang zhabs 'bring nyid du 'gyur/ / shin tu dag cing gtsang ma yis/ / sngags 'di btu bar bya ba yin/ /
The master will become the slave of a woman And kings will turn into servants. By means of the extremely pure and clean This mantra can be removed.
dbang du bya ba'i cho ga'o/ /
This is the ritual for enthrallment.
bsrung ba'i don du 'khrul 'khor 'byung bar 'gyur te/
Next follows the diagram for protection:
ut+pal 'dab bzhi byas nas ni/ / de la dbus su zla ba bri/ / shar du mda' ni bri bar bya/ / lho nyid du ni gzhu bri'o/ /
One should draw a four-petal lotus, And then, in its center, a moon. In the east one should draw an arrow, And in the south, a bow.
mi 'jigs lag pa nub tu'o/ / byang du ut+pal bri bar bya/ / dbus kyi zla bar bsrung bya ste/ / sa bon bdun gyis bskor ba'o/ /
In the west is a hand showing the mudrā of fearlessness, And in the north, one draws a lotus. In the central moon is the one to be protected Surrounded by the seven seed syllables.
'khor lo phyi yi rim pa la/ / ut+pal phreng bas brgyan pa'o/ / 'di ni gro ga la bris la/ / rang gi dpung la gdags par bya/ /
As for the outer perimeter, It is adorned with a garland of utpalas. Having drawn this on birch bark, One should wear it on one’s upper arm.
gzhan yang byis pa rgan po dar la bab/ / 'khrul 'khor gyis ni rang srung 'grub/ /
Moreover, children, the old, and the young will be self-protected by the diagram.

gal te dbang phyug thob par bya 'dod na/ sa bon gyi grong khyer bris la de'i dkyil du gzhu bri bar bya'o/ / gzhu'i dkyil du rin po che'i rnam pa lta bu'i ut+pal gyi myu gu bri bar bya'o/ / ut+pal snying po'i dbus su yi ge dzruM la yi ge bdun gyis bskor ba'o/ / sa le sbram gyi byang bu la mngon par bris la khyim gyi steng du nges par gzhag par bya'o/ / phyi rol nas ut+pa la'i phreng bas mngon par bskor bar byas nas tshes bcu gnyis sam brgyad la rin po che lnga dang ldan pa'i bum pa gang bas phab la khrus byas nas mchod nas bzlas pa brgya rtsa brgyad byas na/ lo gcig gis nor 'dzin dang mtshungs par 'gyur ro/ / de lta bu'i rig pa'i ril bu yang dag par gdags par bya'o/ / de nas sbyor ba gzhan yang 'byung bar 'gyur te/ mig dmar la bab pa na 'gron bu gan rgyal du gnas pa rnyed na lag mthil du bzhag nas sngags 'bum phrag gcig bzlas na/ rgyan po 'debs pa na pha rol po las rgyal bar 'gyur ro/ / 'gron bu de blangs la ku ru kul+le'i sngags brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas/ tshes bcu gnyis sam/ brgyad la khrus byas nas mchod la dar gyi nang du gtums nas dpung pa la btags na/ 'dis nor gyi dbang phyug chen por 'gyur ro/ / 'gron bu de snod du bcug pa'i nang du sba bar byas na nyin rer kAr ShA pa Na re re rnyed par 'gyur ro/ /

If one desires the attainment of a lord, one should draw a citron and, in its center, a bow. Inside the bow, one should draw a jewel-shaped lotus bud. In the center of the lotus bud is the syllable jrūṃ, surrounded by the seven syllables. One should draw this on a golden tablet and keep it in the upper part of the house. One should surround it with an outer garland of lotuses, and, on the eighth or twelfth day of the month, using a jar containing five types of jewels, one should take it down. Having washed and worshiped it, one should recite the mantra one hundred and eight times. Within a year, one will become the equal of Kubera. Such a charm should be worn correctly. Next follows another method: on a Tuesday, if one finds a cowrie shell lying with its face up, one should place it in the palm of the hand and recite the mantra one hundred thousand times. If one plays dice, one will win. Taking up the cowrie one should recite the Kurukullā mantra one hundred and eight times. On the twelfth or eighth day of the month, one should perform ablutions and make offerings. Then one should wrap the shell in silk and wear it on one’s arm. Whoever does so will become a great master of riches. If one puts this shell in a box and hides it in the ground one will every day obtain a kārṣa’s worth of wealth.
don bsgrub pa dang / rgyal srid bsgrub pa dang / rgyal po rnyed pa dang / 'bras bu bsgrub pa'i rgyud do/ /
This is the tantra on obtaining wealth, a kingdom, royalty, and the fruit.
rtog pa gsum pa rdzogs so// //
This completes the third chapter.
Chapter 4
gang gis rdul tshon mthong tsam gyis/ / sangs rgyas myur du thob par byed/ / dkyil 'khor mthong ba'i rim pa bzhin/ / de nas yang dag bshad bya ba/ /
The mere seeing of the colored powder Quickly brings about the attainment of buddhahood, As one progresses through the stages of perception of the maṇḍala. That shall now be explained correctly.
gru bzhi pa la sgo bzhi pa/ / rta babs bzhi yis nye bar brgyan/ / de yi dkyil du lha mo bkod/ / b+ha ga'i rnam pa kha dog legs/ /
Four-sided and with four doors, It is adorned with four arches. In its center one should place the goddess, In a bhaga form of good color.
mda' ni shar du bri bya ba/ / gzhu ni lho yi phyogs su'o/ / mi 'jigs lag pa nub tu ste/ / byang du de bzhin ut+pa la'o/ /
mtshams kyi cha ni thams cad du'o/ /
All are in the border areas:
rdo rje 'khor lo sogs de bzhin/ / gos dmar po yi stod g.yogs bgos/ / dar dmar pos gdong bkab pa yi/ / slob ma der ni gzhug par bya'o/ /
The vajra, the wheel, and so forth. Wearing a red upper garment, And with his face covered by a red silken cloth, The disciple should enter there.

'dis sems ma rdo rje ma'i phyag rgya bcings la 'khor lor me tog dbul bar bya ste/ pra tIts+tsha badzra hoH zhes bya'o/ / g.yogs pa bkrol la dkyil 'khor bstan par bya'o/ / dkyil du bab na ni mchog go/ / mda' la bab na ni dbang du byas pa'i las la dbang bar 'gyur ro/ / mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa la bab na ni dug 'gugs pa la bslab par bya'o/ / ut+pal la bab na shes rab 'phel ba la bslab par bya'o/ / gzhu la bab na ni thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes la bslab par bya'o/ /

At this point the sattvavajrī mudrā should be displayed, a flower should be offered to the circle, and the words “praticcha vajra hoḥ” be spoken. Then, as the cover is removed, the maṇḍala is to be revealed. In the best case, the flower has fallen in the center. If it has fallen on the arrow, the student will be capable of performing the acts of enthrallment. If it has fallen on the giver of fearlessness, the student should study the removal of poison. If it has fallen on the utpala, it is the development of insight that should be studied. And if it has fallen on the bow, omniscient wakefulness is to be pursued.

'jug pa'i dus su 'di skad smra bar bya'o/ / khyod kyis de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi mchog tu gsang ba 'di dkyil 'khor du ma zhugs pa gang gi yang mdun du brjod par bya ba ma yin no/ / dam tshig nyams par gyur ta re/ yang ba ma spangs par 'chi ba'i dus byas nas dmyal bar ltung bar gyur ta re/ zhes pa brjod nas/ de'i rjes la dam tshig sbyin par bya ste/ dkon mchog gsum ni yongs mi spangs/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa rgyas par rgyud las grub pa yin no/ / mna' bsgag par yang bya ste/

At the time of the entry, the following should be declared: “You must not speak of this supreme secret of all the thus-gone ones in front of anyone who has not entered this maṇḍala. Your samaya vow would definitely degenerate. Having failed to avoid the distressful, you would certainly die and fall into hell.” After that the samayas are to be given with the words, “The Three Jewels must never be abandoned…,” and so forth, just as it is extensively taught in the tantra. The oath is to be administered with the following words:
chos kyis rgyal po dam tshig che/ / nga las blangs nas 'ga' nyams na/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' dag / gsang sngags spyod mchog spyod pa rnams/ /
“If any among the great samaya vows of the King of Dharma That you have received from me should degenerate, The buddhas and bodhisattvas Who engage in the supreme conduct of secret mantra
khrag chen dang ni snying chen kyang / / de tshe phyungs nas gsol bar byed/ / chos kyis bstan pa skyong byed pa/ / nga la khyod kyis brnyas mi bya/ /
“Will extract and consume The great blood and the great heart. I am the guardian of the Dharma; Do not displease me.

rtag tu gos dmar bgo bya zhing / / phreng ba dmar po bcing bar bya/ / mtshal gyi phye ma dag gam ni/ / dmar po'i dris kyang byug bya zhing / /
rin chen dmar po sogs kyis brgyan/ / chags pa'i sems kyis bsgom bya zhing / / sngags kyang chags pa'i sems kyis bzla/ / btsag gam sin d+hu ra dag gis/ / pho brang dag ni bri bar bya/ /
mtshal gyi phye ma dag gam ni/ / gur gum dang ni tsan+dan dmar/ / byi ru'i phye ma dag kyang rung / /

“You should always wear red clothes, A red mala, Vermillion powder, Apply red perfume, “And adorn yourself with red jewels and the like. With the mind of passion you must meditate, Just as you must recite the mantra with a passionate mind. The palaces are to be painted With red ocher or sindhura, “Vermillion powder, Saffron, red sandal, Or coral powder‍—all of these are appropriate.
kar ke ta yi phye mas bris/ / sbyin sreg yang na 'khor lo'o/ / rab tu gnas pa de bzhin te/ / kun kyang dmar ba'i rang bzhin sbyar/ /
