“Karketa dust is used for the drawing. Whether for oblations, the circle, Or inauguration, Red substances are always to be applied.

sangs rgyas ngur smrig mtshon byed yin/ / srog chags gsad par mi bya zhing / / bden pa min pa yang mi smra/ / ma byin pa yang blang mi bya/ /
gzhan gyi chung ma bsten mi bya/ / lus kyi las ni rnam gsum dang / / ngag gi rnam pa bzhi dag dang / / yid kyi rnam pa gang gsum pa'i/ /
mi dge ba dag spang bar gyis/ / chos dang de bzhin zang zing dang / / byams dang mi 'jigs zhes bya bzhi/ / sbyin pa khyod kyis rtag tu byin/ /

“These are indicative of the saffron of the Buddha. You must not kill living beings, Not speak what is not true, Not take what has not been given, “And not associate with another’s wife. Three acts of the body, Four of speech, And three of the mind‍— “Give up these unvirtuous acts. Dharma, material things, Love, and fearlessness‍— You must always practice this fourfold generosity.
med na bsam gtan las kyis so/ / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi dag kyang / / khyod kyis rtag tu bstan par bya/ / pha rol phyin pa'i sku dag dang / / stobs rnams dang ni dbang dag dang / /
“If you possess nothing, be generous through acts of meditation. Also, you must always display the four means of magnetizing, Along with the body of the perfections, The powers, and the masteries.
bud med 'gro ba brnyas mi bya/ / sgrol ma'i ming can khyad par du/ / gsang sngags spyod pa'i khyim pas kyang / / bud med de ni blang mi bya/ /
“You must not look down on females, Particularly not anyone by the name of Tārā. Even a householder practitioner of secret mantra May not take such a woman.

grong khyer sgo dang grong dag dang / / yul gang na ni sgrol ma ni/ / sgo stengs bzhi mdo rtsig ngos dang / / sum mdo dag tu khyad par du/ /
gnas pa'i gnas der rtag phyag bya/ /

“In a town, at a gate, in a marketplace‍— Wherever Tārā resides‍— In a high street, at a four-road junction, At the side of a wall, “And in particular at a three-road junction‍— You should always pay homage at such places,
bstod cing mchod pa chen po bya/ / gnas der gnas pa byas nas ni/ / sngags la sogs pa bsgrub par bya/ /
Offer praise, and present great offerings. Having made such places your dwelling “You should practice the mantra and so forth.
sgrol ma'i ming can bud med gang / / kha dog dmar ser mig legs ma/ / de mthong rnal 'byor gus pa yis/ / yid kyis phyag ni bya ba yin/ /
Seeing a woman whose name is Tārā, Of white and red complexion and beautiful eyes, The yogin should respectfully “Pay homage to her in his mind.
ban+d+hu ze'u 'bru'i me tog dang / / de bzhin ka ra bI ra 'dzin/ / gzhan yang me tog dmar po la/ / sgrub pa pos ni 'gom mi bya/ /
Upon bandhūka flowers, The karavīra-holder, As well as other red flowers The practitioner should never step.”
de ltar sdom pa byin pas ni/ / gtsang zhing dag pa'i lha rdzas chu/ / bum pa bzhi na gnas pa'i chus/ / slob ma sngags chus dag par bya/ /
As the vows are given in this way There is the clean and pure water of divine substance. The disciple should be purified with the water in the four vases And the water of mantra.
slob dpon gyis ni rim pa bzhin/ / mda' gzhu sogs kyi phyag rgyas bkru/ / dang por mda' can bum pas te/ / gnyis pa gzhu dang ldan pas so/ / gsum pa mi 'jigs pa lag ste/ / ut+pal gyis ni bzhi par ro/ /

In the right order, the master should then Wash him with the gestures of the arrow, the bow, and so forth. First by means of the vase with the arrow, And secondly, the one with the bow. The third is the one with the hand of fearlessness, And the fourth, the one with the utpala.
ji ltar sangs rgyas shAkya yis/ / seng ge'i sras bcas rdo rje 'dzin/ / rgyal srid chen por dbang bskur ltar/ / de bzhin bdag gis khyod dbang bskur/ /
“Just as the Lion of the Śākyas received “From the buddhas and their offspring, the vajra holders, The empowerment for the great kingdom, So also do I empower you.
khyod kyis sangs rgyas thams cad nyid/ / de nyid dkyil 'khor 'di ru rnyed/ / rdul tshon 'di gzigs sangs rgyas rnams/ / rab tu dgyes par gyur pa yin/ /
The very essence of all the buddhas, “That, indeed, you have found in this maṇḍala. Beholding these colored powders The buddhas are thoroughly delighted.
'di ni 'chi med nad med kyang / / mya ngan med cing phongs pa med/ / theg pa chen po gtsang ma 'dis/ / khyod kyis rdzogs pa'i byang chub 'thob/ /
Here there is no death and disease, “No grief and no poverty. Through this pure Great Vehicle You will attain complete enlightenment.”
mda' sogs bzhi yis dbang bskur bas/ / dam chos snod du byas nas ni/ / slob ma la ni gsang ba dag / cho ga bzhin du sbyin par bya/ /
Empowered through the arrow and the other three The disciple has been made a vessel for the Dharma, And is, in accordance with the ritual, To be granted the secrets.
de la re zhig dang po klu la bsdigs pa la bslab par bya'o/ /
First one should train in the method of warding off the nāgas.

na mo rat+na tra yA ya/ na mo bud d+ha bo d+hi/ sa twe b+h+yaH na mo as+tha/ ma hA a n+yar+ya pra ka lA yaM/ namasmap+te b+h+yo/ bud d+ha ko Ti b+h+yaH tad+ya thA/ oM hrIH hrIH hrIH sarba nA gA nAM/ a nan+ta ku lA nAM/ bA su ki ku lA nAM/ sha~M ka pA la ku lA nAM/ karko Ta ku lA nAM/ pad+ma ku lA nAM/ ku li ka ku lA nAM/ pun+da rI ka ku lAnA~M/ ga nA ka ku lAnA~M/ me ka ku lAnA~M/ dzA la dA ku lAnA~M/ dza la d+ha ra ku lA nAM/ badzrI mu ta ku lAnAM/ saM brta ku lAnAM/ e sa brta ku lA nAM/ ku mu d+ha ku lAnAM/ ka ha ra ku lanAM/ sau gan d+hi ku lA nAM/ ha na ha na sha re na/ ban d+ha ban d+ha tsa bin tA Da ya tA Da ya up+ta lenAM/ birtaM na/ a b+ha yA na/ de hi de hi/ pra la ya/ ka le badzra la da ra/ ma b+ha ta ra yan/ bar Sha na ta nA gA na ba shi ku su/ ku ru ku ru phuH/ ku ru ba ya ku ru ba ya/ phuHphuH oM ku ru kul+le hrIH hU~M swA hA phaT/

namo ratnatrayāya. namaḥ sarvabuddhabodhisattvebhyaḥ. namo ˈṣṭasarpapudgalāya. namaḥ samastebhyo buddhakoṭibhyaḥ.. tadyathā. oṁ hrīḥ hrīḥ hrīḥ sarvanāgānām anantakulānāṃ vāsukikulānāṃ takṣakakulānāṃ śaṅkhapālakulānāṃ karkoṭakulānāṃ padmakulānāṃ mahāpadmakulānāṃ kulikakulānāṃ varāhakulānāṃ puṇḍarīkakulānāṃ ghanakulānāṃ meghakulānāṃ jaladakulānāṃ jaladharakulānāṃ jīmūtakulānāṃ saṃvartakulānāṃ vasantakulānāṃ airāvatakulānāṃ kumudakulānāṃ kahlārakulānāṃ saugandhikakulānāṃ hana hana śareṇa bandha bandha cāpena tāḍaya tāḍaya utpalena bhītānām abhayaṃ dehi pralayakāla iva jaladhāram avatāraya varṣaṃ tān nāgān vaśīkuru kuru phuḥ kulāpaya kulāpaya phuḥ phuḥ, oṁ kurukulle hrīḥ hūṁ phaṭ svāhā phaṭ[16]

sngags 'dis dgon pa'i lci ba las dkyil 'khor byas la/ cho ga bzhin du tsan+dan gyis byug pa pad+ma 'dab ma brgyad pa bris la/ shar la sogs pa 'dab ma la dga' bo la sogs pa'i klu brgyad bzhag nas/ sha kha ra dang gu gul gyis/ rgyu skar snar ma la bab pa'i tshe/ brgya rtsa brgyad bzlas nas/ klu rnams la bdug pa byin nas/ de nas mchod pa'o/ / gal te char 'bab par mi 'gyur na/ chang gis khrus byas la/ seng ldeng gi mes gdung bar bya'o/ / de ltar byas na char 'bab par 'gyur ro/ / gal te char 'bebs par mi byed na/ mdzes thebs par 'gyur ro/ /

With this mantra, one should draw the maṇḍala with gaur dung. As prescribed, one should draw an eight-petaled lotus with sandalwood paste and place on its petals, starting from the eastern one, Ananta and the others‍—the eight nāgas‍—using candied sugar and bdellium. When the moon is in the Rohiṇī lunar house, one should perform a hundred and eight recitations, offer incense to the nāgas, and make offerings. If it does not begin to rain, they should be washed with wine and tormented with the fire of khadira wood. Doing this will bring rain. However, if the nāgas do not send rain, leprosy will break out.
rig pa 'dzin pa 'di dag bya ba'i zas dang ldan par bya ba yin no/ / phyi nas nye bar bsdus la chu bo chen por dor bar bya'o/ /
This is to be carried out by a knowledge holder who is a performer of rites. Afterward, they should be gathered and released in a great river.
lha yang dus su char 'bebs shing / / lo thog phun sum tshogs par shog / 'jig rten mtha' dag skyid pa dang / / rgyal po chos dang ldan gyur cig / ces yongs su bsngo ba yang bya'o/ /
“May the gods send rain And may the crops be excellent. May the people prosper And the king be in accord with the Dharma.” Thus one should perform the dedication.

char shin tu ches pa gcad 'dod na/ sbrul 'dul ba'i mi las sbrul cig blangs la/ tsan+dan gyis byugs nas 'o ma blud par bya zhing / sngags 'di lan bdun bsngags par byas pa'i bum pa dmar po ma tshos pa'i nang du bcug la/ phyag rgya chen pos rgyas btab nas/ bum pa bcag par gyur na/ de ma thag tu char pa gcod par byed do/ /

One who wishes to stop excessive rainfall should obtain a snake from a snake charmer, anoint it with sandalwood paste, and feed it milk. One should pronounce this mantra over it seven times, put it in a red, unbaked jar, and seal it with the great seal. Breaking the vase will make the rain stop immediately.

phyi nas tshogs kyis ston mo bya/ / yang na nyan thos dge 'dun mchod/ / khye'u bu mor zas skom sbyin/ / de ltar byas na klu rnams dga'/ /
char ni 'bab par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ / gal te 'di ltar mi byed na/ / klu rnams dga' bar ma byas pas/ / mdze yis thebs par gyur pa yin/ /

Later, one should offer a feast for the gathering, Or make offerings to the saṅgha of listeners, And give food and drink to boys and girls. Doing this will delight the nāgas. If, when it rains, One does not do this The nāgas will be displeased And so one will contract leprosy.

rgyal po'i bu dang btsun mo'i 'khor dang bcas pa khrus byas la phyir bzlog pa'i tshes lnga la phyir bzlog pa'i rtsa ba btsal nas/ 'o ma'am/ yang na mar dang sbyar te/ dngul gyi snod du blugs la btung zhing dge slong la gsol bar byas na/ lo gcig gi bar du sbrul gyi 'jigs pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de la mi dge ba'i las kyis gal te sbrul gyis bzung na/ sbrul de nyid 'chi bar 'gyur te/ lan bdun mngon par bsngags pas 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / yang mdze nad sos par 'dod na/ sngags 'di nyid kyis dug med par byas nas/ zos na mdze nad sos par 'gyur ro/ / rtsa ba'i sngags kyis chu la bsngags la sbrul gyis bzung ba'i rma la bkrus na dug med par 'gyur ro/ /

The king, along with his sons and queens, should bathe on the fifth day of the waning moon. They should obtain the root of pratyaṅgirā, blend it with milk or ghee, and having poured it into a silver dish, they should drink it. If the dish is offered to an ordained monk there will not be any danger from snakes for one year. Moreover, if, because of its unvirtuous actions, a snake does bite, the snake itself will die. Success comes with seven repetitions of the mantra. Also, if one wishes to cure leprosy, one should, by means of this very mantra, neutralize a poison and then ingest it. This will cure leprosy. If one recites the root mantra over water, and then uses that water to wash the wound from a snake bite, that will remove the poison.

yang klu mthong bar 'dod na/ ut+pal dmar po'i 'dab ma la/ yi ge'i grangs kyis 'bum bzlas nas/ klu gnas shing byin gyis brlabs pa mtshe'u la sogs par btab na/ de'i rjes la klu'i chung ma 'dar bar 'gyur ro/ / sgrub pa po la kye bcom ldan 'das ci zhig bgyi zhes bka' lung nod par byed do/ / sngags pas kyang 'dod pa de blang bar bya'o/ /

Moreover, if one wishes to see nāgas, one should pronounce the mantra upon a red utpala petal one hundred thousand times for each of its syllables. The petal should then be tossed into a pond, or the like, that is inhabited by nāgas and blessed. This will make the females of the nāgas tremble. They will request orders from the practitioner: “What shall we do, O lord?” The practitioner of mantra should then request what he wishes.
rtog pa bzhi pa'o// //
This was the fourth chapter.
Chapter 5

de nas gzhon nu sgra gcan 'dzin bzang pos gang gi tshe bsod snyoms la rgyal po'i khab tu zhugs nas yang 'od ma'i tshal du zhugs te/ lhung bzed bkru ba'i phyir rdzing bu ring por zhugs pa na/ grags 'dzin ma'i bus dge slong dkar po dang 'khrul nas rdzing bur drangs pa dang / de'i tshe gzhon nu sgra gcan 'dzin bzang pos rig pa 'di bzlas so/ / bzlas pa tsam gyis ji ltar 'ga' zhig rang gi khyim nas byung ba bzhin du/ sgra gcan 'dzin bzang po yang de bzhin du bcom ldan 'das kyi thad du song ngo / /

Once when young Rāhulabhadra had gone to Rājagṛha to receive alms, he went to the Veṇuvana grove, and there descended into a long pond to wash his alms bowl. While there, he, the son of Yaśodharā, was mistaken for a white ascetic and so was pulled into the pond. At that time the young Rāhulabhadra recited this spell. No sooner had he recited the mantra than‍—just like someone emerging from his house‍—he arrived in the presence of the Blessed One.

nye bar song nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / yab lags khyed kyis bdag la gsang sngags gang stsal ba'i mthu de bdag gis mthong lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ gang du mthong / klu rnams kyi drung du'o/ /
de lta bas na bcom ldan 'das srog chags gzhan dag srung ba'i slad du sngags 'di bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan du gsol/

Having approached the Lord, he said, “Father, I have seen the power of the secret mantra which you have granted.” The Blessed One asked, “Where have you seen that?” “In the presence of the nāgas. Therefore, I request that the Blessed One teach this mantra, so that other beings too may be protected by it.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis de'i tshe de'i dus su sngags 'di dang / rtog pa 'di lag na rdo rje la bskul nas nyan thos rnams dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams dang / dge slong dang / dge slong ma dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan pa srung ba'i phyir/ nag po chen po nyid kyi bsod snyoms kyis gsos pa'i srin mo'i 'phrog ma la byin no/ / de yang sngon gyi las mi dge ba la blo rtul bar gyur to/ / de nas shin tu dga' bas bcom ldan 'das la zhu ba zhus pa/ bcom ldan 'das bdag gi bu gzugs bzang zhing mdzes pa stobs che zhing mtshan dang ldan pa zhig skyes par gyur na/ 'on kyang blo rtul bar gyur to/ / bcom ldan 'das de ji ltar na de'i shes rab 'phel bar 'gyur/ gal te bdag gi bu de'i yi ge dang bcas par gyur na/ de lta na khyod kyis bstan pa rjes su bsrung bar bgyi'o/ / dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / lo bcu gnyis kyis bstan bcos thams cad la 'jigs pa med pa dang / bzo'i gnas kyi thabs thams cad la mngon par shes pa dang ldan par gyur to/ / rigs kyi bu de'i phyir shes rab chen po 'phel bar bya ba'i phyir gsang sngags dang / rtog pa 'di la bslab par bya ba yin no/ /

So then, at that very time and on that occasion, the Lord dispatched Vajrapāṇi, and benevolently granted this mantra and this manual of instruction to the listeners and the bodhisattvas, to the monks and nuns, and to the male and female lay practitioners. Therefore, children of noble family, one who creates a sandalwood maṇḍala and reads this mantra and this manual of instructions will not be harmed by poison, will not die from poison, and will have no fear of boils, eczema, leprosy, disease, nāgas, snakes, tigers and other beasts of prey, weapons, enemies, poverty, or untimely death. None of these will occur.
In order to protect the Teachings, the Lord granted Mahākāla the demoness Hārītī, whom he had nourished from his own alms bowl. She, however, was lacking in fortune because of her former bad deeds. She was not agreeable to Mahākāla, and so he did not stay with her, did not love her, and did not protect the Teachings either. She therefore became depressed, and in order to enthrall Mahākāla this Kurukullā compendium was taught. From then on, her fortune became vast and excellent. For that reason, children of noble family, if you wish to enthrall sentient beings you should familiarize yourselves with this mantra and this manual of instructions.
It also came to pass that Sunanda’s son was born handsome and good looking, athletic and in possession of auspicious marks, and yet nevertheless dull-witted. Sunanda therefore said to the Blessed One, “O Lord, my son was born handsome and good looking, athletic and in possession of auspicious marks, and yet nevertheless dull-witted. How, O Lord, may he develop insight? Lord, if this child becomes literate he shall become a protector of your doctrine.” Upon hearing this, the Blessed One, with words preceded by mindfulness, spoke this manual of practice and gave this mantra. As soon as he had done so, Sunanda’s son, Rohiṇīkumāra by name, acquired insight. By the twelfth year he was free from being intimidated by any of the treatises, as he was thoroughly acquainted with all of the crafts and arts. Therefore, children of noble family, in order to accumulate great insight, you should study this very mantra and its manual of practice.
de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis mkha' spyod kyi dngos grub bka' stsal pa/
Then the Blessed One spoke of the magical power of sky travel:
ro yi skyon dang bral ba yi/ / dngul chu legs par blangs nas su/ / rdo rje gtan gshong du byas nas/ / 'jig rten mgon dang btags par bya/ /
“Mercury free from the mountain defect[17] One should properly obtain, Place in a vajra hollow, And grind with the world-protector.
slar yang chos sku dang btags la/ / dza ba ti ki ti ka dang / / byi na'i lo ma'i khu ba dang / / nyi ma gsum du mnye bar bya/ /
“Again, one should grind with dharmarasa,[18] With yavatiktikā, And the juice of ākhukarṇī[19] For a period of three days.
ban+da ka ko la yi lo ma dang / / ha ka badzra 'o ma dang / / rna ma phug pa'i khu ba dang / / nu ma'i 'o ma dang mnye ba/ /
“The sap of vandhyā and kākolī, The sap of bhāskara and vajra, The juice of aviddhaśravaṇa, And breast milk‍—with these it should be blended.
dngul chu dang ni rtsab mo yis/ / lan bdun bar du bkru zhing mnye/ / lcags kyi snod du legs bcug nas/ / pri ta ra ka'i zan bcug btso/ /
“Having washed this mercury Seven times with acidulated rice water, One should grind it, put it in an iron pot, And cook it in a lump of vṛddhadāraka dough.
ka na ka yi me tog gong bu dag / 'og dang steng du nges par bskor/ / rtsa ba'i gsang sngags 'bum bzlas na/ / dngul chu de ni g.yas nas 'khor/ /
“A lump of kanaka flowers One should certainly spin on the top and the bottom. When the root mantra has been recited one hundred thousand times, The mercury will revolve clockwise.
mu zi nyi mas bsgos pa la/ / gsang sngags des ni bzlas byas nas/ / lcags snod me la bzhag pa la/ / phye ma'i sbyor ba cung zhig blugs/ /
“Upon that which is infused with the sun of sulfur One should recite the mantra, And in an iron pot placed over fire Pour a little through the method of pulverization.
mu zi cung zad zhu gyur nas/ / nam mkha'i 'dab ma bcug nas bzhu/ / phyi nas phyi ni sa le sbram/ / de la ma ki ki yang bzhag /
“When the sulphur has melted slightly, Sky-leaf is infused and smelted; Thereafter, subsequently gold And mākṣika is infused.
dngul dang zangs kyang de nas gzhug / de bzhin lcags kyang lnga 'gyur ro/ / gzhan kun drug 'gyur bzhu byas nas/ / nyi ma'i 'od dang mnyam par 'gyur/ /
“Then, silver and copper should be infused, And, similarly, iron five times. Everything else should be infused six times. It will then become equal to the light of the sun.
de yi ri thig gzhan phung chen/ / mkhas pas sgyur bar byed pa yin/ / man cas bra zhing bsgyur nus na/ / dngul chu grub par shes par bya/ /
“With one guñja of this, An experienced person will transform a great quantity. If a pala can be transformed with māṣā, It should be known that the mercury has been perfected.
ma he ra dang bcas pa yi/ / spyi yi 'o mas rdo rje bsad/ / byi ba mchu rings khra dang ni/ / grub pa'i dngul chu nang du gzhug /
“Kept together with meṣaśṛṅgī, The vajra should be killed with the sap of snuhī. The bodily products of a female musk shrew Are to be infused into the perfected mercury.
'di dang dngul chu 'dres gyur na/ / mar ka ta la sogs pa'ang 'ju/ / ku ru kul+le'i rnal 'byor pas/ / mig gi phyir ni mu tig bzhu/ /
“When this has mingled with the mercury, Emeralds and so forth are also to be infused. The Kurukullā yogin Should dissolve a pearl on account of the eye;
rtag tu gzigs ma rtswa zos ma/ / bud med brgya la 'dod pa spyod/ / mtshan bdun tsam zhig sbyor bas ni/ / brtul zhugs can ni mkha' spyod 'gyur/ /
“Taking always just a small amount He will take pleasure with a hundred women. With just seven nights of practice The adept will be flying through the sky.
dngul chu mkha' spyod bsgrub pa'i rgyud do/ /
“This is the tantra on the use of mercury for journeying in the sky.
zha nye'i ril bu byas nas ni/ / 'bang hu'i sa bon snod du ni/ / khrag 'dzag kany+tsa'i snod bcug nas/ / sa snod dmar por bcug nas ni/ /
“Taking a ball of lead, One places it in a vessel with bakula seeds. Having placed it in a vessel with the blood-dripping kañcu, One places it in a red earthen vessel.
dngul chu dang bcas zha nye de/ / 'chi bar 'gyur bar the tshom med/ / de dang dngul chu srang re bsres/ / phyi nas srang gcig drug cur bsre/ /
“Together with mercury The lead will undoubtedly die. It is mixed with one pala-measure And afterward with sixty palas.

rang dang mnyam par bsgrub byas nas/ / dngul gyi ril bu byed pa yin/ / sgrol mas dngul chu grub gyur nas/ / sems can don byed nus par 'gyur/ / sems can don las bsod nams tshogs/ / tshogs las byang chub mchog tu 'gyur/ /

“As one practices, correspondingly, A lump of silver will be produced. As Tārā grants the accomplishment of silver One is able to benefit sentient beings. With the welfare of sentient beings comes the accumulation of merit, And from that accumulation, complete enlightenment.
dngul chu bsgrub pa'i rgyud do/ /
“This is the tantra on silver practices.
bstan pa'i krun to'i me tog sngo/ / tsi tra ka sngon zhes bya dang / / rnal 'byor pa yis zla gcig tu/ / 'o ma dar 'thungs lo stong 'tsho/ /
“Nīlakroṇṇa flower, as has been explained, Is known as the blue citraka. For a month, the yogin should drink this with milk; His life will extend for one thousand years.

“The Golden Rosary”, being an account which clearly shows the origins of the Tantra[3] of Tārā.

bla ma la phyag 'tshal lo/ chos kun gdod nas spros dang bral la phyag 'tshal lo/ / thugs rje chen pos dngos kun khyab la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mtha' dag 'gro ba mchog tu sgrol la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rgyal ba'i yum gyur sgrol ma khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Homage to the Lama![4] Homage to all things which from their beginnings are incomprehensively non-diverse![5] Homage to the All-pervading Ones, chiefly the Great Compassionate One![6] Homage to the complete liberation of all beings! Homage to Thee, O Tārā, who became the mother of the Victorious One![7]

'dir sgrol ma'i rgyud gsung pa'i thog mar lo rgyus gsung ba dag bsnyad na/ sngon thog ma med pa'i dus shig na/ 'jig rten gyi khams sna tshogs 'od ces bya bar/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa rnga sgra zhes bya ba byung ste/ de'i bstan pa la mchog tu gus pa'i rgyal po'i bu mo ye shes zla ba zhes bya ba zhig yod de/ des sangs rgyas de 'khor nyan thos dang byang chub sems dpa'i dge 'dun grangs med pa dang bcas pa la lo bye ba brgya stong gi bar du mchod par byas te/ nyi ma re re bzhin du phyogs bcur dpag tshad bcu gnyis thams cad rin po ches go mtshams med par bkang pa'i rin thang gi tshad dang mnyam pa'i mchod rdzas dag bshams so/ / de'i mthar byang chub tu sems bskyed de sems dang po bskyed pa yin no/ / de'i tshe dge slong rnams kyis khyed dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di nyid kyis lus 'di nyid la skyes par gyur te/ bstan pa la bya ba byed par smon lam btab na de bzhin du 'gyur ba'i phyir de ltar rigs so zhes bskul ba las/ dri lan mang du yod skad pa la/ mthar rgyal po'i bu mos smras pa/ 'di na skyes pa med cing bud med med/ / bdag med gang zag med cing rnam rig med/ / pho mor btags pa 'di ni ya ma brla/ / 'jig rten blo ngan rnam par 'khrul par gyur/ / ces bya ba la sogs pa brjod de/ skyes pa'i rten la byang chub 'dod pa ni mang gi bud med kyi lus kyis 'gro ba'i don spyod pa ni 'ga' yang med do/ / de bas na 'khor ba ma stongs kyi bar du bud med kyi gzugs kyis 'gro ba'i don bya'o zhes dam bcas so/ /

Herein at the start of the account of Tārā’s Tantra, if one were to tell of its various historical accounts (one would say): Long ago, in an age before which there was nothing else, the Victorious One, the Tathāgata[8] Dundubhisvara[9] came into existence and was known as Light of Various Worlds. The Princess ‘Moon of Wisdom’[10] had the highest respect for his teaching, and for 10 million and 100,000 years she made offerings to this Enlightened One, his attendant Śrāvakas[11] and to countless members of the Saṅgha[12] of Bodhisattvas.[13] The offerings she prepared each day were in value comparable to all the precious things which filled a distance of 12 yojanas[14] in each of the 10 directions, leaving no intermediate spaces unfilled. Finally, after all this she awoke to the first concepts of Bodhi-Mind.[15] At that time some monks said to her, “It is as a result of these, your roots of virtuous actions, that you have come into being in this female form. If you pray that your deeds accord with the teachings, then indeed on that account you will change your form to that of a man,[16] as is befitting.” After much discourse she finally replied, “In this life there is no such distinction as ‘male’ and ‘female’, neither of ‘selfidentity’, a ‘person’ nor any perception (of such), and therefore attachment to ideas of ‘male’ and ‘female’ is quite worthless. Weak-minded worldlings are always deluded by this.” And so she vowed, “There are many who wish to gain enlightenment in a man’s form, and there are but few who wish to work for the welfare of sentient beings in a female form. Therefore may I, in a female body, work for the welfare of beings right until Saṃsāra[17] has been emptied.”

de nas lo bye ba brgya stong gi bar du/ de rgyal po'i pho brang du gnas shing*/ 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga la thabs mkhas pas spyod bzhin du ting nge 'dzin bsgoms pas/ mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob cing / 'gro ba thams cad sgrol ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin bsgrubs so/ / ting nge 'dzin grub pa de'i nus pas/ de nas nyin re bzhin du snga dro'i dus kyi tshe/ sems can bye ba brgya stong re 'jig rten pa'i sems las bsgral te/ bzod pa la ma bkod kyi bar du zas za bar mi byed do/ / nyi ma phyi dro'i tshe yang de tsam re 'god par byed do/ / de nas sngar gyi ming de 'gyur nas/ sgrol ma zhes bya bar gyur to/ / de nas de bzhin gshegs pa rnga sgras kyang / / ji srid bla na med pa'i byang chub mngon du byas pa de srid du/ ming lha mo sgrol mas mtshan pa 'ba' zhig tu 'gyur bar lung bstan to/ /

Then she remained in the palace for 10 million and 100,000 years in a state of meditation, wisely applying her mind to the five sensual pleasures. As a result of this she gained success in the realisation that dharmas are non-originating[18] and also perfected the meditation known as ‘saving all sentient beings’, by the power of which, every morning she released 10 million and 100,000 beings from (the bondage of) their worldly minds. As long as all of them were not fully instructed in this steadfast course, she would take no nourishment at all. This same policy was followed each evening when she set a like number of beings on the same path. Then her former name was changed and she became known as the Saviouress.[19] Then the Tathāgatha Dundubhisvara prophesied, “As long as you can possibly continue manifesting such supreme Bodhi, you will be exclusively known as ‘Goddess Tārā’.”

de nas bskal pa bi bud+d+ha rnam par rgyas pa zhes bya ba la/ de bzhin gshegs pa don yod grub pa'i drung du/ phyogs bcu'i zhing rab 'byams thams cad kyi sems can rnams la nye bar 'tshe ba thams cad bsrung zhing skyob par dam bcas/ bdud thams cad rnam par 'joms pa'i ting nge 'dzin la snyoms par bzhugs pas bskal pa dgu bcu rtsa lnga'i bar du nyin re bzhin du 'gro ba'i gtso bo bye ba brgya stong 'bum phrag re bsam gtan la yang dag par bkod/ nub re bzhin gzhan 'phrul bdag po ste bdud bye ba brgya stong re btul bas sgrol ma/ bdud ma/ myur ma/ dpa' mo zhes mtshan du btags so/ /

Then in the aeon of Vibuddha known as ‘very vast’,[20] she vowed in the presence of the Tathāgata Amoghasiddhi[21] to preserve and defend from all harm all the sentient beings in the profound vastness of the 10 directions. Seated in the equanimity of the meditation known as ‘completely subduing all demons’ daily, for 95 aeons, she established the minds of one billion and 10,000 million beings in deep meditation. Each night, too, in her capacity as Mistress of Kāmadeva’s Realm[22] she vanquished 10 million and 100,000 demons. Thus she became garlanded with the names of ‘Saviouress’, ‘Mainstay’, ‘Swift One’ and ‘Heroine’.[23]

de nas bskal pa thogs pa med pa zhes bya ba la/ dge slong dri ma med pa'i 'od kyi snang ba zhes bya ba phyogs bcu'i de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis snying rje chen po'i 'od zer gyis mngon par dbang bskur bas/ de nyid 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs su gyur la/ de'i tshe de bzhin gshegs pa rigs lnga la sogs pa sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis/ slar yang mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi ngo bor gyur pa 'od zer chen po'i dbang bskur bas/ 'od zer snga phyi gnyis yab yum du gyur pa 'chis pa las lha mo sgrol mar gyur te/ spyan ras gzigs kyi thugs ka nas byung nas sangs rgyas thams cad kyi dgongs pa bskang ba dang / sems can rnams 'jigs pa chen po brgyad dang / bcu drug las skyob par mdzad do/ /

In the aeon known as ‘all-pervading’, the monk known as ‘Radiant Pure Light’ was given the higher initiation of the Rays of Great Compassion by all the Tathāgatas of the 10 directions, and he became the Noble Avalokiteśvara.[24] At that time, the Tathāgatas of the Five Families[25] and all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas also gave the initiation of the Great Rays through which he gained insight into the ultimate nature of divine wisdom. From the father-mother union of the former and latter light rays the Goddess Tārā was created, and after her birth from the heart of Avalokiteśvara she worked, with satisfied thought of all the Buddhas, to protect sentient beings from the Eight and Sixteen Great Fears.[26]

de nas bskal pa bzang po chen po zhes bya ba la mi g.yo dbugs dbyung gi skabs nas 'byung ba ltar bstan no/ / de nas bskal pa a sang+ga zhes pa la phyogs bcu'i de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis dbang bskur bas sangs rgyas thams cad bskyed pa'i yum du gyur to/ / de dag ni sngon thog ma med pa'i dus so/ /

Then in the aeon known as ‘Vastly Good’, it is taught that Tārā gave instructions at the stage known as ‘Immovable Encouragement’. Then in the aeon called Asangka,[26A] when all the Tathāgatas of the 10 directions[27] had consecrated her, she became the Mother who produces all the Buddhas. All that happened a beginningless time ago.

de nas bskal pa 'di nyid la/ ri po Ta lar sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' lha klu gnod sbyin la sogs pa grangs med cing tshad med pa'i dbus su 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs kyis sgrol ma'i sngags rgyud 'bum phrag brgya gsungs so/ / rdzogs ldan gyi dus su rigs drug gi sems can gyi don de kas byed skad/ gsum ldan gyi tshe de nub nas 'bum phrag drug pa byung ngo / / gnyis ldan gyi dus na de yang nub nas stong phrag bcu gnyis pa byung ngo*/ / de nas rtsod ldan gyi dus na sgrol ma 'dus pa bloka stong yod pa 'di byung ngo / / 'dir bla ma'i zhal nas/ rdzogs ldan la sogs pa de rnams su rgyud kyi glegs bam ni yod pa ma yin mod/ lha dang rig 'dzin rnams kyi sar rgya cher spyod pas 'gro ba gzhan thams cad kyi yang don chen por gyur pa la dgongs pa yin no/ / zhes gsung / 'on kyang sngags kyi gdul bya dus de dag tu yang 'byung ba mi 'gal ba'i phyir/ glegs bam yang 'byung du rung la/ mtha' gcig tu de 'dra'i nges gzung mi dgos par mngon no/ khyad par rgyud 'di rnams slar yang 'o skol gyi ston pas bzlos te gsungs pa'ang yin te/ 'di nyid kyi bshad pa'i rgyud mkha' 'gro ma gsang ba'i thig le las/ gru 'dzin ri yi rtse mor ni/ / shAkya seng ges gsungs pa'i rgyud/ ces gsungs pas so/ /

Then in this very aeon at the Potala Mountain,[28] countless Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Gods, Nāgas,[29] Yakṣas[30] and others gathered, and there in that limitless centre (axis mundi), Ārya Avalokiteśvara intoned Tārā’s Tantra and Mantra[31]10 million times. In Satyayuga[32] it is said that the same thing was done (in the way described above) for the welfare of the six classes of sentient beings.[33] In Tretāyuga[34] 600,000 (such verses) arose when the Tantra had disappeared. In Dvāparayuga,[35] furthermore, another 12,000 arose when these too had disappeared. Then in Kāliyuga[36] a thousand Tārā verses, all in one convocation, came into being. About that time, my Guru has said, “In Satyayuga and in the other ages there was no book of the Tārā Tantra at all. However, they were extant in the lands of the Gods and Vidyādharas[37] and they are aimed at the increased welfare of all other sentient beings.” However, so that there appears to be no contradiction in saying that there might well have been disciples of the mantra path at that time, it is entirely possible that there were books extant at that time too. We should not stick to only one extreme or the other. These tantras were taught by our very own Teacher (Buddha Śākyamuni) since it is taught in the explanatory tantra named ‘The Ḍākinī[38] Secret Essence’, first uttered at the peak of the Potala Mountain by the Lion of the Śākyas.”[39]

'di'i gtam rgyud zhal snga nas 'byung ba ni 'di yin te/ / de yang ston pa 'di nyid sangs rgyas pa'i mdzad pa sems can la ston par bzhed nas/ byang chub kyi snying po la bzhugs te/ smin mtshams kyi 'od zer gyis bdud kyi gnas thams cad khyab par mdzad pa na/ bdud kyi dmag rnams lhags pa'i tshe/ sgrol mas bzhad pa brgyad kyis bzhad pas de thams cad sa la 'gyel zhing brgyal bar gyur skad/ de nas ston pa nyid khro bo mi g.yo bar gyur te/ bdud thams cad mthag par byed pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyis bdud bcom ste/ slar yang byang chub kyi snying po la mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas/ de bzhin gshegs pa mi bskyod pa dang gnyis su med par gyur pa la/ lha mo sgrol mas mchod par byas te/ de'i sngags rgyud rgyas par gsungs so/ / de bzhin du rgyal ba rigs drug gi dkyil 'khor rgyas par bstan nas/ ji skad du bshad pa'i rgyud rnams mi nub par bya ba'i phyir 'gro ba rigs drug gi sems can la ston par bzhed de/ sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs dang bcas nas ri po ta lar gshegs te/ lha klu gnod sbyin dri za la sogs pa grangs med cing tshad med pa'i 'gro ba la dbang bskur te/ sngags kyi theg pa bshad nas dngos grub la bkod do/ /

This then is the essence of the legend itself, I heard from my own Guru. After this very teacher Śākyamuni Buddha taught about the Enlightenment itself to all sentient creatures, and while abiding in the Heart of Bodhi, he filled all the demon haunts with light rays emanating from the space between his eyebrows. At another time when the demon hosts were approaching, Tārā laughed eight times and, tumbling them to the ground, made them unconscious, so it is said. Then, changing himself into Krodhācala,[40] Śākyamuni Buddha fettered all the demons with bonds of meditation and was completely victorious over them. Again, in a state of Bodhi, Tārā saw the Fully Enlightened One and the Tathāgata Aksobhya[41] become identical, and she paid them homage and he intoned to her the grand Tantras. Accordingly he preached about the Maṇḍala[42] of the Six Jina Families to ensure that whatever had been said about the Tantras would not be erased, and wishing to demonstrate this to the six classes of sentient beings, went to the Potala Mountain together with a gathering of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. There, a countless number of Gods, Nāgas, Yakṣas and Gandharvas etc.[43] were empowered, as well as innumerable sentient beings. Having preached about the Mantrayana,[44] he also established all of them in states of Siddhi.[45]

mthar phyag na rdo rje la rgyud rnams gtad de/ lcang lo can la sogs pa'i rig pa 'dzin pa'i gnas rnams su spyod cing / mi'i 'jig rten du rgyud thams cad mi nub par bya ba'i phyir/ lag na rdo rje rgyal po in+d+ra b+hu ti zhes bya bar gyur te/ rgyud mtha' dag glegs bam la bris nas chos kyi mdzod ces bya bar sbas nas/ dpa' bo dang rnal 'byor ma rnams kyis nyams su len pa yin skad/ spyir sngags kyi theg pa dbugs dbyung drug gi bstan pa la/ da lta he ru ka'i bstan pa yin par gsungs so/ / dbugs dbyung drug gi rnam gzhag rgyud nyid na gsal lo/ khyad par bstan pa 'di nyid la 'dzam bu gling du sgrol ma'i rgyud ji ltar byung ba'i tshul ni/ rgyal ba mya ngan las 'das nas/ lo sum brgya lhag pa tsam nyan thos rnams kyis bka' bsdu ba gsum pa zin pa'i dus lha dang klu dang gnod sbyin dang dri za dang srin po gzhan zhig na/ rnams kyi gnas na bzhugs pa'i theg pa chen po'i mdo sde phal che ba yang rgya gar gyi yul tha dad pa rnams su byon/ rang byung gi glegs bam rnams kyang byung zhing gcig car dar bar gyur la/ de dag ston pa po sdom brtson chos smra ba/ mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob cing / 'jam dpal dang / spyan ras gzigs dang / byams pa la sogs pa'i zhal mthong ba rnal 'byor spyod pa'i slob dpon lnga brgya dang*/ ngo bo nyid med smra ba'i bdag nyid chen po brgyad la sogs pa byung ngo*/ /

Finally the Tantras were handed to Vajrapāṇi[46] who secreted them in the abodes of Vaiśravaṇa[47] and the Vidyādharas so that (thereafter) they would not disappear from the world of humans. To further ensure this, Vajrapāṇi transformed himself into King Indrabhūti,[48] and having written all the Tantras up in book-form, hid them in the so-called ‘Dharma Treasury’, so it is said. There, various tantric initiates[49] and yoginīs then committed them to memory. In general the Mantrayāna doctrine of the ‘Six Encouragements’ is nowadays spoken of as being Heruka’s[50] doctrine. Their order and method of application are made clear in this particular Tantra, however. How, then, did this unique doctrine of Tārā’s Tantra arise in the world? About 300 years after the Jina had died, after the time when the Śrāvakas were holding their Third Council,[51] Gods, Nāgas, Yakṣas, Gandharvas and Rākṣasas[52] were seated at their abodes when the separate volumes of the Mahāyāna Sūtra[53] Collection known as the “Avataṃsaka”[54] arrived severally from India. The self-arisen volumes spread alone and unaided, and at that time teachers and ascetics attained steadfastness in the (concept of) dhārmas as uncreated. As well as this, 500 Masters of the Yogācāra[55] and eight Mahātmas,[56] preachers of the doctrine of ‘no real existence’[57] and others saw the countenances of Mañjuśri,[58] Avalokiteśvara, Maitreya[59] etc.

de dag dang dus mnyam par bya spyod rnal 'byor rgyud gsum dang / theg pa bla na med pa'i thabs dang shes rab kyi rgyud ci rigs pa dang bcas pa yang dar zhing / rdo rje sems dpa' dang / gsang ba'i bdag po zhal mthong ba rnams kyis skal pa dang ldan pa rnams la bstan pas/ dus de'i tshe sngags kyi theg pa thos pa thams cad dngos grub ma thob pa gcig kyang med skad de/ shar phyogs b+ha ga la na/ rgyal po ha ri tsan+d+ra 'khor stong dang bcas pa zung 'jug gi sku grub pa dang / o Di bi shar rgyal po muN+Da zhes bya ba 'khor stong dang bcas pa rig pa 'dzin pa'i gnas thob pa dang / nub phyogs ma la war/ rgyal po b+ho dza de wa zhes bya ba 'khor stong dang bcas pa mi snang bar gyur pa dang / lho phyogs korlu nar rgyal po ha ri b+ha dra 'khor dpag tu med pa dang bcas te/ ril bu'i dngos grub grub pa sogs la brgya 'am nyis brgya tsam gyi bar du skye bo 'bum phrag lhag gcig gis dngos grub thob/ 'on kyang rtag tu gsang ba bsrung ba'i phyir dngos grub ma thob bar du gzhan sus kyang sngags kyi spyad pa spyod pa yin par mi shes skad/ de dag gi tshe/ rje btsun ma 'phags ma sgrol ma nyid kyi thugs rjes ma bsgrubs par yang zhal bstan cing / rjes su gzung ba'i lo rgyus gsung 'phros las 'byung ba mdo tsam zhig bsnyad na/

The texts of the three tantra groups of Kriyā, Caryā and Yoga and the Anuttara method,[60] as well as part of the Wisdom Tantras, also spread and were taught to those blessed with the good fortune of seeing the visages of Vajrasattva[61] and Vajrapāṇi. At that time it is said that of all those who heard the Mantrayāna not even one was unable to attain Siddhi. In the east in Bhaṅgala, the King Haricandra together with 1,000 attendants attained the Bodhi Perfection of Yuganaddha.[62] In the north the King of Oḍiviśa called Muñja attained the state of Vidyādhara together with 1,000 attendants. King Bhojadeva of Mālava in the west vanished together with 1,000 courtiers.[63] In the south at Kongkuna, King Haribhadra together with innumerable servants perfected the Siddhi of Making Pills etc,[64] and for between 100 and 200 years (as a result) more than 100,000 beings attained Siddhi. Because of the constant protection accorded to this secret practice, we do not know of other practitioners who were able to gain Siddhi. Now follow, culled from annals and stories, some accounts of Noble Ārya Tārā’s mercy, perfections and her promises. They will be in the form of a discourse.
dgra'i 'jigs pa las ji ltar skyabs pa'i tshul

1. dgra'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ o Di bi shar rgyal rigs zhig skyed mos tshal du gnyid kyis log pa na/ dgra'i dmag tshogs go mtshon thogs pa stong tsam gyis bskor bas/ skyabs gzhan med de/ sgrol ma zhes bya ba 'jigs pa bcu drug las skyob pa zhig yod ces thos te/ de kho na la skyabs su 'gro'o bsam pas/ sgrol ma'i mtshan nas bos shing / skad phyung bas skad cig de nyid la rje btsun ma mdun gyi nam mkhar byon te/ zhabs kyi 'og nas rlung drag po g.yos pas dmag rnams phyogs bcur khyer nas rang gi yul du sleb skad/

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Enemies. A Kṣatriya[65] from the land of Oḍiviśa awakened one day in a grove where he had fallen asleep, and found himself surrounded by a host of 1,000 enemy soldiers, all brandishing their swords at him. He recalled having heard that Tārā was the Protectress against the 16 Fears, and as he had no other (divinity) in which to seek refuge, he thought he would go to the Goddess as his defence. At the same instant in which he called out her name, the Noble Lady herself appeared before him, arriving from the skies. From underneath her feet whirlwinds carried the soldiers off in the 10 directions, and so the man was able to arrive safely in his own country.

2. seng ge'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ shing 'thun zhig nags tshal du song ba las/ seng ge mo bkres pa dang 'phrad nas za bar brtsams te khar thogs nas rang gi tshang dang nye bar song / der 'jigs shing skrag pas sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas/ mdun du bud med shing lo'i gos can zhig byung nas seng ge mo'i kha nas de blangs te/ grong khyer gyi tshong 'dus su bzhag go /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Lions. A wood-gatherer went off into the forest and there he came face to face with a ravenous lioness who held him in her jaws and prepared to eat him. His hope faded away. Terrified and scared, he begged Tārā to come to his assistance, and she suddenly appeared before him, clothed in leaves. She pulled him from the lioness’ jaws and set him down safely in the city marketplace.

3. glang po'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ yul gyi bu mo lo bcu gnyis lon pa zhig me tog 'thu bar nags seb tu song ba na/ khu ni zhes bya ba glang po che gtum po dang 'phrad de/ des sna shal gyis bcings/ mche ba snyan par brtsams pa na/ sgrol ma'i mtshan dran par byas shing / snying thag pa nas gsol ba btab pas glang po che dbang du gyur te/ rdo'i stegs mthon po la bzhag ste/ sna shal gyis phyag byas shing / yang blangs nas grong khyer gyi tshong 'dus kyi gnas su yang de bzhin du byas so/ / de nas 'dun khang dang / lha khang dang / rgyal po'i pho brang gi sgor yang de ltar du byas pas/ bu mo 'di ni bsod nams dang ldan pa zhig go zhes rgyal po'i btsun mor gyur to/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Elephants. A 12-year-old girl went to the forest one day to gather flowers, and there she was confronted by a fierce elephant named Kuni, who bound her in his trunk and started to crush her with his tusks. Remembering. Tārā’s name, the girl earnestly begged her to help and Tārā brought the elephant under control. The creature then put the girl up on a high stone ledge and saluted her with his trunk and, leading her away, took her to the town’s market-place. Then he took her to the council chambers, the temple and around the King’s palace. The King heard of this girl and her great stock of merits and took her as his Queen.

4. me'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ sha 'khon chags pa'i khyim tshang gcig nub mo khang pa la dgra yis me btang bas 'bros par brtsams pa las ma thar ba'i tshe/ / kye sgrol ma kye ma ho sgrol ma zhes mtshan nas brjod pas/ khyim gyi steng du sprin shin tu sngo zhing mdzes pa zhig byung ste/ char gyi rgyun gnya' shing tsam khyim kho na la babs pas me zhi'o/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Fire. A certain householder hated his enemy (neighbour) and one night set fire to his house. The latter started to flee but could not get free—at that instant he called out, “O Tārā, O Mother Tārā!” A beautiful blue cloud arose above the house, and from it fell a continual shower of rain, like a yoke, on the house itself, completely quenching the flames.

5. dug sbrul gyi 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ grong khyer gyi smad 'tshong ma zhig dus lan gcig mu tig gi do shal lnga brgya sbyin pa'i tshong dpon zhig rnyed de/ nam phyed kyi dus na tshong dpon gyi khyim du 'gro bar 'dod pas/ rang gi khyim nas song ste/ lam du shing shi ri sha'i yal ga zhig la 'jus pa na/ shing la 'khril ba'i sbrul gdug pas lus la 'khril shing zin pa'i tshe/ rje btsun ma sgrol ma dran par byas pa tsam gyis dug sbrul de nyid me tog gi 'phreng bar gyur nas/ zhag bdun gyi bar du lus la gnas bar gyur to/ / de nas sbrul de nyid dkar po dug dang bral bar gyur nas chu bor zhugs so zhes grags so/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Poisonous Snakes. In a certain city there once lived a prostitute who was given a necklace of 500 pearls. She wanted to go to the merchant’s house at midnight. Leaving her house, and while on the road there, she happened to grasp an acacia branch around which was coiled a poisonous snake, which seized her around the body. By her mere recollection of Ārya Tārā, the snake was transformed into a flower garland, in which form it remained for seven days. Thereafter it lost its white venom and proceeded into the river, so it is said.

6. chom rkun gyi 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ gu dza ra tha'i yul gyi nang tshan b+ha ru kats+tsha zhes bya bar/ tshong dpon shin tu longs spyod che ba zhig yod pa/ ma ru'i yul du rnga mong stong tsam dang / khyu mchog lnga brgya tsam gyi khal bkal te song ba las/ lam khar chom rkun stong tsam gnas pa'i 'brog dgon par phyin pas/ sngon du song ba'i tshong pa thams cad bsad pa'i sha khrag rus pas phyogs thams cad khyab/ tshong pa brgya stong ni gsal shing la btsugs/ chom rkun de rnams mi'i sha yang za ba srin po lta bur yod pas/ tshong dpon de shin tu 'jigs nas/ mgon skyabs gzhan med pas sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pa na/ sgrol ma'i sprul pa dpa' bo go mtshon thogs pa'i dmag dpag tu med pa byung ste/ chom rkun de rnams rgyang ring du bskrad cing shi bsad ni med do/ de ltar chom rkun rnams byer ba'i shul du tshong pa de nyid bde bar phyin nas slar yang b+ha ru kats+tshar sleb bo/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Brigands. A man from a certain part of Gujarat known as Bharukaccha was a very wealthy trader. On the way to the land of Maru[66] with about 1,000 camels and half that number of bulls, all fully laden, he found that his path went through the territory of a bandit gang which was situated in the midst of a veritable wilderness. All the previous traders who had gone there had been slain, and their flesh, blood and bones were scattered in the four directions. A myriad of these traders had been impaled on wooden stakes and the robbers who behaved like devils even ate their flesh. The (chief) trader was absolutely terrified, and as he had no other protector he begged Tārā to help him. She immediately arose in the phantom form of ‘Tārā the heroine’;[67] holding aloft a sword and accompanied by a huge army, Tārā banished the bandits to a remote land without slaying any of them and brought the dead back to life. Accordingly, when the robbers had been scattered into isolation the trader happily set off and again arrived at Bharukaccha.

7. btson ra las bskyabs pa ni/ rkun po'i dpon zhig gis rgyal po'i bang mdzod kyi khyim phug ste song ba na/ chang gi bum pa zhig rnyed de/ de 'thungs pas de nyid du myos shing gnyid du song ba/ rgyal po'i mi rnams kyis rig ste bzung nas/ btson dong du bcug zhags pas bcings sdug bsngal sna tshogs pa myong ba na/ / gzhan mgon skyabs med de/ sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas 'dab chags kha dog sna lnga pa zhig nam mkha' nas babs te byung nas zhags pa rnams kyang bkrol/ btson khang gi sgo yang rang bye bar gyur te/ ci bder thar nas rang yul du phyin pa na/ rmi lam du bud med rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa zhig byung ste/ gal te khyed nga'i drin dran na khyed cag 'khor dang bcos pa rkun po'i las spongs shig ce sa byung bas rkun po de nyid 'khor lnga brgya dang bcas chom rkun gyi las spangs nas dge ba rgya chen po byed pa byung ngo / /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Prison Walls. A leader of a robber band went to the subterranean treasury of the king. There he found a jug of beer which he drank, and being a bit befuddled he went to sleep. However, he was seen and seized by the king’s men who flung him into a dungeon, bound up. There he underwent various sufferings. Bereft of any other protector he prayed to Tārā and a five-coloured bird descended from the sky, loosened his bonds and caused the dungeon door to open by itself. Having thus been freed and once again at large,[68] he returned to his own country. (That night) in a dream, a beautiful girl adorned with all types of ornaments arose and said to him, “If you recall my kind deed to you, then you and your followers must relinquish your thieving ways!” And so it happened that the robber and his 500 accomplices gave up their lives of crime and did many virtuous deeds instead.

8. rgya mtsho'i rlabs kyi 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ lho phyogs kyi lam du zhugs pa'i tshong pa lnga stong tsam zhig gru bo che *** gsum bzung ste gzings chen por zhugs nas/ rin po che'i gling du phyin te/ gru gcig ni rin po ches khengs par byas so/ / yang de nas song ba na/ tsan dan sa mchog gi gling dang 'phrad de/ gru gnyis pa tsan dan sa mchog gis gang bar byas so/ / de nas yul du 'ong bar 'dod pa la/ rgya mtsho'i nor bdag rnams khros te rlung chen po btang bas thag ring du khyer te/ rgya mtsho kha dog mi gcig pa mang po brgal ba'i mthar/ cha klong drag tu 'khrugs pa zhig tu sleb/ de gong du tshong pa rnams kyis/ tshangs pa/ khyab 'jug dbang phyug zla ba/ nyi ma/ ku be ra la sogs pa rnams la nyin mtshan du gsol ba 'debs kyang ma phan la/ der gru'i thag pa chad de/ rin po che dang tsan dan gyi gru yang stor/ gru bo che yang nub la khad pa na/ de na sangs rgyas pa'i dge bsnyen gcig yod pas/ sgrol ma dran pas yi ge bcu pa'i sngags skad gsangs mthon pos bzlas pas/ de ma thag tu mthun pa'i rlung byung ste/ gru tshur log nas nub gcig la 'dzam bu'i gling du sleb pa na/ rin po che dang tsan dan gyi gru yang rlung gis tshur bdas te/ mnyam du 'dzom mo/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Ocean Waves. In the southern regions lived 5,000 traders, and they took three large ships and set out for the Land of Precious Things. One vessel was filled with all manner of jewels and, setting off again, the traders finally reached the Land of Yellow Sandalwood where they filled up the second boat. After that they wished to return home, but the ‘Treasure Holder’ of the ocean was very angry with them and sent down a great windstorm which carried them far away.[69] After crossing oceans of many different colours, they were confronted by huge, raging billows, and the merchants prayed both night and day to Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Śiva, the Moon and Sun, to Kuvera and all the other divinities,[70] but to no avail. The hawsers of the boats snapped and the vessels carrying the jewels and sandalwood were scattered. The large boat of theirs was driven to the point of sinking. Then a Buddhist Upāsaka[71] remembered Tārā and in a mystic and reverend voice recited her 10-letter mantra.[72] Immediately an agreeable wind arose and the boat turned around, arriving back in India one night. The vessels carrying the jewels and the sandalwood all joined together again.

9. sha za'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ shar phyogs kyi gtsug lag khang zhig tu/ nyan thos sen+ta pa kho na gnas pa zhig yin pa las/ der dus lan cig nub mo res kyi gtsug lag khang gi phyi rol sa la 'chag tu song ba'i dge slong re re shi nas/ gtsug lag khang de nyid kyi tshogs pa 'grib par gyur pa las/ nub cig dge tshul zhig 'chag sar song bas/ sha za mdog ngam nag cing mi sdug pa mche ba gtsigs pa gcig byung nas mgo bo nas bzung ba na/ theg chen pa rnams la sgrol ma zhes bya ba 'jigs pa brgyad las skyob pa cig yod ces zer gyi/ de la skyabs su 'gro'o snyam nas/ sgrol ma zhes mtshan nas bos so/ / der lha mo nag mo ral gri thogs pa zhig byung nas sha za de la sdigs par/ sha za des dge tshul la bzod par gsol te sa 'og nas lcags kyi bum pa mu tig gis gang ba zhig phyung nas byin no/ / de phyin chad gtsug lag khang der gnod pa de rgyun chad do/ /

She is the Protectress from the Dread of Flesh-eating Ogres.[73] In the east was a temple which was the sole dwelling place for Śrāvakas of the Sendhapa Sect.[74] At that time it happened that every evening each monk who went outside the temple precincts for his constitutional walk was slain, and consequently the number of those remaining inside the temple dwindled. One evening a certain novice went for his stroll when a cannibal ogre, black, ugly and baring its fangs, leapt out and grabbed him by the head. The novice remembered that Mahāyānists believe Tārā to be the Saviouress from the Eight Great Fears, and he thought that he would go to her as his Protectress. He cried out her name. A black goddess arose, holding a sword aloft, and she menaced the ogre with it. The ogre begged the novice for forgiveness and offered him an iron pot, stuffed full of pearls which it got from underground. Ever since then it has never harmed that temple.

10. mdze nad kyi 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ yul ku ma ra k+She trar las kyi dbang gis bram ze'i slob dpon shig la mdze nad kyis thebs nas/ der phan tshun gcig la gcig 'gos te/ bram ze lnga brgya mdze nad drag pos zin par gyur/ nye du dang sman pa rnams kyis kyang bor shing / bram ze gtsang sbra'i chos las nyams te lhag mas 'tsho zhing / slong mor spyod pa las/ lam gar rje btsun ma 'phags ma sgrol ma'i rdo sku gcig mthong bas dad pa skyes te/ bram ze lnga brgya po rnams kyis gsol ba btab pas/ sgrol ma'i phyag nas rtsi sman gyi rgyun byung ba la khrus byas pa tsam gyis mdze nad de nyid du zhi/ lha'i lus ltar mchog tu mdzes pa'i lus su gyur skad/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Leprosy. In the land of Kumārakṣetra, by the power of his karma, a powerful ācārya caught leprosy, and as he wandered here and there from one person to another, he infected them. About 500 Brahmins caught that virulent disease from him. Relatives and doctors fled from his presence for he defiled their state of purity. Eventually he was reduced to begging for a living. One day on the road he saw a stone image of Noble Ārya Tārā, and with faith welling up inside him he begged her on behalf of the 500 (infected) Brahmins. A liquid-like medicine trickled in an endless stream from Tārā’s hand, and when he had bathed in it (he found that) the leprosy had subsided. It is said that he became as completely beautiful as the gods.

11. dbang po'i pho nya ba'i 'tshe ba las bskyabs pa ni/ de la dbang po ni shar phyogs kyi phyogs skyong yin la/ de'i pho nya ba ni dri za'i gdon yin/ shin tu rtsub cing rgyug sla ba chos la bar du gcod pa che ba zhig yin no/ / de las bskyabs pa'i gtam ni/ yul bcom brlag gi nags tshal zhig na/ nyan thos kyi dge slong bsam gtan pa lnga brgya yod de/ de rnams dge ba'i chos la brtson par gnas pa las/ dus nam zhig na dbang po'i pho nya ba byung ste/ kha cig ni bram ze/ kha cig ni bud med/ kha cig ni dge slong gi gzugs brnyan can dang / res 'ga' gnod sbyin gyi rnam pa drag po seng ge dang glang po dang / sha ra b+ha la sogs pa 'jigs su rung ba'i gdong can mang po byung ste/ res 'ga' ni sdig pa dang / res 'ga' ni bstod pa la sogs pas 'brid par byed pa na/ dge slong kha cig ni dran med du song / kha cig ni smyo/ kha cig ni yid gzhan du 'gyur te/ glu dang gar kho nas dus 'da' bar byas so/ / der dge slong zhig gis 'byung po'i bar chad kyis gtses par shes nas/ lha mo sgrol ma zhes bya ba 'jigs pa thams cad las skyob bo zhes grags pas/ 'di la phan par 'gyur ro snyam ste/ nags tshal 'di ni lha mo sgrol ma'i yin no zhes bris nas shing la btags so/ / de tsam gyis 'jigs pa de nyid rang zhi bar gyur te/ de thams cad lha mo sgrol ma la mos pas theg pa chen po la zhugs so/ /

She is the Protectress from the Mischief of Indra’s Angels. Indra was the protector of the eastern areas and his emissaries were demonic sprites known as Gandharvas who, being quite easy to anger, had become an obstacle to the supreme Dharma. Now, as to the account of the protection: in a forest grove in the land of Mathurā[75] lived 500 Śrāvaka monks and meditators. They abided there, practising the sublime Dharma assiduously. Sometimes the sprite would appear as a Brahmin, sometimes as a young girl, at other times in the bodily image (form) of a monk and even occasionally as a Yakṣa or a fierce lion, elephant or as an eight-legged beast known as Sarabha, fierce with its many faces. Sometimes the sprite used wicked, and at other times more fair methods, to beguile the monks. The result was that some monks lost their memories, others went mad and yet others took on aspects of the minds of others. Thus deranged, they passed the time in singing and dancing. Then a particular monk, realising the hindrance caused by the evil sprite’s mischief, recalled that Tārā was renowned as the Protectress from all such terrors, and he thought that she would be of great benefit to them. He wrote the words, “This forest belongs to the Goddess Tārā,” and affixed it to the trees in the forest. All those (monks) who had been scared out of their wits became quite calm and all of them paid her homage and abided from then on in the Mahāyāna.

12. dbul ba'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ bram ze shin tu dbul po zhig nyams thag pas/ lam srang zhig na sgrol ma'i rdo sku zhig 'dug pa la/ rang gi sdug bsngal byung tshul gyi gtam rnams zhus pas/ mchod rten zhig dang nye ba'i sa phyogs zhig bstan te/ 'di rkos la gter rnyed par 'gyur ro zhes gsung la/ des kyang brkos pas gser gyi bum pa mu tig gis gang ba dang / dngul gyi bum pa rin po che sna tshogs kyis gang ba la sogs pa mang du rnyed nas/ bdun brgyud kyi bar du dbul ba'i sdug bsngal bsal skad/ yang zhing pa dbul po zhig gis/ rje btsun ma sgrol ma'i mtshan nas brjod cing gsol ba btab pas/ bud med shing lo'i gos can cig byung nas/ shar phyogs su song shig ces lung bstan/ des kyang shar phyogs su song ste/ bye ma'i steng zhig tu nyal ba na/ dril bu'i sgra grags pas gnyid sad/ der lta ljang khu dril bu'i rgyun can zhig rmig pas bye ma rko zhing 'dug go /de nas rta de yud tsam gyis gzhan zhig tu song pas/ rta'i rmig pa'i shul de brkos pas dang por dngul gyi sgo/ de nas gser dang / shel dang / bai DU r+Ya la sogs pa rin po che sna bdun gyi sgo rnams byung ba rim pas bye ste/ sa 'og gi yul zhig tu klu dang lha ma yin mang po'i gtso bar gyur nas 'dod yon gyi dga' 'dum nyams mu myong ste/ lan cig sa'i bu ga'i sgo nas rang gi yul du 'ongs pas/ de bar du rgyal po rabs gsum 'das 'dug zer ro/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Poverty. A Brahmin who was extremely poor and suffering considerably as a result, came upon a stone image of Tārā one day in a narrow street, and he poured out an account of how his troubles had arisen. Pointing out a site near the shrine, she said that it would be changed into a treasure trove. Then, exactly as she had indicated, he found many golden vessels filled with pearls and silver vessels filled with various jewels. It is said that down to the seventh generation all the sufferings due to his poverty were resolved. Also, there was once a poor farmer who invoked Noble Tārā and supplicated her. She appeared in the form of a maiden clothed in leaves and prophesied that he should go eastwards. He did just this and, sleeping in the desert one night, he was awakened by the sound of tinkling bells and saw a green horse, ornamented with bells, pawing at the sand. In a flash the horse vanished and the farmer, digging in the furrow made by the horse’s hoof, found first of all a silver door, then one made of gold, then one of crystal, one of lapis lazuli, and finally one made up of seven precious gems.[76] In the underground kingdom (to which the doors led) he became king over many Nāgas and Asuras,[77] and experienced many of his dearest wishes. When he re-emerged from the door to the hole in the ground and arrived back in his own country, he found that in the meantime three kings had occupied the throne, so it is said.
gnyen dang bral ba'i 'jigs pa las ji ltar skyabs pa'i tshul

13. gnyen dang bral ba'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ bram ze zhig gnyen mang zhing nor che bar yod pa las/ nam zhig na mi ngas chen po byung bas bu dang chung ma dang / spun zla skud po zhang po sogs thams cang shi ste/ yid mya ngan gyis non nas wa ra Na sir 'ongs so/ / de na sangs rgyas pa'i dge bsnyen rnams sgrol ma'i dus ston chen po byed pa'i sar phyin pas sgrol ma'i che ba thos pas/ me tog snyim pa gang gtor te gsol ba btab/ phyir 'ongs pa na/ rgyal po dza ya tsan+d+ra'i bu mo bag mar thob ste sa'i dbang phyug tu gyur/ des sgrol ma'i lha khang brgya rtsa brgyad bzhengs shing / thams cad du sangs rgyas pa'i dus ston chen po re yang btsugs so/

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Losing Relatives. Once there was a Brahmin who had many kinsmen and a great deal of wealth. One day a contagious disease arose and carried off his children, wife, brother’s lineage and his uncles too. With his mind assailed by grief he arrived at Vārāṇasī[78] He went to the site where some Buddhist Upāsakas were performing a festival for Tārā, and while there he heard of the great qualities of Tārā. On her request, he strew a handful of flowers and on coming back he gained King Jayacandra’s[79] daughter as his bride and became a governor. The Brahmin erected 108 Tārā temples and at all of them great Buddhist festivals were observed.

14. rgyal po'i chad pa'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ yul a yo d+h+ya ces par/ khyim bdag dbang thang dang longs spyod che ba zhig yod pa/ dus lan cig rkyen 'ba' zhig gis/ yul gyi rgyal po des khyim bdag de la mi dga' bar gyur te/ bsnyad 'tshol ba la zhugs pa na/ des kyang rgyal po'i mi mang po brid nas khrid te ti rA hu tir song ngo*/ / dus gzhan zhig na/ des yul tsi pAr+Na ru phyin pas/ a yo d+h+ya'i rgyal pos gyad mi bzhi btang ste/ khyim bdag de bcings nas/ a yo rgyu ru khrid do/ / des rje btsun mo sgrol ma dran bzhin du gsol ba btab pas/ lha'i byin rlabs kyis khyim bdag de'i rkang pa sgo them la bzhag pas gser du gyur pa dang // btson khang du bcug pas der mu tig gi do shal gyi char babs pa dang*/ bsal shing la bskyon par gzas pa na/ bsal shing de a mra'i shing sdong me tog dang 'bras bus brgyan par song bas/ rgyal po la sogs pa thams cad ya mtshan skyes te/ 'di ni ches bsod nams dang ldan pa zhig na/ chad pas bcad pa ga la 'os zhes byas nas/ rgyal po'i blon po'i sa la bzhag go /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Royal Punishment. In the country of Ayodhyā[80] lived a very mighty and wealthy householder. Once, for some reason or other, the king of that country became displeased with the householder, believing rumours about him. The man, in his turn, led many of the king’s subjects away to Tirāhut.[81] At another time he went to the Land of Campāraṇa[82] where the King of Ayodhyā sent four strong men after him. The householder was bound up and led by them to Ayodhyā. Recalling Ārya Tārā, the householder begged her for assistance, and by her grace when his foot was merely put on the doorstep it was turned into gold. When he was flung into prison a shower of pearl necklaces fell on to him, and when he was bound to an impaling stake, the stake turned into a mango tree branch, ornamented with both fruit and flowers. The king and all the others were amazed at a person with such a stock of merit, and his punishment was commuted as was proper. He was later made a minister of the king.

15. rdo rje lhung ba'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ /b+ha ga la'i yul na dge bsnyen zhig zhing las kyi mtha' la blta zhing song ba las lam kha na gnod sbyin gyi lha rten zhig yod pa la/ dge bsnyen gyis 'goms nas phyin pas gnod sbyin de khros par gyur nas/ nub mo dge bsnyen de rang gi khyim du gnas pa na/ nam mkha' nas gnam lcags 'bar ba nyi shu rtsa gcig lhung ste/ der 'phags ma sgrol ma dran pa tsam gyis gnam lcags kyi me lce thams cad me tog tu gyur/ dge bsnyen rang nyid/ bu dang chung ma/ nor rdzas sogs gang la yang gnod pa med/ gnam lcags rnams kyang khyim du lus te/ de thams cad rig sngags 'chang ba lnga brgya tsam la byin pas/ de rnams kyi grub pa'i rdzas la nye bar mkho bar byung skad/ /

She is the Protectress from the Fear of Vajra Missiles.[83] In the land of Bhaṅgala, a certain Buddhist Upāsaka, after his day’s work in the fields, came upon the shrine of a Yakṣa[84] on the road(side). The Upāsaka crushed it underfoot and walked on while the Yakṣas became enraged. That night 21 fiery sky-bolts[85] fell from the sky on to the Upāsaka’s home. He merely recalled Noble Tārā and the sky-bolts’ tongues of flame were transformed into flowers, injuring neither his children, nor his wife, nor his wealth and property. The sky-bolts, remaining in and around the house, were donated to 500 mantra reciters and it is said that all types of things needed for their attainment of Siddhi appeared as a result.

16. don nyams pa'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa ni/ khyim bdag zhig zong thogs te yul gzhan du song / rgyal po las sa gzhi slang par 'dod de/ rang gi nor rnams grogs la bcol/ rang nyid rgya mtshor gru bo cher zhugs so/ / lo mang por rgya mtsho'i gling rnams su phyin pa la/ / longs spyod kyi khyad par gang yang ma 'grub cing / lan cig stes dbang gis gru rlung gis bdas te/ ma la kha zhes bya ba'i gling der sleb bo/ / gling de na byu ru dang / tsan dan sa mchog ci bder blang du yod pas mang du blangs te gru gang bar byas nas 'ongs so/ / lam du ma ga ra mats+tshi zhes bya ba'i chu srin nya'i rigs can gyis sna'i lcag bsnun pas gru zhig der shing leb la 'jus pas rlabs kyis bdes te 'dzam bu gling du sleb bo/ / slar rang gi grogs po rtsad bcad pa na/ de yang lam du song ba stag gis zos nas shi bar shes/ der don gang yang ma grub pas ngal bas sdug bsngal cing yid mi bde ba'i tshe/ grogs zhig gis bskul nas/ sgrol ma la dad pa bskyed de gsol ba btab pa las/ rmi lam du khyod chu bo sin+d+hu'i 'gram du song zhig 'dod pa'i don rnams 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / zhes byung bas de bzhin du byas pas/ chu bo sin+d+hu'i nang nas sngar gru nang gi nor rdzas rgya mtshor nub pa thams cad rnyed/ de nas grogs po shi ba'i sar phyin nas/ sa zhig brkos pa las/ rang gi nor rdzas bcol ba rnams thon/ de nas rang yul du phyin te/ tsan dan sa mchog gi sdong dum zhig rgyal po la skyes su phul bas/ rgyal pos kyang grong khyer gyi mchog lnga byin no// //

She is the Protectress from Fear of Ruination of (one’s) Aims. A householder went with all his property to another country. (There) he hoped to get land from the king. He entrusted his wealth to a friend and set out in a big ship to cross the oceans in search of more wealth. Although he voyaged for many years to various continents in the ocean, he did not manage to find any riches or special items. One day, by the power of fate, the boat was driven by the winds to the isle of Mallacca. There he found as much coral and yellow sandalwood as he wanted to take, and filling his boat completely he set out to come home. On the way he met Macchi, a (huge) crocodile of the fish family but with an iron nose with which he crushed the ship. By holding on to a plank, the man was driven by the waves back to India where he finally arrived. He tried to find his friend again, but while on the way to his place he learned that a tiger had killed and devoured him. The man was filled with grief and sadness because all his plans were thwarted and fruitless. At the exhortation of a friend he prayed to Tārā and faith arose in him. In a dream she said to him, “Go to the banks of the river Sindhu![86] (There) all your longed for wishes will be fulfilled.” Doing as he had been instructed, (he found that) his former vessel containing all the precious things he had found in the western oceans had come up out of the river, and going to the house of his dead friend he found all the wealth that he had entrusted to him (hidden) in a specified place. Then he went back to his own country and offered a whole trunk of yellow sandalwood to the king, who in turn gave him (custodianship over) five of the very best villages.

gzhan yang dus phyis slob dpon klu sgrub sgrub pa la bskul ba dang / tsan+d+ra go mi chu'i 'jigs pa las lan gnyis su bskyabs pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i bshes gnyen me'i 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa dang*/ dge bsnyen btsun pa ngo bo nyid med pa dug sbrul gyi 'jigs pa las bskyabs pa dang / slob dpon blo gros brtan pa la zhal bstan pa sogs ya mtshan can gyi gtam rgyud shin tu mang ngo / / yang rdo rje'i gdan du gnas pa'i nyan thos sen+d+ha ba gcig /dbyar dus rgyu 'grul la phyin pas chu klung ne rany+dza na'om/ phal skad du phal gu zhes yongs su grags pa/ de gsar du 'brub pa la brgal bas rab ma tshugs par chus khyer ro/ / der theg chen pa rnams la sgrol ma zhes bya ba chu'i 'jigs pa las skyob pa yod ces grags so snyam nas/ sgrol ma zhes skad phyung pas/ rdo rje gdan gyi phyi'i khyams kyi sgrol ma'i shing sku zhig yod pa de der dngos su byon nas/ khyod nam yang nga mi dran par da ltar nga bos pas ci rung zhes gsungs/ chu nang nas rang thon no/ / sku brnyan de la yang chu klung sgrol ma zhes grags so/ /

Moreover, previously Tārā urged the Ārya Nāgārjuna[87] on to attain perfection, and on two occasions she protected Candragomin[88] from the Dread of Water. She protected Sarvajñamitra[89] from the Fear of Fire and the Noble Upāsaka Asvabhāva[90] from the Fear of Poisonous Snakes, and gave the Ācārya known as ‘Firm Intellect’ and his attendants many amazing legends (to tell of). There was a Sendhapa Śrāvakā who lived at Vajrāsana[91] and one summer he was going via the Nerañjana river valley (more commonly known by its colloquial name, the river Phalgu) to the holy site of Māyā.[92] The river had recently been in flood and the Śrāvaka could not withstand the current on the ford and was carried off by the river. He thought, “Mahāyānists have a goddess called Tārā who protects from the fear of water,” and so he cried out, “O Tārā!” to her. The wooden image of Tārā[93] kept in an outer courtyard of Vajrāsana arrived in its bodily form and said, “You never even (usually) remember me—now you call out to me—is that the proper way to behave?” He managed to get out of the water himself and thereafter that particular image became known as ‘River Valley Tārā’.[94]

yang lan cig rdo rje gdan du rgan mo zhig gis sgrol ma'i lha khang zhal phyir bstan zhig bzhengs pa las/ bzhengs zin pa na/ byang chub chen po la rgyab bstan pa 'di ma legs snyam nas rgan mo 'gyod pa la/ sku brnyan nyid kyis gsung byon te/ khyod mi dga' na byang chub chen po la blta bar bya'o/ / gsungs nas/ lha khang gi sgo dang sku brnyan gnyis ga byang chub chen po la phyogs par gyur pas zhal bsgyur sgrol ma zhes grags so/ / yang rgyal po d+harma pA la'i dus rdo rje gdan gyi byang shar dge slong rnams kyi chu len sa'i chu mig gcig gi drung na/ sgrol ma'i rdo sku zhig bzhugs la/ de dus sing+g+ha la pa'i nyan thos sen+d+ha pa rnams kyis sngags kyi rgyud mang po me la bsregs/ dngul las bsgrubs pa'i he ru ka'i sku 'dra chen po'ang rnyed pa'i phyir bshig slob dpon sangs rgyas dpal ye shes kyi chos 'khor la yang gnod pa cher byas pas/ sing+ga gling pa'i nyan thos rnams la rgyal po'i chad pa byung / sen+d+ha pa'i dge slong zhig gis sgrol ma'i sku de'i drung du phyin te/ bdag rgyal po'i chad pa'i 'jigs pa las bskyab tu gsol zhes gsol ba btab pas/ khyod dal ba'i dus nga mi dran par da ltar dran nam gsung ste/ yang chu khung der zhugs shig gsung / chu 'bab pa'i chu khung shin tu chung du der lus yongs su rdzogs par shong ste/ rgyal po'i mi rnams kyis btsal bas ma rnyed do// de nas mtshan mo bros te rgya gar shar phyogs thag ring por sleb pa na/ dus ston gyi tshe rdo rje gdan gyi steng khang bya 'dabs kyi 'og gi sgo ma phye ste/ slar yang sing+ga la'i dge slong de nyid bkug ste phye bas sgo rang bye/ de la rgyal po yang mgu ste/ yo byad du ma yongs su stabs so/ / de la slob dpon klu sgrub kyi snga rol du/ sgrol ma'i rig sngags la brten nas/ dngos grub thob pa lnga stong tsam byung ste/ klu sgrub kyi ring la yang lnga stong tsam byung ngo skad/ /

Once, at Vajrāsana, an old lady erected a Tārā temple with the image’s face showing outwards. On completion the old lady grieved that the image had its back facing the Mahābodhi Shrine[95] and thought that it was not at all good like that. Then the image itself said, “If you are not happy about it, I will look towards the Mahābodhi site!” So the image itself changed direction so that both it and the temple door faced the Mahābodhi, and (from then on) that particular image became known as ‘Tārā of the Turned Face’.[96] At the time of King Dharmapāla[97] there was a stone statue of Tārā which was situated beside the spring from which the monks of north-eastern Vajrāsana drew their water. At that time the Singhala Śrāvakas known as the Sendhapas burned many tantric scriptures and, finding a large silver image of Heruka, they destroyed that as well.[98] They also did a great deal of damage to the Maṇḍala of Buddhaśrījñāna.[99] The king punished the Singhala Śrāvakas and a certain Sendhapa monk went before the mentioned Tārā image, begging her, “Save me from the fear of the king’s punishment!” The Tārā statue replied: “In times of peace you never so much as even remember me—do you recall me now? Get down into the water spout!” Although the spout was very small his whole body was contained within it and the king’s men who were searching for him were unable to find him. Then, fleeing at night, he eventually arrived in distant eastern India. At a great festival time at Vajrāsana there was a certain door of an attic which would not open. At the very summoning of the Singhala monk, the closed door opened of its own accord. The king rejoiced at the abundance and variety of things found inside. It was at an earlier time from that of Ācārya Nāgārjuna, when about 5,000 persons gained Siddhi supported by Tārā’s Mantra, and in Nāgārjuna’s time another 5,000 practitioners arose, so it is said.

bye brag tu rgyud 'di nyid dang 'brel ba'i lo rgyus ni/ shar phyogs b+ha ga lar bram ze'i rigs las rab tu byung ba'i dge slong sde snod gsum pa ha ya pA la zhes bya ba zhig theg pa chen po thog mar dor ba la shin tu mos te/ slob dpon rnams las legs par nyan nas mkhas par shes so/ / de nas phyag na rdo rje zhal mthong ba'i bram ze gu h+pha shi la te/ gsang ba'i ngang tshul zhes bya ba zhig la sgrol ma 'byung ba'i dbang bskur ba nod cing / gdams pa dang / rjes su gdams pa mtha' dag thob bo/ / de skabs rig sngags 'chang rnams kyi sa na/ rgyud 'di'i dum bu dum bu snyan brgyud du ston pa zhig las/ rgyud tshig yongs su rdzogs pa'ang med la/ yi ger bkod pa'ang med do/ /

Of particular noteworthiness in regard to this Tantra are these legends. In the east, at Bhaṅgala, a Tripitaka[100] master who was an ordained monk from the Brahmin caste by the name of Hayapāla, revered and taught the Mahāyāna above all other doctrines, and as a result of having listened carefully to his Ācāryas became known as a very wise person. Then there was a Brahmin named Guhyaśīla[101] who had seen the countenance of Vajrapāṇi. He obtained the empowerment[102] leading to the arising of Tārā as well as the supplementary instructions on it. At that time in the places where the Mantrayānists lived, due to the teaching of this fragmented oral tradition, the wording of this Tantra was not complete and moreover there was not even a written version of it.

de nas slob dpon des rtse gcig tu bsgoms pas rdzu 'phrul thob ste/ o Di ya na rdo rje'i gnas su song nas/ mkha' 'gro ma rnams las sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rtsa bshad kyi rgyud dang / gtum po khro bo'i rgyud rtsa bshad dang / log na rdo rje mchog tu gsang ba'i rgyud dang / he ru ka bskyed pa zhes bya ba'i rgyud spyan drangs te/ yul ti pu rar/ nags gseb tu lha khang byas nas der bzhugs nas/ thun mong gi 'gro ba rnams la shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa bsdus pa dag ston cing / sgrol ma'i rig sngags la brten nas shar phyogs kyi rgyal po lnga dbang du bsdus/ thams cad dkon mchog la dad par byas/ lha mo u ma dang / lha'i rgyal po rab tu dga' ba zhes bya ba dbang du bsdus te/ yon thams cad des sbyor bar byed do/ /

mi g.yo ba'i rig sngags la brten nas sgyu 'phrul 'grub ste/ dpag tshad bcu gnyis khor yug tu rin po che'i ljon shing dang / rwa ba dang / khang bzang dang / lha dang / / lha mo la sogs pa sprul/ phyag na rdo rje'i rigs sngags la brten nas/ bstan pa la sdang ba lnga brgya tsam tshar bcad/ lo mang por pha rol tu phyin pa'i chos bstan nas/ he ru ka'i rig sngags kyi mthu las nam mkha' la gya gyur gshegs te/ lcang lo can du lus de nyid kyis bzhud do/ / des gsang sngags bstan pa'i slob ma ni/ slob dpon ha la g+ho Sha gcig pu yin te/ 'di yang slob dpon snga ma dang mdzad pa 'dra ba las/ 'di ni khro bo'i rgyal po rta mgrin grub ste/ srin po'i 'jig rten du lus ma spangs bar bzhud do/ / slob dpon de gnyis ni bram ze sa ra ha dang dus mnyam pa tsam yin no/ /

Supported by the Mantra of Acala, he acquired the power of causing magical illusions. For a distance of 12 yojanas right up to the very horizon appeared (phantoms of) the Precious Wish-Granting Tree, the Mountain Peak of Paradise and the Palace of the Gods, as well as gods and goddesses. Supported by Vajrapāṇi’s Mantra, he completely eradicated as many as 500 enemies of the Dharma. Having taught the Prajñāpāramitā doctrine for many years, by the power of Heruka’s Mantra he wended his way into the sky. In that very body (human form) he departed for Vaiśravaṇa’s Abode-Paradise. As for his particular student of the secret mantra teachings it was Ācārya Hayaghoṣa.[108] Rather like his own teacher’s deeds, he perfected the evocation of the fierce divine King Hayagriva[109] and departed for the world of the Rākṣasas, leaving no bodily traces at all. He was a contemporary of the Brahmin Saraha.

slob dpon de la rgyud bzhi po de rnams 'phags pa klu sgrub kyis zhus te slob dpon 'dis ni rig sngags de thams cad grub pa yin no des Ar+ya de wa la bshad/ des sgra gcan 'dzin bzang po chung ba la gdams te/ slob dpon 'di ni dmangs rigs las rab tu byung ba/ rig pa'i gnas lnga la byang zhing / theg pa che chung gi sde snod thams cad mkhyen pa zhig yin la/ 'dis 'phags pa klu sgrub kyi gzhung rnams lam gyi lus gcig tu bsgril nas bstan pa'i bstan bcos asma gat+na zhes bya ba brtsams gsung / 'dis rtsod pa'i sgo nas mu stegs tsakra warma zhes bya ba sun phyung ste/ sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la bkod/ nyan thos mang po rtsod pas pham par byas te theg chen la bcug /rang nyid kyis sgrol ma'i rig sngags la brten te/ gnod sbyin mo grub nas sa 'og gi gter phyung zhing / nags nang stong pa rnams su yang dge slong stong phrag re'i 'tsho ba sbyor nus skad/ mthar yul b+hi ra ko Tar sku 'das so/ / de yang 'grel pa tshig gsal las/ klu sgrub sgra gcan 'dzin bzang po'i zhal snga nas dang bcas 'phags pa lhas kyang rjes su bstan pa dang / zhes gsung pa'i sgra gcan 'dzin bzang po de yang 'di kho na yin pas/ bram ze chen por 'dod pa ni mun sprul lo/ /

Ārya Nāgārjuna asked him (Hayaghosa) for the fourfold tantras, and he perfected all of them.
