He explained them to Āryadeva,[110] and he in turn to Rāhulabhadra the Younger.[111] This Ācārya was consecrated from among the lowest caste, and was learned in the five areas of study[112] as well as fully conversant with all the Pitakas of both Mahāyāna and Theravāda. The essential doctrines of Ārya Nāgārjuna were made available as an integrated path in his work Asmagarbha. Rāhulabhadra refuted the heretic Cakravarma in disputations and manifested the Enlightened One’s doctrine. By defeating many Śrāvakas in disputations he established the Mahāyāna Doctrine amongst them. Supported by his personal Tārā Mantra, it is said that together with a Yakṣi[113] who had become perfected they drew treasures out of her underground residence, with which he was able to provide sustenance for 1,000 monks who inhabited lonely forests. The Ācārya passed away in the borderlands of Dhingkoṭa. Furthermore it is evident from commentaries that Rāhulabhadra clearly explained all the later teachings to Nāgārjuna and he to Āryadeva. The so-called Rāhulabhadra is one and the same person but to refer to him as ‘The Great Brahmin’ (Saraha) is confusing and obscuring.

de yan chad rgyud de rnams glegs bam yang gcig pu kho na yin la brgyud pa'ang gnyis su gyes pa med gsung ngo / / des slob dpon dz+wa la shiSh+Tha la gdams/ des kha che d+harma b+ha dra pA la la gdams/ des nA ga mi tra la gdams/ de rnams kyi lo rgyus mi gsung / des nyi ma sbas pa sogs la gdams/ de la nyi ma sbas pa ni/ kha che'i yul du sku 'khrungs skye ba bdun du sgrol ma'i sgrub pa po yin par grags la/ skye ba de nyid la blo rno zhing chung ngu nas rig pa'i gnas mtha' dag la mkhas pa zhig yod pa yul dbus su song ste/ rab tu byung bas klu sgrub kyi ring lugs la brten nas/ theg pa chen po'i mdo sde mtha' dag la mkhas par byas so/ / slob dpon nA ga mi tA la sgrol ma'i dbang bskur ba zhus te/ spyir sgrol ma'i rgyud brgya rtsa brgyud mkhyen par grags/ slob dpon 'dis sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud la bsten pa'i sgrub thabs dang / dkyil 'khor gyi cho ga la sogs pa gzhung bcu gsum tsam mdzad ces zer ro/ / slob dpon 'di ni slob dpon blo brtan gyi slob ma tsan+d+ra go mi dang dus mtshungs pa tsam yin no/ / des na da ltar 'jigs pa brgyad skyob kyi bstod pa byin rlabs can du grags pa 'di yang nyi ma sbas pa gzhan zhig gis ni yin du rung mod/ / slob dpon 'dis mdzad pa ma yin par shes par bya'o/ / 'di'i slob ma'i gtso bo ni thams cad mkhyen pa'i bshes gnyen yin te/ gzhan yang sgrol ma'i rig sngags grub pa'i slob dpon dpag tu med pa byung ngo*/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i bshes gnyen gyis d+ha na mi tra la gdams/ des ta thA ga ta mi tra la gdams/ / des seng+ga la gling pa d+harma mi tra la gdams/ des shi la rak+Shi ta la gdams te/ 'di ni sgeg pa'i rdo rje dang dus mtshungs pa ste/ de yan chad du brgyud pa ma chad par byung zhes sngon gyi slob dpon rnams kyi rabs dang / gtam gyi tshig bcad las 'byung zhes gsung ngo*/ /

Up to that time those particular tantras were (contained) in only one volume and it is said that the lineage has not become divided. Rāhulabhadra taught Jvalaśeṣpa who taught the Kaśmiri Dharmabhadrapāla. He in his turn instructed Nāgamitra.[114] Accounts of them are not mentioned. Nāgamitra instructed Sūryagupta[115] and the rest. Now, as to Sūryagupta. He was born in Kaśmir and was renowned as a Tārā mystic throughout seven lifetimes. He was intelligent from his youth and was skilled in several areas of learning. Going to Madhyadeśa and being consecrated, and also supported by Nāgārjuna’s doctrine, he became fully skilled in the complete Mahāyāna Sūtra collection. He begged Ācārya Nāgamitra for the empowering initiation of Tārā, and later on became renowned as one fully skilled in the 108 Tantras of Tārā. It is said that this Ācārya composed 13 texts, such as the Maṇḍala Ritual and sādhana Method of Accomplishment in connection with “The Origin of Tārā Tantra” and so forth. He was a contemporary of Ācārya Sthiramati, or ‘Firm Intellect’s’,[116] pupil Candragomin.[117] Therefore the work known as The Praises To The Protector From The Eight Great Fears must have been by another Sūryagupta, certainly not this one. One should know what are and are not the deeds of this Ācārya. Sūryagupta’s principal disciple was Sarvajñamitra[118] and moreover innumerable other Ācāryas arose, supported by the Tantra of Tārā. Sarvajñāmitra instructed Dhanamitra who taught Tathāgata-mitra who taught Siṃhaladvīpin Dharmamitra who taught Śīlarakṣita who was a contemporary of Līlāvajra or Lalitavajra.[119] So the above unbroken lineage[120] arose, the details being gained from the work entitled The Accounts of the Succession of Ācāryas of Yore, so it is said.

de dag gi skabs su/ slob dpon brgyad la 'jigs pa brgyad las bskyabs pa'i lo rgyus ni/ rgya gar lho phyogs su slob dpon dika warma zhes bya ba sdom brtson sde snod 'dzin pa chen po/ / gshin rje gshed dang / sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud 'di nyid la brten pa'i rig sngags grub pa zhig ste/ des lho phyogs be dag+ha'i yul du mu stegs kyi bram ze'i slob dpon ga pu ri pa zhes pa dang rtsod pa byas te/ mu stegs pham pas/ de'i spyod yul thams cad sangs rgyas pas blangs so/ / de nas slob dpon de gtsug lag khang du dge slong rnams dang lhan cig chos ston gsol ba'i tshe/ mu stegs rnams kyis gtsug lag khang la me btang ba na/ slob dpon gyis rje btsun ma la gsol ba btab pas/ rje btsun ma nam mkha'i dbyings su byon te/ nam mkha' las chu bo'i rgyun dngos su babs nas me zhi bar gyur to/ /

The account of the eight Ācāryas being saved from the Eight Fears dates from that period. In the south of India was the Ācārya Dikavarma, a great practitioner of the Scriptural Collection for Ascetics and, by relying on the Tārā Tantra and Yamāntaka, he became perfected in the application and practice of Mantras. Debating with the heretic Brahmin Ācārya Gapurīla in the southern land of Vidarbha, the heretic was defeated and as a result all the others were taken under the aegis of the Enlightened One. Then at a time when the Ācārya and the monks were together in the temple and the latter were supplicating him for explanations of the Dharma, the heretic set fire to the temple. The Ācārya beseeched The Noble Lady (Tārā), and arriving from the heavenly spheres she caused a veritable endless river of rain to shower down from the skies, and so the fire was quenched.

yang slob dpon a ma ra sing ha bya ba/ rgyal po'i yig mkhan rab tu byung ba/ theg pa che chung gi mngon pa smra ba zhig sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud la brten te/ / 'phags ma sgrol ma la thugs dam du mdzad pa zhig yin no/ / des lho phyogs ma la wa'i yul du gnas gzhi byas nas bzhugs te/ mngon pa slob pa lnga brgya tsam la chos mngon pa ston cing / lo nyi shu rtsa bzhi'i bar du gnas de nyid du bzhugs skad/ / de dag thams cad du mngon po la blo sbyong ba lta brgya tsam gyi 'khor gyis bskor nas yod pa las/ dus lan cig phyogs de na nag phyogs kyi klu rgyal po ma li ta zhes bya ba yod de/ des glo bur du chor drag po mi bzad pa phab ste/ char chu las chu bo'i rgyun chu klung ya mu na tsam byung ste/ slob dpon gyi gnas gzhi dang / grong khyer mang po khyer la khad pa na/ slob dpon gyis rje btsun ma sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas/ gnas gzhi grong khyer u ta dza ya na dang bcas pa la chu de nyid g.yas skor du bskor mang du byas nas/ mthar chu bo chen po gzhan zhig la babs pa na// klu de nyid rang gi gnas dang / tu ruska'i grong khyer chung ngu zhig khyer ro/ / slob dpon de la sgrol mas mngon brjod kyi bstan bcos gyis shig ces lung bstan pas 'chi med mdzod brtsams/ 'di da lta'i bar du yang rgya gar na phyi nang gnyis ka la shin tu dar bar yod do/ / 'di rgyal po'i yig mkhan yin ces pa'i rgyal po ni bi pra karma di ta yin par grags/ yang slob dpon lha'i seng ge zhes bya ba rten dge bsnyen bzhugs pa/ theg pa che chung gi mdo sde dang*/ mngon pa la cher mkhas pa/ kha che'i yul gyi rgyal po hra hen de ba zhes bya ba'i bla mar gyur pa/ chos smra ba zhig yin te/ de kha che/ la hor/ ma ru rnams su rgyal po dang*/ khyim bdag dang bram ze sna tshogs pa/ dad par byas nas/ sangs rgyas pa'i lha khang lnga brgya tsam bzhengs so/ /

Also the Ācārya Amarasiṃha was a fully ordained monk as well as the king’s scribe and could also discourse on the metaphysics of both Mahāyāna and the Theravāda. Supported by the Tārā Tantra, he was able to make the Noble Lady into his personal tutelary divinity.[121] Having made his abode in the land of Mālava in the west,[122] he taught Abhidharma (Metaphysics) to about 500 advanced students for about 24 years while he stayed there, so it is said. All of those 500 students in attendance on him gained exceedingly pure minds. Once there was the heretic Nāga King known as Lalita in that area and he suddenly caused a fierce, unbearable rainstorm to fall and the rain formed a fast-running river like the Yamunā. It drew very near to the Ācārya’s abode and also to many hamlets. The Ācārya prayed to Ārya Tārā and as a result the water swirled round to the right of the Ācārya’s home and the city of Utajayana (Ujjain) many times and finally flowed off into another great river, and only the Nāga’s den and a small Turuska[123] village were carried away. Tārā prophesied to him in the following words, “Compose a work explaining key terms!” and he wrote the work known as the Amara-koṣa, which to this very day is extremely widely known in India among Buddhists and non-Buddhists. The king whose scribe he was is said to have been Vikramāditya. Moreover, the Ācārya Devasimha[124] was an Upāsaka. He was particularly skilled in the Sūtra Collections of both Mahāyāna and Theravāda and also their metaphysics, and consequently he became guru to the Kaśmiri King Śrī Harṣadeva.[125] Being a preacher of the Doctrine, he caused the King’s householders and the Brahmins in Kaśmir, Lahore and Rajputana to have faith and to erect about 500 Buddhist temples.

kha che dang nye ba'i yul ga dza ni la sogs par chos mang du bshad pas/ tu ruka stag gzig gi lugs phal cher nub/ stag gzig gi rgyal po zhig gis/ slob dpon btson du bzung ste/ khyod dkon mchog la skyabs su 'gro ba btang ste/ kla klo'i lugs byed na legs/ mi byed na gsod do zhes pa las/ slob dpon gyis srog la babs kyang dkon mchog las gzhan du skyobs gnas med do zhes brjod pos/ lcags sgrog bcug ste btson dong mi bzad par bor bas/ / slob dpon gyis rang gi thugs dam gyi lha sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas lcags sgrog de me tog gi lu gu brgyud du song / lha mo rnams kyis btson khang du me tog dang / tsan dan gyi phye ma'i char chen po phab/ rol mo'i sgra chen po bsgrags pas/ tu rusku'i rgyal pos lta ru 'ongs pa na lcags sgrog med par mthong ste/ yang lcags sgrog gzhan zhig bcug pas de yang me tog gi phreng bar gyur/ de ltar lcags sgrog bdun me tog gi phreng bar song bas/ rgyal po ya mtshan skyes te mchod gnas su bzung ngo / / 'on kyang der dam pa'i chos dar bar ma nus pas/ thugs 'byung nas kha cher byon no/

In the areas near Kaśmir, such as Ghazni etc., he preached many sermons on the Doctrine, and generally speaking the religion of the Persian Turuṣkas declined. A certain Persian king flung the Ācārya into prison and told him, “Give up the Three Jewels as your Refuge! If you practise the faith of the Muslims all will be well and good, but if you do not you will be slain!” The Ācārya said, “Even at such a threat to my life I will not give up the Three Jewels, for there is no other Refuge.” Bound up in shackles, the Ācārya was hidden in an impregnable dungeon. The Ācārya prayed to his tutelary divinity, Tārā, and the iron fetters were transformed into a chain of flowers, and goddesses showered a great rain of flowers and sandalwood powder into the prison, while a sound of music spread everywhere. The Turuṣka king came to see what it was all about and saw that there were no longer any iron bonds (on the Ācārya) and that another bond which had been put on had also changed into a flower garland—indeed this happened with seven such fetters. The king was amazed and seized them as objects of veneration. Nevertheless, despite all this, the holy teachings were never able to prosper in that place, and so the Ācārya with renewed spirits arrived again in Kaśmir.

yang sang+g+ha mi tra zhes bya ba bye brag tu smra ba'i slob dpon chen po zhig la mnal lam du/ thub pa chen po 'khor bcas kyi drung na lha mo sngon mo zhig 'dug ste/ de na re khyod theg pa chen po la legs par slobs shig gsung / des kha cher byon te/ theg chen mdo sngags kyi chos lugs mang du nyan/ rje btsun ma sgrol ma la yi dam du mdzad pas/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa nyan pa'i yul ma rnyed nas/ yul dbus na slob dpon grol sde zhes bya ba shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa 'chad pa yod ces thos te/ yul dbus su chos pa las lam du chom rkun gyis bzung ste/ lha mo durga la mi bsad pa'i khrag dron mos mchod dgos pas/ de'i phyir bzung ngo zhes zer ro/ / der lha mo durga'i gnas dur khrod lta bu der sleb pa na/ rje btsun ma sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas lha mo'i rten de dum bu mang por rang gas so/ / der chom rkun rnams kyang skrag cing bros/ slob dpon thar ro/ /

Once, in a dream, the great Vaibhāṣika[126] preacher Sanghamitra saw a green goddess in front of the Buddha and his attendants. The goddess said, “You must study the Mahāyāna well!” (Later) he arrived in Kaśmir where he attended expositions of many Mahāyāna Sūtras and Tantras and also made Ārya Tārā his tutelary divinity. Not finding a place where he could hear the Perfection of Wisdom teachings, and hearing of the Ācārya Muktasena who lived in the centre of the country and who preached those very teachings, he went there and on the road he was seized by brigands. They had to offer warm blood from a slain man to the goddess Durga,[127] and for that very purpose they departed with him, so it is said. Arriving at the Goddess Durga’s abode, which looked like a charnel ground, he prayed to Ārya Tārā and Durga’s shrine burst into many fragments of its own accord. At that the robbers fled and thus the Ācārya was freed.

yang slob dpon su b+ha Sha kirti zhes bya ba/ 'dul ba 'dzin pa chen po/ nang du sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud la brten te thugs dam du mdzad pa zhig yin la/ lan cig yul dbus nas nub phyogs kyi rgyud ltar song ba las/ / mthar ri bo zhig tu gtsug lag khang byas te/ chos bstan pas dge slong gi sde yang mang du tshugs te/ de na gar log gi dpon mang du yod pas mgo breg gos dmar can de rnams kyis bdag cag la gnod par 'ong gi /'di thams cad brlag par bya'o zhes glang po che sum brgya tsam gyi dmag 'ongs so/ / der sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas/ / dmag 'ong ba'i phyogs su chu gtor cig gsung / de ltar byas pas glang po che thams cad shin tu 'jigs zhing skrag pas sus kyang kha lo ma nus par rang gnas su khyer ro/ /

The Ācārya Subhāṣākīrti, the great Vinaya[128] expert, was one who, supported by the Tantra causing Tārā to arise, made her his tutelary divinity. Once, while going from the centre of the country to look at the western areas, he erected a temple on a border mountain. He preached there and established many centres for monks. There were many Garlog[129] chiefs there who said, “The shaven-headed, red-robed monks[130] will harm us. We must destroy them.” And so an army of about 300 elephants arrived there. The Ācārya prayed to Tārā who said, “Hurl water in the oncoming army’s path!” When that very thing was done, all the elephants became extremely terrified and were quite beyond the control of any of their mahouts which were carried back to their own dwelling places.

yang slob dpon bud+d+ha dA sa zhes bya ba d+ha na pu ri'i mkhan po mdzad pa zhig yod pa/ rgyu 'grul zhig la byon pas grong stong zhig na stag gi tshang mang du yod de/ slob dpon gyis gtam dris pa na/ stag rnams kyis nyin re bzhin grong khyer gyi mi mang po yang za bar byed na/ srog chags phra mo gzhan lta ci smos/ zhes thos pas/ snying rje chen po skyes te/ lam du song ba las stag rnams thams cad slob dpon gyi thog tu byung ba/ sgrol ma la gsol ba btab nas/ sngags bzlas pa'i chu gtor bas stag de rnams zhi ba'i sems dang ldan par gyur te/ phyin chad srog chags la gnod pa mi byed par kha zas bcad de dus las 'das pas lhar skyes pa'i rtags su me tog gi char chen po babs so/ /

The Ācārya Buddhadāsa[131] was made Abbot of Dhanapuri, and while he was once on a journey, he came upon an almost deserted village in which there were many tiger lairs. The Ācārya made enquiries and discovered that the tigers would eat many villagers not to mention the other small creatures. Having heard this outcry the Ācārya was moved to great compassion and whilst he was going along the road all the tigers came and confronted him. He prayed to Tārā and, intoning mantras and scattering libations of water, he caused all the tigers to become quite tranquil. Ever since then they did no more mischievous harm to living beings and stopped eating at all and passed away. A shower of flowers descended as a sign that the creatures had been reborn in the region of the celestial beings.

yang slob dpon dkon mchog gsum gyi 'bangs zhes bya ba/ slob dpon phyogs kyi glang po'i slob mar gyur pa zhig yin te/ des shar phyogs o Di bi sha'i yul du chos ston cing bzhugs pa'i tshe/ lan cig rgya mtsho chen po nas dug sbrul sbram chen zhig byung nas mi dang glang po che mang du zos/ uta ka la'i grong khyer dang nye bar byung ba na/ skye bo grangs med pa la gnod pa 'byung bar gzigs te/ sgrol ma la gsol ba drag tu btab cing / sgrol ma'i sngags bzlas pa'i yungs kar gtor te/
sa 'di gdengs can dbang lags kyang / / gang la phan pa'i thugs mnga' ba/ / de yi tshig 'di khyod longs la/ / sa 'og nyams dgar song zhig kye/ / zhes brjod pa'i mod la sbrul de nyid phyir ldog ste/ gro ga'i lam la zhugs nas rgya mtshor song ngo / /

The Ācārya Triratnadāsa[132] became a student of the Ācārya Dignāga.[133] Once when he was staying in the east in Oḍiviśa preaching the Dharma, a huge poisonous snake arose from out of the sea and devoured many men and elephants. As it drew near the town of Utakala, fearing that it would harm countless more creatures the Ācārya urgently prayed to Tārā, while simultaneously intoning her mantra and strewing white mustard seeds. He then said to the snake:
Although you might well be the King of the Nāgas here on earth, These are the words of the One who has (great) compassion. Get up and leave this place And return in peace underground! Thus the snake returned to the ocean through the Ganges river.

yang slob dpon ye shes lha zhes bya ba/ zhi ba lha'i slob ma zhig ste/ rgya gar lho phyogs tri ma la'i yul du nyan bshad kyi bya ba yun ring du mdzad de/ mthar du ni ri kha ba can du bsgom par bya'o/ / zhes byang phyogs su byon nas/ ti rA gu ti'i yul du 'gro ba'i don ci rigs pa mdzad/ de'i tshe yul de'i phyogs zhig na/ tha nu'i rigs kyi grong khyer chung ngu zhig tu tshangs pa'i srin po'i gdon byung ste/ yul gyi slob dpon nas/ zhing las kyi gla mi'i bar thams cad dus gcig tu shi'o/ / de'i nyin mo slob dpon der byon pas/ / ro langs mi bzad pa cig rgyug cing byung bas/ sgrol ma'i sngags bzlas pa'i phur bu 'phangs pas/ ro langs gyi spyi bor thil gyi song zhing 'gyel/ grong khyer gyi nang du byon te/ sgrol ma la gsol ba btab pas 'chi ba gso bar nus ba'i bdud rtsi'i char chen po babs te/ grong khyer gyi mi shi ba phal che ba gsos so/ / yang grub pa brgyad ma bsgrubs par yang 'grub pa'i gtam rgyud ni/ sgrol ma la yi dam du byed pa'i dge slong zhig gis/ gtsug lag khang bzheng pa'i don du slong mo la phyin no/ / bram ze zhig gis/ gi haM bre gang byin pa blangs nas/ sgrol ma'i lha khang zhig tu de ril bur byas so/ / de'i lhag ma zhig nyi ma la bzhag pas/ rlung gis gsar tsag dang / spang ma la sogs pa ril bu'i rdzas rnams kyi rdul khyer te de la btab bo/ / de la yang ril bu zhig byas nas/ sngags thun bzla yin yod pa'i tshe/ ril bu'i dbus nas me 'bar ro/ / de lus la bcangs nas yod pa las/ lan cig sum cu rtsa gsum lha'i grong khyer yid la bsam pa na/ sum cu rtsa gsum du phyin te/ mi'i lo bcu gnyis kyi bar du der 'dug go / /

The Acārya Jñānadeva was a student of Śāntideva.[134] He went to the south of India, to Trimala, to preach over a long period of time. Finally he went to the Himalaya mountains to meditate. Having thus arrived in the northern areas he worked for part of the time for the welfare of beings in the Tirāhut district. At that time in a certain part of the country in a small village of the Tharu people,[135] there was much mischief caused by a Rākṣasa of the Brahma-(gods) and as a result all those (whose position was) between village headman and senior field-worker were slain in one blow. On that very day the Ācārya arrived there. A malicious Zombie[136] was cavorting about the place. The Ācārya, intoning Tārā’s Mantra and wielding his phurbu[137] at the corpse, caused the Zombie to fall backwards and collapse, with the crown of its head caved in. Arriving back in the village, the Ācārya prayed to Tārā and a great shower of nectar, able to cure death, rained down, and the great host of dead villagers were revived. Now follow stories about the eight unaccomplished saints and the accounts of their perfection. A certain monk who had made Tārā his tutelary divinity went, off to gather alms so that he might build a temple. A Brahmin offered him a full measure of giham[138] which he accepted and made into pills inside a certain Tārā temple. The remainder of the ingredients he put in the sun. The wind took the gold particles and the dust of herbs and other substances of the pills and scattered them. However, when the monk recited some mantras and counted them on his rosary, flames started to shoot from the middle of one pill in particular. The monk grasped hold of it and at one instant saw in his mind’s eye the (celestial) city of the Thirty-Three Gods, visited them and resided there for 12 earthly years.

yang sgrol ma la yi dam du byed pa'i zhing pa zhig gis/ phu phu zhes sa brkos pas sa 'og gi sgo bye ste/ klu'i gnas su sleb nas bdud rtsi 'thungs pas lus 'ja' lus su gyur skad/ rnal 'byor ma zhig gis/ dur khrod du nyi shu dgu'i nub mo mi ro mang po bsreg cing / sgrol ma'i sngags bzlas pas me dreg chags pa'i dbus nas 'od 'phro zhing 'dug go /de mig la byugs pas/ grogs po rnams kyi dbus de nyid du mi snang bar gyur to/ / yang sgrol ma la yi dam du byed pa'i dge bsnyen zhig grogs dang bcas te dur khrod du song bas/ ro langs 'jigs su rung ba kha nas me 'bar ba zhig byung nas/ grogs rnams 'jigs shing bros pa la/ dge bsnyen des sgrol ma dran par byas shing de'i gnya' bar zhon pas/ de nyid lag gsum rkang gsum mgo gsum par gyur te/ rkang pa dang lag pa gcig gis rgya mtshor nyul/ gcig ni ri dang sa'i khongs su nyul/ gcig ni nam mkha'i khongs su nyul ba'i cho 'phrul bstan te/ gdong gsum po re res dpa' bo chen po bdag gis ci 'gyid/ nam mkha'i lam nas lha'i gnas su 'gro bar bgyi'o/ / sa 'og gi lam nas lha min gyi gnas su 'gro bar bgyi'o/ / rgya mtsho'i lam nas klu'i gnas su 'gro bar bgyi'o/ / zhes zer ba la/ de dag las gang 'dod pa zhig smras na 'grub par 'gyur ba las/ sgrub pa po blo rtul te/ de dag mi 'tshal gyis/ bdag la rin po che'i gter byin cig byas pas/ de na re/ 'o na ri bo sngon por gshegs 'tshal zer nas skad cig gis der sleb ste rin po che'i gter chen po bstan no/ / de ji srid 'tsho'i bar du rgyal po chen po las kyang longs spyod che bar gyur skad/ /

A farmer named Phu Phu, who had made Tārā his tutelary divinity, was digging in the ground when a subterranean door opened. Having arrived in the abode of the Nāgas and drunk some nectar,[139] it is said that his body was transformed into that of a ‘rainbow body’.[140] A Yogini who had inhabited a cemetery for 29 nights, during which time many corpses were cremated, recited Tārā’s mantra and from the midst of the ash-pile rays of light streamed forth. It covered her eyes and (from then on) she could become invisible even in the midst of her friends. An Upāsaka who had made Tārā his tutelary divinity went with his friends to a charnel ground where a fearful, walking corpse,[141] with flames belching out of its mouth, arose. His friends were absolutely terrified and fled but the Upāsaka, recalling Tārā, leaped up on to the ghoul’s neck. It then was miraculously transformed so that it had three sets of arms, three sets of legs and three heads. With one set of feet and hands it wandered about the ocean, with another it wandered around the mountains and other areas of the earth, and with the third pair it travelled throughout the heavens, manifesting the miracle. It said from each of its three faces, “O great hero, what should I do now? I can go via the heavens to the Abode of the Gods, via the subterranean paths to the Abode of the Asuras, and via the oceans to the Nāga Lands.” Whatever he desired, if he had just so much as mentioned it then it would have happened, but the Sādhaka (worshipper), being foolish, did not ask for any of those things. Instead he said, “Give me a jewel mine!” Well, the story goes that he was commanded, “Set off for a certain bluish mountain!” He arrived there in an instant and was shown a huge mine of jewels. As long as he lived he had greater wealth than a king, so it is said.

yang sgrol ma'i sgrub pa po zhig shing bim pa la'i rtsa ba zhig tu sngags bzla zhing 'dug pa/ lan cig tho rangs kyi dus na/ rang gi mdun du sngon med pa'i lam srang zhig mthong ngo*/ / der zhugs te phyin pa las/ nam zhig na nags tshal yid du 'ong ba'i dbus su/ gser gyi khang pa zhig mthong / der zhugs pas gnod sbyin na Da ku ba ra'i g.yog mo gnod sbyin mo nag mo zhes bya ba/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ lus kha dog ma nges pa zhig 'dug ste/ de na re/ sgrub pa po tshur byon bcud len 'di gsol zhig zhes bum pa bcud kyis gang ba zhig byin no/ / zla ba gcig tu de 'thungs pas skye 'chi med pa'i lus su gyur to/ / yang dge bsnyen dad pa can/ sgrol ma la yi dam du byed pa zhig lam du phyin pas khab len gyi ral gri zhig rnyed de/ sgrol ma'i sngags bzla bzhin du phyin pas ral gri las du ba 'thul lo/ / yang bzlas pas me 'bar ro/ / de nas de yid la ji ltar 'dod pa'i gnas su 'gro nus par gyur te/ nyin re bzhin du lha klu mi ma yin tha dad pa'i gnas su song ste/ de dag gi longs spyod kyi khyad par sna re blangs nas dge 'dun la 'bul ba zhig yod pa/ lo mang po zhig na de nyid kyang rig pa 'dzin pa'i gnas su song ngo / / yang dge slong zhig gis sgrol ma'i lha khang cig la lo gsum bskor ba byas pas/ phyag gi mchog sbyin las bcud len 'o ma'i rgyun lta bu babs so/ / de 'thungs pas rgyas pa med par gyur te/ lo sum brgya'i bar du 'tsho zhing lo bcu drug tsam gyi na tshod la gnas skad/ yang dge bsnyen zhig gis/ sgrol ma'i lha khang zhig tu gsol ba 'debs kyin bsdad pas/ nang gcig sgrol ma'i sku brnyan gyi zhabs la phyag btsal bas zhabs 'og nas rdo'i bum pa zhig byung ngo*/ / bum pa de'i nang nas ji ltar 'dod pa'i longs spyod zad med du byung nas/ dge slong lnga brgya re'i 'tsho ba sbyor ba lo sum cu'i bar du byas so/ /

A Tārā worshipper once intoned her mantra at the foot of a bimpala tree, and at dawn he saw before him a straight, beginningless road. Travelling on it, in a flash he found himself in a beautiful grove, in the middle of which he saw a golden house. In it lived the Yakṣi called ‘Blackie’ who was maidservant to the Yakṣa Natakuvara. Blackie was profusely ornamented and had a multi-coloured body. She said to him, “O worshipper (of Tārā), come here, take this juice and drink it!” She offered him a bowl brimming with juice. After a month had passed he had drunk all of it and was transformed so that he was no longer subject to birth and death. A faithful Upāsaka who had made Tārā his tutelary divinity found a sword made from magnetic steel one day while going along a road. Continuing along his path and while intoning Tārā’s Mantra smoke started to billow forth from the sword. When he finished intoning flames belched out, and he found thereafter that he could go wherever his mind desired. So he went to the various abodes of gods, Nāgas and Asuras and, having received some of their unique kinds of treasures, he offered them to the order of monks. After some years he departed for the realm of the Vidyādharas. Over a period of about three years a certain monk constructed a Tārā temple and from the hand of the Tārā image a long-life elixir dripped like a perpetual flow of milk. The monk, having drunk some, relinquished old age and, living for 300 hundred years, looked as if he were a 16-year-old youth. Once, an Upāsaka stayed in a Tārā temple to pray. One night while doing his prostrations at the feet of the Tārā image, a stone vessel emerged from underneath the statue’s feet. Whatever wealth he wished for came out of that vessel in endless quantity and also sustenance for 500 monks for a period of 30 years.

'phags pa klu sgrub sku 'das nas/ rgyal po d+harma pA la byung gi bar du yang sgrol ma la brten te dngos grub thob pa lnga stong tsam byung ste/ 'di skabs kyi rnams sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud la brten te grub pa thob pa kho na mang gsung ngo*/ / de dag sgrol ma'i rgyud 'di sngon ji ltar dar ba'i tshul lo/ / bar skabs su cung zad nub pa'i tshul ni/ rgyal po d+harma pA la'i sku tshe'i smad/ dge slong sde snod 'dzin pa 'ga' zhig gis bskul nas yin yang zer/ rgyal sar 'khod ma thag pa'i skabs yin yang zer te/ sangs rgyas ye shes sku 'das nas yin par gsal bas snga ma dag go /gang ltar yang nyi 'og gi rgyal khams na gsang sngags kyi glegs bam dang / nyan bshad yod pa'i sa thams cad du byon te/ shin tu zhib mor dpyad nas rgyud nas man ngag so so'i bzhugs tshul thams cad mkhyen pa na/ dus kyi khyad par gyis sngon bzhin du gsang sngags gsang ste spyod pa mi 'byung zhing / rnal 'byor chen po'i rgyud rnams nyan bshad sgom gsum 'jig / rten gyi mngon du shin tu dar bar gyur par/ 'dus pa la sogs pa rdo rje'i tshig gis rgyas btab pa 'di rnams rgyu cher shod la/ shin tu gsang ba 'gal ba'i tshig yod pa 'di rnams phyin chad ma shod cig ces dril bsgrags te/ dpal he ru ka'i rgyud 'ga' shas dang / nag po chen po dang / sgrol ma 'byung ba dang / gtum po khro bo dang / gdan bzhi las kyi phreng ba la sogs pa rgyud sde chen po 'ga' shas dang / grub thob rnams kyis spyan drangs pa'i rgyud kyi du ma bu chung ngu lnga brgya tsam mo yang zer/ stong tsam mo yang zer te/ shin tu mang po yod pa de thams cad kyi dpe rnams bsdus nas gser gyi sgrom chen po brgyad du bcug de rnams dngul gyi snod du bcug pa sogs rin po che sna bdun gyi snod du bcug ste/ dur khrod bsil ba tshal du sbas so/ / de'i tshe re zhig rgyud 'di'i nyan bshad kyang rgyun chad skad/

From the demise of Nāgārjuna to the ascendancy of King Dharmapāla, there were about 5,000 persons who, supported by Tārā, attained Siddhi. During these particular times it is said that there were many who, supported solely by the arising Tantra of Tārā, gained Siddhi. The above has been a description of how they spread this very Tantra of Tārā. Now follows an account of how it declined a little in the interim period. Some say it was in the latter half of King Dharmapāla’s life, at the behest of some Tripiṭaka monks (who raised doubts). Yet others say this happened immediately after he commenced his reign.[142] It is quite clear that Buddhajñāna[143] had already died prior to this time. Under the sun of the whole kingdom, whatever was found, be it books of mystic mantras or discourses, was gathered together and after minute investigation, the method of getting the various Upadeśas[144] from the tantras became fully known. Because of the peculiarities of the time, the secret tantras were not practised quite as secretly as before. The Mahāyoga Tantras, however, were heard, lectured and meditated over, and being thus revealed they became widely spread throughout the world. It was proclaimed by him to those assembled there, “Spread these sealed Vajra-words far and wide! Do not teach any particularly secret words which contradict these ones.” The great Tantra collection comprised in part the Tantras of Śrī Heruka, Mahākāla,[145] the Arising of Tārā, the Caṇḍamahā-roṣaṇa and the Catuḥ-pīṭha-karmāvalī,[146] as well as some thousand fragments of the Siddha’s Invocations of Divinities, and some further 500 (such) fragments. All those very many texts were gathered up together and put in due order into eight great gold coffers, which were put into silver vessels which in turn were put into vessels made of the seven precious gems. Finally they were hidden in the so-called ‘cool sandalwood charnel ground’.[147] At that time it is said that the instructions and study on each of these tantras was interrupted.

phyis dar ba'i tshul ni slob dpon til+li pa grub pa ma brnyes pa'i sngon rol zhig na/ shar phyogs kyi gtsug lag khang zhig tu bzhugs pa'i tshe/ thub pa'i dbang po'i sku brnyan zhig yod pa'i khri'i 'og nas yang dang yang du 'od 'byung zhing / dus dus su rol mo'i sgra 'byung ba gsan no/ / des sa drus te gzigs pas sgrol ma'i rgyud 'di byung nas/ dus de'i tshe zhu ba'i yul ma rnyed do/ / phyis dngos grub brnyes nas nub phyogs o rgyan gyi yul du gshegs pa na/ bud med sngo sangs mkha' 'gro'i rtags dang ldan pa zhig 'dug pa la/ rgyud nas bshad pa'i brda bstan te des kyang brda'i lan byas so/ / der gsol ba btab pas/ de nyid lha mo sgrol mar gyur te rgyud byin gyis brlabs shing dbang bskur ro/ / des ni slob dpon na ro pa la bshad/ des Dom+b+hi pa dang / ka na ka shrI dang / kan+d+ha pa dang / thaki na ga pa rnams la bshad/ Dom+b+hi pa la ku sa la chung bas zhus/ de la a se ta g+ha nas zhus/ de la dz+nyA na mi tras gsan/ de la grub chen zhi ba sbas pas gsan/ de la bdag gi bla ma gsum gyis gsan no/ / yang til+li pa la/ lI la badz+ras zhus/ de la ra hu la gupas zhus/ de la dI paM kA ra shrI dz+nyA nas zhus/ de la ma rgya ma sid+d+his zhus/ de la tA ra shrI mi tras zhus/ de nas rim pas sang+g+ha shrI/ rat+na d+hu dza/ na ya ka shrI/ d+harma shI/ shAkya rak+Shi ta/ su dzA ta/ bud+d+ha shrI b+ha dra/ dz+nyA na rat+na/ dz+nyA na s+ya na/ rA te gusta/ des slob dpon chen po zhi ba sbas pa la'o/ / yang kan+d+ha pa/ pri ka ba/ d+hu pi rA dza/ ha re b+hany+dza pa/ a si ta g+ha na rnams las brgyud kyang chog yang ka na ka shi/ lo ka prad+ha/ chos 'byung zhi ba sogs nas brgyud pa'ang yod gsung / Thak+ki nag+na pas/ slob dpon man+da ra pA la bshad/ de ltar na bar skabs brgyud pa tha dad pa mang por dar la/ / phyis ni grub chen zhi ba kho na la bzhugs pas da lta de las rgya cher 'phel ba'o/ /

As regards the later spread (of the teachings)... The Ācārya Tillipa,[148] in a previous time when he had not attained Siddhi and when he was living in a temple in the eastern areas, from time to time saw light arise from underneath the plinth of an image of Buddha Sunendra, and occasionally he heard the sounds of music. Digging in the earth and looking there he saw this very Tantra of Tārā. At that time he was not able to find anywhere for empowerment into that Tantra. Later, having attained the supernormal Siddhi powers, he went to the western land of Urgyen where there was a certain bluish-green girl who bore all the signs of a Ḍākinī. He showed the signs which had been explained in the tantra and she gave the answering signs back to him. Tillipa prayed to her and she was transformed into the Goddess Tārā and gave him the_blessings and the empowerment of the Tantra. Tillipa taught Ācārya Nāropa[149] who taught Ḍombhīpa,[150] Kanakaśrī, Kandhapa and Thakkinagnapa.[151] Kusala the Younger begged for the teachings from Ḍombhīpa and Asitaghana[152] got them from him and the Mahāsiddha Śāntigupta[153] got them from Jñānamitra,[154] and my three Gurus listened to Śāntigupta. Tillipa was begged for instruction by Līlāvajra who was himself requested by Rāhulagupta.[155] Dīpaṅkara Śrijñāna[156] asked Rāhulagupta for instruction and Madhyamasiṃha[157] asked Dīpaṅkara. He (Madhyamasiṃha) was requested (for instruction) by Tāraśrīmitra; then in due order came Saṅghaśrī,[158] Ratnadvāja, Nāyakaśrī, Dharmaśrī, Śākyarakṣīta, Sujāta, Buddhaśribhadra, Jñānaratna, Jñānasena, and Ratigupta[159] who transmitted them to Śāntigupta. Also the Tantra was ornamented with the following names—Kandhapa, Pṛkka-pa, Dhupirāja, Hairbhañ-japa, and also Asitaghana. Moreover, the Tantra was spoken of by Kanakaśrī to Lokapradā, Dharmākaraśānti[160] and others. Thakkinagnapa communicated the Tantra to Ācārya Mandirapāla and accordingly many lineages have spread in the meantime up to the present day. Later the teachings remained exclusively with the Mahāsiddha Śānti(gupta) and now they spread more widely than ever before.

de dag gi nang nas lo rgyus gzhan du bkod zin pa rnams dang de dag tu shes par bya la/ der ma 'khod pa dag bshad na/ ka na ka shrI 'di ni bal po ka shi min ma ga d+ha nyid du sku 'khrungs shing / ku ru ku le'i sde pa las rab tu byung ba/ rnam gnon ngang tshul gyi dgon par mdo sngags rig gnas thams cad la mkhas par sbyangs te/ b+haM ga lar paN+Di ta d+harma mi tra zhes bya ba zhig la gsang ba 'dus pa'i dbang nos te lo bdun du sgom bzlas byas kyang mtshan ma bzang ba tsam yang ma byung ste/ sgom 'phro bcad nas ci bder bzhugs pas/ nub cig rmi lo du bud med gcig gis dpal na ro pa'i drung du song zhes lung bstan/ de nas na ro pa la 'khor lo sdom pa'i dbang bskur zhus pa tsam gyis ting nge 'dzin bzang po rang shugs su skyes/ zla ba drug tu bsgoms pas 'khor lo sdom pa'i zhal gzigs/ slar yang na ro pa chen po lo bdun gyi bar du bsten te/ rgyud sde dpag tu med pa gsan/ khyad par 'khor lo bde mchog dang / gdan bzhi dang / sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud rnams la mkhas par grags/ ma ga d+hAr rgyal po ni ya pA la'i skabs dbang phyug gi rjes su 'brang ba/ kha sa ma de ba zhes pa dang nus pa 'gran pas mu stegs kyis 'dom gang tsam gyi nam mkha' la dkyil 'khor bris shing bum pa bzhag pa la/ slob dpon gyis yungs kar gtor bas dkyil 'khor zhig cing bum pa lhung / slob dpon gyis/ sgrol ma'i sku zhig ta la gcig tsam gyi nam mkha' la bzhag pa/ slob dpon nyid kyis mo bsdus bar du mu stegs rnams kyi sngags dang me mda' la sogs pa thabs gang gis kyang lhung bar ma nus pas/ slob dpon rgyal/ rgyal pos bri ka ma la shI lar ma rgyud 'chad pa po'i slob dpon du spyan drangs so/ / 'dis sgrol ma'i zhal gzigs shing / sgrol ma'i rig sngags la brten nas phan tshun dbang du bsdu ba'i las sbyor mdzad de/ 'khrug pa chen po lan brgyud snum skad/

All that can be known from those accounts which are set out elsewhere;[161] those accounts not set out there will now be treated. Kanakaśrī, not the Nepalese Ka(naka) śrī, was born in Magadha, and was consecrated into Kurukullā’s[162] entourage. At Vikramaśīla[163] he studied and became well-versed in all the Sūtras, Tantras and auxiliary sciences. Getting the initial empowerment for Guhyasamāja[164] from the Pandit Dharmamitra in Bhaṅgala, he meditated for seven years, performed japa[165] etc. but no auspicious signs whatsoever arose out of it. Discontinuing his meditations, he lived as he pleased.[166] One night in a dream, a maiden prophesied to him, “Go before Śrī Nāropa!” Then he begged Nāropa for the empowerment consecration for Cakrasaṃvara,[167] and good quality meditation was born within him from his own natural powers. Within six months of meditation he saw the countenance of Cakrasaṃvara and, moreover, staying with Nāropa for a further seven years he heard an immeasurable number of Tantric Collections. He became renowned for his ability and wisdom in the unique Mahāsukha Cakrasaṃvara, the Catuḥ-pīṭha and the Tantra Causing Tārā to Arise. In Magadha, during the reign of King Nayapāla,[168] a follower of the God Śiva named Kasamadeva and he competed in magic. The heretic drew a maṇḍala, which measured one cubit across, high in the sky and placed a vase in it. The Ācārya scattered white mustard seeds and, the maṇḍala being destroyed, (it) tumbled down with the jar. The Ācārya then set up an image of Tārā as tall as a palmyra tree and set it high up in the sky, and even when the Ācārya was not concentrating, the heretic’s mantras and fiery arrows etc. and indeed all his methods were unable to overthrow it, and the Ācārya was victorious. The King invited the Ācārya, a ‘holder’ of the Mother Tantra, to Vikramaśīla. Seeing Tārā’s face and being supported by her Mantra he was able to subdue and join together (disparate forces) both near and far, and it is said that on eight occasions he reconciled both parties in major feuds.

kan+d+ha pa ni/ sangs rgyas pa'i rnal 'byor pa blo shin tu rtul ba ltar snang ba zhig jo bo na ro pa la/ sgrol ma 'byung ba'i dbang dang byin rlabs rnams zhus/ rgyud 'di las 'byung ba'i he ru ka lha dgu bsgom zhing lo bcu gnyis bsgrubs pas/ he ru ka dang / sgrol ma zhal mthong / dngos grub thob ste/ dpag tshad brgya'i lam yang yud tsam gyis chod par byed/ de skabs grong khyer Di lir sog po'i rgyal po zhig yod pa des pho brang chen po gsar du bcos pa na/ / slob dpon des kyang bem po zhig 'tshem gyin de dang nye bar bzhugs so/ / pho brang zin pa na/ bem po de dum bur dral zhing gshags pa na/ pho brang de yang rmangs nas zhig go de ltar lan gsum song bas/ rgyal po des kyang gtam de thos te/ slob dpon spyan drangs/ zhabs la phyag btsal/ slob dpon gyi gsung las byung ba'i dam bca' bzhi byed par byas pa/ bzhi ni/ sangs rgyas pa'i lha khang la gnod pa mi byed pa dang / pho brang nang na gnas pa rnams kyis srog gcod spong ba dang / rab tu byung ba rnams la mchod pa byed pa dang / nyin re bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi mtshan nas brjod cing phyag 'tshal ba rnams yin skad/ kan+d+ha ri bem po'i ming ste/ de phyin chad grub thob kan+d+ha par grags/ yun ring du 'gro don mdzad/ mthar sku lus de nyid kyis mkha' spyod du gshegs so/ /

As regards Kandhapa, he was a Buddhist yogin who appeared as if he were very simple. He begged Lord Nāropa for the empowerment consecration and for the blessing for the Arising of Tārā. With this Tantra and by meditating on the Arising of Heruka in his nine forms for a period of 12 years, he saw the faces of Heruka and Tārā. Gaining too the magic powers of Siddhi, he was able to go along a road 100 leagues long in just an instant.[169] At that time a Mongol king resided in Delhi. He had just rebuilt a great palace and the Ācārya was living nearby sewing his worn out clothes. When the new palace was completed the Ācārya ripped his rags to pieces and at the very same time the foundations of the new palace too were (magically) smashed. That happened on three occasions. When the king heard the news he invited the Ācārya and prostrated himself at his feet. The Ācārya made him undertake four vows. They were: 1. Never to harm any Buddhist temples 2. To renounce killing any palace residents 3. To pay homage to those who had been consecrated as monks 4. To make daily obeisance by calling the Buddha’s name. The word Kandhari means ‘worn out clothes’ and as a result of that he was known as the Siddha Kandhapa. He worked for the welfare of sentient beings for a long time and finally, in that very body, he departed for the heavenly regions.

yang Tha ka ki na ka ni pa ni/ Tha ka ki zhes pa g.yo sgyu'i bya ba sna tshogs pas 'tsho ba sgrub pa'i don te/ mtha' 'khob kyi rigs ngan gcig yin gsung / na ka na ni tshan che ba'am/ stobs che ba'i don no/ / Tha ka ka'i rigs su lus stobs shin tu che bas mtshan yang de bzhin du thogs pa yin no/ / 'di yang rnal 'byor pa byas te/ mi thub zla ba'i slob ma zhig la dgyes rdor zhus nas/ lho phyogs ni la bya ba'i ri la lo bco lnga'i bar du rtse gcig tu bsgoms kyang rtags gang yang ma byung bas/ skye ba gzhan du 'grub par smon lam btab ste/ g.yang sa chen po zhig la mchongs so/ / der lus kyang ma snad/ nam mkha' las kyang sgra byung ste/ khyod na ro pas rjes su 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / zhes so/ / de nas na ro pa'i zhabs bsten te/ dgyes pa rdo rje'i dbang bskur bar gsol ba btab pas/ khyod kyis dgyes pa rdo rje mi 'grub/ bde mchog 'khor lo sgom dgos pas bde mchog gi dbang bskur dgos gsung / jo bo na ro pa la ni/ bde mchog 'khor lo zhu ba ni shin tu dka' ste/ dkyil 'khor gzhan rnams las brgyad 'gyur gyis lhag pa'i yo byad dgos pas/ de skabs bdag la yo byad kyang med cing blo gros rtul bas rgyud rgya chen po gsar du nyan pa'i nus pa med zhus pas/ sgrol ma'i dbang bskur zhing rgyud kyang gnang la/ bde mchog yab yum go zlog gi gdams ngag thams cad rdzogs par gnang ba rtse gcig tu bsgoms pas mchog gi dngos grub thob ste/ na ro pa tshogs kyi mchod pa rgya chen po'i gral dbu la bzhugs pa'i drung du/ phyag 'tshal du 'ongs te/ lus las me 'bar ba dang / sa g.yo ba la sogs pa'i cho 'phrul du ma bstan te mi snang bar gyur to/ /

Now about Thakkinaganapa.[170] Thakki (for that is what he was called) practised various acts of low cunning for the purpose of getting a good living. It is said that he belonged to a low caste in a border (i.e. barbarian) area.[171] The word ‘na-gana’ means ‘very powerful’. Thakki was the strongest in his clan’s branch and so his name accorded with his body. Thakki became a yogin and begged a disciple of Durjayacandra (mi thub zla ba) for (the initiation of) Hevajra. In the south at the ‘Nīla bird mountain’ he engaged in one-pointed meditation for 15 years, but no good signs arose out of it. Praying that he might achieve perfection in another birth, he leapt off a great precipice. However, he was not harmed at all. A voice came out of the heavens, saying, “You will become a follower of Nāropa.” Then, serving at Nāropa’s feet, he asked him for the empowerment consecration of Hevajra. Nāropa said to him, “You could not complete the Hevajra initiation. You must meditate on Mahāsukha Saṃvara, and for that you must have the Saṃvara empowerment consecration.” Thakki then begged Lord Nāropa for the Saṃvara Maṇḍala which, being much more difficult to perform than other maṇḍalas, needed more than eight times the amount of equipment and ritual objects. At that time Thakki had none of those items and this intelligent but foolish person told Nāropa that he was unable to perform this great new Tantra of which he had just heard, and (instead) was initiated into the Tārā Tantra and its inner meaning. So he was given the empowerment and the Tantra of Tārā as well as all the teachings for the reversed form of Saṃvara. He engaged (again) in one-pointed meditation and attained the highest powers of Siddhi. When Thakki, seated at the head of many rows of supplicants at an offering ceremony for Nāropa, came forth to make his prostrations, flames started to shoot forth from his body, the earth quaked and many other miracles were manifested. Finally he became completely invisible.

de skabs 'gro don mdzad pa ma byung bas/ na ro pa'i slob ma grub thob bzhi'i grangs su ma bgrangs la/ phyis a b+ha ya ka ra'i slob ma man+da ra pA la zhes bya ba rnal 'byor pa shin tu bzang ba zhig yod pa la/ zla gcig tsam du sku dngos su bstan nas/ sgrol ma'i dbang bskur ba dang / rgyud bshad man ngag rnams kyang gnang nas/ des kyang brtson par bsgoms pas zla ba drug na dngos grub thob ste mthar klu'i gnas su song skad/ de la yang slob ma bzhi tsam yod cing / brgyud pa'ang gnyis gsum du rgyud 'di nyan bshad sogs byung 'dug kyang / lo rgyus rgyas par ma thos gsung ngo*/ /

During that time as he was not working for the welfare of sentient beings, he is not counted as one of the four siddha students of Nāropa. Abhayākara’s[172] student was Mandirapāla, a very accomplished yogin indeed. Thakki manifested the absolute nature of form for one month and gave him the empowerment consecration for Tārā and the abbreviated explanations of the Tantra. He attained Siddhi powers after six months of strenuous meditation. Finally it is said that he departed for the Abode of the Nāgas. He too had four pupils, and two or three lineages evolved from hearing discourses on this Tantra. However, no extended accounts of this have been told to me by my Teachers.

li la badz+ra ni rgyal rigs zhig yin la/ bya ba zhig la ma ga d+har phyin nas/ lam du shing drung zhig na rnal 'byor pa zhig 'dug pa mthong bas mchog tu dad de/ zhabs la phyag byas so/ / slar yang yul du ldog ba'i tshe/ rang gi bud med de mi gzhan dang 'dre ba sogs kyis sems la gnod par gyur nas yang ma ga d+har chos la 'ongs pas/ shing drung der sngar gyi grub thob de nyid dang mjal ba/ grub thob de ni til+li pa chen po'o/ / der til+li pas rgyud byin gyis brlabs nas dbang bskur zhing gdams ngag bstan pas ring por mi thogs par grub pa brnyes te/ gling bu 'bud cing smyon pa'i spyod pas sems can gyi don byed pa zhig yod skad/ 'di'i lo rgyus rgyas pa mi gsung ngo*/ / dI paM kA ra'i lo rgyus ni grags che bas gzhan du shes so/ /

Lalitavajra[173] was from the Kṣatriya caste, and one of his exploits occurred on his way to Magadha. On the road, in front of a tree, was a yogin and on merely seeing him Lalitavajra felt a perfect faith within himself and prostrated at the yogin’s feet. Again, at a certain time, he was returning to that country, his mind assailed because of his wife who had been fraternising with other men etc. He was coming to Magadha to practise the teachings, and he met up with that self-same ascetic who had been before the tree previously. That ascetic was the great Tillipa. Right there he gave Lalitavajra the empowerment blessing of the Tantra, the empowerment consecration and preached about its methodology. Finally Lalitavajra attained the state of perfection known as ‘unhindered’. Blowing on a flute and acting in a crazy manner, he too was one who worked for the welfare of sentient beings, so it is said. A more copious account of this story has not been taught to me. The account of Dīpaṅkara is very well known and can be learned elsewhere.[174]

ma d+h+ya ma sid+d+hi ni/ jo bo rje'i slob ma zhig ste/ sgra tshad dang mdo'i lugs la mkhas/ 'dis gsang sngags gzhan mi mkhyen/ sgrol ma'i rgyud 'di kho na la mkhas/ nus pa'ang thon te/ rgya gar shar phyogs kyi chu bo gang+gA la gshegs kyang thang la 'gro ba bzhin thogs pa med pa/ dug sbrul dang stag la sogs pa la bka' bsgo bar nus pa zhig go / /

As for Madhyamasiṃha, a disciple of Atīśa, he was very skilled in the practices of grammar, logic and Sūtras; he was not at all well-versed as regards (the practice of) mantras and such like things. (However) he became quite learned in the Tārā Tantra specifically. Performing it and evoking (Tārā) he set out for India’s eastern river, the Ganges, and it was as if he was walking on the plains for he met with absolutely no hindrances at all. He was able to forbid and repulse venomous snakes, tigers and other such harmful animals.

tA ra shrI ni/ rtsod pa smra ba'i khyu mchog ste/ ma ga d+har mu stegs kyi rtsod pa las lan gsum du rgyal/ lho phyogs kyi yul du nyan thos rnams kyi rtsod pa bzlog pa dang*/ kha che'i yul du phyi nang gi paN+Di ta thams cad rtsod pas zil gyis mnan skad/ kha che'i rgyal po'i bla mar gyur/ yul ga ja ni'i rgyal po sgrol ma'i rig sngags kyis dbang du bsdus te/ sangs rgyas pa la bcug go sang+g+ha shrI nas/ d+harma shI'i bar gyi lo rgyus mi gsung / /

As for Tāraśri, he was the chief among the (religious) debaters. In Magadha he was victorious over the heretics in debate, while in a southern land he completely reversed the arguments put up by the Śrāvakas, and in Kaśmir it is said that he crushed the glorious reputations of all the pandits, both Buddhist and non-Buddhist. He became priest to the King of Kaśmir, and the ruler of the land of Ghazni was brought under the sway of Tārā’s Mantra and became a Buddhist. The accounts from Saṅghaśrī to Dharmaśrī have not been taught to me.

shAkya rak+Shi ta ni/ sing ga la'i yul du 'khrungs shing / dang po nyan thos sen+d+ha pa yin cing / de'i ring lugs la shin tu mkhas pa zhig ste/ ra khang gi yul gru'i char gtogs pa ha ri puny+tsa gser gyi grong ste de'i slob dpon d+harma shI la/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / sngags kyi chos mang du gsan/ khyad par du dgyes pa rdo rje/ bde mchog 'khor lo/ sgrol ma 'byung ba nag po chen po'i rgyud de bzhi po de dag phal cher la mkhas pa/ he ru ka'i zhal gzigs shing / sgrol ma'i rig sngags la brten nas nag po chen po dbang du bsdus te/ dge bsnyen nag po'i gzugs kyis ji ltar bzhed pa'i dngos po rnams dpag tshad brgya'i pha rol nas 'gugs pa zhig yod skad/ tsig la rA dzA zhes bya ba rgyal po zhig gis ha ri puny+dzar grong khyer dang lha khang rnams 'joms pa'i phyir dmag 'dren par brtsams pa na/ nag po chen po'i phyag mtshan rtse gsum 'phangs pa zla ba tsam gyis bgrod dgos pa'i pha rol yin na'ang / / rgyal po'i pho brang gi steng du tri shu la sleb te pho brang zhig go de ltar nus mthu dang ldan par grags/ /

Śākyarakṣita, born in the Land of Singhala, was first a Śrāvaka of the Sendhapa sect and was very learned in their doctrines. Being assigned to the Land of Rakang[175] for the duration of the monsoon season, there, in the Golden City of Haripuñja, he heard the Perfection of Wisdom teachings and many mantras from the Ācārya Dharmaśrī. He became generally quite learned in the four Tantras of the most excellent Hevajra, Cakrasaṃvara, the Arising of Tārā and that of Mahākāla; moreover, he saw the visage of Heruka and, supported by Tārā’s Mantra, he was able to subjugate Mahākāla. In the form of the ‘black Upāsaka’ he was able to summon from 100 leagues away exactly whatever he wished for and in what quantities he desired. The king known as Tsakla Raja had undertaken to conquer Haripuñja town and the temples there. In order to spare the temples Śākyarakṣita threw the emblem of Mahākāla, the trident, and although it was about a month’s journey away the trident miraculously appeared above the king’s palace and destroyed it, and accordingly the Ācārya became known for having just that sort of power (which can destroy).

su dzA ta ni yul kaspro dza'i gtsug lag khang daN+Da pu ri'i mkhan po ste/ rgyal rigs las rab tu byung ba yin no/ / bud+d+ha shrI b+ha dra dang / dz+nyAn rat+na gnyis kyang yul de nyid du byon pa'o/ /
As for Sujāta, he was the Abbot of Daṇḍapuri Temple of Kamboja,[176] and was ordained from the Kṣatriya caste. Buddhaśrībhadra and Jñānaratna both also came to this land.

dz+nyAn s+yan ni yul der 'khrungs shing / mkhan po dz+nyA na rat+na las rab tu byung ba/ / gsang sngags phyi nang gi rgyud mang du mkhyen pa/ khyad par sgrol ma'i rgyud la mkhas shing nus pa brnyes pa/ sku tshe'i smad la bal po'i yul du bzhugs shing / rnal 'byor pa'i spyod pa mdzad/ phyag rgyu pad+ma can las dngos grub thob pa/ 'bras bre gang dang / chang bum pa gcig gis sngags btsun stong phrag gnyis tsam la 'khor lo'i mchod pa shin tu rgyas par mdzad pa sogs ngo mtshar ba'i ** rtags mang po can zhig go / slob dpon rA ti gupas/ sgrol ma'i rgyud dang / nag po chen po'i rgyud dang / bde mchog sdom pa 'byung ba dang / ku ru kul+le'i rtog pa la sogs pa sngags kyi rgyud sde 'ga' shas kyi dbang rgyud 'tshol bar bal po'i yul du phebs te/ dz+nyA na s+ya na dang / dzA ba s+ya na dang / shrI ta nu pA la/ git+ti pA la rnams las rgyud sde mang du gsan pa las/ rgyud 'di ni slob dpon dz+nyA na s+ya na la gsan pa yin no/ /

Jñānasena, born in that country, was ordained by the Abbot Jñānaratna. He understood many tantras in both their inner and outer meanings, and being learned in the unique Tantra of Tārā, he got the power to perform it too. Later in his life, while living in Nepal and performing all the (requisite) deeds of a yogin, he attained Siddhi from his consort who was a lotus holder. He was an amazing person with many special signs, such as being able to make one measure of rice and one jar of beer be quite enough for a feast for 2,000 monks. The Ācārya Ratigupta[177] went to Nepal to seek some of the mantra and tantra collections as well as their empowerments, especially those of Tārā’s Tantra, Mahākāla, the Arising Tantra for the whole troupe of Mahāsukha Saṃvara and an understanding etc of (the Tantra of) Kurukullā. He heard much of the Tantra Collection from Jñānasena, Jīvasena, Śrītanupāla and Gittipāla, but it was from the Ācārya Jñānasena that he heard this particular Tantra.

yang grub thob bri ka pa ni/ grub thob kan+d+ha pa las dbang dang man ngag thams cad thob nas/ yun ring du sgrub pa mdzad cing / mthar spri ka'i me tog gi tshal zhig tu dkyil 'khor bzhengs nas/ sgrub pa byas pas me tog gcig zla ba bcu gnyis kyi bar du mi rnyings shing / de'i mthar nub gcig me tog la me 'bar ro/ / de gsol ba tsam gyis thun mong gi dngos grub thob ste/ sa 'og la thogs med du bgrod pa zhig go / /

Siddha Pṛkkapa, having received all the empowerment consecrations and abbreviated instructions from the Siddha Kandhapa, practised them for a long time and finally set up his maṇḍala in a grove of pṛkka flowers. While he was practising his evocations not a single flower aged for 12 months and, after that, one night all the flowers were consumed by flames. By his prayers, he (Pṛkkapa) attained the ordinary degree of Siddhi and was able to wander quite unimpeded under the ground.

d+hu pi ra dza ni/ khrus mkhan gyi rigs las grub pa thob pa zhig yin gsung / ha ri b+hany+dza ba'i lo rgyus mi gsung / lo ka dA pa ni/ rgyal rigs kyi paN+Di ta zhig ste/ ka na ka shI la rtsa ba'i bla mar mdzad/ gsang sngags kyi chos ni sgrol ma 'byung ba'i chos skor kho na la legs par sbyangs pa zhig yin la/ yul gu dzi ra tha na skyed tshal stong pa zhig tu gnas gzhi byas nas/ lo drug tsam du sngags 'chang mo zhig gis sgrub grogs byas te/ sgrol ma'i bskyed rdzogs kho na bsgom pas/ mkha' 'gro mas lung bstan pa thob nas/ rig mo bcu gnyis la brten nas rig pa'i brtul zhugs zla ba drug byas pas 'dod pa'i dngos grub brnyes te/ gnas de nyid du bzhugs pa las/ lan cig yul de'i rgyal po gar log gis rang gi yul ljongs bltar 'ongs pa'i tshe/ slob dpon gyi gnas de nyams dgu'i bar mthong nas/ 'di na su zhig gnas zhes dris pa na/ 'di na sangs rgyas pa'i khyim btsun zhig yod do zhes rgyal po'i * g.yog rnams kyis smras so/ / de nas rgyal pos gnas de 'phrog par brtsams pa na/ skad cig la de'i phyi nang thams cad mer 'bar te/ rgyal po 'khor bcas kyang tshig la khad par song ngo / / der slob dpon grub pa thob par shes nas/ gsol ba btab pas me zhi'o/ / de nas slob dpon na re/ rgyal po khyod kyis sangs rgyas pa mchod par byed na legs/ mi byed na da lta nyid du brlag par bya'o gsung / rigs brgyud dang bcas pas sangs rgyas pa mchod par mna' bor ro/ / de phyin nas da lta'i bar du yang yul 'di'i rgyal po ni rus gar log yin yang sangs rgyas pa la gtso bor mchod par byed pa yin no/ /

It is said that Dhupirāja of the washermen’s caste also was one who attained Siddhi. I have not been taught the story of Haribhañjapa. Lokapradā was a pandit of the Kṣatriya caste and he made Kanakaśrī his root teacher. He studied only the Doctrines of Secret Mantras and the teaching of the Arising of Tārā and this he did very carefully indeed. He made his abode in an empty grove in the Land of Gujarat and for six years he made a lady mantra-reciter his companion in the practices (sādhana). Meditating solely on the production of Tārā (outside oneself) and her final perfection (within oneself), having attained the Ḍākinī’s prophecy and been supported by 12 consorts, for six months he performed arduous practices to gain knowledge and found the desired Siddhi. Once while staying in that place, the Garlog king of the country came to the Ācārya’s part of his land to sightsee. Having seen the Ācārya’s pleasant spot he asked, “Whoever is it that lives in this grove?” The king’s attendants replied, “This, O King, is the abode of a Buddhist.” Then the king started to plunder the place, and instantly both the interior and exterior of the house were completely engulfed in flames and the king and his attendants were prevented from escaping. At that they knew that the Ācārya had attained Siddhi, and they prayed to him and the flames subsided. After that, the Ācārya said, “Now, King, if you make offerings to Buddhists everything will be alright, but if you do not you will be destroyed this very instant.” The king swore an oath that he and his whole lineage would revere Buddhists and from then right up to the present times, the kings, although of the Garlog people, have made their principal homages to Buddhists.

de gong yul de na sangs rgyas pa nyung ngu las med pa la/ rgyal po de nyid kyis kyang gtsug lag khang brgyad bzhengs so/ / de nas brtsams te rim pas da lta'i bar du yang sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa dar bar yod do/ / der rgyal po de sangs rgyas la dad par gyur pa'i tshe/ kla klo'i ston pa kA dzi rnams kyis slob dpon gyi gnas la me btang bas/ slob dpon gyis kyang de rnams nyid la lta stangs mdzad pas thams cad rengs shing dran med du gyur/ zhag gsum gyi bar du ma gsos pa las/ de rnams kyi nye dus gsol ba btab pa las/ dril bu 'khrol ba'i sgras slar gsos/ / de rnams rgyal po'i chad pas 'jigs pas rang gi yul nub phyogs thag ring por bros te song ngo*/ / kla klo'i gnas gzhi ma si ta thams cad slob dpon gyis yungs kar gtor ba kho nas zhig ste/ de dag gi shul du yang sangs rgyas kyi mchod rten re bzhengs/ sgrol ma'i lha khang brgya rtsa bzhengs so/ / rgyal po pad+ma gar dbang dbugs dbyung ba'i dkyil 'khor du dbang bskur ro/ / gsang sngags kyi lha khang zhig kyang bzhengs/ sngon rgyal po de'i mnga' 'og na bram ze dang mu stegs mang zhing rgyal po'i mchod gnas gyi gtso bo gar log kA dzi rnams kyis byed pas kla klo'i grub mtha' 'dzin pa stong tsam yod/ sangs rgyas pa'i rab tu byung ba nyi shu tsam las med pa la slob dpon de nyid kyi sku ring nyid la kla klo pa thams cad nub cing rgyal pos sangs rgyas pa'i slob dpon mang po spyan drangs pa la brten nas dge slong rang yang stong phrag gnyis tsam 'phel skad/ lan cig yul der mu ge chen po byung ba la slob dpon gyis sa 'og nas 'bru'i gter chen po byung nas/ yul gyi mi thams cad la 'bru khal brgya brgya byin cing / klu dang gnod sbyin rnams las blangs te dbul 'phongs thams cad la mu tig gi do shal re re dang*/ nyin re bzhin du to la re'i rin thang gi kha zas sbyin pa lo gsum gyi bar du mdzad/ mthar 'gro lding dang nye ba'i gling zhig na/ khye'u shi ba'i lus mtshan dang ldan pa zhig yod pas de la grong 'jug mdzad de/ sku lus snga ma de byin gyis brlabs nas mi rul bar mchod rten sgo can cig gi nang du bzhugs so/ / 'gro lding du yang spros bcas kyi spyod pa mdzad pa zhig byung la/ slob ma bud med brgyad rga shi med pa'i lus su gyur te/ sku lus snga ma de la mchod pa byed cing yod pa las/ lo drug cu nas de nyid slar yang sku lus snga ma nyid la zhugs te/ der yang lo bcu tsam du skal ldan gyi sems can 'ga' zhig gi don mdzad do/ /

In that previously mentioned country there were few, if any, Buddhists but nevertheless that king erected eight temples. From that starting point, by gradual stages up to the present time the Buddha’s Doctrine has flourished there. At the time when the king was coming to have faith in the Buddha, the Muslim teachers known as Kāji set fire to the Ācārya’s abode. However, he transfixed them with a ritual gaze[178] and all of them swooned and were petrified rigid. After three days without any nourishment their relatives prayed (to the Ācārya) for them and they were revived by the tolling of a bell. They were greatly afraid of the king’s wrath and fled far away to their country in the west. The Ācārya went to all the Muslim mosques, and by merely scattering white mustard seeds they were all destroyed. In place of each a Buddhist stupa was erected and 100 Tārā temples were also built. The king was initiated into the encouragement stage maṇḍala of the Lotus Lord of Dance (Padma-Narteśvara)[179] and a Secret Mantra temple was also erected. Formerly, because the majority of the king’s subjects were Brahmins and heretics, the main priestly officiants were the Garlog Kājis. Those who held the heretical doctrines were about 1,000 in number. Other than the 20 fully-ordained Buddhist monks there were no Buddhists, and yet it is said that within the Ācārya’s lifetime all the Muslims were converted and that the king invited many Buddhist Ācāryas. Thus the supported (Buddhist) monks increased to about 2,000. Once in that land a great famine arose. The Ācārya, drawing from underground a great store of grain, gave each citizen a hundred measures of grain, and getting pearl garlands from the Nāgas and Yakṣas, he gave one to every poor person. Moreover, for the three years of the famine he gave to each person a tola weight[180] of delicacies. Later, on an island near Drāviḍa, he came upon a child with all the marks of death about its body. He performed the ritual of resurrection[181] upon it, restoring the body to its previous state with his blessings, and in its state of non-putrefaction. He enshrined it in a reliquary which had entrance doors. Also, while he was in Dravida the Ācārya engaged in many kinds of work. He made eight of his female students’ bodies no longer subject to old age and death, but because they were prone to revere his previous form, he rejoined his previous body for a further 60 years. There, too, for a period of 10 years he did things for the welfare of certain fortunate beings.

slar yang mi lo gsum gsum du sku lus phan tshun du 'pho ba lan drug tsam mdzad nas/ sku lus gnyis rig ma'i 'khor tshogs dang bcas pa mi snang bar gyur to/ / slob dpon 'di la tA ra shrI mi tra dang / chos 'byung zhi ba gnyis kyis rgyud 'di gsan/ chos 'byung zhi ba ni/ rtsod dus kyi thams cad mkhyen par grags zhes nyi ma dpal gyis bshad kyang / / lo rgyus mi gsung / de la sang+g+ha shrIs zhus par byas kyang chog gsung / grub pa'i slob dpon lo ka pra d+has sgrub thabs dang / rgyud kyi bsdus pa'i don dang / rdzogs rim dang / dbang gi cho ga dang / sbyin bsreg rnams mdzad cing / mi'i nyi ma'i 'grel pa yang 'di'i rjes 'brang ngo*/ / phyis rgyud 'di'i nyan bshad shin tu dkon pa la/ grub chen zhi ba'i zhabs kyis rgya cher dar bar mdzad de/ kho bos kyang / zhi ba'i zhabs kyi man ngag phyin ci ma log pa bla ma'i zhal gyi gdams pa kho nar gyur pa dang / 'grel pa gnyis gzhung phran brgyad dang bcas legs par mnos pas/ kha ba can gyi phyogs 'dir sngon chad bdag kho na'i bsod rnams kyi skal bar thob bo/ /

Moreover, having performed the rite of Consciousness Transference[182] between bodies on six occasions every three years, the bodies involved became invisible members of his entourage of consorts. Both Tāraśrīmitra and Dharmākaraśānti[103] heard this Tantra from the Ācārya himself. Dharmākaraśānti is renowned as being omniscient in this final Kāli (dark) Age, as was said by Śrīsūrya, but an account of him has not been taught. Saṅghaśrī asked him for instruction but he said that he had had enough. The accomplished Ācārya, Lokapradā bestowed evocations, abbreviated meanings of tantras, sampannakramas,[104] initiation rituals, and burnt offering sacrifices,[185] and the commentary by Narāditya follows these. As regards the later, very rare explanations of this Tantra, the Mahāsiddha Śāntipada caused them to spread widely and I myself, having very thoroughly studied both explanations, that is Śāntipada’s Incontrovertible Elucidations and my own Guru’s exclusive instructions, as well as the eight minor texts, have come to believe that it is as a result of my previous merits in the Land of Snows that I have been fortunate enough to attain them.

ma rgyud rgyal po zab mo'i mthar thug pa/ / sgrol ma 'byung ba'i rgyud kyi byung khungs rnams/ / bla ma'i gsung bzhin bkod 'di rgyal khams pa/ / tA ra nA tha zhes byas sbyar ba yin/ /
zhes pa rang lo sum cu pa la chos grwa gser mdog can du smras pa'o/ /

The origin of the profound King of the Mother Tantras, And the Origin of the Tārā Tantra itself Have been written down in accordance with his Guru’s precepts By rGyal khams pa Tāranātha who prepared this work.
These words were spoken when I was 30 years old[106] at gser mdog can Monastery.[107]
dge legs 'phel/ bkra shis/
MAY HAPPINESS INCREASE! JOY!
